AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (11): UKRAINE, NOT
*****************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 20 Mar 2023
From multiple sources known to ProMED


re: ProMED Avian influenza, human (10): Ukraine, RFI, poultry 20230319.8709043
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
ProMED received responses to our RFI from both the FAO and a representative of the Ukrainian government. Both sources confirm there are no reported cases of avian influenza in humans or poultry in the Kherson area as was alleged in the TASS story that was the source of the ProMED post.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[We thank those that provided timely responses to our RFI. - Mod.JH

ProMED map:
Ukraine: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709054,123>]

[See Also:
Avian influenza, human (10): Ukraine, RFI, poultry 20230319.8709043]

column2:
DIPHTHERIA - NIGERIA (07): FATAL
********************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sat 18 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<http://outbreaknewstoday.com/nigeria-diphtheria-outbreak-more-than-1000-suspected-cases-reported-from-21-states-48069/>


In a follow-up on the diphtheria outbreak in Nigeria, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC) reports a total of 377 suspected cases from 7 states across the country. The majority of the cases 355 (96.8%) were from Kano in February 2023. 102 (27.1%) cases were confirmed (9 lab-confirmed, 93 clinically compatible). 6 deaths were recorded from confirmed cases [CFR 5.8%]. [Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC), Diphtheria Situation Report no. 3, <https://www.ncdc.gov.ng/themes/common/files/sitreps/d6dbbc4af6e2781520043f4aee0c031f.pdf>.]

Cumulatively, between week 19 (mid-May) of 2022 and week 9 (end of February) of 2023, a total of 1064 suspected cases were reported from 21 states. Kano (843), Yobe (86), Katsina (46), Lagos (22), Sokoto (14) & Zamfara (13) accounted for 96.2% of suspected cases.

Of the 1064 suspected cases reported, 389 (36.6%) were confirmed (45 were lab confirmed, 343 were clinically compatible, and 1 was epidemiologically linked). A total of 62 deaths were recorded among all confirmed cases (CFR: 15.9%). The majority (305 [78.4%]) of the confirmed cases occurred among children aged 2-14 years.

Only 60 (15.4%) out of 389 confirmed cases were fully vaccinated with a diphtheria toxin-containing vaccine.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Of Nigeria's 36 states and federal capital territory, the Nigerian state of Kano continues to have the most cases and deaths in the ongoing Nigerian diphtheria outbreak: from epi-week 6 2023 (2nd week of February) to epi-week 9 2023 (1st week of March), Kano reported 355 (94%) of the total of 377 suspected diphtheria cases, reported from 7 states. Kano has reported 56 (90%) deaths among confirmed cases of the 62 total deaths among confirmed cases in Nigeria since the outbreak began.

Data from the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC), Diphtheria Situation Report no. 3, for the period epi-week 19 (mid-May) 2022 to epi-week 9 (26 Feb-4 Mar) 2023 (<https://www.ncdc.gov.ng/themes/common/files/sitreps/d6dbbc4af6e2781520043f4aee0c031f.pdf>):
A total of 1064 suspected cases were reported from 21 states;
Total confirmed cases: 389 (36.6% of total suspected cases);
Total deaths among confirmed cases: 62;
Deaths among confirmed cases for epi week 6-9 2023: 6 (CFR 15.9%).
- Mod ML]

column2:
BOTULISM, AVIAN - NEW ZEALAND: (WAIKATO)  WATERFOWL
***************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sat 18 Mar 2023 11:29 PM NZDT
Source: New Zealand Herald [edited]
<https://bit.ly/3JS3m5n>


A deadly outbreak of avian botulism in Waikato's Whangamarino Wetland has killed thousands of birds, including some rare indigenous species.

Fish and Game New Zealand say it's "yet another wake-up call for urgent action" to be taken by the Waikato Regional Council.

"The latest outbreak of the deadly bacterium, which produces a toxin that can paralyse and kill birds, follows multiple and increasing outbreaks during summers in and around the Waikato region over the past decade [2010-2019]," Fish and Game New Zealand said in a press release on its website [<https://fishandgame.org.nz/news/regional-council-must-act-on-deadly-botulism-outbreaks/>].

Poor water quality and changes to water flows as a result of human activities contribute to low oxygen levels, creating the perfect growing conditions for these bacteria.

"This results in fish dying, followed by birds before botulism spreads to other surrounding wetland environments," Fish and Game New Zealand said, calling it "yet another wake-up call for urgent action."

The Whangamarino Wetland is the 2nd-largest freshwater wetland in the North Island, covering almost 7000 hectares [about 17 300 acres] in Waikato, and was chosen as one of 3 nationally-significant wetland sites in the Department of Conservation's Arawai Kākāriki wetlands restoration programme [<https://www.doc.govt.nz/our-work/freshwater-restoration/arawai-kakariki-wetland-restoration/sites/whangamarino/>].

Fish and Game New Zealand chief executive Corina Jordan says the outbreak is an appalling situation and has had a massive impact on fish and bird populations in these wetlands.

"Parts of this wetland have been without oxygen for the best part of 3 months, leading to massive aquatic deaths of even the hardiest freshwater species such as eels. This isn't normal in healthy freshwater wetland systems," Jordan said.

Jordan says the Waikato Regional Council needs to take a hard look at how the system is managed and limit discharges into these waterways to help decrease the likelihood and severity of these incidents continuing to occur in the future.

"There have been long-term systemic failures in freshwater policies and a lack of implementation that has caused severe degradation in our freshwater ecosystems. Lake Waikare, one of the Southern Hemisphere's most polluted lakes, has also been diverted into the wetland as part of the flood control scheme, which is adding even more nutrients to the wetland," she said.

Degradation of waterways and associated environments, coupled with predictions of longer hotter summers, means these types of botulism outbreaks are likely to become more common, Jordan said.

Fish and Game New Zealand's southern game bird manager for the Auckland and Waikato region, David Klee, says the situation is grim.

"Botulism is symptomatic of severely degraded ecosystems and this area is being adversely impacted by human activity to the point where its resilience is severely compromised," Klee said.

"Fish and Game, the Department of Conservation, Mana Whenua, and hunter volunteers, in conjunction with contractors, have recovered close to 1500 dead birds and rescued hundreds of sick ones from the wetland, an important step in trying to minimise the size and scale of the outbreak."

Klee says Fish and Game NZ is doing everything it can with the limited resources available, however, many parts of the wetland area, covering 7000 ha, are inaccessible.

"It is an appalling situation both in terms of animal welfare and the environmental impact," he said.

[Byline: Benjamin Plummer]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. - Mod.PMB

ProMED map of New Zealand: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709052,68925>]

column2:
FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - LIBYA: CATTLE, SEROTYPE O, SHEEP SUSPECTED, SPREAD
*************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 19 Mar 2023
Source: National Centre for Animal Health - Libya [in Arabic, trans. Mod.SF, abridged, edited]
<https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=538772518402770&set=a.270452858568072>


Spread of FMDV seroytpe O
-------------------------
Date of start of FMDV outbreaks:
Tobruk: 1 Mar 2023
Tripoli (Oudi Al Rabi): 20 Feb 2023
Bayda (Al Jabal al Akhdar): 20 Feb 2023
Al Marj (Farzouga): 23 Feb 2023
Misrata: 14 Mar 2023
Djeffara (Abou Issa): 7 Mar 2023

Number of infected cattle farms: Tobruk (1), Tripoli (1), Bayda (1), Al Marj (1), Misrata (3), Djeffara (5)

All cases were recorded in cattle with the exception of one suspected case in sheep observed on a farm in Awled Issa, Djeffara.

The serotype has been identified (O), and samples were sent to the FMDV reference laboratory for topotyping: Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale della Lombardia e dell'Emilia Romagna (IZSLER).

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
via
ProMED-MENA

[The original version of the report above lists sanitary measures to be taken in case of a suspected outbreak. Outbreaks registered in Tobruk, Bayda, and Al Marj have been reported to WOAH on 8 and 9 Mar 2023; see follow-up reports at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-event/3835/dashboard>. Information regarding the topotype registered is anticipated. This information is crucial for the adaptation of the vaccination strategy in Libya and its neighboring countries. - Mod.SF

Historically, Libya encountered numerous FMDV incursions. Overall, 3 different serotypes have circulated: O, A, and SAT2. Type O is the most prevalent serotype, followed by serotype A. In 2012 an FMDV O/EA-3 topotype was reported, co-circulating with ME-SA topotype PanAsia-2 lineage ANT-10 sublineage; however, those EA-3 strains were more closely related with eastern Africa strains (that is, Ethiopia and Sudan) while the 2019 incursion was more correlated with strains circulating in the Maghreb from a western Africa route (<https://doi.org/10.3390/ani12223198>). FMDV SAT2 was last reported from Libya in 2003 and 2012; this serotype has recently been reported from Jordan, Iraq, and Turkey. - Mod.AS

ProMED map:
Libya: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709051,68>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (52): ASIA (TAIWAN) POULTRY, LPAI H9N2, FIRST REPORT, PUBLIC ALERT
**********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 17 Mar 2023
Source: Taiwan Centers for Disease Control [in Chinese, trans., edited]
<https://www.cdc.gov.tw/Bulletin/Detail/DsyNVP30MIP1fy0mlR_MuQ?typeid=9>


The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention stated today (17 Mar 2023) that the avian influenza epidemic in domestic poultry farms continues to heat up. A few days ago, a poultry farm detected H9N2 virus, which was the 1st time that this subtype of the virus was detected in a poultry farm in our country.

Personnel should wear personal protective equipment and practice respiratory hygiene when working. If you have flu-like symptoms, you should seek medical attention as soon as possible and inform the medical staff of TOCC (travel history, occupation history, contact history, and cohort history), and the general public should also reduce contact with birds.

The CDC pointed out that for the domestic poultry farms where the H9N2 subtype virus was detected, the health unit has assisted the personnel involved in culling and clearing the farms to assist them in putting on and taking off their personal protective equipment, and has compiled a list and carried out health checks as soon as possible. Currently, there are 21 contact people, of which 20 prevention-and-control personnel and 1 poultry farm personnel. None of them have flu-like symptoms. Regarding contacts related to the domestic bird flu epidemic since January 2023 (47 outbreaks), a total of 695 people have been listed in the health management tracking; no human case of new type A influenza has been found.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention stated that since 2013, sporadic human cases of H9N2 infection have been continuously reported internationally. So far, at least 97 cases have been reported, of which 7 are young children. There are 8 severe cases and 2 deaths (all with a history of chronic diseases). In Asia, nearly 90% of the cases occurred in China. The latest case was a mild case in Hunan Province, China in November 2022. According to the WHO risk assessment of H9N2 dated 24 Feb 2023, most of the cases were found as exposed to poultry or contaminated environments. As the virus continues to circulate in poultry, sporadic human cases are expected to continue, but current evidence shows that it has not obtained the ability to transmit from person to person (human to human). The possibility of community transmission is low, though occasional cases of human infection may occur and close monitoring is required. H9N2 is currently a novel influenza A subtype with "low" disease severity in humans.

The Department of Disease Control and Prevention reminds that due to the continuous occurrence of domestic poultry epidemics, the respiratory secretions and excreta of poultry infected with avian influenza may contain viruses. Entering the human body, the risk of human exposure and infection increases, and livestock-related workers are urged to wear personal protective equipment during work. In order to prevent the new type A influenza, doctors are urged to ask patients meeting the notification requirements (as laid out in the attachment at <https://www.cdc.gov.tw/File/Get/6fydaRrKYG7AmF3hCo85Hw>; in Chinese) their TOCC (travel history, occupation history, contact history, and cohort history). In case found suspected, they must report it as soon as possible.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[H9N2 viruses, an LPAI (low pathogenic avian influenza) subtype, have become globally widespread and hyperendemic in poultry in many areas of Eurasia and Africa. They represent a genuine threat both to the global poultry industry but also to humans through their high rates of zoonotic infection and pandemic potential. Stamping out, which involves culling infected and exposed birds and birds presenting influenza-related morbidity, has occasionally been used as a 1st line of defence against H9N2 in countries without a history of the virus. This was the case during early outbreaks in Korea, Russia, and Ghana. However, once the virus becomes endemic in a country, stamping out becomes uneconomical and unfeasible, therefore vaccination is commonly used beyond this point. Many countries including China, Israel, South Korea, Morocco, Pakistan, Egypt, Iran, and UAE have adopted vaccination at either a national or local level as a key approach for preventing H9N2 disease in poultry.
(ref: Peacock THP, James J, Sealy JE, Iqbal M. A global perspective on H9N2 avian influenza virus. Viruses. 2019; 11(7): 620; <https://doi.org/10.3390/v11070620>).

It remains to see what control policy has been decided upon by Taiwan's animal health authorities following the discovery of the virus. A well-weighed decision depends upon the availability of accurate information about the rate of the pathogen's current distribution. - Mod.AS

ProMED map:
Taiwan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709046,193>]

column3: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention stated today (17 Mar 2023) that the avian influenza epidemic in domestic poultry farms continues to heat up. A few days ago, a poultry farm detected H9N2 virus, which was the 1st time that this subtype of the virus was detected in a poultry farm in our country.Personnel should wear personal protective equipment and practice respiratory hygiene when working. If you have flu-like symptoms, you should seek medical attention as soon as possible and inform the medical staff of TOCC (travel history, occupation history, contact history, and cohort history), and the general public should also reduce contact with birds.The CDC pointed out that for the domestic poultry farms where the H9N2 subtype virus was detected, the health unit has assisted the personnel involved in culling and clearing the farms to assist them in putting on and taking off their personal protective equipment, and has compiled a list and carried out health checks as soon as possible. Currently, there are 21 contact people, of which 20 prevention-and-control personnel and 1 poultry farm personnel. None of them have flu-like symptoms. Regarding contacts related to the domestic bird flu epidemic since January 2023 (47 outbreaks), a total of 695 people have been listed in the health management tracking; no human case of new type A influenza has been found.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention stated that since 2013, sporadic human cases of H9N2 infection have been continuously reported internationally. So far, at least 97 cases have been reported, of which 7 are young children. There are 8 severe cases and 2 deaths (all with a history of chronic diseases). In Asia, nearly 90% of the cases occurred in China. The latest case was a mild case in Hunan Province, China in November 2022. According to the WHO risk assessment of H9N2 dated 24 Feb 2023, most of the cases were found as exposed to poultry or contaminated environments. As the virus continues to circulate in poultry, sporadic human cases are expected to continue, but current evidence shows that it has not obtained the ability to transmit from person to person (human to human). The possibility of community transmission is low, though occasional cases of human infection may occur and close monitoring is required. H9N2 is currently a novel influenza A subtype with "low" disease severity in humans.The Department of Disease Control and Prevention reminds that due to the continuous occurrence of domestic poultry epidemics, the respiratory secretions and excreta of poultry infected with avian influenza may contain viruses. Entering the human body, the risk of human exposure and infection increases, and livestock-related workers are urged to wear personal protective equipment during work. In order to prevent the new type A influenza, doctors are urged to ask patients meeting the notification requirements (as laid out in the attachment at <https://www.cdc.gov.tw/File/Get/6fydaRrKYG7AmF3hCo85Hw>; in Chinese) their TOCC (travel history, occupation history, contact history, and cohort history). In case found suspected, they must report it as soon as possible.--Communicated by:ProMED[H9N2 viruses, an LPAI (low pathogenic avian influenza) subtype, have become globally widespread and hyperendemic in poultry in many areas of Eurasia and Africa. They represent a genuine threat both to the global poultry industry but also to humans through their high rates of zoonotic infection and pandemic potential. Stamping out, which involves culling infected and exposed birds and birds presenting influenza-related morbidity, has occasionally been used as a 1st line of defence against H9N2 in countries without a history of the virus. This was the case during early outbreaks in Korea, Russia, and Ghana. However, once the virus becomes endemic in a country, stamping out becomes uneconomical and unfeasible, therefore vaccination is commonly used beyond this point. Many countries including China, Israel, South Korea, Morocco, Pakistan, Egypt, Iran, and UAE have adopted vaccination at either a national or local level as a key approach for preventing H9N2 disease in poultry.(ref: Peacock THP, James J, Sealy JE, Iqbal M. A global perspective on H9N2 avian influenza virus. Viruses. 2019; 11(7): 620; <https://doi.org/10.3390/v11070620>).It remains to see what control policy has been decided upon by Taiwan's animal health authorities following the discovery of the virus. A well-weighed decision depends upon the availability of accurate information about the rate of the pathogen's current distribution. - Mod.ASProMED map:Taiwan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709046,193>]

column2:
GREENING DISEASE, CITRUS - URUGUAY: FIRST REPORT (ARTIGAS)
**********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: FreshPlaza, Citrus Industry report [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://www.freshplaza.com/latin-america/article/9512355/first-hlb-detections-in-uruguay/>


The 1st cases of plants with citrus greening disease have been confirmed in Uruguay, according to a health emergency note released by the country's Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture and Fisheries. Plants with symptoms were found in a residence in Artigas Department.

After laboratory analysis, the presence of the disease was confirmed. Inspections were carried out in the surroundings of the outbreak and no new positive cases were detected. Measures were adopted to prevent the spread of the disease, including constant monitoring of homes and farms following an action plan developed earlier for the management and control of citrus greening.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Citrus greening (CG) is one of the most damaging diseases of the crops, affecting leaves and fruit. It is caused by fastidious phloem-inhabiting bacteria classified as _Candidatus_ Liberibacter asiaticus (CaLas; Asian greening; huanglongbing), africanus (including a subsp. capensis; African greening) or americanus (South American greening). The 3 pathogens can only be distinguished by molecular methods. Several phytoplasma species have been reported to cause symptoms similar to greening disease in citrus; coinfections of phytoplasmas with CaLas have also been recorded (e.g. ProMED posts 20180214.5629251, 20190329.6392077). Further research is needed on symptomatology, epidemiology, and host impact of both single and mixed infections of these pathogens.

Symptoms may include blotchy mottling and yellowing of leaves, as well as small, irregularly shaped fruits with a thick, pale peel and bad taste. Early symptoms may be confused with nutrient deficiencies. Affected trees become stunted, bear multiple off-season flowers, and may live for only a few years without ever bearing usable fruit. CG is restricted to _Citrus_ and close relatives because of the narrow host range of its psyllid vectors. The pathogens can also be spread by grafting and possibly by seed from infected plants or transovarially in the vector insects. Both pathogens and vectors can be spread with plant material.

Disease management requires an integrated approach including use of clean planting and grafting stock, elimination of inoculum, use of pesticides for vector control in orchards, as well as chemical or biological control of vectors in non-crop reservoirs. Control using cultural methods, such as interplanting with non-host crops, is being trialled. In areas where a pathogen has not yet been detected, biological control of vectors has been used successfully to reduce insect numbers and, therefore, the risk of greening outbreaks (see, for example, ProMED post 20090601.2034). Antibiotics as leaf sprays, seed treatments, or trunk injections are being used occasionally to treat CG (e.g. ProMED posts 20181119.6154764, 20190320.6377319), but are subject to strict regulations in most countries due to their associated risks of facilitating the emergence of antibiotic resistances in other crop, animal, and human pathogens. Furthermore, beneficial soil microbes may be killed off as collateral damage, making the plants weaker and more susceptible to other diseases. Residues of antibiotics may also lead to rejection of exported produce by some countries.

In South America, citrus in colder areas has been found less affected by CG (ProMED post 20201207.7999673), possibly due to vector insects in colder temperatures being less active. However, elsewhere citrus psyllids have been found at increasing altitudes (ProMED post 20161129.4660906), potentially due to increasing overall temperatures there. This reflects similar effects observed for other pathogens and pests (e.g. ProMED posts 20160902.4459660, 20160622.4302098, 20160509.4211696) migrating to new areas in many regions due to warming climates.

In the report above, it is not specified which of the 3 liberibacters has been identified in Uruguay. While CaLas appears to be the likely pathogen, both the Asian and South American species are present in neighbouring Brazil and other parts of the region.

<https://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/southamerica/map-of-Uruguay.gif> and
<https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709045,2369>

<http://ontheworldmap.com/south-america/political-map-of-south-america.jpg>

Pictures
Citrus greening symptoms:
<http://www.citrusalert.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/GreenIslandsOfColor.jpg>,
<https://geneticliteracyproject.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/citrus_greening.jpg>, and
<http://www.abc.net.au/reslib/200904/r362894_1677317.jpg>
Asian greening, symptoms and vector photo galleries:
<http://www.invasive.org/browse/subinfo.cfm?sub=4695>

Links

<http://cisr.ucr.edu/citrus_greening.html> and
<https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/resources/pests-diseases/hungry-pests/the-threat/citrus-greening/citrus-greening-hp>

<https://gd.eppo.int/taxon/LIBEAS> and
<http://www.planthealthaustralia.com.au/pests/huanglongbing-or-citrus-greening-asiatic-strain/>

<http://www.psyllids.org/index.htm>
- Mod.DHA]

column2:
HANTAVIRUS - AMERICAS (12): ARGENTINA (CHUBUT)
**********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sat 18 Mar 2023
Source: Noticias Bariloche, Noticials del Bolsón, report [in Spanish trans. Mod.TY, edited]
<https://noticiasbariloche.com.ar/chubut-salud-confirmo-un-nuevo-caso-de-hantavirus-en-el-maiten/>


The Chubut Ministry of Health, through the Esquel Program Area, confirmed this Friday [17 Mar 2023] the detection of a new case of hantavirus [infection] in the Andean region, relating to a minor residing in the town of El Maitén, who is currently hotpitalized in the Zonal Hospital in Esquel, with good clinical progress.

This endemic event was ratified by the Andean hospital laboratory, after carrying out the appropriate tests.

The case in question is a minor who, after presenting symptoms compatible with the disease, was initially treated at the El Maitén health center, and was later referred to the Zonal Hospital of Esquel given the complexity of the clinical picture.

Given this and following the national norms that establish the procedures to be carried out in the event of the appearance of a case of hantavirus [infection], once the situation was reported, technical teams of Epidemiology, Mental Health, Environmental Health, and Community Health Workers in the Field of the Programmatic Area in Esquel moved to the town of El Maitén to continue with the investigation of the episode together with the health teams of the local hospital. They are also implementing the pertinent preventive measures and alert guidelines, as well as the identification of close contacts and their consequent respiratory isolation.

The main actions carried out throughout Friday [17 Mar 2023] included:
- the deepening of field research to identify close contacts
- the corresponding respiratory isolations
- the subsequent monitoring and containment of close contacts during the days following exposure;
- the detection of suspected symptomatic persons; and,
- as a final result of the identification of the activities carried out for the confirmed case, the execution of an environmental focus control, including the placement of traps to capture rodents and virus isolation from them.

It should be noted that having identified that some of the close contacts are also minors, with attendance at the Buenos Aires Chico agrarian school, during the final hours of Friday [17 Mar 2023] a meeting was held between the health teams and the educational community to inform and work jointly on the actions and care guidelines that support and bring peace of mind to adolescents and their families.

The provincial Ministry of Health requests that those involved in health and education in the affected area reinforce prevention messages, placing special emphasis on the need to refrain from going to work, school, social, or family activities in case of symptoms compatible with the disease, among which are fever of 38 deg C [100.4 F] or higher, muscle aches, chills, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or diarrhea without involvement of the upper airways.

In addition, it is vitally important to remember that the incubation period of the virus fluctuates between 7 and 45 days, for which the development of focus control actions for close contacts of a positive case becomes greatly relevant, as well as is the implementation of preventive environmental practices, to avoid the appearance of secondary cases.

Finally, the Provincial Directorate of Prevalent Pathologies and Epidemiology, an agency of Chubut Health detailed that hantaviruses are transmitted mainly by inhalation of virus-laden aerosols from feces, urine, or saliva of infected rodents. Other possible routes of transmission are contact of the conjunctival, nasal, or oral mucosa with excrement or secretions of infected rodents, and the bites of infected rodents. There is also evidence of airborne transmission from person to person.

Hantavirus cardiopulmonary syndrome can present as a mild condition with a non-specific febrile syndrome or manifest in a more serious form with severe respiratory failure and cardiogenic shock, so it is extremely important to go to the closest healthcare provider when the 1st symptom appears.

[Byline: Laura Alves]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[There were several cases of hantavirus infections in Chubut province last year (2022) including 2 cases with infections acquired in the Los Alerces National Park of Chubut province (see ProMED posts listed below).

There is no indication in the report above of the environmental setting where this boy might have acquired his infection. The health agency's investigation may determine that and is informing the public in that locality about preventive measures for avoiding infection.

Although the virus involved in the case above and the previous ones is not mentioned, the most likely virus involved is Andes virus, found in western Argentina in the long-tailed pygmy rice rat host, _Oligoryzomys longicaudatus_. There is also the possibility of infection with Seoul hantavirus, which is widely distributed in the world in brown rats (_Rattus norvegicus_). Andes virus can also be transmitted directly between people in close physical contact. That is why close contacts of the positive case are under surveillance in case of transmission from the case above. - Mod.TY

ProMED map of Argentina: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709044,68924>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (10): UKRAINE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION, POULTRY
**********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[Several sources have confirmed there are no reported cases of avian influenza in humans or poultry in the Kherson area as is alleged in the TASS story below (see Avian influenza, human (11): Ukraine, NOT 20230320.8709054) - Mod.JH]

Date: Sun 19 Mar 2023
Source: TASS [in Russian, machine trans., edited]
<https://tass.ru/proisshestviya/17308475?ysclid=lffvcnud7b679449250>


An outbreak of bird flu occurred at a poultry farm in the village of Velyka Oleksandrivka, which is located on the right bank of the Dnieper river controlled by the Kyiv regime in the Kherson region. A total of 18 people have been hospitalized, 2 of whom have died, an emergency services spokesman told reporters on Sunday [19 Mar 2023].

"From our sources among local residents, it became known that an outbreak of bird flu occurred at the poultry farm in the village of Velyka Oleksandrivka, Kherson region. 18 people were hospitalized. The disease is very severe and has already claimed the lives of 2 people," he said.

The carriers of the virus, presumably, were wild ducks living on the Kakhovka reservoir. Symptoms similar to bird flu have already been found in residents of the villages of Velyka Oleksandrivka, Borozenskoe, Kachkarovka, Dudchany and Mylovoe -- all of them are located in the territory of the Kherson region controlled by Kiev.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Any additional information on the above report from knowledgeable sources would be greatly appreciated. As it's in a conflict area, there is the real potential it could be disinformation. However, the area has had documented H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b in ostriches in February 2023 (<https://bit.ly/3LAQIZL>). This combined with poultry as a potential point source for human exposure and infection lends some plausibility based on other recent human cases. The 2 deaths combined with the large number of hospitalizations is concerning as it could either indicate a large/multiple exposure/infection event(s) and/or human to human transmission. It is also possible it's another non-H5N1 influenza strain. Any additional information corroborating or refuting the report from those in the area would be greatly appreciated. - Mod.JH

column3: An outbreak of bird flu occurred at a poultry farm in the village of Velyka Oleksandrivka, which is located on the right bank of the Dnieper river controlled by the Kyiv regime in the Kherson region. A total of 18 people have been hospitalized, 2 of whom have died, an emergency services spokesman told reporters on Sunday [19 Mar 2023]."From our sources among local residents, it became known that an outbreak of bird flu occurred at the poultry farm in the village of Velyka Oleksandrivka, Kherson region. 18 people were hospitalized. The disease is very severe and has already claimed the lives of 2 people," he said.The carriers of the virus, presumably, were wild ducks living on the Kakhovka reservoir. Symptoms similar to bird flu have already been found in residents of the villages of Velyka Oleksandrivka, Borozenskoe, Kachkarovka, Dudchany and Mylovoe -- all of them are located in the territory of the Kherson region controlled by Kiev.--Communicated by:ProMED[Any additional information on the above report from knowledgeable sources would be greatly appreciated. As it's in a conflict area, there is the real potential it could be disinformation. However, the area has had documented H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b in ostriches in February 2023 (<https://bit.ly/3LAQIZL>). This combined with poultry as a potential point source for human exposure and infection lends some plausibility based on other recent human cases. The 2 deaths combined with the large number of hospitalizations is concerning as it could either indicate a large/multiple exposure/infection event(s) and/or human to human transmission. It is also possible it's another non-H5N1 influenza strain. Any additional information corroborating or refuting the report from those in the area would be greatly appreciated. - Mod.JHProMED map:Ukraine: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709043,123>]

column2:
DIPHTHERIA - INDONESIA (02): (WEST JAVA) FATAL, MORE CASES, VACCINE CAMPAIGN, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*****************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 17 Mar 2023
Source: Antara News [in Indonesian, machine trans., edited]
<https://m.antaranews.com/berita/3446052/kasus-meninggal-akibat-difteri-di-garut-bertambah-jadi-sembilan-orang>


Catch-up immunization for children whose immunization status is incomplete, especially in areas where vaccination coverage is below 70 percent

The Health Service (Dinkes) of Garut Regency, West Java, said that the number of deaths due to the diphtheria epidemic in the area had increased to 9 people from a total of 14 positive cases.

"Yes, one (added) from Cisurupan, aged 9," said Garut District Health Office Secretary Leli Yuliani in Garut on Friday [17 Mar 2023].

He said Garut Regency had determined the diphtheria case as an Extraordinary Event (KLB) until November 2023 to provide optimal health services.

Previously, he said, 8 people died of diphtheria in February 2023; now one more has increased [the tally] to 9 people.

The condition of the diphtheria patient who died, he said, was because he had not received the complete diphtheria vaccination as recommended by the government.

The existence of the death case, said Leli, made his staff continue to increase immunization efforts by pursuing the target of vaccination among children.

"Chase immunization for children whose immunization status is incomplete, especially in areas where vaccination coverage is below 70 percent," he said. He said that currently the focus is on vaccination in the Pangatikan District area because many cases of diphtheria have been found in that area.

In addition to massive vaccinations, he said, his staff also continues to socialize efforts to prevent and treat diphtheria to the people in Garut.

Based on reports from the Garut Health Office, positive diphtheria patients have gradually improved, and some have been declared cured.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[In a previous ProMED post (Diphtheria - Indonesia: fatal, more cases, vaccine campaign, alert 20230222.8708538), the 7 deaths at the time (in mid-Feb 2023) were suspected to be due to diphtheria, because of contact with 2 "positive" [confirmed?] cases in Pangatikan District, Garut Regency, Indonesia. The number of deaths has now increased to 9, but we are not told if this number includes the previous 7 deaths of suspected diphtheria, although the current number of 9 deaths are assumed to be confirmed diphtheria, since the 9 are said in the news report above to be "from a total of 14 positive [confirmed?] cases." Clarification of these numbers would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.

For a discussion of diphtheria in Indonesia, please see my moderator comments in ProMED post Diphtheria - Indonesia: fatal, more cases, vaccine campaign 20180106.5542510.

Garut Regency (pop. over 2.6 million in 2021) is located in West Java province on the western part of the island of Java (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garut_Regency>). Garut Regency is currently divided into 42 districts; Pangatikan (estim. pop.: 38 472 in 2020) is a district in central West Java. A map showing the location of Pangatikan can be seen at <https://goo.gl/maps/JaLhc3sYA2oDrHTT6>. - Mod.ML

column2:
HUMAN ENTEROVIRUS 71 - TAIWAN
*****************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 15 Mar 2023
Source: Taiwan News [edited]
<https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2023/03/15/2003796129>
 

CDC issues enterovirus warning
------------------------------
Two cases of enterovirus 71 (EV71) were reported last week, the Taiwan Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said yesterday, adding that it was a warning sign, as the virus has not been detected for more than a year.
 
Parents are advised to remind their children to practice good hand hygiene, it said.
 
Guo Hung-wei, director of the CDC's Epidemic Intelligence Center, said that 165 230 people visited a hospital for diarrhea last week, which is a high number.
 
Most of the diarrhea case clusters were caused by norovirus infection, but there were also enterovirus cases, and weekly caseloads are slowly increasing, Guo said.
 
Most of last week's enterovirus cases had Enterovirus D68 (EV-D68), but 2 young children in northern Taiwan had EV71, weekly enterovirus data showed.
 
One of the EV71 cases is a 1-year-old boy who had a fever and fatigue, while the other is a 4-year-old girl who had a fever, sore throat and mouth ulcers, CDC physician Lin Yung-ching said.

While their family members did not have symptoms, classmates at their nursery and preschool had enterovirus infections, Lin said.
 
"EV71 infection can cause nervous system complications, including encephalitis, meningitis and even acute flaccid paralysis," he said.
 
Mild symptoms include herpangina (blister-like sores in the mouth and throat) and foot-and-mouth disease, Lin said, adding that the 4-year-old girl's ulcers were a typical symptom.
 
"There has been no enterovirus outbreak in the past 3 years, so many young children have never been infected with an enterovirus and do not have immunity, making cluster infections more likely," he said.
 
Enteroviruses mainly spread through respiratory droplets and direct contact with contaminated objects, so parents should remind their children to wash their hands frequently and wear a mask if they have symptoms, Lin said.
 
People should seek medical attention if suspected symptoms occur and rest at home, he added.
 
CDC Deputy Director-General Philip Lo said the 2 EV71 cases are a warning sign, as the virus has not been detected in Taiwan for more than a year.
 
There have been large outbreaks in the past, and the virus can cause severe complications, so the CDC plans to tell healthcare facilities to be cautious and ask schools and parents to remind young children to practice good hand hygiene, he said.
 
Children aged 5 or under are at higher risk of severe complications, and parents should seek medical attention immediately if their children are persistently sleepy or repeatedly vomiting, or if they have concentration issues, fatigue, weakness of the limbs, myoclonic jerks, shortness of breath or a rapid heartbeat when their body temperature is normal, Lin said.
 
Meanwhile, 3 cases of severe flu complications were reported last week: one with the influenza A (H1N1) virus and 2 with the influenza A (H3N2) virus, Lin said, adding that they were all over the age of 50 and did not get vaccinated this flu season.
 
Separately, the Central Epidemic Command Center yesterday [14 Mar 2023] reported 9860 new local COVID-19 cases, 225 imported cases and 28 deaths.
 
The local case count is 8.8% lower than it was on Tuesday [7 Mar 2023] last week, it said.
 
[Byline: Lee I-chia]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[EV71 was first isolated from the faeces of a female suffering from encephalitis in 1969 in California. However, a retrospective study conducted in the Netherlands indicated that the virus could have emerged as early as 1963; a finding consistent with reports of possible worldwide EV71 epidemics in the late 20th century, throughout the world and with epidemics in Asia, Europe and the Americas. EV71 virus causes a range of effects from asymptomatic infection and mild HFMD to neurological disease with severe central nervous system complications and cardiopulmonary failure. In severe cases mortality rates can be high, especially in children aged 5 years and younger. EV71 is considered to be the most severe neurotoxic enterovirus and severe EV71 disease has become a major public health problem in China.

Enterovirus 71 vaccines
-----------------------
To date 3 vaccines against EV71 have been licensed in China, all using C4 genogroup strains. The efficacy of these 3 vaccines after 2 doses of immunization ranges from 90.0% to 97.4% after one year of surveillance to 95.1% after 2-year follow-up. Candidate vaccines containing B4 and B5 genogroups are in development elsewhere but have not yet reached the licensing stage. Other vaccines such as recombinant and other forms of subunit vaccines, vectored vaccines, and virus-like particle vaccines are in the early stages of development. In addition, the development of vaccines against Coxsackie A16, A6 and A10 is being considered with a view to developing combination/multivalent vaccines. (<https://bit.ly/3ZXYZeH>)

In other previous news from 2022, a Taiwan-made enterovirus 71 vaccine was forecast to hit the market in 2023. 

"The phase 3 clinical trial of a vaccine for the enterovirus 71 (EV71) virus which is safe for babies as young as 2 months has been successful, a research team announced on Thursday [5 May 2022], expecting it to hit the market in early 2023. (<https://focustaiwan.tw/society/202205050024#:~:text=Taipei%2C%20May%205%20(CNA),the%20market%20in%20early%202023>) - Mod.LK]

column2:
POLIOMYELITIS UPDATE (13): WILD POLIOVIRUS TYPE 1 ACUTE FLACCID PARALYSIS PAKISTAN, EFFICACY OF BOPV BOOSTER POST IPV
*********************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Pakistan (Khyber Pakhtunkhwa): AFP WPV1
[2] Efficacy evaluation of bOPV booster post IPV

******
[1] 
[A] Date: Sat 18 Mar 2023
Source: Dawn [edited]
<https://www.dawn.com/news/1742825/polio-free-pakistan-evasive-dream-as-first-case-of-2023-reported>


Polio-free Pakistan 'evasive dream' as 1st case of 2023 reported
----------------------------------------------------------------
Pakistan has reported its 1st polio case of 2023 after a 3-year-old boy in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa's Bannu district became the latest victim of the crippling disease, the health ministry confirmed on Friday [17 Mar 2023].

The case has been reported at a time when delegations of the French Agency for Development (FAD) and Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) are in the country to analyse efforts to eradicate the disease. According to a statement issued by the health ministry on Friday [17 Mar 2023], the FAD and BMGF delegations met the federal health minister to discuss avenues for cooperation in social protection and health, with a focus on polio eradication.

The head of the National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) for Polio, Dr Shahzad Baig, said an investigation is ongoing to identify whether the child received the vaccination or if the parents had refused vaccination. "However, it is clear that the child was not fully protected and that is why [he was] attacked by the virus," Dr Baig said while talking to Dawn.

He said this was the 1st case of the current year [2023] which has been reported after a gap of 5 months. Health authorities have issued an alert on the back of the expected movement from tribal districts to urban areas in Ramadan and Eid. The authorities are now planning a vaccination drive in tribal districts from 10 Apr 2023 as currently, security personnel are engaged in the digital census.

The NEOC head said there were 7 districts in southern KP, including Dera Ismail Khan, Lakki Marwat, Tank, Bannu, South Waziristan and North Waziristan where the virus is prevalent. "(These areas) need to be targeted vigorously in the vaccination campaign." The region was the epicentre of the virus in 2022 with all 20 cases being reported from districts in southern KP. Of them, 17 were from North Waziristan, 2 from Lakki Marwat and 1 from South Waziristan.

While a polio campaign was carried out in Sindh, Punjab and Islamabad in March [2023], the drive couldn't be started in KP and Balochistan as security staff was occupied with census duties.

Support of international community
----------------------------------
The BMGF is one of the biggest contributors supporting Pakistan's efforts to end the virus. The visits are aimed at identifying Pakistan's needs and understanding areas for support in light of the 2022 floods, which left more than 33 million people in need of aid. During the meeting on polio eradication, Minister Abdul Qadir Patel said the health service infrastructure was severely damaged in many districts as a result of floods.

"Thousands of people lost their homes and livelihoods, placing a severe strain on social protection mechanisms. We are still recovering, but despite these toughest of times, Pakistan has not diluted its focus from polio eradication," the health ministry's statement said, quoting Mr Patel. The Gates Foundation delegation was led by Jay Wenger, the global head for polio eradication, while the FAD delegation was headed by Agnès Soucat, the director of health and social protection.

The delegations appreciated the progress made by Pakistan in 2022 and hoped that the virus, restricted to 7 districts, will soon be eradicated. "Thanks to the generous support of the international community, Pakistan has been aggressively fighting the poliovirus," the health minister said. 

The delegation admired the "political commitment at all levels" to eradicate the virus, according to the statement.
 
Earlier this year in January [2023], environmental samples from Lahore -- the 2nd biggest city after Karachi -- tested positive for the polio virus, prompting the authorities to start a vaccination campaign in 26 union councils of the city.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-SOAS

---
[B] Date: Sat 18 Mar 2023
Source: Republic World [edited]
<https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/pakistan-news/pakistan-witness-its-first-polio-case-in-2023-health-ministry-issues-alert-articleshow.html>


Pakistan witnesses its 1st polio case in 2023; Health Ministry issues Alert
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pakistan's health ministry confirmed that the 1st 2023 case of polio in Pakistan has been reported when a 3-year-old boy became the latest victim of the disease, reported Dawn. The young boy is a Khyber Pakhtunkhwa resident in the Bannu district. This case of polio surfaced in the presence of the French Agency for Development (FAD) and Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) delegates, who were in Pakistan to study the efforts that have been taken to eradicate the disease. 

After the discovery of the new case of polio from Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, the head of the National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) for Polio, Dr. Shahzad Baig said that an investigation has been conducted to study and identify if the child had got vaccinated or the parents refused vaccination.

While talking to Dawn on the Pakistan polio crisis, he added, "However, it is clear that the child was not fully protected and that is why [he was] attacked by the virus." Further, he shared that the case of 3 old boys having polio emerged after a gap of 5 months. An alert has been issued by the Pakistan health authorities after they analysed that there would be an expected movement from tribal districts to urban areas in Ramadan and Eid. Currently, from 10 Apr 2023, the Pakistan authorities would commence their vaccination drive in tribal districts with Pakistan security personnel.
 
In southern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), there are 7 districts including Dera Ismail Khan, Lakki Marwat, Tank, Bannu, South Waziristan, and North Waziristan. In these districts, the virus is quite prevalent, as per the NEOC head statement. "(These areas) need to be targeted vigorously in the vaccination campaign," he added. KP was the epicenter of the polio virus in 2022, where 20 cases have been reported. Of those 20, 17 were from the North Waziristan district, 2 were from Lakki Marwat and 1 was from South Waziristan, as per a Dawn news report. 

[Byline: Saumya Joshi]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The elephant in the room is the cVDPVs AFP cases associated with the use of OPV, especially cVDVPV2. A mixed schedule combining IPV followed by OPV has been the route many countries took going from only OPV to only IPV. The recent occurrence of 2 outbreaks of cVDPV2 AFP cases in Burundi and DR Congo associated with the nOPV2 virus after 2 years of use of the nOPV2 is a sobering reminder that the nOPV2 is not without the risk of neurovirulence reversion (see Poliomyelitis update (12): nOPV2-assoc cVDPV2 (Burundi, DRC), WPV1 ES, cVDPV2 AFP 20230317.8708985). - Mod.MPP

ProMED map:
Pakistan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709028,140>]

column3: Pakistan witnesses its 1st polio case in 2023; Health Ministry issues Alert---------------------------------------------------------------------------Pakistan's health ministry confirmed that the 1st 2023 case of polio in Pakistan has been reported when a 3-year-old boy became the latest victim of the disease, reported Dawn. The young boy is a Khyber Pakhtunkhwa resident in the Bannu district. This case of polio surfaced in the presence of the French Agency for Development (FAD) and Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) delegates, who were in Pakistan to study the efforts that have been taken to eradicate the disease. After the discovery of the new case of polio from Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, the head of the National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) for Polio, Dr. Shahzad Baig said that an investigation has been conducted to study and identify if the child had got vaccinated or the parents refused vaccination.While talking to Dawn on the Pakistan polio crisis, he added, "However, it is clear that the child was not fully protected and that is why [he was] attacked by the virus." Further, he shared that the case of 3 old boys having polio emerged after a gap of 5 months. An alert has been issued by the Pakistan health authorities after they analysed that there would be an expected movement from tribal districts to urban areas in Ramadan and Eid. Currently, from 10 Apr 2023, the Pakistan authorities would commence their vaccination drive in tribal districts with Pakistan security personnel. In southern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), there are 7 districts including Dera Ismail Khan, Lakki Marwat, Tank, Bannu, South Waziristan, and North Waziristan. In these districts, the virus is quite prevalent, as per the NEOC head statement. "(These areas) need to be targeted vigorously in the vaccination campaign," he added. KP was the epicenter of the polio virus in 2022, where 20 cases have been reported. Of those 20, 17 were from the North Waziristan district, 2 were from Lakki Marwat and 1 was from South Waziristan, as per a Dawn news report. [Byline: Saumya Joshi]--Communicated by:ProMED[The elephant in the room is the cVDPVs AFP cases associated with the use of OPV, especially cVDVPV2. A mixed schedule combining IPV followed by OPV has been the route many countries took going from only OPV to only IPV. The recent occurrence of 2 outbreaks of cVDPV2 AFP cases in Burundi and DR Congo associated with the nOPV2 virus after 2 years of use of the nOPV2 is a sobering reminder that the nOPV2 is not without the risk of neurovirulence reversion (see Poliomyelitis update (12): nOPV2-assoc cVDPV2 (Burundi, DRC), WPV1 ES, cVDPV2 AFP 20230317.8708985). - Mod.MPPProMED map:Pakistan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709028,140>]

column2:
INFLUENZA (02): INDIA (MAHARASHTRA) SWEDEN, H3N2, INFLUENZA A, INFLUENZA B
**************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] India: Mumbai H3N2
[2] India: Pune H3N2 fatality
[3] Sweden: Influenza B in young adults

******
[1] India: Mumbai
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: The Indian Express [edited]
<https://bit.ly/40kgqpq>


The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) on Thursday [16 Mar 2023] said 32 patients were admitted in Mumbai of whom 4 have been diagnosed with H3N2 and the remaining 28 with H1N1. All patients are in a stable condition, the BMC's public health department said.

The BMC also stated that wards E (Byculla, Mazgaon), D (Tardeo, Girgaum, Walkeshwar), F South (Parel, Sewri), F North (Matunga, Sion), G South (Worli, Lower Parel, Prabhadevi) and G North (Dharavi, Shivaji Park) are high-risk areas as they have reported the maximum number of cases of influenza.

Measures taken by BMC to curb the spread of influenza include:
- Treatment of all suspected cases with Oseltamivir if the fever is not decreasing within 24 hours.
- Oseltamivir has been made freely available at all municipal hospitals, dispensaries, medical colleges and maternity homes in Mumbai.
- Daily house to house survey to identify fever patients and people who are possibly exposed to risk.
- Health awareness activities are conducted in the community with help of posters, health talks and short movies.

On Wednesday [15 Mar 2023], Maharashtra health minister Tanaji Sawant had informed the state Assembly that 352 patients in the state have been diagnosed with the H3N2 virus so far.

"H3N2 is not fatal. It can be cured through proper medical treatment. There is no need to panic," he had said. He also said that 2 persons had died due to influenza, including a 23-year-old 1st-year student of MBBS in Ahmednagar, who tested positive for COVID-19 as well as H1N1 and H3N2 viruses. Another victim is a 74-year-old man from Nagpur, who died of H3N2.

Meanwhile, Chief Minister Eknath Shinde chaired a meeting to review the health department's preparedness to tackle H3N2, an official release said. "If treated early, influenza can be cured. This should be known to everyone," he was quoted as saying.

Shinde further directed authorities to ensure that the ongoing strike of government employees for the Old Pension Scheme does not impact the treatment of patients at government hospitals. He added that the private medical sector should be roped in if needed.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2] India: Pune H3N2 fatality
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: The Economic Times [edited]
<https://m.economictimes.com/news/india/h3n2-virus-pune-records-its-first-death-73-year-old-man-dies-from-the-hong-kong-flu/videoshow/98706651.cms>


Pune recorded its 1st death from H3N2 virus on Thursday morning [16 Mar 2023], as a 73-year-old man died after being infected with the virus. For the last few days, the patient was admitted in the ICU at Yashwantrao Chavan Memorial Hospital in Pimpri-Chinchwad. 

The Health Officer said the patient had symptoms of COPD and another heart issue called Arterial Fibrillation. 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[3] Sweden: Influenza B in young adults
Date: Fri 17 Mar 2023
Source: Swedish Public Health Agency [in Swedish, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/folkhalsorapportering-statistik/statistik-a-o/sjukdomsstatistik/influensa-veckorapporter/aktuell-veckorapport-om-influensa/>


The total number of confirmed cases of influenza and the number of cases of influenza A decreased in week 10. The number of cases of influenza B was at the same level in week 10 as in week 9, after several weeks of increase. The spread of both influenza A and B is estimated to be ongoing throughout the country. Several newly admitted intensive care patients are still reported every week. Confirmed cases that died within 30 days of sampling continue to be reported as well. It is important that those who are sick with respiratory symptoms stay at home and avoid close contact with others. In this week's special episode, you can read more about other causes of respiratory infection.

The Public Health Agency, together with the Infection Control Unit in the Orebro County region, is investigating a few cases of influenza B with serious complications that have been reported in the region. The cases, which have been among people under the age of 18 without an underlying disease or condition, have been very seriously ill with complications such as myocarditis or encephalitis. It is already known that the reported complications can occur in connection with influenza infection, but this is unusual. The investigation aims to assess whether there are more influenza B cases with serious complications than expected and whether there is any common contributing cause in addition to the influenza infection. Therefore, the Public Health Authority has asked other infection control units to investigate whether there are similar cases in other regions. The Public Health Authority is also investigating whether there are similar accumulations of cases in other European countries, but nothing of the sort has been reported so far. Virological analyses show that all Swedish characterized influenza B strains in the 2022-2023 season, including samples from severe cases, belong to the same genetic group of lineage type B/Victoria that dominates in the rest of Europe and is included in the season's influenza vaccines.

Since 14 Mar 2023 Region Orebro County has been offering, in consultation with the Public Health Authority, school-age children free vaccination against influenza for a limited period.

During week 10, a total of 749 cases of influenza A and B were reported, which is 8% fewer than the previous week. The sampling and the percentage of positives were largely at the same level as in week 9, see Table 1 [tables and figures available at source URL].

So far this season, the majority of all reported cases have been influenza A, but the proportion of influenza B cases has increased in recent weeks. During week 10, there were roughly the same number of cases of influenza A (385 cases) as influenza B (364 cases). Between weeks 9 and 10, the number of cases of influenza A decreased by 13%, while influenza B was unchanged, after increasing for several weeks. Of subtyped influenza A samples during the season, 53% have been influenza A(H1)pdm09 and 47% have been influenza A(H3). Line typing of influenza B samples shows that only B/Victoria is circulating. The number of influenza B cases per week is at about the same level as the corresponding week in the 2019-2020 season, when B/Victoria last circulated, but significantly lower than the intensive influenza B/Yamagata season of 2017-2018, see Figure 1B.

The number of cases of influenza per 100 000 inhabitants was unchanged in all parts of the country and remained highest in Svealand. There was no statistically significant difference in the number of cases per 100 000 in any age group between weeks 9 and 10, either overall or for influenza A and influenza B, respectively. Compared to the average for the previous 3 weeks, cases of influenza A decreased in all age groups. For the influenza B cases, no statistically significant changes were seen compared to the average value for the previous 3 weeks. During week 10, for influenza A there were the most cases per 100 000 in the age group 65 years and older, and correspondingly for influenza B there were the most cases in the age group of 0-4 years.

So far, 11 newly admitted patients with laboratory-confirmed influenza have been reported in intensive care during week 10, of which 6 are with influenza A and 5 with influenza B. The reported number of patients treated in intensive care is estimated to be slightly higher due to a delay in reporting. So far this season, 231 intensive care patients have been reported, of which 207 had influenza A and 24 had influenza B. The median age of the intensive care patients was 60 years for those with influenza A and 17 years for those with influenza B. Overall, 71% of all patients belonged to a medical risk group based on an underlying disease or condition or were 65 years of age or older. Among people under the age of 65, 53% belonged to a medical risk group. During the season, 46 people under the age of 18 were reported admitted to intensive care.

Due to a delay in the reporting of deaths, the analysis of deaths focuses on data up to 2 weeks ago. During week 8, 15 deaths were reported within 30 days of influenza diagnosis. For the previous 3 weeks (weeks 5-7), the average was 25 deaths per week. To date [17 Mar 2023], 18 and 15 confirmed cases have been reported deceased during weeks 9 and 10, respectively. Since week 40, 503 deceased confirmed cases have been reported to date [17 Mar 2023], with a median age of 83 years. Of these, 97% have had influenza A. In week 8, mortality in Sweden was within the normal range according to the excess mortality model EuroMoMo.

Within the sentinel sampling, 6 samples have been received for week 10. Two samples were positive for influenza B/Victoria and one sample was positive for influenza A(H1)pdm09, the other 3 samples were negative.

Web searches show unchanged flu activity in Sweden compared to the previous week. The level is lower compared to the seasons before the COVID pandemic, which is mainly due to the fact that the spread of influenza A this season reached its peak already in December [2022]. The updated diagram can be found via the link.

The number of cases of influenza A and B in Denmark is at the same level in week 10 as in week 9. During week 10, influenza B accounted for 59% of all cases. Hospitalizations continue to decline for both influenza A and B. In Norway, the number of cases of both influenza A and B continued to decline in week 10, but there are geographic differences in influenza activity at the moment. Through week 6, influenza A predominated, followed by a period of even distribution, and since week 9, more cases of influenza B have been reported. Hospital admissions have decreased since week 8.

ECDC/WHO-Europe reports with data up to and including week 9 show that slightly more than half of all reporting countries in Europe had high or medium influenza activity. Both influenza A and B circulate and during week 9 more cases of influenza B (57%) than influenza A were reported in the other surveillance except the sentinel surveillance. Since a few weeks ago, the proportion of influenza B has increased and now dominates in several countries.

Special section: Other causes of respiratory infection
------------------------------------------------------
Voluntary reporting of broad respiratory diagnostics from microbiological laboratories in the region of Kronoberg, Blekinge, Skane, Vastmanland, Orebro, Sormland, Vastra Gotaland and Stockholm provides an overview of other causes of viral respiratory infections, in addition to influenzas A and B, RSV and SARS-CoV-2. Specimens analyzed with broad respiratory diagnostics have in most cases already been tested for influenza, RSV and SARS-CoV-2 and have been negative for these viruses.

This report includes analyzed samples with sampling dates from week 35 2022 through week 10 2023, reported in 4-week periods. Rhino and enteroviruses remain at the same level as in the previous period. For human coronaviruses, an increase from 5 to 9% positive is seen for this period compared to the period week 03-06 2023. Human metapneumoviruses also increase slightly, from 2 to 4% positive. Other viruses remain at low levels. Some regional differences occur.

Human coronaviruses and rhinoviruses and enteroviruses continue to account for the highest percentage of positive samples during the period of week 7-10 2023.

Comments on the statistics on other causes of respiratory tract infection
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Rhino and enteroviruses are reported together because both belong to the picornaviridae family and can be difficult to distinguish. In Table S1 and Figure S1, SARS-CoV-2 is not included in the accounting of the occurrence of human coronaviruses. See the weekly reports for COVID-19 instead.

Comments on the statistics
--------------------------
From week 40 2022 until week 20 2023, the enhanced surveillance of influenza is ongoing. The Public Health Agency uses a number of different monitoring systems to monitor the spread of influenza in Sweden during the season. These are described in the weekly report for week 40 2022.

Most samples are analyzed using various multiplex methods that include other agents (including RSV and SARS-CoV-2) and with the broad sampling for COVID-19, it means that significantly more samples are now analyzed for influenza than in the seasons before the pandemic. This means that the number of cases per week is not comparable to levels in seasons prior to 2020-2021.

Confirmed cases are reported per sampling week, alternatively reporting date if sampling date is missing. Statistics on age and gender distribution are based on cases where information on age and legal gender has been received.

Data on deceased confirmed cases includes confirmed influenza cases that died within 30 days after the influenza diagnosis was registered. The analyses mainly focus on data up to 2 weeks ago, as the registry from which the data is taken is updated with some delay.

--
Communicated by:
Mary Marshall
<mjm2020@googlemail.com>

[As the 1st 2 reports note, India is seeing an uptick in Influenza A cases due to the H3N2 strain. This is in addition to the ongoing circulation of COVID-19 and adenovirus. It would be interesting to see how many of the cases involve co-infections and whether or not co-infections are over-represented in the fatalities that have been observed. As the 2nd piece notes, other co-morbidities continue to be a major factor in mortality just as was noted with adenovirus cases.

The cases of Influenza B in Sweden are also cause for concern given the atypical occurrence of myocarditis or encephalitis. This begs the question if underlying conditions may have been present along with any other co-infections, especially COVID-19 given its link to myocarditis. Based on the later portion of the report it appears most cases are being tested for multiple respiratory pathogens so hopefully additional information can be provided as to the likely cause(s) of the atypical symptoms seen in the young adult cohort. Although uncommon, encephalitis has been seen in this age group in previous case reports (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5548692/>). Myocarditis is typically thought to be rarer with Influenza B than Influenza A, but multiple case reports demonstrate it occurs across age cohorts to include children (<https://journals.lww.com/pidj/fulltext/1997/06000/myocarditis_with_influenza_b_infection.18.aspx> and <https://westjem.com/case-report/fatal-influenza-b-myocarditis-in-a-34-year-old-female.html>). - Mod.JH
