Therefore, the Public Health Authority has asked other infection control units to investigate whether there are similar cases in other regions. The Public Health Authority is also investigating whether there are similar accumulations of cases in other European countries, but nothing of the sort has been reported so far. Virological analyses show that all Swedish characterized influenza B strains in the 2022-2023 season, including samples from severe cases, belong to the same genetic group of lineage type B/Victoria that dominates in the rest of Europe and is included in the season's influenza vaccines.Since 14 Mar 2023 Region Orebro County has been offering, in consultation with the Public Health Authority, school-age children free vaccination against influenza for a limited period.During week 10, a total of 749 cases of influenza A and B were reported, which is 8% fewer than the previous week. The sampling and the percentage of positives were largely at the same level as in week 9, see Table 1 [tables and figures available at source URL].So far this season, the majority of all reported cases have been influenza A, but the proportion of influenza B cases has increased in recent weeks. During week 10, there were roughly the same number of cases of influenza A (385 cases) as influenza B (364 cases). Between weeks 9 and 10, the number of cases of influenza A decreased by 13%, while influenza B was unchanged, after increasing for several weeks. Of subtyped influenza A samples during the season, 53% have been influenza A(H1)pdm09 and 47% have been influenza A(H3). Line typing of influenza B samples shows that only B/Victoria is circulating. The number of influenza B cases per week is at about the same level as the corresponding week in the 2019-2020 season, when B/Victoria last circulated, but significantly lower than the intensive influenza B/Yamagata season of 2017-2018, see Figure 1B.The number of cases of influenza per 100 000 inhabitants was unchanged in all parts of the country and remained highest in Svealand. There was no statistically significant difference in the number of cases per 100 000 in any age group between weeks 9 and 10, either overall or for influenza A and influenza B, respectively. Compared to the average for the previous 3 weeks, cases of influenza A decreased in all age groups. For the influenza B cases, no statistically significant changes were seen compared to the average value for the previous 3 weeks. During week 10, for influenza A there were the most cases per 100 000 in the age group 65 years and older, and correspondingly for influenza B there were the most cases in the age group of 0-4 years.So far, 11 newly admitted patients with laboratory-confirmed influenza have been reported in intensive care during week 10, of which 6 are with influenza A and 5 with influenza B. The reported number of patients treated in intensive care is estimated to be slightly higher due to a delay in reporting. So far this season, 231 intensive care patients have been reported, of which 207 had influenza A and 24 had influenza B. The median age of the intensive care patients was 60 years for those with influenza A and 17 years for those with influenza B. Overall, 71% of all patients belonged to a medical risk group based on an underlying disease or condition or were 65 years of age or older. Among people under the age of 65, 53% belonged to a medical risk group. During the season, 46 people under the age of 18 were reported admitted to intensive care.Due to a delay in the reporting of deaths, the analysis of deaths focuses on data up to 2 weeks ago. During week 8, 15 deaths were reported within 30 days of influenza diagnosis. For the previous 3 weeks (weeks 5-7), the average was 25 deaths per week. To date [17 Mar 2023], 18 and 15 confirmed cases have been reported deceased during weeks 9 and 10, respectively. Since week 40, 503 deceased confirmed cases have been reported to date [17 Mar 2023], with a median age of 83 years. Of these, 97% have had influenza A. In week 8, mortality in Sweden was within the normal range according to the excess mortality model EuroMoMo.Within the sentinel sampling, 6 samples have been received for week 10. Two samples were positive for influenza B/Victoria and one sample was positive for influenza A(H1)pdm09, the other 3 samples were negative.Web searches show unchanged flu activity in Sweden compared to the previous week. The level is lower compared to the seasons before the COVID pandemic, which is mainly due to the fact that the spread of influenza A this season reached its peak already in December [2022]. The updated diagram can be found via the link.The number of cases of influenza A and B in Denmark is at the same level in week 10 as in week 9. During week 10, influenza B accounted for 59% of all cases. Hospitalizations continue to decline for both influenza A and B. In Norway, the number of cases of both influenza A and B continued to decline in week 10, but there are geographic differences in influenza activity at the moment. Through week 6, influenza A predominated, followed by a period of even distribution, and since week 9, more cases of influenza B have been reported. Hospital admissions have decreased since week 8.ECDC/WHO-Europe reports with data up to and including week 9 show that slightly more than half of all reporting countries in Europe had high or medium influenza activity. Both influenza A and B circulate and during week 9 more cases of influenza B (57%) than influenza A were reported in the other surveillance except the sentinel surveillance. Since a few weeks ago, the proportion of influenza B has increased and now dominates in several countries.Special section: Other causes of respiratory infection------------------------------------------------------Voluntary reporting of broad respiratory diagnostics from microbiological laboratories in the region of Kronoberg, Blekinge, Skane, Vastmanland, Orebro, Sormland, Vastra Gotaland and Stockholm provides an overview of other causes of viral respiratory infections, in addition to influenzas A and B, RSV and SARS-CoV-2. Specimens analyzed with broad respiratory diagnostics have in most cases already been tested for influenza, RSV and SARS-CoV-2 and have been negative for these viruses.This report includes analyzed samples with sampling dates from week 35 2022 through week 10 2023, reported in 4-week periods. Rhino and enteroviruses remain at the same level as in the previous period. For human coronaviruses, an increase from 5 to 9% positive is seen for this period compared to the period week 03-06 2023. Human metapneumoviruses also increase slightly, from 2 to 4% positive. Other viruses remain at low levels. Some regional differences occur.Human coronaviruses and rhinoviruses and enteroviruses continue to account for the highest percentage of positive samples during the period of week 7-10 2023.Comments on the statistics on other causes of respiratory tract infection-------------------------------------------------------------------------Rhino and enteroviruses are reported together because both belong to the picornaviridae family and can be difficult to distinguish. In Table S1 and Figure S1, SARS-CoV-2 is not included in the accounting of the occurrence of human coronaviruses. See the weekly reports for COVID-19 instead.Comments on the statistics--------------------------From week 40 2022 until week 20 2023, the enhanced surveillance of influenza is ongoing. The Public Health Agency uses a number of different monitoring systems to monitor the spread of influenza in Sweden during the season. These are described in the weekly report for week 40 2022.Most samples are analyzed using various multiplex methods that include other agents (including RSV and SARS-CoV-2) and with the broad sampling for COVID-19, it means that significantly more samples are now analyzed for influenza than in the seasons before the pandemic. This means that the number of cases per week is not comparable to levels in seasons prior to 2020-2021.Confirmed cases are reported per sampling week, alternatively reporting date if sampling date is missing. Statistics on age and gender distribution are based on cases where information on age and legal gender has been received.Data on deceased confirmed cases includes confirmed influenza cases that died within 30 days after the influenza diagnosis was registered. The analyses mainly focus on data up to 2 weeks ago, as the registry from which the data is taken is updated with some delay.--Communicated by:Mary Marshall<mjm2020@googlemail.com>[As the 1st 2 reports note, India is seeing an uptick in Influenza A cases due to the H3N2 strain. This is in addition to the ongoing circulation of COVID-19 and adenovirus. It would be interesting to see how many of the cases involve co-infections and whether or not co-infections are over-represented in the fatalities that have been observed. As the 2nd piece notes, other co-morbidities continue to be a major factor in mortality just as was noted with adenovirus cases.The cases of Influenza B in Sweden are also cause for concern given the atypical occurrence of myocarditis or encephalitis. This begs the question if underlying conditions may have been present along with any other co-infections, especially COVID-19 given its link to myocarditis. Based on the later portion of the report it appears most cases are being tested for multiple respiratory pathogens so hopefully additional information can be provided as to the likely cause(s) of the atypical symptoms seen in the young adult cohort. Although uncommon, encephalitis has been seen in this age group in previous case reports (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5548692/>). Myocarditis is typically thought to be rarer with Influenza B than Influenza A, but multiple case reports demonstrate it occurs across age cohorts to include children (<https://journals.lww.com/pidj/fulltext/1997/06000/myocarditis_with_influenza_b_infection.18.aspx> and <https://westjem.com/case-report/fatal-influenza-b-myocarditis-in-a-34-year-old-female.html>). - Mod.JHProMED maps:India: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709027,142>Sweden: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709027,108>]
column4: Swedish Public Health Agency, The Indian Express, The Economic Times

column2:
HANTAVIRUS - AMERICAS (11): CHILE (LOS LAGOS)
*********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 17 Mar 2023
Source: Bio Bio Chile [in Spanish, trans. Mod.TY, edited]
<https://www.biobiochile.cl/noticias/nacional/region-de-los-lagos/2023/03/17/nina-de-11-anos-es-el-primer-caso-de-virus-hanta-de-este-2023-en-la-region-de-los-lagos.shtml>


An 11-year-old girl is the 1st case of hantavirus [infection] in 2023 in the Los Lagos region
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Health Seremi [Secretaría Regional Ministerial de Salud; regional health ministerial secretariat], confirmed the 1st case of Hantavirus [infection] in 2023 in the Los Lagos region. The victim is an 11-year-old girl from the Río Negro commune.

According to information issued by Radio Bío Bío in Osorno, the minor was infected in the Riachuelo sector.

She is currently in stable condition and is recuperating. 

The Health Seremi, Karin Solís, confirmed this information and called for caution and self-care. "It is very important to maintain Hantavirus preventive measures, such as those if they are going to use structures or houses that have been closed for a long time, ventilate them for at least 30 minutes. In addition, also keep garbage in closed containers and maintain the cleanliness of houses and shelves where food is kept," emphasized the Seremi.

[Byline: Manuel Stuardo]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Apparently the girl has had a somewhat milder infection and, although hospitalized, has not developed the more serious hantavirus cardiopulmonary syndrome and is recovering. There is no information in the above report about the environmental conditions where the girl became infected nor if there is a search for other cases in the area. Contacts should also be monitored since Andes virus, the hantavirus most like responsible for her disease, can be transmitted to others in close contact with her. 

Hantavirus infections occur in a broad Andean region of Chile every year. Although not specified in this or previous reports from affected regions, the hantavirus involved in this case no doubt is Andes virus, which is endemic in Chile. The patient likely came into contact with areas inhabited by the rodent reservoir of the virus in the region, which is why the Los Lagos regional health Seremi issued warnings about following preventive recommendations in areas of risk where the rodent host of Andes virus is found.

Andes virus is rarely transmitted directly from person to person and only through close physical contact, usually within the family. This is why contacts are warned about possible risk of infection. The commonest source of the infection is the long-tailed pygmy rice rat. Images of the long-tailed pygmy rice rat (_Oligoryzomys longicaudatus_), the sigmodontine rodent host of Andes hantavirus, can be seen at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oligoryzomys_longicaudatus#/media/File:Raton_colilarga.jpg>. - Mod.TY

[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[This official report complements the information published in ProMED post 20230311.8708893.

"Sheep pox and goat pox are viral diseases of sheep and goats characterised by fever, generalised papules or nodules, vesicles (rarely), internal lesions (particularly in the lungs), and death. Both diseases are caused by strains of capripoxvirus, all of which can infect sheep and goats. Although most of the strains examined cause more severe clinical disease in either sheep or goats, some strains have been isolated that are equally pathogenic in both species."

"Sheep pox and goat pox are endemic in Africa north of the Equator, the Middle East, and Asia, while some parts of Europe have experienced outbreaks recently. Countries that reported outbreaks of the disease between 2010 and 2015 include Bulgaria, Chinese Taipei, Israel, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Morocco, Greece, and Russia, with Greece, Israel, and Russia having experienced recurring incidences." Source: WOAH Terrestrial Manual, 2023, Chapter 3.8.12 Sheep pox and goat pox. - Mod.CRD
(<https://www.woah.org/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/3.08.12_S_POX_G_POX.pdf>)

[WOAH's high-pathogenicity avian influenza (HPAI) situation report covering 17 Feb to 9 Mar 2023 is available at <https://www.woah.org/app/uploads/2023/03/hpai-situation-report-20230311.pdf>.

According to this report, "the World Organization for Animal Health (WOAH) recommends that countries maintain their surveillance efforts, biosecurity measures at farm level, and continue timely reporting of avian influenza outbreaks in both poultry and non-poultry species. WOAH also stresses the importance of reporting outbreaks of avian influenza in unusual hosts, as it has been noted that the virus has been increasingly detected in mammals in recent months, a situation that should be monitored. High quality of information is key to support early detection and rapid response to potential threats to both animal and public health." - Mod.CRD
(<https://www.woah.org/app/uploads/2023/03/hpai-situation-report-20230311.pdf>)

FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - JORDAN (13): CATTLE, SEROTYPE SAT-2, RESOLVED, WOAH
**************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 9 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4906>


Jordan - Foot-and-mouth disease virus (Inf. with)
-------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: Follow-up 2, final
Started: 26 Jan 2023
Confirmed: 2 Feb 2023
Report date: 9 Mar 2023
End date: 6 Mar 2023
Causal agent: Foot-and-mouth disease virus
Serotype: SAT 2
Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory test
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Dhlail, Zarqa, Zarqa
Quantitative data summary (total):
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered for use / Vaccinated
Cattle / 13 400 / 10 963 / 379 / 0 / 0 / 73 000

Affected population description:
The affected population is the cattle farms in Dhlail area in Zarqa Governorate with severe clinical signs shown on dairy cattle: fever, lesions on mouth, hooves and udder with a significant reduction in milk yield and deaths of calves.

Epidemiology:
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: All cattle in the outbreak zone were vaccinated with a booster dose of an FMD vaccine containing inactivated SAT-2 Eritrea serotype. Since last follow-up report no new cases were detected in the infected zone or outside the infected zone (the buffer zone). Surveillance in the buffer zone and surveillance zone revealed no positive animals using the NSP ELISA.

Control measures at event level
Applied in domestic animals: Quarantine, traceability, surveillance outside the restricted zone, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), movement control, disinfection

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4906>].

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[According to Jordan's final report, the FMD serotype SAT-2 event, which started in January 2023, has been resolved, after severely affecting the cluster of dairy cattle in Dhlail. Remaining restricted to a single district is remarkable. Such scenario could have been achieved by the timely application of animal movement restrictions, closure of animal markets, and ring vaccination around the focus, with a matching vaccine. Another scenario, namely subclinical infections by FMD SAT-2 virus in resistant livestock elsewhere in Jordan, deserves to be examined by a serosurvey in indigenous, possibly resistant cattle, sheep, and goats.
 
Currently, FMDV SAT-2 is continuing its circulation in the region, reportedly in Turkey and Iraq. It will be interesting to compare, in these 2 countries, FMDV strains SAT-2 and (endemic) O strains in regard to their respective pathogenicity, particularly in juvenile ruminants.

Genotyping results of the causative agents in the 3 affected countries are anticipated. - Mod.AS

ProMED map of Jordan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709021,54774>]

column3: Jordan - Foot-and-mouth disease virus (Inf. with)-------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: Follow-up 2, finalStarted: 26 Jan 2023Confirmed: 2 Feb 2023Report date: 9 Mar 2023End date: 6 Mar 2023Causal agent: Foot-and-mouth disease virusSerotype: SAT 2Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory testThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Dhlail, Zarqa, ZarqaQuantitative data summary (total):Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered for use / VaccinatedCattle / 13 400 / 10 963 / 379 / 0 / 0 / 73 000Affected population description:The affected population is the cattle farms in Dhlail area in Zarqa Governorate with severe clinical signs shown on dairy cattle: fever, lesions on mouth, hooves and udder with a significant reduction in milk yield and deaths of calves.Epidemiology:Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: All cattle in the outbreak zone were vaccinated with a booster dose of an FMD vaccine containing inactivated SAT-2 Eritrea serotype. Since last follow-up report no new cases were detected in the infected zone or outside the infected zone (the buffer zone). Surveillance in the buffer zone and surveillance zone revealed no positive animals using the NSP ELISA.Control measures at event levelApplied in domestic animals: Quarantine, traceability, surveillance outside the restricted zone, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), movement control, disinfection[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4906>].--Communicated by:ProMED[According to Jordan's final report, the FMD serotype SAT-2 event, which started in January 2023, has been resolved, after severely affecting the cluster of dairy cattle in Dhlail. Remaining restricted to a single district is remarkable. Such scenario could have been achieved by the timely application of animal movement restrictions, closure of animal markets, and ring vaccination around the focus, with a matching vaccine. Another scenario, namely subclinical infections by FMD SAT-2 virus in resistant livestock elsewhere in Jordan, deserves to be examined by a serosurvey in indigenous, possibly resistant cattle, sheep, and goats. Currently, FMDV SAT-2 is continuing its circulation in the region, reportedly in Turkey and Iraq. It will be interesting to compare, in these 2 countries, FMDV strains SAT-2 and (endemic) O strains in regard to their respective pathogenicity, particularly in juvenile ruminants.Genotyping results of the causative agents in the 3 affected countries are anticipated. - Mod.ASProMED map of Jordan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709021,54774>]

column2:
YELLOW FEVER - AMERICAS (04): BRAZIL (SAO PAULO)
************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 17 Mar 2023 14:49 BRT
Source: G1 [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY, abridged, edited]
<https://g1.globo.com/sp/sao-carlos-regiao/noticia/2023/03/17/macaco-saua-encontrado-morto-testa-positivo-para-febre-amarela-em-aguas-da-prata.ghtml>


An Atlantic titi monkey [_Callicebus personatus_] found dead in Águas da Prata (Sao Paulo) tested positive for yellow fever, according to a statement from the prefecture released on social media this Friday [17 Mar 2023].

The animal's body was found by a resident in the rural area of municipality, in the district of São Roque da Fartura, on 24 Feb 2023. In January [2023], Vargem Grande do Sul, which is near the district, confirmed the 1st case of yellow fever in the State of São Paulo since 2020. The 73-year-old has recovered from his illness.

According to the city government, biological samples were collected from the animal by the Zoonoses Service of the municipality for laboratory diagnosis by the Adolfo Lutz Institute in São Paulo, confirming the disease.

Since the case registered in Vargem Grande do Sul, the Secretary of Health of Águas da Prata, through the Epidemiological Surveillance, already intensified vaccination for all residents of the rural area of the municipality.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
via
ProMED-PORT

[The distance between Águas da Prata, where yellow fever is now confirmed in non-human primates, and Vargem Grande do Sul, where in January 2023 a human case of the disease was confirmed (see PRO/PORT Yellow fever - Brazil (SP), human, information preliminary, official (?), awaiting further information <http://promedmail.org/post/20230126.8707990>), is 20 km (12 mi) in a straight line.

The distance between Vargem Grande do Sul and Monte Santo de Minas (Minas Gerais) where a human case of yellow fever was also confirmed (see PRO/PORT Yellow fever - Brazil (05) (MG), human, death confirmed <http://promedmail.org/post/20230315.8708943>) is 71 km (44 mi) in a straight line.

These were definitely not isolated transmissions, but an ecoepidemiological scenario with evident enhancement/amplification of yellow fever virus circulation over an area probably much more extensive and potentially with great possibility of expansion north-south and east-west in the territory of the state of São Paulo, as we had warned in a previous comment in post (PRO/PORT Yellow fever - Brazil (05): (MG) human, death confirmed <http://promedmail.org/post/20230315.8708943>). At the end of 2022, ProMED-PORT reported the occurrence of yellow fever epizootics in non-human primates in the state of Minas Gerais (see PRO/PORT Yellow fever - Brazil (04) (MG), primate non-human, confirmed <http://promedmail.org/post/20221231.8707530>). In August 2022, a human case was confirmed also in Minas Gerais (PRO/PORT Yellow fever - Brazil (02) (MG), confirmed case <http://promedmail.org/post/20220803.8704838>). The circulation of the virus was already taking place. This now confirms 1st case (fatal) of yellow fever in 2023 in the state. It is quite plausible that new epizootics in non-human primates will be observed and, depending on the number of people still susceptible, it will come as no surprise that new human cases will occur in Minas Gerais and, eventually, neighboring states.

In this context, more robust action should be adopted and coordinated at not just the local/regional level, but state. [This should include:]

- Risk communication to the population
- Intensification of vaccination, with an effective active search for non-immunized individuals
- Training of health professionals for suspicion, investigation and clinical management of suspected cases
- Active search for suspected human cases, including those with less severe febrile conditions (often confused with the currently very common dengue and leptospirosis)
- Intensified surveillance of epizootics and population monitoring of non-human primate populations
- Entomological research actions and, eventually, measures of vector control in peri-urban areas. - Mod.RNA [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY]

Although the occurrence of a single case in a non-human primate may not seem significant, it is a clear indication that yellow fever virus is circulating in the area in the sylvan (forest) transmission cycle. There is the risk that a person who becomes infected could carry the virus to urban or periurban localities where the vector of the urban transmission cycle, _Aedes aegypti_, is abundant. Should there be unvaccinated people in that circumstance, the risk of initiation of an outbreak is possible. That is why a prompt, coordinated response by heath authorities at all levels as noted by Mod.RNA, coupled with an increase in vaccination coverage as noted in the report above, is essential to prevent spread of the disease. - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Sao Paulo, Brazil: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709020,45784>]

column2:
HEPATITIS A - USA (02): (WASHINGTON) FROZEN STRAWBERRIES, ALERT, RECALL
***********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 13 Mar 2023
Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [edited]
<https://www.cdc.gov/hepatitis/outbreaks/2023/hav-contaminated-food/index.htm>


Outbreak of hepatitis A virus infections linked to frozen organic strawberries
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
At a glance
-----------
Reported cases: 5
States: 1
Hospitalizations: 2
Deaths: 0

Investigation details
---------------------
CDC, state public health and regulatory officials, and the FDA are investigating an outbreak of hepatitis A linked to frozen organic strawberries imported from certain farms located in Baja California, Mexico, by a common supplier. Frozen organic strawberries may be sold to a variety of retailers under multiple brand labels. Traceback and epidemiological investigations show that people with outbreak-associated cases in Washington purchased the same retail brand of frozen organic strawberries prior to becoming ill.

As of 13 Mar 2023, a total of 5 outbreak-associated cases of hepatitis A have been reported from one state.

Illnesses started on dates ranging from 24 Nov 2022 to 27 Dec 2022. Ill people range in age from 38 to 61 years, with a median age of 52 years; 40% of ill people are female. Of 5 people with available information, 2 (40%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.

Investigation of the outbreak
-----------------------------
Epidemiologic and traceback evidence indicate that frozen organic strawberries, imported fresh from certain farms located in Baja California, Mexico in 2022, are the likely source of this outbreak. The hepatitis A virus strain causing illnesses in this outbreak is genetically identical to the strain that caused a foodborne hepatitis A outbreak in 2022, which was linked to fresh organic strawberries imported from Baja California, Mexico, and sold at various retailers.

In interviews, ill people answered questions about the foods they ate and other exposures in the 2 to 7 weeks before they became ill. Of people who were interviewed, all of them reported eating frozen organic strawberries. This proportion was significantly higher than results from a survey of healthy people in which 24% reported eating frozen berries in the week before they were interviewed.

In response to this investigation, California Splendor, Inc. of San Diego, California voluntarily recalled certain lots of 4-lb. bags of Kirkland Signature Frozen Organic Whole Strawberries that were sold at Costco stores in Los Angeles, California; Hawaii; and 2 San Diego, California business centers. The lots subject to this recall include 140962-08, 142222-23, 142792-54, 142862-57, 142912-59, 142162-20, 142202-21, 142782-53, 142852-56, 142902-58, 142212-22, 142232-24, 142842-55.

In response to this investigation, Scenic Fruit Company of Gresham, Oregon voluntarily recalled frozen organic strawberries, sold to Costco, Trader Joe's, Aldi, KeHE, Vital Choice Seafood, and PCC Community Markets in certain states. [Products subject to this recall can be found at the source URL above. - Mod.LL]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The previously reported outbreak of the genetically identical virus in 2022 involved 17 American cases and 10 Canadian cases.

The best way to prevent hepatitis A is by getting vaccinated. The hepatitis A vaccine became available in 1995 and is recommended as part of the routine childhood vaccination schedule. However, many adults have not been vaccinated and may be susceptible to the hepatitis A virus.

Two doses of hepatitis A vaccine are routinely recommended for:
- All children (1st dose of vaccine between 12 months and 23 months of age, and the 2nd dose 6 to 18 months later)
- Travelers to countries that have higher rates of hepatitis A (high-risk areas include parts of Africa and Asia, and moderate risk areas include Central and South America, Eastern Europe, and parts of Asia)
- Men who have sex with men
- Users of injection and non-injection illegal drugs
- People experiencing homelessness
- Household or sexual contacts of hepatitis A patients
- People with chronic liver diseases, such as cirrhosis, hepatitis B or hepatitis C
- Family members or caregivers of a recent adoptee from countries where hepatitis A is common
- People who are treated with clotting-factor concentrates
- Mod.LL

ProMED map:
Washington State, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709019,248>]

column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - NEW CALEDONIA: FATAL
************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<https://outbreaknewstoday.com/new-caledonia-reports-dozens-of-leptospirosis-cases-in-first-two-months-of-2023/>


New Caledonia health officials report a rise in leptospirosis cases since the beginning of the year [2023]. As of 28 Feb 2023, 65 leptospirosis cases have been confirmed. This includes 25 cases in January [2023] and 40 cases in February [2023]. There were in total 56 hospitalizations (86%) and one death recorded since the beginning of the year. The cases have been spread over 20 municipalities in both the southern and northern provinces.

New Caledonia reported 265 confirmed cases of leptospirosis in 2022. Among them, 227 people (85.6%) were hospitalized and 4 deaths were recorded (1.1%). In 2021, 229 cases of leptospirosis were declared. Among them, 178 people (77.7%) were hospitalized and 4 deaths were recorded (1.7%).

Leptospirosis is a bacterial disease. People (and animals) can get infected when they are exposed to the urine of infected animals. They can also get infected from water, soil, or food contaminated with infected animal urine. Leptospirosis bacteria can enter the body through skin or mucous membranes (eyes, nose, or mouth).

To reduce your individual risk, it is important to understand that exposure to animals, soil, mud, and floodwaters during work or recreational activities increases your risk of infection.

Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea, jaundice (yellow eyes and skin), red eyes, and skin rash. Without treatment, leptospirosis can lead to kidney damage, meningitis (inflammation of the membrane around the brain and spinal cord), liver failure, respiratory distress, and even death.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[New Caledonia (pop., 271 407 in 2019), a French overseas territory, is an archipelago located east of Australia, north of New Zealand, south of the Equator, and just west of Fiji and Vanuatu; it includes the main island of Grande Terre, the Loyalty Islands, and smaller islands and is divided into 3 provinces -- the North and South Provinces are on the main island, while the Loyalty Islands Province is a series of islands east of the main island (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Caledonia>).

Leptospirosis is a zoonotic spirochetal infection that occurs worldwide and is transmitted to humans by exposure to soil or freshwater contaminated with the urine of wild and domestic animals (including dogs, cattle, swine, and especially rodents) that are chronically infected with pathogenic _Leptospira_. _Leptospira_ may survive in contaminated freshwater or moist soil for weeks to months. Outbreaks of leptospirosis frequently follow heavy rainfall, flooding with fresh water, and increasing rodent numbers.

New Caledonia's wet season is November to April, when heavy rain may be frequent. For example, heavy rainfall is forecast across New Caledonia through at least 17 Mar 2023 (<https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2023/03/new-caledonia-adverse-weather-forecast-territory-wide-through-at-least-march-17>), but there has been notification of extensive flooding in news reports online so far this year. - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
Collectivité spéciale de New Caledonia, France: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709009,459>]

For example, heavy rainfall is forecast across New Caledonia through at least 17 Mar 2023 (<https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2023/03/new-caledonia-adverse-weather-forecast-territory-wide-through-at-least-march-17>), but there has been notification of extensive flooding in news reports online so far this year. - Mod.MLProMED map:Collectivité spéciale de New Caledonia, France: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709009,459>]

column2:
PSEUDOMONAS AERUGINOSA - USA (04): INDIA-MADE/EXTENSIVELY DRUG RESISTANT/CONTAMINATED EYE DROPS, MORE CASES
***********************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: Ars Technica [edited]
<https://arstechnica.com/science/2023/03/more-people-lose-eyeballs-in-outbreak-linked-to-eye-drops/>


An alarming outbreak of extensively drug-resistant bacteria linked to eye drops has now sickened 68 people across 16 states, according to the latest update from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [<https://www.cdc.gov/hai/outbreaks/CRPA-artificial-tears.html>]. At least 16 people have been hospitalized, 8 have lost vision, and 4 have had their eyeballs surgically removed (enucleation). One person has died, which was reported earlier.

The agency first released a health alert on the outbreak on 1 Feb 2023. At that point, the outbreak had sickened 55 people in 12 states, with the one death reported in a Washington patient. In an update emailed to Ars on 22 Feb 2023, the CDC said the case count had reached 58, with 5 cases of vision loss and one enucleation.

The continued rise in cases and severe outcomes highlights the challenge of fighting the germ behind the outbreak, which is an extensively drug-resistant form of _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_. It has the unwieldy name of Verona Integron-mediated Metallo-β-lactamase (VIM) and Guiana-Extended Spectrum-β-Lactamase (GES)-producing carbapenem-resistant _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_ -- or VIM-GES-CRPA, for short.

The VIM-GES-CRPA outbreak strain is rare and has never been seen in the US before. Health officials think it was brought into the country in contaminated eye drops manufactured by Global Pharma, a Chennai, India-based manufacturer. The products were sold under the brand names EzriCare Artificial Tears and Delsam Pharma's Artificial Eye Ointment, which were available nationwide via Amazon, Walmart, and other retailers.

Both products have been recalled, and the Food and Drug Administration put out separate warnings for consumers to immediately stop using the products. The agency noted that Global Pharma has had multiple manufacturing violations, including "lack of appropriate microbial testing, formulation issues (the company manufactures and distributes ophthalmic drugs in 
multi-use bottles, without an adequate preservative), and lack of proper controls concerning tamper-evident packaging."

VIM-GES-CRPA can be difficult to shake even if the eye drops are quickly ditched. The bacteria can lie low, sometimes spreading stealthily, which is particularly problematic in health care facilities with vulnerable patients. Of the 68 cases so far, 37 are linked to clusters in 4 health care facilities.

"Patients can carry these organisms on or in their body without showing signs of illness -- this is called asymptomatic colonization," Marissa Grossman, a CDC Epidemic Intelligence Service Officer, told Ars last month [February 2023]. "This attribute helps facilitate their silent spread in health care facilities." Once a case is found in a health care facility, the CDC and other health officials recommend screening patients to find silent carriers, which is how some of the cases in the current outbreak were found, Grossman said. Most of the health care-linked cases had exposure to the eye drops, but some did not, suggesting person-to-person transmission, she said.

Antibiotic sensitivity testing suggests at least one newer antibiotic is still effective at treating the VIM-GES-CRPA strain. But Grossman noted that the germ's widespread distribution in the US via the eye drops is "concerning."

"To-date, extensively drug-resistant _Pseudomonas_ with genes that rapidly spread resistance, like VIM and GES, have been rare in this country, and typically associated with person-to-person spread in health care facilities," she said. "The widespread introduction of the outbreak strain, which has not been seen before in the US, threatens to undermine efforts to prevent these highly resistant organisms from becoming more common."

Anyone who has used the recalled eye drops and has signs of an eye infection should seek medical care immediately. But, Grossman adds that "at this time, there is no recommendation for testing of patients who have used this product and who are not experiencing any signs or symptoms of infection."

This month [March 2023], the FDA posted recall notices for 2 other types of eye drops -- from Pharmedica and Apotex -- for non-sterility concerns, but they have not been linked to the VIM-GES-CRPA outbreak.

[Byline: Beth Mole]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The citation for the CDC Healthcare-Associated Infections (HAIs) report entitled "Outbreak of Extensively Drug-resistant _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_ Associated with Artificial Tears", and the "Current Update", and "Investigative summary & strain information for clinicians, laboratory scientists, and public health officials" extracted from this report follow below:

Citation: CDC Healthcare-associated Infections (HAI). Outbreak and Patient Notifications. "Outbreak of Extensively Drug-resistant _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_ Associated with Artificial Tears" <https://www.cdc.gov/hai/outbreaks/CRPA-artificial-tears.html>.

"Current Update
---------------
"As of 14 Mar 2023, CDC, in partnership with state and local health departments, identified 68 patients in 16 states (CA, CO, CT, FL, IL, NC, NJ, NM, NY, NV, PA, SD, TX, UT, WA, WI) with VIM-GES-CRPA, a rare strain of extensively drug-resistant _P. aeruginosa_. Thirty-seven patients were linked to 4 healthcare facility clusters. One person has died and there have been 8 reports of vision loss and 4 reports of enucleation (surgical removal of eyeball). Dates of specimen collection were from May 2022 to February 2023. Isolates have been identified from clinical cultures of sputum or bronchial wash (15), cornea (17), urine (10), other nonsterile sources (4), and blood (2), and from rectal swabs (26) collected for surveillance; some patients had specimens collected from more than one anatomic site.

"Most patients reported using artificial tears. Patients reported over 10 different brands of artificial tears and some patients used multiple brands. EzriCare Artificial Tears, a preservative-free, over-the-counter product packaged in multidose bottles, was the brand most commonly reported. This was the only common artificial tears product identified across the 4 healthcare facility clusters. Laboratory testing by CDC identified the presence of VIM-GES-CRPA in opened EzriCare bottles from multiple lots; these bottles were collected from patients with and without eye infections and from 2 states. VIM-GES-CRPA recovered from opened products match the outbreak strain. Testing of unopened bottles of EzriCare Artificial Tears is ongoing to assist in evaluating for whether contamination may have occurred during manufacturing. Patients and healthcare providers should immediately stop the use of EzriCare Artificial Tears pending additional information and guidance from CDC and FDA."

"Investigative summary & strain information for clinicians, laboratory scientists, and public health officials:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"The infections are caused by a strain of carbapenem-resistant _P. aeruginosa_ that produces the Verona integron-encoded metallo-β-lactamase (VIM) and the Guiana-Extended Spectrum-β-Lactamase (GES). Isolates are _P. aeruginosa_ sequence type (ST) 1203 and harbor blaVIM-80 and blaGES-9, a combination not previously identified in the United States.

"VIM-GES-CRPA isolates associated with this outbreak have been extensively drug-resistant (XDR). Isolates that underwent testing at public health laboratories were not susceptible to cefepime, ceftazidime, piperacillin-tazobactam, aztreonam, carbapenems, ceftazidime-avibactam, ceftolozane-tazobactam, fluoroquinolones, polymyxins, amikacin, gentamicin, and tobramycin. A subset of 3 isolates that underwent antimicrobial susceptibility testing for cefiderocol were susceptible to this agent.

"Carbapenem-resistance mechanism testing for carbapenem-resistant _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_ and expanded antimicrobial susceptibility testing for clinical decision making is available through the Antibiotic Resistance Laboratory Network [<https://bit.ly/4083VNM>] which can be accessed through state health department healthcare-associated infections programs [<https://bit.ly/3YWuRPx>]."

The full CDC report is available at the source URL.

_Pseudomonas aeruginosa_, a Gram-negative bacillary pathogen, is a frequent cause of healthcare-associated infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract, and bloodstream infections. In 2017, multidrug-resistant _P. aeruginosa_ caused an estimated 32 600 infections in hospitalized patients and 2700 estimated deaths in the United States (<https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/pdf/threats-report/pseudomonas-aeruginosa-508.pdf>).

Outbreaks of _P. aeruginosa_ in healthcare facilities are often caused by multidrug-resistant _P. aeruginosa_ clones that colonize the hospital environment and patients and routes of transmission may be patient-to-patient or hospital environment-to-patient, via contaminated hands of hospital staff or equipment (<https://aricjournal.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13756-016-0157-9>, <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19046054>, <https://journals.asm.org/doi/10.1128/JCM.03071-12>, <https://journals.asm.org/doi/10.1128/JCM.01772-06>, and <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4219028/>).

Carbapenem resistance can be due to multiple mechanisms that include increased expression of antibiotic efflux pumps, decreased outer membrane permeability due to reduced expression of transmembrane porin channels, and increased AmpC beta-lactamase activity, in addition to the acquisition of plasmid- or chromosomal-encoded carbapenemases (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2620637/> and <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7930500/>). 

The carbapenem-resistant _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_ (VIM-GES-CRPA) outbreak strain in the CDC alert above has been shown to produce Verona integron-encoded metallo-beta-lactamase (VIM) that inactivates carbapenem antibiotics. Other metallo-beta-lactamases (MBLs) include NDMs (New Delhi MBLs) and IMPs (imipenemases). All MBLs are Ambler class B beta-lactamases, which have 1 or 2 divalent zinc ions at the active site, rather than serine. MBLs hydrolyze almost all beta-lactam antibiotics (including carbapenems), except aztreonam, the monobactam antibiotic, and cefiderocol, a siderophore-modified cephalosporin active against carbapenem-resistant Gram-negative bacteria. Aztreonam, the only monobactam currently in clinical use, is an anti-pseudomonal antibiotic and is not hydrolyzed by MBLs owing to poor, nonproductive binding with the enzymes (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7428391/>).

However, some MBL producers are also resistant to aztreonam due to co-production of extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs) that destroy aztreonam. The CRPA outbreak strain co-produces the ESBL Guiana-Extended Spectrum-beta-lactamase (GES). This GES ESBL likely accounts for the CRPA outbreak strain's resistance to aztreonam.

The older beta-lactam beta-lactamase inhibitors (BLIs), such as clavulanic acid, sulbactam, and tazobactam do not inhibit MBLs, nor do the newer non-beta-lactam BLIs that include avibactam and relebactam, which have a diazabicyclooctane core, and vaborbactam, which has boronic acid core. However, avibactam should block GES, allowing aztreonam to exert its bactericidal effects against the VIM-, GES-producing CRPA outbreak strain. 

Avibactam is currently marketed with ceftazidime, an anti-_P. aeruginosa_ extended-spectrum cephalosporin, and if tested in combination with aztreonam, may have antimicrobial activity against the VIM-GES-CRPA outbreak strain (<https://academic.oup.com/jac/article/73/2/542/4641705>). The combination of avibactam and aztreonam is currently under clinical development (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8388901/>). 

Among those who used the eye solution contaminated with the VIM-GES-CRPA outbreak strain, only 20% of the infections with this strain involved the eye; the other CRPA infections due to the outbreak strain in users involved sites other than the eye (bloodstream, and respiratory, GI and urinary tracts), suggesting the VIM-GES-CRPA applied to the eye can subsequently colonize and/or infect many other sites in users. In addition, we learned that, although the VIM-GES-CRPA outbreak strain had never been seen in the USA before, some of those infected with this XDR outbreak strain had never been exposed to the contaminated eye drops, suggesting person-to-person transmission. - Mod.ML

column2:
FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - TURKEY (04): LIVESTOCK, SEROTYPE SAT-2, CONTROL, VACCINATION
***********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 15 Mar 2023
Source: Turkish Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry Press Release [in Turkish, machine trans., edited]
<https://vetkontrol.tarimorman.gov.tr/sap/Haber/55/Sat-2-Virusu-Hakkinda-Bilgilendirme>


Information About the SAT-2 Virus
---------------------------------
Upon the emergence of developments related to foot-and-mouth disease [FMD] in Iraq, samples from different locations were sent to our Ministry's Foot and Mouth Institute [Alum, Ankara] Directorate within the framework of the Sample Sending and Testing Protocol under the coordination of the European Union Commission for Combating Foot and Mouth Disease (EuFMD).

Our institute determined that a sample was serotype SAT-2, which has not been found in our country before. The agent was isolated and studies were immediately started for the production of a vaccine against this serotype in our country. All stakeholders, as well as our Provincial Directorates, were warned about the issue.

In order to prevent the spread of the disease to our country, our Ministry immediately contacted the relevant institutions and provided necessary information on increasing border surveillance and road control activities.

As a result of meticulous work in the field, the 1st case with FMDV serotype SAT-2 was identified. All measures, including cordon-quarantine, have been taken in 8 enterprises that are currently infected. On 8 Mar 2023, the necessary notification was made to the World Animal Health Organization [WOAH].

As a result of the studies carried out by our Alum Institute Directorate, a vaccine against the SAT-2 serotype was produced and made ready for use as of 9 Mar 2023.

All measures to prevent the spread of the disease were taken by the National Center for Disease Control, which was deployed upon these developments, and all movements (in and out of the province) of animals susceptible to FMD were stopped throughout the country during the spring FMD vaccination campaign, except for consignments for slaughter, import and export purposes.

All developments regarding FMDV SAT-2 were closely followed by our Ministry from the start and all necessary precautions have been taken. Our Ministry, which has completed the production of vaccine against this serotype, which is seen for the 1st time in our country, is rapidly carrying out the necessary studies for the vaccination of our entire cattle stock. 

A total of 2.5 million doses of a tetravalent FMD vaccine, containing SAT-2, produced by our FMD Institute Directorate, have been shipped to the field. Our Institute Directorate continues to produce vaccines containing SAT-2, aiming to complete the dispatch process to all provincial directorates of agriculture as soon as possible .

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[While some information included in the above press release was published by Turkey's Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry on 9 Mar 2023 and cited by the local media (see 20230310.8708855), the vaccine production details are new and encouraging. It may be assumed that the release of the vaccine's 1st batch "to the field" is indicative of its safety having already been tested, and its efficacy tested as well or yet under study. Turkey's livestock statistics (2022 data) are -- roughly -- 17 million cattle, 45 million sheep, and 12 million goats. 

The Ministry's "Foot and Mouth Disease in Turkey" review is available at <https://vetkontrol.tarimorman.gov.tr/sap/Menu/34/Turkiyede-Sap-Hastaligi>. It includes information on the FMD vaccination policy, coordinated with and supported by FAO/EuFMD, as applied in Turkey since 1962, when FMDV serotype SAT-1 spread from Bahrain to the Mesopotamian region, the Middle East and Anatolia. The policy has undergone changes since then, according to epidemiological considerations and international OIE/WOAH animal health requirements. Initially, Thrace was declared a (vaccinated) buffer zone. Later, western and eastern buffer zones were established, to prevent, respectively, FMD spread westwards to the Balkan and its introduction from Middle East countries. A trivalent vaccine (serotypes A, O, and Asia1) was applied in the buffer zones. Thrace was the only region maintaining, most of the time, FMD freedom. This situation is currently under threat from FMDV SAT-2. As indicated in the above press release, FMDV SAT-2 has now been added to the (killed) vaccine produced by the Alum Institute in Ankara, becoming tetravalent. 

Ramadan is expected to begin this year on 22 Mar 2023, ending 20 Apr 2023. Intensified animal movements are expected preceding and during Ramadan. A large proportion of domestic ruminants will probably remain unvaccinated against the exotic SAT-2 strain. This is the background to the very severe measures undertaken by the Turkish authorities, including closing of animal markets and standstill. - Mod.AS

column3: Information About the SAT-2 Virus---------------------------------Upon the emergence of developments related to foot-and-mouth disease [FMD] in Iraq, samples from different locations were sent to our Ministry's Foot and Mouth Institute [Alum, Ankara] Directorate within the framework of the Sample Sending and Testing Protocol under the coordination of the European Union Commission for Combating Foot and Mouth Disease (EuFMD).Our institute determined that a sample was serotype SAT-2, which has not been found in our country before. The agent was isolated and studies were immediately started for the production of a vaccine against this serotype in our country. All stakeholders, as well as our Provincial Directorates, were warned about the issue.In order to prevent the spread of the disease to our country, our Ministry immediately contacted the relevant institutions and provided necessary information on increasing border surveillance and road control activities.As a result of meticulous work in the field, the 1st case with FMDV serotype SAT-2 was identified. All measures, including cordon-quarantine, have been taken in 8 enterprises that are currently infected. On 8 Mar 2023, the necessary notification was made to the World Animal Health Organization [WOAH].As a result of the studies carried out by our Alum Institute Directorate, a vaccine against the SAT-2 serotype was produced and made ready for use as of 9 Mar 2023.All measures to prevent the spread of the disease were taken by the National Center for Disease Control, which was deployed upon these developments, and all movements (in and out of the province) of animals susceptible to FMD were stopped throughout the country during the spring FMD vaccination campaign, except for consignments for slaughter, import and export purposes.All developments regarding FMDV SAT-2 were closely followed by our Ministry from the start and all necessary precautions have been taken. Our Ministry, which has completed the production of vaccine against this serotype, which is seen for the 1st time in our country, is rapidly carrying out the necessary studies for the vaccination of our entire cattle stock. A total of 2.5 million doses of a tetravalent FMD vaccine, containing SAT-2, produced by our FMD Institute Directorate, have been shipped to the field. Our Institute Directorate continues to produce vaccines containing SAT-2, aiming to complete the dispatch process to all provincial directorates of agriculture as soon as possible .--Communicated by:ProMED[While some information included in the above press release was published by Turkey's Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry on 9 Mar 2023 and cited by the local media (see 20230310.8708855), the vaccine production details are new and encouraging. It may be assumed that the release of the vaccine's 1st batch "to the field" is indicative of its safety having already been tested, and its efficacy tested as well or yet under study. Turkey's livestock statistics (2022 data) are -- roughly -- 17 million cattle, 45 million sheep, and 12 million goats. The Ministry's "Foot and Mouth Disease in Turkey" review is available at <https://vetkontrol.tarimorman.gov.tr/sap/Menu/34/Turkiyede-Sap-Hastaligi>. It includes information on the FMD vaccination policy, coordinated with and supported by FAO/EuFMD, as applied in Turkey since 1962, when FMDV serotype SAT-1 spread from Bahrain to the Mesopotamian region, the Middle East and Anatolia. The policy has undergone changes since then, according to epidemiological considerations and international OIE/WOAH animal health requirements. Initially, Thrace was declared a (vaccinated) buffer zone. Later, western and eastern buffer zones were established, to prevent, respectively, FMD spread westwards to the Balkan and its introduction from Middle East countries. A trivalent vaccine (serotypes A, O, and Asia1) was applied in the buffer zones. Thrace was the only region maintaining, most of the time, FMD freedom. This situation is currently under threat from FMDV SAT-2. As indicated in the above press release, FMDV SAT-2 has now been added to the (killed) vaccine produced by the Alum Institute in Ankara, becoming tetravalent. Ramadan is expected to begin this year on 22 Mar 2023, ending 20 Apr 2023. Intensified animal movements are expected preceding and during Ramadan. A large proportion of domestic ruminants will probably remain unvaccinated against the exotic SAT-2 strain. This is the background to the very severe measures undertaken by the Turkish authorities, including closing of animal markets and standstill. - Mod.ASProMED map:Turkey: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709006,87>]

******
[3] USA: serial interval and incubation period estimates of mpox
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [abridged, edited]
<https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/29/4/22-1622_article>


Citation: Madewell ZJ, Charniga K, Masters NB, et al. Serial interval and incubation period estimates of monkeypox virus infection in 12 jurisdictions, United States, May-August 2022. Emerg Infect Dis. 2023.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The serial interval is defined as the time between symptom onset in a primary case-patient and symptom onset in the secondary case-patient and depends on the incubation period (the time from a person's infection to the onset of signs and symptoms), epidemic phase, and population contact patterns. The serial interval is critical for estimating the effective reproduction number (Rt) and forecasting incidence, both of which are important for understanding the course of an outbreak and the effect of interventions (e.g., antiviral drugs and vaccines). In the current outbreak, many patients report multiple anonymous sex partners or attendance at large events, such as festivals, in the 3 weeks before symptom onset, which has complicated efforts to identify primary and secondary case pairs. By using preliminary data from 17 mpox case pairs in the United Kingdom, researchers estimated the mean serial interval to be 9.8 days with high uncertainty (95% credible interval [CrI] 5.9-21.4 days). An investigation of 16 primary and secondary case pairs in Italy indicated the estimated mean generation time, or time between infection of primary and secondary cases, to be 12.5 (95% CrI 7.5-17.3) days. In this report, we estimate the serial interval and incubation period for symptom onset and rash onset for MPXV infection in the United States.

The Study
---------
Data on self-reported symptom and rash onset dates for primary and secondary case pairs, including the type of contact that occurred between pairs, were compiled by 12 state and local health departments. We examined serial interval for both earliest symptom onset and rash onset because the latter may be more specific to mpox than the other signs. Earliest symptom onset included any mpox symptom as defined by CDC, including rash. We only included cases if there was a high degree of certainty that the secondary case-patient was infected by the primary case-patient (Appendix).

Conclusions
-----------
Determining the serial interval of a pathogen can inform our understanding of the timing of transmission relative to symptom onset. The serial interval of 8.5 days for symptom onset was similar to an estimate from the United Kingdom of 9.8 days after correcting for right-truncation but shorter than the generation time of 12.5 days reported from Italy. The serial interval correlates with human behavior and can decrease with increasing awareness among men who have sex with men or interventions, a pattern similar to that observed among the general population during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Italy estimates were from the initial period of the epidemic (May-June 2022), whereas our study was for July-August 2022. Serial interval changes can be very rapid. We also found a serial interval of 7.0 days for rash onset. The estimated serial interval for symptom onset was longer than that for the incubation period (5.6 days), suggesting most transmission occurred after the onset of symptoms in the primary case-patient. Conversely, the serial interval for rash onset (7.0 days) was slightly shorter than that for the rash incubation period (7.5 days), which may suggest some prerash transmission; indeed, there were instances in the observed data where secondary case-patients were exposed before onset of reported rash in the primary case-patient. However, the credible intervals for the estimates overlap. The serial interval for symptom onset ranged from 2 to 25 days. This wide range may be attributable in part to variability in the nature and intensity of contact.

The 1st limitation of this study is that precise ascertainment of symptom and rash onset dates is critical for serial interval estimation, but initial mpox symptoms are often nonspecific and may be unrelated to MPXV infection. Second, despite careful selection of linked primary and secondary case pairs, exposure from additional unknown sources may have occurred. Third, social desirability bias may have factored into the self-reported exposures before infection. Fourth, serial interval may vary by age, underlying conditions, vaccination status, or contact type (route of exposure); we did not stratify our analysis by these factors because of limited data. Fifth, we excluded secondary case-patients who had symptom onset on the same day as or before the primary case-patient to ensure a high degree of confidence linking case pairs; however, the serial interval could be negative. Sixth, the serial interval for rash onset could be biased if rash is more quickly identified in the secondary case-patient because of case finding and investigation of the primary case-patient.

Notwithstanding those limitations, our estimate of the serial interval for MPXV infection includes more case pairs than have been reported previously from the United Kingdom and Italy. We also provide estimates for rash onset, which may be more reliable than initial symptom onset for determining serial interval.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[This study provides preliminary evidence that the serial interval of mpox is approximately 8-12 days, but further research is needed. Although a rough estimate at this point, these data can help inform the public on how to take proper precautions to help stop the spread of mpox. This is also extremely relevant as we head into the festival and pride seasons as stated in the article. A system for reporting dates of exposure along with when patients become symptomatic is needed to ensure the data can be used to full effect and updated with new case information. - Mod.CS]

******
[4] A case of mpox reinfection
Date: Sat 11 Mar 2023
Source: Clinical Infectious Diseases [edited]
<https://doi.org/10.1093/cid/ciad147>


Abstract
--------
A healthy young man first diagnosed with mpox in May 2022 presented again in November 2022 with anal proctitis and a positive PCR on a rectal swab for MPX virus (MPXV) after a recent trip to Brazil, where he engaged in condomless sexual intercourse with multiple male partners.

--
Communicated by:
Mary Marshall

[This is one of the few instances of reinfection that has been seen since this outbreak began. Although this report did not include more information about this patient's vaccination status, patient education needs to focus on safe sex practices as well. Vaccination, while helpful, is not completely effective at preventing further infection, and continued exposure to the virus in vaccinated patients could contribute to possible mutations in the future. - Mod.CS]

******
[5] Mexico: 50 mpox cases in 2 weeks
Date: Sun 12 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<https://outbreaknewstoday.com/mexico-reports-more-than-50-mpox-cases-in-two-weeks-90775/>


The Mexico Ministry of Health reports that in the last 14 days a total of 74 probable cases and 51 confirmed cases of mpox or monkeypox have been identified in the country.

The Fortnightly Technical Report on Epidemiological Surveillance in Mexico states that since the confirmation of the 1st case on 28 May 2022, and until 6 Mar 2023, 6559 people who meet the definition have been identified. Of these, 3928 were confirmed, 293 are under study, and 2338 were ruled out by laboratory tests.

The Institute of Epidemiological Diagnosis and Reference (InDRE) notified that the accumulated positive cases are distributed in the 32 states: Mexico City, 2029 infections; Jalisco, 402; State of Mexico, 361; Quintana Roo, 238; Yucatan, 169; Nuevo Leon, 125; Puebla, 68; Veracruz, 64; Tabasco, 57; Chiapas, 52; Lower California, 32; Tamaulipas, 31; Queretaro, 30; Hidalgo, 26; and Morelos, 25.

In addition, Campeche, 23; Chihuahua, 25; Guanajuato, 22; Sinaloa, 19; Aguascalientes, 18; Coahuila, 16; Guerrero, 15; Oaxaca, 14; San Luis Potosi, 12; Tlaxcala, 12; Nayarit, 10; Michoacán, 8; Baja California Sur, 6; Colima, 6; Sound, 5; Zacatecas, 5; and Durango, 3.

Regarding the distribution by sex assigned at birth, the predominance is in men, with 97%; the age group from 30 to 34 years is the one with the highest prevalence, which presents an incidence rate of 10.8 per 100 000 inhabitants; that is, 1025 of the 3928 confirmed cases.

Regarding the gender of those who provide information, 95.76% corresponds to male and 3.29%, female; 0.22% is non-binary; 0.11%, bigender; 0.20%, transgender; and 0.42% corresponds to another group.

The most common symptoms reported are rash in 100% of cases, followed by fever in 72.1%, and headaches in 62.9%. Those who live with HIV, suffer from syphilis and diabetes mellitus, among others, are more vulnerable to developing the disease.

As of 6 Mar 2023, 18 deaths have been identified, of which 4 are directly related to mpox infection, 2 are not related to this cause, and 12 are being analyzed by a group of experts in infectious diseases and epidemiology to define whether there is a causal association between death and mpox infection. These are 17 men and one woman who during medical care presented lesions compatible with mpox.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Jalisco, State of Mexico, and Quintana Roo are all popular vacation destinations for members of the gay community with many groups planning annual trips, especially to Puerto Vallarta. Given the statistics reported in this article, the spread of mpox in these areas is not surprising. Efforts to vaccinate members of these communities need to be made, as well as in other areas where travel within these communities is popular. This includes places like Provincetown, Mykonos, and Fire Island, which are all popular summer vacation destinations for the gay community. Areas that host large music festivals as well should consider education and vaccination campaigns for their citizens to help prevent outbreaks moving forward. - Mod.CS]

******
[6] One-dose Jynneos vaccine effectiveness estimated at 78%
Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: CIDRAP [edited]
<https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/mpox/1-dose-jynneos-vaccine-effectiveness-against-symptomatic-mpox-estimated-78>


Estimated vaccine effectiveness (VE) of a single dose of the Jynneos attenuated smallpox/mpox vaccine against symptomatic mpox infection was 78% at least 14 days later, according to a study published yesterday [13 Mar 2023] in The Lancet Infectious Diseases.

Researchers at the UK Health Security Agency sent questionnaires to men who have sex with men (MSM) in England diagnosed as having mpox from 4 Jul to 9 Oct 2022, and linked the answers to lab data and a public health case-management system.

The team calculated VE by comparing vaccine coverage among eligible patients from the number of estimated doses given to at-risk MSM and the estimated size of that population.

By October [2022], 47% of 363 mpox patients had received one dose of the Jynneos vaccine. Eight respondents (2.2%) had breakthrough infections at least 14 days after vaccination, 32 (8.8%) were diagnosed within 13 days after vaccination, and 323 (89.0%) were unvaccinated.

Estimated one-dose VE against symptomatic mpox was 78% after at least 14 days (95% confidence [CI], 54% to 89%), ranging from 71% to 85% in sensitivity analyses. VE was -4% in the first 13 days after vaccination (95% CI, -50% to 29%).

"A single MVA-BN [Jynneos] dose was highly protective against symptomatic mpox disease among at-risk [MSM], making it a useful tool for mpox outbreak control when rapid protection is needed," the authors wrote. "For cases in which numbers at highest risk of infection exceed vaccine supply, there might be benefit in prioritising delivery of 1st doses."

In a related commentary, Dimie Ogina, MBBS, of Niger Delta University in Nigeria, and Nathalie Strub-Wourgaft, MD, of the Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative in Switzerland, noted that half of the breakthrough mpox infections occurred in HIV patients.

"However, the MVA-BN vaccines have previously been shown to be immunogenic among adults with a history of AIDS, and larger cohorts of people living with HIV will be required to ascertain if HIV is a risk factor for MVA-BN vaccine failure," they wrote.

[Byline: Mary Van Beusekom]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[This article highlights the importance of quick responses to the mpox virus, both by prophylactic vaccination and also via the rapid administration of a single dose when outbreaks occur. As we move into a time when there are many events that could produce outbreaks, this information should inform the allocation of vaccines to prioritize use of a single dose to greatly reduce the spread of mpox and more rapidly bring an end to localized outbreaks. - Mod.CS]

[1]
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: All Africa [edited]
<https://allafrica.com/stories/202303170158.html>


A rapid response medical team has been dispatched to Kagera Region to investigate an unknown disease that has killed 5 people. Two other patients have been admitted. Chief Medical Officer Prof Tumaini Nagu's report released on Thursday [16 Mar 2023] says areas that have been affected by the mysterious disease are Bulinda and Butayaieba villages of Maruku and Kanyangereko wards, respectively, in Bukoba Rural District.

"The Government is closely monitoring the situation and take measures to contain the disease," Prof Nagu states in the statement made available to the Daily News. The government is carrying out a public health awareness campaign in Kagera for people to take all necessary precautions.

The health expert has advised anyone with high fever, vomiting and diarrhoea and bleeding to immediately report to a health center for investigation and treatments. She has also advised people to avoid shaking hands with people who have such symptoms.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2]
Date: Fri 17 Mar 2023
Source: Africa News [edited]
<https://www.africanews.com/amp/2023/03/17/tanzania-authorities-investigates-mysterious-illness-that-killed-five/>


Tanzania has asked medical experts to investigate a mysterious "communicable" disease that has already killed 5 people in the country, authorities said.

The disease has been detected in "7 people with symptoms such as fever, vomiting, bleeding and kidney failure," the health ministry said in a statement late Thursday night [16 Mar 2023]. Medical experts have been dispatched to the Kagera region (northwest) bordering Uganda to investigate the "communicable" disease, said health official Tumaini Nagu.

"Samples have been taken from patients and the dead to identify the source and type of disease," she said in a statement, calling on the population to remain calm.

The case comes after an Ebola outbreak in Uganda that lasted almost 4 months and left 55 people dead. Uganda declared the end of the outbreak in January [2023]. Last year [2022], Tanzania identified an outbreak of leptospirosis, or "rat disease," a disease whose symptoms included nosebleeds, fever, headaches and fatigue, that killed 3 people in the southeastern region of Lindi.

--
Communicated by:
Ryan McGinnis
<Ryan@digicana.com>

[Few clinical and epidemiologic details are given in the above initial reports beyond the fact that the disease is characterized by high fever, vomiting, diarrhea and bleeding, with an apparently high fatality rate. Such features are found in a number of viral hemorrhagic fevers, including Ebola Virus Disease (EVD), Marburg Virus Disease, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, Rift Valley fever (RVF), and yellow fever. EVD should certainly be ruled out as quickly as possible, given the 2022 Ebola outbreak that occurred in Uganda, which borders the Kagera region. 

In 2019, EVD was also a possible concern in an undiagnosed fatal illness in a Tanzanian student that occurred at the same time as an Ebola outbreak in neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo (see below under See Also). A major RVF epidemic in eastern Africa occurred in 2007 that involved Tanzania as well as Kenya and Somalia. In July 2022, a disease outbreak characterized by fever, headache, fatigue and bleeding (especially from the nose) that occurred in the southern Lindi region, affecting 20 people with 3 fatalities, was ultimately identified as leptospirosis. Undiagnosed fatalities due to aflatoxin poisoning have also occurred in Tanzania.

Given that the above differential diagnosis includes communicable viral hemorrhagic fevers, it is essential that rapid diagnosis, isolation of cases and contact tracing be implemented without waiting for the causal agent to be identified. More information on this outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.

ProMED map: Kagera Region, Kagera, Tanzania: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708998,11438>. A description of the Kagera region may be found at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kagera_Region>. - Mod.LXL

ProMED map of Tanzania: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8709005,11438>]

column2:
STREPTOCOCCUS, GROUP A UPDATE (09): UK, SCARLET FEVER, INVASIVE, FATAL, CHILDREN
********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: UK Health Security Agency [edited]
<https://www.gov.uk/government/news/ukhsa-update-on-scarlet-fever-and-invasive-group-a-strep-1>


The latest data from the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) shows that scarlet fever infections and invasive group A streptococcus (iGAS) infections remain high, although they have significantly reduced since the peak in December 2022.

High levels of activity at such an early point in the season remains a concern, with further increases possible in the coming weeks as we move towards the usual peak time of the year for infections. While iGAS is still very rare, notifications remain relatively high in children compared to what we typically see -- these rates are more in keeping with the previous high season of 2017 to 2018.

There continue to be increased notifications in older adult age groups, and as in previous seasons, the majority of iGAS cases have continued to be among those aged over 45 years, particularly in those aged over 75 years.

So far this season (from 12 Sep 2022 to 10 Mar 2023), there have been 49 372 notifications of scarlet fever. In the last comparable high season (from September 2017 to September 2018) there were 30 768 scarlet fever notifications overall across the year.

iGAS infections remain rare but are currently higher than expected in a typical year. So far this season, there have been:

- 2415 iGAS cases across all age groups, compared to 2898 across the whole of the last comparably high season in 2017 to 2018
- 575 iGAS cases in children aged 18 years and under, compared to 205 cases in the 2017 to 2018 season

Sadly, so far this season, there have been 319 deaths across all age groups in England. This figure includes 40 children aged under 18 years in England. In the September 2017 to September 2018 season, there were 354 deaths in total across the season, including 27 deaths among children aged under 18 years.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[A discussion of infections due to group A streptococcus (also called GAS or _Streptococcus pyogenes_) can be found in my moderator comments in ProMED posts Streptococcus, gp A update (05): UK, fatal, scarlet fever, iGAS 20221231.8707549 and Streptococcus, gp A update (06): Denmark, invasive, new subvariant, RFI 20230222.8708507. - Mod.ML
