column2:
BABESIOSIS - USA: (NORTHEASTERN STATES) INCREASE CASES, CLIMATE WARMING, 2011-2019
**********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 17 Mar 2023 11:32 EDT
Source: The New York Times [edited]
<https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/16/health/babesiosis-tick-disease-northeast.html?>


Cases of a tick-borne disease, called babesiosis, more than doubled in some northeastern states between 2011 and 2019, researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported on Thursday [16 Mar 2023] (<https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/72/wr/mm7211a1.htm>).

Although many people with babesiosis are asymptomatic, others develop flulike symptoms, including fevers, chills, sweats and muscle aches (<https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/babesiosis/disease.html>). The disease can be severe or even fatal in people who have compromised immune systems or other risk factors.

The disease, which for decades was extremely rare in the United States, is now endemic in 10 states in the Northeast and the Midwest, the agency said. The increase may have been fueled by rising temperatures and the growing population of deer, 2 factors that help ticks thrive, experts said. "I think this is an unfortunate milestone," said Dr. Peter Krause, a babesiosis expert at the Yale School of Public Health, who was not involved in the study.

Babesiosis is caused by parasites that typically make themselves at home in mice and other rodents. Poppy seed-size blacklegged ticks, which are also known as deer ticks and can transmit Lyme disease, can spread the disease to humans after feeding on infected mice.

The 1st person known to have been infected in the United States was reported in 1969 in Massachusetts. Today, most cases occur in the Northeast and the upper Midwest in the spring and summer. (The parasite can also be transmitted by blood transfusions, and the Food and Drug Administration recommends screening donated blood in certain states.)

In the new study, researchers analyzed 16 174 babesiosis cases reported in 10 states between 2011 and 2019. In 2019 alone, there were more than 2300 cases, more than twice as many as in 2011. The disease was most common in New York, Massachusetts and Connecticut, which typically tallied hundreds of cases per year.

But there were regional differences in the trends. In 2 Midwestern states, Minnesota and Wisconsin, the number of annual cases held relatively steady. By contrast, in 8 northeastern states, the number of cases increased significantly over that period, with the steepest increases in Vermont, Maine, New Hampshire and Connecticut.

In 3 of those states -- Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont -- babesiosis had not previously been considered endemic. The increases in those states are particularly notable, said Edouard Vannier, a babesiosis expert at Tufts Medical Center in Boston who was not involved in the new study. "The disease is going north," he said. "And it's probably due to climate change."

The ticks, which prefer warm, wet conditions, have indeed expanded their territory northward (<https://www.nytimes.com/2022/05/13/us/lone-star-tick-bite-meat-allergy.html>). The findings highlight the need to expand surveillance and screening for the disease, Dr. Vannier said.

A growing deer population could also be fueling the rise in babesiosis. Although deer do not carry the parasites that cause babesiosis, they are the preferred food source for adult ticks. "That greatly amplifies the number of ticks," Dr. Krause said. "A lot more survive, a lot more females lay eggs."

The building of new housing in areas where ticks are present could also play a role, he added, as could increased awareness, which may be prompting more doctors to test patients for the disease.

It is unclear why the midwestern states have not experienced the same rise in cases. "I don't have an explanation for it," Dr. Vannier said. But the disease had typically been less common there than in the Northeast, he noted.

Babesiosis can be treated with antimicrobial drugs. It can be prevented by avoiding tall grass and underbrush, and wearing long pants and tick repellent, in areas where the disease is endemic. Daily tick checks can help people spot and remove the ticks before the arachnids have the chance to transmit the parasite.

[Byline: Emily Anthes]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The citation and abstract from the journal article referenced in the news report above follow:

Swanson M, Pickrel A, Williamson J, Montgomery S. Trends in reported babesiosis cases -- United States, 2011-2019. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2023; 72: 273-7; <http://dx.doi.org/10.15585/mmwr.mm7211a1>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
------
"What is already known about this topic? Babesiosis is an emerging zoonotic tickborne parasitic disease in the United States and occurs primarily in the Northeast and Midwest.

"What is added by this report? During 2011-2019, US babesiosis incidence significantly increased in northeastern states. Three states (Maine, New Hampshire, and Vermont) that were not considered to have endemic babesiosis had significantly increasing incidences and reported case counts similar to or higher than those in the 7 states with known endemic transmission.

"What are the implications for public health practice? As case rates rise in multiple states, tick prevention messaging, provider education, and traveler risk awareness should be emphasized."

The following is extracted from my moderator comments in a prior ProMED post (Lyme disease, anaplasmosis, babesiosis - USA: (ME) 20220819.8705108):

"An increased incidence of Lyme disease, anaplasmosis, and babesiosis can be due to a true increase in the number of cases as the primary vector and the reservoir hosts expand locally or spread geographically into previously uninvolved regions, but also better recognition and reporting of these diseases may contribute to the increases in the number of reported cases.

"Factors that could account for a true increase in the incidence of these tick-borne diseases in the US state of Maine include climate change, growth of suburban neighborhoods into surrounding wooded areas, and enlarging populations of deer, white-footed mice, and other small rodents, and _Borrelia burgdorferi_-infected nymphal _Ixodes scapularis_. Nymphal _I. scapularis_ are the primary tick vector for these diseases in the northeastern US and southeastern Canada. Deer, although not susceptible to Lyme disease, supply the adult tick with a required blood meal and they are responsible for transporting ticks; white-footed mice and other small rodents are the primary reservoirs for Lyme disease.

"_I. scapularis_ likely traveled from endemic areas in the northeastern US by attaching themselves onto migrating mammals and birds (<https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/07/150706143251.htm>). Deer ticks by themselves unlikely travel far; travel over greater distances is achieved by the ticks' attaching themselves to migrating mammals and birds. Ticks can only climb the short distance on vegetation to a height at which they are most likely to contact their preferred host and wait (known as "questing") for a host to pass by. Nymphs quest for a blood meal at temperatures greater than 7 deg C/45 deg F (<http://jtm.oxfordjournals.org/content/15/1/39.long>).

"A photo of the characteristic rash of early Lyme disease can be found at <http://www.medicinenet.com/image-collection/lyme_disease_picture/picture.htm>.

"In the United States, _I. scapularis_ can transmit simultaneously one or more of the following pathogens: _Borrelia burgdorferi_ (the spirochete that causes Lyme disease), _Anaplasma phagocytophilum_ (a bacterium that causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis or HGA), _Borrelia miyamotoi_ (a spirochete that causes a relapsing fever-like illness), _Babesia microti_ (the protozoan that causes babesiosis), and Powassan virus (a virus that causes encephalitis) (<https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fcimb.2020.00142/full>). For a picture of the tick nymph, see <http://www.cdc.gov/parasites/babesiosis/>.

"A prevalence of 45% of deer ticks carrying the bacterium that causes Lyme disease is high and means that there are many infected white-footed mice (_Peromyscus leucopus_) on which ticks fed. White-footed mice are the reservoir of _B. burgdorferi_.

"Decreased rainfall in the summer months in Maine could have reduced the questing nymph tick population because nymph ticks require a high humidity of more than 85% (<http://jtm.oxfordjournals.org/content/15/1/39.long>), forcing them to move down the vegetation into more humid leaf litter on the ground to maintain hydration during summer drought conditions.

"The increased incidence of Lyme disease and anaplasmosis in Maine could be due to an increase in the number of questing infected tick vectors during a wet fall season. Because nymphs quest for a blood meal at temperatures greater than 7 deg C/45 deg F (<http://jtm.oxfordjournals.org/content/15/1/39.long>), the local daytime temperatures in the fall season would have to be above this value. In fact, daytime temperatures are mostly above 7 deg C/45 deg F in September and October in Maine (<https://www.currentresults.com/Weather/Maine/temperature-october.php>)."

"It should be noted that cases are reported by county of residence, which is assumed to be the county of exposure. But people are often exposed to infected ticks outside their county of residence." - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708997,106>]

Deer ticks by themselves unlikely travel far; travel over greater distances is achieved by the ticks' attaching themselves to migrating mammals and birds. Ticks can only climb the short distance on vegetation to a height at which they are most likely to contact their preferred host and wait (known as "questing") for a host to pass by. Nymphs quest for a blood meal at temperatures greater than 7 deg C/45 deg F (<http://jtm.oxfordjournals.org/content/15/1/39.long>)."A photo of the characteristic rash of early Lyme disease can be found at <http://www.medicinenet.com/image-collection/lyme_disease_picture/picture.htm>."In the United States, _I. scapularis_ can transmit simultaneously one or more of the following pathogens: _Borrelia burgdorferi_ (the spirochete that causes Lyme disease), _Anaplasma phagocytophilum_ (a bacterium that causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis or HGA), _Borrelia miyamotoi_ (a spirochete that causes a relapsing fever-like illness), _Babesia microti_ (the protozoan that causes babesiosis), and Powassan virus (a virus that causes encephalitis) (<https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fcimb.2020.00142/full>). For a picture of the tick nymph, see <http://www.cdc.gov/parasites/babesiosis/>."A prevalence of 45% of deer ticks carrying the bacterium that causes Lyme disease is high and means that there are many infected white-footed mice (_Peromyscus leucopus_) on which ticks fed. White-footed mice are the reservoir of _B. burgdorferi_."Decreased rainfall in the summer months in Maine could have reduced the questing nymph tick population because nymph ticks require a high humidity of more than 85% (<http://jtm.oxfordjournals.org/content/15/1/39.long>), forcing them to move down the vegetation into more humid leaf litter on the ground to maintain hydration during summer drought conditions."The increased incidence of Lyme disease and anaplasmosis in Maine could be due to an increase in the number of questing infected tick vectors during a wet fall season. Because nymphs quest for a blood meal at temperatures greater than 7 deg C/45 deg F (<http://jtm.oxfordjournals.org/content/15/1/39.long>), the local daytime temperatures in the fall season would have to be above this value. In fact, daytime temperatures are mostly above 7 deg C/45 deg F in September and October in Maine (<https://www.currentresults.com/Weather/Maine/temperature-october.php>).""It should be noted that cases are reported by county of residence, which is assumed to be the county of exposure. But people are often exposed to infected ticks outside their county of residence." - Mod.MLProMED map:United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708997,106>]

POLIOMYELITIS UPDATE (12): NOVEL ORAL POLIO VACCINE TYPE 2-ASSOCIATED CIRCULATING VACCINE DERIVED POLIOVIRUS TYPE 2 (BURUNDI, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO), WILD POLIOVIRUS TYPE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES, CIRCULATING VACCINE DERIVED POLIOVIRUS TYPE 2 AC
***************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Burundi, DR Congo: cVDPV2 from nOPV2
[2] Global update as of 15 Mar 2023: WPV1 ES (Pakistan), cVDPV2 AFP (Benin, Burundi, Chad, DR Congo, Niger)
[3] Israel: 175 000 of less than 2-year-old children unvaccinated

******
[1] Burundi and DR Congo: cVDPV2 from nOPV2
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI)/World Health Organization (WHO) [edited]
<https://polioeradication.org/news-post/gpei-statement-on-cvdpv2-detections-in-burundi-and-democratic-republic-of-the-congo/>


GPEI Statement on cVDPV2 detections in Burundi and Democratic Republic of the Congo - 16 Mar 2023
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Through ongoing surveillance, the Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) has received notification of the detection of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) in Burundi and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) linked with the novel oral polio vaccine type 2 (nOPV2). The viruses were isolated from the stool samples of 7 children with acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) -- 6 in DRC (eastern Tanganyika and South Kivu provinces), 1 in Burundi (Bujumbura Rural province) -- and from 5 environmental samples collected in Burundi (Bujumbura Mairie province). All reported isolates stem from 2 separate and new emergences of cVDPV2 linked with nOPV2 that originated in Tanganyika and South Kivu provinces in DRC.

GPEI is supporting local authorities in both and neighbouring countries to conduct a thorough risk assessment and plan vaccination responses to reduce the risk of further transmission, as per outbreak response protocols. Burundi and DRC have scheduled initial vaccination campaigns to be conducted in April [2023] and based on the ongoing risk assessment, subsequent campaigns may be expanded to include areas in neighbouring countries.

Additionally, both AFP and environmental surveillance are being stepped up in the areas of detection, and the operationalization of further environmental surveillance sites is being evaluated. Samples from Burundi, DRC, and neighbouring countries are also being prioritized for testing by the Global Polio Laboratory Network.

These are the 1st instances of cVDPV2 linked with nOPV2 since roll-out of the vaccine began in March 2021. While detection of these outbreaks is a tragedy for the families and communities affected, it is not unexpected with wider use of the vaccine. All available clinical and field evidence continues to demonstrate that nOPV2 is safe and effective and has a significantly lower risk of reverting to a form that cause paralysis in low immunity settings when compared to monovalent oral polio vaccine type 2 (mOPV2).

To date [16 Mar 2023], close to 600 million doses of nOPV2 have been administered across 28 countries globally, and the majority of countries have seen no further transmission of cVDPV2 after 2 immunization rounds. Throughout the vaccine's extensive field use, the strains in DRC and Burundi are the only 2 cVDPV2 emergences detected that have been linked with nOPV2. A preliminary assessment suggests an estimated 30-40 new cVDPV2 emergences, conditional on surveillance inputs, would have been detected by 1 Mar 2023 if mOPV2 was used instead of nOPV2 at the same scale.

Focused safety, effectiveness and genetic stability monitoring will continue for the duration of the vaccine's use under WHO Emergency Use Listing (EUL) and work continues to advance towards nOPV2's WHO prequalification, expected by the end of this year [2023].

Importantly, eastern DRC is classified as 1 of GPEI's 7 most consequential geographies for poliovirus outbreak risk. Complex humanitarian challenges in the country, including insecurity, have created longstanding barriers to reaching every child with the polio vaccine. This has contributed to the continued spread of variant poliovirus within DRC and its exportation to nearby countries. GPEI continues to adapt its strategy and work with local authorities to protect all children from this devastating disease through targeted, flexible campaign efforts.

Ultimately, no vaccine sitting in a vial can protect a child. The success of nOPV2 and any polio vaccine depends on the ability to rapidly implement high-quality immunization campaigns to ensure that every child is vaccinated and poliovirus' spread is stopped.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The nOPV2 has been the hope of the polio eradication effort to eliminate the cVDPV2 outbreaks being seen in more than 30 countries. The vaccine was described as more stable than the current OPV2 with no real reversions seen during clinical trials. I recommend reading the 3 posts in which we covered nOPV2 (Poliomyelitis update (18): cVDPV2 (Pakistan, CAR, Chad, Somalia), nOPV2 20201211.8009474, Poliomyelitis update (103): global (WPV1, cVDPV) Pakistan, nOPV2 soon to release 20191220.6850114, Poliomyelitis update (44): WPV1, cVDPV2, WHO, nOPV2 20190606.6507515). In the post Poliomyelitis update (103): global (WPV1, cVDPV) Pakistan, nOPV2 soon to release 20191220.6850114, my moderator comment said the following: "Reading this article has me very cautious about the early release of the nOPV2. It doesn't mention the size of the study population. The one paper I was able to find on the early studies on this vaccine mentions a cohort of 30 individuals with previous history of IPV (inactivated polio vaccine) vaccination. A very small study size when compared with the millions of children who will be vaccinated with this vaccine. I am also reminded of the observation that OPV was in use for 20+ years before cVDPVs were recognized (field trials in the early 60s). One thought is what happens to the nOPV2 after multiple passages through unvaccinated/susceptible individuals in areas with pockets of susceptibles?"

The paper I referred to in the post is: Van Damme P, De Coster I, Bandyopadhyay AS, et al. The safety and immunogenicity of 2 novel live attenuated monovalent (serotype 2) oral poliovirus vaccines in healthy adults: a double-blind, single-centre phase 1 study. Lancet. 2019; 394(10193): 148-158. doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736(19)31279-6. Epub 4 Jun 2019. (The full text of this article can be found at: <https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(19)31279-6/fulltext>)

And is the discussion over IPV entering the immunization programs worldwide to replace the use of OPV up for renewal? 

A map of Burundi showing provinces can be found at <https://reliefweb.int/map/burundi/reference-map-burundi-administrative-provinces-and-communes>.

A map of DR Congo showing provinces can be found at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo#/media/File:2006_Nouvelles_provinces_de_la_R%C3%A9publique_D%C3%A9mocratique_du_Congo.png> - Mod.MPP]

[2] Global update as of 15 Mar 2023: WPV1 ES (Pakistan), cVDPV2 AFP (Benin, Burundi, Chad, DR Congo, Niger)
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative/WHO [edited]
<https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/>


[Note: These data come from a weekly email sent by GPEI and the data on the website may transiently be different. - Mod.MPP]

Poliovirus Weekly Update 15 Mar 2023, WHO
-----------------------------------------
New wild poliovirus isolates reported this week:
AFP cases: 0
Environment: 1
Others: 0
 
New cVDPV isolates reported this week: 
AFP cases: 11
Environment: 5
Others: 5

Headlines
• The Global Commission for the Certification of Poliomyelitis Eradication (GCC) met recently in Amman, Jordan, to review progress towards interrupting wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) transmission in polio-endemic Pakistan and Afghanistan, implementation of the Global Surveillance Action Plan, and to hear from the 6 regional certification commissions on current regional priorities and issues. (see <https://polioeradication.org/news-post/confidence-in-surveillance-essential-for-certifying-a-polio-free-world/>)
• The GPEI has received confirmation of the detection of cVDPV2 in Burundi and Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), originating from novel oral polio vaccine type 2 (nOPV2) (see country sections below). Read the GPEI's statement on the detections [See section [1] above].
 
Summary of new polioviruses this week: 
- Pakistan: 1 wild poliovirus type 1-positive environmental sample
- Benin: 1 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) case
- Burundi: 1 cVDPV2 case and 5 cVDPV2-positive environmental samples
- Chad: 2 cVDPV2 cases
- Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo): 6 cVDPV2 cases
- Niger: 1 cVDPV2 case
 
Afghanistan 
• No wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) cases were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2022.
 
Pakistan
• No wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) cases were reported this week. There are 20 cases detected in 2022.
• 1 WPV1-positive environmental sample was reported in the past week, collected on 21 Feb 2023, from DI Khan in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.
 
Algeria
• No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) were reported this week. There are 3 cases detected in 2022.

Benin
• 1 cVDPV2 case was reported in the past week, from Littoral province, with onset of paralysis on 2 Jan 2023. It is the 1st case reported in 2023. In 2022, 11 cVDPV2 cases had been reported. 
 
Botswana
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental sample was reported this week. There are 4 positive samples reported in 2022 and 1 in 2023.
 
Burkina Faso
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021. 
 
Burundi
• 1 cVDPV2 case was reported this week, from Bujumbura Rural province, with onset of paralysis on 24 Nov 2022. 
• 5 cVDPV2-positive environmental samples were reported in the past week, from Bujumbura Mairie province, collected in November and December 2022. 
• Viruses isolated are linked to eastern DRC's Sud-Kivu's emergence.
• The GPEI is supporting local authorities to conduct a thorough risk assessment and with the planning of activities to mitigate risk of spread. 
 
Cameroon
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There are 3 cases reported in 2022.
 
Canada
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported in the past week. Previously, cVDPV2 was isolated from 2 environmental samples from a large wastewater treatment plant and a target site in the city of Montreal, Quebec, collected on 27 and 30 Aug 2022, after the country conducted retrospective analysis of wastewater samples. Genetic sequencing confirmed it is linked to the cVDPV2 currently affecting New York, USA. 
 
Central African Republic
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There are 5 cases detected in 2022.
 
Chad
• 2 cVDPV2 cases were reported in the past week, with onset of paralysis on 4 and 6 Jan 2023, from Lac and Logone Occidental provinces, respectively. These are the 1st reported cases in 2023. There were 44 reported cases in 2022.
 
Congo (Republic of)
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) was reported this week. There is 1 case detected in 2022 . 
 
Côte d'Ivoire
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There were no cases reported in 2021.
 
Djibouti
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental samples were reported this week. 
 
Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo)
• 6 cVDPV2 cases were reported in the past week, 5 from Tanganyika province (with onset of paralysis in October, November and December 2022) and 1 from Sud-Kivu province (with onset of paralysis on 27 Sep 2022, bringing the total number of cVDPV2 cases for 2022 to 318. There are also 115 cVDPV1 cases reported in 2022. 
• Viruses isolated are linked to 2 separate emergences in eastern DRC's Tanganyika and Sud-Kivu provinces.
• The GPEI is supporting local authorities to conduct a thorough risk assessment and with the planning of activities to mitigate risk of spread. 
 
Egypt
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental sample was reported this week. There are 18 positive samples reported in the country in the last 2 years.
 
Eritrea
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There is 1 case in 2022.
 
Ethiopia
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022.
 
Gambia
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental samples were reported this week. There were 9 positive samples in 2021.
 
Ghana
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There are 3 cases in 2022.

Guinea
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There were 6 cases in 2021.
 
Guinea-Bissau
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There are 3 cases in the country which are linked to the Jigawa outbreak in Nigeria in 2021. 

Indonesia
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2023. There was 1 case detected in 2022.
 
Israel
• No cVDPV cases were reported in the past week. In 2023, 1 cVDPV2 case was reported, with onset of paralysis on 13 Feb 2023, linked to cVDPV2-positive environmental samples previously detected in the country (54 samples in total were reported in 2022, the most recent sample had been collected on 24 Oct 2022).
• In 2022, 1 cVDPV3 case had been reported, with onset of paralysis on 12 Feb 2022, linked to cVDPV3-positive environmental samples previously detected in the country (25 samples in total were reported in 2022, the most recent sample had been collected on 15 Mar 2022). 
 
Liberia
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There were 3 cVDPV2 cases in 2021. 
 
Madagascar
• No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) were reported in the past week. There are 14 cases detected in 2022 and 5 in 2023.
 
Malawi
• No case of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) was reported this week. 1 case from 2021 has been reported in 2022. 
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) was reported this week. There were 4 cases in the country in 2022.
 
Mali
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2022.
 
Mauritania
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental sample was reported this week. There were 7 positive samples linked to the Jigawa outbreak in 2021.
 
Mozambique
• No wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case was reported this week. There are 8 cases detected in 2022. 
• No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) were reported in the past week. There were 21 cases in 2022.
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. The number of cases in 2022 remains 4.
 
Niger
• 1 case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week, with onset of paralysis on 25 Dec 2022, from Tillaberi province, bringing the total number of cVDPV2 cases in 2022 to 15.
 
Nigeria
• No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) this week. There is 1 case detected in 2023 and 48 cases detected in 2022. 
 
Senegal
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week.

Sierra Leone
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. 

Somalia
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported in Banadir. There is 1 case in 2023 and 5 cases detected in 2022 .
 
South Sudan
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week.
 
Sudan
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022. 
 
Togo
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There are 2 cases in 2022.
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental sample was reported this week. There are 2 positive samples reported in 2022.
 
Uganda
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental sample was reported this week.
 
Ukraine
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021. 
• Disease surveillance continues to be strengthened, to the degree possible given the evolving situation, including by building capacity, conducting training, implementing environmental surveillance and supporting routine immunization.
 
United Kingdom
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental samples were reported this week. 6 positive samples were reported following the isolation of vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (VDPV2) from environmental samples in London, UK.
• No cases of paralysis associated with this strain have been detected -- virus has been isolated only from environmental (sewage) samples.
 
United States of America
• No case of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported this week. 1 cVDPV2 case was reported in New York in 2022.
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental sample was reported this week. There were 14 positive samples reported in 2022.
 
Yemen
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) was reported in the past week. There are 162 cases detected in 2022.

Zambia
• No circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive environmental samples were reported this week. There are 3 positives samples reported in 2022.
 
Officially reported WPV1 and cVDPV cases as of 14 Mar 2023
Wild poliovirus (WPV)
- Total global WPV1 cases in 2023: 0 (compared with 1 for the same period in 2022)
- Total global WPV1 cases in 2022: 30
Circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) cases
- Total global cVDPV cases in 2023: 13 (compared with 9 for the same period in 2022)
- Total global cVDPV cases in 2022: 786
 
--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[After several weeks of no identified WPV1 activity there is a positive environmental sample in Pakistan and 5 countries had evidence of cVDPV2 (Benin, Burundi, Chad, DR Congo, Niger). AFP cases with onset in 2022 continue to be identified bringing the total number of cVDPV AFP cases in 2022 to 786.

A map showing the locations of each confirmed case of polio worldwide in the past 12 months can be found at <https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/>. One can see cases of WPV1 in Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Mozambique; cVDPV1 in Congo (Brazzaville), DR Congo (Kinshasa), Malawi, Madagascar and Mozambique; cVDPV2 in 19 countries in a band across Africa and in Afghanistan, Pakistan and the USA; and a cVDPV3 in Israel - Mod.MPP]

******
[3] Israel: 175 000 of less than 2-year-old children unvaccinated
Date: Mon 13 Mar 2023
Source: The Times of Israel [edited]
<https://www.timesofisrael.com/some-175000-israeli-kids-not-immunized-against-polio-virus-health-ministry/>


At least 175 000 Israeli children have not been vaccinated against polio, a viral disease that mainly affects children and can cause disability, paralysis and death, according to a new assessment by the Health Ministry cited by Channel 12 on Monday [13 Mar 2023].

Parents of children who have not been immunized were urged to take them to a local health center to receive the vaccine.

Polio vaccinations are standard for children and are an effective preventive measure, but vaccine skepticism has recently enabled the disease to rear its head again.

Earlier this month [March 2023], 4 children were diagnosed with the disease in the northern city of Safed, and the Health Ministry warned that there was evidence in recent months "of a spread of polio in many sewage systems in Israel." The ministry said at the time that it estimated that 150 000 Israeli children were unvaccinated against the virus, 25 000 fewer than Monday's [13 Mar 2023] figures. Three of the children became infected with the virus after being exposed to an 8-year-old girl in Safed who tested positive for the polio virus despite not having any symptoms. [the 8-year old had AFP; the 3 contacts were asymptomatic infections - Mod.MPP]

The Health Ministry said it would continue to monitor and update the public, and encouraged people to maintain good hygiene practices to stymie any outbreak.

Last March [2022], the 1st case of polio in 33 years was discovered in Israel, leading to a small outbreak and a vaccination drive to combat the disease. [There were 6 confirmed AFP cases plus 1 highly suspected. All were not vaccinated. The outbreak was associated with a cVDPV3. See Poliomyelitis update (14): Israel, RFI 20220331.8702310. - Mod.MPP]

The finding landed Israel on the World Health Organization's Polio Eradication Initiative's list of countries with outbreaks, after being declared polio-free in 1988.

On Friday [10 Mar 2023], the State of New York's health department called for residents to get vaccinated against polio before traveling to Israel, warning of the recent diagnoses in the country. In a statement, the New York Department of Health called on New Yorkers "to get fully immunized" before flying to Israel or other countries with polio. [See Poliomyelitis update (11): cVDPV1 AFP, cVDPV2 AFP, Pakistan truck art, USA alert 20230311.8708880. Mod.MPP].

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Israel continues to struggle with pockets of unvaccinated individuals that support the circulation of polioviruses. In a nutshell, vaccine hesitancy is a real and disruptive process for disease eradication or just disease control. - Mod.MPP]

column3: At least 175 000 Israeli children have not been vaccinated against polio, a viral disease that mainly affects children and can cause disability, paralysis and death, according to a new assessment by the Health Ministry cited by Channel 12 on Monday [13 Mar 2023].Parents of children who have not been immunized were urged to take them to a local health center to receive the vaccine.Polio vaccinations are standard for children and are an effective preventive measure, but vaccine skepticism has recently enabled the disease to rear its head again.Earlier this month [March 2023], 4 children were diagnosed with the disease in the northern city of Safed, and the Health Ministry warned that there was evidence in recent months "of a spread of polio in many sewage systems in Israel." The ministry said at the time that it estimated that 150 000 Israeli children were unvaccinated against the virus, 25 000 fewer than Monday's [13 Mar 2023] figures. Three of the children became infected with the virus after being exposed to an 8-year-old girl in Safed who tested positive for the polio virus despite not having any symptoms. [the 8-year old had AFP; the 3 contacts were asymptomatic infections - Mod.MPP]The Health Ministry said it would continue to monitor and update the public, and encouraged people to maintain good hygiene practices to stymie any outbreak.Last March [2022], the 1st case of polio in 33 years was discovered in Israel, leading to a small outbreak and a vaccination drive to combat the disease. [There were 6 confirmed AFP cases plus 1 highly suspected. All were not vaccinated. The outbreak was associated with a cVDPV3. See Poliomyelitis update (14): Israel, RFI 20220331.8702310. - Mod.MPP]The finding landed Israel on the World Health Organization's Polio Eradication Initiative's list of countries with outbreaks, after being declared polio-free in 1988.On Friday [10 Mar 2023], the State of New York's health department called for residents to get vaccinated against polio before traveling to Israel, warning of the recent diagnoses in the country. In a statement, the New York Department of Health called on New Yorkers "to get fully immunized" before flying to Israel or other countries with polio. [See Poliomyelitis update (11): cVDPV1 AFP, cVDPV2 AFP, Pakistan truck art, USA alert 20230311.8708880. Mod.MPP].--Communicated by:ProMED[Israel continues to struggle with pockets of unvaccinated individuals that support the circulation of polioviruses. In a nutshell, vaccine hesitancy is a real and disruptive process for disease eradication or just disease control. - Mod.MPP]
column4: The Times of Israel, Global Polio Eradication Initiative/WHO, Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI)/World Health Organization (WHO)

column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - ECUADOR (03): (SANTO DOMINGO DE LOS TSÁCHILAS) FATAL, FLOODING, RAT INFESTATION
************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Sun 12 Mar 2023
Source: La Hora [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.lahora.com.ec/santo-domingo/una-mujer-muere-por-leptospirosis-en-santo-domingo/>


There are 54 registered cases [of leptospirosis] in Ecuador, as announced by the Ministry of Health.

An 18-year-old woman died of leptospirosis in the Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas province. There are 4 people receiving treatment, as announced by Francisco Ayala, provincial director of Health. According to Ayala, the 5 registered cases occurred in the Cristo Vive cooperative, specifically, on the road that leads to the Bellavista prison. They were infected on the Carnival holiday, when bathing in a pool in the sector.

The symptoms appeared 6 days ago, approximately, when they arrived at the health centers, where they underwent the corresponding tests. "Unfortunately, an 18-year-old girl died; her condition was complicated because, in addition to leptospirosis, she had other diseases. The others are stable.

Francisco Pérez, Undersecretary of Surveillance, Prevention and Health Control, indicated that leptospirosis is a disease that exists in Ecuador; however, in recent weeks, as a result of the winter season, cases have increased, reaching 54 in the country.

He said that the epidemic occurs in places where there is no [safe] drinking water, sewerage [the infrastructure that conveys sewage or surface runoff], and there is little environmental sanitation.

The provinces with the highest infections are: Guayas with 32 cases, Manabí with 9 and Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas with 5.

After receiving the results of the examinations, personnel from the Ministry of Health traveled to the area of origin of the epidemic, to carry out prevention campaigns and deliver medicines to about 190 people who had contact with the patients.

Ayala recommended [people in] Santo Domingo not to walk barefoot, or have contact with stagnant water, [and] always wash food [with uncontaminated water] to avoid getting infected.
 
So far, they have only registered 5 cases; they are waiting for more results to find out if the disease persists in other areas of Santo Domingo. 

The people who were confirmed as positive are between 17 to 20 years in age.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2]
Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: La Hora [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.lahora.com.ec/santo-domingo/aumentan-a-16-los-contagiados-con-leptospirosis/>

 
The number of people infected with leptospirosis have increased to 16. There are patients in intensive care units, apparently stable, while others are in hospital and in their homes.

The increase from 5 to 16 cases of people infected with leptospirosis prompted the authorities to activate the Technical Health Table, to take biosecurity measures and prevent the disease from spreading further.

The 11 new confirmed cases so far are from the cooperatives Cristo Vive and Rumiñahui, as well as from km 1 of Quevedo avenue, from whom samples tested positive.

Among the 1st 5 cases is that of the 18-year-old girl, who died and the infection was detected when the autopsy was performed.

There are patients in intensive care units (ICU) who are apparently stable, while others are hospitalized and in their homes. The Ministry of Public Health (MSP) continues to carry out epidemiological surveillance where cases have occurred.

Mayra Quiroz, municipal director of Environmental Management, maintained that after the alert issued by the MSP, they intensified the rat extermination campaign in the cooperative where the 1st outbreak occurred. The technicians arrived in several sectors with an insecticide that they placed in strategic places and that makes the rodent petrify. They also destroyed the burrows to prevent them from reproducing. The official said that this type of work is carried out every month, they intervene in health centers in urban and rural areas. The work is carried out in markets too, where these types of animals accumulate the most.

Likewise, he indicated that pets, such as dogs and cats, can also be infected with the disease and can be transmitting entities, for which reason he recommended that they be vaccinated.

The residents of Cristo Vive wait for the authorities to arrive in the sector, to try to exterminate the rodents that infest the area, especially in abandoned houses.

Ana Zambrano, a general practitioner, pointed out that a person who is infected with leptospirosis and is not treated quickly can die in less than 10 days. Diarrhea that occurs should be controlled with constant hydration. Those who present symptoms of high fever, headache, chills, red eyes, vomiting and diarrhea should immediately go to a health facility.

This disease is transmitted through skin contact with dirty or stagnant water, and with food contaminated by rodent urine.

It is recommended not to self-medicate, as it would be dangerous to health. 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[In addition to leptospirosis cases reported from the Ecuadoran province of Guayas (see previous ProMED posts Leptospirosis - Ecuador (02): (GY) flooding, garbage, rodent, dog 20230308.8708809 and Leptospirosis - Ecuador: (GY) floods 20230304.8708729), the news articles above report additional cases from Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas Province, which is located inland, north of Guayas. A map showing the location of these provinces can be found at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_Ecuador#/media/File:Ecuador,_administrative_divisions_-_es_-_colored.svg>.

Heavy rainfall in February 2023 caused freshwater flooding in multiple regions of Ecuador (<https://floodlist.com/america/ecuador-floods-february-2023>), but flooding is being compounded in Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas Province by an infestation of rats that excrete _Leptospira_ in their urine, contaminating the floodwater. A similar situation is occurring in Guayas Province. 

Many species of wild and domestic animals (including dogs, cattle, swine, and rats) are susceptible to chronic kidney infection with pathogenic _Leptospira_. Leptospirosis is usually acquired after contact of the skin or mucous membranes with the urine of infected animals or by contact with fresh water, wet soil, vegetation, or food that has been contaminated by the urine of leptospira-infected animals, especially rats. _Leptospira_ shed in the urine of chronically infected animals may survive in freshwater or moist soil for weeks to months. - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
Ecuador: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708984,8>]

[See Also:
Leptospirosis - Ecuador (02): (GY) flooding, garbage, rodent, dog 20230308.8708809
Leptospirosis - Ecuador: (GY) floods 20230304.8708729
2003
----
Leptospirosis - Ecuador (Manabi) 20030214.0385
1998
----
Leptospirosis - Ecuador (07) 19980709.1297
Leptospirosis - Ecuador 19980207.0232]

FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - TURKEY (03): (ZONGULDAK) LIVESTOCK, SEROTYPE SAT-2, SUSPECTED, WOAH, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*******************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1] Follow-up report (FUR) 1: Agri and Kars Provinces
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4959>


Türkiye - Foot and mouth disease virus (Inf. with) - Follow up report 1
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Submitted: 16 Mar 2023
Disease: Foot and mouth disease virus (Inf. with) 
Causal agent: Foot and mouth disease virus SAT2 
Start date: 3 Mar 2023

New outbreaks:

1. Location: Kars (province); Sarıkamış (district); Yayikli (village).
Start: 8 Mar 2023
Quantitative data summary:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and Disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Cattle / 2948 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0

2. Location: Agri (province); Merkez (district); Sagirtas (Village) 
Start: 13 Mar 2023
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and Disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Cattle / 147 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0

Total since the start of the FMD SAT-2 event:
3 Outbreaks (3 provinces)
Quantitative data summary:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and Disposed of / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Cattle / 4944 / 7 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0

[A map presenting the 3 accumulated outbreaks is available at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[According to Turkiye's immediate notification and FUR 1, 3 provinces have been affected since the start of the FMDV SAT-2 event, on 3 Mar 2023. These provinces, located in the east, border each other and neighboring countries, as follows: the provinces of Ağrı, bordering Iran to the east; Iğdır, bordering on its east Armenia, Azerbaijan (the area of Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic) and Iran; and Kars, bordering Armenia. In each province, one village was reported affected. Out of a total of 4944 susceptible cattle in the 3 provinces combined, 7 clinical cases are reported; no deaths. For an exotic FMD serotype, against which the domestic ruminant population is fully susceptible, this is a rather benign presentation of the event than expected, based on previous experience. - Mod.AS] 

******
[2] Zonguldak Province: media report
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: CNN Turk [in Turkish, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.cnnturk.com/turkiye/son-dakika-sap-hastaligi-hangi-illerde-goruldu-koyler-karantinaya-alindi-sat-2-virusu-nedir-zonguldakta-sap-virusu-alarmi>


Foot and mouth disease was detected in animals such as cows, sheep and goats in the pens and dairy farms in the districts of Ereğli, Alaplı, Kozlu, Gökçebey and the villages of the capital district center in Zonguldak. As a precautionary measure, Devrek district was included in the coverage and a total of 215 villages were quarantined. Provincial Directorate of Agriculture and Forestry teams started vaccination studies in the regions where the disease is seen.

Eastern Anatolia Livestock Market in Erzurum, Europe's largest animal market, was closed due to the FMDV SAT-2 spread.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[3] Zonguldak Province: media report
Date: Wed 15 Mar 2023
Source: Al Mashhad [in Arabic, machine trans., abridged, edited] 
<https://tinyurl.com/yw8bjfhs>


Turkiye isolates 215 villages due to foot-and-mouth disease outbreak
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Turkish authorities have announced the isolation of villages in the northern region of Zonguldak, due to the spread of the foot-and-mouth disease virus among animals.

Teams from the provincial Directorate of Agriculture and Forestry have begun vaccination studies in areas where the disease was found, according to local media reports.

The incubation period of the virus in the body of animals is up to 15 days. The disease leads to lowered milk production, eating disorder and high temperatures.

Foot-and-mouth disease is transmitted from one animal to another by various means, including feed.

The foot-and-mouth disease virus is not transmitted to humans through meat. 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Zonguldak Province, situated along the western Black Sea coast region of Turkiye (see <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zonguldak_Province>), is divided into 8 districts: Alaplı, Çaycuma, Devrek, Gökçebey, Ereğli, Kilimli, Kozlu and Zonguldak (capital district). According to the above media reports, 5 of the districts have been declared FMD-infected with the consequent measures applied. As a precautionary measure, a similar policy is being applied in a 6th district of the province, namely Dverek, which borders 3 neighboring provinces: Düzce to the southwest, Bolu to the south, and Karabük to the southeast. 

On 9 Mar 2023, the President of Turkiye's Chamber of Agriculture, İslam Yıldırım, was cited by Safak Gazete, stating, "Currently, foot and mouth disease is seen in animals in most parts of our country"; see also post number 20230310.8708855. Zonguldak Province is nearly 1000 km (620 mi) distant, as the crow flies, westwards from the 3 eastern provinces which have been, so far, officially reported as infected. Turkiye's interactive administrative map is available at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey>. 

Confirmation or otherwise on the FMD situation in Zonguldak will be welcomed. - Mod.AS

ProMED map:
Turkey: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708982,87>]

column2:
MEASLES UPDATE (14) : INDIA (MADHYA PRADESH, JHARKHAND) ARMENIA, WHO
********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] India
[A] Madhya Pradesh
[B] Jharkhand
[2] Armenia
[3] WHO

******
[1] India 
[A] Madhya Pradesh
Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: The Free Press Journal [edited]
<https://www.freepressjournal.in/bhopal/national-health-mission-adopts-fire-fighter-model-to-check-outbreak-of-measles-in-madhya-pradesh>


National Health Mission adopts 'fire fighter' model to check outbreak of measles in Madhya Pradesh
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
National Health Mission (NHM) has adopted the 'Fire fighter' approach to check the measles outbreak in the state. NHM officials said this year [2023] on National Immunization Day, which is going to be observed on 16 Mar 2023, the focus will be on checking measles spread as currently 4 districts in Madhya Pradesh have emerged as hotspots.

As many as 135 cases of measles have been reported across the state. Maximum cases have surfaced in Indore, Narsinghpur, Jabalpur and Burhanpur districts.
.
NHM director Dr Santosh Shukla said that they have adopted a 'fire fighter' model to check the spread of measles in a particular area. "We have pressed all forces in affected areas right from raising public awareness regarding vaccination, to vaccination and distribution of vitamin tablets to infected children. We handle situations from all corners as it is the need of the hour for our teams."

The day of 16 Mar is observed as Measles Immunization Day every year in order to raise awareness about this infection and the importance of vaccination to fight it. The firefighter model includes making public announcements to create awareness about the illness as people instead of visiting doctors take their infected children to temple, then we focus on vaccination and distribution of vitamin tablets to boost immunity among children, he added. 

He further said that public announcements are being made from places of worship like mosques, temples and gurudwaras. The parents are advised to consult doctors if the child shows symptoms of measles like fever, cold, cough with rashes. We make them understand that delay in medical treatment leads to complications and it deteriorates a child's health, said Shukla.

--
Communicated by: 
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts 

---
[B] Jharkhand
Date: Mon 13 Mar 2023
Source: News 9 Live [edited]
<https://www.news9live.com/health/measles-outbreak-in-jharkhand-expert-says-mmr-vaccine-provides-99-protection-against-disease-au2180-2074381>


Measles outbreak in Jharkhand: Expert says MMR vaccine provides 99% protection against disease
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Amid the rising concerns over the increase in measles cases in 9 districts of Jharkhand, the state government has decided to organise a special measles-rubella campaign for 5 weeks from 15 Apr 2023 in these districts.

Under the campaign, 4 562 492 children between the ages of 9 months and 15 years will receive the vaccine as part of the campaign. According to a WHO report, the maximum number of measles patients have been reported in Maharashtra, Jharkhand, Gujarat and Haryana.

They described how a record number of nearly 40 million children had missed at least one measles vaccine dose in 2021. The measles vaccine, which can be administered by itself or in combination with other vaccinations such as mumps and rubella to make up the MMR immunisation, is very effective. Most countries have a 2-dose schedule, with the 1st jab usually given at 12 months of age and the 2nd dose when the child is 4 years old.

MMR vaccines provide long-lasting protection
--------------------------------------------
Dr Hemlata Arora, a general physician and infectious diseases specialist with Nanavati Hospital in Mumbai, spoke with News9 about the importance and effectiveness of the MMR vaccination.

She said, "Measles, mumps, and rubella are the 3 illnesses that are known to occur commonly and for which vaccinations were developed years ago. Since all 3 of these vaccinations are live and have a similar formulation, they can be blended into one. Live vaccines mean they cannot be given in immunocompromised people."

The vaccine provides very high and long-lasting protection, and is a model example of the term "vaccine-preventable disease". The 2-dose schedule gives about 99% protection against measles infection. In developing countries where vaccine uptake is low, as many as 1 in 10 who get measles, die from it. In developed countries, deaths are overwhelmingly in unvaccinated people at a rate of around 1 in 1000 to 5000 measles cases.

Around 40 children died of measles across the country, out of whom 9 were from Jharkhand, as per reports. Of the 230 measles cases reported in the country, 120 were from Jharkhand.

The districts where the campaign will be carried out are Dumka, Pakur, Sahibganj, Godda, Jamtara, Deoghar, Dhanbad, Koderma and Giridih. Children who have been vaccinated before will be re-vaccinated.

Is MMR immunisation compromised due to the pandemic?
----------------------------------------------------
Scientists say low vaccine coverage rates had already resulted in preventable outbreaks of diseases like measles and polio. In March 2020, WHO and partners asked countries to suspend their polio eradication efforts amid the accelerating COVID-19 pandemic. There have since been dozens of polio epidemics in more than 30 countries.

As per a UN report, "This is particularly tragic as tremendous progress was made in the 2 decades before the COVID-19 pandemic to improve childhood vaccination rates globally." Dr Arora said the news was shocking but not surprising, noting that immunisation services are frequently an "early casualty" of major social or economic disasters. 

Dr Sumit Chakravarty, senior consultant, Paediatrics and Neonatology and head-NICU, Asian Institute of Medical Sciences in Faridabad said that one can still get complete immunisation even if there has been a delay.

There are many inoculations that are given at 1-and-a-half months, 2-and-a-half months and 3-and-a-half months. Unfortunately, these were missed because parents were scared to step out with their babies.

Diphtheria, tetanus, hepatitis B, measles, and polio vaccines were some that were missed. These are primary immunisations that are extremely important.

While it was not right to miss them, there is no cause of worry as they can be taken even now.

[Byline: Sneha Kumari]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[The day of 16 Mar is Measles Immunization Day. The impact of measles vaccination rates on disease transmission and outbreaks has been significant. High vaccination rates help in establishing herd immunity and prevent measles outbreaks. "When a significant portion of the population is vaccinated, the disease becomes less likely to spread, and hence protecting vulnerable individuals. However, a fall in vaccination rates may increase the risk of outbreaks, leading to serious health consequences. Therefore, it is important to maintain high vaccination rates to protect individuals and communities from measles," adds Dr Praveen Khilnani, Chairman, Pediatrics, Pediatric Pulmonology and Pediatric Critical Care, Paediatrics, Medanta, Gurugram.

(Barriers to establishment of herd immunity) include vaccine hesitancy, lack of access to healthcare, and misinformation about vaccines. Addressing these challenges requires a multifaceted approach that involves awareness, education, community engagement, and policy initiatives to increase vaccine uptake and promote public health," feels Dr Khilnani.

On Measles Immunization Day, it's important to emphasize the role of vaccination and address the concerns of the parents. On the other hand, parents should consult with their healthcare provider to understand the benefits of vaccination and to learn more about the safety and effectiveness of the measles vaccine. Getting vaccinated not only protects children but also helps to prevent the spread of measles in the community," signs off Dr Khilnani. (<https://www.news18.com/lifestyle/measles-immunization-day-2023-importance-of-measles-vaccination-for-your-kids-health-7302715.html>) - Mod.LK]

[2] Armenia
Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: Crisis24 [abridged, edited]
<https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2023/03/armenia-elevated-measles-activity-reported-in-armenia-in-march>


Armenia: Elevated measles activity reported in Armenia in March 2023
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Event
-----
Armenian health officials have reported elevated measles activity, with over 50 cases reported from 1 Jan to 13 Mar 2023. This is compared to the 15 cases reported nationwide in Armenia in 2022. Of the 50 reported cases, 44 were not vaccinated against measles, 4 were partially vaccinated with 1 dose, and 2 were fully vaccinated. The Armenian Ministry of Health has advised that parents should vaccinate their children if they missed any of their scheduled vaccinations. Unvaccinated direct contacts of confirmed cases should also get vaccinated. This report represents the most complete data available as of 14 Mar 2023.

Context
-------
Measles vaccination coverage in Armenia was estimated at 94% in 2020 and 2021, which falls within the 92-95% required to prevent wider community transmission. Armenia reported roughly 15 cases nationwide in 2022, no cases in 2021, and 2020.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from Google Alerts

******
[3] WHO
Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: WHO [edited]
<https://www.who.int/news/item/14-03-2023-message-by-the-director-of-the-department-of-immunization--vaccines-and-biologicals-at-who---march-2023>


Message by the Director of the Department of Immunization, Vaccines and Biologicals at WHO - March 2023
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In February [2023], we marked the revitalisation of the Measles and Rubella Initiative, under the new banner of the Measles and Rubella Partnership (MRP), together with UNICEF, US CDC, the American Red Cross, Gavi and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. The Measles and Rubella Initiative was launched in 2000: From 2000 to 2021, the annual number of estimated measles deaths decreased 83%. 

Then came the pandemic, and as a result of COVID and related disruptions, we have witnessed the worst continued backsliding in global immunization coverage in 30 years. Measles vaccination coverage has suffered, with the latest data indicating that 40 million children missed at least 1 dose of measles vaccine in 2021 alone. The goal of the MRP is to collaborate with countries and partners to achieve the Immunization Agenda 2030 (IA2030) target, to save another 50 million lives through access to essential vaccines by the end of 2030, with measles immunization contributing a large percentage.

The transition comes at a time when we need to work more closely than ever before, to address the majority of missed and unimmunized children born during 2019 and 2022. In 2021 alone, 25 million children missed at least 1 essential vaccine and 18 million children received no vaccines at all. Our action on immunization in the years leading to 2025 will shape how the story of the pandemic is written. If we fail, we will see tragedies like unprevented cervical cancer and increased child mortality, leading to more deaths in generations that should have been living longer. 

We commend the countries have made great strides in recovering immunization programmes during the height of the pandemic, while noting more remains to be done. Under the banner 'The Big Catch-up', WHO and partners, will coordinate a year-long global push to mobilize and amplify country plans and implementation for catching up on missed children, commitments and plans for catch up, recovery and strengthening. The sum of WHO and partners' year-long activities will be targeted to help achieve: (1) catch-up of individuals who missed out on vaccinations during the pandemic period (by 2023 and at latest by 2025); (2) immunization programme recovery to at least 2019 coverage levels (by 2023); and (3) immunization programme strengthening, to get back onto the 2030 trajectory (by 2023 and at latest by 2025). These efforts will mobilize and accelerate country commitments and plans for catch-up, restore and strengthening, while also mobilizing public support to vaccinate the millions of children and adolescents who have or will be missed, unless action is taken now.

World Immunization Week (WIW) on 24-30 Apr 2023, will be a foundational pillar in this year-long advocacy and communications push, 'The Big Catch-up', to recover lost progress in essential immunization through catch-up, recovery and programme strengthening efforts.
 
WHO will use the WIW 2023 platform to highlight successes from countries from the last few years, with a 'Week of Wins' programme of activities to inspire action by showcasing progress. The visual identity for WIW is being finalized and soon we will share with you the social media hashtags, toolkit, and assets. We anticipate the utility and adaptability of developed assets and cross sharing through the WHO website linking to assets, regional and country content, as well as an external WIW microsite to showcase WHO and partner activities.

During my recent visit to Kenya, I lauded the Ministry of Health's leadership for its resilience in sustaining immunization through COVID-19 and for the positive impact of the malaria vaccine, with nearly 400 000 children reached with the malaria vaccine in the country as of March 2023, resulting in a substantial reduction in severe malaria and a drop in child deaths. Kenya very recently launched an expansion of malaria vaccine delivery into new areas that will more than double the number of children with access to the life-saving vaccine. Across the 3 pilot countries of Ghana, Kenya, and Malawi more than 1.3 million children are protected by the malaria vaccine and more than 4.0 million doses have been administered. Demand for the vaccine is unprecedented with at least 28 countries expressing interest in applying for Gavi support to introduce the vaccine. Of these, 12 countries have submitted a formal application at the first opportunity in the January 2023 application round. The 3 pilot countries have already been approved by Gavi to receive vaccine support to maintain vaccination services in the pilot areas once the pilot programme ends at the end of 2023.

Kenya like many other countries is experiencing outbreaks and I had the opportunity to observe the campaign to mitigate the current cholera outbreak during my visit. Through our ongoing efforts and commitments for catch up, recovery and strengthening, we are amplifying the urgency to act. We must support countries to avoid multiple outbreaks of life-threatening diseases like cholera, diphtheria, measles, and yellow fever and to help every child catch up on their measles, polio, and other vaccines.

We commend the African Union (AU) for its leadership on 2 recent events, demonstrating political alignment and leadership on immunization recovery efforts and strengthening in Africa. We welcome the AU declaration on "Building momentum for routine immunization recovery in Africa" at the Heads of State Summit on 19 Feb 2023, in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The declaration can be found at <https://www.afro.who.int/media-centre/events/high-level-side-event-36th-ordinary-session-au-assembly-heads-state-and>.

In 2023, we will continue to implement our collective work on our portfolio of highest priority activities including HPV, measles, malaria and zero dose, towards securing the interruption of wild polio transmission, reducing zero dose and achieving measles control, while recognizing the need for immunization programme strengthening cannot be overstated.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from Google Alerts

[The pandemic has had a huge impact on the global immunization program that must now be addressed in haste. As stated above, "In 2021 alone, 25 million children missed at least 1 essential vaccine and 18 million children received no vaccines at all." It is crucial to try to regain the trajectory from prior to the pandemic to avoid future outbreaks.

"Apart from its direct effect on the body, which can be lethal, the measles virus also weakens the immune system and makes a child more vulnerable to other infectious diseases like pneumonia and diarrhea, including for months after the measles infection itself among those who survive. Most cases occur in settings that have faced social and economic hardships due to COVID-19, conflict, or other crises, and have chronically weak health system infrastructure and insecurity. ...

As countries work to respond to outbreaks of measles and other vaccine-preventable diseases, and recover lost ground, UNICEF and WHO, along with partners such as Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, the partners of the Measles & Rubella Initiative (M&RI), Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, and others are supporting efforts to strengthen immunization systems by:
• Restoring services and vaccination campaigns so countries can safely deliver routine immunization programmes to fill the gaps left by the backsliding;
• Helping health workers and community leaders communicate actively with caregivers to explain the importance of vaccinations;
• Rectifying gaps in immunization coverage, including identifying communities and people who have been missed during the pandemic;
• Ensuring that COVID-19 vaccine delivery is independently financed and well-integrated into overall planning for immunization services so that it is not carried out at the cost of childhood and other vaccination services;
• Implementing country plans to prevent and respond to outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases and strengthening immunization systems as part of COVID-19 recovery efforts." (<https://www.unicef.org/armenia/en/press-releases/unicef-and-who-warn-perfect-storm-conditions-measles-outbreaks-affecting-children>) - Mod.LK

column2:
ANTHRAX - RUSSIA (03): (CHUVASH) HUMAN, BOVINE SOURCE, FEED SUSPECTED, HUMAN VACCINATION
****************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: TASS [in Russian, machine trans., edited]
<https://tass.ru/obschestvo/17288323>


Rosselkhoznadzor announced the possible cause of the outbreak of anthrax in Chuvashia
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The probable cause of the outbreak of anthrax in Chuvashia was the illegal backyard slaughter of an illegally purchased animal. This is stated in the message from Rosselkhoznadzor [the Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance].

"During the investigation into the circumstances of the outbreak of anthrax in the Chuvash Republic, which is being conducted by the territorial department of the Rosselkhoznadzor together with the environmental prosecutor's office, the fact of illegal household slaughter in one of the private farms in the village of Staroye Aktashevo of a bull that is not registered with the veterinary service was established. According to the owner, the animal was purchased on the basis of an advertisement without veterinary accompanying documents. The bull was fed with grain of unknown origin," the report says.

According to the Rosselkhoznadzor, vaccination against anthrax was not carried out. The slaughter of the animal was carried out on 3 Mar 2023 due to the deterioration of its health. Veterinary and sanitary pre-slaughter examination was not carried out. Infection of people occurred through cuts on the hands during the processing of the carcass.

The department also noted that the resulting meat and skin were sold to unknown people. The office of the Rosselkhoznadzor turned to the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia for the Chuvash Republic to assist in the investigation of the origin of the animal and its movement history. At present, representatives of the Rosselkhoznadzor and the prosecutor's office are on an inspection trip to the personal subsidiary plot in which the specified animal was kept. According to the department, the introduction pathway of the anthrax pathogen and the circumstances of the sale of meat and meat products are being established.

According to the Rosselkhoznadzor, on 16 Mar 2023, an extraordinary meeting of the Government Emergency Anti-Epizootic Commission of the Chuvash Republic will be held to develop a set of measures to eliminate the focus of anthrax in the Tsivilsky municipal district of the Chuvash Republic. Rosselkhoznadzor reminded animal owners of their obligation to take economic and veterinary measures to ensure the prevention of animal diseases and the safety of animal products in veterinary and sanitary terms, to maintain livestock premises and facilities for storing feed and processing animal products in proper condition, and to prevent environmental pollution animal waste.

"Before the arrival of specialists from the State Veterinary Service of the Russian Federation, it is necessary to take measures to isolate animals suspected of having a disease. It is also mandatory to follow the instructions of specialists on taking measures to prevent animal diseases and combat these diseases," the message says.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2]
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: TASS [in Russian, machine trans., edited]
<https://tass.ru/obschestvo/17283319>


Chuvashia plans to purchase (human) anthrax vaccine
---------------------------------------------------
The Ministry of Health of Chuvashia plans to conclude a contract for the purchase of anthrax vaccine after the detection of cases of infection in the region. This was reported to TASS on Thursday [16 Mar 2023] by the press service of the republic.

"At the moment, work is underway to purchase anthrax vaccine. A contract for its supply is expected to be concluded in the near future," the agency's interlocutor said.

The press service specified that the vaccine will be intended for routine vaccinations of persons whose work is associated with an increased risk of anthrax infection. "They include agricultural workers, employees of livestock farms, slaughterhouses and meat processing plants, and tanneries. This category of persons also includes employees of wool washing factories, shops for the production of meat, bone meal and bone glue, and veterinarians," the agency's interlocutor added.

Chuvash Health Minister Vladimir Stepanov told TASS on Wednesday [15 Mar 2023] that 2 people in the republic were hospitalized with anthrax. They are in a moderate condition. According to the results of an epidemiological investigation, the cause of infection was contact with a butchered bull carcass.

As the head of Chuvash Republic, Oleg Nikolaev, reported, the source of anthrax infection in an animal could be poor-quality compound feed, which the owners most likely purchased from private individuals.

The administration of the Tsivilsky municipal district of Chuvashia, where those infected with anthrax live, reported to TASS that the veterinary service has not yet detected cases of infection in livestock in the district. There are no grounds for introducing quarantine yet. 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[3]
Date: Thu 16 Mar 2023
Source: TASS [in Russian, machine trans., edited]
<https://tass.ru/obschestvo/17282085>


No cases of anthrax have been detected among animals in Chuvashia
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Employees of the veterinary service did not find any cases of livestock infection in the Tsivilsky municipal district of Chuvashia, where 2 residents had hospitalized with this diagnosis. There are no grounds for introducing quarantine, Ruslan Sayfutdinov, spokesman for the head of the district administration, told TASS on Thursday [16 Mar 2023].

"Employees of the veterinary service are doing all the necessary work in their line, and at the moment there are no facts of anthrax disease in the territory of the Tsivilsky municipal district," the agency's interlocutor said.

He clarified that in the personal subsidiary plots of citizens, samples of feed, animal blood, and stomach contents had been taken and sent for examination. "Today [16 Mar 2023], there are no legal grounds for introducing quarantine in the settlement where patients with a confirmed diagnosis of anthrax live," Saifutdinov added.

According to him, information about the sale of infected meat is being checked by law enforcement agencies, all versions are being worked out. "Today [16 Mar 2023], there is no reason to talk about the risk for consumers, since all the necessary preventive measures have been taken. All services work in close coordination," the agency's interlocutor emphasized.

Sayfutdinov added that the residents of the municipal district who had been infected with anthrax were in a stable condition and their lives were not under threat. "Medical workers continue to monitor contact persons, and on the morning of 16 Mar 2023, there are no new cases of the disease," he said.

Chuvash Health Minister Vladimir Stepanov told TASS on Wednesday [15 Mar 2023] that 2 people had been hospitalized with anthrax in the republic. According to him, patients were in a state of moderate severity. On 15 Mar 2023, the press service of the Rospotrebnadzor administration in the republic reported that, according to the results of an epidemiological investigation, contact with a butchered bull carcass was the cause of infection. The head of Chuvash Republic, Oleg Nikolaev, said that the source of anthrax infection could be poor-quality feed, which the owners most likely purchased from private individuals. 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The Russian bureaucracy has produced a flood of words, but I will be brief.

To date (16 Mar 2023) the veterinary service has not found any other sick livestock and do not perceive the necessity to vaccinate the local livestock. So this infected bull was singular. That the authorities are pointing to it being purchased without permission suggests it might have come from an area under anthrax quarantine. So unless it arrived incubating disease it may have been a case of latent anthrax infection. These are known though seldom reported. A useful reference is: Robert S. Gainer, Gilles Vergnaud & Martin E. Hugh-Jones. 2020. A review of arguments for the existence of latent infections of _Bacillus anthracis_, and research needed to understand their role in the outbreaks of anthrax. Microorganisms 2020, 8, 800; doi:10.3390/microorganisms8060800.

That the authorities are organizing a human vaccination program is unusual as this is very expensive and ignores the fact that anthrax is primarily an animal disease which occasionally spills over into humans. Occupational exposure through hides, wool, or hair from infected animals is possible but rarely seen these days. Nowadays, human cases are from slaughtering dead sick livestock. If you vaccinate your livestock, which is straightforward, you prevent both animal and human cases.

If your recognition of this disease is primarily though human cases, you will be missing a large number of livestock outbreaks in which no people were infected and showed clinical signs. Speculatively the livestock outbreaks of anthrax are not being observed. In my experience one sees human cases in the order of 10 livestock outbreaks per single human case. Unexpected livestock deaths will be seen, but if they are not checked for anthrax, the disease goes unobserved.

They still have the possibility of the source of infection being from "poor quality compound feed" but the laboratory results of checking samples have not come in yet. - Mod.MHJ
