column3: No cases of anthrax have been detected among animals in Chuvashia-----------------------------------------------------------------Employees of the veterinary service did not find any cases of livestock infection in the Tsivilsky municipal district of Chuvashia, where 2 residents had hospitalized with this diagnosis. There are no grounds for introducing quarantine, Ruslan Sayfutdinov, spokesman for the head of the district administration, told TASS on Thursday [16 Mar 2023]."Employees of the veterinary service are doing all the necessary work in their line, and at the moment there are no facts of anthrax disease in the territory of the Tsivilsky municipal district," the agency's interlocutor said.He clarified that in the personal subsidiary plots of citizens, samples of feed, animal blood, and stomach contents had been taken and sent for examination. "Today [16 Mar 2023], there are no legal grounds for introducing quarantine in the settlement where patients with a confirmed diagnosis of anthrax live," Saifutdinov added.According to him, information about the sale of infected meat is being checked by law enforcement agencies, all versions are being worked out. "Today [16 Mar 2023], there is no reason to talk about the risk for consumers, since all the necessary preventive measures have been taken. All services work in close coordination," the agency's interlocutor emphasized.Sayfutdinov added that the residents of the municipal district who had been infected with anthrax were in a stable condition and their lives were not under threat. "Medical workers continue to monitor contact persons, and on the morning of 16 Mar 2023, there are no new cases of the disease," he said.Chuvash Health Minister Vladimir Stepanov told TASS on Wednesday [15 Mar 2023] that 2 people had been hospitalized with anthrax in the republic. According to him, patients were in a state of moderate severity. On 15 Mar 2023, the press service of the Rospotrebnadzor administration in the republic reported that, according to the results of an epidemiological investigation, contact with a butchered bull carcass was the cause of infection. The head of Chuvash Republic, Oleg Nikolaev, said that the source of anthrax infection could be poor-quality feed, which the owners most likely purchased from private individuals. --Communicated by:ProMED[The Russian bureaucracy has produced a flood of words, but I will be brief.To date (16 Mar 2023) the veterinary service has not found any other sick livestock and do not perceive the necessity to vaccinate the local livestock. So this infected bull was singular. That the authorities are pointing to it being purchased without permission suggests it might have come from an area under anthrax quarantine. So unless it arrived incubating disease it may have been a case of latent anthrax infection. These are known though seldom reported. A useful reference is: Robert S. Gainer, Gilles Vergnaud & Martin E. Hugh-Jones. 2020. A review of arguments for the existence of latent infections of _Bacillus anthracis_, and research needed to understand their role in the outbreaks of anthrax. Microorganisms 2020, 8, 800; doi:10.3390/microorganisms8060800.That the authorities are organizing a human vaccination program is unusual as this is very expensive and ignores the fact that anthrax is primarily an animal disease which occasionally spills over into humans. Occupational exposure through hides, wool, or hair from infected animals is possible but rarely seen these days. Nowadays, human cases are from slaughtering dead sick livestock. If you vaccinate your livestock, which is straightforward, you prevent both animal and human cases.If your recognition of this disease is primarily though human cases, you will be missing a large number of livestock outbreaks in which no people were infected and showed clinical signs. Speculatively the livestock outbreaks of anthrax are not being observed. In my experience one sees human cases in the order of 10 livestock outbreaks per single human case. Unexpected livestock deaths will be seen, but if they are not checked for anthrax, the disease goes unobserved.They still have the possibility of the source of infection being from "poor quality compound feed" but the laboratory results of checking samples have not come in yet. - Mod.MHJProMED map:Chuvash Republic, Russia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708980,395>]

column2:
MYCOBACTEROIDES ABSCESSUS - USA: (MA) FATAL, NOSOCOMIAL, FAULTY WATER PURIFICATION SYSTEM
*****************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 7 Mar 2023
Source: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News [edited]
<https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/antimicrobial-stewardship/multidrug-resistant-mycobacteria-outbreak-linked-water-purification>


A study published today in the Annals of Internal Medicine suggests a multidrug-resistant bacteria outbreak that killed three hospital patients was likely linked to a commercial water purification system.

The study describes a _Mycobacterium abscessus_ outbreak that occurred at Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital from March 2017 to October 2017. The outbreak involved four cardiac surgery patients--two who had bloodstream infections, one with a left ventricular assist device driveline infection, and one with a sternal wound infection. All four patients were treated with multi-agent anti-mycobacterial regimens, and three died. Whole-genome sequencing of _M. abscessus_ isolates from the four patients suggested the infections were closely related.

Investigation into the source of the outbreak led researchers from Brigham and Women's and Harvard Medical School to obtain cultures from sinks and showers in each of the patient's rooms as well as two ice and water machines on the cardiac surgery intensive care unit and a step-down unit. The specimens from the ice machines were both positive for high concentrations of mycobacteria, as were two additional ice machines on the care patients' floor. Direct DNA extraction from ice and water machine samples found an exact match to a gene present in the outbreak samples.

Our cluster demonstrates the risk for unintended consequences associated with systems designed to improve hospital water.
Further investigation revealed that a commercial water purifier with charcoal filters and an ultraviolet irradiation unit that filtered water for one of the hospital's three inpatient towers was depleting chlorine levels, which may have allowed mycobacteria present in the municipal water system (which provides water to the hospital) to colonize that building's ice and water machines. The machines were removed, as was the water purification system, and no additional cases have since been reported.

"Our cluster demonstrates the risk for unintended consequences associated with systems designed to improve hospital water, the predilection of ice and water machines for microbial contamination and the risk this poses to patients, as well as the potential importance of augmenting hospitals' water management programs to monitor and prevent mycobacterial infections in addition to _Legionella_," the study authors wrote.

[Byline: Chris Dall]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The citation and abstract for the journal article referenced in the news report above follow:
Klompas M, Akusobi C, Boyer J, et al. _Mycobacterium abscessus_ Cluster in Cardiac Surgery Patients Potentially Attributable to a Commercial Water Purification System. Published online 7 March 2023. <https://doi.org/10.7326/M22-3306>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"Abstract
----------
"Background
Nontuberculous mycobacteria are water-avid pathogens that are associated with nosocomial infections.
"Objective: To describe the analysis and mitigation of a cluster of _Mycobacterium abscessus_ infections in cardiac surgery patients.
"Design: Descriptive study.
"Setting: Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts.
"Participants: Four cardiac surgery patients.
"Intervention: Commonalities among cases were sought, potential sources were cultured, patient and environmental specimens were sequenced, and possible sources were abated.
"Measurements: Description of the cluster, investigation, and mitigation.
"Results: Whole-genome sequencing confirmed homology among clinical isolates. Patients were admitted during different periods to different rooms but on the same floor. There were no common operating rooms, ventilators, heater-cooler devices, or dialysis machines. Environmental cultures were notable for heavy mycobacterial growth in ice and water machines on the cluster unit, but little or no growth in ice and water machines in the hospital's other 2 inpatient towers or in shower and sink faucet water in any of the hospital's 3 inpatient towers. Whole-genome sequencing confirmed the presence of a genetically identical element in ice and water machine and patient specimens. Investigation of the plumbing system revealed a commercial water purifier with charcoal filters and an ultraviolet irradiation unit leading to the ice and water machines in the cluster tower but not the hospital's other inpatient towers. Chlorine was present at normal levels in municipal source water but was undetectable downstream from the purification unit. There were no further cases after high-risk patients were switched to sterile and distilled water, ice and water machine maintenance was intensified, and the commercial purification system was decommissioned.
"Limitation: Transmission pathways were not clearly characterized.
"Conclusion: Well-intentioned efforts to modify water management systems may inadvertently increase infection risk for vulnerable patients."

_Mycobacteroides (formerly _Mycobacterium) abscessus_ is a non-tuberculous mycobacterium (NTM). NTM are a grouping of acid-fast bacilli separate from the _M. tuberculosis_ complex (<http://www.cdc.gov/hai/organisms/mycobacterium.html>) that differ among themselves on the basis of in vitro growth rate, colonial pigmentation, and molecular diagnostics. Non-pigmented, rapidly growing NTM species (RGM) include the _Mycobacteroides chelonae-abscessus_ group and the_Mycolicibacterium [formerly _Mycobacterium] fortuitum_ complex. RGM produce mature growth on agar plates within 7 days of incubation. More slowly growing NTM include _Mycobacterium marinum_, _M. gordonae_, _M. kansasii_, and the _M. avium/intracellulare_ complex. Other slow growers include _M. ulcerans_, _M. haemophilum_, and _M. simiae_.

NTM are environmental mycobacteria, found in water and soil, which can form biofilms on the inner surfaces of water distribution systems and are resistant to chlorine (<https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpubh.2020.00190/full>), constituting a risk for certain people, for example, by microaspiration or by inhalation of aerosols. 

Biofilms form on the inner walls of dental unit waterlines because of the long, small-diameter tubing and low flow rates, resulting in bacteria, such as NTM and Legionella, in dental unit water systems used for irrigating surgical sites and creating aerosols that can be inhaled by the patients. Outbreaks of oro-maxillary and pulmonary infections due to _M. abscessus_ have consequently occurred after pulpotomies at pediatric dentistry (ProMED post Mycobacterium abscessus - USA: (CA) nosocomial, dental, child 20160918.4496529 and <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27054966/>). 
Ice machines are known to promote bacterial growth due to compressors warming the incoming water lines to the machine and this would be a particular concern in healthcare facilities (<https://www.ijmyco.org/article.asp?issn=2212-5531;year=2020;volume=9;issue=4;spage=347;epage=362;aulast=Millar>). For example, ice packs are commonly recommended as part of routine post-operative care following blepharoplasty. Atypical mycobacterium infections have been reported following this surgical procedure and one study demonstrated a significant reduction in the incidence of infection following blepharoplasty by substituting reusable gel packs for ice compresses after an isolated outbreak in North Carolina, suggesting contaminated ice as the source of infection (<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30124611/>). 
Contaminated water can also contaminate medications and medical instruments. Outbreaks of infections due to RGM have been related to subcutaneous injection of substances contaminated with the bacterium or through invasive medical procedures employing contaminated equipment or implanted devices. Infection can also occur after accidental injury where the wound is contaminated by soil. In addition, _M. abscessus_ is one of the mycobacteria most often isolated from cystic fibrosis patients. In immunocompromised patients, RGM can also cause disseminated infection.

_M. abscessus_ complex consists of 3 subspecies: _M. abscessus_ subsp. _abscessus_, subspecies _bolletii_, and subspecies _massiliense_. The erm(41) gene, which confers macrolide resistance through methylation of 23S ribosomal RNA, is present in the _M. abscessus_ complex group, but many strains of _M. abscessus_ subsp. _massiliense_ have a nonfunctional erm(41) gene, and because of this, the rate of macrolide susceptibility is higher in _M. abscessus_ subsp. _massiliense_ than in the other _M. abscessus_ subsp. (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4550155/>). Because macrolide-resistance can be inducible, strains of _M. abscessus_ initially susceptible can emerge resistant during macrolide therapy. Efflux pumps have also been shown to contribute to macrolide resistance in _M. abscessus_ (<https://www.dovepress.com/efflux-pumps-contribute-to-intrinsic-clarithromycin-resistance-in-clin-peer-reviewed-fulltext-article-IDR>).

_M. abscessus_ is also highly resistant to most beta-lactam antibiotics, likely due to its bacterial cell wall biochemistry and a broad-spectrum, chromosomal-encoded Ambler class A beta-lactamase (BlaMab) that is resistant to the beta-lactamase inhibitors clavulanate, tazobactam, and sulbactam (<https://academic.oup.com/jac/article/69/3/691/784297> and <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6167491/>). Of the beta-lactam subclasses, carbapenems have the greatest activity against _M. abscessus_, and among the carbapenems, imipenem has the most activity (<https://jcm.asm.org/content/54/6/1586>). Newer non-beta-lactam beta-lactamase inhibitors -- avibactam, relebactam (marketed with imipenem), and vaborbactam (marketed with meropenem) -- improve the activity of carbapenems against _M. abscessus_ (<https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-57844-8> and <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6395916/>). Combinations of different beta-lactam subclasses, such as amoxicillin plus imipenem/relebactam, may be required to fully inhibit peptidoglycan biosynthesis in _M. abscessus_ (<https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-57844-8>).

_M. abscessus_ isolates display in vitro resistance to most oral antibiotics and are generally susceptible to a limited number of parenteral agents, including tigecycline, imipenem, cefoxitin, and amikacin (<https://www.idsociety.org/practice-guideline/nontuberculous-mycobacterial-ntm-diseases/#toc-1>). Current (2020) therapeutic guidelines with respect to pulmonary _M. abscessus_ infection (<https://www.idsociety.org/practice-guideline/nontuberculous-mycobacterial-ntm-diseases/>) suggest multidrug therapy that includes at least 3 active drugs in the initial phase of treatment that often include amikacin and a beta-lactam--imipenem or cefoxitin (guided by in vitro susceptibility testing that includes detection of a functional or nonfunctional erm(41) gene). The duration of therapy, usually more than 12 months, depends on disease severity. Macrolides are very active in vitro against _M. abscessus_ strains without a functional erm(41) gene, and evidence supports their use in patients with disease caused by macrolide-susceptible _M. abscessus_. The 2020 ATS/IDSA guidelines also suggest treatment regimens should be designed in collaboration with experts in the management of these complicated infections. - Mod.ML

AVIAN INFLUENZA (50): AFRICA (SENEGAL) WILD, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, WOAH
*********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post

[1]
Date: Mon 13 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4964>


Senegal - influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 8 Mar 2023
Confirmed: 10 Mar 2023
Reported: 13 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 24 Feb 2022
Manifestation of disease: clinical disease
Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus
Serotype: H5N1
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, necropsy, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Parc national de la Langue de Barbarie, Saint Louis
Date of start of the outbreak: 8 Mar 2023
Epidemiological unit: natural park
Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Laridae (unidentified) (wild) / - / 637 / 637 / - / - / -
Affected population: the number of birds present in the national park is estimated at 8020.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species.
Epidemiological comments: the population affected with highly pathogenic avian influenza includes royal terns, sandwich terns, Caspian terns, grey-headed gulls, and cormorants.

Control measures at event level
Domestic control measures applied: surveillance outside the restricted zone; surveillance within the restricted zone; movement control; screening.
Wild control measures applied: surveillance outside the restricted zone; movement control; disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; surveillance within the restricted zone

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result

[Originally posted on 8 Mar 2023, a new outbreak of infections from _Salmonella_ of unknown origin has now sickened at least 47 people, but no other details have been released as of this afternoon [15 Mar 2023]. The outbreak of infections from _Salmonella [enterica_ serotype] Hartford was announced by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), but no information is yet available from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

The FDA did not report the ages or states of residence of the patients. However, the agency did report that it has begun traceback efforts, though it did not say what food or foods are being traced. - Mod.LL]

column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - FIJI: (NORTHERN)
********************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 15 Mar 2023
Source: RNZ [edited]
<https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/486011/pacific-news-in-brief-for-march-15>


In Fiji, there has been a surge in leptospirosis cases in the provinces of Macuata and Bua in the Northern Division.

Leptospirosis is a bacterial disease with symptoms including high fever, headache, chills, muscle aches, vomiting, jaundice, and abdominal pain. It is spread through the urine of infected animals.

The Ministry of Health and Medical Services said between 1 Jan 2023 and 26 Feb 2023, there were 171 cases.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[For a discussion of leptospirosis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED post Leptospirosis - Fiji: fatal, flood-related 20220215.8701482

The news report above says that the region worst hit by leptospirosis in 2023 has been the Northern Division.

The usual sources of leptospirosis in Fiji have been attributed to flooding with fresh water following heavy rainfall (see also's below). Fiji's wet season is from November to April, with the heaviest rains falling between December and mid-April (<https://www.tourismfiji.com/fiji-weather.html>).

Fiji is an island nation in Melanesia in the South Pacific Ocean about 2000 km (1300 mi) northeast of New Zealand's North Island (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiji>). Fiji is divided into 4 major divisions: Central, Eastern, Northern, and Western. The Northern Division (island of Vanua Levu) has 3 provinces: Bua (located in the west of the northern island of Vanua Levu), Cakaudrove (located in the south-eastern third of the island of Vanua Levu], and Macuata (located in the north-eastern 40 percent of the island of Vanua Levu). A map of Fiji showing the location of provinces on Vanua Levu can be found at <https://tinyurl.com/yhj4atmz>. - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
Northern Division, Fiji: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708967,58439>]

column2:
BLACK SIGATOKA, BANANA AND PLANTAIN - DOMINICA
**********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 8 Mar 2023
Source: Dominica News Online [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://dominicanewsonline.com/news/homepage/government-tackles-black-sigatoka-on-island/>


The Government of Dominica is reviewing the treatment for black sigatoka (BS). The disease was first detected in Dominica in July 2012. A banana and plantain unit was established at the Ministry of Agriculture to deal with challenges from BS and to ensure a satisfactory level of production.

A team is currently going around spraying for BS, but plans are to equip and train farmers to do their own spraying. Field sanitation, nutrients for crops, and other cultural practices are also essential for proper management of the disease.

In 2017, Dominica welcomed a team of French technicians to advise on methods to combat the fungus affecting the country's banana crops. The objective of the cooperation is to control BS, as well as to reduce the use of pesticides. The French team proposed a series of trials on approaches to fight BS so that crops can be sold and exported on local, regional, and international levels.

--
Communicated by:
FreshPlaza
<https://www.freshplaza.com>

[Black sigatoka (BS), also known as black leaf streak, is caused by the fungus _Pseudocercospora fijiensis_ (previously _Mycosphaerella fijiensis_). It only affects species and hybrids of _Musa_, which include bananas and plantains (cooking bananas). Worldwide, BS is one of the most devastating leaf diseases of bananas, with yield losses of 50% or more. It is present in the Americas, China, Southeast Asia, and parts of Africa. Infection occurs on the youngest leaves of the plant; older leaves are not readily infected. BS seriously affects photosynthetic ability and plant vigour. Fruit can ripen prematurely during commercial shipment, causing further losses.

The fungus is spread by water and wind and with contaminated materials (including suckers for planting). Disease management may include frequent applications of fungicides, phytosanitary measures to reduce inoculum, as well as cultural practices. However, high costs of some measures may make them unavailable to smallholders. Furthermore, resistances to frequently used fungicides have been reported as emerging in different global populations (see link below). Use of agrochemicals may also cause problems for fruit export, for example to Europe. BS is another example of a warm climate disease spreading due to global climate change (see links below).

Related fungi cause yellow sigatoka (YS; sigatoka leaf spot; _P. musae_) and eumusa leaf spot (_P. eumusae_). Symptoms and epidemiology are similar for all 3. YS is more adapted to cooler temperatures; less damage is caused to photosynthetic tissue. There are more crop cultivars with degrees of resistance to YS than to BS.

BS (and also YS) has been causing serious crop losses in the Caribbean and continues to spread there, despite some national quarantine measures (e.g., ProMED post 20100204.0381). This would suggest that a regional approach is likely to be the best control option, especially since wind-borne spores may spread between neighbouring islands.

column2:
TOMATO BROWN RUGOSE FRUIT VIRUS - CANADA: (ONTARIO)
***************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: HortiDaily [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://www.hortidaily.com/article/9511502/tobrfv-affects-southwestern-ontario-tomato-crops/>


First detected in Canada in 2019 in Ontario, _Tomato brown rugose fruit virus_ (ToBRFV) hit hard again throughout the last 2022/23 growing season in southwestern Ontario tomato crops, leading to yield losses and the destruction of large amounts of produce. Glasshouse growers are struggling to develop a tomato variety resistant to this fast-spreading virus. ToBRFV is a global issue that can quickly affect yields and farming operations.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[_Tomato brown rugose fruit virus_ (ToBRFV) was recently identified as a new member of the genus _Tobamovirus_ (type member _Tobacco mosaic virus_, TMV) in Jordan and soon after in Israel (see update links below). Since then, it has also been reported from Europe and the Mediterranean region, where it continues to spread (see links below), as well as from North America and China. It was shown to also affect capsicum and has been detected in both plants and seeds of both crops. ToBRFV symptoms on tomato vary depending on host cultivar but may include chlorosis, mottling, mosaic, and crinkling (rugosis) on leaves; necrotic spots on petioles and calyces; and yellowish mottling, brown spots, and rugosis on fruit to make them unmarketable. On capsicum, leaf symptoms are similar; fruits may be deformed with yellow mottling or green stripes. Almost 100% incidence was reported for some outbreaks in tomato, but not every fruit on an infected plant may show symptoms.

ToBRFV (like many tobamoviruses) is seed transmitted and can also be spread by mechanical means, contaminated equipment, as well as with plant or other materials. It is very stable and can remain infectious for months outside a host. Recently, bumblebees, which are used widely as commercial pollinators in glasshouse tomato production, have been shown to be effective vectors of ToBRFV (see link below). Volunteer crop plants and solanaceous weed species are likely pathogen reservoirs. The Tm-22 resistance gene used in some tomato cultivars to protect from other tobamoviruses (such as _Tomato mosaic virus_) does not appear to be effective against ToBRFV. Disease management relies mainly on exclusion but may include phytosanitation (disinfecting tools, removing crop debris) and control of virus reservoirs. Use of certified clean seeds or crop transplants is crucial. Research on possible seed treatments to eliminate the virus is being carried out (see link below). Tomato seeds are traded widely and are known to pose a risk of spreading viruses and other pathogens internationally (e.g., ProMED post 20140122.2222560).

Coinfection of ToBRFV with _Pepino mosaic virus_ (genus _Potexvirus_) and _Tomato spotted wilt virus_ (genus _Orthotospovirus_) have been found in tomato (ProMED posts 20191029.6751082, 20200507.7307615). It is thought that the respective symptoms may have been due to either virus or synergism. Further research is needed to clarify a potential role of ToBRFV in coinfections and to determine whether its presence in coinfections may have led to earlier cases of misdiagnosis and delayed identification of this new virus.

Maps
Canada (with provinces):
<http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png>

Pictures
ToBRFV on tomato:
<https://gd.eppo.int/media/data/taxon/T/TOBRFV/pics/1024x0/4137.jpg> and
<https://gd.eppo.int/media/data/taxon/T/TOBRFV/pics/1024x0/4138.jpg>

column3: First detected in Canada in 2019 in Ontario, _Tomato brown rugose fruit virus_ (ToBRFV) hit hard again throughout the last 2022/23 growing season in southwestern Ontario tomato crops, leading to yield losses and the destruction of large amounts of produce. Glasshouse growers are struggling to develop a tomato variety resistant to this fast-spreading virus. ToBRFV is a global issue that can quickly affect yields and farming operations.--Communicated by:ProMED[_Tomato brown rugose fruit virus_ (ToBRFV) was recently identified as a new member of the genus _Tobamovirus_ (type member _Tobacco mosaic virus_, TMV) in Jordan and soon after in Israel (see update links below). Since then, it has also been reported from Europe and the Mediterranean region, where it continues to spread (see links below), as well as from North America and China. It was shown to also affect capsicum and has been detected in both plants and seeds of both crops. ToBRFV symptoms on tomato vary depending on host cultivar but may include chlorosis, mottling, mosaic, and crinkling (rugosis) on leaves; necrotic spots on petioles and calyces; and yellowish mottling, brown spots, and rugosis on fruit to make them unmarketable. On capsicum, leaf symptoms are similar; fruits may be deformed with yellow mottling or green stripes. Almost 100% incidence was reported for some outbreaks in tomato, but not every fruit on an infected plant may show symptoms.ToBRFV (like many tobamoviruses) is seed transmitted and can also be spread by mechanical means, contaminated equipment, as well as with plant or other materials. It is very stable and can remain infectious for months outside a host. Recently, bumblebees, which are used widely as commercial pollinators in glasshouse tomato production, have been shown to be effective vectors of ToBRFV (see link below). Volunteer crop plants and solanaceous weed species are likely pathogen reservoirs. The Tm-22 resistance gene used in some tomato cultivars to protect from other tobamoviruses (such as _Tomato mosaic virus_) does not appear to be effective against ToBRFV. Disease management relies mainly on exclusion but may include phytosanitation (disinfecting tools, removing crop debris) and control of virus reservoirs. Use of certified clean seeds or crop transplants is crucial. Research on possible seed treatments to eliminate the virus is being carried out (see link below). Tomato seeds are traded widely and are known to pose a risk of spreading viruses and other pathogens internationally (e.g., ProMED post 20140122.2222560).Coinfection of ToBRFV with _Pepino mosaic virus_ (genus _Potexvirus_) and _Tomato spotted wilt virus_ (genus _Orthotospovirus_) have been found in tomato (ProMED posts 20191029.6751082, 20200507.7307615). It is thought that the respective symptoms may have been due to either virus or synergism. Further research is needed to clarify a potential role of ToBRFV in coinfections and to determine whether its presence in coinfections may have led to earlier cases of misdiagnosis and delayed identification of this new virus.MapsCanada (with provinces):<http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/Canada_Provinces_and_territories_map.png>PicturesToBRFV on tomato:<https://gd.eppo.int/media/data/taxon/T/TOBRFV/pics/1024x0/4137.jpg> and<https://gd.eppo.int/media/data/taxon/T/TOBRFV/pics/1024x0/4138.jpg>ToBRFV symptoms on capsicum:<https://www.naktuinbouw.nl/sites/default/files/news/20100623_M_0275.jpg> and<https://agriculture.vic.gov.au/__data/assets/image/0009/555759/TOBRFV_figure-5.jpg>LinksInformation and characterisation of ToBRFV:<https://gd.eppo.int/taxon/TOBRFV> (with distribution and host list),<https://doi.org/10.1007/s00705-015-2677-7> (Jordan),<https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0170429> (Israel) and via<https://www.semanticscholar.org/topic/Tomato-brown-rugose-fruit-virus/3579397>ToBRFV spread:<https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0282441> (new reservoir hosts) and<https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0210871> (by pollinators)Tomato resistance breeding:<https://www.hortidaily.com/article/9265808/we-can-eradicate-tobrfv-from-the-tomato-industry-with-our-newly-found-resistance/> and<https://www.hortidaily.com/article/9272889/commercial-tomato-variety-with-tobrfv-resistance-to-be-offered-in-early-2021/>ToBRFV seed treatment:<https://doi.org/10.1007/s10658-020-02151-1>Recent ToBRFV updates. Europe:<https://gd.eppo.int/reporting/article-7531> (1st report Slovakia, ex Austria) and<https://www.hortidaily.com/article/9507097/thirteen-new-tobrfv-infections-in-the-netherlands/> (1st at seed production and breeding site)International spread of tobamoviruses by seeds (review):<https://doi.org/10.5772/intechopen.70244>Virus taxonomy via:<https://ictv.global/taxonomy>- Mod.DHA]

column2:
LUMPY SKIN DISEASE - ASIA (03): INDONESIA, CATTLE, SPREAD, FAO
**************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 15 Mar 2023
Source: EUFMD/EMPRES symposium lumpy skin disease [LSD] webcast [abridged, edited]
<http://www.fao.org/webcast/home/en/item/6118/icode/>


[The European Commission for the Control of Foot-and-Mouth Disease (EuFMD) and FAO's Emergency Prevention System (EMPRES) launched on Tuesday [14 Mar 2023] the symposium "Lumpy Skin Disease: How science can support disease management and control."  The hybrid meeting (virtual and in FAO headquarters, Rome) is being held 14-16 Mar 2023.

Here we present some of the data presented by Indonesia, LSD's most recently infected country. The presentation took place during the 2nd day of the event, Wed 15 Mar 2023. - Mod.AS]

1. Monthly number of new LSD outbreaks/cases since the start of the event:
2022: February 58/152, March 107/211, April 377/900, May 584/2951, June 702/5193, July 223/1330, August 567/1744, September 438/1563, October 247/778, November 327/1510, December 352/1171. 2023: January 1700/4315, February 2396/7168 (updated 27 Feb 2023).
2. Monthly number of vaccinations since the start of the project:
2022: March 6370, April 16 367, May 6847, June 4926, July 3650, August 2956, September 17 124, October 16 611, November 74 526, December 55 951. 2023: January 33 501, February 10 367.

Vaccinations: The vaccinations started March 2022. Total number of doses, applied in 9 provinces as of 27 Feb 2023, is 249 196 (updated 27 Feb 2023).

3. Recently, reported LSD cases are increasing, especially when it spread to Java Island where most of the susceptible population is present.

4. Main challenges encountered:
- Extensive animal farming system
- Illegal animal movement
- Limited number of officers to implement vaccination
- High workload for FMD control activities (vaccination, animal identification), affecting the LSD control.
[For each of the above, recommended solutions were presented.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[LSD's 1st detection in Indonesia was located in central Sumatra, in March 2022. In September 2022, LSD was confirmed near Semarang in Central Java. On 8 Dec 2022, Australian sources reported its spread to East Java, including the environs of Malang, the capital of Java's main dairy district. The spread of LSD to Java, synchronic with the spread of foot-and-mouth disease, are a matter of grave concern for Australia. The Australian government and industry support Indonesia's efforts to contain both murrains.

During the 1st 2 days of the above meeting, the following sessions were held:
1. Current status and advances in epidemiological knowledge on LSD;
2. Combatting LSD in different farming scenarios (transmission pathways and risk monitoring and challenges).

Tomorrow's (Thu 16 Mar 2023) sessions are dedicated to the following issues:
Session 1: Vaccines and vaccination strategies (3 papers);
Session 2: Diagnostics (6 papers); final recommendations and conclusions.

The agenda of the meeting is available at <https://www.fao.org/3/cc4866en/cc4866en.pdf>. - Mod.AS

column2:
ANTHRAX - RUSSIA (02): (CHUVASH) HUMAN, BOVINE SOURCE, SUSPECT FEED
*******************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 15 Mar 2023
Source: en.newizv.ru [edited]
<https://en.newizv.ru/news/2023-03-15/the-source-of-anthrax-infection-has-been-identified-in-chuvashia-400923>


The press service of the Department of Rospotrebnadzor for the Chuvash Republic revealed the source of infection of 2 people with anthrax. According to the regional department, the cause of infection was contact with raw meat when butchering a bull carcass.

"Samples of environmental objects were taken to determine the source of infection, pathways and transmission factors. According to the results of the epidemiological investigation, the cause of infection was contact with animal raw materials -- a butchered carcass of a bull. Disinfection was carried out in the hearth, medical supervision of contact persons was established," -- is stated in the message on the website of Rospotrebnadzor for Chuvashia.

Earlier, the governor of the republic reported 2 detected cases of anthrax infection. He noted that the patients were hospitalized in moderate severity and their lives are not in danger. No infected people have been identified among those who came into contact with them, but they are all under medical supervision.

Earlier, the Telegram channel Mash reported that those infected were a married couple. According to the source, the husband became infected when he injured his hand while cutting a bull. It is also noted that about 500-600 kg (1100-1320 lb) of meat managed to be sold.

"Presumably to gypsies on the highway. Where they migrated to, whether they stayed in the region, and where half a ton of meat with anthrax is now is unknown," - Mash reports.

According to the publication, the infection of livestock occurred through purchased feed, the origin of which is being investigated by the Rosselkhoznadzor.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Two lessons from this Russian outbreak:
1. Never dismiss cutaneous anthrax lesions. They can turn nasty and do in around 19% of cases. They respond very well to antibiotic treatment.
2. Thanks to bovine spongiform encephalopathy, we see very few livestock cases these days from bone meal and such, but it is still possible, and Russia has reported outbreaks from bone meal in the past. Though rare, outbreaks have occurred through contaminated silage and hay. Chuvashia is off on its own, and present-day regulations might not be as strictly observed as elsewhere in Russia. This province reports very few anthrax outbreaks; therefore, it might be missing them when they occur, and dead animals could go for rendering and the bones end up in bone meal. The source is under investigation, and we should hear in due course what they find out. - Mod.MHJ

Chuvash Republic, Russia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708955,395>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (49): AMERICAS (CHILE) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, WOAH
***************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 15 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4966>


Chile - High pathogenicity avian influenza viruses (poultry)
------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 10 Mar 2023
Confirmed: 13 Mar 2023
Reported: 14 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: 1st occurrence in a zone or a compartment
Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI)
Serotype: H5N1
Detailed characterization: Clade: 2.3.4.4b - Lineage: reassortment Eurasian and North American
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Rubiana 1, Rancagua, Cachapoal, Libertador General Bernardo O'Higgins
Started: 10 Mar 2023
Epidemiological unit: farm
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 41 378 / 541 / 511 / 40 867 / 0 / 0
Affected population: this is an epidemiological unit (sector) with 19-week-old broiler breeders.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: in the epidemiological unit, mortality began to increase slightly on 10 Mar 2023 (0.34%), increasing on 11 Mar 2023 (0.65%). On 12 Mar 2023, there was a greater increase than on the previous days (3.16%), and the company notified the SAG. The SAG confirms avian influenza type A by PCR Matrix type A on day 12 at 22:00 hours. The stamping out begins the same night of 12 Mar 2023. On 13 Mar 2023, highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 is confirmed by PCR and sequencing. The stamping out of all birds in the epidemiological unit ends on the evening of 13 Mar 2023. Two zones have been established, an infected zone of 3 kilometers (1.86 mi) and a surveillance zone of 7 kilometers (4.35 mi), to complete a radius of 10 kilometers (6.21 mi) around the outbreak. Within these zones, the sanitary measures described in the current avian influenza contingency plan will be applied. Poultry and backyard (non-poultry) establishments will be included in the surveillance. This sanitary event is related to event 4775 in wild birds (from December 2022) and backyard birds (non-poultry) (February 2023), which is still ongoing in the country.

Control measures at event level
To be applied in domestic animals: Surveillance outside the restricted zone; screening; stamping out; traceability; surveillance within the restricted zone; disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; zoning; movement control; quarantine; disinfestation; process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products; official destruction of animal products
To be applied in wild animals: surveillance outside the restricted zone; screening; control of wildlife reservoirs; surveillance within the restricted zone; selective killing and disposal

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Result date / Result
Lo Aguirre Laboratory, Agricultural and Livestock Service (SAG) / birds / 1 / gene sequencing / 13 Mar 2023 / positive
Lo Aguirre Laboratory, Agricultural and Livestock Service (SAG) / birds / 1 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 13 Mar 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above. - Mod.CRD]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[This report complements the information published in ProMED post 20230314.8708926.

Detailed information and updates on avian influenza in Chile can be found at <https://www.sag.gob.cl/ia> (in Spanish). - Mod.CRD

column3: Chile - High pathogenicity avian influenza viruses (poultry)------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 10 Mar 2023Confirmed: 13 Mar 2023Reported: 14 Mar 2023Reason for notification: 1st occurrence in a zone or a compartmentCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI)Serotype: H5N1Detailed characterization: Clade: 2.3.4.4b - Lineage: reassortment Eurasian and North AmericanNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Rubiana 1, Rancagua, Cachapoal, Libertador General Bernardo O'HigginsStarted: 10 Mar 2023Epidemiological unit: farmAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 41 378 / 541 / 511 / 40 867 / 0 / 0Affected population: this is an epidemiological unit (sector) with 19-week-old broiler breeders.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: in the epidemiological unit, mortality began to increase slightly on 10 Mar 2023 (0.34%), increasing on 11 Mar 2023 (0.65%). On 12 Mar 2023, there was a greater increase than on the previous days (3.16%), and the company notified the SAG. The SAG confirms avian influenza type A by PCR Matrix type A on day 12 at 22:00 hours. The stamping out begins the same night of 12 Mar 2023. On 13 Mar 2023, highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 is confirmed by PCR and sequencing. The stamping out of all birds in the epidemiological unit ends on the evening of 13 Mar 2023. Two zones have been established, an infected zone of 3 kilometers (1.86 mi) and a surveillance zone of 7 kilometers (4.35 mi), to complete a radius of 10 kilometers (6.21 mi) around the outbreak. Within these zones, the sanitary measures described in the current avian influenza contingency plan will be applied. Poultry and backyard (non-poultry) establishments will be included in the surveillance. This sanitary event is related to event 4775 in wild birds (from December 2022) and backyard birds (non-poultry) (February 2023), which is still ongoing in the country.Control measures at event levelTo be applied in domestic animals: Surveillance outside the restricted zone; screening; stamping out; traceability; surveillance within the restricted zone; disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; zoning; movement control; quarantine; disinfestation; process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products; official destruction of animal productsTo be applied in wild animals: surveillance outside the restricted zone; screening; control of wildlife reservoirs; surveillance within the restricted zone; selective killing and disposalDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Result date / ResultLo Aguirre Laboratory, Agricultural and Livestock Service (SAG) / birds / 1 / gene sequencing / 13 Mar 2023 / positiveLo Aguirre Laboratory, Agricultural and Livestock Service (SAG) / birds / 1 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 13 Mar 2023 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above. - Mod.CRD]--Communicated by:ProMED[This report complements the information published in ProMED post 20230314.8708926.Detailed information and updates on avian influenza in Chile can be found at <https://www.sag.gob.cl/ia> (in Spanish). - Mod.CRDProMED map:Chile: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708954,7>]

column2:
MALARIA - PANAMA: INCREASE
**************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: Prensa Latina [in Spanish, trans., edited]
<https://www.elpais.cr/2023/03/14/panama-intensifica-acciones-ante-auge-de-malaria/>


Panamanian health authorities today [14 Mar 2023] intensify preventive actions to combat malaria, given the worrying rise in cases. Reports from the Department of Epidemiology of the Ministry of Health (Minsa) indicate that as of 7 Mar 2023, a total of 1922 cases of malaria were recorded in the country, a disease caused by the _Plasmodium_ parasite and transmitted by the _Anopheles_ mosquito.

The reason for the increase in patients is multifactorial, but above all is a result of a decrease in compliance with the programs caused by the confinement that COVID-19 forced, according to the Minsa. As a result of the health crisis since 2020, it was not possible to recruit on personal time, or to acquire the supplies, because the budget was allocated to the contingency due to the pandemic.

The researcher and entomologist Lorenzo Cáceres explained to the press that in the last 10 years until 2018 an annual average of 646 cases of malaria were reported, but from 2019 to date an annual average of 3764 has been registered.

Cáceres opined that the increase is also due to the change in the insecticide fenitrothion, which according to a recent study by the Gorgas Institute was killing 80% of mosquitoes up to the 5th month of its application. That insecticide was replaced in 2018 by sumishield, which was not previously evaluated.

In this sense, the Executive adopted other measures such as the creation last January of an operation center against malaria, that is, an intersectoral table led by the Minister of Health, Luis Francisco Sucre, for the management of the disease. In addition, to reduce the risk of cases, bed nets and hammocks have been delivered to the native communities of Wacuco, Río Rubén, Igarwala and Tortí Medio abajo.

Most malaria cases are registered in the Guna Yala region, Darién, Ngäbe Buglé region and eastern Panama. Epidemiology reports show that last year [2022] there were more than double the number of malaria cases than in 2021, since 7112 were reported, that is, 3469 more than in 2021, when the figure was 3643.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2]
Date: Sun 12 Mar 2023
Source: Fundacionio.com [in Spanish, trans., edited]
<https://fundacionio.com/malaria-en-panama-5/>


Health authorities in Panama have reported 1915 cases of malaria so far in 2023. Guna Yala presents the highest number, 788, and Ngäbe Buglé with 351. By provinces, Darién has had 571 cases and Panama East, 102 cases.

Some figures (Source: World Malaria Report)
-------------------------------------------
4% of the population lives in malaria-risk areas
2022: 6087 cases notified (January-December)
2021: 4585 cases
2018: 715 cases
2017: 689 cases
2016: 769 cases
2013: 874 cases
2004: 4912 cases

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[In the WHO Region of the Americas, as well as worldwide, there has been a marked increase in malaria cases and deaths since 2019, and much of this is attributable to disruptions in malaria prevention, diagnosis, and treatment caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (WHO World Malaria Report 2021; <https://www.who.int/teams/global-malaria-programme/reports/world-malaria-report-2021>). The Panama Ministry of Health (MINSA) registered 6087 cases of malaria in 2020, more than any prior year since 2000.

As discussed in the most recent post about malaria in Panama (below in the See Also section), Guna Yala has the highest incidence of malaria of any region in Panama, even though it has one of the lowest populations. This may be due in part to its long coastline and other climactic conditions, but it is also a relatively remote autonomous region where access to health services is limited.

For a map of the provinces of Panama, see <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_Panama>. -Mod.LXL

column2:
YELLOW FEVER - AMERICAS (03): BRAZIL (MINAS GERAIS)
***************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023 19:37 BRT
Source: G1 [in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY, edited]
<https://g1.globo.com/mg/sul-de-minas/noticia/2023/03/14/febre-amarela-monte-santo-de-minas-tem-morte-pela-doenca-confirmada-pelo-estado.ghtml>


The Minas Gerais State Health Secretariat (SES-MG) confirmed a death due to yellow fever in Monte Santo de Minas (MG). The death from the disease in the city was reported by the state this Tuesday [14 Mar 2023].

According to SES-MG, the victim is a 41-year-old man [vaccinated? - Mod. RNA], a rural worker, who died on 23 Feb 2023. Confirmation of death from yellow fever occurred after a positive test was done by the Ezequiel Dias Foundation (Funed) and [results] were received by SES-MG this Tuesday [14 Mar 2023].

With the confirmation of a fatal case in the state, SES-MG announced that there will be an epidemiological investigation to determine the probable site of infection, whether it was exported from São Paulo or indigenous to Minas Gerais. SES also pointed out that there will be a meeting to align actions with municipalities and regional health units in Passos and Alfenas to delineate the actions that will be developed with the support of the state. In addition, SES said it will intensify the actions of immunization to increase vaccination coverage against yellow fever.

On 27 Jan 2023, the state of São Paulo recorded the 1st confirmed case of yellow fever since 2020. This case was in a 73-year-old man, a resident of a rural area in the municipality of Vargem Grande do Sul in the interior of São Paulo.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED
via
ProMED-PORT

[At the end of 2022, ProMED-PORT reported the occurrence of yellow fever epizootics in non-human primates in the state of Minas Gerais [see PRO/PORT Yellow fever - Brazil (04) (MG) confirmation non-human primate, <http://promedmail.org/post/20221231.8707530>].

In August of the same year (2022), a human case was confirmed also in Minas Gerais [PRO/PORT Yellow fever - Brazil (02) (MG) confirmed case, <http://promedmail.org/post/20220803.8704838>]. The circulation of the virus was already taking place. And now we have confirmation of the 1st case (fatal) of yellow fever in 2023 in the state.

It is plausible that new epizootics in non-human primates will be observed and, depending on the number of people still susceptible, it will come as no surprise that new human cases will occur in Minas Gerais and, eventually, neighboring states. - Mod. RNA (in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY)

Although the occurrence of a single case in a rural area may not seem significant, it is a clear indication that yellow fever virus is circulating in the area in the sylvan (forest) transmission cycle. There is the risk that an individual who becomes infected could carry the virus to urban or periurban localities where the vector of the urban transmission cycle, _Aedes aegypti_, is abundant. Should there be unvaccinated people in that circumstance, the risk of initiation of an outbreak is possible. That is why a prompt, coordinated response by heath authorities at all levels, coupled with an increase in vaccination coverage as noted above, is essential to prevent spread of the disease. - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Minas Gerais, Brazil: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708951,4517>]

column2:
SHIGELLOSIS - CANADA: (ALBERTA) INNER CITY POPULATION
*****************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 10 Mar 2023
Source: Alberta Health Services [edited]
<https://www.albertahealthservices.ca/news/Page17209.aspx>


Due to a number of cases confirmed in the last 3 weeks, as of 9 Mar 2023, Alberta Health Services (AHS) has reopened the _Shigella_ outbreak that is impacting Edmonton Zone inner-city residents. In the 3 weeks following the outbreak's closure, 5 new cases were identified, all of whom required hospitalization. Even with heightened public health surveillance for illness, we recognize there are cases that go undetected and given case numbers are rising again, AHS is acting in the interest of public health by reopening the outbreak.

The 1st person became ill on 17 Aug 2022 with a confirmed diagnosis on 29 Aug 2022, and an outbreak was declared on 8 Sep 2022. It was initially declared over on 16 Feb 2023, following 2 weeks of no new cases. Closure of an outbreak following 2 weeks of no new cases is standard practice. To date [10 Mar 2023], we have identified 211 people with _Shigella_, 144 of which have required hospitalization. No deaths have been reported connected to this outbreak.

Shigellosis is a disease that is commonly associated with diarrhea, as well as fever, nausea and stomach cramps. It can cause severe illness, resulting in hospitalization, and it spreads when someone comes into contact with fecal matter from an infected person and also by eating food contaminated with the bacteria.

AHS' response to this outbreak began immediately following the 1st confirmed case, and that work involves connecting with shelters, inner-city agencies, and local family physicians about the ongoing situation. In early October 2022, AHS reached out to the City of Edmonton for support, and in mid-October AHS struck a task force to coordinate resources and a response between inner-city community partners. That task force continues to meet. Going forward, the task force will discuss additional options for limiting the spread of illness and the possibility of carrying out another medical outreach effort in the inner-city to boost access to testing and treatment.

The majority of the cases to date are within the city's inner-city population, so the risk to the general public remains low. As always, we would like to remind the general public that proper hand hygiene helps prevent the spread of any illnesses, including _Shigella_.

Alberta Health Services is the provincial health authority responsible for planning and delivering health supports and services for more than 4 million adults and children living in Alberta. Our mission is to provide a patient-focused, quality health system that is accessible and sustainable for all Albertans. Our current focus is on reducing emergency department wait-times, improving EMS response times, increasing access to surgeries, and improving patient flow.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[_Shigella_ was discovered more than 100 years ago by the Japanese microbiologist Kiyoshi Shiga, for whom the genus is named. There are 4 species: _S. boydii_, _S. dysenteriae_, _S. flexneri_, and _S. sonnei_. _Shigella_ organisms can survive transit through the stomach because they are less susceptible to acid than other bacteria; for this reason, as few as 10-100 organisms can cause disease. Ingested bacteria pass into the small intestine where they multiply; large numbers of bacteria then pass into the colon, where they enter the colonic cells. Given its relatively low infectious dose, transmission can occur via contaminated food and water or via direct person-to-person spread, including sexual practices commoner in men who have sex with men. Humans are the only natural reservoir for the disease.

The bacterium is the classical cause of bacterial dysentery (formerly known as flux or the bloody flux), an inflammatory disorder of the colon, which results in severe diarrhea containing mucus and/or blood in the feces with fever, abdominal pain, and rectal tenesmus (pain while passing diarrhea).

A relatively recent review on shigellosis follows:

Citation: Kotloff KL, Riddle MS, Platts-Mills JA, et al. Shigellosis. Lancet. 2018; 391: 801-12; <https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(17)33296-8>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
------
"Shigellosis is a clinical syndrome caused by invasion of the epithelium lining the terminal ileum, colon, and rectum by _Shigella_ species. Although infections occur globally, and in people of all ages, endemic infections among children aged 1-4 years living in low-income and middle-income settings constitute most of the disease burden. The versatile manifestations of these highly contagious organisms range from acute watery diarrhoea to fulminant dysentery characterised by frequent scant bloody stools with fever, prostration, and abdominal cramps. A broad array of uncommon, but often severe, intestinal and extraintestinal complications can occur. Despite marked reductions in mortality during the past 3 decades, there are roughly 164 000 annual deaths attributable to shigellosis. Intercontinental dissemination of multiresistant shigella strains, facilitated by travellers and men who have sex with men, has prompted new recommendations for antibiotic therapy. Awareness of disease burden and the emerging threats posed by shigella have accelerated interest in development of shigella vaccines, many of which are being tested in clinical trials."
- Mod.LL

Alberta Province, Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708950,263>]

column2:
BOTULISM - EUROPE (02): ex TURKEY, IATROGENIC, TURKISH CASES, ECDC
******************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) [edited]
<https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/news-events/botulism-cases-europe-following-medical-interventions-botulinum-neurotoxin>


Since late February 2023 and as of 10 Mar 2023, 67 cases of botulism linked to intragastric injection of the botulism neurotoxin (BoNT) have been reported in Germany (12), Austria (1), Switzerland (1) and Turkey (53). The information currently available indicates that all patients had medical interventions aimed at helping them lose weight performed between 22 Feb 2023 and 1 Mar 2023. Among 63 cases with available information, 60 cases are linked to a private hospital in Istanbul while 3 cases are linked to a private hospital in Izmir, Turkey. The symptoms have ranged from mild to severe, and several cases have been hospitalized. Among those hospitalized, a number are reported to have been admitted to intensive care units (ICU) and received treatment with botulinum antitoxin.

Individuals who have travelled to Istanbul and Izmir for intragastric BoNT treatment between 22 Feb 2023 and 1 Mar 2023 are encouraged to seek medical advice from their healthcare provider, particularly if they experience symptoms such as weakness, difficulty in breathing and/or swallowing.

ECDC strongly encourages EU/EEA citizens to avoid intragastric treatments with BoNT for obesity in Turkey, as this is currently associated with a significant risk of developing botulism. At this time, it is unclear whether this event represents a therapeutic or procedural issue in the involved hospitals, or whether there is a problem with the product administered. Investigations carried out by Turkish authorities revealed that licensed BoNT products were administered in the treatments but that these products are not approved for the treatment of obesity by intragastric injection. Consequently, the relevant departments of both hospitals have had their activities suspended, and investigations have been launched against the parties involved.

Botulism is a serious neuroparalytic illness caused by BoNTs mainly produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. The disease naturally occurs in 4 different forms:

- Food-borne botulism, caused by eating food containing BoNTs
- Intestinal botulism, when botulinum spores germinate within the intestine of adult persons
- Infant botulism, when botulinum spores germinate within the intestine of babies under one year of age
- Wound botulism, when a wound gets contaminated by botulinum spores which then germinate

There are 2 other forms of botulism that do not occur naturally: inhalation botulism and iatrogenic botulism, of which the latter may occur as an adverse event following the administration of BoNTs for therapeutic or cosmetic reasons.

While it is considered rare, individuals receiving BoNT injections for cosmetic purposes (for example, for facial wrinkle lines) or therapeutic treatments (for example, management of muscle spasticity) may develop botulism if they are injected with an excessive dose of the BoNTs.

Symptoms of iatrogenic botulism include weakness and fatigue. Toxicities following cosmetic treatment can include blurred vision, drooping eyelids, difficulty in swallowing, and dry mouth, while toxicities following therapeutic treatments include difficulty in breathing, indicating an administration of an overdose.

The symptoms of botulism can be very severe requiring intensive-care treatment as well as the administration of botulinum antitoxin. Even when such treatments are available, complete recovery usually takes weeks to months. Limited information is available quantifying mortality in botulism cases caused by medical interventions. For food-borne botulism, 5-10% of cases are fatal.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[This information was also contributed by Chris Dall.

The number of cases in Germany (where the outbreak was first reported), Austria and Switzerland has not increased since the ECDC report on 10 Mar 2023; however, not surprisingly, cases -- indeed a formidable number -- are now reported from Turkey itself. In addition, a 2nd site has been reported where the procedure produced botulism. As the ECDC report states, it is unclear whether this event represents a therapeutic or procedural issue in the involved facilities, or whether there is a problem with the product administered. Additionally, as discussed in the previous post on the outbreak (Botulism - Europe: ex Turkey, iatrogenic, ECDC 20230314.8708929), it remains unclear what the efficacy is for this procedure in producing weight loss in humans. - Mod.LL

column3: Since late February 2023 and as of 10 Mar 2023, 67 cases of botulism linked to intragastric injection of the botulism neurotoxin (BoNT) have been reported in Germany (12), Austria (1), Switzerland (1) and Turkey (53). Among 63 cases with available information, 60 cases are linked to a private hospital in Istanbul while 3 cases are linked to a private hospital in Izmir, Turkey. column2:
CONTAMINATED DRUG - EUROPE (03): (DENMARK) DICLOXACILLIN, MULTIDRUG-RESISTANT ENTEROBACTER, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*******************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 13 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<https://outbreaknewstoday.com/denmark-reports-additional-cases-of-multi-resistant-bacteria-after-dicillin-ingestion-23618/>


In a follow-up on the carbapenemase-producing organisms (CPO) detected in Denmark, the Statens Serum Institut (SSI) has detected 2 more cases of multi-resistant bacteria in patients who have been treated with the drug Dicillin [dicloxicillin brand].

In addition, traces of the special multiresistant CPO bacterium have been found in a further 12 patients, of whom it has been confirmed that 8 have been treated with Dicillin in the period before the discovery. The remaining 4 cases are still being investigated.

Thus, the outbreak with the bacterial strain now includes a total of 25 cases, as 11 cases had previously been identified.

The case of the multi-resistant bacteria and the drug Dicillin began when, in October 2022, the SSI registered an increase in a special multi-resistant CPO bacterium that had not been seen before. On closer examination, the increase in bacteria could not be related to infection in hospitals or travel abroad but was detected last month [February 2023] on the surface of capsules of the medicine Dicillin. It also turned out that all the patients had taken the medicine up to the detection of the bacteria.

SSI is following the outbreak closely and the Danish Medicines Agency is working with the manufacturer [Sandoz] to uncover the causes of the outbreak.

None of the Danish patients have become seriously ill from the bacteria, just as it has not been necessary to initiate other treatments for the bacteria. "This is not dangerous for the individual patient, but we must of course do what we can to avoid the spread of multi-resistant bacteria," professional director at SSI, Tyra Grove Krause. says and continues: "We know that most CPO bacteria have the ability to share their resistance with other bacterial species, so that part is not so surprising."

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Dicillin is a brand name for dicloxacillin marketed in Denmark, an orally administered beta-lactam antibiotic of the penicillin class that is active against Gram-positive cocci, including methicillin-susceptible staphylococci and streptococci, including beta-lactamase (penicillinase)-producing _Staphylococcus aureus_ that are resistant to penicillin (ie, methicillin-susceptible _S. aureus_ (MSSA). However, methicillin-resistant _S. aureus_ (MRSA) are resistant to dicloxacillin.

The reports above say that there are now 25 patients (who are not related) who were colonized (but not infected) by the same carbapenemase-positive organism ("CPO"), now identified as _Enterobacter hormaechei_ sequence type 79, in the past 4 months (October 2022 to March 2023) in Denmark. 21 of these patients had been treated with Dicillin® (500 mg capsules) from the pharmaceutical company Sandoz. The remaining 4 cases are still being investigated. _E. hormaechei_ sequence type 79 has been identified on the surface of a capsule of Dicillin® 500 mg taken from previously unopened packages of Dicillin®.

In addition, one person in Iceland who had taken dicloxacillin manufactured by Sandoz (Staklox® brand in Iceland) in July 2022 has been said to have developed an "infection" with the same bacterium identified in the 25 patients in Denmark. Also, this organism was isolated from 2 patients in 2020 in Denmark who had taken Dicillin® shortly before isolation of _E. hormaechei_ sequence type 79.

It is likely that several lots of dicloxacillin manufactured by Sandoz, called Dicillin® in Denmark and Staklox® in Iceland, have been contaminated since affected patients are located in 2 different European countries, and dates of exposure extend from 2020 to 2023. All dicloxacillin is being recalled by Sandoz in Denmark and Iceland. However, we are not told which lots of dicloxacillin are affected, where the affected lots of the drug were manufactured and bottled, or how widely these lots have been distributed.

More information on this outbreak would be greatly appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML

Denmark: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708948,111>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (48): AMERICAS (USA, CANADA) SKUNK, HPAI
********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this posting:
[1] USA (Colorado): skunk
[2] Canada (British Columbia): skunk

******
[1] USA (Colorado): skunk
Date: Sun 12 Mar 2023
Source: Coloradoan [edited]
<https://www.coloradoan.com/story/news/2023/03/12/dead-skunks-in-larimer-county-test-positive-for-avian-flu/69996339007/>


Within the last 2 weeks [1st half of March 2023], 4 dead skunks found in Larimer County [Colorado] have tested positive for highly pathogenic avian influenza, or HPAI, marking a growing trend of the deadly disease showing up in mammals in Colorado.

The county's 4 deaths are the most HPAI mammal deaths in the state.

HPAI has devastated domestic poultry operations and killed countless wild waterfowl and raptors in Colorado and elsewhere in one of the most deadly outbreaks in years. In Colorado, it was first detected in the wild population in geese, in March 2022.

"We always suspected this transition (from wild waterfowl to mammals) would happen,'' Colorado Parks and Wildlife spokesperson Kara Van Hoose said. "Because it's so new and science takes time, we don't know what kind of impacts it will have. The number of fatalities doesn't cause alarms to go off but we certainly are testing and monitoring.''

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention considers the risk of transmission to humans, pets, and wild mammals as low.

Colorado Parks and Wildlife confirmed the positive tests, 1 on 2 Mar 2023 and 3 on 28 Feb 2023, but would not identify where in the county the skunks were located. It began testing for mammals on 9 Feb 2023.

Among the mammal deaths in Colorado are 5 skunks, 4 mountain lions, 2 bobcats, 2 red foxes, and 1 black bear, according to the US Department of Agriculture's website that tracks such deaths. Nationally, red foxes are by far the most impacted mammal, representing 60 of the 144 confirmed mammal deaths as of 9 Mar 2023.

Colorado is tied for 4th in mammal deaths due to the disease. Wisconsin is 1st, with 19 deaths.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Colorado, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708945,1298>]

****
[2] Canada (British Columbia): skunk
Date: Mon 13 Mar 2023 1:00 PM PDT
Source: BC Gov News [edited]
<https://news.gov.bc.ca/releases/2023AF0017-000312>


Testing has confirmed 8 skunks found dead in late February [2023] in Richmond and Vancouver [British Columbia] are positive for avian influenza.

The skunks were found in residential areas in both cities and were taken to BC's Animal Health Centre due to concerns they may have been deliberately poisoned. Testing revealed the skunks were infected with the same strain of H5N1 avian influenza that caused the deaths of wildlife and domestic poultry in the province since the April 2022 outbreak began. The skunks may have contracted influenza by scavenging infected wild birds.

While influenza in skunks is considered to be a low risk to human health, there are always risks when people and pets come into contact with sick or dead wild animals, including skunks and birds. People who encounter a dead skunk in Richmond or Vancouver should leave the animal where it is and contact the BC Wildlife Health Program at 250 751-7246.

Since April 2022, wildlife infected by avian influenza in BC has included more than 20 species of wild birds, as well as 2 skunks and one fox found in rural areas of the province.

The cases of H5N1 avian influenza in BC are part of a larger national and international outbreak.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of British Columbia, Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708945,264>

Infections by HPAI viruses in mammals were typically not common, but since April 2022 there has been a growing number of events of Eurasian HPAI H5N1 in a wide spectrum of wild carnivores (order Carnivora). There have been reports in red foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_, family Canidae), bobcats and mountain lions (family Felidae), skunks (family Mephitidae), raccoons (family Procyonidae), bears (family Ursidae), otters and minks (family Mustelidae), seals and sea lions (suborder Pinnipedia, families Phocidae and Otariidae, respectively). There have also been cases in cetaceans.

Molecular analyses of mammalian virus strains revealed mutations in the PB2 gene segment (PB2-E627K and PB2-D701N) that are known to facilitate viral replication in mammals. However, these mutations were not present in the strain that killed hundreds of sea lions in Peru. - Mod.PMB]
