column3: Testing has confirmed 8 skunks found dead in late February [2023] in Richmond and Vancouver [British Columbia] are positive for avian influenza.The skunks were found in residential areas in both cities and were taken to BC's Animal Health Centre due to concerns they may have been deliberately poisoned. Testing revealed the skunks were infected with the same strain of H5N1 avian influenza that caused the deaths of wildlife and domestic poultry in the province since the April 2022 outbreak began. The skunks may have contracted influenza by scavenging infected wild birds.While influenza in skunks is considered to be a low risk to human health, there are always risks when people and pets come into contact with sick or dead wild animals, including skunks and birds. People who encounter a dead skunk in Richmond or Vancouver should leave the animal where it is and contact the BC Wildlife Health Program at 250 751-7246.Since April 2022, wildlife infected by avian influenza in BC has included more than 20 species of wild birds, as well as 2 skunks and one fox found in rural areas of the province.The cases of H5N1 avian influenza in BC are part of a larger national and international outbreak.--Communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of British Columbia, Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708945,264>Infections by HPAI viruses in mammals were typically not common, but since April 2022 there has been a growing number of events of Eurasian HPAI H5N1 in a wide spectrum of wild carnivores (order Carnivora). There have been reports in red foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_, family Canidae), bobcats and mountain lions (family Felidae), skunks (family Mephitidae), raccoons (family Procyonidae), bears (family Ursidae), otters and minks (family Mustelidae), seals and sea lions (suborder Pinnipedia, families Phocidae and Otariidae, respectively). There have also been cases in cetaceans.Molecular analyses of mammalian virus strains revealed mutations in the PB2 gene segment (PB2-E627K and PB2-D701N) that are known to facilitate viral replication in mammals. However, these mutations were not present in the strain that killed hundreds of sea lions in Peru. - Mod.PMB]

column2:
STREPTOCOCCUS SUIS - VIET NAM: RAW PORK MEAT/BLOOD CONSUMPTION, ALERT
*********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023 14:29 CST
Source: China Daily, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]
<https://www.chinadailyhk.com/article/320287#Vietnam-on-alert-after-human-cases-of-pig-related-disease-discovered>


Viet Nam's health ministry has urged medical facilities to be vigilant for suspected cases of _Streptococcus suis_, a bacterium that comes from pigs, after a number of human cases were found over the past few months, local media reported on Tuesday [14 Mar 2023].

Since the beginning of the year [2023], several _Streptococcus_ infections have been recorded across the nation and the majority of cases have involved people eating pork products such as blood pudding, or those who slaughter pigs, the Vietnam News reported, citing the health ministry.

Patients often suffer severe clinical symptoms and need long-term, expensive treatment. Once people become infected with the virus [_S. suis_ is a bacterium, not a virus], the disease develops quickly, leading to complications such as septic shock, coma, and multiple organ failure.

The ministry's Department of Preventive Medicine has called on local health authorities to strengthen supervision to early detect suspected cases of infections and have measures to handle the outbreak. People were urged to cook pork properly in order to eliminate the potential risk of infection, as no vaccination against the disease is available at the moment.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2]
Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: VietNamNet Global, Viet Nam News (VNS) report [edited]
<https://vietnamnet.vn/en/health-ministry-issues-alert-after-human-cases-of-pig-related-disease-discovered-2120392.html>


A report from the ministry's infectious disease surveillance system showed that in the 1st months of this year [2023], a number of _Streptococcus_ infections were recorded across the nation.

The Medical Centre of Sóc Sơn District in Hà Nội reported that it has successfully saved a patient suffering from anaphylactic [?] shock after eating blood pudding. [The 51-year-old], residing in Phù Linh Commune, was admitted to the hospital with red skin, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and high blood pressure. The patient said he had no allergies and had a good health record.

On 1 Mar 2023, doctors at Bãi Cháy Hospital received a Chinese patient suffering from a fever. The patient tested positive for _Streptococcus suis_. He is now in stable health condition after 12 days of treatment.

The 1st human cases of _Streptococcus suis_ were recorded last month [February 2023] when a 52-year-old resident of Hà Đông District, who was the owner of a restaurant that sells blood pudding, was infected with the virus [_S. suis_ is a bacterium, not a virus]. The man underwent examination at 103 Military Hospital are suffering from high fever, nausea, and vomiting.

The ministry said that the majority of cases have involved people eating pork products such as blood pudding, or those who slaughter pigs. Patients often suffer severe clinical symptoms ad need long-term, expensive treatment. Once people become infected with the [bacterium], the disease develops quickly, leading to complications such as septic shock, coma, and multiple organ failure.

In 1960, the 1st human case was detected and since then there have been around 490 human cases of _S. suis_, of which the mortality rate stands at 17.5 per cent.

In Viet Nam, about 10 patients have been admitted to the National Hospital for Tropical Diseases in the past several years.

According to a study by the HCM City-based Hospital for Tropical Diseases, this disease is more prevalent during hot weather. The majority of patients are farmers who are exposed to pork products or pig slaughtering. Most of the patients had meningitis symptoms such as fever, headache, vomiting, stiff neck, and impaired consciousness.

To prevent the disease, the ministry's Department of Preventive Medicine has called on local health authorities to strengthen supervision to early detect suspected cases of infections and have measures to handle the outbreak.

They have also advised people to stop eating blood pudding and cook pork meat properly in order to eliminate the potential risk of infection, as no vaccination against the disease is available at the moment. Furthermore, people should avoid the purchase, transport, or slaughter of sick or dead pigs and use protective gloves when in contact with pigs.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[_Streptococcus suis_ is an alpha-hemolytic Gram-positive coccus growing in chains on blood agar. It has a worldwide distribution. _S. suis_ is divided into 29 serotypes, based on the antigenic specificity of its capsular polysaccharide, which vary in pathogenicity.

_S. suis_ is an important pathogen of pigs, causing mainly septicemia with sudden death, meningitis, arthritis, and endocarditis, mostly in post-weaned piglets. _S. suis_ has also been isolated from asymptomatic pigs, usually from the throat, but also from the reproductive and GI tracts (<https://www.merckvetmanual.com/generalized-conditions/streptococcal-infections-in-pigs/streptococcus-suis-infection-in-pigs?query=streptococcus%20suis#v3275263>).

In humans, it causes a potentially fatal zoonotic infection, most commonly meningitis, but also sepsis or endocarditis; toxic shock has been reported if the pathogen produces the appropriate toxins.

_S. suis_ infection occurs mainly in pig breeders, abattoir workers, meat processors, cooks, and those who eat raw pork products. Consumption of raw pork is a common tradition in South East Asia, where infection with _S. suis_ associated with these products has been frequently reported (see prior ProMED posts listed below). Eating cooked meat or organs from infected pigs poses no risk and person-to-person spread does not seem to occur (<http://jac.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/50/2/201>).

For the patients in the news reports above, the source for infection was frequently blood pudding made from raw pig blood (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiết_canh>).

There is no human vaccine available for _S. suis_. Prevention of the disease in humans involves wearing gloves when handling raw pork and washing hands and cleaning utensils, equipment, and kitchen surfaces that have been in contact with raw pork (<https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/healthtopics/content/24/3648.html>) and all pork products should be cooked thoroughly before eating.

The viral infection, porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) in pigs is known to have an immunosuppressive effect, which is thought to increase pigs' susceptibility to infection with _S. suis_. - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
Vietnam: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708940,152>]

column2:
EQUINE INFECTIOUS ANEMIA - SOUTH AMERICA: URUGUAY (SALTO) WOAH
**************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 10 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4961>


Uruguay - equine infectious anemia
----------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 10 Mar 2023
Confirmed: 10 Mar 2023
Reported: 10 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 26 Jul 2019
Causal agent: Equine infectious anemia virus
Nature of diagnosis: laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Salto
Started: 10 Mar 2023
Epidemiological unit: farm
Affected animals:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Equidae / - / 2 / - / - / - / -

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreaks(s): unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: within the framework of equine disease surveillance, 2 equines were diagnosed with equine infectious anemia in the Department of Salto. Tracing activities have started in the area to identify the origin of the infection. The animals will be culled.

Control measures at event level
Control measures applied in domestic animals: movement control; selective killing and disposal

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name / Species / Test / Test date / Result
Veterinary Laboratory Division / equidae / Coggin's test/ 10 Mar 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above. - Mod.CRD]


--
Communicated by:
ProMED

["Equine infectious anaemia (EIA) is a persistent viral infection of equids. The causative agent, EIA virus (EIAV) is a lentivirus in the family Retroviridae, subfamily Orthoretrovirinae."

"Although EIA may be suspected on the basis of clinical signs and pathological lesions, confirmation of infection requires further serological and molecular-based testing. Infected horses remain viraemic carriers for life and, with very rare exceptions, yield a positive serological test result. Although antibody levels fluctuate, EIA infection generates a persistent antibody response. All equids older than 12 months that test seropositive are identified as virus carriers. In young equids less than 12 months of age, positive serological reactions can be due to maternal antibodies; therefore, the EIA status may have to rely solely on molecular techniques. As virus reservoirs, infected equids are a transmission risk to other equids. The virus is primarily blood-borne. Biting flies are mechanical vectors for the virus in nature and infection is often spread via iatrogenic routes."

EIAV is not considered a risk for human health."
<https://www.woah.org/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/3.06.06_EIA.pdf>
- Mod.CRD

ProMED map of Uruguay: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708937,27383>]

column2:
LEAF RUST, SOYBEAN - BRAZIL: INCREASE
*************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 10 Mar 2023
Source: AgroPages [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://news.agropages.com/News/NewsDetail---45811.htm>


Since its introduction in Brazil in 2001, Asian soybean rust has been the most serious disease of soybean crops. The national Antirust Consortium said that recent cases of Asian soybean rust for the 2022/23 harvest exceeded 119 in 9 Brazilian states. Compared to the previous harvest period, between November 2022 and January 2023, this was an increase of more than 220% in just one cropping season.

Management strategies are centered on practices such as the "sanitary void" [host free period between crops] in the field for at least 90 days to reduce inoculum. Use of cultivars with early maturation sown at the beginning of their recommended period, as well as resistant cultivars and use of fungicides, can also help control the disease.

Currently, the fungus has mutations that confer resistance to the 3 main groups of site-specific fungicides [e.g. ProMED post 20171226.5523371]. New mutations can emerge over time counteracting some of the control strategies, such as losing sensitivity to additional fungicides or breaking down genetic resistance of soybean cultivars.

[Byline: Leonardo Gottems]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Leaf rust (also called soybean rust, and Asian rust) caused by the fungus _Phakopsora pachyrhizi_ can result in yield losses of soybean crops of up to 90 percent. It is widespread in Asia and Africa and spreading in the Americas, but data are lacking on its establishment in Europe. Besides soybean, over 30 other species in the family of Fabaceae can also be affected and may serve as pathogen reservoirs.

Spores are spread locally by splashing rain, or by wind over long distances. Several epidemic cycles may occur in one cropping season. In Brazil, volunteer soybeans as pathogen reservoirs have been identified as a threat to new crops (ProMED-mail post 20120911.1287887). Fungicides may be used in disease management, but timing of applications is considered important. Rotating or mixing chemical classes of fungicides is vital to extend the useful life of any of the compounds. Partially resistant soybean lines are available. However, as mentioned above, new fungal strains with increased virulence and fungicide resistances are emerging in soybean producing countries, including Brazil (ProMED posts 20171226.5523371, 20090501.1644).

While the related species _P. meibomiae_ is also found in South America and the Caribbean causing similar symptoms, it is not referred to as 'Asian' rust. This species is less virulent and considered of lesser economic significance.

<https://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/samerica/lgcolor/brnewzzl.gif>,
<https://geology.com/world/brazil-states-map.gif>, and <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708936,6> (states)
South America, overview:
<https://ontheworldmap.com/south-america/political-map-of-south-america.jpg>

Pictures
Leaf rust on soybean:
<http://www.ent.iastate.edu/images/plantpath/soybean/asianrust/asian_soyrust_lesions.jpg>,
<http://www.state.nj.us/agriculture/plant/soybeanrust.jpg>, and
<https://brunswick.ces.ncsu.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/soybeanrustuuky.jpg>
Close-up of rust pustules:
<http://www.mississippi-crops.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/DSC00127.jpg>
Fungicide treated vs. untreated crops:
<http://eidupont.scene7.com/is/image/eidupont/cp_A-327_soybean_rust_callout_2>
Electron microscopy of leaf rust pustules:
<https://pesticideguy.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/30-soybean-rust.png>

Links
Information on soybean leaf rust:
<https://doi.org/10.1079/cabicompendium.40019>
<https://cropwatch.unl.edu/plantdisease/soybean/soybean-rust>,
<https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1364-3703.2009.00589.x>,
<https://doi.org/10.1590/0100-5405/220951>,
<https://doi.org/10.1094/9780890546642.05> and
<https://www.pioneer.com/home/site/us/agronomy/crop-management/soybean-insect-disease/soybean-rust/>
Disease history and pathogen evolution:
<https://doi.org/10.1590/S1415-47572008005000026>

<https://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/NamesRecord.asp?RecordID=121037> and
<https://www.speciesfungorum.org/GSD/GSDspecies.asp?RecordID=121037>

<https://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/NamesRecord.asp?RecordID=102469> and
<https://www.speciesfungorum.org/GSD/GSDspecies.asp?RecordID=102469>
Fungicide groups & modes of action:
<https://www.frac.info/fungicide-resistance-management/by-frac-mode-of-action-group>
- Mod.DHA]

This species is less virulent and considered of lesser economic significance.MapsBrazil:<https://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/samerica/lgcolor/brnewzzl.gif>,<https://geology.com/world/brazil-states-map.gif>, and <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708936,6> (states)South America, overview:<https://ontheworldmap.com/south-america/political-map-of-south-america.jpg>PicturesLeaf rust on soybean:<http://www.ent.iastate.edu/images/plantpath/soybean/asianrust/asian_soyrust_lesions.jpg>,<http://www.state.nj.us/agriculture/plant/soybeanrust.jpg>, and<https://brunswick.ces.ncsu.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/soybeanrustuuky.jpg>Close-up of rust pustules:<http://www.mississippi-crops.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/DSC00127.jpg>Fungicide treated vs. untreated crops:<http://eidupont.scene7.com/is/image/eidupont/cp_A-327_soybean_rust_callout_2>Electron microscopy of leaf rust pustules:<https://pesticideguy.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/30-soybean-rust.png>LinksInformation on soybean leaf rust:<https://doi.org/10.1079/cabicompendium.40019><https://cropwatch.unl.edu/plantdisease/soybean/soybean-rust>,<https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1364-3703.2009.00589.x>,<https://doi.org/10.1590/0100-5405/220951>,<https://doi.org/10.1094/9780890546642.05> and<https://www.pioneer.com/home/site/us/agronomy/crop-management/soybean-insect-disease/soybean-rust/>Disease history and pathogen evolution:<https://doi.org/10.1590/S1415-47572008005000026>_P. pachyrhizi_ taxonomy & synonyms:<https://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/NamesRecord.asp?RecordID=121037> and<https://www.speciesfungorum.org/GSD/GSDspecies.asp?RecordID=121037>_P. meibomiae_ taxonomy & synonyms:<https://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/NamesRecord.asp?RecordID=102469> and<https://www.speciesfungorum.org/GSD/GSDspecies.asp?RecordID=102469>Fungicide groups & modes of action:<https://www.frac.info/fungicide-resistance-management/by-frac-mode-of-action-group>- Mod.DHA]

column2:
BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE - RUSSIA: (SAKHA) DOG, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*****************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: Baikal 24 [in Russian, machine trans., edited]
<https://baikal24.ru/text/14-03-2023/022/>


An outbreak of brucellosis, an infectious animal disease that is dangerous for humans, for which there is no vaccine, has been recorded at a dog and cat detention center in Yakutsk.

Human infection occurs through direct contact with the secretions of sick animals. 533 samples taken at the shelter were positive for brucellosis.

Viktor Semenov, deputy head of the Veterinary Department of the Republic of Yakutia [Republic of Sakha], said that brucellosis in the shelter is the main problem in Yakutsk today. The results of laboratory tests are expected from St. Petersburg and Stavropol.

"After the examinations that were carried out in the Yakut Republican Veterinary Testing Laboratory, Moscow and Amur laboratories, we are waiting for bacterial studies from St. Petersburg and Stavropol. After that, further measures will be taken to solve this problem," Viktor Semenov said.

Animals that are kept in shelters are prohibited from being killed; they can only be euthanized "in case of a disease, identified by a veterinarian, that is incompatible with the life of the animal." Also, local animal rights activists believe that the tests give a false result, and that [the authorities] just want to get rid of the animals.

At the Yakut detention centre, there are now 919 animals, caught within the all-Russian OSVV program ("catch, sterilize, vaccinate, return"). The dog must be examined, quarantined if necessary, vaccinated, sterilized, and after 30 days, if the dog is healthy and does not present aggression, returned to the site where it was picked up.

Public activists claim that brucellosis was detected in October [2022] in one of the city veterinary clinics in domestic dogs of the Cane Corso breed [<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cane_Corso>]. The study was carried out by ELISA kit manufactured by the Kursk biofactory, which, according to animal rights activists, "often present false positive results."

The infection, according to animal rights activists, is curable, but according to the order of the Ministry of Agriculture, the animals must be euthanized. [A dog owner] from Nyurba, whose dog they wanted to euthanize because of alleged brucellosis, recorded a video message to the head of Yakutia, Aisen Nikolaev.

"We know that there is such a video message. In Nyurba there was, according to the results of the analysis of the Moscow [Vladimir] laboratory, a positive test for brucellosis in a puppy. Now, after all these appeals, we are waiting for bacterial studies, and after these studies, we will take all measures. This dog [from Nyurba] has not been euthanized and is with the owners at the moment," said Viktor Semenov, deputy head of the Department of Veterinary Medicine of the Republic of Yakutia.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[It may be assumed that _Brucella canis_ is the causative agent of the canine brucellosis cases suspected in dogs in Yakutsk (the world's coldest major city). It should be clearly differentiated from other _Brucella_ species, in particular _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_, important zoonotic pathogens. Occasionally, these _Brucella_ species may be associated with disease in dogs. Final results from Russia's reference laboratories are expected with interest, allowing adequate further measures undertaken to protect human and animal health.

_B. canis_ "is an important cause of reproductive failure in dogs, especially in kennels. Infections can result in abortions and stillbirths in bitches, and epididymitis, prostatitis, orchitis, and sperm abnormalities in males. Although spayed or neutered dogs do not have reproductive signs, they occasionally develop other conditions such as ocular disease and discospondylitis. _B. canis_ may persist in an animal even after antibiotic treatment. In kennels, infected dogs are often euthanized to prevent them from infecting other dogs or people. Canine brucellosis is sometimes difficult to diagnose with the currently available tests.

"The importance of _B. canis_ as a cause of human illness is still unclear. Few clinical cases have been reported in people, and most have been mild. However, human infections with this organism may be underdiagnosed, as the symptoms are nonspecific, diagnostic suspicion among physicians is low, and obtaining a definitive diagnosis may be difficult."

"Dogs are thought to be the only significant hosts for _B. canis_ among domesticated animals."

"Antibodies to _B. canis_ have also been reported occasionally in wild canids."

"_B. canis_ appears to be widely distributed and has been reported in North, Central, and South America and parts of Asia, Africa, and Europe."
(<https://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_canis.pdf>)

Additional information is available at <https://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_canis.pdf>. - Mod.AS

ProMED map of Sakha (Yakutia) Republic, Russia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708935,407>]

column2:
ANTHRAX - RUSSIA: (CHUVASH) HUMAN, EXPOSED DURING LIVESTOCK SLAUGHTER
*********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: REN TV [in Russian, machine trans., edited]
<https://ren.tv/news/v-rossii/1084577-dva-cheloveka-zarazilis-sibirskoi-iazvoi-v-chuvashi>


In Chuvashia, 2 people were hospitalized with symptoms of anthrax infection. As it became known to REN TV, the case was confirmed on 14 Mar [2023].

"Infection occurred in the Tsivilsky municipal district after receiving a wound during the slaughter of livestock," the source explained. The injured were taken to the district hospital.

In 2022, a case of anthrax infection was detected in a resident of the village of Rozhdestvenskaya in the Stavropol Territory. In the territory of the village, preventive enterprises were carried out, which included disinfection of premises, prophylaxis with antibiotics, as well as vaccination of farm animals.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The reason for referencing the 2022 outbreak is obscure, but it would appear to be the last outbreak of anthrax in Russia (Anthrax - Russia (02): (SL) human, calf 20220623.8704021).

We have just a single previous report, from 2010, of an outbreak in Chuvashia in 2 foals (Anthrax, equine - Russia: (CV, KL) 20101212.4420), but it was not laboratory confirmed and was probably strangles.

This recent pair of human infections in March [2023] -- from the history, probably cutaneous anthrax -- has been confirmed in these 2 men, but there is no history of livestock anthrax nor of their laboratory confirmation.

"Chuvashia, officially the Chuvash Republic - Chuvashia, is a republic of Russia located in Eastern Europe. It is the homeland of the Chuvash people, a Turkic ethnic group. Its capital is the city of Cheboksary. As of the 2010 Census, its population was 1 251 619."
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuvashia>)

The Wikipedia site has a good map showing its location. - Mod MHJ

ProMED map of Chuvash Republic, Russia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708934,395>]

column2:
BSE, CATTLE - SWITZERLAND: (GRAUBÜNDEN) ATYPICAL L-TYPE, WOAH
**************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 13 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4962>


Switzerland, bovine spongiform encephalopathy
---------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 3 Mar 2023
Confirmed: 8 Mar 2023
Reported: 13 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 3 Feb 2020
Causal agent: bovine spongiform encephalopathy prion (atypical BSE type L)
Nature of diagnosis: laboratory
This event pertains to the whole country.

Outbreak location: Prättigau-Davos, Graubünden
Started: 3 Mar 2023
Epidemiological unit: farm
Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Cattle / 19 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 1 / 0

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive

Epidemiological comments: The 12-year-old cow from a holding in the Canton of Grisons has been sampled at slaughter in the framework of the BSE surveillance program on [27 Feb 2023]. The brain stem material was tested positive by IDEXX HerdChek BSE-Scrapie Ag Test on [3 Mar 2023]. The result was confirmed on [8 Mar 2023] by Western lmmunoblot at the National Reference Laboratory for Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathies (Neurocenter, Vetsuisse Faculty, Berne, Switzerland). The pathological prion protein was classified as (L) -Type, therefore the case has been categorized as atypical BSE. The entire carcass was disposed of as category 1 material.

Control measures applied in domestic: traceability; selective killing and disposal; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection; official destruction of animal products.

Control measures to be applied in domestic: ante and post-mortem inspections

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type: NeuroCenter, Department of Clinical Research and Veterinary Public Health (DCR-VPH), Division of Experimental Clinical Research, University of Bern
Species / Test / Test date / Result
Cattle / antigen detection Western blot (Ag Western blot) / 8 Mar 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Cases of atypical BSE do not impact the official BSE risk status of a country; therefore, this detection will not change the negligible risk status of Switzerland. - Mod.CRD

ProMED map:

column2:
BOTULISM - EUROPE: ex TURKEY, IATROGENIC, ECDC
**********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 10 Mar 2023
Source: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) [edited]
<https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-Disease-Threats-Report-10-Mar-2023.pdf>


ECDC Communicable Disease Threats Report Week 10, 5-11 Mar 2023
Iatrogenic botulism, exposure in Turkey
---------------------------------------------------------------
Overview
--------
As of [Fri 10 Mar 2023], Germany reports 12 cases of clinical botulism, apparently iatrogenic, due to intragastric injection of botulism neurotoxin (BoNT). The cases are middle-aged adults, originating from different regions of Germany, who underwent treatments with 1000-1500 units of BoNT in Turkey between [22 and 25 Feb 2023]. The clinical presentation of the cases ranged from mild to severe; several cases have been hospitalized among whom a number are reported to have been admitted to Intensive Care Units (ICU). Among 8 cases with known information, all received treatment at the same clinic in Istanbul, Turkey. There is no indication of treatment being organized by a commercial medical travel company at this time. Information received from patient interviews indicated a WhatsApp group was used to contact the hospital. A total of 3 cases who recalled the name of the BoNT product used on them, reported having been treated with one and the same product.

Austria reports 1 case (female; 25-44 years) of apparently iatrogenic botulism after intragastric injection of BoNTs administered in Turkey on [22 Feb 2023]. The case reported receiving treatment, which was self-arranged, at the same clinic as the cases in Germany and Switzerland. The patient was hospitalized with botulism symptoms (ptosis, dysphagia, dyspnea, neck weakness, generalised muscle weakness).

Switzerland (information reported to ECDC by France on behalf of Switzerland) reports 1 suspected case of botulism (female, 45-64 years), probably associated with intragastric injection of BoNT, also administered in Turkey on [22 Feb 2023]. The case reported receiving treatment at the same clinic as the cases in Germany and Austria.

Background information
----------------------
In 2019, France reported a suspected case of botulism (female; 25-44 years) following an intragastric injection of BoNT in Egypt (in order to lose weight), with hospitalization in France.

A WHO medical product alert from August [2022], reported 5 falsified batches of a BoNT product detected in 5 countries - Jordan [May 2022], Turkey [May 2022], Kuwait [June 2022], United Kingdom [June 2022], and Poland [July 2022]. It is not known, however, if these batches have been used for treatment in the cases reported so far. Outbreaks of iatrogenic botulism, sometimes linked to counterfeit or unlicensed BoNT, have also been reported in the past following different clinical procedures, for example in Egypt and Turkey.

Botulism is a serious neuroparalytic illness caused by BoNTs mainly produced by the bacterium, _Clostridium botulinum_. The disease naturally occurs in 4 different forms: a) food-borne botulism, b) intestinal botulism, c) infant botulism, and d) wound botulism. There are 2 other forms of botulism that do not occur naturally: a) inhalation botulism and b) iatrogenic botulism, which is the most recent human-made form of botulism. Intoxication may occur as an adverse event following the administration of BoNTs for therapeutic or cosmetic reasons.

While it is considered rare, individuals receiving BoNT injections for cosmetic purposes (for example: for facial wrinkle lines) or therapeutic treatments (for example: for management of muscle spasticity), may develop iatrogenic botulism if they are injected with an excessive dose of the BoNTs.

Symptoms of iatrogenic botulism are characterized by weakness and difficulty swallowing. Toxicities following cosmetic treatment include ophthalmological and oropharyngeal symptoms (blurred vision, drooping eyelid, difficulty swallowing, and dry mouth) while toxicities following therapeutic treatments are linked with difficulty breathing and weakness. The symptoms of botulism can be very severe requiring intensive-care treatment as well as the administration of an anti-toxin. Even when such treatments are available, complete recovery usually takes weeks to months. Limited information is available quantifying mortality in iatrogenic botulism cases. For foodborne botulism, 5-10% of cases are fatal.

Further information about botulism can be found on the websites of ECDC, US CDC, and WHO. 

ECDC assessment
---------------
This is a multi-country outbreak of at least 14 cases of iatrogenic botulism in Germany (12 cases), Austria (1 case), and Switzerland (1 case) with gastric injections of BoNT administered in Istanbul, Turkey on dates between [22 and 25 Feb 2023]. The cases are middle-aged adults. Among cases with known information in Germany (8 cases), Austria (1 case), and Switzerland (1 case), all are reported to have received treatment at the same clinic. Considering the possible variation in the clinical presentation of botulism illness it is possible that some cases are yet to be identified. New cases may occur, particularly among those traveling to Turkey for medical treatments involving intragastric injection of BoNTs.

Individuals who have traveled to Istanbul, Turkey for intragastric BoNT treatment and experience symptoms consistent with botulism illness (weakness, difficulty breathing, and/or swallowing), are advised to seek medical attention as soon as possible. Patients may inform their healthcare provider of the present ongoing multi-country outbreak.

Actions
-------
ECDC is monitoring the event in EpiPulse and via Epidemic Intelligence activities and is sharing information through the CDTR report. A teleconference call is scheduled with affected and involved countries, DG SANTE, and WHO- Europe on [Fri 10 Mar 2023]. ECDC encourages countries to report any information relevant to this outbreak in the EpiPulse event 2023-FWD-00013.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Now there are more cases reported from Germany and single cases from Austria and Switzerland. In all cases where the information is available, the therapy was given at the same clinic in Istanbul, Turkey.

Injecting the gastric muscles with botulinum toxin A is sometimes used as a relatively minimally invasive weight loss procedure. The injections are done using endoscopy with a flexible tube equipped with a syringe, inserted into the stomach through the mouth.

The medication immobilizes the muscles of the stomach wall for about 3 months, preventing the injected muscles from contracting. This results in the food in the stomach staying longer, slowing digestion and the patient feels fuller faster and for a longer time.

Initially, studies in mice did show desired weight loss but there remains debate on whether the therapy is effective in achieving the weight loss goal. As an example, the following non-controlled study, actually from Istanbul, Turkey, in 13 patients did not show positive results.

Şen O and Gökhan Türkçapar A: Gastric botulinum toxin-A application for weight loss therapy. Turk J Gastroenterol. 2021;32: 66-69
<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8975509/>

Abstract
---------
"Background/Aims: The aim of this study is to share the results of gastric botulinum toxin (BTX) application in individuals who are overweight or type 1 obese without comorbidity.

"Materials and Methods: In this study, 13 patients were included who were enrolled for gastric BTX application for the first time. A total of 300 U of BTX-A (Allergan Botox ®1 vial 100 U) was diluted with 8 mL of 0.9% NaCl saline, and antrum (100 U to 8 spots), corpus (100 U to 8 spots), and fundus (100 U to 8 spots) regions were injected intramuscularly. Patients were given a 1200-calorie low-carb diet and this was followed for 6 months.

"Results: Gastric BTX application was applied to 13 patients with a mean age of 40.9 ± 5.2 (85% female), a mean body mass index (BMI) of 28.41 ± 1.4 kg/m2 (26-31.6) and a mean excess weight of 10.1 ± 3.6 kg. As a result of the 6-month follow-up, only 4 patients (30.8%) were able to lose more than 50% of their excess weight (6-15 kg). A total of 6 patients (46.2%) could not lose any weight. There was an average decrease of 3.3 kg in the weight of patients before and after BTX application (P = .03). A mean decrease of BMI was detected, 1.17 kg/m2 (P = .032).

"Conclusion: It was concluded that the application of gastric BTX for weight loss does not provide effective results."

The following is extracted from the above paper (the citations can be found in the original URL):
"In the literature, there are 3 experimental studies that investigated the effect of BTX [botox] application in the stomach on weight loss and stomach functions. The first one is the study by Gui et al. where they compared the injection of BTX and saline into the gastric antrum in mice. After 10 weeks of follow-up, they detected more weight loss and less food consumption in the BTX group (8). In a similar study conducted in our country, it was found that weight loss was observed for a temporary period and gastric emptying was accelerated in the scintigraphic study (9). A similar study from Korea has recently been published, and a 6-week follow-up revealed significant weight loss in mice treated with BTX compared to the saline group.

"BTX application to stomach in an obese patient was performed for the first time by Rolnikk et al. and it was published as a case study. In this study, 100 U BTX were applied to the pre-pyloric antral wall in a patient with a BMI of 31.4 kg/m2 and a decrease of 8.9% was observed in the total BMI (10). Later, the first clinical study was done by Garcia-Compean et al. In their study, Garcia-Compean et al. applied 100 U BTX to 8 spots in the antrum in 12 obese individuals, and they did not detect any significant difference in terms of weight loss after 8 weeks of follow-up (11). Foschi et al. administered saline to one group of patients and 200 U of BTX were applied to the antrum in another group, and both groups were supported with a 1200-calorie diet. During the follow-up, the BTX group lost an average of 11.2 kg and the saline group lost 5.7 kg (12) of excess weight. In a study by Liu et al., 300 and 100 U BTX were compared and it was detected that 300 U provided more weight loss (13) In another study by Topazian et al. including 60 patients, patients were divided into 4 groups and saline, 100, 300 and 500 U BTX injections were administered using guided ultrasound. After 16 weeks of follow-up, there was no difference in weight loss in the groups (14).

"Two meta-analyses have been published on gastric BTX application. The first, published by Bang et al. in 2015, evaluates 7 studies and BTX application was found to be more effective than placebo (15). The 2nd meta-analysis was published in 2017 and it was concluded that the application of BTX to the stomach has no effect on weight loss (16).

"In our study, at the end of the 6-month follow-up after 300 U of BTX application, when the patients were compared according to their weight status, there was an average decrease of 3.3 kg (P = .03). As many as 6 patients could not lose any weight. However, 4 patients were able to lose more than 50% of their excess weight (6-15 kg). The remaining 3 patients were able to lose 25% of their excess weight. When this comparison was made in terms of BMI, after 6 months, a decrease of 1.17 kg/m2 was detected in patients (P = .032).

"Gastric BTX application has recently become one of the frequently used weight loss methods in our country. The reason might be that it is non-invasive and perceived as a completely risk-free weight-loss therapy. In our study, no complications developed in the patients administered BTX. In fact, there were no serious side effects reported in clinical studies either. Only in one case report, total gastric necrosis after BTX application was reported which necessitated total gastrectomy (17). In the report published in 2008 due to various indications for BTX application, the American Food and Drug Administration (FDA) reported 16 deaths due to respiratory arrest aspiration pneumonia (17,18) From this perspective, gastric BTX should not be seen as a completely risk-free application.

"In our study, only overweight and type 1 obese individuals without comorbidity were included. Morbidly obese individuals were not included. Participants received a single session of BTX application. With repeated BTX applications, no evidence has been obtained as to whether a more effective weight loss can be achieved in this study."

It remains to be seen how effective this modality is in the short and long-term management of obesity. This report appears to document one of the risk factors of therapeutic botulinum toxin injection, that is, the development of clinical botulism. With this cluster of cases, one would suspect problems with dosing and/or administration techniques. - Mod.LL

column3: ECDC Communicable Disease Threats Report Week 10, 5-11 Mar 2023Iatrogenic botulism, exposure in Turkey---------------------------------------------------------------Overview--------As of [Fri 10 Mar 2023], Germany reports 12 cases of clinical botulism, apparently iatrogenic, due to intragastric injection of botulism neurotoxin (BoNT). The cases are middle-aged adults, originating from different regions of Germany, who underwent treatments with 1000-1500 units of BoNT in Turkey between [22 and 25 Feb 2023]. The clinical presentation of the cases ranged from mild to severe; several cases have been hospitalized among whom a number are reported to have been admitted to Intensive Care Units (ICU). Among 8 cases with known information, all received treatment at the same clinic in Istanbul, Turkey. There is no indication of treatment being organized by a commercial medical travel company at this time. Information received from patient interviews indicated a WhatsApp group was used to contact the hospital. A total of 3 cases who recalled the name of the BoNT product used on them, reported having been treated with one and the same product.Austria reports 1 case (female; 25-44 years) of apparently iatrogenic botulism after intragastric injection of BoNTs administered in Turkey on [22 Feb 2023]. The case reported receiving treatment, which was self-arranged, at the same clinic as the cases in Germany and Switzerland. The patient was hospitalized with botulism symptoms (ptosis, dysphagia, dyspnea, neck weakness, generalised muscle weakness).Switzerland (information reported to ECDC by France on behalf of Switzerland) reports 1 suspected case of botulism (female, 45-64 years), probably associated with intragastric injection of BoNT, also administered in Turkey on [22 Feb 2023]. The case reported receiving treatment at the same clinic as the cases in Germany and Austria.Background information----------------------In 2019, France reported a suspected case of botulism (female; 25-44 years) following an intragastric injection of BoNT in Egypt (in order to lose weight), with hospitalization in France.A WHO medical product alert from August [2022], reported 5 falsified batches of a BoNT product detected in 5 countries - Jordan [May 2022], Turkey [May 2022], Kuwait [June 2022], United Kingdom [June 2022], and Poland [July 2022]. It is not known, however, if these batches have been used for treatment in the cases reported so far. Outbreaks of iatrogenic botulism, sometimes linked to counterfeit or unlicensed BoNT, have also been reported in the past following different clinical procedures, for example in Egypt and Turkey.Botulism is a serious neuroparalytic illness caused by BoNTs mainly produced by the bacterium, _Clostridium botulinum_. The disease naturally occurs in 4 different forms: a) food-borne botulism, b) intestinal botulism, c) infant botulism, and d) wound botulism. There are 2 other forms of botulism that do not occur naturally: a) inhalation botulism and b) iatrogenic botulism, which is the most recent human-made form of botulism. Intoxication may occur as an adverse event following the administration of BoNTs for therapeutic or cosmetic reasons.While it is considered rare, individuals receiving BoNT injections for cosmetic purposes (for example: for facial wrinkle lines) or therapeutic treatments (for example: for management of muscle spasticity), may develop iatrogenic botulism if they are injected with an excessive dose of the BoNTs.Symptoms of iatrogenic botulism are characterized by weakness and difficulty swallowing. Toxicities following cosmetic treatment include ophthalmological and oropharyngeal symptoms (blurred vision, drooping eyelid, difficulty swallowing, and dry mouth) while toxicities following therapeutic treatments are linked with difficulty breathing and weakness. The symptoms of botulism can be very severe requiring intensive-care treatment as well as the administration of an anti-toxin. Even when such treatments are available, complete recovery usually takes weeks to months. Limited information is available quantifying mortality in iatrogenic botulism cases. For foodborne botulism, 5-10% of cases are fatal.Further information about botulism can be found on the websites of ECDC, US CDC, and WHO. ECDC assessment---------------This is a multi-country outbreak of at least 14 cases of iatrogenic botulism in Germany (12 cases), Austria (1 case), and Switzerland (1 case) with gastric injections of BoNT administered in Istanbul, Turkey on dates between [22 and 25 Feb 2023]. The cases are middle-aged adults. Among cases with known information in Germany (8 cases), Austria (1 case), and Switzerland (1 case), all are reported to have received treatment at the same clinic. Considering the possible variation in the clinical presentation of botulism illness it is possible that some cases are yet to be identified. New cases may occur, particularly among those traveling to Turkey for medical treatments involving intragastric injection of BoNTs.Individuals who have traveled to Istanbul, Turkey for intragastric BoNT treatment and experience symptoms consistent with botulism illness (weakness, difficulty breathing, and/or swallowing), are advised to seek medical attention as soon as possible. Patients may inform their healthcare provider of the present ongoing multi-country outbreak.Actions-------ECDC is monitoring the event in EpiPulse and via Epidemic Intelligence activities and is sharing information through the CDTR report. A teleconference call is scheduled with affected and involved countries, DG SANTE, and WHO- Europe on [Fri 10 Mar 2023]. column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - INDONESIA (04): (EAST JAVA) SEASONAL FLOODING, RATS
*******************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 10 Mar 2023 19:43 WIB
Source: Kompas [in Indonesian, machine trans., edited]
<https://regional.kompas.com/read/2023/03/10/194327378/5-kasus-leptospirosis-ditemukan-di-sampang-warga-diminta-jaga-kebersihan>


Five cases of leptospirosis or rat urine [?] were found in Sampang District, East Java. Based on data from the Sampang Regency Health and Family Planning Office, the 5 cases of leptospirosis were registered from January [2023] to early March 2023.

Head of the Community Health and Family Planning Office of Sampang, Agus Mulyadi, said that 5 people were infected with leptospirosis when the flood affected Sampang Regency. When the seasonal disaster comes, rats appear a lot. "Basically, leptospirosis easily infects residents during floods or stagnant water. _Leptospira_ bacteria can enter the body through the skin, especially of those with open wounds," said Agus in his statement on Friday [10 Mar 2023].

[Byline: Ach Fawaidi]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[For a discussion of leptospirosis, please see my moderator comments in a prior ProMED post (Leptospirosis - Indonesia: (YO) rain, fatal 20220621.8703994).

In the past month (March 2023) ProMED posted several reports of leptospirosis in Central Java, Yogyakarta, West Java, and East Java, Indonesia (see also's below), attributed to heavy seasonal rainfall and flooding. ProMED posted a report that most cases of leptospirosis occurred in Pacitan Regency, East Java, in 9 of its 12 districts, and is also being attributed to seasonal flooding, due to heavy rainfall, and increasing numbers of rats (Leptospirosis - Indonesia (03): (JI) fatal, floods 20230307.8708784).

The above news article reports cases of leptospirosis in Sampang District, Sampang Regency, East Java. Sampang Regency is located on Madura Island, off the northeastern coast of Java
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampang_(town)>). A map showing the location of Sampang Regency, East Java, Indonesia, can be found at <https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sampang+Regency,+East+Java,+Indonesia>. - Mod.ML

ProMED map of East Java, Indonesia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708927,68918>]

AVIAN INFLUENZA (47): AMERICAS (CHILE) POULTRY, HPAI
****************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>

International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 13 Mar 2023 19:31 CLST
Source: Agricultural and Livestock Service, Chile Ministry of Agriculture [in Spanish, machine trans., abridged, edited]
<https://www.sag.gob.cl/noticias/ministerio-de-agricultura-confirma-primer-caso-de-influenza-aviar-en-plantel-productivo-y-sag-auto-suspende-exportaciones-de-carnes-de-ave>


The Agricultural and Livestock Service, SAG, confirmed the detection of the 1st case of avian influenza in the private sector, corresponding to an industrial poultry farm located in O'Higgins region. After the finding, the SAG activated the existing protocol that involves the slaughter of affected birds and the isolation of the area, sanitary measures that aim to prevent the spread of the disease to other poultry farms.

The Minister of Agriculture, Esteban Valenzuela, specified that it is "a confirmed case in a commercial premises in the western sector of the Rancagua commune. The SAG has proceeded to control the area and in addition, immediately and in compliance with the highest standards, the World Organization for Animal Health (OMSA) has been informed and, therefore, the export of poultry meat has been ceased," said the authority.

The measure, taken by the SAG, translates into the self-suspension of the certification of exports of national poultry products, a decision reported to the WOAH and all its trading partners.

Regarding this, Carlos Orellana, head of SAG's Livestock Protection Division, explained that the measure taken by the Service is based on the fact that "we are now seeing the involvement of a commercial farm, we are talking about 40 000 breeding birds. This farm is located in Region VI [O'Higgins Region], and as a precaution, we have suspended our export certification," he said.

The SAG reaffirms the urgent call to poultry owners to take extreme biosecurity measures in their facilities, mainly locking up their birds to avoid contact with wild birds or others that could be affected, to avoid the contagion with highly pathogenic avian influenza and in case of suspected symptoms to contact the SAG immediately.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[According to the latest follow up report sent to the WOAH on 13 Mar 2023, to date, Chile has reported 66 outbreaks of HPAI subtype H5N1 in wild birds and in backyard premises. See the report at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4775>.

Chile has also reported HPAI H5N1 in sea lions (3 cases) and marine otters (1 case) <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4922>

column3: The Agricultural and Livestock Service, SAG, confirmed the detection of the 1st case of avian influenza in the private sector, corresponding to an industrial poultry farm located in O'Higgins region. After the finding, the SAG activated the existing protocol that involves the slaughter of affected birds and the isolation of the area, sanitary measures that aim to prevent the spread of the disease to other poultry farms.The Minister of Agriculture, Esteban Valenzuela, specified that it is "a confirmed case in a commercial premises in the western sector of the Rancagua commune. The SAG has proceeded to control the area and in addition, immediately and in compliance with the highest standards, the World Organization for Animal Health (OMSA) has been informed and, therefore, the export of poultry meat has been ceased," said the authority.The measure, taken by the SAG, translates into the self-suspension of the certification of exports of national poultry products, a decision reported to the WOAH and all its trading partners.Regarding this, Carlos Orellana, head of SAG's Livestock Protection Division, explained that the measure taken by the Service is based on the fact that "we are now seeing the involvement of a commercial farm, we are talking about 40 000 breeding birds. This farm is located in Region VI [O'Higgins Region], and as a precaution, we have suspended our export certification," he said.The SAG reaffirms the urgent call to poultry owners to take extreme biosecurity measures in their facilities, mainly locking up their birds to avoid contact with wild birds or others that could be affected, to avoid the contagion with highly pathogenic avian influenza and in case of suspected symptoms to contact the SAG immediately.--Communicated by:ProMED[According to the latest follow up report sent to the WOAH on 13 Mar 2023, to date, Chile has reported 66 outbreaks of HPAI subtype H5N1 in wild birds and in backyard premises. See the report at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4775>.Chile has also reported HPAI H5N1 in sea lions (3 cases) and marine otters (1 case) <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4922>ProMED map of Chile: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708926,4960>]
column4: Agricultural and Livestock Service, Chile Ministry of Agriculture

column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - USA: (CALIFORNIA) SEA LION
******************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 12 Mar 2023 5:00 AM PT
Source: The San Diego Union-Tribune [edited]
<https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/story/2023-03-12/sea-lion-rescued-from-la-jolla-cove-treated-for-rare-contagious-bacteria-dozens-of-rocks-in-belly>


When the folks at SeaWorld's animal rescue team saw a lethargic juvenile sea lion at La Jolla Cove [San Diego County, California], they knew something was wrong. The problem turned out to be 2 things, both of them rather unexpected.

First, the male sea lion rescued on 12 Jan 2023 tested positive for a rare and contagious bacterium that is harmful -- and potentially deadly -- to both animals and humans. It was the 1st time the bacteria have been found in local waters in 8 years, SeaWorld San Diego veterinarian Dr Kelsey Herrick said Friday [9 Mar 2023].

Then there was the surprising matter of the rocks in the animal's stomach. Sea lions eat them from time to time. But this 1.5-old pinniped had gulped down about 100. "That was very striking," Herrick said. "We were like, 'Wow, that is a lot of rocks.'" And that find earned the sea lion an affectionate nickname: Rocky.

Herrick said there is no evidence of a local outbreak of leptospirosis, a potentially lethal bacterial disease. It's also what she called a "zoonotic" pathogen, in that it can transfer from animals to humans and back.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, bacteria that cause leptospirosis spread through the urine of infected animals, and can survive for weeks or months in water or soil.

After SeaWorld San Diego found Rocky, the organization rescued a 2nd sea lion -- this one at Torrey Pines [San Diego County, California] -- that tested positive, the veterinarian said. But it had other medical issues and was euthanized.

Herrick said the medical team suspected Rocky had leptospirosis early on -- the sea lion was drinking water excessively, and the disease affects the kidneys -- so the team started antibiotic treatment and kept the animal in quarantine. The team also had to give Rocky fluids at 3 to 4 times the usual dose.

The sea lion started eating but still "looked like he didn't feel good," the veterinarian said. The medical team X-rayed the animal and found the rocks, dozens of them.

Herrick leans toward the possibility that after Rocky caught the bacteria, the animal slurped up the rocks while drinking sea water excessively -- a behavior that itself is odd. Sea lions don't drink water. They get their water from eating fish.

The medical team tried to get Rocky to vomit some of the stones out, Herrick said, but "his stomach was too heavy." So the team performed 5 procedures over 5 weeks, during which the doctors removed several rocks from Rocky's stomach each time.

"He also removed some rocks on his own -- in 2 different ways," Rescue Team member Jeni Smith said -- with a laugh -- in a video interview provided by SeaWorld. "We removed over a 1.5 lb [about 680 gm] of rocks from that California sea lion -- which is crazy."

Getting rid of the rocks cleared room in Rocky's belly for food. When the team rescued the sea lion in January [2023], he weighed nearly 63 pounds. By the time he was released back into the ocean 3 Mar 2023], he was pushing 95 pounds [about 29 kg].

Rocky had company on his return home. SeaWorld San Diego also released an elephant seal found in Imperial Beach in January [2023]. The seal, a female, was dehydrated and suffering from more than 10 cookie-cutter shark bites. "Poor thing had bites everywhere, Smith said. "Her wounds have healed," Smith said. "She looks amazing and she gets a 2nd chance."

It was the only elephant seal among the 17 wild animals SeaWorld San Diego rescued and brought to its facility this year [2023]. Rocky was one of 10 rescued sea lions. The other rescues this year include 1 harbor seal, 2 sea turtles, and 3 Guadalupe fur seals.

The goal is to heal them and return them to the ocean.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The 1st mortality event in sea lions (_Zalophus californianus_) caused by _Leptospira interrogans_ was reported in 1970, in wild populations along the coast of California and Oregon (USA). Thereafter, leptospirosis outbreaks have been occurring at regular intervals, and leptospirosis has been implicated as a cause of premature parturition in California sea lions. The serovar implicated is Pomona. The occurrence of the disease appears to be cyclic. Every 4-5 years there are peaks of exposure (seroprevalence increases), which coincides with sea lion strandings due to leptospirosis. - Mod.PMB

ProMED map of California, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708925,787>]

Date: Tue 14 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4950>


India - high pathogenicity avian influenza viruses (poultry) (inf. with)
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 2 Feb 2023
Confirmed: 17 Feb 2023
Reported: 9 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: recurrence
Date of previous recurrence: 20 Sep 2019
Manifestation of disease: clinical disease
Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus
Serotype: H5N1
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Government Poultry Farm, Bokaro, Jharkhand
Started: 2 Feb 2023
Epidemiological unit: farm
Affected animals:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 6147 / 2615 / 2615 / 3532 / - /-

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive

Control measures at event level
Domestic control measures applied: surveillance within the restricted zone; surveillance outside the restricted zone; stamping out; quarantine; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; movement control; disinfection.

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result
National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India / birds / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 17 Feb 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above. - Mod.CRD]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[In addition to this current case, during 2021 and 2022 India reported several cases associated with HPAI H5N1 and H5N2. The situation for those events was as follows:

In 2022, HPAI H5N1: event started in February 2022; 3 outbreaks were reported in Maharashtra state, and the event was communicated as resolved in February 2023. See the latest follow-up report dated 9 Feb 2023, at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4331?reportId=159232>

column2:
PERTUSSIS UPDATE (05): CANADA (ONTARIO) LOW VACCINATION COVERAGE, 2022-2023
***************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 12 Mar 20232:46 PM CDT
Source: Precision Vaccinations [edited]
<https://www.precisionvaccinations.com/2023/03/12/canadas-whooping-cough-outbreak-centered-southwest-ottawa>


Parents living in St Thomas, Elgin, and Oxford counties in Ottawa were recently advised to be alert to respiratory symptoms, which are particularly dangerous in young children. Symptoms of the vaccine-preventable disease pertussis start with a runny nose or nasal congestion, sneezing, mild cough, and mild fever.

Southwestern Public Health, which is located between Detroit and Toronto, announced on 8  Mar 2023, parents and guardians should keep themselves and their children up to date with the pertussis vaccine after a recent dramatic rise in cases in the region.

"Our region has seen 82 confirmed cases of pertussis between January 2022 and 28 Feb 2023. This represents about 40% of the provincial total from that time period." "Combine this with the number of children who are unvaccinated or under-vaccinated, and I am concerned in particular for the youngest members of our community," says Dr Ninh Tran, Medical Officer of Health for Southwestern Public Health, in a related press release [<https://www.swpublichealth.ca/en/news/swph-warns-community-of-rising-cases-of-pertussis.aspx>].

Pertussis, commonly known as whooping cough, is a vaccine-preventable disease. This vaccine is routinely administered to children along with protection from polio, tetanus, and diphtheria (DTaP). In the US, DTaP vaccines such as Boostrix are offered at clinics and pharmacies. Pertussis is very contagious and spreads via droplets from the noses and mouths of those who are infected. The cough, which can last anywhere from 2 to 8 weeks, gets progressively worse and may lead to vomiting or trouble breathing and coughing up mucous. It can often be recognized by the loud "whooping" sound that occurs when the child is inhaling after a coughing spell. Untreated pertussis in infants can lead to hospitalization, brain damage, and death.

Furthermore, new research indicates an expecting mother can take action to protect her future child. According to an Original Investigation published by JAMA Pediatrics in February 2023 [<https://www.precisionvaccinations.com/maternal-vaccination-reduces-whopping-cough>], maternal Tdap vaccination reduces pertussis burden in infants (2 months). "I have 2 asks of our local parents. The first is that you make yourself familiar with the symptoms of pertussis and seek medical care if your child has these symptoms. It can be treated with antibiotics, and after 5 days on the treatment, the person can no longer spread the disease to others. Second, please contact your family healthcare provider or Southwestern Public Health to get your child's routine vaccinations up to date. The vaccine is free, and we have openings in our clinics throughout the month of March 2023," adds Tran.

Ottawa residents requiring a public health vaccination clinic appointment can book online at <http://www.swpublichealth.ca/booking>.

[Byline: Karen McClorey Hackett]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED posts: Pertussis update (06): Afghanistan, fatal 20221129.8706974 and Pertussis update (05): Bolivia, alert 20221122.8706855.

The news article above reports that pertussis is occurring in Elgin, St Thomas, and Oxford County, which are located in the Southwestern subregion of the Canadian province of Ontario (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwestern_Ontario>). Elgin is a county (pop., 50 069 in 2016); St Thomas is a city (pop., 42 918 in 2021) and seat of Elgin County; Oxford County (pop., 121 781 in 2021] is a regional municipality, but has retained the word "county" in its name (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_County,_Ontario>). Southwestern Ontario occupies most of the Ontario Peninsula bounded by Lake Huron to the north and northwest, Lake Erie to the south, and Central Ontario and the Golden Horseshoe to the east.

ProMED recently reported pertussis in the Wellington Dufferin Guelph Public Health Region, also located in Southwestern Ontario, Canada (Pertussis update (04): Canada (ON) more cases, low vaccination coverage, 2022 20230309.8708832). A map showing the locations of Elgin County and Wellington County (in the Wellington Dufferin Guelph Public Health Region) in Southwestern Ontario can be found at <https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Wellington+County,+Ontario,+Canada/Elgin+County,+ON,+Canada>. - Mod.ML
