column2:
PIGEON BREEDERS' LUNG - INDIA: (MAHARASHTRA) MORE CASES, ALERT
**************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 7 Mar 2023 02:01 PM IST
Source: Times Now News [edited]
<https://www.timesnownews.com/health/hypersensitive-pneumonia-pigeon-droppings-on-rise-officials-warn-people-against-feeding-birds-article-98472848>


Municipal Corporation officials in Maharashtra's Thane have warned against feeding pigeons as cases of hypersensitive pneumonia, a lung disease, are on the rise.

The Thane Municipal Corporation or TMC had put up several posters in the city recently to spread public awareness about the disease, which spreads due to pigeon droppings, as bacteria, and mold causes inflammation in the lungs, completely destroying them.

Health experts say that the numbers shoot up in people who live in the vicinity of droppings and feathers accumulating nearby. The breathable antigen arising from the bird droppings and feathers goes into the lung and leads to an immunological reaction, which damages the lung.

The symptoms of hypersensitivity pneumonitis can be acute or chronic. Acute symptoms come on within a few hours of being around an allergen and last a few hours or days. Chronic symptoms on the other hand can develop slowly and get worse over time. A few common signs of the ailment are breathlessness, dry cough, tightness in the chest, chills, fatigue, high fever, muscle pains, chronic cough, and unexpected weight loss.

How can hypersensitive pneumonia be diagnosed? Diagnoses for hypersensitivity pneumonitis can be done based on your symptoms and personal history, physical exam, and a few other tests. A few of these tests include:
- Allergy tests: this is done through blood samples that check if you have signs of a reaction to the allergens.
- Imaging: chest x-rays and CT scans can look for the damage.
- Pulmonary function tests: most lung function tests involve breathing into a tube attached to a machine to measure how well your lungs are working.
- Bronchoscopy: a small, flexible tube that passes through your nose or mouth can view the inside of your lungs and collect samples.

Ways to prevent hypersensitive pneumonia: according to health experts, hypersensitive pneumonia is not reversible, and so it is best to prevent the damage caused by the ailment. Avoiding exposure to allergens that cause lung inflammation to reduce your risk include:
- Wearing masks and personal protection gear if your workplace has a lot of birds and animals around, or there is heavy usage of animals, lumber, paper, grain, etc.
- Keep humidifiers, hot tubs, and heating and cooling systems clean and in good condition.
- Avoid feather-filled bedding. Keep your pets' living spaces clean.

[Byline: Ashima Sharda Mahindra]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is due to a hypersensitivity reaction in the lung after inhalation of aerosolized particles, 4 to 5 micrometers, which contain the disease-evoking antigens, in susceptible individuals (<https://www.scopus.com/record/display.uri?eid=2-s2.0-0035464580&origin=inward&txGid=822c73c2eb87a0758ad54ac2fc2fb5aa>). The resulting lung disease carries various names, such as pigeon breeders' lung, bird fanciers' lung, mushroom-pickers' disease, grain-handler's lung, bagassosis, lumber/paper mill workers' lung, chemical worker's lung and farmers' lung, depending on the type of exposure (<https://erj.ersjournals.com/content/48/3/818>).

In pigeon breeders' lung, patients have flu-like symptoms (chills, fever, cough, myalgia, and dyspnea) when exposed to pigeons and recover with cessation of exposure. However, with repetitive exposure, chronic symptoms of dyspnea and cough may develop, without remission after cessation of exposure.

The diagnosis is made from a combination of clinical features, radiographic abnormalities, lung function tests and immunological tests (e.g., counterimmunoelectrophoresis (CIE) and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)). Avoidance of the disease-evoking antigen is key the treatment.

Thane (pop., over 8 million residents 2011) is a district in the Indian State of Maharashtra. The city of Thane is the district's headquarters. The Arabian Sea forms the western boundary, and the Mumbai Suburban district is to the south west. A map showing the location of Thane district can be found at <https://www.google.com/maps/place/Thane,+Maharashtra,+India>. - Mod.ML

ProMED map of Maharashtra, India: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708833,6243>]

PERTUSSIS UPDATE (04): CANADA (ONTARIO) MORE CASES, LOW VACCINATION COVERAGE, 2022
**********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 8 Mar 2023 6:08 PM CET
Source: Kitchener CTV News [edited]
<https://kitchener.ctvnews.ca/twelve-cases-of-whooping-cough-cases-identified-in-wellington-dufferin-guelph-1.6302487>


Twelve cases of pertussis -- also known as whooping cough -- have been reported in Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph [Ontario] since the fall [2022] and local public health says that's higher than normal.

In a news release issued Tuesday [7 Mar 2023], Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph Public Health (WDGPH) said many individuals may be behind on their vaccinations because of COVID-19 delays.

"Pertussis is serious -- especially for our children," Dr Nicola Mercer, medical officer of health for Wellington-Dufferin-Guelph said in the release. "While we have only seen a few cases so far, it is particularly dangerous for children under one year of age and those who are not fully vaccinated. Infection in these individuals can result in hospitalization or death." Public Health said now is the time to get fully vaccinated "as we engage in more community activities." Vaccination is the best way to prevent whooping cough, the release said. Vaccines are available at public health clinics or doctor's offices.

Whooping cough is a bacterial infection that spreads through droplets that are sprayed when someone sick with the disease sneezes, coughs, or talks. According to public health, it could also be spread by direct contact with objects used by someone sick.

Early symptoms of whooping cough resemble a cold with a runny nose and a cough. "The cough becomes more frequent and severe," WDGPH said. Public Health said that a child may gag, vomit, have trouble breathing, or give a loud "whoop" sound when breathing in, but not all infected persons make that sound. If these symptoms develop, experts advise you to contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[For a discussion of pertussis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED posts: Pertussis update (06): Afghanistan, fatal 20221129.8706974 and Pertussis update (05): Bolivia, alert 20221122.8706855.

The Wellington Dufferin Guelph Public Health Region includes all of Wellington County, Dufferin County, and the City of Guelph (<https://wdgpublichealth.ca/covid-19/covid-19-information-public/status-cases-wdg>). Wellington (pop., 241 026 residents) (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wellington_County,_Ontario>) and Dufferin (pop., 61 735 in 2016) (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dufferin_County>) are adjacent counties located in Southwestern Ontario, Canada and are part of the "Greater Golden Horseshoe", which surrounds the western end of Lake Ontario. Guelph, the seat of Wellington County is about 70 km (43 mi) west of Downtown Toronto (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guelph>). A map showing the location of this region can be found at <https://www.google.com/maps/place/Wellington+County,+ON,+Canada>. - Mod.ML

column2:
SYPHILIS - USA (06): (OREGON) MEN, WOMEN, CONGENITAL, INCREASING CASES, 2022
****************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: The Lund Report, Salem State Journal report [abridged, edited]
<https://www.thelundreport.org/content/syphilis-rise-marion-county-residents-encouraged-get-tested>


Syphilis cases are spiking in Marion County [Oregon], with a 216% increase from 2018 to 2022, Marion County Health and Human Services data show. The rise in cases is widespread, according to the health department. It said there was no clear reason for the spike. Officials are encouraging anyone age 45 and younger who has been sexually active to get tested.

"Syphilis rates are rising among men, women, and newborns. Fortunately, syphilis remains 100% preventable and treatable when affected community members have access to healthcare," Marion County public health officer Dr Caroline Castillo said.

Syphilis spreads through person-to-person sexual contact, mainly through direct contact with a syphilitic sore, which may not always be easy to see. Some people can have syphilis without even knowing it.

Congenital syphilis cases, which are contracted during pregnancy, are also on the rise. There has been a 235% increase in congenital syphilis nationwide since 2016, preliminary Center for Disease Control data shows. Congenital syphilis can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, illness, and death in newborns.

Marion County has also seen an increase in gonorrhea and chlamydia cases, according to county data.

The county health department provides free sexually transmitted infection testing and treatment at its public clinic at 3180 Center Street NE in Salem. To schedule an appointment, call 503-588-5342. Everyone is eligible for testing at the public clinic, even those without health insurance.

Who is impacted? Anyone who is sexually active can contract syphilis. The only way to fully avoid syphilis or other sexually transmitted infections is to not have sexual contact. The risk of contracting syphilis can be reduced by properly using condoms and getting tested regularly when sexually active.

In Marion County, the highest rate of syphilis is among adults aged 20 to 39. The county is currently seeing more positive cases in white men but emphasized the rise in cases is not isolated to a specific group or demographic.

Positive test ... what next? Syphilis testing is done using a blood test. If the test is positive, it is typically treated with penicillin. Individuals who receive a positive test can receive treatment at the Marion County Health clinic or from their local healthcare provider. Marion County Health can provide bus passes to individuals needing transportation to the clinic, and sometimes it will give gas cards to those with financial barriers. Marion County Health stressed the importance of seeking treatment after testing positive. Untreated Syphilis can cause long-term health problems such as dementia, heart disease, nerve damage, and blindness.

[Byline: Sydney Wyatt]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[Marion County (pop., 345 920 in 2020), located in the Willamette Valley, is one of the 36 counties in the US state of Oregon; the county seat is Salem, which is also the state capital of Oregon (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marion_County,_Oregon>). The Willamette Valley is a 150-mile (240 km) long valley in central Oregon, along which the Willamette River flows, surrounded by the Cascade Range to the east and the Oregon Coast Range to the west (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willamette_Valley>). A map showing the location of Marion County can be found at <https://www.google.com/maps/place/Marion+County,+OR>.

For a discussion of syphilis in the USA, please see my moderator comments in ProMED post Syphilis - USA (12): (AL) congenital, increasing cases, RFI 20220922.8705732. A discussion of congenital syphilis in the United States can be found in my moderator comments in ProMED post Syphilis - USA (03): (OK) congenital, increasing cases, RFI 20230223.8708550. - Mod.ML

ProMED map of Oregon, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708831,5700>]

column2:
DENGUE/DHF UPDATE (02): AFRICA, ASIA, THERAPEUTIC DEVELOPMENT HALTED
********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Sudan (Khartoum): fatal, increase
[2] Malaysia (Kelantan)
[3] Malaysia: 212% increase in cases in 1st 2 months of 2023
[4] Atea Pharmaceuticals: dengue drug development halted

******
[1] Sudan (Khartoum): fatal, increase
Date: Sun 5 Mar 2023
Source: Dabanga Sudan [abridged, edited]
<https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/two-more-die-as-sudan-dengue-fever-epidemic-spreads-in-khartoum-state>


The Ministry of Health of Khartoum state has initiated several interventions, after 2 people suffering from dengue fever died on Wednesday [1 Mar 2023]. In a statement on Friday [3 Mar 2023], the ministry said that the number of confirmed cases of dengue fever has risen to 487, which represents an increase of 30 cases since Wednesday. These figures include 103 patients who are affected by both dengue fever and malaria.

The number of suspected cases has reached 1055, which is 106 more than on Wednesday.

According to the reports, the disease is now prevalent in the densely populated Ombadda and Karari localities in Omdurman, and Khartoum locality.

The Ministry announced interventions to contain the spread of dengue fever, including inspection and home education to reduce breeding sites for mosquitoes inside homes, spraying with machines carried on vehicles, and treatment of cases, as well as activities to raise health awareness.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of  Sudan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708830,44264>]

******
[2] Malaysia (Kelantan)
Date: Sun 5 Mar 2023 4:42 PM MYT
Source: Malaymail.com, Malaysian National News Agency (Bernama) report [abridged, edited]
<https://www.malaymail.com/news/malaysia/2023/03/05/health-dept-increased-number-of-dengue-cases-in-kelantan/58101>


The cumulative number of dengue cases in Kelantan up to the epidemiological week 8 this year [week of 20 Feb 2023] was up by 41, with 280 recorded compared to 239 during the same period last year [2022].

"However, no death has been recorded so far and one of the contributing factors to the increase in dengue cases is the unpredictable weather," said Kelantan state Health Department (JKNK) director Datuk Dr Zaini Hussin

He told reporters this after the Syariah Compliant Nursing Course opening ceremony at Kolej Poly-Tech Mara (KPTM) Kota Bharu today [5 Mar 2023], which was also attended by KPTM Kota Bharu deputy academic president Mohd Sahidi Yaakob.

Elaborating, Dr Zaini said a total of 97 784 premises were inspected and 463 were issued with compound notices, amounting to RM 231 500 [about USD 51 200], under the Destruction of Disease-Bearing Insects Act (APSPP) 1975 (Act 154) for being breeding grounds for _Aedes_ mosquitoes.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

******
[3] Malaysia: 212% increase in cases in 1st 2 months of 2023
Date: Thu 8 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<https://outbreaknewstoday.com/malaysia-dengue-cases-up-more-than-200-in-2023/>


The Malaysia Ministry of Health reports 19 450 cumulative dengue fever cases through the 1st 2 months of 2023, an increase of some 212 percent compared to the same period in 2022 (6229).

In 2023 to date, 15 dengue-related fatalities have been reported in Malaysia, compared to 2 deaths same period last year.

Dengue is a disease caused by a virus spread through mosquito bites. The disease can take up to 2 weeks to develop with illness generally lasting less than a week. Health effects from dengue include fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, rash, muscle and joint pain, and minor bleeding.

Dengue can become severe within a few hours. Severe dengue is a medical emergency, usually requiring hospitalization. In severe cases, health effects can include hemorrhage (uncontrolled bleeding), shock (seriously low blood pressure), organ failure, and death.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Malaysia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708830,147>]

******
[4] Atea Pharmaceuticals: dengue drug development halted
Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023 06:50 AM
Source: Fierce Biotech [edited]
<https://www.fiercebiotech.com/biotech/atea-dumps-dengue-drug-unevaluable-endpoint-causes-forecast-rd-timelines-costs-spiral>


Clinical data have convinced Atea Pharmaceuticals it cannot make the numbers add up in dengue fever. Based on the results, the antiviral biotech calculates it would take at least 3 years and cost several hundred million dollars to run phase 2 studies, prompting it to put the program on the back burner.

Atea ran 2 small clinical trials of AT-752, a double prodrug of a guanosine nucleotide analog, to assess its potential in the treatment and prevention of dengue. The results precipitated the end of the program.

In the 1st cohort of the treatment trial, investigators randomized 21 dengue-infected patients to receive the oral drug AT-752 or a placebo 3 times a day for 5 days. Atea designed the study to assess change in dengue virus load from baseline. The problem? Some patients already had low or undetectable levels of dengue at baseline. As such, Atea found the primary endpoint was "unevaluable."

Atea thinks participants presented too late in the course of the infection to evaluate change in viral load. The clinical trial sought to mitigate that risk by limiting participation to people who had developed a fever in the previous 48 hours, but that inclusion criteria may have failed to have the desired effect.

"Patients sometimes have a hard time identifying when the fever started exactly. And so they probably presented later by the time we were able to enroll them," Arantxa Horga, MD, chief medical officer at Atea, explained on a conference call with investors. "Another factor is that the test that we use for enrollment...is an antigen test. They're not as sensitive as PCR, but sites don't have PCRs available. So, we will need to develop better, more sensitive diagnostic tests."

Atea's human challenge infection study encountered other problems. The study was designed to test the ability of AT-752 to prevent dengue infection, but results from the 5 healthy volunteers showed high variability in the levels of the virus and antigens as well as in the onset and severity of symptoms. Atea concluded it would need to test the drug candidate in more than 50 people to account for the variability.

The realization that it will take longer and cost more than expected to show whether AT-752 works led Atea to deprioritize the program. Atea, which ended last year [2022] with USD 646.7 million to its name, will focus on drugs against COVID-19 and hepatitis C. The narrowing of focus will extend Atea's runway out to 2026.

There is a chance another organization will step in and take AT-752 forward. Atea CEO Jean-Pierre Sommadossi, PhD, told investors there are nonprofit and government agencies that may be interested in the program, and, while the company isn't giving guidance on if and when a deal may happen, it is interested in discussing potential agreements with 3rd parties.

[Byline: Nick Paul Taylor]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The dengue situation in Asia and Africa continues much the same as it ended in 2022, breaking records for cases. Malaysia and Sudan have generated most media reports in the past several weeks so it will be interesting to see if dengue has finally plateaued in other hard-hit areas, or if they too will set monthly records. It is also worth noting that while the vaccine front has been much more promising of late, the difficulties in developing a therapeutic that can be evaluated in the face of endemic/epidemic dengue circulation pose unique challenges. Improvements in diagnostics and screening questions will be critical for therapeutic development to ensure trial enrollees are not already in middle to later stages of infection before initiation of treatment. - Mod.JH]

column2:
ADENOVIRUS - INDIA (04): (WEST BENGAL) FATAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 8 Mar 2023 05:36 PM IST
Source: Odisha TV, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]
<https://odishatv.in/news/national/adenovirus-three-more-child-deaths-reported-from-kolkata-198710>


Adding further panic over the adenovirus spread in West Bengal, the deaths of 3 more children, admitted to 2 hospitals in Kolkata with related symptoms, have been reported during the last 24 hours.

Of the 3 fresh deaths, 2 have been reported from Calcutta Medical College & Hospital and one from BC Roy Children's Hospital. Though the state Health Department has stopped issuing any bulletin on virus-related deaths, there are claims of 48 deaths during the last 11 days.

One of 2 children reported to have died at the Calcutta Medical College & Hospital is [SP] (10 months) of a family residing in Hooghly district. He was referred to the hospital from Imambara Sadar Hospital in Chinsurah in Hooghly.

The 2nd death in the same hospital during the last 24 hours was of [ST] (6 months). He was admitted to the hospital on 26 Feb 2023 with flu-like symptoms.

[SB] (10 months) also passed away in BC Roy Children's Hospital. One of his family members told media persons that he was admitted to the hospital a week back with a severe lung infection, fever, and breathing problems.

A senior state Health Department official said that because of the tendency of referring affected children from the district hospitals, the pressure on Kolkata, especially the BC Roy Children's Hospital is enormous and that is why the maximum number of child deaths during the last few days have been reported from city hospitals.

The department has already issued an advisory for doctors, especially paediatricians, to take special care of children being admitted with flu-like symptoms, especially those aged 2 years or below since they are most vulnerable to being affected by adenovirus. In wake of the alarming situation, the Health Department has cancelled all the leaves of staff for an indefinite period.

Special outdoor units have been opened at state-run hospitals with special paediatric units so that such cases do not have to wait at the general outdoor units.

So far there is no approved medicine or any specific line of treatment for adenovirus, which can spread through skin contact, by air through coughing and sneezing, and through an infected person's stools.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The number of fatalities attributable to adenovirus continues to be difficult to ascertain. Last week (week of 27 Feb 2023) there were approximately 12 deaths in the region, while this week the death toll has climbed to anywhere from 48 to 100 (the latter coming from <https://zeenews.india.com/india/adenovirus-linked-deaths-underreported-top-west-bengal-doctor-slams-mamata-banerjee-govt-claims-kids-not-getting-beds-2581430.html>).

The situation is further complicated by acute respiratory illness (ARI) cases due not only to adenovirus but to influenza, RSV, etc. With reports of H3N2 influenza infection surging in India, it too needs to be ruled out. - Mod.JH]

[It is not clear in how many cases in this ongoing outbreak of fatal acute respiratory tract infections in children, being attributed to adenovirus, have been laboratory-confirmed. The determination of the microbial etiology or etiologies in these infections is obviously important. ProMED would be very interested in the results of any laboratory testing that have been done in these cases to confirm the microbial etiology. - Mod.ML

column2:
RESPIRATORY VIRUSES: IMMUNOCOMPROMISED PATIENTS, 2 MONOCLONAL ANTIBODY COCKTAIL PROPHYLAXIS
*******************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023
Source: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center [abridged, edited]
<https://www.fredhutch.org/en/news/center-news/2023/03/rsv-respiratory-viruses-antibodies.html>


There are few complications of bone marrow transplantation more dangerous than a viral infection that heads for the lungs.

Jim Boonyaratanakornkit, MD, PhD, aims to do something about it. With a team of researchers at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, he is reporting progress on the development of an experimental drug combination to prevent infection by 4 common respiratory viruses. Before the emergence of COVID-19, these 4 have been blamed for more than half of serious lung infections in patients with compromised immune systems, such as those recovering from transplants.

In experiments described in the journal Nature Communications [see reference below], the team reports how they discovered 2 rare antibodies that, if combined into a "cocktail," can block infection by all 4 of those viruses: respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV; human metapneumovirus, or HMPV; and 2 types of human parainfluenza viruses, HPIV1 and HPIV3.

Respiratory viruses of all kinds are a serious threat for patients recovering from transplants of bone marrow or blood stem cells, while their new immune systems are gaining strength. Boonyaratanakornkit said 1/3 of those patients acquire a respiratory viral infection within 6 months; and in 1/3 of those, the virus progresses to the lower respiratory tract.

"Once the virus gains a foothold in the lower tract, little can be done," he said. "As a result, up to 40% of patients with lower tract disease die within 3 months."

RSV has been in the news lately because of a US outbreak last fall [2022] that led to a spike in hospitalizations of children in respiratory distress. In addition, a 1st ever vaccine for RSV is nearing US Food and Drug Administration approval for adults over 60. A new drug to prevent RSV in infants and children up to 24 months old is also under FDA review. It could be an improvement over an old standby, palivizumab, in use since 1998.

While these advances may be good news for young children, Fred Hutch's Boonyaratanakornkit said that cancer patients facing transplant have more complex needs because of the threats from multiple viruses.

"The new drugs and vaccines don't translate well into the immune compromised population," he said. "You really need to cover much more ground to make an impact on these patients. The key point of our work is that we wanted to go broad."

His team's answer is to produce a single drug, an infusion of immune-proteins called antibodies, that can block RSV and the other 3 viral threats at once. Their new paper describes how they came up with it, and although it has been tested only in hamsters so far, it has shown it can block infections by all 4 viruses.

Years more work is needed before a candidate drug can be readied for human clinical trials, and the Fred Hutch team is continuing to study ways to improve on antibodies they discovered and describe in their new paper.

It took some nifty lab detective work to find the 2 rare antibodies used in their formulation.

The ability to block 2 different viruses with one antibody is known as "cross-reactivity," a feature that is critical for giving one drug the capability to deal with multiple viruses.

One antibody, dubbed 3 x 1, is capable of blocking 2 different parainfluenza viruses. A 2nd antibody, which they call MxR, cross-reacts to both respiratory syncytial virus and human metapneumovirus (yes, they are a mouthful).

Boonyaratanakorkit's work on this project took off when he and Fred Hutch immunologist Justin Taylor, PhD, began tracking down antibodies that can block parainfluenza.

Despite the name, parainfluenza has nothing to do with the flu. Influenza and parainfluenza viruses may look similar under a microscope, but they are from entirely different viral families. Instead of causing respiratory illness in winter like influenza, parainfluenza causes disease in the other 9 months of the year.

Boonyaratanakornkit and Taylor's 1st success was with HPIV3. Their research focused on finding white blood cells, components of the immune system known as B cells, that produced antibodies that could block that virus. They came up with one that did.

Out of 200 million B-cell rich spleen cells, they fished out 2 rare B cells that were naturally cross reactive. Using laboratory techniques, they were able to generate multiple copies of just one of them. They now could grow a single antibody that could knock down both parainfluenza viruses. They named it 3 x 1.

"We didn't know that a cross-reactive antibody for these existed, but we found one we could use. It was just luck," Boonyaratanakornkit said.

With a somewhat similar screening process, they used bits of RSV and HMPV as bait in a pool of 200 million blood cells taken in blood draws. Out of that large pool, they were able to fish out B cells that made an antibody that would cross-react, or bind, to either of those viruses. They now had MxR.

When these rare immune proteins are produced in large numbers through a laboratory process, they are called monoclonal antibodies.

The researchers then made batches of 3 x 1 and MxR monoclonal antibodies and mixed them into a "cocktail." It is a single drug meant to be injected, designed to prevent infection by any of the 4 viruses. In tests with hamsters, the experimental drug bound to the viruses and prevented infection.

The Fred Hutch team is attempting to target 4 different viruses with their 2-antibody cocktail, delivered in a single injection. Boonyaratanakorkit said the 4 [viruses] they are targeting do not have a history of rapid genetic mutation, like influenza and SARS-CoV-2.

In future research, Boonyaratanakornkit and colleagues are hoping to genetically engineer their experimental drug so it will last longer in the body. Antibodies lose their potency over time, and longer-lasting versions of these 2 cross-reactive antibodies would hold an advantage.

Eventually, they hope to engineer a so-called "bi-specific" antibody, which on a single Y-shaped protein would contain, on the respective left and right arms of the protein, the separate binding sites for MxR and 3 x 1. This is a dream drug -- an infusion containing millions of antibodies of a single design that can efficiently knock out 4 dangerous respiratory viruses. "We're working on that," Boonyaratanakornkit said.

[Byline: Sabin Russell]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Reference
---------
Cabán M, Rodarte JV, Bibby M, et al. Cross-protective antibodies against common endemic respiratory viruses. Nat Commun. 2023; 14(1): 798; <https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-023-36459-3>

"- Respiratory viral infections [RVI; including RSV, adenovirus, influenza virus, parainfluenza virus, human metapneumovirus, and rhinovirus] are associated with high morbidity and mortality among transplant recipients [both solid organ (SOT) and hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) patients]
- The infections typically occur within the 1st 6 months after transplantation.
- Currently, management options are limited or lack strong clinical evidence.
- Infection control practices vary across institutions.
- Vigilant hand washing and other standard precautions are key to preventing outbreaks."

"Compared to immunocompetent hosts, SOT and HSCT patients are much more likely to experience a prolonged duration of illness, prolonged shedding, and progression of upper respiratory tract disease to pneumonia when infected with respiratory viruses. Adenovirus and respiratory syncytial virus tend to have the highest mortality and risk for disseminated disease, but all the RVIs are associated with higher morbidity and mortality in these patients than in the general population. These viruses are spread via direct contact and aerosolized droplets, and nosocomial spread has been reported."
(<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijid.2017.07.011>)
- Mod.LK]

Using laboratory techniques, they were able to generate multiple copies of just one of them. They now could grow a single antibody that could knock down both parainfluenza viruses. They named it 3 x 1."We didn't know that a cross-reactive antibody for these existed, but we found one we could use. It was just luck," Boonyaratanakornkit said.With a somewhat similar screening process, they used bits of RSV and HMPV as bait in a pool of 200 million blood cells taken in blood draws. Out of that large pool, they were able to fish out B cells that made an antibody that would cross-react, or bind, to either of those viruses. They now had MxR.When these rare immune proteins are produced in large numbers through a laboratory process, they are called monoclonal antibodies.The researchers then made batches of 3 x 1 and MxR monoclonal antibodies and mixed them into a "cocktail." It is a single drug meant to be injected, designed to prevent infection by any of the 4 viruses. In tests with hamsters, the experimental drug bound to the viruses and prevented infection.The Fred Hutch team is attempting to target 4 different viruses with their 2-antibody cocktail, delivered in a single injection. Boonyaratanakorkit said the 4 [viruses] they are targeting do not have a history of rapid genetic mutation, like influenza and SARS-CoV-2.In future research, Boonyaratanakornkit and colleagues are hoping to genetically engineer their experimental drug so it will last longer in the body. Antibodies lose their potency over time, and longer-lasting versions of these 2 cross-reactive antibodies would hold an advantage.Eventually, they hope to engineer a so-called "bi-specific" antibody, which on a single Y-shaped protein would contain, on the respective left and right arms of the protein, the separate binding sites for MxR and 3 x 1. This is a dream drug -- an infusion containing millions of antibodies of a single design that can efficiently knock out 4 dangerous respiratory viruses. "We're working on that," Boonyaratanakornkit said.[Byline: Sabin Russell]--Communicated by:ProMED[Reference---------Cabán M, Rodarte JV, Bibby M, et al. Cross-protective antibodies against common endemic respiratory viruses. Nat Commun. 2023; 14(1): 798; <https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-023-36459-3>"- Respiratory viral infections [RVI; including RSV, adenovirus, influenza virus, parainfluenza virus, human metapneumovirus, and rhinovirus] are associated with high morbidity and mortality among transplant recipients [both solid organ (SOT) and hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) patients]- The infections typically occur within the 1st 6 months after transplantation.- Currently, management options are limited or lack strong clinical evidence.- Infection control practices vary across institutions.- Vigilant hand washing and other standard precautions are key to preventing outbreaks.""Compared to immunocompetent hosts, SOT and HSCT patients are much more likely to experience a prolonged duration of illness, prolonged shedding, and progression of upper respiratory tract disease to pneumonia when infected with respiratory viruses. Adenovirus and respiratory syncytial virus tend to have the highest mortality and risk for disseminated disease, but all the RVIs are associated with higher morbidity and mortality in these patients than in the general population. These viruses are spread via direct contact and aerosolized droplets, and nosocomial spread has been reported."(<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijid.2017.07.011>)- Mod.LK]

column2:
MULTIPLE DISEASES, CEREAL CROPS - AUSTRALIA: (QUEENSLAND, NEW SOUTH WALES) ALERT
********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: Grain Central [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://www.graincentral.com/cropping/researchers-sound-alarm-on-disease-at-goondiwindi-update/>


The Australian Grains Research and Development Corporation (GRDC) has issued an alert for a range of cereal diseases, after a "tsunami" of diseases had affected cereal crops in the eastern states in 2022 due to excessively wet conditions. The upcoming winter cropping season carries mammoth disease risks from heavy stubble loads and infected seeds. 

Crops and varieties should be chosen carefully and good quality seed used. Timing of fungicide applications and rotating modes of action is also important. Since chickpeas are no longer favoured by farmers in crop rotations, they are encouraged to plant oilseed rape and faba beans rather than wheat after wheat. Volunteer cereals and weeds serving as green bridge for carrying inoculum into this season must be destroyed with herbicides or heavy grazing prior to planting.

Diseases of concern include wheat and barley rusts; crown rot of wheat and durum wheat; white grain; and fusarium head blight (FHB). One registered fungicide is available for FHB, but there is no reliable treatment for crown rot as yet. The major barley diseases in 2022 were powdery mildew and leaf rust. Resistance to powdery mildew has broken down in some of the European varieties with a single resistance gene. Loose smut was an issue in a number of varieties.

New pathotypes are expected to be detected in the next year or so. Exotic incursions of pathogens and their hybrids are making it harder to control leaf rusts and develop varieties resistant against not one, but several genotypes. Pathotypes have been seen to travel extensively within Australia, not just in wet years.

[Byline: Liz Wells]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[All diseases mentioned above are caused by or associated with fungi:
- wheat and barley rusts by closely related species and strains of _Puccinia_;
- crown rot of wheat and fusarium head blight of small grain cereals by several species currently or originally classed into the genus _Fusarium_;
- white grain was shown to be associated with _Botryosphaeria zeae_ (ProMED post 20101226.4552), but may also be due to fusarium head blight in other cases;
- powdery mildews of cereals are due to different pathovars of _Blumeria graminis_; f. sp. _tritici_ affecting wheat and triticale; f. sp. _hordei_ affecting barley; f. sp. _avenae_ affecting oats; f. sp. _secalis_ affecting rye;
- loose smut of barley is caused by _Ustilago tritici_.

For more information on the pathogens, see previous ProMED posts in the see also section below and the archives.

<https://www.nationsonline.org/maps/australia-political-map.jpg>

<https://www.ipmimages.org/>

<https://www.apsnet.org/edcenter/resources/commonnames/Pages/Wheat.aspx>
List of major diseases and pathogens of barley:
<https://www.apsnet.org/edcenter/resources/commonnames/Pages/Barley.aspx>

<https://www.indexfungorum.org/names/names.asp>

column2:
FLAVESCENCE DOREE, GRAPEVINE - FRANCE: (SOUTHWEST)
**************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: Just Drinks [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://www.just-drinks.com/news/france-provides-up-to-eur67m-to-help-bordeaux-wineries-rip-up-vines/>


France is providing up to EUR 67 million [USD ~70.6 million] of support to grape growers in the area around Bordeaux and Gironde who decide to replace vines infected with flavescence dorée with other crops.

[Byline: Jessica Broadbent]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Flavescence doree (FD) is one of the most important and destructive diseases of grapevines owing to its fast rate of spread within vineyards. The disease was first reported in 1954 in southern France and has been spreading in southern Europe. FD was thought to have been introduced from the United States, the home of its primary vector. It is caused by a phytoplasma (_Candidatus_ Phytoplasma vitis) belonging to the 16SrV (elm yellows) group.

Symptoms can vary on different grape varieties and usually appear in late spring. They may include shortened internodes, stunting, leaves with downward rolled margins, as well as drooping shoots. Leaves turn yellow in white grape cultivars and red in red ones. Leaf necrosis and bark splitting may also develop; yield is severely reduced. Some vines die, usually in the year following infection. The survivors continue to harbour the pathogen but appear symptomless (latent infections) unless they are re-infected.

FD is spread by the vine leafhopper _Scaphoideus titanus_ and through infected propagation material. Symptomless budwood can carry both eggs of the vector and the pathogen. Reliable diagnosis in both symptomatic and asymptomatic host tissue by molecular methods is vital for disease management, which may include pathogen exclusion, certification of clean propagation material and removal of infected plants (pathogen reservoirs). Insecticides can reduce vector numbers. The phytoplasma may be eliminated by treating dormant canes with hot water (heat therapy).

In Europe, a northward spread of the disease is being observed. The vector was reported to have overcome the Alps in the mid 1990s, followed by the 1st report of FD north of the Alps in 2014 (from Germany; ProMED post 20141217.3038025). The spread of FD in central Europe is considered another example of "warm climate diseases" moving into cooler regions due to climate change (see, for example, Esca disease of grapevine, ProMED post 20141024.2895414).

<https://www.worldometers.info/img/maps/france_physical_map.gif>

<https://mapofeurope.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/europe-political-map.jpg>

<https://charente.chambre-agriculture.fr/fileadmin/user_upload/Nouvelle-Aquitaine/096_Inst-Charente/Documents/PRODUIRE/VITICULTURE/FLAV_DOREE/VITI_FlavescenceD2.jpg>

column2:
WILT DISEASE, COFFEE - COTE D'IVOIRE: RE-EMERGENCE
**************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Feb 2023
Source: Voie de Femme [in French, machine trans., summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://voiedefemme.net/dossier-de-la-semaine/gagnoa-pourquoi-la-production-du-cafe-a-t-elle-baisse/>


Coffee wilt (tracheomycosis) appeared in Ivory Coast in the 1930s and 1950s, destroying many coffee plantations. At that time, more resistant varieties of coffee were introduced. Now, the disease is back in all coffee-producing areas of the country.

A survey in 2022 showed that of 169 plots visited in parts of Goh-Djiboua district, 14.2% were affected by coffee wilt; in upper Sassandra district, orchard contamination rate is estimated at 50%. Scientists are working to develop techniques so that growers can manage the disease.

[Byline: Alain Doua]

--
Communicated by:
Dr E. Boa
University of Aberdeen
<e.boa@abdn.ac.uk>

[Coffee wilt (CW) disease (also called tracheomycosis) is caused by the fungus _Fusarium xylarioides_ (Fx; previously _Gibberella xylarioides_). A number of strains exist with different host preferences for (1) _Coffea canephora_ (robusta or lowland coffee); (2) _Coffea arabica_(arabica or highland coffee); and (3) other _Coffea_ spp. Of these, the robusta strains are the most aggressive and have caused the worst losses to commercial coffee cultivation.

CW can attack all stages of growth; infected plants show 100% mortality. Symptoms include wilting, defoliation and streaks in the wood; they occur sequentially until all branches are killed. Berries ripen prematurely and dry up. Pathogen spread occurs with infected plant material (firewood, seedlings), contaminated soil or tools, and by wind, water and mechanical means. Although cultural practices have shown some success in disease management, crop varieties with higher levels of CW resistance appear to be the most promising approach. CW-resistant varieties are being developed, but in the past problems were encountered in the region with distributing them to farmers.

Previously, the disease occurred sporadically in Africa, decimating coffee production in the 1920s-1950s. It re-emerged in the 2000s and is now considered a major constraint to African coffee production. Recent research on Fx genetics suggests that different populations arose independently and that Fx can increase its virulence by acquiring genes from related _Fusarium_ species (see links below).

<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/ivory_coast_pol88.jpg> and
<https://i.pinimg.com/originals/6c/05/4d/6c054d2757c204ea2cb3e561ea1ece2a.jpg> (districts)

column3: Coffee wilt (tracheomycosis) appeared in Ivory Coast in the 1930s and 1950s, destroying many coffee plantations. At that time, more resistant varieties of coffee were introduced. Now, the disease is back in all coffee-producing areas of the country.A survey in 2022 showed that of 169 plots visited in parts of Goh-Djiboua district, 14.2% were affected by coffee wilt; in upper Sassandra district, orchard contamination rate is estimated at 50%. Scientists are working to develop techniques so that growers can manage the disease.[Byline: Alain Doua]--Communicated by:Dr E. BoaUniversity of Aberdeen<e.boa@abdn.ac.uk>[Coffee wilt (CW) disease (also called tracheomycosis) is caused by the fungus _Fusarium xylarioides_ (Fx; previously _Gibberella xylarioides_). A number of strains exist with different host preferences for (1) _Coffea canephora_ (robusta or lowland coffee); (2) _Coffea arabica_(arabica or highland coffee); and (3) other _Coffea_ spp. Of these, the robusta strains are the most aggressive and have caused the worst losses to commercial coffee cultivation.CW can attack all stages of growth; infected plants show 100% mortality. Symptoms include wilting, defoliation and streaks in the wood; they occur sequentially until all branches are killed. Berries ripen prematurely and dry up. Pathogen spread occurs with infected plant material (firewood, seedlings), contaminated soil or tools, and by wind, water and mechanical means. Although cultural practices have shown some success in disease management, crop varieties with higher levels of CW resistance appear to be the most promising approach. CW-resistant varieties are being developed, but in the past problems were encountered in the region with distributing them to farmers.Previously, the disease occurred sporadically in Africa, decimating coffee production in the 1920s-1950s. It re-emerged in the 2000s and is now considered a major constraint to African coffee production. Recent research on Fx genetics suggests that different populations arose independently and that Fx can increase its virulence by acquiring genes from related _Fusarium_ species (see links below).MapsIvory Coast:<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/ivory_coast_pol88.jpg> and<https://i.pinimg.com/originals/6c/05/4d/6c054d2757c204ea2cb3e561ea1ece2a.jpg> (districts)PicturesCoffee wilt symptoms:<https://scx1.b-cdn.net/csz/news/800a/2021/70-year-old-coffee-kil-1.jpg>,<https://coffeegeography.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Coffee-Wilt-Disease-2.jpg>,<https://coffeegeography.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Coffee-Wilt-Disease.jpg>,<https://d3i71xaburhd42.cloudfront.net/1b56a65f15d17f5c915eb91671fe2772c711c574/5-Figure2-1.png>,<https://www.hawaiicoffeeed.com/uploads/2/6/7/7/26772370/1-s2-0-s2090123210001050-gr7-2.jpg> and<https://image.slidesharecdn.com/coffeewiltdiseaseresistancebreedinginuganda-november2012-140212072716-phpapp02/95/coffee-wilt-disease-resistance-breeding-in-uganda-november-2012-7-638.jpg>_F. xylarioides_ hyphens, microscopy:<https://scx1.b-cdn.net/csz/news/800a/2021/70-year-old-coffee-kil.jpg>LinksAdditional news story (in French):<https://www.aip.ci/cote-divoire-aip-le-cnra-forme-les-agents-anader-a-la-lutte-contre-les-maladies-du-cafeier-a-gagnoa/>Coffee wilt, disease and pathogen information:<https://doi.org/10.1079/cabicompendium.25166>,<https://doi.org/10.1079/pwkb.20117800546>,<https://doi.org/10.1094/PHYTO-04-15-0097-R>,<https://www.earth.com/news/coffee-killing-fungus-has-acquired-genes-from-its-relatives/>,<https://sca.coffee/sca-news/25/issue-16/malawis-unfulfilled-promise-the-impact-of-coffee-wilt-disease-and-subsidies-on-coffee-production>,<https://www.hawaiicoffeeed.com/uploads/2/6/7/7/26772370/what_is_coffee_wilt_disease.pdf>,<https://doi.org/10.1094/PHYTO-96-0663> and via<https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/book/10.1079/9781845936419.0000>Research on _F. xylarioides_ genetics:<https://doi.org/10.1186/s12864-021-07700-4>,<https://phys.org/news/2021-06-year-old-coffee-killing-fungus-brought-life.html>,<https://www.earth.com/news/coffee-killing-fungus-has-acquired-genes-from-its-relatives/> and<https://coffeegeography.com/2021/06/05/researchers-activated-70-year-old-coffee-killing-fungus-in-the-lab-to-fight-the-disease/>CW, recent review via:<https://www.bspp.org.uk/category/Plant-Pandemic-Studies/>_F. xylarioides_ taxonomy & synonyms:<https://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/NamesRecord.asp?RecordID=286515> and<https://www.speciesfungorum.org/GSD/GSDspecies.asp?RecordID=286515>- Mod.DHAProMED map:Cote d'Ivoire: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708822,52>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (37): EUROPE (SWEDEN) NOT HPAI H5N5, OFFICIAL CORRECTION UPDATE
*******************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 8 Mar 2023
From: Caroline Brojer <caroline.brojer@sva.se> [edited]


re: ProMED Avian influenza (37): Europe, wild bird, poultry, HPAI H5N1, H5N5, WOAH 20230304.8708726
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Swedish National Veterinary Institute (NVI) would like to comment on item [3] Sweden: wild bird, HPAI H5N5 of the posting, as further investigations have shown that the date of detection is incorrect in the report to WOAH (<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4942>).

On 23 Feb 2023, the NVI received several recently dead birds for avian influenza testing within the national surveillance program. The barnacle goose that tested positive for H5N5 was marked with information that it died on 20 Feb 2023. Upon detection of an unexpected strain (H5N5), the submitter was contacted to confirm the date and location of the finding. He informed the NVI that the goose had died on 20 Feb 2021, not 2023, and had been sent for sampling by mistake.

Thus, this case does not represent a reoccurrence of the H5N5 subtype, which has not been detected in Sweden since May 2021.

--
Caroline Brojer
National Veterinary Institute (SVA)
Sweden
<caroline.brojer@sva.se>

[ProMED thanks Caroline Brojer for the information provided. - Mod.CRD]

[See Also:
Avian influenza (37): Europe, wild bird, poultry, HPAI H5N1, H5N5, WOAH 20230304.8708726]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (41): AMERICAS (CHILE) MARINE OTTER
***************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 7 Mar 2023
Source: El Diario de La Araucanía [in Spanish, trans. Mod PMB, edited]
<https://eldiariodelaaraucania.cl/2023/03/07/sernapesca-informa-primer-caso-de-influenza-aviar-en-especie-lontra-felina-popularmente-conocida-como-chungungo/>


The National Director of SERNAPESCA [National Fisheries and Aquaculture Service], Soledad Tapia Almonacid, delivered a new report on the situation of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in marine species in Chile.

"Over the weekend [4-5 Mar 2023] we were notified of a positive result for bird flu by the Agricultural and Livestock Service after the laboratory results tested samples of a marine otter in Arica. This male specimen was stranded dead in the vicinity of the Lluta River wetland near Las Machas beach [Arica and Parinacota region] along with other birds, for which the procedure for suspicion was started with the corresponding sampling conducted jointly 
with the Chilean Secretariat of Agriculture (SAG)", said Tapia.

This is the 1st specimen of the _Lontra felina_ species officially affected in our country by avian influenza. This is added to the confirmation of a 3rd common sea lion with a positive result, this time in the Tarapacá region. The balance to date indicates that 4 marine mammals have been reported infected with HPAI.

"Let's remember that until last week [first of Mar 2023] the focus was on the Antofagasta region, with 2 sea lions and 2 penguins, and today we already have confirmation of affected marine mammals in the Arica and Parinacota, and Tarapacá regions," confirmed the national director of Sernapesca.

This case (marine otter) also corresponds to the variant of the H5 virus that has already been detected in wild birds in 12 regions of the country, and that is present in countries of the northern and southern hemispheres.

The entity that controls fishing and aquaculture activity, SERNAPESCA, indicated that they have activated a special plan to address this contingency. On the one hand, a territorial deployment that consists of a special surveillance system in coastal areas identified as at risk, and, on the other hand, to strengthen the notification systems, in order to determine early cases of avian influenza in marine animals. In addition, work is being done in coordination with the presidential delegations of the northern zone regions where positive cases have been documented, the SAG, MINSAL [Ministry of Health], SENAPRED [National Service For Disaster Prevention And Response], and other regional and local authorities, such as municipalities.

In addition to the measures mentioned above, SERNAPESCA and the Undersecretary of Fisheries and Aquaculture, SUBPESCA, have been working together since February [2023] at the level of authorities and with expert technical teams, to safeguard the health of those who carry out various jobs associated with artisanal fishing and other sectoral agents that cohabit with marine species susceptible to contagion with avian influenza, or that maintain higher levels of interactions with marine fauna, by coordinating a series of training workshops, especially in places identified as high risk. "Through our regional directorates and the fishing zones of the Undersecretary, we will train our users in biosecurity measures, to avoid risky manipulation. Our interest is that men and women of the sea remain safe," said Tapia.

--
Communicated by:
Mary Marshall
<mjm2020@googlemail.com>

[Infections by HPAI viruses in mammals were typically not common, but since April 2022 there has been a growing number of events of Eurasian HPAI H5N1 in a wide spectrum of wild carnivores (order Carnivora). There have been reports in red foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_, family Canidae), bobcats and mountain lions (family Felidae), skunks (family Mephitidae), raccoons (family Procyonidae), bears (family Ursidae), otters and minks (family Mustelidae), seals and sea lions (suborder Pinnipedia, families Phocidae and Otariidae, respectively). There have also been cases in cetaceans.

The marine otter (_Lontra felina_) is a rare South American mustelid that only lives in saltwater environments. Marine otters are rare and are protected under Peruvian, Chilean, and Argentinian laws, and are classified as endangered by the IUCN. (International Union for Conservation of Nature). For a picture go to <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_otter#/media/File:Lfelina.jpg>. - Mod.PMB

ProMED map of Chile: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708815,68910>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (40): AMERICAS (URUGUAY) BACKYARD, HPAI H5, FIRST REPORT, WOAH
******************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 8 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4947>


Uruguay - influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 3 Mar 2023
Confirmed: 3 Mar 2023
Reported: 3 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: 1st occurrence in the country
Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]
Serotype: H5
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: San Gregorio de Polanco, Tacuarembó
Started: 3 Mar 2023
Epidemiological unit: backyard
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 195 / 94 / 94 / - / - / -

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: a notification regarding deaths in birds in a multi-species backyard was received yesterday [2 Mar 2023]. The owners report that mortality in hens began on [26 Feb 2023]. Out of 100 domestic hens, 70 died; out of 15 guinea fowl, 14 died, and out of 80 ducks, 10 died. 8 birds with clinical signs were sampled and tested positive for avian influenza and 5 of them were positive for H5. The premises were quarantined and the animals will be culled, the carcasses and products will be destroyed and buried and disinfection will be carried out. The official service is conducting an epidemiological investigation in the area. Surveillance areas of 5 km [3 mi] (outbreak) and 10 [6 mi] km (around the outbreak) have been put in place.

Control measures at event level:
Applied in domestic animals: surveillance outside the restricted zone; surveillance within the restricted zone; movement control.
To be applied in domestic animals: disinfection; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste.

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Result date / Result
[Veterinary Laboratories Division (DILAVE)] / birds / 1 / real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 3 Mar 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[According to a press release on 3 Mar 2023, The MGAP (Ministerio de Ganaderia, Agricultura y Pesca/Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries) intervened in this case and applied the protocol corresponding to this type of case, isolating the area, and establishing surveillance with a radius of 5 km (3 mi).

The work is carried out in conjunction with the Departmental Emergency Committee (CDE) of Tacuarembó, chaired by Mayor Wilson Ezquerra.

In Uruguay to date (8 Mar 2023), HPAI subtype H5 has been detected in wild birds (Laguna Garzon, see <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4900?reportId=159471>) and now in backyard premises (San Gregorio de Polanco); <https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-ganaderia-agricultura-pesca/comunicacion/noticias/comunicado-prensa-actualizacion-332023> (in Spanish).

More information is available at <https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-ganaderia-agricultura-pesca/influenza-aviar> (in Spanish). - Mod.CRD

column3: Uruguay - influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 3 Mar 2023Confirmed: 3 Mar 2023Reported: 3 Mar 2023Reason for notification: 1st occurrence in the countryCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: San Gregorio de Polanco, TacuarembóStarted: 3 Mar 2023Epidemiological unit: backyardAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 195 / 94 / 94 / - / - / -EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: a notification regarding deaths in birds in a multi-species backyard was received yesterday [2 Mar 2023]. The owners report that mortality in hens began on [26 Feb 2023]. Out of 100 domestic hens, 70 died; out of 15 guinea fowl, 14 died, and out of 80 ducks, 10 died. 8 birds with clinical signs were sampled and tested positive for avian influenza and 5 of them were positive for H5. The premises were quarantined and the animals will be culled, the carcasses and products will be destroyed and buried and disinfection will be carried out. The official service is conducting an epidemiological investigation in the area. Surveillance areas of 5 km [3 mi] (outbreak) and 10 [6 mi] km (around the outbreak) have been put in place.Control measures at event level:Applied in domestic animals: surveillance outside the restricted zone; surveillance within the restricted zone; movement control.To be applied in domestic animals: disinfection; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Result date / Result[Veterinary Laboratories Division (DILAVE)] / birds / 1 / real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 3 Mar 2023 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[According to a press release on 3 Mar 2023, The MGAP (Ministerio de Ganaderia, Agricultura y Pesca/Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries) intervened in this case and applied the protocol corresponding to this type of case, isolating the area, and establishing surveillance with a radius of 5 km (3 mi).The work is carried out in conjunction with the Departmental Emergency Committee (CDE) of Tacuarembó, chaired by Mayor Wilson Ezquerra.In Uruguay to date (8 Mar 2023), HPAI subtype H5 has been detected in wild birds (Laguna Garzon, see <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4900?reportId=159471>) and now in backyard premises (San Gregorio de Polanco); <https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-ganaderia-agricultura-pesca/comunicacion/noticias/comunicado-prensa-actualizacion-332023> (in Spanish).More information is available at <https://www.gub.uy/ministerio-ganaderia-agricultura-pesca/influenza-aviar> (in Spanish). - Mod.CRDProMED map of Uruguay: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708814,68909>]

**************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 8 Mar 2023
From: Rhys Powell <rhys.powell@dpi.nsw.gov.au> [edited]


re: ProMED Canine distemper - Australia: (NT) dogs 20230307.8708779
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The article in question refers to a USA outbreak, not an Australian one. Palm Springs in the Northern Territory is part of a national park and there will be limited dogs present.

--
Rhys Powell
NSW Department of Primary Industries
<rhys.powell@dpi.nsw.gov.au>

[ProMED thanks Rhys Powell for alerting us to this mistake.

The outbreak was reported at the Palm Valley Animal Society in Edinburg (Hidalgo County), south Texas, United States, not in Australia's Northern Territory.

ProMED regrets any confusion or inconvenience that this post may have generated. - Mod.TG

ProMED map of Texas, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708812,25962>]

column2:
DIPHTHERIA - NIGERIA (06): (KANO) FATAL
***************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023 15:11 WAT
Source: The Cable [edited]
<https://www.thecable.ng/61-killed-in-diphtheria-outbreak-in-kano-says-ncdc>


At least 61 persons are said to have died from the outbreak of diphtheria in Kano State.

Salma Suwaid, Kano diphtheria case manager, spoke on Monday [6 Mar 2023] at a webinar organised by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) with the theme 'Diphtheria outbreak in Nigeria: Vaccination Response.'

Diphtheria is a bacterial infection caused by the _Corynebacterium_ species that affects the nose, throat, and sometimes, the skin of an individual. Some symptoms of diphtheria include fever, runny nose, sore throat, cough, red eyes, neck swelling, and difficulty in breathing.

Suwaid said a total of 783 -- 360 male and 423 female -- patients have been admitted so far in Kano. She added that the average hospital stay of the patients is 4 days. "83 percent of deaths occurred in patients with the onset of symptoms greater than 3 days and an average of 15 admission days," she said. "68 percent of patients have been discharged, 1.66 percent absconded, and 12.2 percent died."

Adejoke Oladele, the representative of the director of disease control and immunisation, National Primary Health Care Development Agency (NPHCDA), said the agency is working closely with the NCDC and partners to ensure a rapid increase in diphtheria vaccination coverage. "Apart from clinical and immunisation interventions, risk communication engagement activities are also carried out in affected communities. We are leveraging on structures implemented for COVID to ensure an effective response," she said.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[According to the news report above, as of 6 Mar 2023, the Nigerian State of Kano apparently has the most cases and the most deaths in the ongoing Nigerian diphtheria outbreak, with a total of 783 (360 male and 423 female) patients admitted so far in the state, with 61 deaths. However, we are not told if these are suspected or confirmed cases or both, and we are not given the timeline over which these cases have occurred.

The prior ProMED post (Diphtheria - Nigeria (05): fatal, RFI 20230305.8708741) reported that between week 19 (mid-May) of 2022 and week 7 (mid-February) of 2023, 724 suspected cases of diphtheria were recorded from 20 states in Nigeria, with the majority of cases reported from Kano (533, 74%), Yobe (86, 12%), Katsina (45, 6%), Sokoto (14, 2%), Enugu (9, 1%), Ogun (7, 1%), Osun (7, 1%), Kaduna (6, 1%), Lagos (5, 1%), and Zamfara (5, 1%) states.

Data from the latest [?] 2nd diphtheria situation report from the Nigeria CDC for the period week 19 2022 (mid-May) - week 5 2023 (last week Jan-1st week Feb 2023):
Total suspected cases: 523 (Kano, 396). Suspected cases for week 4-5 2023 [23 Jan-5 Feb 2023]: 189 (Kano, 172 or 91%).
Total confirmed cases: 216 (Kano, 211). Confirmed cases for week 4-5 2023: 56 (Kano, 56 cases or 100%).
Total deaths among confirmed cases: 40. Deaths among confirmed cases for week 4-5 2023: 4.

For further details from the 2nd diphtheria situation report from the NCDC, please see <https://www.ncdc.gov.ng/diseases/sitreps/?cat=18&name=An%20Update%20of%20Diphtheria%20Outbreak%20in%20Nigeria> and <https://www.ncdc.gov.ng/themes/common/files/sitreps/0f2332677defbd072e8b797f23a7d0d3.pdf>. - Mod.ML

ProMED map of Nigeria: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708810,887>]

column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - ECUADOR (02): (GUAYAS) FLOODING, GARBAGE, RODENT, DOG
*********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023 17:16 ECT
Source: El Comercio [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.elcomercio.com/actualidad/ecuador/leptospirosis-duran-aguas-estancadas-insalubridad.html>


Leptospirosis in Durán [Guayas province] gains ground due to stagnant waters and unsanitary conditions.

The garbage collection car passes up to 3 times a day. But that's far from keeping the sidewalks clean. And at all times the sidewalks and gutters remain full of bags with scattered garbage, flies, and dogs prowling the waste. In addition, stagnant water from the rains aggravates the leptospirosis problem in Durán.

On a tour of the 1st and 2nd stages of El Recreo de Durán, EL COMERCIO verified unsanitary conditions. El Recreo concentrates 12 cases of leptospirosis out of the 18 detected in the province of Guayas.

Another 4 cases are located in other sectors of Durán. The Ministry of Public Health (MSP) reported 2 infected in Guayaquil. The disease is transmitted by the urine of rats [contaminating] stagnant water and in contact with human skin. And the urine of infected dogs and cats also transmits the bacteria [_Leptospira_] that cause the disease.

On Monday morning, [6 Mar 2023], a resident of El Recreo II was helping a street sweeper from the municipal company uncover a rainwater grate covered with mud. The sinkhole was located next to a mound of garbage full of flies and the dogs sniffed the open covers.

At 10:00 a.m., the garbage collection truck had not yet passed through the sector, when it usually does around 8:00 a.m. "The collection car sometimes comes late; it does not have a fixed schedule, but not everything is the fault of the collection. Some neighbors throw open garbage bags on the corner. And others wait for the truck to pass to take out the waste," said the man.

The poor disposal of garbage, even at night, favors the proliferation of rats and leptospirosis in Durán. Jesús Narváez, a pharmacist in the sector, says that intensive education campaigns for the population are required, followed by ordinances and fines for bad neighbors.

An MSP brigade passed fumigating and offering talks on the morning [6 Mar 2023]. But in one block they could only reach 6 homes and the brigade workers were harassed by crime, said Narváez.

The stench emanates from corners that have become large garbage dumps. In Colinas de El Recreo, the waste rots in a flooded area next to the railways. An entire body of water remains full of garbage. "The smell is unbearable, the truck only picks up the bags that are left on the shore," says a neighbor.

Leptospirosis cases produce symptoms such as fever, chills, headaches, muscle pain, and abdominal pain, as well as vomiting, diarrhea, and yellowing of the eyes and skin. The authorities urge residents to consult a doctor or go to a health center before signs of alarm.

The infection mainly affects the kidneys. People are urged to avoid environments contaminated by animal urine and when in contact with stagnant water, it is recommended to clean the skin with plenty of clean water and soap.

Lucy Jurado, Zonal 8 coordinator of the MSP, informed that the cases of leptospirosis in Durán and Guayaquil are so far uncomplicated. The State agency is executing a disease prevention plan. Antibiotics [doxycycline] can cure the infection and the pathogen is usually eliminated from the urine after a week. But without treatment, it can cause kidney and liver damage, or even death.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Heavy rainfall in February 2023 caused freshwater flooding in multiple regions of Ecuador (<https://floodlist.com/america/ecuador-floods-february-2023>), but flooding in Duran is being compounded by mounds of garbage that are blocking drainage of the floodwater and attracting rats, dogs, and other animals that likely excrete _Leptospira_ in their urine, contaminating the floodwater.

Many species of wild and domestic animals (including dogs, cattle, swine, and rats) are susceptible to chronic kidney infection with pathogenic _Leptospira_. Leptospirosis is usually acquired after contact of the skin or mucous membranes with the urine of infected animals or by contact with fresh water, wet soil, or vegetation that has been contaminated by the urine of leptospira-infected animals, especially rats. _Leptospira_ shed in the urine of chronically infected animals may survive in freshwater or moist soil for weeks to months.

Durán (population 235 769 residents) is a canton located in the province of Guayas, Ecuador, located across the Guayas River from Guayaquil (population almost 2.7 million residents), the capital of Guayas Province and Ecuador's 2nd-largest city (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durán,_Ecuador>). A map showing the location of Durán and Guayaquil can be found at <https://www.google.com/maps/place/Duran,+Ecuador>. - Mod.ML

ProMED map of Ecuador: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708809,20178>]

[See Also:

2003
---

1998
---

Leptospirosis - Ecuador 19980207.0232]
