column2:
HARD TICK-BORNE RELAPSING FEVER - USA: (ALABAMA) BORRELIA LONESTARI, AMBLYOMMA AMERICANUM, FIRST REPORT
*******************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023
Source: Infectious Disease Special Edition [edited]
<https://www.idse.net/Zoonotic-Diseases/Article/03-23/Borrelia-lonestari-Ticks-Tickborne-Relapsing-Fever-B-lonestari/69648>


For the 1st time, a case of tickborne relapsing fever (TBRF) related to the _Borrelia lonestari_ organism has been found in an Alabama man, according to the CDC.

The patient, a 75-year-old [immunocompromised] Alabama resident, sought treatment at The Kirklin Clinic of the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB), during April 2019, for extreme fatigue and relapsing fevers accompanied by chills, sweating, headache, and dizziness (Emerg Infect Dis 2023; 29(2): 441-4; [see below]). He indicated that the symptoms had been recurring one to 2 times per week for the previous month.

The patient reported having removed an attached tick approximately 4 weeks before symptom onset.

Oral doxycycline treatment was initiated. The patient developed a fever and became stuporous following the 1st dose, but he stabilized and was able to complete a 10-day course of treatment without additional complications.

"The potential for _B. lonestari_ to cause disease, and if so what type of disease, has been rather mysterious," researcher Joshua A Lieberman, MD, PhD, an assistant professor of laboratory medicine in the Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology at the University of Washington, in Seattle, told Infectious Disease Special Edition.

PCR testing of a blood sample taken from the patient was analyzed by the University of Washington Medical Center molecular microbiology laboratory. The test had 100% identity to three published 16S rRNA gene sequences from _B. lonestari_ (GenBank accession nos. AY166715, AY682921 and U23211), and 99.79% identity to another published 16S rRNA gene sequence from _B. lonestari_ (GenBank accession no. AY682920).

Although _B. lonestari_ was initially proposed as the cause of southern tick-associated rash illness, following bites from lone star ticks, efforts to isolate the bacterium in biopsies of rashes have largely been unsuccessful.

"This case report sheds light onto the potential of _B. lonestari_ to cause human illness and contributes to the body of knowledge on TBRF," Laia J Vazquez Guillamet, MD, an infectious disease specialist at UAB, told Infectious Disease Special Edition. "It is the 2nd tickborne _Borrelia_ species transmitted by hard ticks that has been identified as a causative agent of relapsing fever, being the previous ones transmitted by soft ticks."

Additionally, Dr Vazquez Guillamet said the report "expands the known geographical distribution of potential etiologic agents of relapsing fever in the US, including many southeastern states where _B. lonestari_ has been detected in both ticks and vertebrate hosts." However, it is important to highlight that this bacterium and this human illness are uncommonly reported in those states, she added. "Discovering this organism in a classic case of relapsing fever makes genetic sense because it is within the 'relapsing fever' group of _Borrelia_ species, not the Lyme disease group," Dr Lieberman said.

Dr Lieberman did note that some questions remain unanswered. "We don't know whether the patient developed relapsing fever because _B. lonestari_ is always a true pathogen, because he was immunocompromised, or both," he said. "Hopefully, future work will help resolve this."

Dr Vazquez Guillamet added that the increasing availability of molecular diagnostics may help continue to illuminate the role of _B. lonestari_ as an emerging tickborne pathogen. "In future years, increased awareness of the pathogenic potential of _B. lonestari_ and the use of molecular diagnostics may give us an approximation about the real burden of human illness caused by this bacterium," she said.

[Byline: Ethan Covey]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The citation and the abstract of the journal article referenced in the news report above follow:

Vazquez Guillamet LJ, Marx GE, Benjamin W, et al. Relapsing fever caused by _Borrelia lonestari_ after tick bite in Alabama, USA. Emerg Infect Dis. 2023; 29(2): 441-4; <https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/29/2/22-1281_article>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
--------
"We report an immunocompromised patient in Alabama, USA, 75 years of age, with relapsing fevers and pancytopenia who had spirochetemia after a tick bite. We identified _Borrelia lonestari_ by using PCR, sequencing, and phylogenetic analysis. Increasing clinical availability of molecular diagnostics might identify _B. lonestari_ as an emerging tickborne pathogen."

----
The relapsing-fever group of _Borrelia_, which includes _B. hermsii_ and _B. miyamotoi_, is genetically diverse and causes a disease characterized by a high temperature that cyclically remits. _B. hermsii_ is the most frequent cause of tick-borne relapsing fever in the USA. This spirochete is transmitted to humans by the soft tick _Ornithodoros hermsi_, which transmits spirochetes through a brief (less than 30 minutes duration) and painless nocturnal bite. Humans typically are exposed to these ticks during an overnight stay in rodent-infested dwellings at elevations greater than 2000 feet (610 m). In the USA, a majority of the reported _B. hermsii_ cases are from California and Washington State. Louse-borne relapsing fever, an illness similar to the tick-borne disease, is caused by _Borrelia recurrentis_, which is transmitted from human to human by the body louse and is spread under conditions of crowding and poor personal hygiene. It remains endemic in parts of central and east Africa and the South American Andes but has occasionally been imported into the USA.

The patient in the case report above had a history of low grade follicular non-Hodgkin lymphoma and was receiving maintenance rituximab therapy. The patient had not traveled out of Alabama for several years but reported that he had removed an attached tick 4 weeks before symptom onset. During the 3 months before the diagnosis was confirmed, pancytopenia (anemia, leucopenia, and thrombocytopenia), mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase, and hepatosplenomegaly were noted. Spirochetes were seen in the peripheral blood smear and empirical oral treatment (100 mg doxycycline 2x/d) was initiated immediately. A Jarisch-Herxheimer-like reaction occurred after initiation of antimicrobial therapy, but he then completed a full 10-day course of doxycycline. His pancytopenia resolved in the subsequent months. The spirochete was identified genetically as _B. lonestarii_.

_B. lonestari_ has been detected in the hard lone star tick, _Amblyomma americanum_, in southeastern states and has been thought to be the cause of southern tick-associated rash illness (STARI) occurring after _A. americanum_ tick bites. _B. lonestari_ infection had previously been identified in an elderly patient with an erythema migrans-like rash that developed after an _A. americanum_ tick bite; PCR identified _B. lonestari_ in both a skin biopsy and the removed tick in this patient (<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11372036/>). The _B. lonestari_ clade is most closely related to _B. miyamotoi_, another _Borrelia_ species causing hard tick (_Ixodes_) relapsing fever.

In the USA, _B. miyamotoi_ has been detected in _Ixodes scapularis_, in Russia and Japan in _I. persulcatus_ (Fukunaga M, Takahashi Y, Tsuruta Y, et al: Genetic and phenotypic analysis of _Borrelia miyamotoi_ sp. nov., isolated from the ixodid tick _Ixodes persulcatus_, the vector for Lyme disease in Japan. Int J Syst Bacteriol. 1995; 45(4):  804-10; <http://ijs.sgmjournals.org/content/45/4/804.long>), and in western Europe, _Ixodes ricinus_, the same tick species that spreads _B. burgdorferi_ sensu lato complex, the causative agents of Lyme disease. - Mod.ML

ProMED map of Alabama, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708808,31904>]

column3: For the 1st time, a case of tickborne relapsing fever (TBRF) related to the _Borrelia lonestari_ organism has been found in an Alabama man, according to the CDC.The patient, a 75-year-old [immunocompromised] Alabama resident, sought treatment at The Kirklin Clinic of the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB), during April 2019, for extreme fatigue and relapsing fevers accompanied by chills, sweating, headache, and dizziness (Emerg Infect Dis 2023; 29(2): 441-4; [see below]). He indicated that the symptoms had been recurring one to 2 times per week for the previous month.The patient reported having removed an attached tick approximately 4 weeks before symptom onset.Oral doxycycline treatment was initiated. The patient developed a fever and became stuporous following the 1st dose, but he stabilized and was able to complete a 10-day course of treatment without additional complications."The potential for _B. lonestari_ to cause disease, and if so what type of disease, has been rather mysterious," researcher Joshua A Lieberman, MD, PhD, an assistant professor of laboratory medicine in the Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology at the University of Washington, in Seattle, told Infectious Disease Special Edition.PCR testing of a blood sample taken from the patient was analyzed by the University of Washington Medical Center molecular microbiology laboratory. column2:
STREPTOCOCCUS, GROUP A UPDATE (08): USA (WISCONSIN) PHARYNGITIS, CHILDREN, INCREASE
***********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 7 Mar 2023
Source: Milwaukee Journal Sentinel [abridged, edited]
<https://eu.jsonline.com/story/news/health/2023/03/07/wisconsin-is-experiencing-a-jump-in-strep-throat-infections/69937400007/>


Wisconsin health experts are seeing a consistent and continuing rise in strep throat infections, the latest respiratory disease to plague patients through the winter.

Dr Greg DeMuri, a pediatric infectious disease doctor for UW [University of Wisconsin] Health Kids and professor at UW-Madison's School of Medicine and Public Health, said this year's [2023] strep season has been unlike anything he's seen in his decade studying and treating the disease.

The good news is that there are many things you can do to keep yourself and loved ones safe, and doctors can effectively treat strep infections with antibiotics.

Here's what you need to know.
- What is strep throat? Strep throat is one of several diseases caused by group A _Streptococcus_ bacteria. It's a common childhood disease that mostly hits kids ages 5 to 15. By one estimate, about a quarter of cases of pharyngitis (sore throat) in kids are caused by strep infection, according to Milwaukee County Chief Health Policy Advisor and Froedtert Hospital emergency department physician Ben Weston.

But anyone at any age can get strep throat, and in recent months, health experts have been monitoring an increase in a rare but serious type of strep infection, called invasive group A strep infections.

Strep throat symptoms include sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue. People might have red and white patches in the throat, enlarged tonsils, and experience nausea or vomiting, fever, and/or headaches. The bacteria that cause strep throat can also cause tonsillitis, cellulitis, and impetigo, a mild but highly-contagious condition that causes skin sores.

- How does strep throat spread? With strep throat, bacteria spread most commonly through respiratory droplets and direct contact, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. That includes droplets from talking, coughing, sneezing, and sharing eating utensils and dishes. In the case of impetigo, the bacteria can spread from touching an infected person's skin sores.

This year [2023], strep throat has been spreading more. The best way to address it is to see a doctor for a test and antibiotic treatment, [if the tests are positive].

[Byline: Devi Shastri]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[For a discussion of group A streptococcal (GAS) infections, please see my moderator comments in ProMED posts Streptococcus, gp A update (05): UK, fatal, scarlet fever, iGAS 20221231.8707549 and Streptococcus, gp A update (06): Denmark, invasive, new subvariant, RFI 20230222.8708507.

Group A streptococcus (GAS) commonly causes pharyngitis, local suppurative extensions to involve the middle ear (otitis media) and sinuses (mastoiditis), and superficial skin infections, but can also cause invasive GAS (iGAS) infections, including bacteremia, necrotizing fasciitis, toxic shock syndrome, endocarditis, puerperal sepsis, pneumonia, and meningitis. Serious non-suppurative sequelae, such as acute rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease, and glomerulonephritis may also occur after GAS pharyngitis.

GAS can be highly contagious; skin lesions, poor personal hygiene, and crowding in shelters for the homeless would be expected to facilitate its spread from person to person.

Some strains of GAS are more virulent than others. Tissue invasiveness of GAS has been attributed to several virulence factors, especially the cell wall M protein, encoded by the emm gene. Strains have been typed based on the antigenic specificity of its M protein. More recently GAS are typed based on sequence analysis of the portion of the emm gene that encodes M serospecificity (<https://www.cdc.gov/streplab/groupa-strep/emm-background.html>). Over 200 emm types have been identified. Molecular analysis of the isolates' emm aids in documenting a common source of an outbreak.

In the UK, in 2016, 84% of all emm1 strains isolated upper respiratory GAS isolates had a distinctive emm type 1 (designated M1UK) (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6838661/>). The iGAS isolates collected in the same period in the UK were also M1UK (<https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(19)30446-3/fulltext>). M1UK was found to produce 9 times more streptococcal exotoxin than previous versions of emm type 1 isolates. In Denmark in January 2023, 35% of the total iGAS cases were due to a new subvariant GAS that has not previously been seen in Denmark (ProMED post Streptococcus, gp A update (06): Denmark, invasive, new subvariant, RFI 20230222.8708507). However, details describing the characteristics of this new subvariant strain were not given. - Mod.ML

column2:
Q FEVER - CROATIA: (PRIMORSKO-GORANSKA) GOAT
********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023
Source: Agroklub (Agricultural portal, Croatia) [in Croatian, machine trans., abridged, edited]
<https://www.agroklub.com/stocarstvo/divlje-koze-zarazene-q-groznicom-haraju-nasim-otokom/83847/>


A large number of wild [see comment] goats, which have been a long-standing problem for the inhabitants of the small Adriatic island of Unije [of the Cres-Lošinj archipelago] are infected with Q fever.

As 'Novi List' writes, tissue samples from dead or shot animals show this, with the note that this infection in humans can cause symptoms similar to flu or pneumonia, and in a small number of cases, damage to the heart, brain, liver, and lungs.

According to estimates, there are about 400 to 500 of these animals, and as revealed by Robert Nikolić, the president of the Council of the local committee of the Union, they were brought to the island in the late '70s and early '80s. The Lošinj company Jadranka had sheep there, so the goal was to speed up the maquis and clear the land for the growth of grass and grazing for their sheep.

"What happened, however, was that they multiplied beyond measure, so now they are also a problem for the island's shepherds, because they also graze the grass that the sheep grazed," he said, noting that they tried to solve the problem in communication with the Town of Mali and others. "The city and the county refer us to the Ministry of Agriculture, and the Ministry simply ignored all our letters, calls, and requests. We never received any response," he told the media.

He also points out that at the beginning of February [2023] they shot 16 goats, 11 of which were infected with Q fever, as shown by the analysis of samples at the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine in Zagreb.

By the way, last year [2022] in the Rijeka area [continental Croatia, facing the archipelago], several locals fell ill from this zoonosis, which is most often transmitted to humans by sheep, goats, or cows. In animals, it is usually not noticed, while in humans the symptoms are high fever, general malaise, and cough, and the disease can therefore be mistaken for flu or COVID-19.

The causative agent is rickettsia _Coxiella burnetii_, which spreads through urine, feces, milk, and especially placenta and amniotic fluid after parturition and/or abortion. Those who are in more frequent contact with animals are exposed to a greater risk of disease, and infection mostly occurs in the lambing season, i.e., in the spring. People most often get sick by inhaling contaminated air and dust.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Unije, an island in Croatia (map at <https://tinyurl.com/2p8xn5p5>), is part of the Cres-Lošinj archipelago, situated at the northern portion of the Adriatic Sea. It is 16.92 square kilometres (6.53 square miles) in size. The only settlement on the island, bearing the same name, contains, reportedly, 280 houses. Its year-round population is less than 85 residents, growing to more than 400 residents during the tourist season.

The goats, referred to in the above media report as 'wild goats' (_Capra aegagrus_), are rather feral goats, genetically similar to the domestic goat (_Capra hircus_), stated to be introduced from the mainland about 40-45 years ago. They are presented in a video clip included in the media report (<https://youtu.be/sf_D3G1tVcQ>). It will be interesting to note if the feral goats on Unije are related to Croatia's iconic, almost extinct Istrian goat breed (see at <https://phys.org/news/2021-04-croatia-iconic-istrian-goat.html>).

In March 2022, an outbreak of Q fever with non-occupational exposure was confirmed in a semi-urban area in Čavle, Croatia. Veterinary and human epidemiological investigations were conducted to identify the source of the outbreak and to implement appropriate control measures. The investigation revealed airborne transmission, from 3 nearby farms that held infected sheep and goats, as the most likely route of transmission. Among the animal samples analysed, all 16 goats (100%) and 24/50 sheep (48%) tested positive for _C. burnetii_ IgM/IgG antibodies, phase I and II. Persons who were near the farms (about 750  m [0.5 mi]) and lived in the nearest street to the farms had the highest risk of contracting Q fever. This was the largest Q fever outbreak in the county in the last 16  years, unexpected due to its location and non-occupational exposure. To stop the outbreak, numerous intensive biosecurity measures were implemented. As indicated in the paper, vaccination of animals and humans against Q fever is not implemented in Croatia due to the low incidence of infection (<https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/zph.13022>).

For more information on Q fever in humans and animals, subscribers are invited to visit the recent moderators' commentaries in ProMED post 20230228.8708632. - Mod.AS

column3: A large number of wild [see comment] goats, which have been a long-standing problem for the inhabitants of the small Adriatic island of Unije [of the Cres-Lošinj archipelago] are infected with Q fever.As 'Novi List' writes, tissue samples from dead or shot animals show this, with the note that this infection in humans can cause symptoms similar to flu or pneumonia, and in a small number of cases, damage to the heart, brain, liver, and lungs.According to estimates, there are about 400 to 500 of these animals, and as revealed by Robert Nikolić, the president of the Council of the local committee of the Union, they were brought to the island in the late '70s and early '80s. The Lošinj company Jadranka had sheep there, so the goal was to speed up the maquis and clear the land for the growth of grass and grazing for their sheep."What happened, however, was that they multiplied beyond measure, so now they are also a problem for the island's shepherds, because they also graze the grass that the sheep grazed," he said, noting that they tried to solve the problem in communication with the Town of Mali and others. "The city and the county refer us to the Ministry of Agriculture, and the Ministry simply ignored all our letters, calls, and requests. We never received any response," he told the media.He also points out that at the beginning of February [2023] they shot 16 goats, 11 of which were infected with Q fever, as shown by the analysis of samples at the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine in Zagreb.By the way, last year [2022] in the Rijeka area [continental Croatia, facing the archipelago], several locals fell ill from this zoonosis, which is most often transmitted to humans by sheep, goats, or cows. In animals, it is usually not noticed, while in humans the symptoms are high fever, general malaise, and cough, and the disease can therefore be mistaken for flu or COVID-19.The causative agent is rickettsia _Coxiella burnetii_, which spreads through urine, feces, milk, and especially placenta and amniotic fluid after parturition and/or abortion. Those who are in more frequent contact with animals are exposed to a greater risk of disease, and infection mostly occurs in the lambing season, i.e., in the spring. People most often get sick by inhaling contaminated air and dust.--Communicated by:ProMED[Unije, an island in Croatia (map at <https://tinyurl.com/2p8xn5p5>), is part of the Cres-Lošinj archipelago, situated at the northern portion of the Adriatic Sea. It is 16.92 square kilometres (6.53 square miles) in size. The only settlement on the island, bearing the same name, contains, reportedly, 280 houses. Its year-round population is less than 85 residents, growing to more than 400 residents during the tourist season.The goats, referred to in the above media report as 'wild goats' (_Capra aegagrus_), are rather feral goats, genetically similar to the domestic goat (_Capra hircus_), stated to be introduced from the mainland about 40-45 years ago. They are presented in a video clip included in the media report (<https://youtu.be/sf_D3G1tVcQ>). It will be interesting to note if the feral goats on Unije are related to Croatia's iconic, almost extinct Istrian goat breed (see at <https://phys.org/news/2021-04-croatia-iconic-istrian-goat.html>).In March 2022, an outbreak of Q fever with non-occupational exposure was confirmed in a semi-urban area in Čavle, Croatia. Veterinary and human epidemiological investigations were conducted to identify the source of the outbreak and to implement appropriate control measures. The investigation revealed airborne transmission, from 3 nearby farms that held infected sheep and goats, as the most likely route of transmission. Among the animal samples analysed, all 16 goats (100%) and 24/50 sheep (48%) tested positive for _C. burnetii_ IgM/IgG antibodies, phase I and II. Persons who were near the farms (about 750  m [0.5 mi]) and lived in the nearest street to the farms had the highest risk of contracting Q fever. This was the largest Q fever outbreak in the county in the last 16  years, unexpected due to its location and non-occupational exposure. To stop the outbreak, numerous intensive biosecurity measures were implemented. As indicated in the paper, vaccination of animals and humans against Q fever is not implemented in Croatia due to the low incidence of infection (<https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/zph.13022>).For more information on Q fever in humans and animals, subscribers are invited to visit the recent moderators' commentaries in ProMED post 20230228.8708632. - Mod.ASProMED map:Primorsko-Goranska Županija, Primorsko-Goranska, Croatia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708806,68692>]

column2:
LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (07): NIGERIA
***************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 26 Feb 2023
Source: Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) [edited]
<https://bit.ly/2KTJfrL>


Key points
----------
Table 1: Summary of current week (8), cumulative epi week 1-8, 2023, and comparison with previous year (2022)

Current week (8): 20-26 Feb 2023 / Cumulative weeks 1-8 2023 / Cumulative weeks 1-8 2022
- Suspected cases: 351 / 2978 / 2433
- Confirmed cases: 59 / 636 / 540
- Probable cases: 0 / 4 / 20
- Deaths: 10 / 104 / 98
- Case fatality rate (CFR [%]): 16.9 / 16.4 / 18.1
- Number of states affected: 10 / 22 / 21
- Local government areas (LGAs) affected: 24 / 88 / 79

Highlights

- In week 8, the number of new confirmed cases increased from 46 in week 7 2023 to 59 cases. These were reported from Benue, Bauchi, Ondo, Taraba, Edo, Ebonyi, Kano, Jigawa, FCT, and Kogi states (Table 3).
- Cumulatively from week 1 to week 8, 2023, 104 deaths have been reported with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 16.4%, which is lower than the CFR for the same period in 2022 (18.1%).
- In total for 2023, 22 states have recorded at least one confirmed case across 88 LGAs (Figures 2 and 3)
- Seventy percent (70%) of all confirmed Lassa fever cases were reported from 3 states (Ondo, Edo, and Bauchi), while 30% were reported from 7 states with confirmed Lassa fever cases. Of the 70% confirmed cases, Ondo reported 33%, Edo 28%, and Taraba 9%.
- The predominant age group affected is 21-30 years (range: 1 to 93 years, median age: 31 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:0.9 (Figure 4).
- The number of suspected cases increased compared to that reported for the same period in 2022.
- 4 new healthcare workers were affected in the reporting week 8.
- National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) activated to coordinate the response activities at all levels.

[The following are available at the source URL above.]

Figure 1 [graph]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases in Nigeria epidemiological week 48, 2022, to week 8, 2023
Figure 2 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever cases by states in Nigeria, week 8, 2023
Figure 3 [map]. Confirmed Lassa fever rate per 100 000 population for LGAs in Nigeria, week 8, 2023
Table 2: Key indicators for current week 2023 and trend compared to previous week, Nigeria
Table 3. Weekly and cumulative number of suspected and confirmed cases for 2023
Figure 4 [graph]. Age and sex pyramid showing the number of confirmed Lassa fever cases for 2023
Figure 5 [graph]: Number of confirmed cases with case fatality rate (CFR) by state, week 8, 2023
Figure 6 [graph]: Trend of confirmed cases by epidemiological week, 2019-2023, Nigeria

Challenges
- Late presentation of cases leading to an increase in CFR
- Poor health-seeking behaviour due to the high cost of treatment and clinical management of Lassa fever
- Poor environmental sanitation conditions observed in high-burden communities
- Poor awareness observed in high-burden communities

Notes on this report
Data source
Information for this disease was case-based data retrieved from the National Lassa fever Emergency Operations Centre.

Case definitions
- Suspected case:
Any individual presenting with one or more of the following: malaise, fever, headache, sore throat, cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, myalgia, chest pain, hearing loss and either
a. history of contact with excreta or urine of rodents; or
b. history of contact with a probable or confirmed Lassa fever case within a period of 21 days of onset of symptoms, OR
c. any person with inexplicable bleeding/hemorrhagia
- Confirmed case:
Any suspected case with laboratory confirmation (positive IgM antibody, PCR, or virus isolation).
- Probable case
Any suspected case (see definition above) who died or absconded without collection of specimen for laboratory testing.
- Contact
Anyone who has been exposed to an infected person, or to an infected person's secretions, excretions, or tissues within 3 weeks of last contact with a confirmed or probable case of Lassa fever.

Calculations
- Case fatality rate (CFR) for this disease is reported for confirmed cases only.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Nigeria may be passing the season of the year (weeks 3-10) when cases increase the most. The number of cases may have peaked earlier this year [2023] during weeks 2-5. The graph in Figure 6 shows an early and relatively higher peak in case numbers so far this year (2023) compared to earlier years. There were 59 new confirmed and 351 new suspected Lassa fever (LF) cases in week 8 (20-26 Feb 2023), indicating that LF virus transmission is decreasing. There were 10 deaths among the confirmed cases for week 8, 2023. There were 4 newly infected healthcare worker reported in week 8.

The report above confirms that Ondo, Edo, Bauchi, and Taraba states have the most confirmed cases. The number of states affected is 22 so far this year (2023), and the number of local government areas (LGAs) with at least one case is 88.

Transmission of LF virus occurs when individuals are in contact with rodent reservoir host excreta or are within healthcare facilities. It is encouraging to learn from previous reports this year (2023) that risk communications and community engagement activities have been scaled up across states in Nigeria using television, radio, print, social media, and other strategies for avoidance of contact with rodent virus reservoirs and their excreta. These efforts may have contributed to the decline in the number of cases over the past month.

Images of the rodent reservoirs of Lassa fever virus:
_Mastomys natalensis_: <https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis>; _Mastomys erythroleucus_ and _Hylomyscus pamfi_: <https://punchng.com/nigerias-large-rat-population-threatens-lassa-fever-war/>

One hopes that the ongoing public information campaign will help the local population to avoid the entry of these reservoir rodents into their houses and other buildings. - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Nigeria: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708805,62>]

column2:
CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE - NORTH AMERICA (02): CANADA (MANITOBA) NEW DEER SPECIES AFFECTED
*****************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 7 Mar 2023
Source: CTV News [edited]
<https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/chronic-wasting-disease-found-in-new-deer-species-in-manitoba-1.6301279>


Another species of deer has been detected suffering from chronic wasting disease (CWD) in Manitoba, according to the province.

CWD was first detected in Manitoba in 2021 in mule deer. Now the province said it has also been found in white-tailed deer.

"CWD is an incurable, fatal disease affecting members of the deer family (cervids)," the province said in a news release. "If the disease spreads and becomes endemic to Manitoba, there is a serious risk CWD will threaten the health of all cervid populations in the province."

Since it was first detected, there have been 20 positive cases found in Manitoba: 18 mule deer and 2 white-tailed deer. [These 2 deer must have come into the laboratory fairly close to the same time. - Mod.TG]

More positive tests could be discovered, as the province said wait times for tests are around 16 to 20 weeks, as there have been more submissions than capacity for testing.

The province said CWD is not known to impact people, but the meat of a CWD-infected animal should not be eaten.

"Hunters who are active in areas where CWD is a concern should have harvested animals tested, practice safe carcass-handling protocols, and avoid consumption of any animal having tested positive for CWD."

Sample results can be found online, and more information can be found on the government's website at <https://www.gov.mb.ca/nrnd/fish-wildlife/wildlife/cwd.html>.

[Byline: Devon McKendrick]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

["Chronic wasting disease (CWD) is a fatal, neurological illness occurring in North American cervids (members of the deer family), including white-tailed deer, mule deer, elk, and moose. Since its discovery in 1967, CWD has spread geographically and increased in prevalence locally. CWD is contagious; it can be transmitted freely within and among cervid populations. No treatments or vaccines are currently available.

"Chronic wasting disease is of great concern to wildlife managers. It has been detected in at least 23 states, 2 Canadian provinces, and South Korea. CWD is not known to infect livestock or humans.

"CWD is transmitted directly through animal-to-animal contact, and indirectly through contact with objects or environment contaminated with infectious material (including saliva, urine, feces, and carcasses of CWD-infected animals)." 
(<https://www.usgs.gov/faqs/what-chronic-wasting-disease>) - Mod.TG

ProMED map:
Manitoba Province, Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708804,261>]

column2:
NIPAH VIRUS - BANGLADESH (09): (RAJSHAHI)
*****************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<https://outbreaknewstoday.com/bangladesh-reports-3-more-nipah-virus-cases-brings-seasonal-total-to-14-89500/>


Health authorities in Bangladesh have reported 3 additional Nipah virus cases, including 2 additional deaths, according to a recent report. This is up from 11 cases and 8 deaths reported a little over 2 weeks ago.

According to the Institute of Epidemiology Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) in Dhaka, from January 2023 as of 4 Mar 2023, a total of 14 Nipah cases are identified through the surveillance system.

The new cases are reported from Manda upazila in Naogaon district in the Division of Rajshahi in western Bangladesh.

This outbreak is related to the consumption of date palm sap.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED-SoAs

[There is no information about the 3 new cases other than 2 of them died and their locations in Bangladesh. The above report mentions that the current outbreak is related to the consumption of raw (uncooked) date palm sap contaminated with Nipah virus. Presumably, that was the source of the infection in the 3 new cases. The previous ProMED post provides an overview of Nipah virus epidemiology and clinical considerations (see Nipah virus - Bangladesh (07): WHO, overview and details 20230218.8708466). - Mod.TY

Rajshahi Division, Bangladesh: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708803,10080>]

column2:
PLASTICOSIS, SEABIRDS - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) NEW ANTHROPOGENIC DISEASE
******************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023
Source: The Guardian [edited]
<https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/mar/03/plasticosis-new-disease-caused-by-plastics-discovered-in-seabirds>


A new disease caused solely by plastics has been discovered in seabirds.

The birds identified as having the disease, named plasticosis, have scarred digestive tracts from ingesting waste, scientists at the Natural History Museum in London say.

It is the 1st recorded instance of specifically plastic-induced fibrosis in wild animals, researchers say.

Plastic pollution is becoming so prevalent that the scarring was widespread across different ages of birds, according to the study, published in the Journal of Hazardous Materials [see reference below].

Young birds were found to have the disease, and it is thought chicks were being fed the plastic pollution by parents accidentally bringing it back in food.

Scientists, including the Natural History Museum's Dr Alex Bond and Dr Jennifer Lavers, studied flesh-footed shearwaters from Australia's Lord Howe Island [Tasman, Sea, Unincorporated area of New South Wales] to look at the relationship between levels of ingested plastic and the proventriculus organ -- the 1st part of a bird's stomach.

They found that the more plastic a bird had ingested, the more scarring it had. The disease can lead to the gradual breakdown of tubular glands in the proventriculus. Losing these glands can cause the birds to become more vulnerable to infection and parasites and affect their ability to digest food and absorb some vitamins.

Researchers called the fibrotic disease plasticosis to make it clear that it was caused by plastic in the environment.

When birds ingest small pieces of plastic, they found, it inflames the digestive tract. Over time, the persistent inflammation causes tissues to become scarred and disfigured, affecting digestion, growth, and survival.

Natural materials found in the stomachs of birds, such as pumice stones, did not cause the same problems, leading scientists to label this a specifically plastic-caused disease.

Bond, principal curator in charge of birds at the Natural History Museum, said: "While these birds can look healthy on the outside, they're not doing well on the inside. This study is the 1st time that stomach tissue has been investigated in this way and shows that plastic consumption can cause serious damage to these birds' digestive system."

Though the scientists studied only one species of bird in one part of the world, they believe it is likely that more species are affected, and say more research is needed to find out how widespread plasticosis is.

They say the exposure of all organisms to plastic is inevitable because plastic emissions are increasing and plastic pollution is becoming prevalent in all environments globally.

As this problem has only emerged in recent decades, it has not been widely studied. The researchers said: "Further, the ingestion of plastic has far-reaching and severe consequences, many of which we are only just beginning to fully document and understand."

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Reference
---------
Charlton-Howard HS, Bond AL, Rivers-Auty J, Lavers JL. 'Plasticosis': Characterising macro- and microplastic-associated fibrosis in seabird tissues. J Hazard Mater. 2023; 450: 131090. Epub ahead of print; <https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhazmat.2023.131090>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
--------
"As biota are increasingly exposed to plastic pollution, there is a need to closely examine the sub-lethal 'hidden' impacts of plastic ingestion. This emerging field of study has been limited to model species in controlled laboratory settings, with little data available for wild, free-living organisms. Highly impacted by plastic ingestion, flesh-footed shearwaters (_Ardenna carneipes_) are thus an apt species to examine these impacts in an environmentally relevant manner. A Masson's Trichrome stain was used to document any evidence of plastic-induced fibrosis, using collagen as a marker for scar tissue formation in the proventriculus (stomach) of 30 flesh-footed shearwater fledglings from Lord Howe Island, Australia. Plastic presence was highly associated with widespread scar tissue formation and extensive changes to, and even loss of, tissue structure within the mucosa and submucosa. Additionally, despite naturally occurring indigestible items, such as pumice, also being found in the gastrointestinal tract, this did not cause similar scarring. This highlights the unique pathological properties of plastics and raises concerns for other species impacted by plastic ingestion. Further, the extent and severity of fibrosis documented in this study gives support for a novel, plastic-induced fibrotic disease, which we define as 'plasticosis'."

Over 300 million tonnes of plastic are produced each year, 10 million tonnes of which enter the ocean and accumulate. This is a clear demonstration that the growing exposure to micro- and macro-plastics may have a considerable impact on the health dynamics of marine wildlife. - Mod.PMB

ProMED map of Lord Howe Island, New South Wales, Australia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708795,68908>]

column2:
HANTAVIRUS - AMERICAS (09): ARGENTINA (SANTA FE)
************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023 18:00 ART
Source: El Litoral [in Spanish trans. Mod.TY, summ., edited]
<https://www.ellitoral.com/salud/hantavirus-santafe-muerto-joven-menor->
edad-florencia-internado-hospital-reconquista-malbran_0_SvHHwWnGV6.html


On Monday morning [6 Mar 2023] the Santa Fe Health Ministry confirmed the death of a patient from [a] hantavirus [infection].

According to information in a press release, "The patient began to have symptoms on 13 Feb 2023 and died on 15 Feb  2023 while hospitalized in the Reconquista Hospital."

The government indicated that the patient who died "was a young male from the Florencia locality" and explained that "given the suspicion about the [etiology of the] case, the territorial teams carried out barrier precautions. To date, no people with symptoms compatible with hantavirus [infections] have been registered."

The clinical picture of hantavirus disease is characterized by a short-duration prodromal phase (average 4-6 days) in which the patient presents with fever, myalgia, fatigue, headache, and sometimes, a gastrointestinal picture with vomiting and diarrhea. In the most severe cases, the disease rapidly progresses to a cardiopulmonary phase, presenting respiratory distress and serious hemodynamic changes. The case fatality rate varies between 16 and 50% depending on the region of the country.

Laboratory findings include thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis with atypical lymphocytes, and elevated transaminases; acute renal failure can be found.

Transmission [of the virus] to humans can include:
- Areas where inhalation or direct contact with secretions with the virus from saliva, urine, or excrement of [infected] rodents.
- Transmission between people is infrequent and just with certain genotypes of the Andes virus that can occur within 48-72 hours from the beginning of fever.

Inter-human transmission with the [virus] genotypes circulating in Santa Fe province has not been reported.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[There is no indication of the specific environmental setting where this man might have acquired his infection. The health agency's investigation may determine that and presumably would inform the public in that locality about preventive measures for avoiding infection.

The virus involved with this unfortunate fatal case is not stated. Andes virus is unlikely because the range of its rodent host, the long-tailed pygmy rice rat, _Oligoryzomys longicaudatus_, is far to the west and south of Santa Fe in the Andes mountains and foothills of Argentina and Chile (a map of the distribution of the pygmy rice rat can be seen at <https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Map-of-the-distribution-of-Oligoryzomys-longicaudatus-in-Chile-and-Argentina-shaded_fig2_236214891>).

As noted in ProMED archive no. 20110430.1348, several endemic hantaviruses have been associated with human infection in Argentina: Andes virus (in western Argentina, in the long-tailed pygmy rice rat host, _Oligoryzomys longicaudatus_); related Andes-like viruses Hu39694 (in central Argentina, rodent host unknown); Maciel virus (in the dark bolo mouse, _Bolomys obscurus_); Lechiguana and Central Plata (in central Argentina, in the yellow pygmy rice rat, _O. flavescens_); Oran (in northwestern Argentina, in the long-tailed pygmy rice rat, _O. longicaudatus_); Anajatuba and Juquitiba viruses (in Fornes's pygmy rice rat, _O. fornesi_); and Bermejo virus (in western Argentina; in Chacoan pygmy rice rat, _O. chacoensis_). There is always the possibility of infection with Seoul hantavirus, widely distributed in the world in brown rats (_Rattus norvegicus_). Without laboratory confirmation, it is not possible to say with certainty which hantavirus was involved in this case in Santa Fe province. - Mod.TY

ProMED map of Argentina: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708781,54461>]

column2:
CORONAVIRUS DISEASE 2019 UPDATE (10): HONG KONG, XBB.1.5, SELECTED COUNTRIES, BIVALENT VACCINE, WHO
***************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Hong Kong: COVID-19 mask mandates 
[2] XBB.1.5: CDC severity guidance
[3] Selected countries
[A] Iran 
[B] UAE
[4] Protection against severe COVID-19 after a 2nd booster dose of the bivalent vaccine
[5] WHO: daily new cases reported (as of 28 Feb 2023)

******
[1] Hong Kong: COVID-19 mask mandates 
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: Financial Times [subscription required, abridged, edited]
<https://www.ft.com/content/e5d7fa78-642a-4189-8e83-bdbaad5ee172>


Asian financial hub was one of the last places to lift the mandate but many prefer to keep faces covered.

The Asian financial centre lifted its mask mandate this week after 945 days, making it one of the last places in the world to do so. But on [Wed 1 Mar 2023], the first time in almost 3 years that masks were not mandatory in classrooms or outdoors, only about 80 of the school's 700 students did not wear a mask.

Their reluctance was not unusual -- the vast majority of Hong Kong residents continue to wear a mask outdoors.

At the height of its COVID-19 outbreak last year [2022], Hong Kong's excess death rate was the worst in the world. But for most of the pandemic, Hong Kong pursued a zero-COVID policy, though a softer version than that implemented in mainland China, meaning the former British colony was effectively free of the virus for months at a time.

More than 93% of Hong Kong's 7.3 million population has now received 2 doses of a COVID-19 vaccine, and health experts said immunity had been built up. But mask-wearing may stem from high levels of anxiety about catching COVID-19 or feelings of "perceived personal control", Hui said.

Elsewhere in east Asia, people have also continued to wear masks.

Japan, which never imposed an official mask mandate, eased guidelines on masks from [13 Mar 2023], including for schools and public transport except during rush hour, when face coverings were still recommended but not enforced.

South Korea scrapped a mask mandate for most indoor public places except on public transport and in medical facilities in January [2023], after lifting the outdoor mask mandate in September [2022]. But many citizens continue to wear masks, and most students cover their faces in class. 

Singapore has mostly dropped its mask rules, which were previously some of the strictest in Asia, with residents risking fines and jail time if caught without a face covering.

The city-state lifted its outdoor mask mandate in March last year [2022], followed by indoors a few months later. Face coverings are no longer required on public transport as of last month. Coupled with year-round hot temperatures, mask-wearing is now minimal.

Mask use was prevalent in the region long before the COVID-19 pandemic. During the spring in South Korea, the government encourages mask-wearing to prevent respiratory problems from thick yellow dust that seasonally blows in from the Chinese desert.

Hongkongers in particular learned that masks could be effective at slowing the spread of respiratory disease during the deadly 2003 SARS epidemic, which killed almost 300 people, with a fatality rate of about 1%. Prior to COVID-19, people suffering from colds and influenza often wore face coverings on public transport and in workplaces.

--
Communicated by
ProMED

******
[2] XBB.1.5: CDC severity guidance
Date: Fri 24 Feb 2023
Source: NHK World [edited]
<https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20230224_18/>


The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says there appears to be no significant difference in disease severity between a quickly spreading omicron subvariant of the coronavirus and a previously dominant strain.

The omicron subvariant known as XBB.1.5 started to spread in the United States around last December [2022]. It is now estimated to account for some 80% of new coronavirus infections in the US.

The CDC studied about 9100 people who became infected with COVID-19 in New York City between last November [2022] and January of this year [2023]. It found that the hospitalization ratio of people infected with XBB.1.5 was 7.3%, compared to 6.4% among those infected with the previously predominant BQ.1.

The study also found no significant difference in the percentage of deaths. The ratio was 0.8% for XBB.1.5 and 0.6% for BQ.1.

The CDC concluded that the preliminary findings do not suggest more severe disease among patients infected with XBB.1.5 compared with those infected with BQ.1.

[XBB.1.5 is currently responsible for about 90% of SARS-CoV-2 infections in the US, according to the US CDC. It is currently the only omicron SARS-CoV-2 subvariant showing significant growth in the US. <https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2023-03-03/cdc-omicron-subvariant-xbb-1-5-responsible-for-90-of-new-coronavirus-infections> - Mod.LWW]

--
Communicated by
ProMED

******
[3] Selected countries
[A] Iran: COVID deaths in Iran become double digit again
Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: Iran Front Page [edited]
<https://ifpnews.com/covid-deaths-iran-double-digit/>


Thirteen more Iranians have died from the coronavirus over the past 24 hours bringing the total number of deaths to 144 858, Iran's Health Ministry said on [Wed 1 Mar 2023]. A total of 997 new cases of infection with COVID-19 were found over the past 24 hours, 422 of whom were hospitalized, he added.

The Iranian Health Ministry noted that [7 339 457] patients out of a total of [7 568 903] infected people have recovered or been discharged from hospitals.

As many as 301 COVID-19 patients are in critical condition and in intensive care units, the report added.

The Iranian Health Ministry also announced that 65 203 494 Iranians have received the first dose and 58 598 023 people have so far received the 2nd dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. Moreover, 31 643 214 people have also received the 3rd or 4th shots as the booster jab.

[It is unclear which SARS-CoV-2 variant is circulating in Iran, but it is reasonable to expect that they will be similar to variants currently circulating in surrounding countries and worldwide. These variants have significant ability to escape vaccine-induced immunity, and those who have received booster doses tend to be better protected against currently circulating variants. Official numbers reported indicate that only about 36% of Iranians have received one or 2 booster doses, and it is unclear which vaccines were predominantly used. More information is needed to assess whether the proportion of severe cases and the fatality rate is higher than usual. ProMED is monitoring reports coming out of selected countries, and welcomes any submissions of information from our readers <https://promedmail.org/submitinfo/>. - Mod.LWW]

--
Communicated by
ProMED

----
[B] UAE
Date: Sun 5 Mar 2023
Source: Khaleej Times [edited]
<https://www.khaleejtimes.com/coronavirus/coronavirus-uae-reports-145-covid-19-cases-65-recoveries-no-deaths>


The UAE Ministry of Health and Prevention on [Sun 5 Mar 2023] reported 145 cases of COVID-19, along with 65 recoveries and no deaths.

The new cases were detected through 17 835 additional tests.

The total number of cases in UAE as of [Sun 5 Mar 2023] is 1 052 664 while total recoveries stand at 1 035 572. The death toll stands at 2349.

Over 199 327 303 PCR tests have been conducted in the country so far.

--
Communicated by
ProMED

******
[4] Protection against severe COVID-19 after a 2nd booster dose of the bivalent COVID-19 vaccine
Date: 23 Feb 2023
Source: Eurosurveillance [abridged, edited]
<https://www.eurosurveillance.org/content/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2023.28.8.2300105>


Citation: Fabiani M, Mateo-Urdiales A, Sacco C, et al., on behalf of the Italian Integrated Surveillance of COVID-19 study group and of the Italian COVID-19 Vaccines Registry group. Protection against severe COVID-19 after a 2nd booster dose of adapted bivalent (original/omicron BA.4-5) mRNA vaccine in persons ≥ 60 years, by time since infection, Italy, 12 September to 11 December 2022. Eurosurveillance. 2023;28(8):pii=2300105. <https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2023.28.8.2300105>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Background
----------
Given the high circulation of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) during the year 2022, characterised by predominance of the omicron variant, hybrid immunity conferred by vaccination and infection has become a frequent immunological status in the population, requiring a careful evaluation to refine indications on timing for the administration of a booster dose. Our aim was to evaluate, among persons ≥ 60 years, the effectiveness against severe coronavirus disease (COVID-19) of a 2nd booster dose of the bivalent (original/BA.4-5) mRNA vaccine (BioNtech/Pfizer, Mainz, Germany/New York, United States (US)), relative to a first booster dose of a monovalent vaccine (Comirnaty (BNT162b2 mRNA, BioNtech/Pfizer) or Spikevax (mRNA-1273, Moderna, Cambridge, US) given at least 120 days earlier, according to the time elapsed since a prior SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Methods
-------
We conducted a retrospective cohort study in Italy based on data from the national vaccination registry and the national COVID-19 surveillance system linked through the participants' individual tax code. The study was conducted during predominant circulation of the omicron BA.5 (Phylogenetic Assignment of Named Global Outbreak lineage (Pango) lineage B.1.1.529.5) subvariant (> 90%) [1]. It started on [12 Sep 2022] and ended on [11 Dec 2022]. We used data extracted from both sources on [11 Jan 2023] to account for an additional 28-day period to ascertain possible hospitalisation or death post-infection and 3 days of possible notification delay.

Findings
--------
We found that, among persons ≥ 60 years of age in Italy, the rVE of a 2nd booster dose of the adapted bivalent original/BA.4-5 mRNA vaccine in the time-interval 7-90 days post-administration, compared with a first booster dose of a monovalent mRNA vaccine received at least 120 days earlier, was 60% in those without a prior infection and in those with a prior infection occurring more than 6 months earlier (≥ 27 weeks). However, we did not observe an additional significant protective effect following the administration of the 2nd booster dose in those infected 4-6 months earlier (17-26 weeks). 

Conclusion
------------
The results of this study suggest that, for persons ≥ 60 years and with a prior SARS-CoV-2 infection, a 2nd booster dose of the bivalent original/BA.4-5 mRNA vaccine 6 months after the latest infection might be warranted.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[5] WHO: daily new cases reported (as of 28 Feb 2023)
Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
Source: WHO [abridged, edited]
<https://covid19.who.int/table>


* Daily case reports as of 28 Feb 2023 18:06 CET

Surveillance

column2:
MUMPS UPDATE: NAMIBIA (OSHANA) PRIMARY SCHOOL
*********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023
Source: The Namibian [edited]
<https://www.namibian.com.na/120459/read/Mumps-outbreak-in-Oshana-region>


The Oshana region has been hit by a mumps outbreak.

The highly contagious disease, which is caused by a virus, was detected at Oshakati West Primary School in the region about 2 weeks ago.

Oshana health director Johanna Haimene yesterday [5 Mar 2023] said a team of healthcare officials will be dispatched to the school today to monitor the situation. Pupils attending the school have been urged to be cautious at all times.

"The outbreak was reported to my office on Friday [3 Mar 2023], however, I cannot divulge any information on the matter, because our health officers are yet to assess the situation at the school.

"We have not gathered any additional information as of yet. More details will be shared tomorrow [7 Mar 2023] after inspection at the school," Haimene said.

About 12 pupils are reportedly affected, and they were last week sent home to recover. Pupils' parents and guardians have been asked to provide the children with masks in an effort to minimise the further spread of the disease.

Haimene said the health directorate, together with the school, will be monitoring the situation until the outbreak has been contained, as mumps is highly contagious. The last suspected pumps outbreak in Namibia was reported in September 2022, when the Erongo regional health directorate issued a warning of a suspected outbreak in the Swakopmund district.

At the time, the chief medical officer of the Erongo region, Dr Leonard Kabongo, said 26 suspected cases were reported in the Swakopmund district as of 9-20 Sep 2022 at Swakopmund and 3 cases each at Arandis and Henties Bay. Kabongo at the time said symptoms of the virus typically appear 16-18 days after infection.

According to a nonprofit academic medical centre, Mayo Clinic, mumps usually affects the glands on each side of the face. Symptoms may be similar to flu, including fever, headache, muscle aches, a loss of appetite, and tiredness.

The disease is spread through saliva, coughing, and sneezing, as well as through touching surfaces where droplets have landed, touching the face, or direct contact, such as kissing.

[Byline: Hileni Nembwaya]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Mumps virus, scientific name _Mumps orthorubulavirus_, is in the family Paramyxoviridae. The virus usually affects the parotid glands, which swell within a few days of infection, causing pain or tenderness around the swelling. The disease, mumps, can be prevented by the mumps vaccine, which is a part of the recommended childhood vaccinations. It's usually given as a combined measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. The schedule is: the 1st dose between the ages of 12 and 15 months; the 2nd dose between the ages of 4 and 6 years, before entering school.

Another version of MMR includes the vaccine against the virus that causes chickenpox, (varicella-zoster virus). But that vaccine, called the measles-mumps-rubella-varicella vaccine (MMRV) is not used for the 1st dose in the standard vaccination schedule for children.

Infection is generally mild but unvaccinated individuals may suffer complications of infection, including swollen testicles (orchitis); swollen ovaries (oophoritis); encephalitis; meningitis; hearing loss (hearing usually gets better after the illness); pancreatitis; miscarriage (especially during the 1st 12 weeks of pregnancy)
(<https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/mumps/symptoms-causes/syc-20375361>). - Mod.LK

ProMED map of Namibia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708787,49155>

]

column2:
MEASLES UPDATE (12): UKRAINE, AUSTRALIA (TASMANIA), USA (KENTUCKY)
******************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Ukraine
[2] Australia (Tasmania, Launceston): travel related
[3] USA (Kentucky, Asbury University): CDC health advisory

******
[1] Ukraine
Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023 15:02 EET
Source: RBC [in Ukrainian, machine trans., summ., edited]
Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023 at 4:24 PM
<https://www.rbc.ua/rus/news/ukrayini-viyavili-dva-vipadki-koru-ukrayintsyam-1678107574.html>


Two cases of measles were detected in Ukraine. Ukrainians were reminded how to protect themselves. This is reported by RBC-Ukraine with reference to the Ministry of Health.

"Both children are from the same family, one of them previously received the 1st dose of vaccination, the other was not vaccinated," the message reads.

Currently, according to the Ministry of Health, the children are being provided with the necessary medical care, those who came in contact with them were subjected to a PCR test to detect measles, and the results were negative.

In order to protect against measles, 2 doses of the vaccine must be given.

"If your child is over 6 months old, if there are epidemic indications, you can administer a zero dose of the vaccine, which is not counted as the 1st dose of vaccination," added the Ministry of Health.

[Byline: Natalia Gurkovska]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[It is difficult to imagine how Ukraine can maintain a vaccination program with the ongoing conflict with Russia. The situation is dire with little hope for a resolution soon. Sadly, it is always the children who suffer the most, but because living conditions are so difficult for everyone, the whole population is at risk.

Holt E. Experts warn over potential for measles in Ukraine. Lancet. 2023;  401(10378): 719; <https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(23)00436-1>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"Ukraine has a history of large outbreaks, and experts say that the disruptions brought by Russia's invasion could trigger new cases. Ed Holt reports.

"Measles vaccine coverage rates in Ukraine have dipped sharply since the start of Russia's full-scale invasion of the country on 24 Feb 2022, raising fears of a large outbreak. Measles is endemic in Ukraine, and there have been two major outbreaks in the past decade. In 2017-19, more than 115 000 people were infected and 41 died. Most infections were among those who were either unvaccinated or whose vaccination status was undetermined.

"At the start of the 2017-19 outbreak, national vaccination coverage was 42% -- well below the 95% that WHO says is needed for herd immunity -- due to a mixture of strong vaccine hesitancy and shortages of the vaccine. Following the outbreak, intensive efforts by Ukrainian health authorities to encourage vaccination pushed coverage up to 88% in 2021. But last year [2022] it fell to 74%.

"Last month [February 2023], WHO warned of the risks of disease outbreaks in the country, and with such low vaccine coverage, some healthcare experts fear a major outbreak is not far off. Pavlo Kovtoniuk was Deputy Health Minister of Ukraine at the time of the outbreak and is now head of the Ukrainian Healthcare Centre, a Kyiv-based non-governmental organisation. "I remember what it was like then and I can see it happening again, maybe not immediately, but within a year", he told The Lancet.

"Experts say mass population displacement due to the Russian invasion -- the UN estimates that there are at least 6 million internally displaced people (IDPs) in Ukraine now -- has affected coverage, with many IDPs missing vaccinations. "Some have lost all their documents and do not want to start vaccination again or do not have the money for tests to check their immunity to measles", said Professor Alla Volokha, Head of the Paediatric Infectious Diseases and Paediatric Immunology Department at Shupyk National Healthcare University of Ukraine. "Registering with local doctors also may not be on top of their list of priorities", she said, adding that others might be reluctant to give personal details over fears of possible army conscription.

"Many IDPs living in crowded accommodations and are often already in weakened health after their ordeal or because of pre-existing illness. "Measles is one of the most contagious diseases and 9 out of 10 unimmune persons will get infected upon contact with a sick person. The higher the number of vulnerable individuals there are in a community, the higher an individual's risk will be of contracting the disease. The risk of developing severe or fatal measles increases for children aged under 5 [years], persons living in overcrowded conditions, those who are malnourished, and those with immunological disorders, such as AIDS", Jarno Habicht, WHO Representative in Ukraine, told The Lancet.

"The health system was already under severe pressure following the COVID-19 pandemic; it has since had to cope with clinics and hospitals being targeted by Russian troops and frequent power outages. "Everyone is doing their best, but disease surveillance may not be as high as it was pre-war", Siddhartha Sankar Datta, Regional Adviser for Vaccine-preventable Diseases and Immunization at WHO, told The Lancet. "If we don't know very quickly where cases are, then if there is a case out there, [the disease] could spread like wildfire."

"Ukrainian health authorities are working to improve vaccination coverage. The health ministry has prioritised immunisation programmes and, in cooperation with organisations such as UNICEF and WHO, has ensured supply and safe storage of vaccines, as well as delivery to areas without accessible healthcare facilities through mobile vaccination teams. Outreach services have also been set up to encourage people to get vaccinated.

"Last year [2022], 11 measles cases were recorded in the country. Ironically, the low number is thought to be largely due to the war, as schools have closed and teaching has moved mainly online, while large public events have not been held. There have been no cases reported yet this year [2023], and Datta said that while a repeat of the 2017-19 outbreak was possible, he was optimistic it could be avoided through a strong vaccination catch-up campaign this year.

"But others believe it is only a matter of time before a large outbreak occurs. Professor Andrii Loboda of the Department of Paediatrics at Sumy State University in Ukraine said one could come as soon as this year as, despite ongoing fighting, a degree of stability was returning to society which would eventually lead to children meeting again in classrooms and others returning to the country from abroad.

"He also warned that any outbreak "could be more severe than the last one". "In the 2017-2019 outbreak, 65-67% of the affected were children and 33-35% were adults...but now we have a new risk group among adults -- our military forces. Our soldiers are suffering from cold, rain, respiratory infections, and stress that predisposes to a lack of immunity; crowds of soldiers and insufficient infection control on the front line of military operations could prompt the rapid spread of measles."
- Mod.LK

ProMED map of Ukraine: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708786,123>]

******
[2] Australia (Tasmania, Launceston): travel related
Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023
Source: Tasmanian Talks [abridged, edited]
<https://www.tasmaniatalks.com.au/newsroom/tasmanian-news/64219-measles-in-launceston>


A person in their late 20s is in isolation in hospital in Launceston as they become Tasmania's 1st measles case since 2019. The patient had recently returned from overseas travel.

This was released by Public Health: Measles is a highly infectious illness that is rare in Australia. Cases and small outbreaks occasionally occur and are usually associated with overseas travel. People who have had 2 doses of the measles vaccine or were born before 1966 are generally protected against catching measles. The case is now in isolation at the Launceston General Hospital. Contact tracing is underway to identify people who may have been exposed to the case while they were infectious.

[See URL above for details on where the case spent time while infectious. - Mod.LK]

People who were present at the locations [noted in the URL] during the times listed and have not received 2 measles-containing vaccines are urged to be alert for measles symptoms for up to 18 days following their exposure. Public Health advises that these locations do not pose an ongoing risk to the public, the risk only remains for up to 30 minutes after the case has left each location. People at risk of measles infection include those born during or after 1966 who have not been fully vaccinated against measles, are immunocompromised, or have not had a previous measles infection. Measles is vaccine-preventable and those who have received 2 doses of a measles-containing vaccine have a high level of protection against measles. If symptoms develop, individuals are advised to isolate, contact the Public Health Hotline, and if they need medical attention, they should call ahead and advise of their concerns of measles to prevent further spread.

2 doses of a measles-containing vaccine provide a high level of protection against measles. The measles vaccine is recommended for all children at 12 months and 18 months of age. Vaccines are available through GPs, council clinics, and community health centres. Under the National Immunisation Program, the vaccine is free for children aged 12 and 18 months. The measles vaccine is also available from pharmacies for eligible people aged 16 years and older. Under a state-funded program, the measles vaccine is also free for
- Tasmanians born during or after 1966 who do not have documented evidence of receiving 2 measles-containing vaccines or serological (blood test) evidence of immunity.
-  Infants aged 6-12 months who are travelling overseas.

Most people born before 1966 are considered immune to measles because they are likely to have had the infection as children.

To find out more about measles and vaccination visit <https://www.health.tas.gov.au/publications/measles-fact-sheet>

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

["Tasmania is an island state of Australia. It is located 240 km (150 mi) to the south of the Australian mainland, separated from it by the Bass Strait, with the archipelago containing the southernmost point of the country. The state encompasses the main island of Tasmania, the 26th-largest island in the world, and the surrounding 1000 islands. It is Australia's least populous state, with 569 825 residents as of December 2021."
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tasmania>)

This is yet another case of travel-related measles. This disease is rare in Australia and cases are generally travel-related. It is important to maintain vaccination even in countries where measles is not recognized as a major problem because of the possibility of travel-related transmission. Measles is one of the most infectious viruses known, thus easily spread. - Mod.LK

ProMED map of Tasmania, Australia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708786,6517>]

******
[3] USA (Kentucky, Asbury University): CDC health advisory
Date: Sat 4 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<http://outbreaknewstoday.com/cdc-undetermined-number-of-these-people-may-have-been-exposed-to-measles-at-asbury-university-78151/>


CDC: 'Undetermined number of these people may have been exposed  to measles at Asbury University

In a follow-up on the confirmed case of measles in an unvaccinated individual who attended a large spiritual revival on Asbury University's campus in Wilmore, Kentucky on 18 Feb 2023, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) issued a health advisory [see ProMED Measles update (11): Ghana, South Africa, India, USA 20230227.8708629].

Officials say an estimated 20 000 people attended the gathering from Kentucky, other US states, and other countries during 17-18 Feb 2023, and an undetermined number of these people may have been exposed.

CDC offered the following recommendations for the public (including children) and those who attended the gathering:
- If you attended the Asbury University gathering on 17 or 18 Feb 2023 and you are unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated against measles, you should quarantine for 21 days after your last exposure and monitor yourself for symptoms of measles so that you do not spread measles to others.
- If you attended the gathering and are not up to date on your measles vaccinations, talk to your healthcare provider right away about getting vaccinated after completing your quarantine.
- If you think that you have measles or have been exposed to someone with measles, isolate yourself from others and call your healthcare provider, urgent care, or emergency room before arriving to be tested. Do not arrive at a healthcare facility without giving advance notice.
- Measles is extremely contagious and can cause life-threatening illness. Anyone who is not protected against measles is at risk. An unvaccinated person can get measles when traveling abroad or in the US.

2 doses of MMR vaccine provide better protection against measles than one dose.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Kentucky, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708786,67866>]

column3: CDC: 'Undetermined number of these people may have been exposed  to measles at Asbury UniversityIn a follow-up on the confirmed case of measles in an unvaccinated individual who attended a large spiritual revival on Asbury University's campus in Wilmore, Kentucky on 18 Feb 2023, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) issued a health advisory [see ProMED Measles update (11): Ghana, South Africa, India, USA 20230227.8708629].Officials say an estimated 20 000 people attended the gathering from Kentucky, other US states, and other countries during 17-18 Feb 2023, and an undetermined number of these people may have been exposed.CDC offered the following recommendations for the public (including children) and those who attended the gathering:- If you attended the Asbury University gathering on 17 or 18 Feb 2023 and you are unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated against measles, you should quarantine for 21 days after your last exposure and monitor yourself for symptoms of measles so that you do not spread measles to others.- If you attended the gathering and are not up to date on your measles vaccinations, talk to your healthcare provider right away about getting vaccinated after completing your quarantine.- If you think that you have measles or have been exposed to someone with measles, isolate yourself from others and call your healthcare provider, urgent care, or emergency room before arriving to be tested. Do not arrive at a healthcare facility without giving advance notice.- Measles is extremely contagious and can cause life-threatening illness. Anyone who is not protected against measles is at risk. An unvaccinated person can get measles when traveling abroad or in the US.2 doses of MMR vaccine provide better protection against measles than one dose.--Communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of Kentucky, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708786,67866>]

column2:
MURRAY VALLEY ENCEPHALITIS - AUSTRALIA (04): (VICTORIA) FATAL
*************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 6 Mar 2023
Source: Victoria Department of Health Facebook  [edited]
<https://www.facebook.com/149267993912219/posts/603502718488742>


Two new cases of Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE) virus infection and one death have been confirmed in Victoria. One case was identified in a woman in her 60s who died in late February 2023 [see Murray Valley encephalitis - Australia (02): (VI) 20230218.8708465], and the other is a man in his 70s who is receiving treatment in hospital. Both were likely exposed to infected mosquitoes in northern Victoria.

The risk of mosquito-borne diseases such as Japanese encephalitis (JE), MVE, and West Nile (Kunjin) virus infections is high this season, particularly in northern Victoria where viruses are being detected in mosquitoes.

A total of 3 cases of MVE virus infection and 2 deaths have been reported in Victoria this mosquito season.

MVE is a rare but potentially serious infection of the brain spread to humans by infected mosquitoes. There is no vaccine for MVE, the best prevention is to protect yourself against mosquito bites.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Additional information is available at <https://www.health.vic.gov.au/health-alerts/murray-valley-encephalitis-virus-detected-in-victoria>.

The Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE) case count in Victoria state is now up to 3 this transmission season, with 2 fatalities. It has been known that MVE is circulating in the state because the very effective mosquito monitoring system in Victoria has found the virus at several locations. More cases could occur in the coming 2-3 months. MVE cases have occurred sporadically in Victoria state in the past. As the report above indicates, there is no vaccine for the virus, so avoidance of mosquito bites is the only preventive measure available. - Mod.TY

ProMED map of Victoria, Australia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708785,288>]

[See Also:
Murray Valley encephalitis - Australia (02): (VI) 20230218.8708465
2011
----
