column3: Contaminated cough and paracetamol syrups imported into Gambia almost certainly caused the deaths of 66 children due to acute kidney injury, according to an investigation led by the United States Center for Disease Control and Prevention and Gambian scientists.The links between the children's deaths and contaminated medicines first came to light in October [2022], when the World Health Organization sent out an alert saying 4 cough syrups made by India's Maiden Pharmaceuticals Ltd contained toxic levels of diethylene and ethylene glycol and should be withdrawn.The new investigation "strongly suggests" medicines contaminated with the toxins, imported into Gambia, led to the cluster of acute kidney injury among 78 children. Most were aged under 2, and 66 died between June and September 2022. Four more children have since died, bringing the official toll up to 70.Maiden has denied its drugs were at fault for the deaths in Gambia, and the Indian government has said the syrups showed no contamination when it tested them. Production at the factory was stopped in October [2022], but the company is now seeking to restart work.The report [see citation below], published in the New England Journal of Medicine on Thursday [2 Mar 2023], reached its conclusions by looking at medical records of patients where available, as well as interviews with their parents and caregivers. It also says other evidence, such as the tests of the medicines, the wide geographic spread of the cases, and the fact the illness did not spread to adults, pointed towards a toxin rather than an infectious agent.There have been a number of poisonings linked to diethylene and ethylene glycol in the past in countries including Haiti and Nigeria, but the report says this is the 1st known incident when imported medicines were at fault rather than domestically developed drugs."This likely poisoning event highlights the potential public health risks posed by the inadequate quality management of pharmaceutical exports," the report said.Since the deaths in Gambia, 201 children have also died in Indonesia, and 19 in Uzbekistan, linked to different manufacturers' contaminated cough syrups.[Byline: Jennifer Rigby]--Communicated by:ProMED[This is a huge tragedy. My heart goes out to the families affected. There is really no excuse for a company, any company, to distribute toxic medication.Testing must be rigorous and excessively thorough, even for toxins, bacteria, or viruses deemed to be on the outer realms of possibility. Yes, such testing may be time-consuming and expensive, but nothing compares to taking the life of a human being, and many individuals in this case.An earlier article stated that diethylene glycol and ethylene glycol "are used as a cheaper alternative in some pharmaceutical products to glycerine, a solvent or thickening agent in many cough syrups."(<https://www.reuters.com/world/india/indian-state-drug-controller-finds-violations-maiden-pharma-factory-cnbc-tv18-2022-10-12/> from ProMED post 20221016.8706145)This issue of a substitution of diethylene glycol and ethylene glycol is not limited to India. It appears to be a much broader situation, as it now encompasses Gambia and possibly Indonesia, and more cases could be discovered in other regions.These glycols have been shown to be toxic in humans and have been known about for many years. While many may argue the dose makes the toxin, it could also be argued the child is much less able to metabolize or excrete these toxins.This is a tragedy or unimaginable heartbreak. Hopefully those responsible will be held accountable. Profit over lives is never acceptable. - Mod.TGThe citation for the report referenced above follows:Schier J, Chang A, Kapil v. Medication-associated diethylene glycol mass poisoning: A preventable cause of illness and death. N Engl J Med. 2023; doi: 10.1056/NEJMp2215840.ProMED map:Gambia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708760,481>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (38): AMERICAS (ARGENTINA, ECUADOR, MEXICO, USA) MIXED POULTRY
******************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this post:
Argentina
[1] Argentina (Córdoba, Salta): wild and domestic birds
[2] Argentina: public message
Ecuador
[3] Avian influenza vaccine
Mexico
[4] Mexico (Aguascaliente): poultry
USA
[5] Tennessee (Weakley County): mixed flocks

******
Argentina
[1] Argentina (Córdoba, Salta): wild and domestic birds
Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023
Source: MercoPress [edited]
<https://en.mercopress.com/2023/02/21/argentina-ups-security-measures-as-number-of-avian-flu-cases-grows>


Argentina's health authorities have decided to up their biosecurity measures following the increase in the number of avian flu cases detected nationwide, particularly in provinces bordering Uruguay, but also in Córdoba and Salta.

After declaring a sanitary emergency a few days ago, the National Agrifood Health and Quality Service (Senasa) reinforced epidemiological surveillance controls. Thus, the agency is dealing with cases in backyards, carrying out surveys in the areas where positive cases were detected.

The agency continues to carry out raking and surveillance in Córdoba and Salta, in addition to preventive controls in the province of Entre Ríos on the border with Uruguay.

In Córdoba, the positive cases of avian influenza were in 2 wild ducks at Las Mojarras lagoon in the Department of General San Martín, and in backyard turkeys located in Alejo Ledesma. In addition to verifying the general condition of the animals, a perimeter was delimited to track and verify possible additional cases.

In Salta, Senasa shut down a backyard establishment where the positive case occurred. Other joint measures were also taken with the provincial Ministry of Production as well as with the National Institute of Agricultural Technology (INTA).

In addition to border controls in Entre Ríos, Senasa continues to carry out checkups in areas bordering Brazil, Bolivia, and Paraguay, it was reported.

Meanwhile, new cases of avian influenza (AI) H5 were confirmed in the province of Santa Fe, Senasa acknowledged. The cases were recorded in the town of Villa Cañás, in backyard chickens and turkeys found dead.

Last week, the Agriculture Secretariat declared a nationwide sanitary emergency after confirming the 1st case of avian influenza in the country in Andean geese in Laguna de Pozuelos, in the north of the province of Jujuy.

Senasa urged the productive sector to reinforce all biosecurity measures and requested the immediate notification of any possible detection of "nervous, digestive, or respiratory clinical signs; decrease in egg production, water, or feed consumption; and high mortality in domestic or wild birds."

In case of suspicion of clinical signs compatible with avian flu, Senasa must be notified. However, Senasa Vice President Rodolfo Acerbi insisted avian influenza does not represent a danger to the human population in Argentina.

The cases of avian flu detected in Argentina are caused by migratory wild birds arriving from the northern hemisphere's winter, Senasa's Health Director Ximena Melón explained.

These birds go down to eat where there is poultry for human consumption, which is where contagion occurs, Melón added. Hence, this poultry should be confined. The signs are easy to recognize: ruffled feathers and diarrhea.

Avian flu is a zoonosis, which can be transmitted to humans, but only when a sick bird is touched or handled without protection.

Melón also explained avian flu cannot be transmitted through the consumption of eggs from sick birds.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Argentina: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708757,4>]

******
[2] Argentina: public message
Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023
Source: Buenos Aires Herald [edited]
<https://buenosairesherald.com/society/bird-flu-is-not-a-risk-for-the-general-public-government-says>


Vice-president of Argentina's National Healthcare and Agrifood Quality Service (Senasa) Rodolfo Acerbi said on Monday [20 Feb 2023] that the chances of people being affected by bird flu are low, stressing that the disease is not transmitted through consuming chicken or eggs.

"The only way people can get infected is if they handle dead or diseased birds," Acerbi told the news agency Télam, adding that avian influenza does not represent a risk to the health of the country's population.

In total, Senasa has confirmed 5 cases among wild birds and birds raised on small farms: the 1st one in Jujuy on 14 Feb [2023] and the latest in Santa Fe on 19 Feb [2023]. The disease has also been detected in Córdoba and Salta. So far, Senasa has received a total of 98 reported cases, which have yet to be confirmed.

Last Wednesday [15 Feb 2023], Health Access Secretary Sandra Tirado said in a press conference people should cook poultry well and consult with physicians if they show symptoms following direct contact with birds. Symptoms in humans can range from mild infections -- a fever or a cough -- to severe respiratory issues and pneumonia.

The Health Ministry also recommended adopting the following preventive measures:

- Frequently wash hands with water and soap or use alcohol-based disinfectants.
- Avoid contact with wild birds.
- In case of finding dead or sick birds, avoid contact and report them to the Senasa.
- Do not touch surfaces possibly contaminated with wild birds' or poultry's saliva, mucosa, or feces.
- There are currently no travel restrictions in place, but people going to areas that are potentially affected by bird flu are being urged to adopt preventive measures.

At the time of writing, the potentially affected areas identified by the ministry were Laguna de las Mojarras and Alejo Ledesma in Córdoba, Laguna de los Pozuelos in Jujuy, Cerrillos in Salta, and Villa Cañas in Santa Fe.

Senasa has reinforced its epidemiological monitoring in those areas, including disinfecting vehicles and farms. In Córdoba and Salta, inspections were held in the zones where the cases were detected, and there are preventive controls at the Uruguayan border in Entre Ríos.

The ministry also clarified that city birds such as pigeons and sparrows are low risk because they are not susceptible to the virus.

The spread of new cases across the region has raised alarms across Latin America, and the Argentine government will hold a summit today [21 Feb 2023] to discuss next steps. So far, cases have been confirmed in Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Uruguay, Chile, and Argentina. Suspected cases of the disease, which have not been confirmed, have been reported in Paraguay and Brazil.

You can report sightings of diseased or dead birds at local Senasa offices, by emailing <notificaciones@senasa.gob.ar>, by calling or sending a WhatsApp message to 11-5700-5704, by downloading the "Notificaciones Senasa" app, or on the Senasa website.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
Ecuador
[3] Avian influenza vaccine
Date: Wed 22 Feb 2023
Source: Prensa Latina [edited]
<https://www.plenglish.com/news/2023/02/22/4m-vaccine-doses-to-arrive-in-ecuador-to-fight-off-bird-flu-outbreak/>


Ecuador´s Agency of Regulation and Phytosanitary and Zoosanitary Control (AGROCALIDAD) on Wednesday [22 Feb 2023] confirmed the arrival of 4 million doses of vaccines against bird flu.

Since 2022, Ecuadorean authorities have detected several outbreaks in the provinces of Pichincha, Cotopaxi, Bolivar, and Tungurahua.

During 1st phase, AGROCALIDAD will allocate the new vaccine doses to the farms where bird flu cases were reported.

In a press release, AGROCALIDAD assured the new vaccine is safe and implies no risk for humans. Plus, AGROCALIDAD believes the new measure helps to reduce mortality rate of infected birds [by 40-80%].

Bird flu virus has been present in Ecuador since end-November 2022. To date [22 Feb 2023], about 1.2 million birds have died or been culled.

In January [2023], local authorities reported the 1st case of human transmission in a minor who was probably infected by direct contact with backyard poultry in the province of Bolivar.

According to the World Organization for Animal Health, bird flu virus is also affecting Canada, the United States, Mexico, Colombia, Peru ,and Chile, among others.

[Byline: Pavel López Lazo]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Ecuador: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708757,8>]

******
Mexico
[4] Mexico (Aguascaliente): poultry
Date: Sat 4 Mar 2023
Source: Mexico Daily Post [edited]
<https://mexicodailypost.com/2023/03/04/outbreak-of-avian-influenza-detected-in-three-aguascalientes-farms/>


After conducting an epidemiological investigation, the National Service for Agrifood Health, Safety and Quality (Senasica ) detected the outbreak of the AH5N1 avian influenza virus in 3 farms in the interior of the state of Aguascalientes. As a result, they implemented the quarantine and will strengthen surveillance to prevent the spread of the pathogen to other regions.

According to the official report, the 3 broiler farms were located in the municipalities of Aguascalientes, as well as in Asientos and Rincón de Romos. In order to prevent dispersion, the general directorate of animal health (DGSA) imposed a definitive quarantine in the 3 poultry production units that housed 826 800 birds.

Influenza AH5N1, also known as bird flu, is considered highly pathogenic, as it has a high chance of causing disease with strong and severe signs in the host. In addition, it can spread rapidly, so there is a risk of causing high mortality rates in different species of birds.

According to the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO ), most avian influenza viruses are not zoonotic, meaning they cannot be easily transmitted between animals and humans. However, some strains with a high degree of pathogenicity may have the ability to spread to people, thus representing a "threat to public health."

The main route of transmission from birds to humans is direct or indirect contact with infected animals. However, there is also the spread of the virus through contact with environments or surfaces contaminated by feces, as well as handling carcasses and preparing birds for consumption.

"When avian influenza is transmitted to humans, symptoms in people can range from a mild upper respiratory infection (fever and cough) to severe pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (difficulty breathing), shock, and even death," reported PAHO, so it is recommended to see a doctor in case of suspicion of contagion of the virus.

The migration of wild birds at the end of winter is one of the factors enhancing the spread of the bird flu virus

In this sense, some of the measures implemented by the veterinarians of the United States-Mexico Commission for the Prevention of Foot-and-Mouth Disease and other Animal Diseases (CPA) consist of the depopulation, cleaning, and disinfection of the 3 farms to comply with the sanitary vacuum and, later, find out the degree of security to return to house new bird populations later.

Another of the sanitary determinations applied consisted of the epidemiological review of family and commercial farms located within 10 km [6.2 mi] of the infected agricultural production units (UPA ), as well as internal quarantine in the state of Aguascalientes.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[ProMED map of Mexico: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708757,14>]

******
USA
[5] Tennessee (Weakley County): mixed flocks
Date: Wed 22 Feb 2023
Source: MSN [abridged, edited]
<https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/state-confirms-avian-bird-flu-spreads-across-tn-farms-birds-disposed-of/ar-AA17N06j>


First identified in Weakley County in West Tennessee, the Tennessee Department of Agriculture released a statement on its website on 20 Jan [2023] disclosing the presence of a highly pathogenic avianinfluenza (HPAI) disease affecting poultry populations in West and Middle Tennessee farms.

According to the press release, "HPAI cases in Tennessee have sickened domesticated chickens, geese, ducks, and turkeys in Bledsoe, Davidson, Obion, Tipton, and Weakley Counties" dating back to September of 2022.

The most recent detection was among a commercial broiler chicken flock in Weakley County in West Tennessee, according to the state Department of Agriculture.

In an effort to combat HPAI spread, a 6.2 mile [10 km] control zone surrounding the Weakley Co. facility, which remains unnamed, has been implemented, and animal health officials are taking measures to eradicate the affected poultry supply, according to state agriculture officials.

Collection data from a 20 Jan 2023 report via the USDA Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service interactive map, affected flocks in Tennessee include 4 affected commercial flocks, 5 affected backyard flocks, and a total of 418 230 affected birds in the outbreak in 2023.

[Byline: Sarah Best]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[ProMED map of United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708757,106>]

[Avian influenza enters its 2nd year of havoc on birds' lives and human livelihood.

As spring and summer arrives for the Northern Hemisphere, we can likely anticipate this viral menace will return with the spring migrations.

Currently, it appears to be causing havoc in its wake through the Southern Hemisphere.

Consequently, please take heed, and protect your birds. Increase your biosecurity. Examine your protocols and see where it could be tightened up. This may mean specific clothing per barn, or the same individuals enter one barn but not the next. It may mean deliveries are at different location for decontamination before entering the property. Remember, this virus can hitch itself to clothing, truck tires, boot soles, even our hair. Some facilities are already implementing procedures for requiring those entering to blow their noses and discard the tissue into designated sealed receptacles.

Bird lives are at stake as are human livelihoods. - Mod.TG]

column2:
EQUINE RHINOPNEUMONITIS - SPAIN: (VALENCIA) EHV-1, HORSE
********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sat 4 Mar 2023
Source: Horse and Hound [edited]
<https://www.horseandhound.co.uk/news/eight-horses-in-hospital-with-neurological-signs-of-equine-herpes-virus-818074>


Nine horses are receiving "close monitoring" in hospital in Valencia, 8 of which are showing neurological signs of equine herpesvirus (EHV-1).

H&H reported that the organisers of the Mediterranean Equestrian Tour in Oliva Nova, Spain, had cancelled the 2nd part of the showjumping tour (7-26 Feb [2023]) as 4 horses on-site had tested positive for EHV-1. Ten horses, 6 of whom were showing signs of illness, were put in isolation on 21 Feb [2023]. Swabs were taken, 4 of which were positive, 4 negative, and 2 inconclusive. At the time, none of the horses were showing signs of neurological illness. The Valencia Veterinary department decided that all the horses stabled in the same tent as the 4 that had tested positive had to remain on the venue for at least one week.

In an update on 2 Mar [2023], a spokesman [for the FEI (Fédération Équestre Internationale; International Federation for Equestrian Sports)] said the Oliva organising committee had set up a "strong organisation" and continues to closely collaborate with the authorities, the national federation, and the FEI. The Spring MET III Tour (7-26 Mar [2023]) has been cancelled, and the organising committee has put meetings in place to keep all athletes informed on the most recent development.

The spokesman added that the venue is operating under the auspices of the regional veterinary authority, which is monitored by the federal veterinary authority, MAPA. An FEI vet has been appointed as responsible for the venue, leading the work on-site and reporting back to the regional veterinary authority.

"To date, there are 9 horses at the University Equine Hospital in Valencia (CEU) for close monitoring, 8 of which have displayed neurological signs. As a preventive measure and to ensure enough treating space, the FEI has ordered 12 temporary boxes to be set up at the hospital grounds in case more horses are brought in," said the FEI spokesman, adding that 103 horses remain at the venue in Oliva, and these have been divided into groups depending on their health status. "The temperature of all horses at the venue is taken 2 to 3 times daily, and in the latest report from 1 March, no horse had presented fever or any clinical signs."

MAPA, supported by the FEI, has extended the initial safety measures to avoid a further spread of virus from the venue. To leave the venue, horses must present a negative sample, followed by a 2nd sample 14 days later, and a 3rd on day 15. All 3 samples must be negative for EHV.

To be unblocked from the FEI database and return to competition, horses must fulfill certain health requirements: either 21 days' isolation with a nasopharyngeal sample taken on day 21 at the earliest, or a minimum isolation of 14 days, with a sample taken on day 7 and a 2nd sample taken 7 days later at the earliest. All samples must be analysed by a PCR and return negative. The measures also include twice-daily rectal temperatures.

"Release from isolation" can only take place on the advice of a vet, and to compete at an FEI event, horses need to complete all return-to-competition precautions and have the restriction lifted by the FEI vet department.

In Lier, Belgium, where one horse had tested positive, the venue has been "given the green light" to reopen for competitions following an inspection by the Belgian national head vet. The affected horse, and each of the 25 in-contact horses, may not attend any FEI events until they have fulfilled "certain health requirements", which are imposed in order to minimise any potential transmission of the virus, to their own horses and the wider horse population.

Discussing the current status of the spread of the disease, the FEI spokesman confirmed 7 horses departed Oliva prior to the 1st confirmed case of EHV-1; one travelled to Valencia, Spain, 4 to Vejer de la Frontera, Spain, and 2 to Doha, Qatar. "They were immediately isolated on request of the FEI and are currently applying the FEI return-to-competition protocols while in isolation. To date, none of the horses have been reported to present fever or clinical signs," he said.

The spokesman added that 6 horses returning from Oliva to Limburg, the Netherlands, have tested positive for EHV-1 and have been placed in quarantine, where they are being closely monitored. "Unrelated to Oliva, in Vilamoura, Portugal, 2 horses with fever were placed in isolation; however, their test results for EHV-1 were negative," he said.

[byline: Becky Murray]

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[FEI (Fédération Équestre Internationale; International Federation for Equestrian Sports) has published 2 press releases on the EHV-1 events, in Oliv (Spain) and in Lier (Belgium). The 2 reports are available at <https://inside.fei.org/media-updates/update-confirmed-ehv-1-cases-lier-bel-and-oliva-esp> (22 Feb 2023) and <https://inside.fei.org/media-updates/update-confirmed-ehv-1-cases-mainland-europe> (2 Mar 2023). It has not been stated if the cases in Oliva and Lier, both described in the same report, are related to each other and if sources of infections have been established.

Equine herpesvirus (EHV-1) is a causative agent of equine rhinopneumonitis (ER), a collective term for any one of several contagious clinical-disease entities of equids that may occur as a result of infection by either of 2 closely related herpesviruses, equid herpesvirus-1 and equid herpesvirus-4 (EHV-1 and EHV-4). Infection with EHV-1 is listed by the OIE; see OIE's Terrestrial Manual, chapter 3.5.9., at <https://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/3.05.09_EQUINE_RHINO.pdf>.

EHV-1 and EHV-4 are endemic in most domestic equine populations worldwide. For an exhaustive information on the agent and the disease, including its control and prevention measures, please refer to Mod.TG's commentary in ProMED post 20210317.8253684.

The disease is not zoonotic. - Mod.AS

Ten horses, 6 of whom were showing signs of illness, were put in isolation on 21 Feb [2023]. Swabs were taken, 4 of which were positive, 4 negative, and 2 inconclusive. At the time, none of the horses were showing signs of neurological illness. column2:
LEGIONELLOSIS - USA (04): (NEVADA) HOTEL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*****************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023
Source: Beaumont Enterprise [edited]
<https://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/article/legionnaires-disease-found-in-2-past-las-vegas-17818973.php>


Las Vegas area health officials say legionnaires' disease was found in 2 people who stayed at the same hotel in recent months. The Southern Nevada Health District announced on Friday [3 Mar 2023] it is looking into 2 cases reported in guests who stayed at The Orleans Hotel & Casino a few miles west of the Strip. One guest visited there in January [2023], the other in December [2022]. The hotel is informing current and past guests going back to 16 Dec [2022] of possible exposure.

The Health District has taken water samples around the hotel and done other environmental testing. Officials say they confirmed the presence of legionella bacteria. The Orleans Hotel has since started remediation procedures and a water management plan.

Legionnaires' disease can develop from the inhaling of aerosol droplets of water contaminated with [legionella] bacteria. This can come from showers, hot tubs, cooling towers, misters, and decorative fountains. Experts say symptoms can surface 2 to 10 days after exposure and present like pneumonia. They include cough, shortness of breath, high fever, muscle aches, and headaches. The disease can be treated with antibiotics.

Health officials have set up a website for guests who experienced symptoms up to 14 days after their stay to fill out a survey.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Legionnaires' disease is usually acquired by inhalation of aerosolized legionella bacteria, but the disease can also be acquired by aspiration of legionella-contaminated potable water in people prone to aspirate, such as debilitated hospitalized patients. Possible person-to-person transmission of legionnaires' disease has also been described by Correia et al (<http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMc1505356>). Legionella infection can be acquired less commonly by contamination of wounds.

Possible sources include aerosols generated from a legionella-contaminated plumbing system by showerheads, sink faucets, cooling towers, decorative fountains, hot tubs/spas, car-wash facilities, and even wastewater treatment plants. Warm water temperatures of 25-40 deg C (77-104 deg F) support the highest concentrations of the organism in plumbing systems.

Genotyping the isolates from patients with legionnaires' disease will help establish whether this is a common source outbreak, if the genotypes match. However, if the diagnosis of legionnaires' disease was based only on a positive urinary antigen assay, there will be no clinical isolates for genotyping. Matching the genotypes of clinical and environmental isolates of legionella will identify the environmental source for the individual cases. Because legionella may be found in water supplies without linkage to any cases, the actual causative source should be demonstrated by matching the genotype of the environmental isolates with that of clinical isolates to assure frequently costly corrective measures are carried out on the actual source (<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC86783/> and <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2730281/>). We will await further findings from the investigation.

About 20-25% of all legionnaires' disease reported to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is associated with travel. Legionnaires' disease is important to diagnose and report because its identification implies the presence of an environmental source to which other susceptible individuals are likely to be exposed. Clusters of legionnaires' disease associated with travel to hotels or aboard cruise ships are rarely detected by individual clinicians or health departments; travelers typically disperse from the source of infection before developing symptoms.

Therefore, a travel history should be actively sought from patients with community-acquired pneumonia, and legionella testing should be performed for those who have traveled in the 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms.

Because of the multi-state nature of travel in the United States, national-level surveillance is necessary to detect outbreaks of travel-associated legionnaires' disease. CDC relies upon state and local health departments to conduct this surveillance; all cases should be reported through National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System (NNDSS). See the CDC legionellosis case report form at <https://www.cdc.gov/legionella/health-depts/surv-reporting/form-instructions.html>.

We would be pleased to hear from knowledgeable sources with more information on this outbreak. - Mod.ML

Nevada, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708754,230>]

column2:
POLIOMYELITIS UPDATE (10): ISRAEL ASYMPTOMATIC CONTACT INFECTIONS, PAKISTAN VACCINE, CIRCULATING VACCINE DERIVED POLIOVIRUS TYPES 1 & 2 ACUTE FLACCID PARALYSIS (BENIN,CONGO,DRC,YEMEN)
***************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Israel (Safed): asymptomatic poliovirus infections identified, RFI
[A] Times of Israel
[B] MOH press release
[C] Precision Vaccinations
[2] Global update as of 1 Mar 2023: cVDPV1 AFP (Congo, DR Congo), cVDPV2 AFP (Benin, Cameroon, DR Congo, Mali, Somalia, Yemen), ES (Algeria, Botswana, Malawi, Somalia) 
[3] Pakistan vaccine refusals

******
[1] Israel (Safed): asymptomatic poliovirus infections identified, RFI
[A] Times of Israel
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023 10:22 PM IST
Source: Times of Israel [edited]
<https://www.timesofisrael.com/three-more-children-diagnosed-with-polio-virus-in-northern-outbreak/>


Three more children have been diagnosed with polio after an 8 year old in the northern city of Safed tested positive for the virus on Monday [27 Feb 2023].

A Health Ministry statement on Thursday [2 Mar 2023] said that the 3 children had been in contact with the infected child, who was unvaccinated, and tested positive for the polio virus despite having no symptoms. The ministry did not reveal the vaccination status of the 3 children who tested positive on Thursday [2 Mar 2023].

"In recent months, there is evidence of a spread of polio in many sewage systems in Israel, which has more than 150 000 children unvaccinated against the virus," the statement warned. The Health Ministry said it would continue to monitor and update the public, and encouraged people to maintain good hygiene practices to stymie any outbreak.

[byline: Ash Obel]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

---
[B] Ministry of Health press release
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: Israel Ministry of Health [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited]
<https://www.gov.il/he/departments/news/02032023-02>


Following the case of polio in an 8-year-old girl from the Safed area who was not vaccinated against polio as part of routine vaccinations, the Northern District of the Ministry of Health conducted an epidemiological investigation, during which it was found that 3 other children who came in close contact with the case, were found to be positive for the polio virus. The 3 children at this stage have no clinical symptoms.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

---
[C] Precision Vaccinations
Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023
Source: Precision Vaccinations [edited]
<https://www.precisionvaccinations.com/2023/03/03/children-israel-confirmed-polio>


According to recent media reports, 4 children in Israel have been diagnosed with polio. The JPost reported the Health Ministry announced in early March 2023 that an unvaccinated child from the Safed region in Galilee was found positive for polio at the Ziv Medical Center.

On 2 Mar 2023, the Times of Israel reported an Israel Health Ministry statement confirming 3 additional children who had been in contact with the infected child and tested positive for poliovirus. The Ministry did not reveal the vaccination status of these 3 children.

In June 2022, the Ministry reported that vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (VDPV2) was detected in sewage in the Jerusalem area. This strain has spread to many places in Israel, from Ramat HaGolan, in the north, to Beer Sheva in the south.

Unfortunately, about 150 000 children in Israel have not been vaccinated with the inactivated vaccine, and therefore they are not protected from pediatric paralysis should they be infected with the virus. Polio is a vaccine-preventable viral disease that affects children and can cause paralysis and related fatalities. The live attenuated oral vaccine (bOPV) currently administered in Israel does not cover the VDPV2 strain.

[byline: Karen McClorey Hackett]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[So far there is one case confirmed to have a poliovirus associated acute flaccid paralysis and 3 asymptomatically infected contacts of this case.

Information on genomic sequencing is still pending but the media reports seem to suggest it is associated with a cVDPV (circulating vaccine derived poliovirus). As mentioned in the prior post (Poliomyelitis update (09): Israel AFP, RFI, WPV1 ES, cVDPV1 & 2 AFP & ES 20230228.8708638) there was 1 AFP case in Jerusalem, Israel reported in March 2022 associated with a cVDPV3 infection (see prior posts in see also section below). In addition, a VDPV2 was identified in wastewater sampling matching VDPV2 identified in wastewater in the USA and the UK in August of 2022.

The estimate of 150 000 unvaccinated children in Israel is very disconcerting as it is a perfect environment for polioviruses (both wild as well as vaccine derived) to circulate if introduced into these pockets of susceptibles. Safed is known to have a sizable Haredi community, which may well mean a sizeable pocket of unvaccinated children and young adults.

A map of Israel showing the location of Safed can be found at <https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Israel_outline_northeast.png>. - Mod.MPP]

******
[2] Global update as of 1 Mar 2023: cVDPV1 AFP (Congo, DR Congo), cVDPV2 AFP (Benin, Cameroon, DR Congo, Mali, Somalia, Yemen), ES (Algeria, Botswana, Malawi, Somalia) 
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative/WHO [edited]
<https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/>


[Note: These data come from a weekly email sent by GPEI and may transiently be different from data found on the website. - Mod.MPP]

Poliovirus Weekly Update 1 Mar 2023, World Health Organization
--------------------------------------------------------------
New wild poliovirus isolates reported this week:
Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) cases: 0
Environmental samples (ES): 0
Others: 0
 
New circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) isolates reported this week: 
AFP cases: 27
ES: 7
Others: 3

Headlines
---------
The United Nations Foundation has released a new report: "Leveraging CSO [civil society organization] contributions to advance polio transition and integration efforts in the African Region". The report highlights the critical role of civil society in advancing polio transition and integration efforts in Africa and outlines key recommendations for how to expand and enhance the contributions of civil society to this crucial work. [<https://unfoundation.org/what-we-do/issues/global-health/leveraging-civil-society-contributions-to-advance-polio-transition-and-integration-efforts-in-africa/>]
 
Summary of new polioviruses this week: 
- Algeria: 2 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive ES
- Benin: 1 cVDPV2 case
- Botswana: 2 cVDPV2 positive ES
- Cameroon: 1 cVDPV2 case
- Congo: one circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) case
- Democratic Republic of Congo [DRC]: 13 cVDPV1 cases, eight cVDPV2 cases and one cVDPV2 positive ES
- Malawi: one cVDPV2 positive ES
- Mali: one cVDPV2 case
- Somalia: one cVDPV2 case and one positive ES
- Yemen: one cVDPV2 case
 
Afghanistan
- No wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) cases were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2022.

Pakistan
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 20 cases detected in 2022.

Algeria
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 3 cases detected in 2022.
- 2 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported: 1 each in Tamanghasset and Ouargla.

Benin
- 1 case of cVDPV2 was reported in Bourgou. There are 11 cases detected in 2022.

Botswana
- 2 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported: 1 each in Gaborone and Francistown.

Burkina Faso
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021.

Cameroon
- 1 case of cVDPV2 was reported in Extreme Nord. There are 3 cases detected in 2022.

Canada
- No cVDPV2 was reported in the past week. Previously, cVDPV2 was isolated from 2 ES from a large wastewater treatment plant and a target site in the city of Montreal, Quebec, collected on 27 and 30 Aug 2022, after the country conducted retrospective analysis of wastewater samples. Genetic sequencing confirmed it is linked to the cVDPV2 currently affecting New York, USA.

Central African Republic
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 5 cases detected in 2022.

Chad
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 43 cases detected in 2022.

Congo (Republic of)
- 1 case of cVDPV1 was reported in Niari, detected in 2022. It is the 1st case of cVDPV1 in the country.

Côte d'Ivoire
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were no cases reported in 2021.

Djibouti
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week.

Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo)
- 8 cases of cVDPV2 were reported; 1 each in Haut Katanga, Haut Lomami, Ituri, Lualaba and Tanganyika and 3 in Tshopo. The number of 2022 cases now stand at 295.
- 1 cVDPV2 positive ES was detected in Haut Katanga.
- 13 cases of cVDPV1 were reported; 6 in Haut Katanga, 3 in Haut Lomami and 4 in Tanganyika. There are 105 cases detected in 2022.
- Outbreak response to both cVDPV1 and cVDPV2 is being intensified.

Egypt
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 18 positive ES reported in the country in the last 2 years.

Ethiopia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022.

Eritrea
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case in 2022 and 1 case reported in 2021.

Gambia
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There were 9 positive ES in 2021.

Ghana
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 3 cases in 2022.

Guinea
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 6 cases in 2021.

Guinea-Bissau
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 3 cases in the country which are linked to the Jigawa outbreak in Nigeria in 2021.

Israel
- No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 3 (cVDPV3) wwereas reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022.
- The country has been confirmed as affected by both cVDPV2 and cVDPV3.

Indonesia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2023. There was 1 case detected in 2022.

Liberia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 3 cVDPV2 cases in 2021.

Madagascar
- No cases of cVDPV1 were reported this week. There are 14 cases detected in 2022.

Malawi
- No cases of WPV1 were reported this week. 1 case from 2021 was detected in 2022.
- No cases of cVDPV1 were reported this week. There were 4 cases in the country in 2022.
- 1 cVDPV2 positive ES was detected in Central. It is the 1st positive ES of cVDPV2 in the country.

Mali
- 1 case of cVDPV2 was reported in Menaka making it the 2nd detection from 2022.

Mauritania
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There were 7 positive ES linked to the Jigawa outbreak in 2021.

Mozambique
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 8 cases detected in 2022. Reporting of these new cases within a short time span indicates that intensified surveillance efforts are working in the province.
- No casesof cVDPV1 were reported this week. There were 21 cases in 2022.
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. The number of cases in 2022 remains 4.

Niger
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. The number of cVDPV2 cases in 2022 remains 14.

Nigeria
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case detected in 2023 and 47 cases detected in 2022.

Senegal
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Sierra Leone
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Somalia
- 1 case of cVDPV2 was reported in Lower Shabelle. There is 1 case in 2023 and 5 cases detected in 2022.
- 1 cVDPV2 positive ES was detected in Lower Juba.

Sudan
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022.

South Sudan
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Togo
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 2 cases in 2022.
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 2 positive ES reported in 2022.

Uganda
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week.

Ukraine
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021.
- Disease surveillance continues to be strengthened, to the degree possible given the evolving situation, including by building capacity, conducting training, implementing environmental surveillance and supporting routine immunization.

United Kingdom
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. 2 positive ES were reported in May [2022] and 1 in August [2022] following the isolation of vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (VDPV2) from ES in London, UK.
- No cases of paralysis associated with this strain have been detected -- virus has been isolated only from environmental (sewage) samples.

United States of America
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. 1 cVDPV2 case was reported in New York in 2022.
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There were 12 positive ES reported in 2022.

Yemen
- 1 case of cVDPV2 was reported in Hajjah. There are 162 cases detected in 2022.

Zambia
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 3 positives ES reported in 2022.
 
Officially reported WPV1 and cVDPV cases as of 28 Feb 2023
Wild poliovirus (WPV)
- Total global WPV1 cases in 2023: 0 (compared with 1 for the same period in 2022)
- Total global WPV1 cases in 2022: 30
Circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) cases
- Total global cVDPV cases in 2023: 4 (compared with 4 for the same period in 2022)
- Total global cVDPV cases in 2022: 749
 
 --
communicated by:
ProMED

[The past week has seen evidence of poliovirus (cVDPV1 and cVDPV2) circulation in 10 countries. cVDPV1 AFP cases were reported in Congo [Brazzaville] and DR Congo [Kinshasa], cVDPV2 AFP cases were reported in Benin, Cameroon, DR Congo, Mali, Somalia and Yemen, and cVDPV2 positive ES were confirmed in Algeria, Botswana, and Malawi. All but 1 of the reported AFP cases were events in 2022 except for the case reported in Somalia with onset in 2023.

The 2022 total reported cVDPV cases has officially overtaken those confirmed in 2021 (698 cVDPV AFP cases in 2021, 749 cases confirmed to date in 2022).

A map showing the locations of each confirmed case of polio worldwide in the past 12 months can be found at <https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/>. One can see cases of WPV1 in Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Mozambique; cVDPV1 in Congo (Brazzaville), DR Congo (Kinshasa), Malawi, Madagascar and Mozambique; cVDPV2 in 19 countries in a band across Africa and in Afghanistan, Pakistan and the USA; and a cVDPV3 in Israel. - Mod.MPP]

******
[3] Pakistan vaccine refusal
Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: First Post [edited]
<https://www.firstpost.com/world/amid-medicine-shortage-polio-outbreak-feared-in-pakistan-as-thousands-refuse-vaccination-12225462.html>


Amid medicine shortage, polio outbreak feared in Pakistan as thousands refuse vaccination
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pakistan is one of the handful of countries where polio is still prevalent. A combination of poor delivery systems and superstitions arising out of religion-induced taboo is to blame for the problem. The latest anti-polio campaign in Pakistan was no different, as more than 62 000 families refused to vaccinate their children.

The highest number of refusals was registered in the Sindh province of Pakistan, where a total of 37 008 households refused to allow their children to take the polio vaccine. The province of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) was 2nd with 20 305 refusals while Islamabad recorded 141, Balochistan 4902, and Punjab 36. The port city of Karachi -- the economic nerve centre of Pakistan -- also recorded a high refusal rate.

While Karachi East registered a 2.4% rejection rate, Korangi district had a 1.2% denial rate. Karachi South registered 1.1% refusals, Keamari district had 1.3%, Karachi Central 1.7%, and Malir district 0.9%. In the Hyderabad district of Sindh, 0.2% families refused to vaccinate their children against polio.

The polio vaccination campaign started in January [2023] after wild poliovirus was found in sewage samples collected from Lahore. A report by the national polio lab at the National Institute of Health revealed on 19 Jan 2023 that the 1st sample which tested positive for polio of in 2023 was genetically related to the poliovirus discovered in the Nangarhar province of Afghanistan in November last year [2022].

This was the 1st known instance of cross-border transmission of polio from Afghanistan to Pakistan in over a year. On 27 Jan 2023, a 2nd sample also tested positive for polio and it was genetically related to a polio virus found in the southern part of the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province of Pakistan.

[byline: Ajeyo Basu]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Sobering information -- approximately 62 000 children were not vaccinated during the major vaccination campaign held in January 2023 in Pakistan. This leaves pockets of susceptibles ripe for the poliovirus to continue circulating.

A good map of Pakistan showing provinces and districts can be found at <https://reliefweb.int/map/pakistan/pakistan-districts-map-03-december-2018> . - Mod.MPP]

column2:
SYPHILIS - CANADA: (SASKATCHEWAN) INDIGENOUS, WOMEN, CONGENITAL
***************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023
Source: CJME Radio Station, Regina [edited]
<https://www.cjme.com/2023/03/03/sask-syphilis-numbers-still-growing-with-639-increase-since-2019/>


The rate of syphilis cases in Saskatchewan has seen a massive jump since an outbreak was first declared in 2019. Dr Ibrahim Khan, regional medical officer of health for Indigenous Services Canada, said that, in 2022, 850 were cases found, an increase of 639% from several years ago. "In 2019, we saw an unprecedented number of syphilis and that led to a declaration of a syphilis-specific outbreak in December of 2019," said Khan. "Since then, we have seen a constant increase in the number of cases and basically the number of syphilis impacting pregnant women and babies born with syphilis."

Between 2020 and now [March 2022], 7 babies have been stillborn because of syphilis and another 24 cases of early congenital infection in newborns have been reported in on-reserve population. "These are really very high numbers for the Indigenous population," Khan explained. [see graphic at source URL].

The incidence of syphilis in Prince Albert grew 8.5% between 2021 and 2022 with 268 cases diagnosed last year [2022], the Saskatchewan Health Authority reported. That does not include numbers seen in reserve populations. The numbers are counted separately because on-reserve health is a federal area of responsibility while provinces manage the remainder of the population.

Increased cases are not isolated to Prince Albert or Saskatchewan; both Manitoba and Alberta have higher numbers as well.

For pregnant women, the potential impact on their baby is staggering. Between 70% and 100% of cases caught during the late stages of pregnancy transmit from mother to child and 40% in earlier stages of pregnancy. Syphilis can also spread through breastfeeding and can cause pre-term births (23%) and low birth weights, and has a 26% risk of stillbirth and a 16% chance of neonatal death.

"With syphilis, which we call early congenital syphilis or babies born diseased to a mother that had been infected with syphilis, those numbers broke all previous records," said Khan. Caring for even one baby born with early congenital syphilis is considered an emergency in the health care field, he explained, and is currently a priority for all concerned.

Officials are working towards increasing the resources and accessibility for people with the condition. Many of the expectant mothers on reserve do not have easy access to health care because of their location so 2 mobile clinics have been put into service. The hope is with increased focus and effort, the number of new cases can be reduced by one half.

One such effort is giving nurses the ability to test a patient and treat them the same day. Treatment includes medication and monitoring of the patient. Health care staff are also hoping to reduce some of the stigma attached so that more people will choose to be tested and then follow up with treatment. "We want to have Indigenous-led, holistic, trauma-informed care available for these clients wherever they live," Khan said. Treating the mother with antibiotics before the baby is born can eliminate any potential health impacts.

[byline: Susan McNeil]

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

["Saskatchewan is home to at least 70 First Nations [Indigenous] and various Métis [people of mixed European and Indigenous ancestry] communities. It contains 782 reserves, settlements and villages, many of which are located in the southern half of the province. Reserves in Saskatchewan were created between 1874 and 1906 by Treaties 2, 4, 5, 6, 8 and 10. As of 2016, 47.5% of the province's 114 570 self-identified First Nations peoples live on reserves, a percentage comparable to the province of Manitoba. Most of the remaining 47% who reside off-reserve in Saskatchewan live in the cities of Saskatoon, Regina and Prince Albert. While roughly 75% of Saskatchewan's reserve lands are within 50 km (31 mi) of other reserves in the southern half of the province, those in the northern half are more dispersed, and some are isolated from cities or towns. No year-long roads directly reach these reserves, which means that people and supplies are mainly moved in and out by airplane or snowmobile.

"The median age of Indigenous peoples living on Saskatchewan reserves is approximately 20 years old, which is half the age of the province's median non-Indigenous population outside of the reserves. In 2011, 59% of people living on the province's reserves are unemployed, compared with a 40% Indigenous unemployment rate off the reserves. About 69% of Indigenous children on Saskatchewan reserves live in poverty, the nation's 2nd-highest rate after Indigenous children living on reserves in Manitoba. The suicide rate for both children and adults is 4 times that of the rest of the population. Drug addiction is a further issue on the reserves." (<https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/reserves-in-saskatchewan>)

In 2019, 2021 and 2022, ProMED posted reports of the increased incidence of primary and secondary syphilis in women, as well as congenital syphilis, in several Canadian provinces and territories (Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec, Saskatchewan, and the Northwest Territories). Also mentioned as a contributing factor to the increase in syphilis cases in Canada is illicit drug use, in particular, methamphetamine. Transmission of syphilis in illicit drug users may occur as a consequence of sharing a needle/syringe contaminated with infected blood from somebody who has primary or secondary syphilis (<https://health.ucsd.edu/news/2010/pages/4-28-syphillis-needle-sharing.aspx>), but more likely the infection is acquired by the practice of exchanging drugs for sex and high-risk sexual behaviors, such as multiple partners and inconsistent condom use (<https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/68/wr/mm6806a4.htm>).

In 2019 ProMED reported on an outbreak of primary and secondary syphilis in Saskatchewan that affected in part Indigenous women of child-bearing age in the province -- 43% of cases were women compared to just 7% in 2017. An increase in the incidence of syphilis in women in the population is commonly accompanied by increasing rates of congenital syphilis (ProMED post Syphilis - Canada (08): (SK, ON) incr. incidence, indigenous, women, meth use 20191212.6836885). Illicit drug use was cited as a contributing factor to the increase in syphilis cases in 2019 in Saskatchewan, as well as in the Canadian provinces of Alberta, Ontario, and Manitoba.

Because many of the Indigenous communities are isolated, access to healthcare may be difficult. Mention was made in a 2021 ProMED report of initiating mobile syphilis clinics to rapidly screen and treat early syphilis in Saskatchewan (ProMED post Syphilis - Canada: (SK) incr incidence, women, congenital, RFI 20210526.8381023), as is reported in the news report above.

More information from knowledgeable sources on the possible use of illicit drugs as a contributing factor in the current outbreak in Saskatchewan would be appreciated. - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
Saskatchewan Province, Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708742,262>]

column2:
DIPHTHERIA - NIGERIA (05): FATAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<http://outbreaknewstoday.com/nigeria-diphtheria-outbreak-update-more-than-300-confirmed-cases-53006/>


In a follow-up on the diphtheria outbreak in Nigeria, between week 19 (mid-May) of 2022 and week 7 (mid-February) of 2023, 724 suspected cases of diphtheria were reported from 20 states in Nigeria, with the majority of cases reported from Kano (533, 74%), Yobe (86, 12%), Katsina (45, 6%), Sokoto (14, 2%), Enugu (9, 1%), Ogun (7, 1%), Osun (7, 1%), Kaduna (6, 1%), Lagos (5, 1%), and Zamfara (5, 1%) states, the World Health Organization reports.

A total of 89 deaths were recorded among all suspected cases, representing a case fatality rate of 12.3%. Of suspected cases, 313 cases were confirmed.

Children aged 2-14 years account for 85.2% of confirmed cases. Only 43.2% of confirmed cases were fully vaccinated with a vaccine containing diphtheria toxin.

Last week, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a travel notice for Nigeria due to the outbreak.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED's recent post -- a news report that cited the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) -- said the diphtheria outbreak involved 5 Nigerian states (Kano, Lagos, Yobe, Osun, and Katsina), with a total of 522 suspected cases, 216 confirmed cases and 40 deaths (ProMED post Diphtheria - Nigeria (04): fatal 20230215.8708396). The period during which these cases occurred was not given. The report above says the outbreak dates from mid-May 2022 to mid-February 2023, with apparently 411 suspected cases and 313 confirmed cases, and involves 20 Nigerian states. The Nigerian State of Kano accounts for most cases.

The US CDC issued a travel alert on 24 Feb 2023 concerning the diphtheria outbreak in several states in Nigeria (<https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/alert/diphtheria-nigeria>).

Clarification from knowledgeable sources would be appreciated on the status the Nigerian diphtheria outbreak.

A map showing the location of the Nigerian states can be found at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Nigeria>.

For a discussion of diphtheria, please see my moderator comments in ProMED posts Diphtheria - WHO European Region, 2010-19 20220226.8701672; Diphtheria - Australia: (NSW) unvaccinated children 20220705.8704239; and Diphtheria - Norway ex Mozambique: cutaneous, traveler 20140621.2556752. - Mod.ML

column2:
LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (06): GHANA (GREATER ACCRA)
*****************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<http://outbreaknewstoday.com/ghana-reports-12-additional-lassa-fever-cases-63186/>


In a follow-up on the report of Lassa fever in Ghana, the Ghana Health Service reports 12 additional Lassa fever cases who were close contacts of the initial cases. This brings the total to 14 confirmed cases in the current outbreak. One death has been recorded.

The 13 surviving cases are in stable condition and being managed by designated health facilities. A total of 97 contacts have been identified.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[The 12 new Lassa fever cases presumably occurred in the Greater Accra area where the original cases are located. These new cases are of concern because they indicate that ongoing transmission has been occurring. They were contacts with the previous cases who presumably were the source of their infections or perhaps the environment, food or water that were contaminated by infected rodents were the sources. Transmission of the virus can occur when in contact with the excrement of infected rodent hosts or with infected individuals as sometimes happens in hospitals or in settings where home care is provided. It will be of interest to see if the 97 additional contact are infected or not. It is good to learn that Ghana health officials are identifying and monitoring these contacts.

As noted earlier, halting the acquisition of Lassa fever virus infection at its source -- at the village level -- is not easy. As noted previously, it can be difficult to get local people to understand that virus transmission to humans occurs when people are in contact with the reservoir rodent host, the multimammate mouse (in the genus _Mastomys_), or its excreta. Preventing this contact requires understanding that leads to action. Rodent control and prevention of contact with rodent excreta have to be undertaken at village level with individual households. This requires an extensive and continuous public education effort. Transmission of the virus also occurs at home or in health facilities when personal protective equipment is not employed and barrier-nursing practices are not adequate to protect staff or other care-givers from the blood and secretions of infected patients. Although no vaccine is available, ribavirin has been used to successfully treat patients and is most effective if patients are treated early in the course of infection.

Images of the _Mastomys_ mouse, the rodent reservoir of Lassa fever virus, can be seen at <https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis>. - Mod.TY

Ghana: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708740,53>]

column2:
STREPTOCOCCUS, GROUP A UPDATE (07): UK, SCARLET FEVER, INVASIVE GROUP A STREPTOCOCCAL INFECTIONS/FATAL, CHILDREN
****************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023
Source: UK Health Security Agency [edited]
<https://www.gov.uk/government/news/ukhsa-update-on-scarlet-fever-and-invasive-group-a-strep-1>


The latest data from the United Kingdom Health Security Agency (UKHSA) shows that scarlet fever infections remain high and are fluctuating with levels similar to those seen during the last comparably high season in 2017 to 2018.

The number of weekly notifications of invasive group A streptococcal infections (iGAS) in children has slowed since December 2022. High levels of activity at such an early point in the season remains a concern, with further increases possible in the coming weeks as we move towards the usual peak time of the year for infections. While iGAS is still very rare, notifications remain relatively high in children compared to what we typically see -- these rates are more in keeping with the previous high season of 2017 to 2018.

There continue to be increased notifications in older adult age groups, and as in previous seasons, the majority of iGAS cases have continued to be among those aged over 45 years, particularly in those aged over 75 years.

Dr Derren Ready, UKHSA incident director, said: "Scarlet fever notifications have fallen significantly since the peak in December [2022] but remain at a high level. This decline should be treated with caution as spring is usually the period of the year that we could see infections rise again. Please contact NHS 111 or your GP if you suspect you or your child have scarlet fever -- with symptoms such as fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing and a sandpapery rash."

Most winter illnesses can be managed at home, and NHS.UK has information to help parents look after children with mild illnesses. Contact NHS 111 or your GP surgery if you think your child is getting worse, for instance, if they are feeding or eating less than normal, are dehydrated, have a high temperature that won't go down, are very hot and sweaty or seem more tired or irritable than normal.

It is important that we continue to help stop the spread of all germs in the community and to vulnerable groups. Wash your hands regularly and thoroughly, catch coughs and sneezes in a tissue, and keep your home well ventilated. If you are unwell with any infection, you should avoid visiting vulnerable people, and stay away from school, nursery or work if you are unwell with a fever.

So far this season (from 12 Sep 2022 to 28 Feb 2023), there have been 47 084 notifications of scarlet fever. In the last comparable high season of 2017 to 2018 (September to September), there were 30 768 scarlet fever notifications overall across the year.

Invasive group A strep infections remain rare but are currently higher than expected in a typical year. So far this season, there have been:
- 2178 iGAS cases across all age groups, compared to 2898 across the whole of the last comparably high season in 2017 to 2018;
- 242 iGAS cases in children aged 1 to 4 years compared to 194 cases in the 2017 to 2018 season; and
- 160 cases in children aged 5 to 9 years, compared to 112 during the 2017 to 2018 season.

Sadly, so far this season, there have been 285 deaths across all age groups in England. This figure includes 35 children under 18 years in England. In the 2017 to 2018 season (September to September), there were 354 deaths in total across the season, including 27 deaths among children under 18 years.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[A discussion of infections due to group A streptococcus (also called GAS or _Streptococcus pyogenes_) can be found in my moderator comments in ProMED posts Streptococcus, gp A update (05): UK, fatal, scarlet fever, iGAS 20221231.8707549 and Streptococcus, gp A update (06): Denmark, invasive, new subvariant, RFI 20230222.8708507. - Mod.ML

column2:
YELLOW FEVER - AMERICAS (02): BRAZIL (RIO GRANDE DO SUL) MONKEY
***************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
Source: Prefeitura de Caxias do Sul [in Portuguese, trans. Mod. TY, edited]
<https://caxias.rs.gov.br/noticias/2023/02/caxias-do-sul-confirma-caso-de-febre-amarela-em-um-bugio>


The Caxias do Sul Municipal Secretariat of Health reports the confirmation of a case of yellow fever in a howler monkey this year [2023]. It is the 1st suspected and then confirmed [yellow fever] event in 2023 and serves as an alert to the circulation of the disease. No other cases have been under investigation until now.

The animal was found dead in Parada Cristal [when? - Mod.RNA], considered peri-urban area (transition between rural areas and urban areas). [Question: Has entomological research been carried out in the area? Were vaccine intensification actions triggered for the susceptible humans residing and/or frequenting the area? - Mod.RNA].

According to veterinarian Rogério Poletto, technical director of environmental health surveillance, in rural environments yellow fever is transmitted by the haemagogus mosquito, which lives in hollows of trees, stone holes, bromeliads, that is, in places difficult to control.

In urban areas, the mosquito that transmits yellow fever is _Aedes aegypti_, the same vector of dengue. In this case, the main way of prevention is to eliminate items with standing water to stop the reproduction of the mosquito since it is in these places that the aedes deposits its eggs.

"The howler monkey with confirmed yellow fever is a sign that yellow fever virus is cycling. That is why it is so important that the unvaccinated population get vaccinated, either the resident population or transient individuals who are those people who do tourism or work only during the harvest period," explains Poletto. The most recent human case of yellow fever inin Caxias do Sul occurred in 2018, when a resident contracted the disease in another state.

--
communicated by:
ProMED
via
ProMED-PORT

[Surveillance of epizootics is one of the main pillars of yellow fever surveillance. When epizootics occur, they must be considered a potential sentinel event (suggestive of virus circulation), often preceding the occurrence of human cases of disease in a given locality, including perturbed environments. For this reason, the actions to be triggered are complex and involve the investigation of primate deaths, entomological research, identification of viral circulation, active search for human cases (syndromic surveillance would be one strategy), confirmation of viral circulation, vaccination of the human population susceptible at risk, control of vector infestation in peri-urban areas close to the focus, and training of the network of assistance for detection and management of human cases. - Mod.RNA (in Portuguese, trans. Mod.TY)

Although the death of a single howler monkey of yellow fever may seem insignificant, as the above report and Mod.RNA indicate, it is an early warning of the presence of circulating virus in the area and risk to people residing in or travelling through the locality. This observation can provide time to intensify surveillance and to mount vaccination efforts for those who have not received the vaccine.

Not only is yellow fever of public health threat, it is also of concern for conservation of non-human primates. One of these is the golden lion tamarin, _Leontopithecus rosalia_, a primate endemic to the Atlantic Forest biome that once stretched uninterrupted for hundreds of miles along Brazil's eastern coast, but which has since been reduced to only patches. By the 1980s, _L. rosalia_ was critically endangered due to habitat loss and extremely high levels of poaching. These tamarins are very susceptible to yellow fever and may die of the infection as does the northern brown howler monkey (_Alouatta guariba guariba_), a species of howler monkey that lives in forests in south eastern Brazil and far north eastern Argentina (Misiones). It is listed as critically endangered. Animal experts in Brazil are vaccinating the golden lion tamarin population against yellow fever (<https://apnews.com/article/science-brazil-climate-and-environment-health-animals-8914729b25c06e1fb2f9e5eaec9d7981>). - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708730,3419>]

column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - ECUADOR: (GUAYAS) FLOODS
****************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023
Source: Yangtse [in Chinese, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.yangtse.com/zncontent/2762953.html>


As of 2 Mar 2023 local time, 18 cases of leptospira [infection] have been confirmed in Ecuador, 16 of which are located in Duran City, Guayas Province in the west of the country, and 2 are located in Guayaquil, the largest city in the country.

On 2 Mar 2023, in response to leptospirosis, staff from the Duran City Public Health Department carried out awareness and prevention efforts in areas of the city where stagnant water exists. On the same day, the Guayaquil municipal government also carried out fumigation interventions in some high-risk areas.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus _Leptospira_. Humans become infected through contact with the urine of infected rodents, dogs, pigs, cows, etc., or through contact with water, soil, or food that has been contaminated with the urine of infected animals.

Clinical features of leptospirosis include fever, headache, myalgia, conjunctival injection, jaundice, and general malaise. Liver and kidney failure and diffuse pulmonary hemorrhage may occur in severe cases, which is life-threatening.

[byline: Wang Bo]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Heavy rainfall in February 2023 caused freshwater flooding in multiple regions of Ecuador (<https://floodlist.com/america/ecuador-floods-february-2023>). Many species of wild and domestic animals (including dogs, cattle, swine, and rats) are susceptible to chronic kidney infection with pathogenic leptospira. Leptospirosis is usually acquired after contact of skin or mucous membranes with the urine of infected animals or by contact with freshwater, wet soil or vegetation that has been contaminated by the urine of leptospira-infected animals, especially rats. Leptospira shed in the urine of chronically infected animals may survive in freshwater or moist soil for weeks to months.

Durán (population 235 769 residents) is a canton located in the province of Guayas, Ecuador, located across the Guayas River from Guayaquil (population almost 2.7 million residents), the capital of Guayas Province and Ecuador's 2nd-largest city (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durán,_Ecuador>). A map showing the location of Durán and Guayaquil can be found at <https://www.google.com/maps/place/Duran,+Ecuador>. - Mod.ML

column3: As of 2 Mar 2023 local time, 18 cases of leptospira [infection] have been confirmed in Ecuador, 16 of which are located in Duran City, Guayas Province in the west of the country, and 2 are located in Guayaquil, the largest city in the country.On 2 Mar 2023, in response to leptospirosis, staff from the Duran City Public Health Department carried out awareness and prevention efforts in areas of the city where stagnant water exists. On the same day, the Guayaquil municipal government also carried out fumigation interventions in some high-risk areas.According to the World Health Organization (WHO), leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus _Leptospira_. Humans become infected through contact with the urine of infected rodents, dogs, pigs, cows, etc., or through contact with water, soil, or food that has been contaminated with the urine of infected animals.Clinical features of leptospirosis include fever, headache, myalgia, conjunctival injection, jaundice, and general malaise. Liver and kidney failure and diffuse pulmonary hemorrhage may occur in severe cases, which is life-threatening.[byline: Wang Bo]--communicated by:ProMED[Heavy rainfall in February 2023 caused freshwater flooding in multiple regions of Ecuador (<https://floodlist.com/america/ecuador-floods-february-2023>). Leptospira shed in the urine of chronically infected animals may survive in freshwater or moist soil for weeks to months.Durán (population 235 769 residents) is a canton located in the province of Guayas, Ecuador, located across the Guayas River from Guayaquil (population almost 2.7 million residents), the capital of Guayas Province and Ecuador's 2nd-largest city (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durán,_Ecuador>). column2:
RHINOVIRUS - CHILE: (SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION)
**************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023 22:28 CLST
Source: Biobiochile [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.biobiochile.cl/noticias/nacional/chile/2023/03/02/escuela-militar-confirmo-enfermedad-que-obligo-a-hospitalizar-a-25-cadetes-rhinovirus.shtml>


The Military School reported this Thursday [2 Mar 2023] that the disease that forced the hospitalization of 25 cadets was a rhinovirus infection, according to tests analyzed by the Institute of Public Health (ISP). The Military School's statement indicated that the 25 cadets who were hospitalized after presenting with serious respiratory symptoms in recent days, had been diagnosed with rhinovirus infection.

The event dates back to 25 Feb 2023, when 25 first-year cadets were admitted to the Military Hospital in Santiago for a serious respiratory condition, for which they had to be isolated and examined. Even until yesterday, Wednesday [1 Mar 2023], t12 cadets were in hospital for this disease. But this Thursday [2 Mar 2023], the results of the tests carried out by the ISP confirmed the initial diagnosis as "common pathogen rhinovirus ruling out other communicable diseases such as Hantavirus, avian influenza and COVID-19".

The Military School added that all the cadets are now in good condition, and that most have been discharged from the Military Hospital, completing their quarantine period at the school. "The medical evolution of the patients has been satisfactory with the established medical treatment, finding all the admitted students in good condition, so that a large part of them have already been discharged from the Military Hospital of Santiago and referred to the Military School, where they are completing their quarantine period," the institution said in a statement.

Finally, the institution added that "it will continue to carry out the necessary actions to achieve the full recovery of all its students and reiterates its deep commitment to their well-being. In addition, and in parallel, it keeps parents informed in a timely manner about the evolution of our cadets."

[byline: Diego Vera]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Rhinovirus, the pathogen usually responsible for the "common cold", was confirmed as the etiologic agent causing the acute respiratory illness outbreak in a group of Chilean military students. Rhinovirus can cause both upper and lower respiratory tract infections and is often associated with seasonal outbreaks, typically in the spring, summer, and fall. As noted in the comment in post 20160831.4453436, the non-enveloped nature of rhinoviruses makes them more difficult to kill than enveloped viruses like influenza A, coronaviruses, etc. A good overview of human rhinoviruses can be found at <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3553670/>. - Mod.JH

ProMED map:
Región Metropolitana de Santiago, Chile: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708728,5078>]
