column2:
TRICHINELLOSIS - ITALY: (APULIA) WILD BOAR MEAT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: The News Dept [abridged, edited]
<https://thenewsdept.com/health/233409.html>


In San Marco in Lamis, in the province of Foggia, mayor Michele Merla has confirmed that there are 5 human cases of trichinellosis. In this case, the ASL (Azienda Sanitaria Locale) Foggia veterinary hygiene service for food of animal origin has started control and verification of food products with suspected trichinella contamination.

According to what has been learned, one of the 5 people involved has been hospitalized at the Casa Sollievo della Sofferenza Hospital in San Giovanni Rotondo, while the other 4 are continuing treatment at home. Before these cases, the human outbreaks observed in Apulia in recent years were caused by the consumption of raw horse meat imported from abroad, wild-bred and clandestinely slaughtered pigs, and uncontrolled wild boar products. Again, the cause could be the consumption of game meat, perhaps wild boar, which has not been checked and came to table after a hunting trip. Now health workers are rebuilding the chain of infection, not from person to person, but through food.

[byline: Barbara Redford]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2] Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023 10:41 CET
Source: La Repubblica [in Italian, machine trans., edited]
<https://bari.repubblica.it/cronaca/2023/03/02/news/allarme_trichinellosi_foggia-390192441/>


The number of cases has risen to 10 and the most accredited hypothesis by the hygienists of the ASL of Foggia is that the parasite was acquired by consumption of unregulated wild boar meat, which would have arrived on the table of positive people after a hunting trip in the Dauni Mountains. Trichinellosis is once again being talked about in Puglia, after the hospitalization of the 1st positive person at Casa Sollievo della Sofferenza, the hospital founded by San Pio in San Giovanni Rotondo.

[byline: Cenzio DiZanni]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Human trichinellosis due to consumption of infected wild boar meat has been a problem for many years in southern Italy, and the Apulia region in particular (ref 1). The source of infection is typically illegally hunted wild boar, eaten by family and friends of the hunter, but may also be homemade wild boar sausage that has entered the marketplace, neither of which sources is properly subjected to veterinary inspection.

Virtually all the _Trichinella_ species detected in both wild boar and human cases in Italy is _T. britovi_, as opposed to _T. spiralis_, the species that is classically associated with swine infections. A recent citizen science survey in southern Italy of 139 160 wild boar hunted during 2015-2021 found a higher infection rate among boar in Apulia than the other 3 regions of southern Italy. The highest prevalence of infected boar was found in areas at least 400 meters above sea level, indicating wider circulation of _T. britovi_ at high altitudes, due to less anthropogenic pressure and increased carnivorous and scavenging behaviours (ref 2).

_T. britovi_ appears to be more resistant to freezing than _T. spiralis_ (ref 3), which is another reason that proper cooking (heating the meat to an internal temperature of 65°C [149°F] for at least one minute) is the recommended method for killing trichinella larvae.

ProMED welcomes any well-founded information that may help establish the source of infection in these cases of human trichinellosis in San Marco in Lamis, Foggia, whether due to infected wild boar or another source.

References
1. Turiac IA, Cappelli MG, Olivieri R, et al. Trichinellosis outbreak due to wild boar meat consumption in southern Italy. Parasites Vectors. 2017; 10: 107; <https://doi.org/10.1186/s13071-017-2052-5>
2. Sgroi G, D'Alessio N, Marucci G, et al. _Trichinella britovi_ in wild boar meat from Italy, 2015-2021: A citizen science approach to surveillance. One Health. 2022; 16: 100480; <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9826805/>
3. Opinion of the Scientific Panel on Biological Hazards on the suitability and details of freezing methods to allow human consumption of meat infected with Trichinella or Cysticercus. EFSA J. 2004; 142: 1-50; <https://doi.org/10.2903/j.efsa.2005.142>
- Mod.LXL

Wild boar meat is an infamous, main source of human trichinosis. This has led many countries to require that the carcasses of hunted wild boar be examined for trichinella as a condition for consumption. The EU's relevant regulations are available at <https://www.food.gov.uk/sites/default/files/media/document/trichinellatesting.pdf>. Abiding to these regulations would have spared the described cases, assuming the patients had consumed the delicacy unchecked or not thoroughly cooked. Those interested in the history of trichinellosis may wish to visit a detailed report, published in The Lancet of 19 Mar 1881, at <https://tinyurl.com/ycxbukbk>. - Mod.AS

ProMED map:
Foggia, Apulia, Italy: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708727,15077>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (37): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, H5N5, WOAH
***********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[There is a correction of this report:
Avian influenza (37): Europe, wild bird, poultry, HPAI H5N1, H5N5, WOAH, corr 20230308.8708819

Item [3] Sweden: wild bird, HPAI H5N5
We have been informed that further investigations have shown that the date of detection is incorrect in the report submitted to WOAH (<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4942>).

"On 23 Feb 2023, the NVI received several recently dead birds for avian influenza testing within the national surveillance program. The barnacle goose that tested positive for H5N5 was marked with information that it died on 20 Feb 2023. Upon detection of an unexpected strain (H5N5), the submitter was contacted to confirm the date and location of the finding. He informed the NVI that the goose had died on 20 Feb 2021, not 2023, and had been sent for sampling by mistake.

Thus, this case does not represent a reoccurrence of the H5N5 subtype, which has not been detected in Sweden since May 2021." - Mod.CRD]

In this post:
[1] Slovenia: poultry, HPAI H5N1
[2] Estonia: poultry, HPAI H5N1
[3] Sweden: wild bird, HPAI H5N5

******
[1] Slovenia: poultry, HPAI H5N1
Date: Sat 4 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4926>


The event started on 24 Feb 2023 and was confirmed on same date. A total of one outbreak (submitted) has been reported to date [4 Mar 2023]. HPAI H5N1 was confirmed in a free-range poultry farm in Zalog pri Cerkljah na Gorenjskem, Gorenjska.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 1053 / 316 / 316 / 737 / 0 / 0

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Slovenia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708726,115>]

******
[2] Estonia: poultry, HPAI H5N1
Date: Sat 4 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4945>


The event started on 15 Feb 2023 and was confirmed on 3 Mar 2023. Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (H5N1) was confirmed in a farm in Urge, Kohila, Rapla.

The poultry farm has 161 birds (117 laying hens, 19 ducks, 11 geese, 10 pigeons, 4 peacocks). On 15 Feb 2023, one laying hen suddenly died and was sent to the laboratory. By 17 Feb 2023, laying hens had also died and by 2 Mar 2023, 3 geese, 3 peacocks and one duck had died too. HPAI virus of subtype H5N1 (RT-PCR) was confirmed in one laying hen by the National Centre for Laboratory Research and Risk Assessment on 3 Mar 2023. Samples taken on 1 Mar 2023 from 5 laying hens, one peacock, one goose and one pigeon were positive for serotype H5N1.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 161 / 24 / 24 / 137 / - / -

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Estonia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708726,117>]

******
[3] Sweden: wild bird, HPAI H5N5
Date: Sat 4 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [abridged, edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4942>


The event started on 20 Feb 2023 and was confirmed on 1 Mar 2023. A total of one outbreak (submitted) has been reported to date [4 Mar 2023]. HPAI H5N5 was confirmed in a dead barnacle goose in Vellinge.

In accordance with the WOAH Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Article 10.4.1, point 4, this outbreak does not change the disease-free status of Sweden, as these are wild birds or birds kept in a single household, and therefore do not fall within the WOAH definition of poultry.

Total animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Barnacle goose (wild) / - / 1 / 1 / - / - / -

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Sweden: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708726,108>.

"For highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses, there is in principle a risk of infection for humans in the event of intensive contact with infected poultry. Therefore, increased protective measures have been recommended when handling potentially infected poultry and wild birds" (Friedrich-Loeffler-Institut, Federal Research Institute for Animal Health, FAQ Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza, <https://www.openagrar.de/servlets/MCRFileNodeServlet/openagrar_derivate_00051836/FLI-Information-FAQ-Gefluegelpest-2023-02-02-en_bf.pdf>).

A map of HPAI detections in Europe during the period of 2 Mar 2022 to 2 Mar 2023 can be seen at <https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2023/Map_AI_EU_2023-03-02.jpg>. - Mod.CRD]

column2:
SYPHILIS - JAPAN (02): INCREASING CASES, WOMEN, 2022
****************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: Fuji News Network [in Japanese, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.fnn.jp/articles/-/488633?utm_source=headlines.yahoo.co.jp&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=relatedLink>


The number of reports of syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease, is increasing rapidly in Tokyo. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced that it will open a free inspection station next month [March 2023]. It is possible to be tested "anonymously" without revealing your identity.

Tokyo governor Koike's regular press conference was held from 2:00 pm on 17 Feb 2023. Usually, the new coronavirus countermeasures and calls for power saving continue, but this day was different: "Recently, syphilis has become a problem."

Governor Koike mentioned at the regular press conference that the number of reports of syphilis infections is increasing rapidly. The number of reports of syphilis infection is increasing nationwide, but the infection situation in Tokyo seems to be particularly serious. Last year [2022], 3677 infections were reported [in Tokyo?], the highest number since the survey began in 1999. Between 2016 and 2020, the number hovered around 1700. Last year [2022], it more than doubled.

By gender, 2291 males and 1386 females were infected. Compared with 10 years ago, the number of male cases was 9 times higher (263 cases in 2012), while the number of female cases was about 40 times higher (34 cases in 2012). Although the rapid increase in the number of women infected is conspicuous, most of them are in their 20s.

In particular, when a pregnant woman is infected with syphilis, not only the mother but also the fetus can be infected through the placenta, which is considered very dangerous.

Immediately after the war, the number of patients in Japan was over 200 000, but the number decreased due to the development of antibacterial drugs. The increasing trend in recent years is said to be due to sexual acts with an unspecified number of people who met on social media and dating apps.

Last year [2022], the number of reported infections nationwide exceeded 10 000 for the 1st time since the current counting method was adopted. It may be said that there is a rapid increase in infections due to the era of "Reiwa". [Reiwa is the current era, which began on 1 May 2019, the day on which Emperor Akihito's elder son, Naruhito, ascended the throne as the 126th emperor of Japan. - Mod.ML]

In response to this situation, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced that it will set up free inspection stations at 4 locations in Tokyo for 4 days next month [March 2023]. The test results will be available on the same day. Inspection stations will be set up in Shinjuku on 3 Mar 2023, Kinshicho on 7 Mar 2023, Tachikawa on 11 Mar 2023, and Tama Center on 16 Mar 2023.

Of these, the test site in Shinjuku is exclusively for women, but it is said that it is not bound by the gender on the family register. The test is pre-booked, and it is not necessary to reveal your name or address when applying. Considering the history of the infection, it can be said that "anonymous" testing is effective.

To prevent infection, the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare and local governments are also calling on people to "use condoms properly". At a press conference, Governor Koike also said, "We can prevent the spread of infection if each and every one of us has correct knowledge and tries to take appropriate actions."

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[For a discussion of syphilis in Japan, please see a prior ProMED post Syphilis - Japan (02): increasing cases, NIID, comment 20220514.8703255. - Mod.ML

column2:
POLIOMYELITIS UPDATE (09): ISRAEL ACUTE FLACCID PARALYSIS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION, WILD POLIOVIRUS TYPE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLE (AFGHANISTAN) CIRCULATING VACCINE DERIVED POLIOVIRUS TYPE 1 ACUTE FLACCID PARALYSIS (MADAGASCAR, MOZAMBIQUE) CIRCULATING VAC
************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[re: ProMED "Poliomyelitis update (09): Israel AFP, RFI, WPV1 ES, cVDPV1 & 2 AFP & ES 20230228.8708638"
---------------------------------------------------------
The post had errors in section [2]. The information used in the GPEI updates comes from an email that is sent out weekly. At times the website has not as yet been updated with the new data and our very diligent editorial process mistook the discrepancy to be an error in the email process. This post replaces the said post. We apologize for any problems that this error may have created. - Mod.MPP]

In this update:
[1] Israel (Safed): AFP polio suspected, RFI
[A] Times of Israel blog
[B] Ministry of Health press release
[C] Walla media report
[2] Global update as of 22 Feb 2023: WPV1 ES (Afghanistan), cVDPV1 AFP (Madagascar, Mozambique), cVDPV2 AFP (Congo DR, Yemen), ES (Algeria)
[3] Global update as of 15 Feb 2023: WPV1 ES (Afghanistan), cVDPV2 AFP (Chad, DR Congo, Indonesia, Nigeria, Yemen), ES (Benin)

******
Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023 8:51 PM IST
Source: Times of Israel live blog [edited]
<https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/child-in-safed-diagnosed-with-polio-health-ministry-says/>


Israel's Health Ministry announces that a case of polio has been diagnosed in an unvaccinated child in Safed. The child was brought into a local hospital with weakness in his limbs and was tested, leading to the diagnosis. Health officials are now looking into the child's contacts to identify any others who may have been affected.

Polio is a viral disease that mainly affects children and can cause disability, paralysis, and death. Today, polio vaccinations are standard for children and are an effective preventive measure, but vaccine skepticism has enabled the disease to pop up from time to time.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

---
[B] Ministry of Health press release
Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: Israel Ministry of Health press release [in Hebrew, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.gov.il/he/departments/news/27022023-03>


The child arrived at the hospital with limb weakness and after an inquiry at the National Virus Laboratory, the sample was found to be positive for the polio virus. There are about 150 000 unvaccinated children in Israel and there is evidence of the continued existence of polio in the sewers in many communities.

The Ministry of Health mentions that the main way to protect children from paralysis is through a killed polio vaccine. To prevent transmission of the virus it is important to maintain hand hygiene.

The district health bureau will open an epidemiological investigation and contact close contacts of the child to provide specific instructions. According to the findings of the investigation, a decision will be made on additional recommendations. The Ministry of Health will continue monitoring and update the findings.

Polio is a virus that causes paralysis in children, which has been eradicated from many countries in the world thanks to effective and safe vaccines that have been known for decades. No child in the State of Israel in 2023 should suffer from polio. A vaccinated child is a protected child.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

---
[C] Walla media report
Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: Walla [in Hebrew, machine trans., abridged, edited]
<https://news.walla.co.il/item/3561973>


Polio is a virus that causes paralysis in children, which has been eradicated from many countries in the world thanks to effective and safe vaccines that have been known for decades. About a month ago [January 2023], members of a delegation from the World Health Organization arrived in Israel, touring countries with ongoing polio outbreaks, with the aim of examining the ways of coping in Israel, sampling, monitoring, and vaccination. The polio outbreak in Israel began in February 2022, when a Jerusalem girl arrived at the hospital with paralysis. Since then there has been evidence of continued circulation of the virus, by its detection in sewers in various cities throughout the country.

Dr Sharon Elroei Price, head of public health services at the Ministry of Health, explained to Walla that there is no reason to worry about the special delegation that arrived in Israel, but about the disease itself: "Most children who are infected do not develop symptoms, in 20% of cases there are symptoms of a viral disease, and in less than 1% of cases in unvaccinated children there can be paralysis. From 2013 there was no evidence of polio in Israel until the case of the Jerusalem girl."

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[This report was originally found in English as a live blog on the Times of Israel website (section [1A] above. According to a brief report in The Jerusalem Post, the affected child is 8 years old and lives near the city of Safed. "An investigation will be conducted among the child's close family and friends to verify the diagnosis." (<https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-732873>)

From the reports available it appears as though this is a case of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) suspected to be caused by poliovirus, with the Ministry of Health having issued an early official alert. One wonders if there were positive environmental samples in the early results of the epidemiologic investigation.

As a reminder, one AFP case in Jerusalem Israel was reported in March 2022, associated with a circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 3 (cVDPV3) infection (see prior posts in the see also section below). In addition, a vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (VDPV2) was identified in wastewater sampling matching the VDPV2's identified in wastewater in the USA and the UK in August of 2022.

In 2013 positive environmental samples of WPV1 were identified at first in the south of Israel and moving north. No AFP cases were associated with this event (see 2013 ProMED polio posts below). At that time Israel had been using inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) alone for vaccination. To stop the ongoing transmission of wild poliovirus (WPV), the oral polio vaccine (OPV) was reintroduced to the vaccination program as a mixed schedule -- IPV followed by OPV.

We await further information.

Safed has a long and rich history through millennia. It is located in the northern Galilee in Israel and is the highest city in the country (<https://www.touristisrael.com/safed/5681/>). It is considered a holy city in Judaism. It was a refuge for the 1492 Spanish expulsion Sephardic population. It was said to have been originally founded by one of Noah's sons after the Flood.

"The Jerusalem Talmud mentions Safed as one of 5 elevated spots where fires were lit to announce the New Moon and festivals during the Second Temple period." "The city today has a large Haredi community and remains a center for Jewish religious studies."
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safed>)
The mention of a sizable Haredi community may well mean a sizeable pocket of unvaccinated children and young adults.

A map of Israel showing the location of Safed can be found at <https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Israel_outline_northeast.png>. - Mod.MPP

ProMED map of Israel: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708724,64333>]

[2] Global update as of 22 Feb 2023: WPV1 ES (Afghanistan), cVDPV1 AFP (Madagascar, Mozambique), cVDPV2 AFP (DR Congo, Yemen), ES (Algeria)
Date: Wed 22 Feb 2023
Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative/WHO [edited]
<https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/>


Poliovirus weekly update 22 Feb 2023, World Health Organization
---------------------------------------------------------------
New wild poliovirus isolates reported this week:
Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) cases: 0
Environmental samples (ES)
Others: 0

New circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) isolates reported this week:
AFP cases: 8
Environment: 15
Others: 4

Headlines
---------
- Novel oral polio vaccine type 2 (nOPV2) rollout: about 585 million doses of nOPV2 have been administered across 27 countries under its WHO Emergency Use Listing (EUL) to date. An additional 14 countries have met the requirements for nOPV2 use in the event of an outbreak. Visit the nOPV2 web page for more information. [<https://polioeradication.org/nOPV2/>]

Summary of new polioviruses this week:
- Afghanistan: 2 wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) positive ES
- Algeria: 2 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive ES
- Congo DR: 4 cVDPV2 cases
- Madagascar: 1 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) case and 8 positive ES
- Mozambique: 2 cVDPV1 cases
- Yemen: 1 cVDPV2 case and 5 positive ES

Afghanistan
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2022.
- 2 WPV1 positive ESwere reported in Nangarhar.

Pakistan
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 20 cases detected in 2022.

Algeria
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 3 cases detected in 2022.
- 2 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported: 1 each in Alger and Tamanghasset.

Benin
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 10 cases detected in 2022.

Botswana
- No cVDPV2 positive environmental sample was reported this week. There are 3 positive samples reported in 2022.

Burkina Faso
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021.

Cameroon
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 2 cases reported in 2022.

Canada
- No cVDPV2 was reported in the past week. Previously, cVDPV2 was isolated from 2 ES from a large wastewater treatment plant and a target site in the city of Montreal, Quebec, collected on 27 and 30 Aug 2022, after the country conducted retrospective analysis of wastewater samples. Genetic sequencing confirmed it is linked to the cVDPV2 currently affecting New York, USA.

Central African Republic
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 5 cases detected in 2022.

Chad
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 43 cases detected in 2022.

Congo (Republic of)
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021.

Côte d'Ivoire
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were no cases reported in 2021.

Djibouti
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week.

Democratic Republic of the Congo (Congo DR)
- 4 cases of cVDPV2 were reported in Haut Lomami bringing the number of 2022 cases to 287.
- No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) were reported this week. There are 92 cases detected in 2022.
- Outbreak response to both cVDPV1 and cVDPV2 is being intensified.

Egypt
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 18 positive samples reported in the country in the last 2 years.

Ethiopia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022.

Eritrea
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case in 2022 and 1 case reported in 2021.

Gambia
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There were 9 positive samples in 2021.

Ghana
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 3 cases in 2022.

Guinea
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 6 cases in 2021.

Guinea-Bissau
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 3 cases in the country which are linked to the Jigawa outbreak in Nigeria in 2021.

Israel
- No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 3 (cVDPV3) were reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022.
- The country has been confirmed as affected by both cVDPV2 and cVDPV3.

Indonesia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2023. There was 1 case detected in 2022.

Liberia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 3 cVDPV2 cases in 2021.

Madagascar
- 1 case of cVDPV1 was reported in Sava. There are 14 cases detected in 2022.
- 8 cVDPV1 positive ES were reported in Analamanga.

Mali
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case detected in 2022.

Malawi
- No cases of WPV1 were reported this week. 1 case from 2021 has been reported in 2022.
- No cases of cVDPV1 were reported this week. There were 4 cases in the country in 2022.

Mauritania
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There were 7 positive samples linked to the Jigawa outbreak in 2021.

Mozambique
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 8 cases detected in 2022. Reporting of these new cases within a short time span indicates that intensified surveillance efforts are working in the province.
- 2 cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) were reported in Zambezia. There were 21 cases in 2022.
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. The number of cases in 2022 remains 4.

Niger
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. The number of cVDPV2 cases in 2022 remains 14.

Nigeria
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported were reported this week. There is 1 case detected in 2023 and 47 cases detected in 2022.

Senegal
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Sierra Leone
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Somalia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported in Banadir. There are 5 cases reported in 2022.

Sudan
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022.

South Sudan
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Togo
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 2 cases in 2022.
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 2 positive samples reported in 2022.

Uganda
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week.

Ukraine
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021.
- Disease surveillance continues to be strengthened, to the degree possible given the evolving situation, including building capacity, conducting trainings, implementing environmental surveillance, and supporting routine immunization.

United Kingdom
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. 2 positive samples were reported in May and 1 in August [2022] following the isolation of vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (VDPV2) from ES in London, UK.
- No cases of paralysis associated with this strain have been detected -- virus has been isolated only from environmental (sewage) samples.

United States of America
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. 1 cVDPV2 case was reported in New York in 2022.
- No cVDPV2 positive ES was reported this week. There were 12 positive samples reported in 2022.

Yemen
- 1 case of cVDPV2 was reported in Alhudaidah. There are 161 cases detected in 222.
- 5 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported; 2 in Alhudaidah and 3 in Aden.

Zambia
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 3 positives samples reported in 2022.

Officially reported WPV1 and cVDPV cases as of [21 Feb 2023]
Wild poliovirus (WPV)
- Total global WPV1 cases in 2023: 0 (compared with 1 for the same period in 2022)
- Total global WPV1 cases in 2022: 30
Circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) cases
- Total global cVDPV cases in 2023: 3 (compared with 4 for the same period in 2022)
- Total global cVDPV cases in 2022: 724

--
communicated by:
ProMED

******
[3] Global update as of 15 Feb 2023: WPV1 ES (Afghanistan); cVDPV2 AFP (Chad, Congo DR, Indonesia, Nigeria, Yemen); ES (Benin)
Date: Wed 15 Feb 2023
Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative/WHO [edited]
<https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/>


New wild poliovirus isolates reported this week:
Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) cases: 0
Environmental samples (ES): 2
Others: 0

New circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) isolates reported this week:
AFP cases: 18
ES: 11
Others: 1

Summary of new polioviruses this week:
- Afghanistan: 2 wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) positive ES
- Benin: 1 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive ES
- Chad: 7 cVDPV2 cases
- Congo DR: 6 cVDPV2 cases
- Indonesia: 1 cVDPV2 case
- Nigeria: 4 cVDPV2 cases
- Yemen: 10 cVDPV2 positive ES

Afghanistan
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2022.
- 2 WPV1 positive ES were reported; 1 each in Nangarhar and Kunar.

Benin
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 10 cases detected in 2022.
- 1 cVDPV2 positive ES was reported in Donga.

Chad
- 7 cases of cVDPV2 were reported; 1 each in Logone Occidental, Dar Sila and Hadjer Lamis, and 2 each in N'djamena and Ouaddai. There are now 43 cases detected in 2022.

Democratic Republic of the Congo (Congo DR)
- 6 cases of cVDPV2 were reported; 4 in Haut Lomami and 1 each in Lualaba and Sud-Kivu. There are 283 cases detected in 2022.
- No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) were reported this week. There are 92 cases detected in 2022.
- Outbreak response to both cVDPV1 and cVDPV2 is being intensified.

Indonesia
- 1 case of cVDPV2 was reported this week, the 2nd detection in 2023. 1 case was detected in 2022.

Nigeria
- 4 cases of cVDPV2 were reported in Zamfara with 1 case being the 1st of 2023. There are now 47 cases detected in 2022.

Yemen
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 160 cases reported in 2022.
- 10 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported; 4 each in Alhudaidah and Sanaa city, and 2 in Aden.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[The past week has seen evidence of poliovirus (WPV1, cVDPV1, and cVDPV2) circulation in 10 countries. WPV1 positive ES in Afghanistan, cVDPV1 AFP cases in Madagascar and Mozambique, cVDPV2 AFP cases in Chad, Congo DR, Indonesia, Nigeria, and Yemen, and cVDPV2 positive ES were confirmed in Algeria and Benin. All reported events (AFP cases and positive ESs) were events in 2022 except the AFP cases in Indonesia and one AFP case in Nigeria which were 2023 events.

The 2022 total reported cVDPV cases has officially overtaken those confirmed in 2021 (698 cVDPV AFP cases in 2021, 724 cases confirmed to date in 2022.

A map showing the locations of each confirmed case of polio worldwide in the past 12 months can be found at <https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/>. One can see cases of cVDPV in a band across Africa and in Israel, Ukraine, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Pakistan; cVDPV1 in DR Congo, Malawi, Madagascar, and Mozambique; and WPV1 in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Malawi, and Mozambique. - Mod.MPP
]

column3: New wild poliovirus isolates reported this week:Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) cases: 0Environmental samples (ES): 2Others: 0New circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) isolates reported this week:AFP cases: 18ES: 11Others: 1Summary of new polioviruses this week:- Afghanistan: 2 wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) positive ES- Benin: 1 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive ES- Chad: 7 cVDPV2 cases- Congo DR: 6 cVDPV2 cases- Indonesia: 1 cVDPV2 case- Nigeria: 4 cVDPV2 cases- Yemen: 10 cVDPV2 positive ESAfghanistan- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2022.- 2 WPV1 positive ES were reported; 1 each in Nangarhar and Kunar.Benin- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 10 cases detected in 2022.- 1 cVDPV2 positive ES was reported in Donga.Chad- 7 cases of cVDPV2 were reported; 1 each in Logone Occidental, Dar Sila and Hadjer Lamis, and 2 each in N'djamena and Ouaddai. There are now 43 cases detected in 2022.Democratic Republic of the Congo (Congo DR)- 6 cases of cVDPV2 were reported; 4 in Haut Lomami and 1 each in Lualaba and Sud-Kivu. There are 283 cases detected in 2022.- No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) were reported this week. There are 92 cases detected in 2022.- Outbreak response to both cVDPV1 and cVDPV2 is being intensified.Indonesia- 1 case of cVDPV2 was reported this week, the 2nd detection in 2023. 1 case was detected in 2022.Nigeria- 4 cases of cVDPV2 were reported in Zamfara with 1 case being the 1st of 2023. There are now 47 cases detected in 2022.Yemen- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 160 cases reported in 2022.- 10 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported; 4 each in Alhudaidah and Sanaa city, and 2 in Aden.--communicated by:ProMED[The past week has seen evidence of poliovirus (WPV1, cVDPV1, and cVDPV2) circulation in 10 countries. WPV1 positive ES in Afghanistan, cVDPV1 AFP cases in Madagascar and Mozambique, cVDPV2 AFP cases in Chad, Congo DR, Indonesia, Nigeria, and Yemen, and cVDPV2 positive ES were confirmed in Algeria and Benin. All reported events (AFP cases and positive ESs) were events in 2022 except the AFP cases in Indonesia and one AFP case in Nigeria which were 2023 events.The 2022 total reported cVDPV cases has officially overtaken those confirmed in 2021 (698 cVDPV AFP cases in 2021, 724 cases confirmed to date in 2022.A map showing the locations of each confirmed case of polio worldwide in the past 12 months can be found at <https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/>. One can see cases of cVDPV in a band across Africa and in Israel, Ukraine, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Pakistan; cVDPV1 in DR Congo, Malawi, Madagascar, and Mozambique; and WPV1 in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Malawi, and Mozambique. - Mod.MPP]

column2:
FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - IRAQ (06): LIVESTOCK, SEROTYPE SAT-2, SPREAD, WOAH
*************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 26 Feb 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [abridged, edited] 
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-event/4856/dashboard>


Iraq, FMDV SAT-2, follow-up report no.5
---------------------------------------
General information
-------------------
Event ID 4856
Disease: Foot and mouth disease virus
Causal agent: Foot and mouth disease virus
Genotype/Serotype: SAT-2
Start date: 3 Jan 2023
Confirmation date: 15 Jan 2023
Event status: ongoing

Epidemiology
------------
Source of event or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: Active surveillance is in place to update and confirm the new disease foci. The source and phylogeny of the causative lineage/sub lineage is under investigation (pathological samples sent to SAP institute/Türkiye). No vaccination zoning / and no mass vaccination campaign due to delay in purchasing vaccines, animal movement restriction.

Quantitative data summary
-------------------------
Epidemiological statistics of 9 new outbreaks, per species:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Culled / Slaughtered / Vaccinated
Buffaloes / 1032 / 336 / 33 / 0 / 0 / 0 
Cattle / 1065 / 600 / 34 / 0 / 0 / 0
Sheep / 1451 / 135 / 7 / 0 / 0 / 0
Goats / 80 / 15 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0 

Total epidemiological statistics of 23 outbreaks since start of event:
Species / Cases / Deaths / Vaccinated
Buffaloes / 2091 / 159 / 0
Cattle / 1926 / 55 / 0
Sheep / 23 878 / 17 / 0
Goats / 80 / 15 / 0

Diagnostic details
------------------
Clinical signs: yes
Method of diagnostic: diagnostic test

a. 
Test name: Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR)
Laboratory: Central Veterinary Laboratory 
Species sampled: cattle, buffaloes
Outbreak: Gogjaly, Zarqa 
Result date: 15 Jan 2023 
Result: positive

b. 
Test name: Gene sequencing 
Laboratory: The Pirbright Institute 
Species sampled: cattle, buffaloes
Outbreak: Gogjaly, Zarqa [other (Latin) names: Gogjali, Gukjalt, Qaryat Kukjali, Gagjali; map at <https://tinyurl.com/y4j5pfdp>]
Result date: 2 Feb 2023
Result: positive 

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Iraq's immediate notification of the event was submitted on 26 Jan 2023. The 5 follow-up reports (FURs) published since, were submitted on 1, 3, 3, 12, and 26 Feb 2023. All are available at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-event/4856/dashboard>.

Follow-up report no.5 presents 9 new outbreaks, similarly spread from the extreme north west to the south east of the country, reported from the following locations/provinces: Mosil/Ninawa, Karbala/Karbala, Dayala/Diyala, Al-Diwania/Al-Qadisiyah, Baghdad/Baghdad, Babil/Babil, Alnajaf/An-Najaf, Alramadi/Al-Anbar, and Al-Basrah/Al-Basrah.

Outbreaks have been reported, since the start of the event in January 2023, from locations spread throughout Iraq, from Mosul in the north-west, bordering north east Syria and south east Turkey (the "Kurdish triangle"), down to the south east, bordering Kuwait on the south and south west Iran on the east. All 23 outbreaks are presented on WOAH's updated (26 Feb 2023) map, at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-event/4856/dashboard>.

Information on the genotyping results of the strain involved may allow tracing the origin of the pathogen, its route of introduction, and its relationship with other FMDV SAT-2 strains, in particular the Jordanian strain and East-African strains.

The WRLFMD, Pirbright, publishes test results after obtaining the consent of the relevant country to do so. When Iraq's consent is given, the genotyping results are expected to become available on Iraq's page (<https://www.wrlfmd.org/western-and-central-asia/iraq#panel-7312>).

The continuing circulation of the exotic virus in Iraq is a cause for great concern, regionally, warranting alertness -- particularly in neighboring Syria, Iran, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia. The situation in Jordan is discussed in ProMED post 20230303.8708700. - Mod. AS

Iraq: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708723,89>]

column2:
LEGIONELLOSIS - USA (03): (SOUTH CAROLINA) FATAL, NURSING FACILITY, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*******************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: ABC25 Columbia [edited]
<https://www.abccolumbia.com/2023/03/02/dhec-investigates-disease-outbreak-at-fairfield-co-nursing-center/>


DHEC [South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control] is investigating an outbreak at a nursing center in Fairfield County [South Carolina]. The health agency says they are looking into multiple cases of legionnaire's disease at the Ridgeway Manor Healthcare Center.

People can catch the infection after breathing in mists from a water source like air conditioning, cooling towers and showers that are contaminated with the bacteria.

According to the Pritzker Law Firm, DHEC is working with the nursing center to put preventative measures in place and to find the source of the contamination.

[byline: Jessica Mejia]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Ridgeway Manor Healthcare Center is a skilled nursing, short-term rehabilitation, and 112-bed long-term care facility in Ridgeway, South Carolina, United States (<https://health.usnews.com/best-nursing-homes/area/sc/ridgeway-manor-healthcare-center-425158>). Ridgeway (population 266 residents in 2020) is a town in Fairfield County, 24 miles (39 km) south of the city of Columbia, the state capital (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ridgeway,_South_Carolina>).

Legionella are Gram negative bacilli that are found in both natural freshwater environments, such as lakes and streams, and in manufactured plumbing systems. Warm water temperatures of 25-40 deg C (77-104 deg F) support the highest concentrations of the organism in plumbing systems.

Humans usually acquire these organisms by inhalation of aerosolized legionella from contaminated water sources. Aerosols can spread for distances outdoors wafting on air currents downwind from their source. In fact, during the outbreak of pneumonia among legionnaires meeting at a hotel in Philadelphia in 1976 that was subsequently thought to be due to inhalation of aerosolized _Legionella pneumophila_ within the hotel, some passersby on Broad Street in front of the hotel, who had never entered the hotel, developed what was called at the time "Broad Street pneumonia" (<https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00045731.htm>). Aerosols containing legionella can be generated from contaminated water by cooling towers, fountains, showers, and misting sprays in outdoor event spaces and in grocery departments.

Home and car air-conditioning units do not use water to cool the air, so they are not a risk for legionella growth (<https://www.cdc.gov/legionella/about/causes-transmission.html>).

Eradication of these bacteria from plumbing systems is often difficult. Long-term persistence within these water systems is favored by the intracellular location of legionella within several species of protozoa, where legionella replicate and which provide protection from environmental stressors, like biocides and heat treatment.

Also, the formation of biofilms allows adherence of legionella to the inner surfaces of the plumbing systems (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5835138/>). _Legionella pneumophila_ have been shown to persist for long periods in biofilms in a viable but nonculturable (VBNC) state after exposure to a biocide or heat treatment (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5515819/>). Monitoring _L. pneumophila_ in water systems, which is usually done by culture, would miss VBNC egionella, which can be revived by the subsequent addition of amoeba (<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18839249>).

Debilitated hospitalized patients who are prone to aspiration may develop legionnaires' disease following aspiration of legionella-contaminated potable water as well as inhaling a fine spray (aerosols) from water sources containing legionella. Possible person-to-person transmission has also been described (Correia AM, Goncalves J, Gomes JP, et al: Probable person-to-person transmission of Legionnaires' disease. N Engl J Med. 2016; 374(5): 497-8; <http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMc1505356>).

During the epidemiological and environmental investigation for the source of legionella organisms, patients should be prohibited from taking showers and should consume only sterile water until the source has been remediated.

Genotyping the clinical isolates from the cases of legionnaires' disease will help confirm if this is a common source outbreak, if the genotypes match. Matching the genotypes of clinical and environmental isolates of legionella will identify the environmental source for the individual cases. However, if the diagnosis of legionnaires' disease was based only on a positive urinary antigen assay, there will be no clinical isolates for genotyping. We have not been told if legionella has been isolated from any environmental water sources or if genotyping has been done on any clinical or environmental legionella isolates.

The news report above offers little information about this outbreak. "Multiple" cases of legionnaires' disease have occurred at Ridgeway Manor, but we are not told patient characteristics, how the diagnoses were confirmed, exactly how many cases there are, over what period of time the cases occurred, and if there are any epidemiologic links between the cases, other than residence at Ridgeway Manor. More information on this outbreak from knowledgeable sources would be appreciated. - Mod.ML

Fairfield County, South Carolina, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708722,25867>]

column2:
HANTAVIRUS - AMERICAS (08): CHILE (ARAUCANIA)
*********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: La Opinion [in Spanish, trans. Mod.TY, edited]
<https://www.laopinon.cl/noticia/sociedad/preocupacion-por-nuevo-contagio-de-virus-hanta-en-la-araucania>


The La Araucanía health authority confirmed a new hantavirus [infection] case in the region. As a result, preventive actions have been reinforced after the forest emergency that hit the area, which could increase infections of this virus.

"The [forest] fires are generating ecosystem disorder that are affecting various animales and that is not unrelated to -- for example, bats and the long-tailed mouse -- whose habitat is always in competition with humans. That is why those who live in the countryside have to redouble their care," said the health SEREMI [Secretaría Regional Ministerial de Salud; regional health ministerial secretariat], Andrés Cuyul.

This case is a person who carries out rural work in Lautaro. "We are currently carrying out environmental and epidemiological investigations in order to see where the areas of risk are located. Preliminarily, it was known that the person worked in different fields and farms, which leads us to ask people who work or visit rural areas to adopt all the preventive measures that have been disseminated," the authority reported.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[The above report does not indicate the condition of the patient. Cases of hantavirus infection in Chile can be serious, leading to hantavirus cardiopulmonary syndrome and death.

Hantavirus infections occur in a broad Andean region of Chile every year. Although not specified in this or previous reports from affected regions, the hantavirus involved in this case no doubt is Andes virus, which is endemic in Chile. The patient likely came into contact with areas inhabited by the rodent reservoir of the virus in the region, which is why the Araucania regional health SEREMI issued warnings about following preventive recommendations in areas of risk where the rodent host of Andes virus is found.

Andes virus is rarely transmitted directly from person to person and only through close physical contact, usually within the family. This is why contacts are warned about possible risk of infection. The commonest source of the infection is the long-tailed pygmy rice rat. Images of the long-tailed pygmy rice rat (_Oligoryzomys longicaudatus_), the sigmodontine rodent host of Andes hantavirus, can be seen at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oligoryzomys_longicaudatus#/media/File:Raton_colilarga.jpg>. - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Región de la Araucanía, Chile: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708716,5111>]

[See Also:
Hantavirus - Americas (06): Chile (BI) 20230217.8708446
Hantavirus - Americas (05): Chile (ML) susp 20230209.8708261
Hantavirus - Americas (01): Chile (AI) 20230101.8707565

column3: The La Araucanía health authority confirmed a new hantavirus [infection] case in the region. As a result, preventive actions have been reinforced after the forest emergency that hit the area, which could increase infections of this virus."The [forest] fires are generating ecosystem disorder that are affecting various animales and that is not unrelated to -- for example, bats and the long-tailed mouse -- whose habitat is always in competition with humans. That is why those who live in the countryside have to redouble their care," said the health SEREMI [Secretaría Regional Ministerial de Salud; regional health ministerial secretariat], Andrés Cuyul.This case is a person who carries out rural work in Lautaro. "We are currently carrying out environmental and epidemiological investigations in order to see where the areas of risk are located. Preliminarily, it was known that the person worked in different fields and farms, which leads us to ask people who work or visit rural areas to adopt all the preventive measures that have been disseminated," the authority reported.--communicated by:ProMED[The above report does not indicate the condition of the patient. Cases of hantavirus infection in Chile can be serious, leading to hantavirus cardiopulmonary syndrome and death.Hantavirus infections occur in a broad Andean region of Chile every year. Although not specified in this or previous reports from affected regions, the hantavirus involved in this case no doubt is Andes virus, which is endemic in Chile. The patient likely came into contact with areas inhabited by the rodent reservoir of the virus in the region, which is why the Araucania regional health SEREMI issued warnings about following preventive recommendations in areas of risk where the rodent host of Andes virus is found.Andes virus is rarely transmitted directly from person to person and only through close physical contact, usually within the family. This is why contacts are warned about possible risk of infection. The commonest source of the infection is the long-tailed pygmy rice rat. Images of the long-tailed pygmy rice rat (_Oligoryzomys longicaudatus_), the sigmodontine rodent host of Andes hantavirus, can be seen at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oligoryzomys_longicaudatus#/media/File:Raton_colilarga.jpg>. - Mod.TYProMED map:Región de la Araucanía, Chile: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708716,5111>]

column2:
SALMONELLOSIS - USA: OYSTER, ex FLORIDA, ALERT, RECALL
******************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023 15:32 EST
Source: Miami (FL) Herald [edited]
<https://www.miamiherald.com/news/recalls/article272630822.html>


Oysters harvested from a small island city in Florida are associated with a salmonellosis outbreak that has sickened people in 3 states, the state's health agency says. The Florida Department of Health and the state health departments of Georgia and Alabama have detected 8 cases linked with the consumption of raw oysters harvested from Cedar Key, on the north west coast of Florida.

On 24 Feb 2023, the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services shut down the shellfish harvesting area in Cedar Key and recalled the wild oysters collected since 16 Dec 2022. There is an elevated risk of getting sick associated with raw oyster consumption, the health agency said, and it warned consumers not to eat the oysters included in the recall.

Eating food contaminated with salmonella can cause salmonellosis, the health agency said. Symptoms include diarrhea, abdominal cramps and fever within 12 to 72 hours after eating a contaminated product. Most people recover without treatment, but in rare circumstances the infection can cause more severe illness and require hospitalization, the health agency noted. Older adults, infants, pregnant women and the immunocompromised are at higher risk of developing a severe illness and should seek medical attention if symptoms arise.

[byline: Omar Rodriguez Ortiz]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[The serotype or serotypes of _S. enterica_ in this, so far, small outbreak is not stated here. While raw or undercooked shellfish-associated salmonellosis is not particularly common, it certainly does occur as summarized here:

Brands DA, Inman AE, Gerba CP, et al. Prevalence of _Salmonella_ spp. in oysters in the United States. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2005;71: 893-7.

Abstract
-------
"Food-borne diseases such as salmonellosis can be attributed, in part, to the consumption of raw oysters. To determine the prevalence of _Salmonella_ spp. in oysters, oysters harvested from 36 US bays (12 each from the West, East, and Gulf coasts in the summer of 2002, and 12 bays, 4 per coast, in the winter of 2002-2003) were tested. _Salmonella_ was isolated from oysters from each coast of the United States, and 7.4% of all oysters tested contained _Salmonella_. Isolation tended to be bay specific, with some bays having a high prevalence of _Salmonella_, while other bays had none. Differences in the percentage of oysters from which _Salmonella_ was isolated were observed between the summer and winter months, with winter numbers much lower probably due to a variety of weather-related events. The vast majority (78 of 101) of _Salmonella_ isolates from oysters were _Salmonella enterica_ serovar Newport, a major human pathogen, confirming the human health hazard of raw oyster consumption. Contrary to previous findings, no relationship was found between the isolation of fecal coliforms and _Salmonella_ from oysters, indicating a necessity for specific monitoring for _Salmonella_ and other pathogens rather than the current reliance on fecal coliform testing."

Indeed, one of the earliest infectious diseases linked to oysters was _S. enterica_ serotype Typhi, the cause of typhoid fever. Several 19th century reports are:
- Broadbent W. A note on the transmission of the infection of typhoid fever by oysters. Br Med J. 1895; 1(1776): 61.
- Eade P. Typhoid fever and oysters and other molluscs. Br Med J. 1895; 1(1777): 121-2.
- Allen K. The transmission of typhoid by sewage polluted oysters. Public Health Pap Rep. 1899; 25: 154-65.

- Mod.LL

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (36): AMERICAS (ARGENTINA) POULTRY, HPAI H5, WOAH
*****************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this post:
[1] Rio Negro: poultry, HPAI H5
[2] Buenos Aires, Cordoba: poultry, backyard, HPAI H5

******
[1] Rio Negro: poultry, HPAI H5
Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4933>


Argentina - High pathogenicity avian influenza viruses (poultry)
-----------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 26 Feb 2023
Confirmed: 28 Feb 2023
Reported: 1 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: 1st occurrence in the country
Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]
Serotype: H5
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Mainque, General Roca, Rio Negro
Started: 26 Feb 2023
Epidemiological unit: farm
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds / 190 000 / 9000 / 9000 / - / - / -

Affected population: The event occurred in a broiler chicken farm with 10 houses that, at the beginning of the event, had around 190 000 broilers at the end of their fattening cycle. On 27 Feb 2023, during inspection, in one of the poultry houses, a mortality rate of around 17% was detected, deaths having occurred the previous day (which represents a daily mortality rate of almost 2% of the production unit). The farmer immediately informed the SENASA (Servicio Nacional de Sanidad y Calidad Agroalimentaria; the National Food Safety and Quality Service), and official attention was given to the suspicion that same day, with quarantine of the premises and sampling for diagnosis. On 28 Feb 2023, a similar mortality was recorded again in the same house. No disease signs were reported in the other houses. That same day (28 Feb 2023) the official SENASA laboratory got positive results for AI type A subtype H5. On 1 Mar 2023, the official outbreak control actions began. All birds were culled and disposed of.

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species
Epidemiological comments: The epidemiological situation in the region (South America) concerns the circulation of HPAI virus in wild, backyard and poultry birds since the end of 2022 and in Argentina since February 2023 in wild and backyard birds.

Control measures at event level
To be applied in domestic animals: disinfection, stamping out, surveillance outside the restricted zone, surveillance within the restricted zone, movement control, zoning, official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste, official destruction of animal products

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Result date / Result
[General Directorate of Laboratories and Technical Control, National Service for Food Health and Quality (SENASA)] / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 28 Feb 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.

Please note that any discrepancies in event start, confirmation, and other dates in ProMED posts and the WOAH corresponding reports are the result of a technical problem already being addressed by WOAH. - Mod.CRD]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2] Buenos Aires, Cordoba: poultry, backyard, HPAI H5
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: National Service for Food Health and Quality (SENASA), Argentina [in Spanish, machine trans., abridged, edited]
<https://www.argentina.gob.ar/noticias/influenza-aviar-4-nuevos-casos-positivos-en-las-provincias-de-buenos-aires-y-cordoba>


On 2 Mar 2023, the National Service for Food Health and Quality (Servicio Nacional de Sanidad y Calidad Agroalimentaria [SENASA]) confirmed 4 new positive cases of avian influenza (AI) H5: one in poultry (2nd case in the country, the 1st was detected in Río Negro) and one in backyard in the province of Buenos Aires and 2 in the backyard in the province of Córdoba, bringing a total of 30 detections of the disease to date throughout the country.

Of the 13 samples analyzed today [2 Mar 2023] by the SENASA national laboratory, 4 had a positive diagnosis for AI H5: one in poultry in an establishment in the Buenos Aires town of General Alvear and one from a backyard in Las Flores, while the remaining 2 in backyard birds correspond to the Cordoba towns of Laboulaye and Colonia El Arbol.

After confirmation of the cases, agents from the Buenos Aires Norte and Cordoba del SENASA regional centers will carry out the corresponding sanitary actions in the affected properties. In turn, SENASA is working on sanitary and raking actions in all the regions where the findings were made.

Of the nearly 200 notifications analyzed by the SENASA Laboratory to date [2 Mar 2023], there are 30 confirmed cases in wild birds (3), backyard (25) and commercial sector (2) distributed as follows: 15 in Cordoba, 7 in Buenos Aires, 2 in Río Negro, 2 in Santa Fe, 1 in Jujuy, 1 in Neuquen, 1 in San Luis and 1 in Salta.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Information on cases of HPAI H5 in wild and backyard birds in Argentina can be seen in the latest WOAH follow-up report 3, dated 21 Feb 2023, at <https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4908>.

Detailed information and updates on avian influenza in Argentina can be found at <https://www.argentina.gob.ar/senasa/influenza-aviar> (in Spanish). - Mod.CRD

ProMED map:
Argentina: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708712,4>]

AVIAN INFLUENZA (35): ASIA (TAIWAN, NEPAL) BACKYARD, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, WOAH
*******************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this post:
[1] Taiwan: backyard, HPAI H5N1
[2] Nepal: crow, HPAI H5N1

******
[1] Taiwan: backyard, HPAI H5N1
Date: Fri 3 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4916>


[Taiwan] - High pathogenicity avian influenza viruses (poultry)
---------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 14 Jan 2023
Confirmed: 19 Jan 2023
Reported: 2 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 29 May 2022
Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]
Serotype: H5N1
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Lunbei Township, Yunlin County, [Taiwan]
Started: 14 Jan 2023
Epidemiological unit: backyard
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Birds (domestic) / 28 / 10 / 10 / 18 / 0 / 0
Affected population: chicken and ducks

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive
Epidemiological comments: The local government reported that dead chickens were discarded on the roadside in Yunlin County on 14 Jan 2023. The local government traced back to the source and confirmed it was from one backyard for their own use and no contact with poultry or poultry facilities. The local government implemented movement restriction to the animals of the backyard. Samples were sent to the National Reference Laboratory (Animal Health Research Institute, AHRI) for diagnosis on the same day. The H5N1 subtype of highly pathogenic avian influenza was confirmed by AHRI on 19 Jan 2023. Meanwhile, 9 chickens and 9 ducks (backyard animals) were culled. Thorough cleaning and disinfection have been conducted after stamping out operation. Surrounding poultry farms within 5 km (3.1 mi) radius of the infected flocks are now under intensified surveillance.

Control measures at event level
Domestic control measures applied: disinfection, movement control, quarantine, stamping out, surveillance within the restricted zone, surveillance outside the restricted zone, traceability, zoning
Domestic control measures to be applied: screening

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result
Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) / birds / 1 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 18 Jan 2023 / positive
Animal Health Research Institute (AHRI) / birds / 1 / gene sequencing / 19 Jan 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

column2:
SYPHILIS - USA (05): CONGENITAL, INCREASING CASES
*************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023 23:53 EST
Source: CNN [abridged, edited]
<https://www.cnn.com/2023/03/01/health/congenital-syphilis-alarming-rise/index.html>


Left untreated, syphilis can lead to stillbirth. It may damage a baby's organs and bones or harm vision and hearing. In 2021, more than 200 infants in the United States with congenital syphilis died. Rates of syphilis in babies are rising at an alarming rate in the United States.

Syphilis is a bacterial infection that is typically spread by sexual contact. It begins with a painless sore called a chancre. These often arise on the genitals or mouth. The disease spreads from person to person through direct contact with these sores. People can have symptoms 10 to 90 days after infection. Syphilis is sometimes called the great pretender because its symptoms can mimic those of many other diseases: fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, hair loss and fatigue.

Without treatment, the infection progresses through a series of stages. It can lie dormant in the body for years or even decades, returning with a vengeance in its later stages to attack the brain, nerves, eyes and other organs. It can lead to deafness, blindness or death. In addition to passing the infection through skin sores, people who are pregnant can pass the infection to a developing baby in the womb. When a baby becomes infected before birth, this is known as congenital syphilis. Public health experts consider congenital syphilis to be a "never event" -- something that should never happen -- because nearly every case is preventable.

Timely treatment -- at least 30 days before delivery -- slashes the risk that the infection will pass from mother to baby by 98%, and syphilis is treated with penicillin, one of the world's oldest and cheapest antibiotics (<https://www.cdc.gov/nchhstp/pregnancy/effects/syphilis.html>). From a public health standpoint, then, stopping this infection should be a no-brainer.

But increasingly, people are falling through the cracks during pregnancy, not getting tested or treated in time to stop transmission from mother to infant. Each case represents "multiple failures of the health system to identify and treat the mom," said Dr Ali Khan, dean of the College of Public Health at the University of Nebraska Medical Center.

Over the past decade, "there's been about a 700% increase in the cases of congenital syphilis in the United States," said Dr Robert McDonald of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Division of STD Prevention, Surveillance and Data Management. "It really is upsetting, because this is something that is fully preventable if we have the right screening and treatment," he said. "It's out there; people just need to be connected with that."

Rates of congenital syphilis, meaning the number of cases for every 100 000 live births, are highest in the South and Southwest, in states such as Arizona, New Mexico, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas, according to a CNN analysis of CDC data.

Cases in the South have grown the fastest: up 432% between 2016 and 2021, which is the latest year for which complete data are available. Individual states have seen increases that are even more eye-popping. From 2016 to 2021, cases shot up 3300% in Mississippi, nearly 3000% in Oklahoma, more than 2200% in Hawaii, more than 1800% in Washington, more than 1600% in New Mexico, more than 1500% in Wisconsin and more than 1000% in Iowa and Arizona, according to CDC data. Even Maine, which had been one of 3 states to have been free of cases in the past decade or so, reported its 1st congenital syphilis case in 3 decades in January [2023] (<https://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/health-advisory.shtml?id=10134153>).

This is a frustrating reversal for the United States, where determined public health efforts and robust contact-tracing programs had driven congenital syphilis cases to almost historically low numbers just a decade ago. In 2012, 324 congenital syphilis cases were reported to the CDC. In 2021, that number had ballooned to 2677 (<https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6444a3.htm>).

The reasons for this increase are complex and intertwined, starting with a lack of funding. At the height of the success of efforts to eradicate congenital syphilis, the government followed what has become a predictable approach when it comes to funding public health. "When something no longer seems to be a problem, we walk away from it," said Elizabeth Finley, communications director for the nonprofit National Coalition of STD Directors.

According to an analysis by the coalition, CDC prevention funding for the prevention of sexually transmitted diseases has fallen more than 40% since 2003, when adjusted for inflation. Next, there's a shortage of qualified personnel. During the COVID-19 pandemic, STD programs were sacrificed in many health departments so their resources -- particularly staffers with much-needed contact tracing experience -- could be diverted to fighting the coronavirus.

One of the main roles of public health programs is messaging, getting the word out. Without staff and resources, awareness has been lacking. Cases of congenital syphilis had become so rare that many doctors no longer recognize the infection. "For many doctors who may have been training in the 1990s or early 2000s, they may not have seen syphilis," McDonald said. "They may not have learned that much about syphilis because it was on such a decline in the country."

Then there's the role of Medicaid, which covers almost half of all births in the United States. Rates of syphilis are 6 times higher among Medicaid participants compared with people covered by private insurance and twice as high compared with those who pay their own healthcare costs, according to a recent study by CDC. Although Medicaid requires that all pregnant women be tested for syphilis in their 1st trimester, state policies differ on repeat testing, in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy and at birth.

Even in states that have not expanded eligibility for Medicaid, lower-income pregnant women are usually covered for prenatal care and for at least 2 months after they give birth. But their male partners may not be. States that haven't expanded Medicaid don't cover childless adults who are not disabled, which may make it difficult for men to get primary care. So even if women are diagnosed and treated, their sex partners may not be, increasing the potential for reinfection during pregnancy.

Of 11 states that haven't expanded eligibility for Medicaid, 7 are in the South, the region that has also seen the biggest increases in congenital syphilis in recent years. The demographics of the infection have shifted, too. Once, syphilis was commonest among men who have sex with men, but recently, the infection has become commoner in heterosexual women and their partners.

It seems to be especially common in certain settings: for example, in situations where substance abuse and transactional sex may be involved. Women addicted to methamphetamine seem to be at particular risk. "We have noticed this in our practice, as well," said Dr Deepika Sankaran, a neonatologist and assistant professor at the University of California at Davis who co-authored a recent review on the increase (<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36712768/>). "Substance abuse, especially methamphetamine abuse and perinatal syphilis or syphilis in moms, goes hand-in-hand." That means many women who are at risk of getting syphilis and passing it on to their babies are in vulnerable situations and difficult for healthcare providers to reach.

This story is not unfamiliar to Sankaran, who noticed the same thing at the healthcare center where she works. Many times, she says, pregnant women at high risk for syphilis would come to the ER for care, but doctors there wouldn't think to check for the disease, which doesn't always have obvious symptoms. "A lot of times, these pregnant moms who may potentially have syphilis, that is the only point of contact. That is our only time we can actually diagnose them, test them and treat them," she said. Sankaran says she talked to colleagues in the ER and set up what amounts to a mini syphilis clinic in emergency department of Rideout Regional Medical Center, the community health center where she works in Marysville, California.

Now, she says, every pregnant woman who shows up in the emergency department gets a blood test to screen for syphilis. If it's positive, they get a shot of penicillin before they leave. "This injection with penicillin is very effective in treating perinatal syphilis and could be helpful in preventing congenital syphilis in the newborn," she said.

New Mexico, which has the 2nd-highest rate of congenital syphilis in the United States behind Arizona, has taken a similar approach. The state recently renewed a public health order issued in 2021 that deems all women in the state at high risk of syphilis infection. The order requires doctors to follow best practices outlined by CDC, which include testing all pregnant women for syphilis 3 times: once in the 1st trimester of pregnancy, again in the 3rd trimester and finally at delivery. It also requires doctors to test pregnant women seen in emergency rooms and urgent care centers.

[byline: Brenda Goodman and Deidre McPhillips]

--

column2:
SYPHILIS - USA (04): (IDAHO) CASES INCREASE, 2022-2023
******************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: Idaho News, CBS2 [edited]
<https://idahonews.com/news/local/cdh-declares-syphilis-outbreak-in-ada-boise-elmore-and-valley-counties>


Central District Health (CDH), Idaho, has declared an outbreak of syphilis in Public Health District 4, according to a recent news release. CDH says it identified 52 syphilis infections in Ada, Boise, Elmore, and Valley counties and reports 168 cases of syphilis infections since 1 Jan 2022 in persons aged 15 to 87. The number of reported cases of syphilis increased in 2022 and continues to grow in 2023.

"The rapid increase in syphilis infections highlights the need for heightened awareness of the potential for syphilis transmission among all ages and populations," says CDH staff epidemiologist Jessica McClenahan. "Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that can have serious health consequences if left undetected and untreated."

Symptoms of syphilis include sores, rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. Some people with syphilis experience no symptoms. If left untreated, syphilis can cause vision or hearing loss as well as other neurological complications.

CDH adds that pregnant individuals should consider the risk of congenital syphilis: when a pregnant person with syphilis passes the infection to the unborn baby. Congenital syphilis can result in stillbirth, early infant death, or long-term health problems for the child. Pregnant individuals should be screened for syphilis at their first prenatal appointment and potentially again before delivery.

CDH recommends safer sexual practices, regular testing for STIs, and rapid treatment for infection as important parts of maintaining overall health and well-being. More information about risk reduction strategies is available from your medical providers or at <https://www.cdc.gov/std/prevention/>.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[For a discussion of syphilis in the USA, please see my moderator comments in ProMED post Syphilis - USA (12): (AL) congenital, increasing cases, RFI 20220922.8705732.

Idaho is a state in the Pacific Northwest region of the Western United States. Located between Washington State and Oregon to the west and Montana and Wyoming to the east; the state's capital and largest city is Boise (population, about 1.8 million residents) (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idaho>). Ada, Elmore, and Valley counties surround Boise county in the center of the state; a map showing the location of Idaho counties can be found at <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_counties_in_Idaho>. - Mod.ML]

column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - INDONESIA (02): FATAL, FLOODS
*********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023 23:17:45 WIB
Source: Xinhua News Agency [edited]
<https://english.news.cn/asiapacific/20230302/7372dc46acd54f1fbab56f0bb0f394e9/c.html>


At least 32 people have died from leptospirosis in Indonesia from January to early March 2023, the Health Ministry said on Thursday [2 Mar 2023]. These death cases were reported in Central Java (18), Yogyakarta (12), and West Java (2).

"Leptospirosis bacteria spread more readily during the rainy season, which leads to flooding or inundation in many areas," Health Ministry spokesperson Siti Nadia Tarmizi told Xinhua.

Out of 1408 cases, 139 leptospirosis deaths were reported in the country last year [2022].

--
