column3: At least 32 people have died from leptospirosis in Indonesia from January to early March 2023, the Health Ministry said on Thursday [2 Mar 2023]. These death cases were reported in Central Java (18), Yogyakarta (12), and West Java (2)."Leptospirosis bacteria spread more readily during the rainy season, which leads to flooding or inundation in many areas," Health Ministry spokesperson Siti Nadia Tarmizi told Xinhua.Out of 1408 cases, 139 leptospirosis deaths were reported in the country last year [2022].--communicated by:ProMED[For a discussion of leptospirosis, please see my moderator comments in ProMED post (Leptospirosis - Indonesia: (YO) rain, fatal 20220621.8703994). - Mod.MLProMED map:Indonesia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708708,184>]

column2:
INFECTIOUS SALMON ANEMIA - CHILE: (MAGALLANES AND CHILEAN ANTARCTICA) SUSPECTED
*******************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023 14:09 GMT
Source: IntraFish [edited]
<https://www.intrafish.com/salmon/isa-outbreak-suspected-at-aquachile-salmon-farm/2-1-1412504> [subscription required]


A suspected infectious salmon anemia (ISA) outbreak is being monitored at a salmon farm operated by Chile's largest producer AquaChile in the South American nation's southern Magallanes region.

The [Punta] Entrada production site holds 766 402 Atlantic salmon in 9 cages with an average weight of 1.1 kilos (2.4lbs), representing a total biomass of just over 861 metric tonnes (949 imperial tons), Chile's National Fisheries and AquaCulture service (Sernapesca) reported.

Sernapesca officials were notified of the suspected outbreak on 28 Feb 2023, and plan to enter the site as soon as the weather conditions allow to take samples from cages.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[ISA is a disease of Atlantic salmon (_Salmo salar_) caused by an orthomyxovirus and affects mainly fish maintained in marine water or exposed to the sea. The disease is systemic and lethal, characterized by severe anemia and hemorrhages in several organs. It is a disease with a great economic impact on the salmon industry. The disease is of obligatory notification to the WOAH. - Mod.PMB

column2:
NIPAH VIRUS - BANGLADESH  (08): (RAJSHAHI)
******************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023 4:48 AM BST
Source: Dhaka Tribune [edited]
<https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2023/03/02/one-dies-of-nipah-virus-in-rajshahi>


One woman died of Nipah virus in Rajshahi Medical College Hospital (RMCH) on Wednesday afternoon [1 Mar 2023]. The deceased, aged 25, was admitted to the neuro medicine ward of RMCH with common symptoms like fever and seizures. Complications escalated after she was diagnosed with Nipah virus on Wednesday morning [1 Mar 2023] and was eventually referred to Nipah intensive care unit. She died around 5 pm while undergoing treatment.

Her mother-in-law [has been] admitted [to] the Nipah Suspect Ward with the same symptoms, [and her] father-in-law died at home with the same symptoms 2 weeks ago.

Although the family thinks it was a natural death, doctors believe that her father-in-law was also infected with Nipah virus. It has been reported that their entire family consumes date juice without boiling it, a common cause of the spread of this disease.

Dr Azizul Haque, medicine specialist at Rajshahi Medical College Hospital, said: "Relatives of deceased patients are at higher risk of infection. So, they need to be extra careful. We are working in coordination with IEDCR." He urged people to be careful while drinking date juice.

However, Rajshahi civil surgeon Dr Abu Yusuf Mohammad Farooq said that there is no need for regular care of the patient's relatives. The IECCR has collected and tested the samples of everyone who came in contact with the infected patient. However, everyone should be careful while drinking date juice.

A total of 5 people have died in Rajshahi Medical College Hospital (RMCH) so far. All of them have a history of drinking date palm juice. Besides, everyone was admitted to the general ward of the hospital with common symptoms like jaundice. Then suddenly the physical condition started to deteriorate. The death occurred on admission to the ICU. Nipah [infection] of one of the deceased was identified after death.

[byline: Abdullah Al Dulal]

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[This may have been a familial cluster of Nipah virus infections. The young woman was a diagnosed case and her mother-in law and father-in-law were suspected cases but not confirmed. All had a history of consuming raw (uncooked) date palm sap, the likely source of the virus. However, person to person transmission can occur and cannot be ruled out in this situation.

The previous ProMED post provides more details on cases so far this year (2023) than were in the previous ProMED posts. It also provides an overview of Nipah virus epidemiology and clinical considerations (see Nipah virus - Bangladesh (07): WHO, overview and details 20230218.8708466). - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Rajshahi Division, Bangladesh: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708701,10080>]

column2:
FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - JORDAN (12): CATTLE, SEROTYPE SAT-2, CONTROL, ECONOMICS
******************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Economic losses
[2] Official statement

******
[1] Economic losses: dairy industry 
Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
Source: Roya News [in Arabic, machine trans., abridged, edited] 
<https://royanews.tv/news/295485>


The minister of agriculture, Eng Khaled Al-Hanifat, confirmed that the local milk production has now recovered, after the decrease in the quantities of milk resulting from the effects of foot and mouth disease [FMD]. Al-Hanifat expects regular production of cow milk in the coming months, to meet market needs.

Al-Hanifat chaired a coordination meeting on Tuesday [28 Feb 2023]  to study the decrease in the quantities of milk resulting from the effects of FMD, which affected the dairy manufacturing sector and caused some decrease in quantities, according to information from manufacturers. Such decrease may affect the availability of the product during the coming weeks, especially for the holy month of Ramadan [2023]. The meeting was attended by representatives/directors of several related agencies, such as the Food and Drug Administration, the Ministry of Industry and Trade, the Amman Chamber of Industry, the Institution for Standards and Metrology, and a number of dairy companies.

The participants discussed the possibility of using limited quantities of powdered milk to cover the needs of the market and a temporary amendment of the specification for some products in the event of a future market need. 

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[According to an earlier (19 Feb 2023, <https://royanews.tv/news/294822>) media report, dairy cattle farms in Jordan produce 400 tons (363 tonnes) of milk daily. This amount was normal before the spread of FMD, which reduced the volume of production to 250 tons (227 tonnes), a loss rate of 30% due to the disease. According to Ali Ghabayen, head of the Cattle Breeders Association, more than 90% of cow farms in Jordan were affected by FMD. According to him, the total losses of cow farms across the Kingdom were about 35 million dinars (about USD 49.3 million). This is composed mainly of the milk production losses and the death of more than 1350 head of cows and calves. Farms in Al Halabat and Al Dhelil constitute 60% of the total milk produced in Jordan, distributed to dairy and cheese factories. As a result of the disease, the production rate decreased by half. - Mod.AS]

******
[2] Official statement: event resolved
Date: Sun 26 Feb 2023
Source: Roya News [in Arabic, machine trans., edited]
<https://royanews.tv/news/295279>


The Ministry of Agriculture has published the daily foot and mouth disease report, noting the results of the work based on the actions taken by the working committee. The statement, a copy of which was received by Roya, stated that, based on the measures taken by the committees working within the FMD file, the results of the work were as follows: 

1st: The infection index decreased to zero for 2 days in a row in the focus of infection, with the spread stopping outside the affected farms.

2nd: The continued recovery in the quantities of milk within the focus of infection, with a noticeable and continuous increase, confirming the availability of appropriate quantities for manufacturing.

3rd: The end of the work of the Committee for the Inventory of Damage related to Mortality in the field, as of this evening, Sunday [26 Feb 2023], and considering today [26 Feb 2023] as the last day to receive the forms, with the continuation of audit and analysis procedures.

4th: The results of the report issued by the committee formed by the Animal Health Organization, which included Italian experts and headed by the Regional Director of the Animal Health Organization, are as follows:
- The new strain of SAT2 virus is genetically identical to the strain currently present in Iraq, and it may have been transmitted by several means, including fodder that was imported exclusively for the Cattle Breeders Association.

5th: It was decided to open livestock markets in all governorates of the Kingdom, with the exception of Zarqa and Mafraq, as of Monday morning [27 Feb 2023], for the trade of sheep and goats, with the exception of the trading of cows and calves.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Following the publication of the above statement by Jordan's Ministry of Agriculture, declaring the FMDV SAT-2 event resolved, Jordan's Veterinarian Association submitted, on 27 Feb 2023, its response "on the reality of FMD in Jordan". The statement, published in the Al Ghad newspaper on the same date, is available (in Arabic) at <https://tinyurl.com/2p9f344p>. 

Among several issues raised by the syndicate, we present here the following (summarised) 3 issues: 
1. The syndicate argues that disease, death and losses are continuing according to the observation of practitioners in the field.

2. The feed from Iraq, referred to by the ministry as one of the possible means of virus introduction, was -- according to the syndicate's information -- not imported specifically for the Cattle Breeders Association (limiting infection to the dairy cattle cluster in the Dhlail region, Zarqa), but was sold to all farms in the Kingdom.

3. The origin, route of introduction, and chronology of the event should be clarified. To this end, they request the publication of the full genotyping report(s) from the labs allowing assessment of virus history, chronology, and geography.

Jordan's News Agency (Petra), published on 5 Feb 2023 that the results of the FMD virus analysis at the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine/University of Science and Technology, Irbid, revealed the emergence of a new strain of the virus called SAT-2, "which was not previously registered in Jordan." The ministry added in a statement that this strain was registered in Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and Ethiopia, indicating that "the results of the analysis were verified by Pirbright" (<https://tinyurl.com/28ax5vuv>).

So far, FMDV SAT-2 is not available among the "samples tested" reports presented on Jordan's page of the WRLFMD at Pirbright (<https://www.wrlfmd.org/western-and-central-asia/jordan#panel-9742>). Notably, the reference laboratory publishes results only after obtaining the consent of the relevant country to do so.

Similarly, the results of FMDV SAT-2 samples from Iraq are not (yet) presented on Iraq's page (<https://www.wrlfmd.org/western-and-central-asia/iraq#panel-7312>). Iraq reported 9 new outbreaks on 26 Feb 2023, spread throughout the country (follow-up-report No 5). - Mod.AS

column2:
AFRICAN SWINE FEVER - ASIA (06): BHUTAN (DAGANA) DOMESTIC, WOAH
***************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4940>


Bhutan, African swine fever virus [ASFV]
----------------------------------------
General information
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 18 Feb 2023
Confirmed: 25 Feb 2023
Reported: 2 Mar 2023
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 17 Feb 2023
Manifestation of disease: clinical disease
Causal agent: African swine fever virus
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Doragaon, Loongsilsa, Lhamoizingkha, Dagana
Date of start of the outbreak: 18 Feb 2023
Epidemiological unit: village
Affected animals
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use 
Swine / 58 / 6 / 6 / 5 / 0 

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: swill feeding, fomites (humans, vehicles, feed, etc.), illegal movement of animals.

Control measures at event level
Domestic control measures applied: selective killing and disposal; surveillance within the restricted zone; surveillance outside the restricted zone; zoning; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; movement control; disinfection.

Wild control measures applied: surveillance outside the restricted zone.

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result
National Centre for Animal Health (NCAH), Serbithang / swine / real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 25 Feb 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[The latest updated report on "ASF situation in Asia and Pacific update," published by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations on 16 Feb 2023, mentioned that since the 1st ASF outbreak occurred in May 2021 in Phuentsholing, Chhukha District, Bhutan, ASF outbreaks have been reported in southern parts of the country, in April 2022 in Samphelling, Chhukha District, in November 2022 in Samdrup Jongkhar and Sarpang districts, and in December 2022 in Sarpang District. A new outbreak in Bhur, Sarpang District was reported on 15 Jan 2023. (<https://www.fao.org/animal-health/situation-updates/asf-in-asia-pacific/en>). - Mod.CRD

Bhutan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708697,154>]

column2:
ADENOVIRUS - INDIA (03): (WEST BENGAL) FATAL
********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] West Bengal: no evidence of viral epidemic
[2] Kolkata and Bankura: pediatric fatalities
[3] Kolkata: co-morbidities

******
[1] West Bengal: no evidence of viral epidemic
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: The Hindu [edited]
<https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/12-deaths-due-to-adenovirus-infection-no-evidence-of-viral-epidemic-says-west-bengal-government/article66570737.ece>


Observing that there was no evidence of a viral epidemic at present, the West Bengal government has stated that there were only 12 deaths in government hospitals due to adenovirus infection. "There were only 12 deaths in government hospitals due to adenovirus and out of the same 8 cases were having severe comorbidities," its press statement said.

The statement by the state government comes after several deaths of children due to adenovirus infection were reported in hospitals of Kolkata and district. On 1 Mar 2023, the state's health secretary Narayan Swarup Nigam visited different state-run hospitals in Kolkata. "There is no evidence of a viral epidemic at present. The current situation is nothing but a seasonal surge and the number of infections due to adenovirus have already started coming down. This infection can affect any age group, but younger children with comorbidities like congenital heart disease, severe malnutrition, etc. are at a higher risk requiring medical attention," the statement issued on Wednesday evening [1 Mar 2023] pointed out.

According to the state government, 5213 cases of acute respiratory infection (ARI) were reported in the state in the past month. The current situation is nothing but a seasonal surge and the number of infections due to adenovirus have already started coming down, the government said. Family members of children suffering from ARI have complained about lack of beds in government hospitals.

"There are more than 5000 beds in 121 hospitals in the state having facilities for management of paediatric ARI, with 600 paediatricians in position. There are 2476 SNCU (sick newborn care units) beds, 654 PICU [pediatric intensive care unit] beds and 120 NICU [neonatal intensive care unit] beds across the State. Number of beds dedicated to attend paediatric ARI are further being increased as per the situation," the press statement said.

The state health department has circulated a standard case management guideline to all medical establishments and control rooms have been set up to monitor the situation on a round the clock basis.

[byline: Shiv Sahay Singh]

--
communicated by:
ProMED via ProMED-SOAS

******
[2] Kolkata and Bankura: pediatric fatalities
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: The New Indian Express [edited]
<https://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/2023/mar/02/kolkata-adenovirus-claims-lives-of-10-children-in-48hours-2552184.html>


A total of 10 children -- newborn to 3 years old -- with symptoms of adenovirus infection died in the past 48 hours at hospitals in Kolkata and Bankura. With this, the number of deaths due to the virus-borne [sic: "viral" would be the correct adjective. - Mod.SH] disease in Bengal has gone up to 45 in the past 2 months.

Following this, the state health department has issued advisories ensuring the presence of pediatricians in government hospitals round-the-clock. A helpline number has been announced. People can call the round-the-clock helpline number for admission-related and other inquiries.

On Wednesday [1 Mar 2023], 4 children died in Kolkata's 2 hospitals and 2 others in Bankura Medical College and Hospital.

Flooded with children coming from districts, the state health department advised that no child with a respiratory ailment can be referred to a hospital in Kolkata without ensuring that a bed is booked at the destination healthcare facility. The referral, if needed, must be done with the knowledge of the superintendent of the hospital.

The state government asked all medical colleges, district hospitals, sub-divisional hospitals and state general hospitals across Bengal to run separate clinics for children with an acute respiratory infection (ARI) in the paediatric outpatient department [OPD]. The special clinics will be meant for those with respiratory illnesses so they do not have to wait in the OPD queue with other patients.

A doctor at a hospital said the current spate of viral attacks was causing immune dysregulation which disrupts the normal immune system and makes children vulnerable to reinfection. "The inflammatory process that is being triggered inside the body to kill live viruses is creating some problems which we call dysregulated immunity. The initiation of the inflammatory process is helping the child recover from the initial infection but leads to some other problems. We have noticed that some children are falling sick again after being discharged from the hospital. We have asked experts to examine the reason behind it,'' said an official of the health department.

[byline: Pronab Mondal]

--
communicated by:
ProMED-SoAs

******
[3] Kolkata: co-morbidities
Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: The Hindu [edited]
<https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/kolkata/childrens-deaths-in-kolkata-hospitals-spark-fears-of-adenovirus-outbreak/article66567906.ece>


Four children died due to respiratory infections at different hospitals in Kolkata within 24 hours on Wednesday [1 Mar 2023], amidst fears of an adenovirus outbreak. Two deaths were reported at the Dr B C Roy Post Graduate Institute of Paediatric Sciences while 2 deaths were reported at the Calcutta National Medical College and Hospital (MCH). This comes a day after the deaths of 5 children were reported across hospitals in Kolkata.

As the number of children with respiratory distress is rising in the hospitals across West Bengal's capital and adjoining districts, the state's health secretary Narayan Swarup Nigam visited hospitals in the city and announced that the number paediatric beds would be augmented. However, he added that most of the children who died had been suffering from "co-morbidities".

"Several of these cases had co-morbidities. These are children who are born underweight or had heart related issues," Mr Nigam said. The health secretary said that he had held discussions with hospital authorities and doctors, who were confident about the treatment and infrastructure available. The official also added that district hospitals would have to speak to the superintendent of the medical college and hospitals for referral of patients.

A father whose child died at the B C Roy Hospital alleged that 3 children were put on a single bed at the hospital and added that the authorities had misbehaved with him. On Tuesday [28 Feb 2023], the West Bengal Health Department said, "All paediatric acute respiratory infection (ARI) clinics will operate at the medical college and hospitals (MCHs), district hospitals and sub-divisional hospitals, among others, round the clock... No paediatric ARI cases shall be referred without the knowledge of the concerned MSVP/Superintendent of the hospital."

There are reports of the deaths of children due to respiratory distress in the districts, where hospitals are also struggling with influx of patients. Five paediatric hubs -- B C Roy Post Graduate Institute of Paediatric Sciences, Calcutta National MCH , North Bengal MCH, Bankura Sammilani MCH and Malda MCH, which were prepared to deal with such situations during the pandemic -- will supervise the multiple secondary hospitals.

Adenoviruses can cause a wide range of illnesses including common cold or flu-like symptoms. People with weakened immune systems, particularly children, are at higher risk.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[As noted in our earlier report, Adenovirus types 3 and 7 were both found circulating in the area and are associated with respiratory disease, with type 7 in particular causing more severe disease outcomes. Co-morbidities only increase the risk. The 3 reports above also paint a somewhat contrasting picture in that case counts may be going down from their seasonal highs, yet hospitals are still seeing large numbers of acute respiratory illnesses. One wonders if this is being compounded by co-circulation of other respiratory pathogens like seasonal influenza, respiratory syncytial virus, and/or COVID-19 (similar to the "tripledemic" that hit large parts of the US in the fall of 2022). - Mod.JH

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (09): CHINA (JIANGSU) H5N1
*************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: BNO News [abridged, edited]
<https://bnonews.com/index.php/2023/03/china-reports-human-case-h5n1-bird-flu/>


A woman in eastern China has tested positive for [Influenza A] H5N1 bird flu, the strain of avian influenza which has spread around the world and worried experts. The news comes just a week after 2 people in Cambodia were infected with a similar variant.

The latest case is a 53 year old woman from Jiangsu province in eastern China, according to WHO. She developed symptoms on 31 Jan 2023 after exposure to poultry. Details about her condition have not been released.

Genetic sequencing carried out in China showed that the new case was caused by clade 2.3.4.4b, the same variant which has spread around the world and raised concern about a possible threat to human health. This sets it apart from the cases in Cambodia, which were caused by clade 2.3.2.1c, an older variant.

The new variant of H5N1, which emerged in late 2021, has caused outbreaks around the world, even in countries where bird flu had never been found. Since then, more than 200 million birds have either died or been culled, most of them in Europe and the US. The global spread of bird flu has raised concern about the possibility of a future variant which could lead to human-to-human transmission. Recent cases in mammals -- including in mink, foxes and sea lions -- have added to those concerns.

"The global H5N1 situation is worrying given the wide spread of the virus in birds around the world and the increasing reports of cases in mammals, including in humans," Dr Sylvie Briand, a WHO official, said on Friday [24 Feb 2023]. "WHO takes the risk from this virus seriously and urges heightened vigilance from all countries."

The World Organization for Animal Health (WOAH) echoed those concerns. "The current situation highlights the risk that H5N1 avian influenza may become better adapted to mammals and spill over to humans and other animals," the agency said on 13 Feb 2023. "Some animals, such as mink, may act as mixing vessels for different influenza viruses, leading to the emergence of new strains and subtypes that could be more harmful to animals and/or humans."

A 9 year old girl in Ecuador tested positive for H5N1 bird flu in January 2023, making it the 1st such case in South America. She was hospitalized in critical condition but has since recovered. In September 2022, a 38 year old woman died of H5N1 in China's Guangxi after exposure to backyard poultry.

--
communicated by:
Ryan McGinnis
<Ryan@digicana.com>

[This adds yet another case to the slow trickle of human avian influenza cases across the globe. As noted in yesterday's H5N6 update (20230302.8708673) the FluTracker website has a more exhaustive list of human avian influenza cases. As with virtually all of the human avian influenza cases of late, the primary factor is close contact with poultry and/or wild birds. Mitigating spillover to humans will require a multi-faceted approach and is only compounded in difficulty by the sheer number of global avian influenza infections we've seen in the past few months across a multitude of species. - Mod.JH

column2:
EQUINE HERPESVIRUS - NORTH AMERICA (01): CANADA, USA, HORSE
***********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this post:
Canada
[1] Ontario (Simcoe County) 
USA
[2] Montana (Flathead County)
[3] Texas (Hood County)
[4] Arizona (Maricopa County)
[5] Idaho (Gem County)
 
******
Canada
[1] Ontario (Simcoe County) 
Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: The Horse [edited]
<https://thehorse.com/1121368/ehv-1-in-ontario-boarding-barn/>


EHV-1 in Ontario boarding barn
------------------------------
A 21 year old mare in Simcoe County, Ontario, is positive for EHV-1. The mare developed mild ataxia on 22 Feb 2023. The day before [21 Feb 2023], a paddock mate developed signs of vestibular disease, including head tilt, nystagmus and ataxia, as well as urinary incontinence. Both horses were referred to an equine hospital on 22 Feb 2023. Test results for the horse with vestibular disease are still pending, but EHV-1 is suspected to be the cause. The horses are affected and alive.

The horses reside at a boarding facility, where 38 horses are now exposed. The facility owner has implemented voluntary movement restrictions and biosecurity measures under the supervision of the attending veterinarian.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

******
USA
[2] Montana (Flathead county)
Date: Thu 2 Feb 2023
Source: The Horse [edited]
<https://thehorse.com/1120239/ehm-outbreak-in-montana/>


EHM outbreak in Montana
-----------------------
Three horses in Flathead County, Montana, tested positive for equine herpesvirus myeloencephalopathy (EHM), and 2 additional cases are suspected. The horses are spread across 3 different barns and developed neurological signs. So far, 4 of the confirmed and suspected cases have been euthanized due to the severity of disease. The 5th is displaying mild clinical signs and is under quarantine. Exposed horses from the affected premises are also subject to quarantine for 21 days beyond the last date of potential exposure.

Several of the affected horses had no travel history. However, herd mates, who are not displaying clinical signs, had attended events at 2 or more event centers in the area where they were exposed. Those horses are likely contributing to the disease spread at their home locations and other equine events.

Now, the Montana Department of Livestock is recommending horse owners and event coordinators in the Flathead Valley limit travel and cancel events bringing horses from multiple sources together through 6 Feb 2023. If additional cases are detected, this date will be extended.

Horse owners who have attended events in the Flathead Valley in recent weeks should monitor their animals for fever or development of neurological signs for 2 weeks after their last travel.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

******
[3] Texas (Hood County)
Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<http://outbreaknewstoday.com/texas-equine-herpes-virus-confirmed-in-hood-county-horse-65279/>


Texas: equine herpes virus confirmed in Hood County horse
---------------------------------------------------------
The Texas Animal Health Commission (TAHC) received confirmation of equine herpes myeloencephalopathy (EHM), the neurologic disease linked to equine herpes virus (EHV-1), in a Hood County Quarter Horse on 9 Feb 2023. This is the 1st positive detection of EHM in Texas this year [2023].

The horse was tested after showing neurologic signs, including poor muscle control in the hind limbs. The local veterinary clinic immediately placed the horse in an isolated quarantine where it remains throughout treatment. The premises of origin has been quarantined and TAHC staff are working closely with the owner and local veterinarian to monitor other horses and enforce biosecurity measures on the premises.
 
The EHM positive horse attended the National Western Stock Show rodeo event in Denver, Colorado on 20 to 21 Jan 2023, and returned to its premises of origin following the event. The horse has not visited any other events which would expose additional equine. The Colorado State Veterinarian was contacted about this case.

Owners of horses attending the event should work with their veterinary practitioner to establish appropriate monitoring and diagnostic plans and are encouraged to take the following precautions: 
- Clean and disinfect tack, boots, equipment, and grooming supplies.
- When you return to your farm, isolate the horses having attended the event for at least 2 weeks.
- Have their temperatures monitored twice daily for at least 14 days after last known exposure. If a fever or other signs consistent with EHM develop, contact your veterinarian.
- When doing feeding and chores, work with the returning horses last, wear boots and coveralls, and remove them before working with your other horses.
- Don't forget to wash your hands.
 
EHM is a neurologic disease of horses linked to the equine herpes virus. Clinical signs of EHM in horses may include: fever of 102°F [38.89 deg C] or greater (fever most often comes before neurologic signs), nasal discharge, lack of coordination, hindquarter weakness, leaning or resting against a fence or wall to maintain balance, lethargy, urine dribbling, head tilt, diminished tail tone, and penile paralysis.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

******
[4] Arizona (Maricopa County)
Date: Fri 24 Feb 2023
Source: Equus Magazine [edited]
<https://equusmagazine.com/news/eq-edcc-health-watch/ehv-1-confirmed-at-turf-paradise-racetrack/>


EHV-1 confirmed at Turf Paradise racetrack
------------------------------------------
A 14 year old thoroughbred gelding at the Turf Paradise racetrack in Maricopa County, Arizona, has tested positive for EHV-1 variant D752. The horse developed clinical signs on 14 Feb 2023 including hindlimb ataxia, weakness, difficulty rising and difficulty maintaining a standing posture. His positive test results were reported on 18 Feb 2023. The horse is now recovering.

Thirty-six horses from Barns C9 and C8W were immediately placed under quarantine. Turf Paradise has restricted movement from the backside until further notice. Biosecurity measures have been implemented for all horses in the quarantined barns, including twice-daily temperature monitoring, movement restriction and area disinfection.

A 4 year old racehorse filly from Barn K6 also developed clinical signs, including depressed attitude, fever and leaning on the stall wall. The filly had raced on 18 Feb 2023 and was claimed from barn D9. She was referred to an equine hospital in the Phoenix area. Barns K6 and K5E were also placed under quarantine, but the filly's test results came back negative for EHV-1.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

******
[5] Idaho (Gem County)
Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: Equus Magazine [edited]
<https://equusmagazine.com/news/eq-edcc-health-watch/idaho-horse-aborts-pregnancy-due-to-ehv-1/>


Idaho horse aborts pregnancy due to EHV-1
-----------------------------------------
A mare at a private facility in Gem County, Idaho, aborted a pregnancy in late February [2023]. On 27 Feb 2023 it was confirmed the abortion was caused by EHV-1 (wild-type) infection, despite all horses on the property being current on all recommended vaccinations.

In recent weeks, several other mares on the property also gave birth to weak foals or experienced unexpected pregnancy loss. EHV-1 diagnosis has not been confirmed in these horses. None of the horses on the property have left or arrived at the premises recently.

In total, 6 horses are suspected positive for EHV-1, and 25 horses are exposed. The affected horses are under voluntary quarantine.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[The vaccine for EHV-1 does tend to decrease the severity of the neurological signs, but thus far there is no vaccine preventing the neurological form of the disease.

Horse owners are encouraged to vaccinate their animals against EHV and use other core vaccines, such as those for eastern and western equine encephalitis (EEE, WEE), West Nile virus (WNV), tetanus, and rabies. Most of these are annual vaccines, except EEE, which needs revaccination approximately every 3-4 months in areas where the disease is prevalent.

See ProMED post Equine herpesvirus - North America (03): USA, horse 20220309.8701891 for comprehensive information about equine herpesvirus from the American Association of Equine Practitioners (also available at <https://aaep.org/risk-based-vaccination-guidelines/equine-herpesvirus-rhinopneumonitis>). - Mod.TG

ProMED maps:
Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708693,12>
United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708693,106>]

column3: Idaho horse aborts pregnancy due to EHV-1-----------------------------------------A mare at a private facility in Gem County, Idaho, aborted a pregnancy in late February [2023]. On 27 Feb 2023 it was confirmed the abortion was caused by EHV-1 (wild-type) infection, despite all horses on the property being current on all recommended vaccinations.In recent weeks, several other mares on the property also gave birth to weak foals or experienced unexpected pregnancy loss. EHV-1 diagnosis has not been confirmed in these horses. None of the horses on the property have left or arrived at the premises recently.In total, 6 horses are suspected positive for EHV-1, and 25 horses are exposed. The affected horses are under voluntary quarantine.--communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts[The vaccine for EHV-1 does tend to decrease the severity of the neurological signs, but thus far there is no vaccine preventing the neurological form of the disease.Horse owners are encouraged to vaccinate their animals against EHV and use other core vaccines, such as those for eastern and western equine encephalitis (EEE, WEE), West Nile virus (WNV), tetanus, and rabies. Most of these are annual vaccines, except EEE, which needs revaccination approximately every 3-4 months in areas where the disease is prevalent.See ProMED post Equine herpesvirus - North America (03): USA, horse 20220309.8701891 for comprehensive information about equine herpesvirus from the American Association of Equine Practitioners (also available at <https://aaep.org/risk-based-vaccination-guidelines/equine-herpesvirus-rhinopneumonitis>). - Mod.TGProMED maps:Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708693,12>United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708693,106>]

[A 13 Dec 2022 report indicated that India had 23 confirmed mpox cases up to 8 Dec 2022 (<https://www.udayavani.com/english-news/23-monkeypox-cases-reported-in-india-till-dec-8-this-year-mos-for-health-bharati-pravin-pawar>). The 23 case total is not yet reflected in the report above. - Mod.TY

Since the last published report there has been a total of 305 new cases and 9 new deaths. The majority of these cases seem to be coming from Central and South America, making up 230 of the newly reported cases worldwide. However, when looking at the number of deaths, the USA contributes 6 of the 9 total reported mpox deaths this week. Further research could be done to look at the factors that contributed to these patient deaths. Multiple studies have shown that those with AIDS or other immune disorders are most susceptible, but understanding what other factors are contributing to severe mpox outcomes would be extremely useful to ensure those at highest risk are aggressively screened and treated. - Mods.CS/JH]

[3] Taiwan: First two cases of locally acquired mpox
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023
Source: Taipei Times [abridged, edited]
<https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2023/03/02/2003795310>


First two cases of locally acquired mpox reported
------------------------------------------------
KAOHSIUNG, HSINCHU: Taiwan's first two cases of locally acquired mpox (formerly known as monkeypox) were reported yesterday (Wed 1 Mar 2023 )as the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) warned that the risk of local infection has increased. CDC Epidemic Intelligence Center deputy director Guo Hung-wei said the two cases are a man in his 40s in Hsinchu and a man in his 20s in Kaohsiung. They had symptoms including a fever, papules, blisters and swollen lymph nodes, and were diagnosed with mpox on Sunday and Monday, Guo said.

Neither man had traveled abroad recently, so they have been counted as local cases, Guo said, adding that since June 23 last year, when mpox was made a Category 2 notifiable communicable disease, seven cases have been reported, with the previous five cases being imported.
The global mpox situation has been slowing, with World Health Organization's analysis of recent cases showing that the majority were young men, with 68.8 per cent of transmission occurring through sexual contact.

WHO on 15 Feb 2023 said that mpox would remain a "public health emergency of international concern". In November last year WHO said that following "a series of consultations with global experts, WHO will begin using a new preferred term 'mpox' as a synonym for monkeypox" and that "both names will be used simultaneously for one year while 'monkeypox' is phased out".

CDC deputy director-general Philip Lo said that no connections had been found between the two local cases and 25 close contacts had been identified, including four family members and two intimate contacts. The condition of the two men would be monitored until 20 March 2023, Lo said.

CDC Division of Chronic Diseases head Chan Pei-chun said that mpox is a viral zoonotic disease that has become more transmissible among humans than avian flu. It is mainly spread through intimate contact with an infected person through bodily fluids, respiratory droplets, lesions or contaminated objects, Chan said. Rashes often start on the face or genital area and can spread to other parts of the body, with phases including spots, blisters and scabbing, she said. People with suspected mpox symptoms should wear a mask and wash their hands before seeking medical attention, she said, adding that they should inform their doctor about their recent travel history and contact with suspected cases. As local cases have been reported, people should take extra precautions in high-risk locations, such as where they might have intimate contact with unfamiliar people.

Asian nations, including Japan and Thailand, have also recently reported local mpox cases, suggesting that a rise in international travel as COVID-19 restrictions have been eased globally has allowed mpox to spread more easily across borders, Lo said. The CDC would convene an expert panel to discuss a program of pre-exposure mpox vaccination and communicate with civic groups about prevention among high-risk groups.

Speaking on other health matters, Guo said that cases of infectious diseases reported last week included four new serious flu complications and a high level of diarrhea cases, while enterovirus cases are expected to gradually increase.

(byline: Lee I-chia)

--
communicated by:
ProMED rapporteur Angela Song-En Huang

******
[4] South Korea: occupational transmission to healthcare workers
Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) [abridged, edited]
<https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/29/5/23-0028_article>


ref: Choi Y, Jeon E-b, Kim T, et al. Case report and literature review of occupational transmission of monkeypox virus to healthcare workers, South Korea. Emerg Infect Dis. May 2023
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
--------
We report a case of occupational mpox virus infection from a needlestick injury in a healthcare worker in South Korea and review similar reports in the literature during 2022. Postexposure prophylactic treatment with a 3rd-generation smallpox vaccine and antiviral agent tecovirimat inhibited local virus spread and alleviated lesion pain.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[This case report demonstrates the usefulness and efficacy of immediate post-exposure treatment in situations with high risk for mpox infection. Providers should provide antiviral therapy as well as post-exposure vaccination to patients to help mitigate the progression of symptoms and improve patient comfort/disease outcomes. - Mods.CS/JH]

******
[5] Longitudinal mpox virus surface sampling
Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023
Source: The Journal of Hospital Infection [edited]
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhin.2023.02.007>


We read with interest the report from Mellon [and colleagues] regarding air sampling for mpox (formerly monkeypox) virus (MPXV) in an outpatient setting and the need for additional data to assess the risk to healthcare workers (HCWs). In August 2022, we performed longitudinal surface sampling at a large sexual health clinic in London, UK, to investigate environmental contamination of a typical outpatient setting where patients with mpox are assessed. During the 4-week period of observation, a total of 85 patients were seen at the clinic that were subsequently diagnosed with mpox based on samples collected during their visit (number of patients confirmed positive seen in 7 days prior sampling: Week 1 = 31 cases, Week 2 = 26 cases, Week 3 = 22 cases, Week 4 = 6 cases). Weekly sampling was performed in the same observation room using Copan UTM swabs with qPCR analysis performed as previously described. Samples were collected from the same 8 locations each week: HCW desk, HCW keyboard, patient chair armrest, floor beneath patient chair, desk between patient and HCW, wall next to examination table (approximately where the patient head will be facing during examination), floor beneath examination table, and the door handle to exit the examination room.

qPCR analysis of the 32 samples collected (8 samples collected weekly for 4 weeks) resulted in only 3 MPXV positive samples all with crossing threshold (Ct) values near the limit of detection for the assay, indicating occasional low-level contamination of the sampled environment. All 3 positive samples were collected from the floor of the examination room; viral isolation using previously described methods detected replicating virus in one sample collected from the floor beneath the examination table (week 2) confirming the presence of infection-competent MPXV in this sample.

Two of the 3 positive samples were identified in the same location on consecutive weeks raising the possibility of duplicate identification. While our data cannot exclude this possibility, surfaces were thoroughly cleaned using disinfectant wipes (Spill Wipes, Clinell) and the floor cleaned with chlorine solution (Chlor-clean, Guest Medical) after each examination of a suspected mpox case, in addition to routine cleaning performed at the end of every working day.

Despite a significant potential for mpox transmission in healthcare settings, few cases of mpox have been reported in HCWs with just 5 cases recorded by WHO as occupational exposures in Europe through January 2023. Infection prevention and control (IPC) measures including the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) may explain, in part, the very small number of occupationally associated infections reported. The PPE recommended for typical UK outpatient consultations (gloves, fluid-repellent surgical mask, apron, and eye protection if splash risk) is simpler than the recommended PPE for UK HCWs caring for patients with mpox admitted to hospital (gloves, fit-tested FFP3 respirator, long-sleeved fluid-repellent gown, eye protection). ... At present, infectious virus has not been detected in air samples and the risk of establishing human mpox infection via the respiratory route is unknown. The absence of numerous cases in HCWs working in outpatient settings suggests that either i) infectious virus in respiratory secretions is rarely present at sufficient titre to establish infection, ii) respiratory transmission of Clade IIb MPXV is not an optimal route of transmission, or iii) that surgical/FFP2 masks are sufficient to mitigate the residual risks of i) and ii).

We have shown that surface contamination occurs in an outpatient setting and, while it was minimal in the environment sampled, infection-competent MPXV could be detected. It is likely that several factors contribute to the low level of contamination observed including minimal time spent in this locality and the frequency of cleaning. Such focussed surface deposition of virus would not be expected if there had been aerosolisation of virus. Thus in future studies, and where feasible, combined surface- and air-sampling may provide additional insights.

It is feasible that the contamination observed could present an infection risk in specific situations; however, UK PPE recommendations combined with frequent standard cleaning procedures appear sufficient to mitigate onward transmission risk in outpatient settings. IPC recommendations should be kept under review as more data emerge regarding infectious virus in respiratory secretions and the risk of respiratory transmission of MPXV.

--
communicated by:
Mary Marshall
<mjm2020@googlemail.com>

[Articles like this remind us why proper PPE and cleaning protocols continue to be the cornerstone of preventing the spread of disease. With the current discussion around mpox spread focused primarily on its potential classification as an STI, this article provides evidence for spread outside of that limited scope. As the authors stated, clearly there is a need for further research on how to better provide revisions and updates in cleaning protocols to ensure that surfaces are properly sanitized. - Mod.CS]

******
[6] Italy: immunological signature in human cases 
Date: Mon 7 Nov 2022
Source: The Lancet Infectious Diseases [abridged, edited]
<https://doi.org/10.1016/S1473-3099(22)00662-4>


ref: Agrati C, Cossarizza A, Mazzotta V, et al. Immunological signature in human cases of monkeypox infection in 2022 outbreak: an observational study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2023; 23(3): 320-330. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Summary
-------
Background
An unprecedented global mpox outbreak started in May 2022. No data are yet available about the dynamics of the immune response against mpox virus. The aim of this study was to describe kinetics of T-cell response, inflammatory profile, and pox-specific T-cell induction in patients with laboratory-confirmed mpox.

Methods
17 patients with laboratory-confirmed mpox admitted at the Lazzaro Spallanzani National Institute for Infectious Diseases (Rome, Italy), from 19 May-7 Jul 2022, were tested for differentiation and activation profile of CD4 and CD8 T (expression of CD38, PD-1, and CD57 assessed by flow cytometry), frequency of pox-specific T cells (by standard interferon-γ ELISpot), and release of interleukin (IL)-1β, IL-6, IL-8, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF) in plasma (by ELISA). All patients were tested 10-12 days after symptom onset. In a subgroup of 9 patients with a laboratory-confirmed mpox, the kinetics of the immune response were analysed longitudinally according to timing from symptom onset and compared with 10 healthy donors (i.e., healthcare workers recruited from the same institution).

Findings
Among the 17 patients, 10 were HIV negative and 7 HIV positive, all with good viro-immunological status. On days 0-3 from symptom onset, patients with laboratory-confirmed monkeypox were characterised by a statistically significant reduction in CD4+ T cells (p = 0·0011) and a concurrent increase of CD8+ T cells (p = 0·0057) compared with healthy donors. A lower proportion of naive (CD45RA+CD27+) CD4+ T cells was observed in 6 (67%) of 9 patients and a concomitant higher proportion of effector memory (CD45RA-CD27-) CD4+ T cells in all patients; this skewed immune profile tended to normalise over time. A similar differentiated profile was also observed in CD8+ T cells with a consistent expansion of terminally differentiated CD8+ T cells. Patients with monkeypox had a higher proportion of CD4+CD38+ and CD38+CD8+ T-cells than healthy donors, which normalised after 12-20 days from symptom onset. The expression of PD-1 and CD57 on CD4+ and CD8+ T-cells showed kinetics similar to that observed for CD38. Furthermore, the inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8, and TNF) were higher in patients with monkeypox than in healthy donors and, although they decreased over time, they remained elevated after recovery. Almost all patients (15 [94%] of 16) developed a pox-specific Th1 response. No differences in immune cells profile were observed between patients with and without HIV, whereas paucysimptomatic patients (without systemic symptoms, with less than 5 skin lesions, and no other mucosal localisation of mpox) showed a less perturbed immune profile early after symptom onset.

Interpretation
Our data showed the immunological signature of mpox virus infection, characterised by an early expansion of activated effector CD4+ and CD8+ T cells that persisted over time. Almost all patients, even regardless of HIV infection, developed a poxvirus-specific Th1 cell response. These results might have implications on the expected immunogenicity of mpox vaccination, suggesting that it might not be necessary to vaccinate people who have already been infected.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[The findings of the article in item 5 above provide evidence that can help inform best practice for mpox vaccine allocation moving forward. Further application of the broader immunologic findings could help scientists to identify areas where mpox is endemic or in patients who are not considered "high risk" resulting in a misdiagnosis. - Mod.CS]

[1] Ukraine (Kherson): domestic
Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023

[African swine fever (ASF) has never been so widespread. Due to its complex epidemiology, the disease has expanded relentlessly since 2018, affecting more than 50 countries.

In the absence of an effective vaccine, controlling and eradicating ASF becomes more challenging. Despite this daunting context, global control of the disease is possible with sustained effort and collaboration at national, regional and international levels, as evidenced by countries that have succeeded in eradicating the disease. (<https://www.woah.org/en/disease/african-swine-fever/#index-2>). - Mod.CRD]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (34): AMERICAS (CHILE) SEA LION, HPAI H5, WOAH
**************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4922>


Chile - influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity (non-poultry including wild birds)
-----------------------------------------------------
Summary
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 10 Feb 2023
Confirmed: 16 Feb 2023
Reported: 24 Feb 2023
Reason for notification: unusual host species
Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]
Serotype: H5N1 [see epidemiological comments]
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Playa El Huascar, Antofagasta
Started: 10 Feb 2023
Epidemiological unit: other
Animals affected:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
South American sea lion / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species
Epidemiological comments: this is the 1st detection of avian influenza H5N1 in an unusual host in the national territory (marine mammal); sea lion _Otaria flavescens_ is the affected species. Regarding organization, the National Directorate of the National Fisheries and Aquaculture Service (El Servicio Nacional de Pesca y Acuicultura; SERNAPESCA) carries out the risk assessment and defines the actions to be implemented in each zone; regional directorates are responsible for implementing these measures. To date, the agent has not been detected in other marine mammals. Following the 1st detection of the pathogen, and based on the location where the affected animal got stranded, a disease control zone was defined along the coastline, where notification of stranded animals is reinforced with sectoral users and clinical and molecular surveillance is implemented in animals with signs and symptoms consistent with highly pathogenic avian influenza, aimed at the early detection and timely control of the spread of the virus. In geographic areas that are not within this zone, passive surveillance will be maintained, focusing on the follow-up of reports.

Control measures applied at event level, wild animals: surveillance outside the restricted zone; surveillance within the restricted zone; disinfection; control of wildlife reservoirs; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste.

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Result date / Result
[Lo Aguirre Laboratory, Agricultural and Livestock Service (SAG)] / South American sea lion / 1 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 15 Feb 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[The Eurasian HPAI H5N1 virus was first detected in January 2022 on the Atlantic coast of North America and rapidly spread to many states of the USA, Canada, and Mexico, probably introduced to the Americas by one of the numerous species of birds that migrate along Nearctic and Palearctic flyways and breed in Arctic tundra regions. In November [2022] H5N1 was first detected in South America in pelicans from Peru, probably brought by infected migrants such as the blue-winged teal (_Anas discors_), which breed in North America and many winter in northern South America, including Peru. The list of South American countries where HPAI H5N1 has been detected include Colombia, Peru, Venezuela, Chile, Bolivia, Uruguay, and Argentina. Passive and active surveillance should be enhanced in poultry and wild birds of the Neotropical region.

Infections by HPAI viruses in mammals are typically not common, but since April 2022 there have been several events of Eurasian HPAI H5N1 in a wide spectrum of wild carnivores (order Carnivora). There have been reports have been in red foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_, family Canidae), bobcats (family Felidae), skunks (family Mephitidae), raccoons (family Procyonidae), bears (family Ursidae), otters and minks (family Mustelidae), seals and sea lions (suborder Pinnipedia, families Phocidae and Otariidae, respectively). There have also been cases in cetaceans. The large numbers of dead sea lions reported in Peru suggest a potential considerable impact on the sea lion populations of the South Pacific. - Mod.PMB

ProMED map of Chile: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708680,68905>.]

column2:
DIPHTHERIA - LATVIA: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 2 Mar 2023 17:05 EET
Source: Latvian Public Media [in Latvian, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.lsm.lv/raksts/zinas/latvija/pec-tris-gadu-partraukuma-latvija-registrets-difterijas-saslimsanas-gadijums.a498720/>


After a 3-year break, a case of diphtheria was registered in Latvia. The Center for Disease Prevention and Control (SPKC) confirmed to Latvian Television that it is a young man between the ages of 25 and 35. He had been vaccinated but not revaccinated.

The infected patient was treated on an outpatient basis. His contacts have been identified and their family doctors have been informed. For the time being, none of the contacts have been diagnosed with the disease. The epidemiological investigation is continuing.

In the period from 2009 to 2019, 119 cases of diphtheria were registered in Latvia, 9 of which (7.6%) were fatal. 

SPKC emphasizes that vaccination plays a crucial role in the prevention of diphtheria. Vaccination against diphtheria decreased from 2020: SPKC data of 2021 show that the vaccination coverage against diphtheria and tetanus was higher only for infants at the age of 2 months 95.9% (vaccination 1) and children at the age of 12-15 months 97.3%. However, as a person's age increases, the vaccination coverage decreases: for infants aged 6-11 months it was 94.4%; for children aged 7 years, 89.3% (in 2022 - 89.5%); for teenagers aged 14 years, 68.3% (81.8% in 2022); and 52.8% for adults (51.7% in 2022).

SPKC emphasized that insufficient vaccination coverage creates the risk of an outbreak of diphtheria and the spread of infection.

Vaccination against diphtheria is paid for by the state. You can get it from your family doctor. To confirm [your] vaccination status, check the entries in the Vaccination Passport and contact your family doctor's practice.

SPKC explained that timely vaccination and booster vaccinations protect against diphtheria. Various combination vaccines contain diphtheria toxoid, that is, diphtheria toxin that has been rendered harmless. The body of a vaccinated person has antibodies which, in case of infection, neutralize the toxin produced by the causative agent of diphtheria [_Corynebacterium diphtheriae_], and the infection does not harm the person. However, the amount of antibodies decreases with time, so regular booster vaccinations are necessary.

Children in Latvia are vaccinated against diphtheria at the ages of 2, 4, 6, and 12 to 15 months, and then at the age of 7 and 14 years. To extend lifelong immunity, adults need a booster vaccination every 10 years.

After contracting diphtheria, full-fledged immunity against diphtheria is not formed, so even people who have had diphtheria in the past should be vaccinated regularly.

SPKC emphasized: no vaccination protects 100% from getting sick. It happens that vaccinated people also fall ill with diphtheria, but in this case, the disease proceeds in a mild form with symptoms similar to a sore and red throat. Such patients recover in a few days and do not have complications caused by diphtheria toxin.

The source of diphtheria infection can be either a person with diphtheria or a healthy person who is asymptomatic but is a carrier of the diphtheria bacterium. Most often, diphtheria affects the tonsils, throat, and nasal mucosa. Diphtheria can be contracted by inhaling air containing microscopic droplets of the bacteria, which are spread by talking, coughing, or sneezing by a diphtheria sufferer or a carrier of the bacteria. In this way, you can get infected in the workplace, shop, public transport, cafe, club, cinema, etc, in public places.

The infection also has a skin form when a person gets infected through a wound, and such lesions are more difficult to recognize, SPKC said.

The incubation period of the disease is from 2 to 5 days, but in some cases, it can be even up to 10 days. Sometimes, at the beginning of the disease, a slightly increased body temperature, weakness, and sweating can be observed. These symptoms gradually progress, and the characteristic signs of diphtheria develop -- general weakness; fever; sore throat, redness, swelling, and difficulty swallowing; a dirty gray plaque appears on the tonsils, which can spread throughout the throat. The plaque is thick, skin-like, and pale gray; in small children, the plaque can start from the larynx, in this case, cough, hoarseness, and difficulty breathing occur; headache and loss of appetite are also possible.

Along with other symptoms, the diphtheria toxin is absorbed into the blood and spreads throughout the body via the bloodstream. It has a toxic effect on the heart muscle, causing muscle inflammation or myocarditis; affects the nervous system by damaging nerve fibers, and also causes kidney, liver, and adrenal tissue destruction or necrosis.

If a person shows any signs characteristic of diphtheria, he/she should be immediately hospitalized and isolated, and specific treatment should be started. If you notice signs of diphtheria, contact your family doctor immediately. Diphtheria is considered confirmed when its causative agent is isolated in the laboratory, SPKC said.

Most often people who have not been vaccinated against diphtheria can get sick; the most susceptible are unvaccinated children under the age of 10 and people who have had more than 10 years since their last vaccination.

Diphtheria can be contracted at any time of the year; people get sick even in the warm months of the year. This can be explained by the fact that in the summer people go on vacation more often and meet each other. However, diphtheria is most common in the cold months of the year -- winter, autumn, and spring.

The World Health Organization has drawn attention to the fact that the number of diphtheria cases has increased in Europe. Between the beginning of 2022 and 2 Feb 2023, 371 cases of diphtheria were reported in Germany (147), United Kingdom (73), Austria (72), Switzerland (25), Belgium (25), France (14), Norway (7), Netherlands (5), Italy (2), and Spain (1). The majority were found in male migrants aged 8 to 49 years from the countries of the Central Asian region, and the skin form of diphtheria was most often determined.

At the beginning of the year [2023], SPKC specialists addressed medical professional organizations and institutions to draw attention to the spread of diphtheria in Europe and the need to evaluate the vaccination status of doctors and patients, especially in risk groups. Healthcare workers [should] consider the possibility of diphtheria and use personal protective equipment when examining or caring for patients with respiratory symptoms of diphtheria or skin lesions such as ulcers, especially in relation to the possible spread of infection among asylum seekers, asylum seeker center workers, and other workers who come into contact with asylum seekers, while family doctors are encouraged to continue to identify unvaccinated patients and urge them to get vaccinated.

[byline: Aija Kinca]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Humans are the only reservoir of _ Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, the cause of diphtheria. Transmission of _C. diphtheriae_ can occur through respiratory droplets, direct contact with cutaneous infections, and articles soiled with discharges from the respiratory tract or skin lesions of an infected person. Travel to an endemic area is a risk factor for the acquisition of _C. diphtheriae_.

ProMED has recently posted several reports on diphtheria at facilities in Europe used to house recent refugees, asylum seekers, and migrants from endemic regions (see ProMED posts Diphtheria - France: migrants, toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae/C. ulcerans 20221230.8707531; Diphtheria - Germany: toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae, cutaneous, migrants 20221119.8706803; Diphtheria - UK (02): (England) asylum seekers 20221127.8706944; Diphtheria - UK: (England) asylum seekers 20221021.8706299; and Diphtheria - Switzerland: (Bern) asylum seekers 20220804.8704867). Diphtheria has also been reported in Europeans who had traveled to an endemic region where they acquired diphtheria and then returned to their place of origin.

However, the news report above says that a recent case of diphtheria in Latvia occurred in a "man between the ages of 25 and 35", who was "vaccinated but not revaccinated". No further details as to the source of his infection are given. Was he a refugee from an endemic region or a traveler who returned from an endemic region, or did he acquire the infection locally, in Latvia? More information from knowledgeable sources on this case would be appreciated . - Mod.ML

Latvia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708677,119>]
