column3: After a 3-year break, a case of diphtheria was registered in Latvia. The Center for Disease Prevention and Control (SPKC) confirmed to Latvian Television that it is a young man between the ages of 25 and 35. He had been vaccinated but not revaccinated.The infected patient was treated on an outpatient basis. His contacts have been identified and their family doctors have been informed. For the time being, none of the contacts have been diagnosed with the disease. The epidemiological investigation is continuing.In the period from 2009 to 2019, 119 cases of diphtheria were registered in Latvia, 9 of which (7.6%) were fatal. SPKC emphasizes that vaccination plays a crucial role in the prevention of diphtheria. Vaccination against diphtheria decreased from 2020: SPKC data of 2021 show that the vaccination coverage against diphtheria and tetanus was higher only for infants at the age of 2 months 95.9% (vaccination 1) and children at the age of 12-15 months 97.3%. However, as a person's age increases, the vaccination coverage decreases: for infants aged 6-11 months it was 94.4%; for children aged 7 years, 89.3% (in 2022 - 89.5%); for teenagers aged 14 years, 68.3% (81.8% in 2022); and 52.8% for adults (51.7% in 2022).SPKC emphasized that insufficient vaccination coverage creates the risk of an outbreak of diphtheria and the spread of infection.Vaccination against diphtheria is paid for by the state. You can get it from your family doctor. To confirm [your] vaccination status, check the entries in the Vaccination Passport and contact your family doctor's practice.SPKC explained that timely vaccination and booster vaccinations protect against diphtheria. Various combination vaccines contain diphtheria toxoid, that is, diphtheria toxin that has been rendered harmless. The body of a vaccinated person has antibodies which, in case of infection, neutralize the toxin produced by the causative agent of diphtheria [_Corynebacterium diphtheriae_], and the infection does not harm the person. However, the amount of antibodies decreases with time, so regular booster vaccinations are necessary.Children in Latvia are vaccinated against diphtheria at the ages of 2, 4, 6, and 12 to 15 months, and then at the age of 7 and 14 years. To extend lifelong immunity, adults need a booster vaccination every 10 years.After contracting diphtheria, full-fledged immunity against diphtheria is not formed, so even people who have had diphtheria in the past should be vaccinated regularly.SPKC emphasized: no vaccination protects 100% from getting sick. It happens that vaccinated people also fall ill with diphtheria, but in this case, the disease proceeds in a mild form with symptoms similar to a sore and red throat. Such patients recover in a few days and do not have complications caused by diphtheria toxin.The source of diphtheria infection can be either a person with diphtheria or a healthy person who is asymptomatic but is a carrier of the diphtheria bacterium. Most often, diphtheria affects the tonsils, throat, and nasal mucosa. Diphtheria can be contracted by inhaling air containing microscopic droplets of the bacteria, which are spread by talking, coughing, or sneezing by a diphtheria sufferer or a carrier of the bacteria. In this way, you can get infected in the workplace, shop, public transport, cafe, club, cinema, etc, in public places.The infection also has a skin form when a person gets infected through a wound, and such lesions are more difficult to recognize, SPKC said.The incubation period of the disease is from 2 to 5 days, but in some cases, it can be even up to 10 days. Sometimes, at the beginning of the disease, a slightly increased body temperature, weakness, and sweating can be observed. These symptoms gradually progress, and the characteristic signs of diphtheria develop -- general weakness; fever; sore throat, redness, swelling, and difficulty swallowing; a dirty gray plaque appears on the tonsils, which can spread throughout the throat. The plaque is thick, skin-like, and pale gray; in small children, the plaque can start from the larynx, in this case, cough, hoarseness, and difficulty breathing occur; headache and loss of appetite are also possible.Along with other symptoms, the diphtheria toxin is absorbed into the blood and spreads throughout the body via the bloodstream. It has a toxic effect on the heart muscle, causing muscle inflammation or myocarditis; affects the nervous system by damaging nerve fibers, and also causes kidney, liver, and adrenal tissue destruction or necrosis.If a person shows any signs characteristic of diphtheria, he/she should be immediately hospitalized and isolated, and specific treatment should be started. If you notice signs of diphtheria, contact your family doctor immediately. Diphtheria is considered confirmed when its causative agent is isolated in the laboratory, SPKC said.Most often people who have not been vaccinated against diphtheria can get sick; the most susceptible are unvaccinated children under the age of 10 and people who have had more than 10 years since their last vaccination.Diphtheria can be contracted at any time of the year; people get sick even in the warm months of the year. This can be explained by the fact that in the summer people go on vacation more often and meet each other. However, diphtheria is most common in the cold months of the year -- winter, autumn, and spring.The World Health Organization has drawn attention to the fact that the number of diphtheria cases has increased in Europe. Between the beginning of 2022 and 2 Feb 2023, 371 cases of diphtheria were reported in Germany (147), United Kingdom (73), Austria (72), Switzerland (25), Belgium (25), France (14), Norway (7), Netherlands (5), Italy (2), and Spain (1). The majority were found in male migrants aged 8 to 49 years from the countries of the Central Asian region, and the skin form of diphtheria was most often determined.At the beginning of the year [2023], SPKC specialists addressed medical professional organizations and institutions to draw attention to the spread of diphtheria in Europe and the need to evaluate the vaccination status of doctors and patients, especially in risk groups. Healthcare workers [should] consider the possibility of diphtheria and use personal protective equipment when examining or caring for patients with respiratory symptoms of diphtheria or skin lesions such as ulcers, especially in relation to the possible spread of infection among asylum seekers, asylum seeker center workers, and other workers who come into contact with asylum seekers, while family doctors are encouraged to continue to identify unvaccinated patients and urge them to get vaccinated.[byline: Aija Kinca]--communicated by:ProMED[Humans are the only reservoir of _ Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, the cause of diphtheria. Transmission of _C. diphtheriae_ can occur through respiratory droplets, direct contact with cutaneous infections, and articles soiled with discharges from the respiratory tract or skin lesions of an infected person. Travel to an endemic area is a risk factor for the acquisition of _C. diphtheriae_.ProMED has recently posted several reports on diphtheria at facilities in Europe used to house recent refugees, asylum seekers, and migrants from endemic regions (see ProMED posts Diphtheria - France: migrants, toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae/C. ulcerans 20221230.8707531; Diphtheria - Germany: toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae, cutaneous, migrants 20221119.8706803; Diphtheria - UK (02): (England) asylum seekers 20221127.8706944; Diphtheria - UK: (England) asylum seekers 20221021.8706299; and Diphtheria - Switzerland: (Bern) asylum seekers 20220804.8704867). Diphtheria has also been reported in Europeans who had traveled to an endemic region where they acquired diphtheria and then returned to their place of origin.However, the news report above says that a recent case of diphtheria in Latvia occurred in a "man between the ages of 25 and 35", who was "vaccinated but not revaccinated". No further details as to the source of his infection are given. Was he a refugee from an endemic region or a traveler who returned from an endemic region, or did he acquire the infection locally, in Latvia? More information from knowledgeable sources on this case would be appreciated . - Mod.MLProMED map:Latvia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708677,119>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (08): CHINA (GUANGDONG) H5N6, H9N2, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
**********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region [edited]
<https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202303/01/P2023030100417.htm>


The Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today (1 Mar [2023]) closely monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in mainland China, and again has urged the public to maintain strict personal, food, and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.

The case involves a 49 year old man living in Qingyuan, Guangdong, who had contact with live domestic poultry before the onset of symptoms, which developed on 17 Dec 2022. He was admitted for treatment on 21 Dec 2022 and was in a serious condition.

From 2014 to date, 83 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by mainland health authorities. "All novel influenza A infections, including H5N6, are notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong," a spokesman for the CHP said.

Travelers to the mainland or other affected areas must avoid visiting wet markets, live poultry markets, or farms. They should be alert to the presence of backyard poultry when visiting relatives and friends. They should also avoid purchasing live or freshly slaughtered poultry and avoid touching poultry/birds or their droppings. They should strictly observe personal and hand hygiene when visiting any place with live poultry.

Travelers returning from affected areas should consult a doctor promptly if symptoms develop and inform the doctor of their travel history for prompt diagnosis and treatment of potential diseases. It is essential to tell the doctor if they have seen any live poultry during travel, which may imply possible exposure to contaminated environments. This will enable the doctor to assess the possibility of avian influenza and arrange necessary investigations and appropriate treatment in a timely manner.

While local surveillance, prevention, and control measures are in place, the CHP will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments.

The public should maintain strict personal, hand, food, and environmental hygiene and take heed of the advice below when handling poultry:
- avoid touching poultry, birds, animals, or their droppings;
- when buying live chickens, do not touch them and their droppings. Do not blow at their bottoms. Wash eggs with detergent if soiled with faecal matter and cook and consume the eggs immediately. Always wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling chickens and eggs;
- eggs should be cooked well until the white and yolk become firm. Do not eat raw eggs or dip cooked food into any sauce with raw eggs. Poultry should be cooked thoroughly. If there is pinkish juice running from the cooked poultry or the middle part of its bone is still red, the poultry should be cooked again until fully done;
- wash hands frequently, especially before touching the mouth, nose, or eyes; before handling food or eating; and after going to the toilet, touching public installations or equipment such as escalator handrails, elevator control panels, or doorknobs; or when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing; and
- wear a mask if fever or respiratory symptoms develop, when going to a hospital or clinic, or while taking care of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms.

The public may visit the CHP's pages for more information: the avian influenza page, the weekly Avian Influenza Report, global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza, the Facebook Page, and the YouTube Channel.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Any additional information on the outcome of the case would be greatly appreciated. As noted on the FluTrackers website (<https://flutrackers.com/forum/forum/china-h5n1-h5n8-h5n6-h5n3-h5n2-h10n8-outbreak-tracking/969529-china-avian-influenza-report-chp-hong-kong-reporting-period-feb-19-2023-%E2%80%93-feb-25-2023-2-new-h9n2-human-cases>), in addition to the H5N6 case, there have also been 2 additional cases of influenza A(H9N2), one from 23 Oct 2022 and another from 15 Nov 2022. An excellent summary of recent avian influenza in humans and animals is available from Hong Kong's Centre for Health Protection (<https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/2023_avian_influenza_report_vol19_wk08.pdf>).

Reports of the demise of influenza during the first year or two of the COVID-19 pandemic were greatly exaggerated, as evidenced not only by this year's seasonal flu outbreaks in the northern hemisphere, but also the continued spillovers of multiple avian influenza strains with H5N1 being the primary culprit globally. - Mod.JH

ProMED map of Guangdong Province, China: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708673,334>.]

column2:
LUMPY SKIN DISEASE - ASIA (02): INDONESIA (EAST JAVA) CATTLE
************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
Source: Surabaya Kompas [in Indonesian, machine trans., abridged, edited]
<https://surabaya.kompas.com/read/2023/02/28/144025478/ratusan-sapi-di-magetan-suspek-lsd-dinas-peternakan-gencarkan-vaksinasi>


The Magetan Regency [East Java] Livestock and Fisheries Service recorded 214 cows owned by residents suspected of having lumpy skin disease (LSD). Head of the Livestock and Fisheries Service for Magetan Regency, Nur Hayani, said that 10 cows belonging to the UPTD [Unit Pelaksana Teknis Daerah; regional technical implementation unit] of the East Java Provincial Government in Pramplelan Village, Karangrejo District, tested positive for LSD.

Related to these findings, the Magetan Regency Animal Husbandry and Fisheries Service will intensify vaccinations, especially for dairy cows. The Magetan Regency Animal Husbandry and Fisheries Service has received 1380 doses of the LSD vaccine. The agency will prioritize administering vaccines to residents' dairy cows.

"Currently, our vaccine is still 700 doses. We do prioritize the 1st for dairy cows. Our dairy cow population currently reaches 1053 heads," he added.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[The first recording of lumpy skin disease (LSD) in Indonesia was related to central Sumatra, in March 2022. In September 2022, LSD was confirmed near Semarang in Central Java. On 8 Dec 2022, Australian sources reported [ProMED post 20221210.8707179] its spread to East Java [Jawa Timur], including near the city of Malang, capital of Java's main dairy district. Its current detection in the inland Magetan Regency, in the west of the province, adjoining Central Java, attests to its continued circulation in several parts of East Java [map at <https://tinyurl.com/mptj73uf>].

LSD is a non-zoonotic, WOAH-notifiable capripox viral disease of cattle. - Mod.AS

ProMED map of East Java, Indonesia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708670,551>.]

column2:
BLACK STREAKED DWARF DISEASE, RICE - INDIA: ETIOLOGY
****************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sat 18 Feb 2023
Source: Times of India [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chandigarh/weed-linked-to-wheat-behind-virus-that-stunts-paddy/articleshow/98032800.cms>


Scientists from Haryana Agricultural University have found that the dwarfing disease in paddy crops in the country is not only caused by _Southern rice black streaked dwarf virus_ (SRBSDV), but also by _Rice gall dwarf virus_ (RGDV). Information has also been obtained on the host range of these viruses.

SRBSDV infection has been found to be more prevalent in the disease, and this virus also affects some weeds in local wheat crops, which is a concern. There has been no instance of the virus infecting wheat in the area. Therefore, farmers should destroy weeds in wheat fields to reduce the risk of dwarfing disease in paddy crops.

The scientists continually record the distribution and spread of the viruses. They recommend regular sanitary measures for fields and irrigation drains to prevent further spread of the disease.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Symptoms of black streaked dwarf disease (BSDD) of rice include darkening and distortion of leaves, black streaked tumours along leaf veins, as well as severe stunting of plants. BSDD due to _Rice black streaked dwarf virus_ (RBSDV; genus _Fijivirus_) has been known to cause serious crop losses in South East Asia. RBSDV also affects some other gramineous hosts including maize, wheat, oat, and barley. It is spread by planthoppers including _Laodelphax striatellus_ and _Unkanodes_ species.

_Southern rice black streaked dwarf virus_ (SRBSDV; genus _Fijivirus_) has been identified more recently and is now considered an emerging BSDD pathogen in Asia. It is transmitted by the white-backed planthopper (WBPH; _Sogatella furcifera_), which is not a vector of RBSDV, while the RBSDV vector _L. striatellus_ cannot spread SRBSDV. SRBSDV can also affect maize, sorghum, and several grasses as additional crop or reservoir hosts.

_Rice gall dwarf virus_ (RGDV; genus _Phytoreovirus_) is spread by the leafhopper _Recilia dorsalis_. It is known to occur in coinfections, for example with _Rice stripe mosaic virus_ (genus _Cytorhabdovirus_), which shares the same vector. RGDV also affects a range of cereal crops and grasses, causing severe stunting, leaf galls, and severe reduction of grain yield.

Disease management for rice viruses may include cultural practices, vector control, and use of cultivars with resistance to the virus, the vector, or both. High vector numbers are often associated with outbreaks of the viruses they transmit. This is a major concern in the region where rice crops are frequently affected by viruses and their insect vectors (see previous ProMED posts in the archives).

column3: Scientists from Haryana Agricultural University have found that the dwarfing disease in paddy crops in the country is not only caused by _Southern rice black streaked dwarf virus_ (SRBSDV), but also by _Rice gall dwarf virus_ (RGDV). Information has also been obtained on the host range of these viruses.SRBSDV infection has been found to be more prevalent in the disease, and this virus also affects some weeds in local wheat crops, which is a concern. There has been no instance of the virus infecting wheat in the area. Therefore, farmers should destroy weeds in wheat fields to reduce the risk of dwarfing disease in paddy crops.The scientists continually record the distribution and spread of the viruses. They recommend regular sanitary measures for fields and irrigation drains to prevent further spread of the disease.--communicated by:ProMED[Symptoms of black streaked dwarf disease (BSDD) of rice include darkening and distortion of leaves, black streaked tumours along leaf veins, as well as severe stunting of plants. BSDD due to _Rice black streaked dwarf virus_ (RBSDV; genus _Fijivirus_) has been known to cause serious crop losses in South East Asia. RBSDV also affects some other gramineous hosts including maize, wheat, oat, and barley. It is spread by planthoppers including _Laodelphax striatellus_ and _Unkanodes_ species._Southern rice black streaked dwarf virus_ (SRBSDV; genus _Fijivirus_) has been identified more recently and is now considered an emerging BSDD pathogen in Asia. It is transmitted by the white-backed planthopper (WBPH; _Sogatella furcifera_), which is not a vector of RBSDV, while the RBSDV vector _L. striatellus_ cannot spread SRBSDV. SRBSDV can also affect maize, sorghum, and several grasses as additional crop or reservoir hosts._Rice gall dwarf virus_ (RGDV; genus _Phytoreovirus_) is spread by the leafhopper _Recilia dorsalis_. It is known to occur in coinfections, for example with _Rice stripe mosaic virus_ (genus _Cytorhabdovirus_), which shares the same vector. RGDV also affects a range of cereal crops and grasses, causing severe stunting, leaf galls, and severe reduction of grain yield.Disease management for rice viruses may include cultural practices, vector control, and use of cultivars with resistance to the virus, the vector, or both. High vector numbers are often associated with outbreaks of the viruses they transmit. This is a major concern in the region where rice crops are frequently affected by viruses and their insect vectors (see previous ProMED posts in the archives).MapsIndia (with states):<https://www.worldometers.info/img/maps/india_physical_map.gif>Asia, overview:<https://www.worldatlas.com/img/areamap/continent/asia_map.gif>PicturesBSDD:<https://vtv1.mediacdn.vn/thumb_w/650/2017/5-54269-1502337429965.jpg>RBSDV symptoms:<https://www.siftdesk.org/articles/images/615/1.png>,<https://www.insectimages.org/browse/detail.cfm?imgnum=5356975>,<https://www.forestryimages.org/browse/detail.cfm?imgnum=5356974> and<https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ppreviews-plos-725668748/1283785/preview.jpg>SRBSDV column2:
LEPTOSPIROSIS - INDONESIA: (EAST JAVA) FATAL
********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023 19:11 WIB
Source: Kompas [in Indonesian, machine trans., edited]
<https://surabaya.kompas.com/read/2023/02/28/191109278/112-warga-pacitan-suspek-leptospirosis-24-positif-dan-3-meninggal>


Three residents in Pacitan Regency, East Java, died as a result of contracting leptospirosis [....] caused by leptospira bacteria. "The results of the rapid diagnostic test (RDT) are suspected to be 24 positive, 3 of whom have died," said coordinator of communicable disease control at the Nawangan Health Center, Tri Widodo, on Tuesday [28 Feb 2023].

According to Tri Widodo, leptospirosis [...] has been spreading [for] the last 3 weeks. 112 residents were [...] suspected [of having] leptospirosis, and 24 of them were positive for leptospirosis. "According to our records, there are 112 suspected cases," said Tri Widodo. These cases were found in 5 villages in Nawangan District, Pacitan Regency, East Java. "The 5 villages are Mujing Village, Nawangan Village, Gondang Village, Sempu Village and Jetis Lor Village," he said.

Of the 24 residents who were positive for leptospirosis, 3 residents in the Nawangan sub-district were declared dead. Of the 24 positive leptospirosis patients, 7 patients were treated at the Nawangan Health Center, while 17 other patients were treated at the Darsono Pacitan Regional General Hospital (RSUD).

[byline: Kontributor Trenggalek, Slamet Widodo, Pythag Kurniati]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[For a discussion of leptospirosis, please see my moderator comments in a prior ProMED post (Leptospirosis - Indonesia: (YO) rain, fatal 20220621.8703994).

Pacitan Regency is located in the south western corner of East Java Province, with Central Java Province on its western border and the Indian Ocean to the south. Pacitan regency is divided into 12 districts: leptospirosis is occurring in 5 of the 9 villages in Nawangan district (pop., 51 240 residents in 2020) (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacitan_Regency>). A map showing the location of Nawangan district in East Java, Indonesia, can be found at <https://www.google.com/maps/place/Nawangan,+Pacitan+Regency,+East+Java,+Indonesia>. - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
Pacitan, East Java, Indonesia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708668,13978>]

column2:
ANTHRAX - USA: NEW TEST
***********************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 1 Mar 2023
Source: CISION Prweb [abridged, edited]
<https://www.prweb.com/releases/2023/3/prweb19198039.htm>


Given the possible severity of anthrax infection, early and fast diagnosis is key. InBios International, Inc., a leading developer of diagnostic tests for emerging infectious diseases and biothreats, has been granted the US Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) 1st marketing rights for an anthrax point-of-care (POC) test. This approval was granted through the FDA's De Novo process for new medical devices or technology where there is no comparable device on the market.

InBios' Active Anthrax Detect Plus Rapid Test for pulmonary anthrax is for use as an aid in the diagnosis of inhalation anthrax, which occurs by breathing in anthrax spores and is the deadliest form of the disease. This test produces results in about 20 minutes and is intended for use by military personnel, medical and/or healthcare professionals only.

This in vitro immunochromatographic assay provides visual and rapid qualitative detection of the _Bacillus anthracis_ lethal factor protein and can be used to test serum and venous whole blood (dipotassium EDTA, sodium citrate and sodium heparin) from individuals who have signs and symptoms consistent with inhalation anthrax and a likelihood of exposure. While a positive Active Anthrax Detect Plus Rapid Test result is presumptively diagnostic for _B. anthracis_ infection, diagnosis of infection must be based on history, signs, symptoms, exposure likelihood, and additional laboratory evidence.

Clinical performance determined that the test had a negative percent agreement (NPA) of 100% and a positive percent agreement (PPA) of >98%. The specificity study (NPA) was conducted at 3 POC clinical sites in the United States, while the sensitivity (PPA) of the test was evaluated using contrived positive serum samples.

"With ease of dispersal and a high mortality rate, inhalation anthrax is a great threat to the security and safety of the world," said Syamal Raychaudhuri, PhD, InBios Chief Scientific Officer. "A fast, accurate test is needed to prepare for a potential bioterrorism attack or outbreak. Our test could play a critical role in thwarting any suspicious activities early on."

The De Novo classification for the Active Anthrax Detect Plus Rapid Test was supported in whole or in part with federal funds from the Department of Health and Human Services; Administration for Strategic Preparedness and Response; Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA), under contract number HHSO100201700029C awarded in 2017. Additionally, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provided significant expertise and resources, which contributed toward the development of the Active Anthrax Detect Plus Rapid Test.

Anthrax is a zoonotic bacterial disease caused by _Bacillus anthracis_, a gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium commonly found in the soil of disease-endemic areas. The disease presents with non-specific symptoms that cannot easily be distinguished from many common diseases. Although anthrax infection is rare, risk of infection remains, whether due to bioterrorism or injectional drug usage. For more information, visit <http://www.cdc.gov/anthrax>.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[This test claims a specificity of 100% and a sensitivity >98%, which are fair numbers to start with. Time will tell whether it will live up to its promise. Human cutaneous cases are infrequent in the United States and Canada, and usually follow from the careless skinning of a dead deer or cow. If the test is cheap, there would be a market for it for livestock and wildlife veterinarians who see cases in the Dakotas, Texas, and other states. Latterly, they have been using a free test out of Fort Detrick based on protective antigen in the blood of dead animals. Humans and white-tail deer do not have PA titres high enough to trigger this test, which has been around for decades. This test may be fine but don't get me wrong: If we really need to be using it, we will be in deep trouble. - Mod.MHJ

ProMED map:
United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708665,106>]

column2:
UNDIAGNOSED RESPIRATORY ILLNESS - CHILE: (REGION METROPOLITANA DE SANTIAGO) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
***************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: MSN, La Tercera report [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.msn.com/es-cl/noticias/others/hospitalizan-a-25-alumnos-de-la-escuela-militar-y-decretan-el-aislamiento-preventivo-de-todos-estudiantes-de-primer-a%C3%B1o/ar-AA17ZwBN>


As reported by the Military School to La Tercera through a statement, "during the recent week, 25 first year students of the school presented an acute respiratory condition, for which they are currently receiving the respective treatments at the Military Hospital of Santiago."

According to the initial records, the event occurred after a training day in Pichicuy [Valparaíso region]. The educational institution of the Army added that "derived from the above, and in compliance with the provisions of the institutional health authority, it was decided to keep all 1st-year students in the Military School in preventive isolation, implementing a series of sanitary measures, in order to avoid new infections."

Finally, they indicated that "the Military School has been permanently communicating to the parents about the evolution of the present situation, providing the corresponding support and adopting the necessary measures, within the framework of the firm commitment to the well-being of its students."

[byline: Carlos Reyes P]

--
communicated by:
ProMED from First Alert

[It is unclear from the information provided if there are any clues as to the etiology of the respiratory issues, beyond the assumption it is infectious given that isolation procedures were implemented. Seasonal influenza and/or COVID-19 would be high on the list of presumptive causes as would adenovirus, given that Adenovirus type 14 in particular, has been associated with outbreaks in military recruit populations.

As noted in the see also section below, legionellosis could also be on the list of potential causes given that summer is turning to fall in Santiago. More information on the Military School can be found at <https://www.escuelamilitar.cl/>).

ProMED would greatly appreciate any additional information on the etiologic agent(s) identified in these cases. - Mod.JH

ProMED map of Chile: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708657,2730>.]

column2:
MEASLES UPDATE (09): SOUTH AFRICA, NEW ZEALAND, KYRGYZSTAN, UK, CORRECTION
**************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
From: ProMED


re: Measles update (09): South Africa, New Zealand, Kyrgyzstan, UK 20230219.8708479
----------------------------------------------------------------
The location for item [4] in the post should have been London, Ontario, Canada, rather than London, UK. ProMED apologizes for the error. - Mod.LK

******
[4] Canada (Ontario): suspected ex India
Date: Sat 18 Feb 2023
Source: London Free Press [abridged, edited]
<https://lfpress.com/news/local-news/clinics-patients-factorys-workers-tracked-amid-first-local-measles-case-since-2014>


Clinic's patients, factory's workers tracked amid 1st local measles case since 2014
-------------------------------------------------------------
Public health officials are alerting citizens, and following up with at least 100 close contacts in Woodstock and London, after identifying a lab-confirmed case of the measles - the 1st in London and surrounding Middlesex County in nearly a decade.

The unidentified individual who tested positive for measles lives in London but works in Woodstock, the Middlesex-London Health Unit and Southwestern Public Health said in a joint statement Saturday afternoon [18 Feb 2023].

Officials believe the person contracted the highly contagious virus during a trip to India, a part of the world where the vaccine-preventable disease still spreads, Middlesex-London's top public health official, Dr. Alex Summers, said Saturday [18 Feb 2023].

"We are really relying, obviously, on our case and contact management team, but also on the underlying vaccination coverage that we have in our community," he said. "We hope that we don't see additional cases, but we have to prepare for that, which is why we're following up with all these individuals."

The health units were notified about the case on Friday afternoon [17 Feb 2023]. The individual had limited contact with others when they were infectious, public health officials say.

The person went to a London medical clinic on 15 Feb 2023 between 8 a.m. and 10 a.m. and worked overnight shifts at Nova Steel in Woodstock on 9 Feb and 12 Feb 2023 from 10 p.m. to 8 a.m.

Middlesex-London Health Unit contact tracers are following up with approximately 100 people who were potentially exposed at the medical clinic, Summers said.

[byline: Jennifer Bieman]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Note that this report is in regards to London, Ontario, Canada, and NOT London, UK. Also see the correctly reported follow-up Measles update (10): Canada, Kenya, Congo DR, New Zealand 20230223.8708558.

There have been reported 32 069 measles cases in India in the provisional data based on monthly data reported to WHO (Geneva) as of early February 2023. Data covers July 2022-December 2022 (<https://www.cdgov/globalhealth/measles/data/global-measles-outbreaks.html>). This number is greater than other countries reporting. - Mod.LK

ProMED map:
Ontario, Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708655,63268>]

column3: Clinic's patients, factory's workers tracked amid 1st local measles case since 2014-------------------------------------------------------------Public health officials are alerting citizens, and following up with at least 100 close contacts in Woodstock and London, after identifying a lab-confirmed case of the measles - the 1st in London and surrounding Middlesex County in nearly a decade.The unidentified individual who tested positive for measles lives in London but works in Woodstock, the Middlesex-London Health Unit and Southwestern Public Health said in a joint statement Saturday afternoon [18 Feb 2023].Officials believe the person contracted the highly contagious virus during a trip to India, a part of the world where the vaccine-preventable disease still spreads, Middlesex-London's top public health official, Dr. Alex Summers, said Saturday [18 Feb 2023]."We are really relying, obviously, on our case and contact management team, but also on the underlying vaccination coverage that we have in our community," he said. "We hope that we don't see additional cases, but we have to prepare for that, which is why we're following up with all these individuals."The health units were notified about the case on Friday afternoon [17 Feb 2023]. The individual had limited contact with others when they were infectious, public health officials say.The person went to a London medical clinic on 15 Feb 2023 between 8 a.m. and 10 a.m. and worked overnight shifts at Nova Steel in Woodstock on 9 Feb and 12 Feb 2023 from 10 p.m. to 8 a.m.Middlesex-London Health Unit contact tracers are following up with approximately 100 people who were potentially exposed at the medical clinic, Summers said.[byline: Jennifer Bieman]--communicated by:ProMED[Note that this report is in regards to London, Ontario, Canada, and NOT London, UK. Also see the correctly reported follow-up Measles update (10): Canada, Kenya, Congo DR, New Zealand 20230223.8708558.There have been reported 32 069 measles cases in India in the provisional data based on monthly data reported to WHO (Geneva) as of early February 2023. Data covers July 2022-December 2022 (<https://www.cdgov/globalhealth/measles/data/global-measles-outbreaks.html>). This number is greater than other countries reporting. - Mod.LKProMED map:Ontario, Canada: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708655,63268>]

column2:
MARBURG VIRUS DISEASE - EQUATORIAL GUINEA (03): (KIE-NTEM)
**********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
Source: RFI [edited]
<https://www.rfi.fr/en/international-news/20230228-death-toll-in-e-guinea-marburg-outbreak-rises-to-11>


There are 2 more people in Equatorial Guinea who have died of Marburg haemorrhagic fever, a cousin of the Ebola virus, bringing the toll of fatalities to 11, the authorities say. "The monitoring system recorded 8 notifications 2 days ago, including the deaths of 2 people with symptoms of the disease," health minister Mitoha Ondo'o Ayekaba said in a statement issued late on Tuesday [28 Feb 2023].

Work is under way "to strengthen assessment of the spread of the epidemic," said the statement, read on national television. "There are 48 contact cases that have been documented, 4 of whom have developed symptoms, and 3 who have been quarantined in hospital," it added.

The Marburg virus is a rare but highly dangerous pathogen that causes severe fever, often accompanied by bleeding and organ failure. It is part of the so-called filovirus family that also includes the Ebola virus, which has wreaked havoc in several previous outbreaks in Africa.

The central African state announced on 13 Feb [2023] that 9 people had died from Marburg between 7 Jan and 7 Feb [2023]. The UN's World Health Organization (WHO) held an emergency session the following day [14 Feb 2023]. The national authorities have declared a health alert in the remote north eastern province of Kie-Ntem province and in the neighbouring district of Mongomo, which are located on the border with Cameroon and Gabon. Measures include a lockdown plan implemented in collaboration with WHO.

In their statement of 13 Feb [2023], the authorities had reported only 3 cases of infection in addition to the fatalities -- individuals who were being isolated with "mild symptoms" in hospital.

The natural host of the Marburg virus is the African fruit bat, which carries the virus but does not fall sick from it. But the animals can pass the virus to primates in close proximity, including humans, and human-to-human transmission then occurs through contact with blood or other bodily fluids. Fatality rates in confirmed cases have ranged from 24% to 88% in previous outbreaks, depending on the virus strain and case management, according to WHO.

There are currently no approved vaccines or antiviral treatments. Potential treatments, including blood products, immune therapies, and drug therapies, as well as early candidate vaccines are being evaluated, says WHO.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from First Alert

[This outbreak is occurring in 2 neighboring localities in north eastern Equatorial Guinea. The report indicates that 4 cases are individuals in contact with one or more diagnosed cases. It is not clear if the 2 recent fatal cases also were contact ones. There are ongoing field investigations by an advance team that will provide additional information as well as detection of any additional cases that may be occurring. The Equatorial Guinea health authorities and WHO are to be congratulated for their rapid response to the outbreak of this serious disease. - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Kié-Ntem, Equatorial Guinea: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708654,68892>]

[See Also:

column2:
JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS - AUSTRALIA (02): (VICTORIA)
**************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: The Guardian [edited]
<https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/feb/28/japanese-encephalitis-may-have-infected-one-in-30-people-in-parts-of-northern-victoria>


Japanese encephalitis has infected as many as one in 30 people in parts of northern Victoria, the state's health department has said as it opened vaccine eligibility to more local government areas. The department estimated the number in affected northern Victorian council areas, which was higher than previously thought, after a serosurvey indicated a greater number of cases than the 13 reported during last year's [2022] mosquito season.

The survey took responses and blood samples from 800 participants in Loddon Mallee, Goulburn Valley, and Ovens Murray. The majority of those who showed evidence of prior infection were male and were identified in all 3 regions surveyed. "By finding more cases than we were previously aware of, this important research reinforces the risk to all in the community that mosquitoborne diseases pose, especially in light of recent flood activity," Victoria's deputy chief health officer, Deborah Friedman, said in a statement. The health department has expanded free Japanese encephalitis virus [JEV] vaccine eligibility to include Greater Bendigo, Northern Grampians, Hindmarsh, Horsham, Buloke, Yarriambiack, and West Wimmera council areas.

Mosquitoborne diseases have been on the rise in flood-affected areas in south eastern Australia, with cases of JEV detected in New South Wales [NSW], Victoria, and South Australia. In February [2023], Victoria recorded its 1st Murray Valley encephalitis [MVE] death since 1974, and NSW confirmed its 1st MVE case since 2011. There is currently no preventive vaccine for MVE.

Most people with either virus do not develop symptoms, but both can cause a clinical illness in a small number of infected people.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[As the above report notes, most human Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infections are asymptomatic or very mild. Since a recent 2nd human JE case has occurred in Victoria state during this transmission season (see Japanese encephalitis - Australia (01): (VI) 20230204.8708161), one would expect that many more individuals had been infected as well, as the above report indicates. The 1st case occurred in a resident of a flood-affected region of the state in late December 2022 (see Japanese encephalitis - Australia (32): (VI) 20221230.8707539). The occurrence of JEV infections in Victoria state is not surprising: JE virus has been detected in mosquitoes in several states in the Murray River watershed in recent weeks, and health authorities have been warning the public of the risk of infection. Recent flooding has provided ample breeding sites for vector mosquitoes. Over the current transmission season,  ProMED has not received reports of JE virus infection in pig farms. Infections in piggeries were common previously, often before human cases occurred, and can be expected again in the near future. Surveillance of mosquitoes in the areas where JE virus transmission has occurred in the past continues, as is monitoring of human cases and, presumably, pigs as well. - Mod.TY

ProMED map of Victoria, Australia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708653,288>.]

column2:
E. COLI EHEC - USA (01): O157, REPEXH01 PERSISTENT STRAIN
*********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 8 Feb 2023
Source: CDC [edited]
<https://www.cdc.gov/ncezid/dfwed/outbreak-response/rep-strains/repexh01.html?ACSTrackingID=USCDC_485-DM99711&ACSTrackingLabel=Food%20Safety%20Updates%20From%20CDC&deliveryName=USCDC_485-DM99711>


Persistent strain of _E. coli_ O157:H7 (REPEXH01) linked to multiple sources
--------------------------------------------------------------------
REPEXH01
---------
REPEXH01 is a persistent strain of Shiga toxin-producing _Escherichia coli_ O157:H7 bacteria [also called enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_, EHEC] that has caused illnesses and outbreaks in the USA.

CDC uses "persistent" to describe some strains of bacteria that have caused illness for years. The strains continue to cause illness, even though the number of illnesses they cause might vary over time. The strains are sometimes linked to more than a single source, making them harder to control.

Illness caused by this strain was first reported to PulseNet in 2017. Illnesses caused by this strain occur year-round but are less common in winter. In the past, the REPEXH01 strain has spread to people through contaminated food and contaminated recreational water.

This strain is relatively diverse genetically. Bacteria in this strain are within 21 allele differences of one another by whole-genome sequencing [WGS], which is more diverse than typical multistate foodborne outbreaks where bacteria generally fall within 10 allele differences of one another. [There is a REPEXH02 EHEC strain that is less genetically diverse. - Mod.LL]

Fast facts
------------
Bacteria: _Escherichia coli_
Serotype: O157:H7
Shiga toxin type: Stx2a and/or Stx2c
Persistent strain: REPEXH01
First detection: April 2017
Illnesses reported in PulseNet: 634
Outbreaks investigated: 14
Identified outbreak sources:
Recreational water (confirmed): 1 outbreak
Romaine lettuce (confirmed): 1 outbreak
Leafy greens (suspected): 1 outbreak
Ground beef (suspected): 2 outbreaks

Outbreaks and outbreak-related illnesses
----------------------------------------
Although most enteric illnesses -- including those caused by REPEXH01 -- are not part of an outbreak, investigation of outbreaks provides information that increases our understanding of germs, sources, settings, and factors that contribute to illness. Moreover, lab-confirmed cases comprise only a small portion of the true number of illnesses that occur because most people do not seek medical care and even fewer submit a stool specimen.

Starting in 2017, CDC and local, state, and federal health and regulatory partners have investigated several outbreaks of _E. coli_ O157:H7 illnesses caused by the REPEXH01 strain.

Summary of selected multistate outbreaks
--------------------------------------
Outbreak / Dates people got sick / Outbreak source / Geographic location of source / # Illnesses / # States
------------------------------------------------------
Outbreak A / July 2017 / recreational water (confirmed) / California / 10 / 1
Outbreak B / March 2018-August 2018 / romaine lettuce (confirmed) / Arizona / 238 / 37
Outbreak C / August 2018-October 2018 / ground beef (suspected) / unknown / 12 / 4
Outbreak D / October 2018-December 2018 / leafy greens (suspected) / unknown / 25 / 10
Outbreak E / May 2019-October 2019 / ground beef (suspected) / unknown / 44 / 12
Outbreak F / December 2020-January 2021 / unknown / unknown / 22 / 7
Outbreak G / April 2021-June 2021 / unknown / unknown / 5 / 3

[The timeline, or epidemiologic curve, of people with _E. coli_ O157:H7 illnesses caused by the REPEXH01 strain, by date illness began and by outbreak, 2017-2022, and map of the cases can be found at the original URL. - Mod.LL]

State of residence / # Sick people / Range (in different outbreaks)
---------------------------------------------------------
AK / 8 / 1-9
AL / 3 / 1-9
AR / 12 / 10-19
AZ / 25 / 20-39
CA / 249 / 40-350
CO / 10 / 10-19
CT / 3 / 1-9
DC / 1 / 1-9

GA / 5 / 1-9
HI / 9 / 1-9
IA / 1 / 1-9
ID / 5 / 1-9
IL / 43 / 40-350
IN / 6 / 1-9
KS / 1 / 1-9
KY / 2 / 1-9
LA / 9 / 1-9
MA / 2 / 1-9
MD / 7 / 1-9
ME / 2 / 1-9
MI / 2 / 1-9
MN / 9 / 1-9
MO / 16 / 10-19
MS / 10 / 10-19
MT / 3 / 1-9
NC / 14 / 10-19
ND / 3 / 1-9
NE / 3 / 1-9
NJ / 2 / 1-9
NM / 12 / 10-19
NV / 3 / 1-9
NY / 3 / 1-9
OH / 18 / 10-19
OK / 11 / 10-19
OR / 11 / 10-19
PA / 7 / 1-9
SC / 27 / 20-39
SD / 2 / 1-9
TN / 3 / 1-9
TX / 19 / 10-19
UT / 20 / 20-39
VA / 9 / 1-9
WA / 16 / 10-19
WI / 7 / 1-9

Laboratory data
--------------
WGS analysis:
Bacteria in this strain are within 21 allele differences of one another by core genome multilocus sequence typing (cgMLST), which is more diverse than typical multistate foodborne outbreaks where bacteria generally fall within 10 allele differences of one another. This strain includes 2 major genetic subclusters. Each has caused at least 2 outbreaks linked to different sources and geographic regions. Possible reasons for the differences among genetic subclusters are still being investigated. More research is needed to determine if any genetic subclusters are associated with specific foods, animal populations, or geographic regions.

Isolates from food, animal, and environmental samples:

Year / Number of isolates / Isolate type / Geographic location of source / Reason collected
2017 / 1 / goose feces / California / outbreak A
2017 / 2 / lake sediment / California / outbreak A
2017 / 4 / lake water / California / outbreak A
2018 / 24 / agricultural irrigation water / Arizona / outbreak B
2019 / 1 / ground beef / California / routine sampling

Genomic information:
The National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) advances science and health by providing access to biomedical and genomic information.

SNP Cluster: PDS000059979.158

Antimicrobial resistance information:

The National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) is a national public health surveillance system that tracks antimicrobial resistance for certain intestinal bacteria from sick people (CDC), retail meats (FDA), and food animals (USDA) in the USA. The NARMS program helps protect public health by providing information about emerging antimicrobial resistance, the ways in which resistance is spread, and how resistant infections differ from susceptible infections.

Bacteria from most sick people's samples showed resistance to the antimicrobials chloramphenicol, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, tetracycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. These findings do not affect treatment guidance because antimicrobials are not recommended for patients with _E. coli_ O157:H7 infection.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[This moderator was not familiar with the REP term or the REPEXH01 designation of the isolate. Two days before the above report, however, the following was published:

"Reoccurring, emerging, and persisting enteric bacterial strains
--------------------------------------------------------
Some enteric bacterial strains cause acute outbreaks linked to specific sources. Other strains, referred to as reoccurring, emerging, or persisting (REP) strains, can reoccur and periodically cause acute outbreaks. They can also emerge and increase in frequency or persist and cause illnesses over periods of months or years, despite investigation and prevention efforts. Investigators use a laboratory method called whole-genome sequencing (WGS) to identify the DNA fingerprints of bacteria from ill people and from foods, animals, and the environment. These DNA fingerprints represent strains of bacteria.

Investigators use these DNA fingerprints to find outbreaks of enteric (gastrointestinal) diseases. When scientists identify a group of people who got sick around the same time with a strain with the same DNA fingerprint, this represents a possible outbreak. Investigators then work to determine what caused the illnesses. These acute outbreaks tend to start off with a significant rise in illnesses followed by a significant decline over a short period of time.

WGS has also enabled investigators to find and investigate groups of illnesses that are caused by the same strain but that occur over time periods longer than an acute outbreak. These strains can reoccur and periodically cause acute outbreaks, emerge and increasingly cause illness, or persist and cause illnesses over periods of months or years. They may continue to cause illnesses despite investigation and prevention efforts.

Identifying a strain as an REP strain is based on many factors, including the number of illnesses, whether illnesses are increasing, the characteristics of the strain (for example, multidrug resistance, high virulence, increased transmissibility), and whether the strain is the cause of large or frequent outbreaks.

"REP strain characteristics
-------------------------
Reoccurring strains: Strains repeatedly causing acute outbreaks separated by periods during which the strain either does not make people sick or causes illnesses at very low levels.

Emerging strains: Previously novel or rare strains that increasingly cause illnesses or show the potential to cause increasing illness.

Persisting strains: Strains causing illnesses consistently over a long time.

"CDC's role
----------
Since 2019, CDC has used the PulseNet system to identify and monitor REP strains of several major pathogens, including salmonella, _E. coli_ O157:H7, listeria, and campylobacter. PulseNet uses a combination of different WGS tools for identifying and tracking these strains and will develop more as new strains are identified and investigated.

CDC uses information gained from investigations of REP strains to better understand their sources, track how they change over time, and collaborate on measures to reduce their spread."
<https://www.cdc.gov/ncezid/dfwed/outbreak-response/rep-strains.html>)

Of note, outbreak B above was described in the peer-reviewed literature (ref), and the REP nomenclature was not found in the paper nor was it found searching in PubMED on 28 Feb 2023. This moderator can see either R, E, or P as a descriptive in noting the epidemiology of the isolate, but are there non-REP strains? - Mod.LL

ref: Bottichio L, Keaton A, Thomas D, et al. Shiga toxin-producing _Escherichia coli_ infections associated with romaine lettuce - United States, 2018. Clin Infect Dis. 2020; 71(8): e323-e330; <https://doi.org/10.1093/cid/ciz1182>.

column3: Persistent strain of _E. coli_ O157:H7 (REPEXH01) linked to multiple sources--------------------------------------------------------------------REPEXH01---------REPEXH01 is a persistent strain of Shiga toxin-producing _Escherichia coli_ O157:H7 bacteria [also called enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_, EHEC] that has caused illnesses and outbreaks in the USA.CDC uses "persistent" to describe some strains of bacteria that have caused illness for years. The strains continue to cause illness, even though the number of illnesses they cause might vary over time. The strains are sometimes linked to more than a single source, making them harder to control.Illness caused by this strain was first reported to PulseNet in 2017. Illnesses caused by this strain occur year-round but are less common in winter. In the past, the REPEXH01 strain has spread to people through contaminated food and contaminated recreational water.This strain is relatively diverse genetically. Bacteria in this strain are within 21 allele differences of one another by whole-genome sequencing [WGS], which is more diverse than typical multistate foodborne outbreaks where bacteria generally fall within 10 allele differences of one another. [There is a REPEXH02 EHEC strain that is less genetically diverse. - Mod.LL]Fast facts------------Bacteria: _Escherichia coli_Serotype: O157:H7Shiga toxin type: Stx2a and/or Stx2cPersistent strain: REPEXH01First detection: April 2017Illnesses reported in PulseNet: 634Outbreaks investigated: 14Identified outbreak sources:Recreational water (confirmed): 1 outbreakRomaine lettuce (confirmed): 1 outbreakLeafy greens (suspected): 1 outbreakGround beef (suspected): 2 outbreaksOutbreaks and outbreak-related illnesses----------------------------------------Although most enteric illnesses -- including those caused by REPEXH01 -- are not part of an outbreak, investigation of outbreaks provides information that increases our understanding of germs, sources, settings, and factors that contribute to illness. Moreover, lab-confirmed cases comprise only a small portion of the true number of illnesses that occur because most people do not seek medical care and even fewer submit a stool specimen.Starting in 2017, CDC and local, state, and federal health and regulatory partners have investigated several outbreaks of _E. coli_ O157:H7 illnesses caused by the REPEXH01 strain.Summary of selected multistate outbreaks--------------------------------------Outbreak / Dates people got sick / Outbreak source / Geographic location of source / # Illnesses / # States------------------------------------------------------Outbreak A / July 2017 / recreational water (confirmed) / California / 10 / 1Outbreak B / March 2018-August 2018 / romaine lettuce (confirmed) / Arizona / 238 / 37Outbreak C / August 2018-October 2018 / ground beef (suspected) / unknown / 12 / 4Outbreak D / October 2018-December 2018 / leafy greens (suspected) / unknown / 25 / 10Outbreak E / May 2019-October 2019 / ground beef (suspected) / unknown / 44 / 12Outbreak F / December 2020-January 2021 / unknown / unknown / 22 / 7Outbreak G / April 2021-June 2021 / unknown / unknown / 5 / 3[The timeline, or epidemiologic curve, of people with _E. coli_ O157:H7 illnesses caused by the REPEXH01 strain, by date illness began and by outbreak, 2017-2022, and map of the cases can be found at the original URL. - Mod.LL]State of residence / # Sick people / Range (in different outbreaks)---------------------------------------------------------AK / 8 / 1-9AL / 3 / 1-9AR / 12 / 10-19AZ / 25 / 20-39CA / 249 / 40-350CO / 10 / 10-19CT / 3 / 1-9DC / 1 / 1-9FL / 1 / 1-9GA / 5 / 1-9HI / 9 / 1-9IA / 1 / 1-9ID / 5 / 1-9IL / 43 / 40-350IN / 6 / 1-9KS / 1 / 1-9KY / 2 / 1-9LA / 9 / 1-9MA / 2 / 1-9MD / 7 / 1-9ME / 2 / 1-9MI / 2 / 1-9MN / 9 / 1-9MO / 16 / 10-19MS / 10 / 10-19MT / 3 / 1-9NC / 14 / 10-19ND / 3 / 1-9NE / 3 / 1-9NJ / 2 / 1-9NM / 12 / 10-19NV / 3 / 1-9NY / 3 / 1-9OH / 18 / 10-19OK / 11 / 10-19OR / 11 / 10-19PA / 7 / 1-9SC / 27 / 20-39SD / 2 / 1-9TN / 3 / 1-9TX / 19 / 10-19UT / 20 / 20-39VA / 9 / 1-9WA / 16 / 10-19WI / 7 / 1-9Laboratory data--------------WGS analysis:Bacteria in this strain are within 21 allele differences of one another by core genome multilocus sequence typing (cgMLST), which is more diverse than typical multistate foodborne outbreaks where bacteria generally fall within 10 allele differences of one another. This strain includes 2 major genetic subclusters. Each has caused at least 2 outbreaks linked to different sources and geographic regions. Possible reasons for the differences among genetic subclusters are still being investigated. More research is needed to determine if any genetic subclusters are associated with specific foods, animal populations, or geographic regions.Isolates from food, animal, and environmental samples:Year / Number of isolates / Isolate type / Geographic location of source / Reason collected2017 / 1 / goose feces / California / outbreak A2017 / 2 / lake sediment / California / outbreak A2017 / 4 / lake water / California / outbreak A2018 / 24 / agricultural irrigation water / Arizona / outbreak B2019 / 1 / ground beef / California / routine samplingGenomic information:The National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) advances science and health by providing access to biomedical and genomic information.SNP Cluster: PDS000059979.158Antimicrobial resistance information:The National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) is a national public health surveillance system that tracks antimicrobial resistance for certain intestinal bacteria from sick people (CDC), retail meats (FDA), and food animals (USDA) in the USA. The NARMS program helps protect public health by providing information about emerging antimicrobial resistance, the ways in which resistance is spread, and how resistant infections differ from susceptible infections.Bacteria from most sick people's samples showed resistance to the antimicrobials chloramphenicol, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, tetracycline, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. These findings do not affect treatment guidance because antimicrobials are not recommended for patients with _E. coli_ O157:H7 infection.--communicated by:ProMED[This moderator was not familiar with the REP term or the REPEXH01 designation of the isolate. Two days before the above report, however, the following was published:"Reoccurring, emerging, and persisting enteric bacterial strains--------------------------------------------------------Some enteric bacterial strains cause acute outbreaks linked to specific sources. Other strains, referred to as reoccurring, emerging, or persisting (REP) strains, can reoccur and periodically cause acute outbreaks. They can also emerge and increase in frequency or persist and cause illnesses over periods of months or years, despite investigation and prevention efforts. Investigators use a laboratory method called whole-genome sequencing (WGS) to identify the DNA fingerprints of bacteria from ill people and from foods, animals, and the environment. These DNA fingerprints represent strains of bacteria.Investigators use these DNA fingerprints to find outbreaks of enteric (gastrointestinal) diseases. When scientists identify a group of people who got sick around the same time with a strain with the same DNA fingerprint, this represents a possible outbreak. Investigators then work to determine what caused the illnesses. These acute outbreaks tend to start off with a significant rise in illnesses followed by a significant decline over a short period of time.WGS has also enabled investigators to find and investigate groups of illnesses that are caused by the same strain but that occur over time periods longer than an acute outbreak. These strains can reoccur and periodically cause acute outbreaks, emerge and increasingly cause illness, or persist and cause illnesses over periods of months or years. They may continue to cause illnesses despite investigation and prevention efforts.Identifying a strain as an REP strain is based on many factors, including the number of illnesses, whether illnesses are increasing, the characteristics of the strain (for example, multidrug resistance, high virulence, increased transmissibility), and whether the strain is the cause of large or frequent outbreaks."REP strain characteristics-------------------------Reoccurring strains: Strains repeatedly causing acute outbreaks separated by periods during which the strain either does not make people sick or causes illnesses at very low levels.Emerging strains: Previously novel or rare strains that increasingly cause illnesses or show the potential to cause increasing illness.Persisting strains: Strains causing illnesses consistently over a long time."CDC's role----------Since 2019, CDC has used the PulseNet system to identify and monitor REP strains of several major pathogens, including salmonella, _E. coli_ O157:H7, listeria, and campylobacter. PulseNet uses a combination of different WGS tools for identifying and tracking these strains and will develop more as new strains are identified and investigated.CDC uses information gained from investigations of REP strains to better understand their sources, track how they change over time, and collaborate on measures to reduce their spread."<https://www.cdc.gov/ncezid/dfwed/outbreak-response/rep-strains.html>)Of note, outbreak B above was described in the peer-reviewed literature (ref), and the REP nomenclature was not found in the paper nor was it found searching in PubMED on 28 Feb 2023. This moderator can see either R, E, or P as a descriptive in noting the epidemiology of the isolate, but are there non-REP strains? - Mod.LLref: Bottichio L, Keaton A, Thomas D, et al. Shiga toxin-producing _Escherichia coli_ infections associated with romaine lettuce - United States, 2018. Clin Infect Dis. 2020; 71(8): e323-e330; <https://doi.org/10.1093/cid/ciz1182>.ProMED map:United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708652,106>]

column2:
BOTULISM - USA: CANNED SHRIMP, RISK, RECALL
*******************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
Source: Seafood Source [edited]
<https://www.seafoodsource.com/news/food-safety-health/kawasho-foods-announces-a-voluntary-recall-on-geisha-shrimp-cans>


Kawasho Foods USA is recalling one of its Geisha canned shrimp products over concerns of potential contamination with _Clostridium botulinum_, a potentially lethal toxin. The voluntary recall, covering the company's Geisha Medium Shrimp 4-Ounce canned product, was initiated after some of the cans were found to be swelling, leaking, or bursting. According to a 27 Feb [2023] announcement from the Food and Drug Administration, there is a possibility the product was underprocessed, leading to spoilage and the development of harmful organisms or pathogens.

The New York City, USA-based company announced the cans were distributed to retail locations of major retailers including Walmart, Albertsons, Safeway, Associated Food Stores, and Stater Bros Markets in the US states of California, Utah, Arizona, and Colorado.

Botulism is a rare but serious illness caused by a toxin that attacks the body's nerves and causes difficulty breathing, muscle paralysis, and even death, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

The company has recalled products with UPC label #071140003909 from lot LGC12W12E22 with a best-by date of 12 May 2026. "Consumers should not use this product, even if it does not look or smell spoiled," the company warned. Consumers are eligible for a full refund if they return the recalled products to their place of purchase.

[byline: Bhavana Scalia-Bruce]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Because of the potential severity of botulism, ProMED posts such recalls even if, as in this case, there are no human cases associated (yet) with the food products. Most food recalls are related to defective preparation procedures that could, but do not necessarily, result in the germination of viable spores of _Clostridium botulinum_.

Foodborne botulism usually occurs when preformed toxin is absorbed through the intestinal tract, and when the botulinum toxin is exposed to the neuromuscular junction, the heavy chain of the botulinum neurotoxin binds to glycoprotein structures specifically found on cholinergic nerve terminals. This specific docking is the reason for BT's (botulinum toxin's) high selectivity for cholinergic synapses. After internalization, the light chain of the botulinum neurotoxin binds with high specificity to the SNARE protein complex. The target proteins vary among the BT serotypes. BT-A cleaves synaptosomal-associated proteins of 25kDa (SNAP-25). BT-B cleaves vesicle-associated membrane protein (VAMP), also known as synaptobrevin II. - Mod.LL

ProMED map:
United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708651,106>]

column2:
AFRICAN SWINE FEVER - EUROPE (08): GERMANY (BRANDENBURG) DOMESTIC, CONTROL
**************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1] Official press release
Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
Source: Brandenburg official State portal, press release 074/2023 [in German, trans. by communicator, edited] 
<https://msgiv.brandenburg.de/msgiv/de/presse/pressemitteilungen/detail/~28-02-2023-asp-hausbestand-cb>


African swine fever (ASF) was confirmed in a herd of domestic pigs in the Spree-Neisse district. The affected smallholding includes 11 animals. The farm was immediately restricted by the official veterinarian and the necessary measures were implemented. The virus was first detected by the Berlin-Brandenburg state laboratory. Today [28 Feb 2023], the national reference laboratory, the Friedrich Loeffler Institute (FLI), confirmed the suspicion of ASF.

Investigations into the means of the entry of the pathogen into the pig population have begun. The veterinary office is supported by the country's animal disease control service. The crisis center of the state of Brandenburg is in constant contact with the veterinary office of the district. The holding is located in core area 6, which is in the south of the district, in the immediate vicinity of the Saxon border. The pigs in the herd were killed today and disposed of.

In [July 2021], ASF was detected in domestic pig populations for the first time in the state of Brandenburg. There were 3 farms (including 2 very small holdings) in the rural districts of Spree-Neisse and Märkisch-Oderland. In [July 2022] there was another ASF outbreak in a pig farm in the Uckermark district.

Secretary of state for consumer protection Dr Antje Töpfer once again appeals to all pig farms and in particular to all small farms to strictly comply with the prescribed biosecurity measures in order to prevent further outbreaks in domestic pigs. African swine fever has already been found in a total of 3007 wild boar in Brandenburg.

African swine fever is a contagious disease of pigs (domestic and wild pigs), which is almost always fatal and incurable. There is no way to protect pigs with preventive vaccination. The disease can be transmitted directly from animal to animal or indirectly by humans to other areas via contaminated objects (clothing, shoes, vehicles) and food. ASF is not contagious or dangerous to humans or other animal species.

--
communicated by:
Sabine Zentis
Castleview English Longhorns
Gut Laach
D-52385 Nideggen
Germany
<cvlonghorns@aol.com>

******
[2] Media report
Date: Tue 28 Feb 2023
Source: Reuters [edited] 
<https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/germany-reports-another-african-swine-fever-case-farm-pigs-2023-02-28/>


Another case of African swine fever (ASF) has been confirmed in farm pigs in east Germany, authorities said on [Tue 28 Feb 2023]. It was reported on a small farm with 11 animals in the eastern state of Brandenburg, the state's health ministry said. All 11 animals were slaughtered as a precaution, it said.

China and a series of other pork buyers banned imports of German pig meat in [September 2020] after the first case was confirmed in wild animals. Discoveries on farms will make it harder for Germany to get the export bans lifted, analysts say.

The disease is not dangerous to humans but is fatal for pigs. Many countries impose bans on pork from regions suffering from the disease, distorting the world food trade.

Wild boar coming into Germany from Poland were believed to have spread the disease to Germany, especially in the eastern states of Brandenburg and Saxony.

--
communicated by
ProMED

[In the absence of a licensed vaccine against ASF, the only way to prevent its introduction to ASF-free countries or to control (ideally, eradicate) it from affected regions are severe biosecurity measures, including culling the pig population of infected and contact holdings and wild boars.
 
Recently, a Philippines-based agriculture product firm announced that ASF vaccines "could soon be available in the country once the clinical trials for a Vietnam-made vaccine are completed and proven successful". Reportedly, "safety and efficacy trials using the AVAC ASF Live vaccine are being conducted, under the supervision of the Bureau of Animal Industry, in 4 local farms. These trials are expected to be completed in April [2023]". See <https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2023/02/20/2246222/vaccines-asf-may-be-available-soon>.

The Vietnamese government recently reported that more than 600 000 doses of the AVAC ASF vaccine have been administered in field trials since July [2022]: "Because of the highly favorable results, the Vietnamese government will also start this month its own nationwide distribution of the vaccine to help local hog farmers."

The field trials in Vietnam and the Philippines are expected to be followed with interest elsewhere. - Mod.AS]
