column2:
CORONAVIRUS DISEASE 2019 UPDATE (09): XBB.1.5, VACCINE, WHO
***********************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Selected countries
[A] China: classes halted amid school COVID cluster, flu returns
[B] Canada: surge in hospitalizations of babies and children due to COVID recorded in 2nd year of pandemic
[C] EU: excess mortality rose sharply to 19% in December 2022
[2] US CDC: XBB.1.5 responsible for 85% of infection in the US, no significant difference in severity
[3] Challenges in updating future COVID-19 vaccine compositions
[4] WHO: daily new cases reported (as of 23 Feb 2023)
[5] Global update: Worldometer updated 02:08 GMT 23 Feb 2023

******
[1] Selected countries
[A] China: classes halted amid school COVID cluster, flu returns
Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023 3:52 AM GMT+1
Source: Bloomberg News [edited]
<https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-02-23/china-halts-some-classes-amid-school-covid-cluster-flu-s-return>


A number of schools across China halted classes earlier this week to stem the spread of COVID and other pathogens ranging from flu to norovirus, as the country begins to see a comeback of other illnesses after pandemic restrictions were eased.

Ten 2nd-graders in the same classroom tested positive for COVID on rapid antigen tests last weekend [17-18 Feb 2023] in eastern e-commerce hub Hangzhou, prompting local education authorities to suspend their class for 4 days starting Monday [20 Feb 2023]. The students were likely infected for the 1st time, officials said.

Shanghai suspended in-person teaching in an elementary school class after 4 students were diagnosed with the flu and others developed similar symptoms. Flu cases -- and subsequent class suspensions -- were also reported in other schools across Zhejiang province, the Chinese capital Beijing, and the nearby city of Tianjin.

The fresh surges parallel what was seen globally after countries eased COVID social distancing rules which kept other illnesses largely at bay. The "twindemic", as the tandem waves of COVID and influenza have been termed, stands to get worse in China which saw years of some of the world's strictest measures, followed by one of its fastest pivots back to normal life.

China's unexpected rush to dismantle nearly all pandemic restrictions in early December [2022] unleashed the world's biggest COVID outbreak, with nearly 90% of the country's 1.4 billion population infected in less than 2 months. While the reopening wave appears to have ebbed, the national CDC still reports around 10 000 COVID cases each day that were confirmed by laboratory tests.

While lockdowns and mass testing have eased as China moves on from its COVID Zero policy, authorities still grant schools the ability to halt in-person teaching -- either by individual grade level, or the entire campus -- to prevent wider outbreaks caused by COVID and other infectious diseases.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

---
[B] Canada: surge in hospitalizations of babies and children due to COVID recorded in 2nd year of pandemic
Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023 3:04 PM CET
Source: CTV News [edited]
<https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/massive-surge-in-hospitalizations-of-babies-and-young-kids-due-to-covid-recorded-in-2nd-year-of-pandemic-1.6285415>


In the 2nd year of the pandemic, hospitalizations due to COVID-19 skyrocketed more than 600 per cent among children aged 0-4 compared with the previous year, according to new data from the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI).

In 2020-2021, there were 325 hospitalizations of children in this cohort due to COVID-19, but in 2021-2022, there were 2315 hospitalizations of children aged 0-4 in Canada due to COVID-19, CIHI reports [seven times higher]. The data, released on Thursday [23 Feb 2023], shows COVID-19 was the 6th highest reason children of this age group were hospitalized.

Respiratory infections not related to COVID-19 also resurged as a cause of hospitalization for children aged 0-4 in 2021-2022. The previous year, non-COVID respiratory infections didn't make the top 10 list of hospitalization causes for this age group at all. In 2021-2022, "other acute lower respiratory infections" were listed as the 2nd highest reason for hospitalizations -- pneumonia was number 5 and "acute upper respiratory infections" was number 7 on the list.

It's concerning to see hospitalizations among young children increasing so significantly, experts say. "This uptick in hospitalizations for COVID-19, respiratory infections, and other viral illnesses seen among the youngest Canadians in the 2nd year of the pandemic is concerning both for the health of our youngest and most vulnerable, and for the additional strain placed on health systems and health care workers that were already stretched thin," Juliana Wu, director of acute and ambulatory care information services at CIHI, said in a press release. "We are continuing to monitor hospital activity in this 3rd year of the pandemic to understand the ongoing impacts of COVID-19 on Canadians."

The data also shows in 2021-2022, COVID-19 hospitalized far more Canadians across all age groups than in 2020-2021.

In 2020-2021, COVID-19 was the 7th commonest cause of hospitalizations for all Canadians, according to CIHI. However, in 2021-2022, the only thing more likely to put you in the hospital than COVID-19 was giving birth.

COVID-19 was 2nd on the top 10 list of reasons Canadians were hospitalized in 2021-2022, ahead of heart failure, acute myocardial infarction, substance use disorders, other medical care such as palliative care, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and bronchitis, neurocognitive disorders, mood (affective) disorders, and osteoarthritis of the knee, in that order.

The total number of inpatient hospitalizations in Canada due to COVID-19 in 2020-2021, according to CIHI, was 47 715. In 2021-2022, there were 77 344 inpatient hospitalizations due to the virus.

The CIHI report noted that for the purposes of this data, COVID-19 hospitalizations were identified as hospitalizations where COVID-19 was responsible for the bulk of the hospital stay. This number may differ from other data sets which include hospitalization data with all COVID-19 diagnoses, regardless of if they are primary or secondary.

[byline: Alexandra Mae Jones]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

---
[C] EU: excess mortality rose sharply to 19% in December 2022
Date: Thu 17 Feb 2023
Source: Eurostat [abridged, edited]
<https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/products-eurostat-news/w/DDN-20230217-1>


Excess mortality in the EU in December 2022 soared to +19% of the average number of deaths for the same period in 2016-2019, the highest recorded value in 2022. This is a sharp increase from November, when excess mortality was at +8%. In comparison, the excess mortality rate was +30% in December 2020 and +24% in December 2021.

This information comes from data on excess mortality published by Eurostat today [17  Feb  2023], based on a weekly death data collection. The article presents a handful of findings from the more detailed Statistics Explained articles on excess mortality and weekly deaths.

In December 2022, excess mortality continued to vary across the EU members. Romania and Bulgaria (both -6%) recorded values lower than the national monthly average for 2016-19, while Hungary (+3%), Luxembourg, Spain, and Malta (all +10%) had excess mortality rates less than half the EU average.

Conversely, the highest rate was recorded in Germany (+37%). Other countries with rates over +20% were Austria (+27%), Slovenia (+26 %), Ireland and France (both +25%), Czechia, the Netherlands, and Estonia (all +23 %), Denmark (+22%), and Finland and Lithuania (both +21%).

The EU registered earlier major peaks in excess deaths in April 2020 (+25%), November 2020 (+40%), April 2021 (+21%), and November 2021 (+27%). July 2022 also showed significantly higher than the baseline mortality, possibly due to the heatwaves that affected parts of Europe during the reference period.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[2] US CDC: XBB.1.5 responsible for 85% of infection in the US, no significant difference in severity
Date: Fri 24 Feb 2023 5:41 pm EST
Source: US News & World Report [edited]
<https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2023-02-24/cdc-estimates-omicron-subvariant-xbb-1-5-responsible-for-85-of-new-coronavirus-infections-in-u-s>


Updated data from the United States' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) shows that the new booster shots offer higher protection against symptomatic COVID-19 infection among kids than adults. The vast majority of new COVID-19 infections are caused by one omicron subvariant that appears to be on its way to complete domination over the US.

The highly transmissible omicron subvariant XBB.1.5 caused 85% of coronavirus cases this week, according to estimates from CDC. It's the only major strain that is increasing, setting it up to potentially drive virtually all infections in the coming weeks. XBB.1.5 is up from 79% of infections last week and 72% the week before. It has been a rapid rise for the subvariant, which made up just 4% of cases 3 months ago.

While the new booster shots were designed to take on omicron subvariants BA.4 and BA.5, updated government data shows that they are holding up against XBB.1.5. CDC officials on Friday [24 Feb  2023] presented updated data on the booster to a meeting of the agency's vaccine experts, finding that the shots have a higher efficacy among children than adults.

They said that the updated booster is about 65% effective against symptomatic infection in kids 5-11 years old up to a month after they get the shot. It's slightly more effective among adolescents 12-17 years old at 68%. The numbers decrease in the following months as efficacy wanes. For adults 18-49, the efficacy against symptomatic infection up to a month after administration is 51%. For people 50-64, the number decreases to 46%. Americans 65 and older mount the lowest protection at 38%, which declines to just 21% up to five months after the shot.

Uptake of the booster has been dismal, attracting just 16% of Americans. Federal health officials are eyeing a switch to an annual COVID-19 booster shot beginning in the fall, but some Americans are hoping to get their next shot sooner than that, citing concerns that the efficacy of the shots starts to wane after a few short months.

[byline: Cecelia Smith-Schoenwalder]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[In another report by NHK World, <https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20230224_18/>, "the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says there appears to be no significant difference in disease severity between a quickly spreading omicron subvariant of the coronavirus and a previously dominant strain."
- Mod.LWW]

[3] Challenges in updating future COVID-19 vaccine compositions
Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: Nature Medicine journal [abridged, edited]
<https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-023-02220-y>


[ref: Grant R, Sacks JA, Abraham P, et al. When to update COVID-19 vaccine composition. Nat Med. 2023
----------------------------------------------------------------
Vaccines against different SARS-CoV-2 variants have been approved, but continued surveillance is needed to determine when the antigen composition of vaccines should be updated, together with clinical studies to assess vaccine efficacy.

In September 2021, the World Health Organization (WHO) established the Technical Advisory Group on COVID-19 Vaccine Composition (TAG-CO-VAC) to assess the public health implications of emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern (VOC) on the performance of COVID-19 vaccines and to issue timely recommendations on proposed modifications to vaccine antigen composition. The TAG-CO-VAC has evaluated evidence to inform its advice on COVID-19 vaccine composition so far, but there remain challenges and evidence gaps that the scientific community needs to address to enable future, timely decisions on modifications to COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition.

The current decision-making process of the advisory group is triggered by the designation of VOCs by WHO, upon the advice of the Technical Advisory Group on SARS-CoV-2 Virus Evolution (TAG-VE), and consists of 2 steps. The 1st step is to decide whether an update to vaccine composition should be considered, based on the nature and location of changes in the spike protein and associated antigenic effect, transmissibility or spread, and clinical severity of the VOC; and the effectiveness of current vaccines. The 2nd step is an assessment of whether an updated vaccine composition is warranted to maintain protection against severe disease and death and elicit a greater breadth in immunological cross-reactivity against circulating and emerging VOCs. The key data considered are cross-neutralization of VOCs in the context of the emerging variant after infection or vaccination with current and alternative antigens in people with varied previous exposure to SARS-CoV-2 antigens.

Although index virus-based vaccines are still highly effective in preventing severe illness and death from omicron, the rates of omicron breakthrough infection among vaccinated people have been high, which suggests that although immunity induced by index virus-based vaccines is sufficient to prevent severe disease, it is not sufficient to prevent Omicron infection. The goal of an update in vaccine strain composition for COVID-19 is to broaden immunological cross-reactivity against newly emerged VOCs while preserving reactivity to current and earlier circulating strains, rather than an attempt to match the vaccine composition to what is circulating. This can be achieved as a booster dose and/or through the use of a multivalent vaccine.

Immunological profiles are increasingly heterogeneous, and so the performance of an updated vaccine will vary depending on the nature and magnitude of previously acquired immunity in each person. Therefore, future vaccine composition decisions will need to be made in the face of increasingly complex and heterogeneous data.

Index virus-based vaccines are available across different platforms, including mRNA-based, viral vectored, and inactivated, and they elicit robust systemic immunity that protects against severe disease caused by all variants, including omicron. However, a preponderance of vaccine effectiveness data is derived from mRNA-based vaccines. So far, available vaccines with an updated composition are predominantly mRNA-based, although others are likely to follow. The paucity of data from vaccines other than those based on mRNA technology is problematic, given the diversity of vaccines in use globally.

Since January 2022, there has been a substantial reduction in SARS-CoV-2 diagnostic testing and sequencing globally, as well as in the number of SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences submitted to open access databases, such as GISAID EpiCov. The reduction in availability of genetic sequence data will delay the identification and phenotypic assessment of new variants needed to understand the effect of variants on vaccine effectiveness and therapeutic agents. Therefore, efforts to sustain SARS-CoV-2 genetic surveillance capacity must be accompanied by phenotypic analysis of the variants.

Decisions on vaccine antigen composition require extensive evaluation of the neutralizing capacity of well-characterized human convalescent sera, which are obtained from naive and previously vaccinated individuals, including after infection with VOCs and descendent lineages, well-characterized panels of human monoclonal antibodies, and sera from naive, infected and vaccinated animal models.

The current approach to vaccine antigen composition may not be sustainable in the long term, given the length of time for vaccine development, the paucity of surveillance data globally, and the regulatory requirements in different countries. Future development of vaccines that protect against all SARS-CoV-2 variants, pan SARS, and all sarbecoviruses will be technically challenging but could offer protection from diverse coronaviruses, including those that are enzootic in many animal species.

--

column2:
LASSA FEVER - WEST AFRICA (05): GHANA (GREATER ACCRA)
*****************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 26 Feb 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<https://outbreaknewstoday.com/ghana-reports-two-lassa-fever-cases-in-residents-of-accra-90047/>


The Ghana Health Service (GHS) reported today [26 Feb 2023] 2 confirmed Lassa fever cases from the Noguchi Memorial Institute for Medical Research on Friday [24 Feb 2023]. Both cases reside in Accra.

The 1st case was a 40 year old trader, who was unwell for about 2 weeks and died at the Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital. The 2nd case, who is a contact of the fatal case, is currently a hospital inpatient and is in a stable condition. To date, 56 contacts have been identified and are being followed up.

Ghana is one of the West African countries where Lassa fever is endemic, along with Benin, Liberia, Guinea, Nigeria, Mali, Sierra Leone, and Togo.

Lassa fever is an acute viral hemorrhagic fever spread through contact with infected rodents or their urine or droppings. Lassa fever can also be spread from person to person through contact with an infected person's bodily fluids.

Symptoms of Lassa fever (fever, chills, headache, and fatigue) develop 1-3 weeks after infection. About 20% of people infected with Lassa fever develop severe illness that can lead to hemorrhaging (bleeding), respiratory distress, vomiting, facial swelling, pain in the chest, back, and abdomen, and sometimes death.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[It is not clear if the 2nd case was in contact with the 1st one in the hospital or outside it. Transmission of the virus can occur when in contact with the excrement of infected rodent hosts or with infected individuals as sometimes happens in hospitals. Although Lassa fever virus (LFV) is endemic in West Africa, including Ghana, cases occur sporadically there. It has been 5 years since the previous LFV ProMED post from Ghana when a case was diagnosed in 2018. Interestingly, LFV in Ghana was predicted many years ago. In commenting on the 2011 cases in Ghana, the late Mod.CP said that Lassa virus infection had not been recorded previously in Ghana, but the lesser prevalence of Lassa fever in Ghana was predicted by a spatial-climatic analysis of Lassa fever data from human cases and infected rodent hosts in West Africa during the period 1965-2007 (see Risk maps of Lassa fever in West Africa. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2009; 3(3): e388; <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19255625/> and also the ProMED-mail archived report: Lassa fever, predictive maps - West Africa 20090428.1605).

Halting the acquisition of Lassa fever virus infection at its source -- at the village level -- is not easy. As noted previously, getting local people to understand that virus transmission to humans occurs when people are in contact with the reservoir rodent host, the multimammate mouse (in the genus _Mastomys_), or its excreta can be difficult. Preventing this contact requires understanding that leads to action. Rodent control and prevention of contact with rodent excreta have to be undertaken at the village level with individual households. This requires an extensive and continuous public education effort. Transmission of the virus also occurs in health facilities when personal protective equipment is not employed and barrier-nursing practices are not adequate to protect staff from the blood and secretions of infected patients. Although no vaccine is available, ribavirin has been used to successfully treat patients and is most effective if patients are treated early in the course of infection.

Images of the mastomys mouse, the rodent reservoir of Lassa fever virus, can be seen at <https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/45326-Mastomys-natalensis>. - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Accra Metropolis, Ghana: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708640,53000>]

column2:
POLIOMYELITIS UPDATE (09): ISRAEL ACUTE FLACCID PARALYSIS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION, WILD POLIOVIRUS TYPE 1 ENVIRONMENTAL, CIRCULATING VACCINE DERIVED POLIOVIRUS TYPES 1 & 2 ACUTE FLACCID PARALYSIS, ENVIRONMENTAL
*******************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[There is a correction of this report: Poliomyelitis update (09): Israel AFP, RFI, WPV1 ES, cVDPV1 & 2 AFP & ES, corr 20230304.8708724. There are errors in section [2] below. The information used in the GPEI updates comes from an email that is sent out weekly. At times the website has not as yet been updated with the new data and our very diligent editorial process mistook the discrepancy to be an error in the email process. Archive 20230304.8708724 has the correct information. We apologize for any problems that this error may have created. - Mod.MPP]

In this update:
[1] Israel (Safed): AFP polio suspected, RFI
[A] Times of Israel blog
[B] Ministry of Health press release
[C] Walla media report
[2] Global update as of 22 Feb 2023: WPV1 ES (Afghanistan); cVDPV1 AFP (Madagascar, Mozambique); cVDPV2 AFP (Congo DR, Yemen); ES (Algeria)
[3] Global update as of 15 Feb 2023: WPV1 ES (Afghanistan); cVDPV2 AFP (Chad, Congo DR, Indonesia, Nigeria, Yemen); ES (Benin)

******
[1] Israel (Safed): AFP polio suspected, RFI
[A] Times of Israel blog
Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023 8:51 PM IST
Source: Times of Israel live blog [edited]
<https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/child-in-safed-diagnosed-with-polio-health-ministry-says/>


Israel's Health Ministry announces that a case of polio has been diagnosed in an unvaccinated child in Safed. The child was brought into a local hospital with weakness in his limbs and was tested, leading to the diagnosis.

Health officials are now looking into the child's contacts to identify any others who may have been affected.

Polio is a viral disease that mainly affects children and can cause disability, paralysis, and death. Today, polio vaccinations are standard for children and are an effective preventive measure, but vaccine skepticism has enabled the disease to pop up from time to time.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

---
[B] Ministry of Health press release]
Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: Ministry of Health press release [in Hebrew, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.gov.il/he/departments/news/27022023-03>


The child arrived at the hospital with limb weakness and after an inquiry at the National Virus Laboratory, the sample was found to be positive for the polio virus.

There are about 150 000 unvaccinated children in Israel and there is evidence of the continued existence of polio in the sewers in many communities.

The Ministry of Health mentions that the main way to protect children from paralysis is through a killed polio vaccine. To prevent transmission of the virus it is important to maintain hand hygiene.

The district health bureau will open an epidemiological investigation and contact close contacts of the child to provide specific instructions. According to the findings of the investigation, a decision will be made on additional recommendations. The Ministry of Health will continue monitoring and update the findings.

Polio is a virus that causes paralysis in children, which has been eradicated from many countries in the world thanks to effective and safe vaccines that have been known for decades. No child in the State of Israel in 2023 should suffer from polio. A vaccinated child is a protected child.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

---
[C] Walla media report
Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: Walla [in Hebrew, machine trans., edited]
<https://news.walla.co.il/item/3561973>


Polio is a virus that causes paralysis in children, which has been eradicated from many countries in the world thanks to effective and safe vaccines that have been known for decades. About a month ago [January 2023], members of a delegation from the World Health Organization arrived in Israel, touring countries with ongoing polio outbreaks, with the aim of examining the ways of coping in Israel, sampling, monitoring, and vaccination. The polio outbreak in Israel began in February 2022, when a Jerusalem girl arrived at hospital with paralysis. Since then there has been evidence of continued circulation of the virus, by its detection in sewers in various cities throughout the country.

Dr Sharon Elroei Price, head of public health services at the Ministry of Health, explained to Walla that there is no reason to worry about the special delegation that arrived in Israel, but about the disease itself: "Most children who are infected do not develop symptoms, in 20% of cases there are symptoms of a viral disease, and in less than 1% of cases in unvaccinated children there can be paralysis. From 2013 there was no evidence of polio in Israel until the case of the Jerusalem girl."

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[This report was originally found in English as a live blog on the Times of Israel website (section [1A] above. According to a brief report in The Jerusalem Post the affected child is 8 years old and lives near the city of Safed. "An investigation will be conducted among the child's close family and friends to verify the diagnosis." (<https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-732873>)

From the reports available it appears as though this is a case of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) suspected to be caused by poliovirus, with the Ministry of Health having issued an early official alert. One wonders if there were positive environmental samples in the early results of the epidemiologic investigation.

As a reminder, one AFP case in Jerusalem Israel was reported in March 2022, associated with a circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 3 (cVDPV3) infection (see prior posts in the see also section below). In addition, a vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (VDPV2) was identified in wastewater sampling matching the VDPV2's identified in wastewater in the USA and the UK in August of 2022.

In 2013 positive environmental samples of WPV1 were identified at first in the south of Israel and moving north. No AFP cases were associated with this event (see 2013 ProMED polio posts below). At that time Israel had been using inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) alone for vaccination. To stop the ongoing transmission of wild polivirus (WPV), oral polio vaccine (OPV) was reintroduced to the vaccination program as a mixed schedule -- IPV followed by OPV.

We await further information.

Safed has a long and rich history through millennia. It is located in the northern Galilee in Israel and is the highest city in the country (<https://www.touristisrael.com/safed/5681/>). It is considered a holy city in Judaism. It was a refuge for the 1492 Spanish expulsion Sephardic population. It was said to have been originally founded by one of Noah's sons after the Flood.

"The Jerusalem Talmud mentions Safed as one of 5 elevated spots where fires were lit to announce the New Moon and festivals during the Second Temple period." "The city today has a large Haredi community and remains a center for Jewish religious studies."
(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safed>) The mention of a sizable Haredi community may well mean a sizeable pocket of unvaccinated children and young adults.

A map of Israel showing the location of Safed can be found at <https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Israel_outline_northeast.png>. - Mod.MPP]

******
[2] Global update as of 22 Feb 2023: WPV1 ES (Afghanistan); cVDPV1 AFP (Madagascar, Mozambique); cVDPV2 AFP (Congo DR, Yemen); ES (Algeria)
Date: Wed 22 Feb 2023
Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative/WHO [edited]
<https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/>


Poliovirus weekly update 22 Feb 2023, World Health Organization
---------------------------------------------------------------
New wild poliovirus isolates reported this week:
Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) cases: 0
Environmental samples (ES): 2
Others: 0

New circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) isolates reported this week:
AFP cases: 8
ES: 15
Others: 4

Headlines
---------
- novel oral polio vaccine type 2 (nOPV2) rollout: about 585 million doses of nOPV2 have been administered across 27 countries under its WHO Emergency Use Listing (EUL) to date. An additional 14 countries have met the requirements for nOPV2 use in the event of an outbreak. Visit the nOPV2 web page for more information [<https://polioeradication.org/nOPV2/>].

Summary of new polioviruses this week:
- Afghanistan: 2 wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) positive ES
- Algeria: 2 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive ES
- Congo DR: 4 cVDPV2 cases
- Madagascar: 1 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) case and 8 positive ES
- Mozambique: 2 cVDPV1 cases
- Yemen: 1 cVDPV2 case and 5 positive ES

Afghanistan
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2022.
- 2 WPV1 positive ES were reported in Nangarhar.

Pakistan
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 20 cases detected in 2022.
- One WPV1 positive ES is reported in Punjab.

Algeria
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 3 cases detected in 2022.
- 2 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported: 1 each in Alger and Tamanghasset.

Benin
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 10 cases detected in 2022.

Botswana
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 3 positive ES reported in 2022.

Burkina Faso
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021.

Cameroon
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 2 cases reported in 2022.

Canada
- No cVDPV2 was reported in the past week. Previously, cVDPV2 was isolated from 2 ES from a large wastewater treatment plant and a target site in the city of Montreal, Quebec, collected on 27 and 30 Aug 2022, after the country conducted retrospective analysis of wastewater samples. Genetic sequencing confirmed it is linked to the cVDPV2 currently affecting New York, USA.

Central African Republic
- One case of cVDPV2 was reported in Region Sanitaire 3. There are 5 cases detected in 2022.

Chad
- 7 cases of cVDPV2 were reported; one each in Logone Occidental, Dar Sila, and Hadjer Lamis, and 2 each in N'djamena and Ouaddai. There are now 43 cases detected in 2022.

Congo (Republic of)
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021.

Côte d'Ivoire
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were no cases reported in 2021.

Djibouti
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week.

Democratic Republic of the Congo (Congo DR)
- 4 cases of cVDPV2 were reported in Haut Lomami bringing the number of 2022 cases to 287.
- No cases of cVDPV1 were reported this week. There are 92 cases detected in 2022.
- Outbreak response to both cVDPV1 and cVDPV2 is being intensified.

Egypt
- No cVDPV2 positive ES was reported this week. There are 18 positive ES reported in the country were the last 2 years.

Eritrea
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is one case in 2022 and 1 case reported in 2021.

Ethiopia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is one case reported in 2022.

Gambia
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There were 9 positive samples in 2021.

Ghana
- No case of cVDPV2 was reported this week. There are 3 cases in 2022.

Guinea
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 6 cases in 2021.

Guinea-Bissau
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 3 cases in the country which are linked to the Jigawa outbreak in Nigeria in 2021.

Israel
- No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 3 (cVDPV3) were reported this week. There is one case reported in 2022.
- The country has been confirmed as affected by both cVDPV2 and cVDPV3.

Indonesia
- One case of cVDPV2 was reported this week making it the second detection in 2023. There was 1 case detected in 2022.

Liberia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 3 cVDPV2 cases in 2021.

Madagascar
- One case of cVDPV1 was reported in Sava. There are 14 cases detected in 2022.
- 8 cVDPV1 positive ES were reported in Analamanga.

Malawi
- No cases of WPV1 were reported this week. One case from 2021 has been reported in 2022.
- No cases of cVDPV1 were reported this week. There were 4 cases in the country in 2022.

Mali
- One case of cVDPV2 was reported in Taoudenit this week. This case is the 1st one in 2022.

Mauritania
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There were 7 positive samples linked to the Jigawa outbreak in 2021.

Mozambique
- No WPV1 case was reported this week. There are 8 cases detected in 2022. Reporting of these new cases within a short time span indicates that intensified surveillance efforts are working in the province.
- 2 cases of cVDPV1 were reported in Zambezia. There were 21 cases in 2022.
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. The number of cases in 2022 remains 4.

Niger
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. The number of cVDPV2 cases in 2022 remains 14.

Nigeria
- 4 cases of cVDPV2 were reported in Zamfara with one case being the first of 2023. There are now 47 cases detected in 2022.

Senegal
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Sierra Leone
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Somalia
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported in Banadir. There are 5 cases reported in 2022.
- One cVDPV2 positive ES was reported in Banadir.

South Sudan
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week.

Sudan
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There is 1 case reported in 2022.

Togo
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 2 cases in 2022.
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 2 positive samples reported in 2022.

Uganda
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week.

Ukraine
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There were 2 cases reported in 2021.
- Disease surveillance continues to be strengthened, to the degree possible given the evolving situation, including by building capacity, conduct trainings, implement environmental surveillance and support routine immunization.

United Kingdom
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. 2 positive samples were reported in May [2022] and one in August [2022] following the isolation of vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (VDPV2) from environmental samples in London, UK.
- No cases of paralysis associated with this strain have been detected -- virus has been isolated only from environmental (sewage) samples.

United States of America
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. One cVDPV2 case was reported in New York in 2022.
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. 12 positive samples were reported in 2022.

Yemen
- One case of cVDPV2 was reported in Alhudaidah. There are 161 cases detected in 2022.
- 5 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported; 2 in Alhudaidah and 3 in Aden.

Zambia
- No cVDPV2 positive ES were reported this week. There are 3 positives samples reported in 2022.

Officially reported WPV1 and cVDPV cases as of [21 Feb 2023]
Wild poliovirus (WPV)
- Total global WPV1 cases in 2023: 0 (compared with 1 for the same period in 2022)
- Total global WPV1 cases in 2022: 30
Circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) cases
- Total global cVDPV cases in 2023: 3 (compared with 4 for the same period in 2022)
- Total global cVDPV cases in 2022: 724

--
communicated by:
ProMED

******
[3] Global update as of 15 Feb 2023: WPV1 ES (Afghanistan); cVDPV2 AFP (Chad, Congo DR, Indonesia, Nigeria, Yemen); ES (Benin)
Date: Wed 15 Feb 2023
Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative/WHO [edited]
<https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/>


New wild poliovirus isolates reported this week:
Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) cases: 0
Environmental samples (ES): 2
Others: 0

New circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) isolates reported this week:
AFP cases: 18
ES: 11
Others: 1

Summary of new polioviruses this week:

- Afghanistan: 2 wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) positive ES
- Benin: 1 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) positive ES
- Chad: 7 cVDPV2 cases
- Congo DR: 6 cVDPV2 cases
- Indonesia: 1 cVDPV2 case
- Nigeria: 4 cVDPV2 cases
- Yemen: 10 cVDPV2 positive ES


Afghanistan
- No WPV1 cases were reported this week. There are 2 cases detected in 2022.
- 2 WPV1 positive ES were reported; 1 each in Nangarhar and Kunar.

Benin
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 10 cases detected in 2022.
- One cVDPV2 positive ES was reported in Donga.

Chad
- 7 cases of cVDPV2 were reported; 1 each in Logone Occidental, Dar Sila and Hadjer Lamis, and 2 each in N'djamena and Ouaddai. There are now 43 cases detected in 2022.

Democratic Republic of the Congo (Congo DR)
- 6 cases of cVDPV2 were reported; 4 in Haut Lomami and 1 each in Lualaba and Sud-Kivu. There are 283 cases detected in 2022.
- No cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 1 (cVDPV1) were reported this week. There are 92 cases detected in 2022.
- Outbreak response to both cVDPV1 and cVDPV2 is being intensified.

Indonesia
- One case of cVDPV2 was reported this week, the second detection in 2023. 1 case was detected in 2022.

Nigeria
- 4 cases of cVDPV2 were reported in Zamfara with 1 case being the first of 2023. There are now 47 cases detected in 2022.

Yemen
- No cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week. There are 160 cases reported in 2022.
- 10 cVDPV2 positive ES were reported; 4 each in Alhudaidah and Sanaa city, and 2 in Aden.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[The past week has seen evidence of poliovirus (WPV1, cVDPV1, and cVDPV2) circulation in 10 countries. WPV1 positive ES in Afghanistan, cVDPV1 AFP cases in Madagascar and Mozambique, cVDPV2 AFP cases in Chad, DR Congo, Indonesia, Nigeria, and Yemen, and cVDPV2 positive ES were confirmed in Algeria and Benin. All reported events (AFP cases and positive ESs) were events in 2022 except the AFP cases in Indonesia and 1 AFP case in Nigeria which were 2023 events.

The 2022 total reported cVDPV cases has officially overtaken those confirmed in 2021 (698 cVDPV AFP cases in 2021, 724 cases confirmed to date in 2022.

A map showing the locations of each confirmed case of polio worldwide in the past 12 months can be found at <https://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/>. One can see cases of cVDPV in a band across Africa and in Israel, Ukraine, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Pakistan; cVDPV1 in DR Congo, Malawi, Madagascar, and Mozambique; and WPV1 in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Malawi, and Mozambique. - Mod.MPP]

column2:
AMOEBIASIS - PHILIPPINES: (NEGROS OCCIDENTAL) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Tue 27 Feb 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<https://outbreaknewstoday.com/philippines-rising-cases-of-amebiasis-in-san-carlos-city-prompts-state-of-health-of-emergency-declaration-52736/>


The San Carlos City government in Negros Occidental province has declared a state of health emergency after reports of an increase in amebiasis [amoebiasis] cases last week. San Carlos City mayor Renato Gustilo said "alarming concerns on the rising cases of amebiasis" prompted him to issue Executive Order (EO) No. 79 declaring a state of health of emergency.

Nearly 200 amebiasis cases have been reported in 10 barangays (villages) from January (90) to February (100) [2023]. Gustilo said since Tuesday [27 Feb 2023], the City Health Office and the San Carlos City Hospital have been advising residents through social media to be cautious of the surge in amebiasis cases. EO 79 noted that anyone, young or old, is prone to contracting food and waterborne diseases such as cholera, diarrhea, typhoid fever, and amoebiasis.

Amoebiasis is a disease caused by the parasite _Entamoeba histolytica_. It can affect anyone, although it is commoner in people who live in tropical areas with poor sanitary conditions. People mostly get infected with the parasite from ingestion of fecally contaminated food and water containing the amoebic cysts. Transmission can also occur through oral-anal contact with a chronically ill or asymptomatic carrier.

According to the United States' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), only about 10% to 20% of people who are infected with _E. histolytica_ become sick from the infection. Of those who do become sick, symptoms may include stomach pain, bloody stools, and fever. Rarely, _E. histolytica_ invades the liver and forms an abscess (a collection of pus). In a small number of instances, it has been shown to spread to other parts of the body, such as the lungs or brain, but this is very uncommon.

--
communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2]
Date: Tue 27 Feb 2023
Source: Panay News [abridged, edited]
<https://www.panaynews.net/amoebiasis-cases-in-san-carlos-city-rise-to-230/>


The number of amoebiasis cases in San Carlos City, Negros Occidental, continues to increase with 230 cases recorded as of yesterday [26 Feb 2023] morning. The patients are currently admitted at the San Carlos City Hospital, said mayor Renato Gustilo.

Amoebiasis is an intestinal illness caused by microscopic parasite _Entamoeba histolytica_, which is spread through human feces. Symptoms include nausea, diarrhea, weight loss, stomach tenderness, and occasional fever.

Gustilo declared a state of health emergency just this 23 Feb [2023]. "Alarming concerns on the rising cases of amoebiasis" prompted him to issue Executive Order (EO) No. 79 declaring an emergency. The city mayor also confirmed that yesterday [26 Feb 2023] 7 inmates at the San Carlos City District Jail were also hospitalized due to amoebiasis. A subsequent inspection and water test at the jail, however, proved negative for amoeba bacteria.

Gustilo scheduled a meeting with the San Carlos Water Works to discuss ways to address the rising amoebiasis cases. Water sampling of households, especially those with positive cases, has been stepped up. The city's main line water system has also been subjected to laboratory tests, which "unofficially" detected presence of the amoeba. The samples have been sent to an accredited laboratory in Bacolod City for further verification, and the results are expected to be released on Fri 3 Mar [2023].

In the meantime, Gustilo advised the city's residents to use bottled water or boil water first before drinking. Amoebiasis can be prevented by boiling water for drinking; keeping surroundings clean; washing hands after using the toilet and before eating; and maintaining proper personal and food hygiene.

[byline: Dominique Gabriel G Bañaga]

--
communicated by:
ProMED

[Amoebiasis due to _Entamoeba histolytica_ infection is one of the commonest parasitic diseases globally, and yet is considered a neglected disease. Amoebiasis is most prevalent in impoverished communities with poor sanitation. Waterborne outbreaks of amoebiasis are very rare. In a recent review of waterborne protozoan outbreaks worldwide from 2017-2020, the vast majority were due to cryptosporidium and giardia, with only one reported outbreak due to _E. histolytica_ [1].

As with many other developing countries, the Philippines has challenges providing clean water to the population, particularly in rural areas with irrigation needs that may also be experiencing rapid urbanization. In a limited study of urban and rural areas around Metro Manila, the free-living amoebae _Acanthamoeba_ spp and _Naegleria_ spp were readily detected in fresh water and potential drinking water sources, but not _E. histolytica_ [2]. However, both _E. histolytica_ and _Entamoeba dispar_ have been detected at very low levels in residents of a Manila slum using stool ELISA and PCR [3,4]. These methods are useful in distinguishing _E. histolytica_ from _Entamoeba dispar_, which is a non-pathogenic intestinal commensal.

Negros Occidental is a province that occupies the north western portion of the large island of Negros in the Western Visayas region of the Philippine archipelago. Cholera cases have been increasing since October 2022 in a number of cities in the northern part of the province (see, for example <https://www.philstar.com/nation/2022/12/21/2232243/negros-occidental-cholera-cases-still-rising>), which is where San Carlos City is located. The rising incidence of cholera may well indicate deficiencies in the provision and use of clean water in this region.

Despite the rarity of waterborne outbreaks of amoebiasis, the very large cluster of cases and other features of the current outbreak in San Carlos City, as reported in the news articles above, are compatible with an outbreak of intestinal amoebiasis from a contaminated water source. That a number of these patients have been hospitalized suggests a significant incidence of severe amoebic dysentery and dehydration. The second report above suggests that the city's main water line system tested positive for "amoeba", with further identification pending. ProMED would welcome information that clarifies links between this outbreak, presumably due to _E. histolytica_, to one or more contaminated water sources.

References
------------
1. Ma JY, Li MY, Qi ZZ, et al. Waterborne protozoan outbreaks: an update on the global, regional, and national prevalence from 2017 to 2020 and sources of contamination. Sci Total Environ. 2022; 806(Pt 2): 150562; <https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2021.150562>.
2. Onichandran S, Kumar T, Salibay C C, et al. Waterborne parasites: a current status from the Philippines. Parasites Vectors. 2014; 7(244); <https://doi.org/10.1186/1756-3305-7-244>.
3. Rivera W L, De Jesus II F C, De Cadiz A E. _Entamoeba histolytica_ infections in a slum community in Manila, Philippines, as detected by stool ELISA. Ann Parasitol. 2021; 67(4): 757-762; <https://doi.org/10.17420/ap6704.393>.
4. Rivera W L, Aquino I M C, De Cadiz A E, et al. Prevalence of _Entamoeba histolytica_ and _Entamoeba dispar_ among residents of an urban slum area in Manila, Philippines, as detected by the polymerase chain reaction. Ann Parasitol. 2020; 66(4): 547-553. doi: 10.17420/ap6604.297 [incorrect doi - Copy Ed.TW]; <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33789027/>.

For a political map of Negros Occidental province, see <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negros_Occidental>. - Mod.LXL]

[See Also:

column2:
Q FEVER - GERMANY: (LOWER SAXONY)
*********************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: Hamburger Morgenpost [in German, trans. Sabine Zentis, edited]
<https://www.mopo.de/im-norden/seltenes-q-fieber-in-der-naehe-von-lueneburg-ausgebrochen-schon-mehrere-infizierte/>


Q fever has been detected in several people in Amt Neuhaus (Lüneburg district). It is a disease that can be transmitted from animals to humans and can manifest itself with flu-like symptoms. "Some are clinically ill; others may not have any symptoms," district spokeswoman Marion Junker said on Monday [27 Feb 2023]. "It's a disease that's coming up from the south because of climate change."

Q fever is a disease caused by the bacterium _Coxiella burnetii_. People can become infected by inhaling small droplets or dust. There have been cases where infection could be detected at 2 km [1.2 mi] distance from sick animals: direct contact with animals is therefore not always necessary. Nevertheless, according to the Robert Koch Institute (RKI), people who have close contact with animals, such as butchers, animal fur processors, animal keepers, and veterinary staff, are more at risk than others. There is also a hazard for laboratory personnel.

In animals, an infection can be asymptomatic, so that without regular sampling, animal owners do not necessarily notice when their animals are ill. Infections reported in Germany have increased, especially since 1995.

--
communicated by:
Sabine Zentis
Castleview English Longhorns
Gut Laach, D-52385 Nideggen, Germany
<cvlonghorns@aol.com>

[Lüneburg is a district in Lower Saxony, north west Germany, bordering the Netherlands. We are informed that no official notification of the event has yet been published, while local authorities are planning a meeting to give overall information to the public and the medical profession.

Query (Q) fever (or coxiellosis), a zoonotic disease notifiable to the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH), occurs in most countries. Humans generally acquire infection through airborne transmission from animal reservoirs, especially from domestic ruminants, but other domestic and wildlife animals (pets, rabbits, birds, etc) can be involved. The causal agent is the obligate intracellular bacterium, _Coxiella burnetii_, which displays different morphological forms in its developmental cycle. Some forms can survive extracellularly and even accumulate in the environment.

Abortions in _C. burnetii_-infected domestic ruminants are accompanied by massive excretion of the bacteria that spread into the environment. This is the most important excretion route of _C. burnetii_, as up to 109 organisms are excreted per gram of placenta tissue. (see WOAH terrestrial manual at <https://www.woah.org/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/3.01.17_Q_FEVER.pdf>).

In Europe, the first cases of Q fever in humans were reported from German soldiers in Greece in June 1941, and subsequently in Germany shortly after World War II, and in the Netherlands in 1956. Human cases and outbreaks are attributed to infection in sheep and goats. Abortion in cattle is a less prominent feature of infection compared with that in sheep and goats, and considered less likely to shed the pathogen. It was speculated that the prominent role of sheep and goats as reservoirs of infection during human outbreaks might be related to the highly seasonal nature of their reproduction cycle, to the larger herd sizes in these species, to differences in management and housing between these species, to the relative importance of shedding and abortions after _C. burnetii_ infection, and possibly to species-related differences in the virulence for humans of _C. burnetii_. Some of the above information is derived from a review addressing Q fever in 4 European countries, undertaken by European Union experts in the aftermath of the major Q fever epidemic in the Netherlands, considered to be the largest community outbreak ever recorded (see Georgiev M, Afonso A, Neubauer H, et al. Q fever in humans and farm animals in 4 European countries, 1982 to 2010. Euro Surveill. 2013; 18(8): pii=20407; <https://doi.org/10.2807/ese.18.08.20407-en>).

The Dutch event involved a cluster of 4026 human cases, notified between 2007 and 2010 (ProMED post 20100930.3546). This outbreak was clearly linked to a dairy goat farm with more than 400 adult goats, where an abortion wave due to _C. burnetii_ was confirmed, starting a few weeks before the first human cases were seen. The said event, and others -- of smaller dimensions, in the Netherlands and in several German states -- were associated with urban areas. Proximity to farm animals and contact with infected animals or their birth products have been identified as the most important risk factors for human disease. Intrinsic farm factors, such as production systems and management, influence the number of outbreaks in an area.

Prompted by the outbreak of Q fever in the Netherlands, concerns were raised by the European Commission about factors contributing to the development of large, sustained Q fever outbreaks.

The statement about Q fever "coming up from the south because of climate change" is in need of clarification. An epidemiological investigation, involving public and animal health investigators, is warranted. - Mod.AS

Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized _C. burnetii_; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta. _C. burnetii_ can be dispersed for a considerable distance in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing _C. burnetii_ to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm, a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (<https://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2>).

Ingestion of contaminated unpasteurized milk or milk products is a less common mode of transmission (<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25692216/>). Rarely, Q fever has been spread person to person through blood transfusion; from a pregnant woman to her fetus; or through sex, infected breast milk, clustered familial cases, and nosocomial infection during delivery or autopsies (<https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/58/11/e146/2895430> and <https://www.cdc.gov/qfever/transmission/index.html>). In 2014, a Q fever outbreak occurred in Canadian and US travelers to Germany, where they received live sheep cell therapy (see ProMED post 20170416.4974554).

Although often asymptomatic, the infection can present acutely 2-3 weeks after exposure as atypical pneumonia or hepatitis, or as a chronic disease (mainly endocarditis/endarteritis) (<http://cmr.asm.org/content/12/4/518.short>). The patients at highest risk for chronic Q fever are those with pre-existing valvular heart disease, a vascular graft, an arterial aneurysm, and pregnancy (<https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6203a1.htm>). Unusual complications include glomerulonephritis and rhabdomyolysis (<http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08860220701460178>). Post-Q fever fatigue syndrome has been reported in up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever.

During pregnancy, Q fever may result in obstetric complications, such as placental infection, spontaneous abortion, intrauterine growth retardation, intrauterine fetal death, premature delivery, and maternal chronic Q fever (<https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/45/5/548/273863>).

Diagnosis of Q fever can usually be confirmed by serology (<https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/qfever/>). In acute Q fever, phase II antibodies are usually much higher than phase I antibodies and are detectable by indirect immunofluorescence 2 to 3 weeks after onset of illness. In chronic Q fever, phase I antibody titers are much greater than phase II titers. Phase I antibody titers of 1:800 or higher are considered diagnostic in endocarditis patients for chronic Q fever.

Tetracyclines are considered the antibiotics of choice for treatment of acute Q fever. Q fever endocarditis is treated with the combination of doxycycline plus hydroxychloroquine for at least 18 months (<https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/414865>).

A human vaccine for Q fever is used in Australia, but it is not available in the United States. In Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in "at-risk" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism (<https://immunisationhandbook.health.gov.au/vaccine-preventable-diseases/q-fever>). - Mod.ML

ProMED map of Lower Saxony, Germany: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708632,2856>.]

[1] Ghana (Northern Region)
Date: Sun 26 Feb 2023
Source: GH Headlines, a Pulse.com report [edited]
<https://ghheadlines.com/agency/pulse/20230226/159368620/northern-region-records-120-cases-of-measles>


About 120 cases of measles had been recorded in the Northern region by end of December 2022 due to the shortage of essential vaccines, the Paediatric Society of Ghana has disclosed.

Dr Agyeiwaa Boundie, a member of the Paediatric Society of Ghana in a discussion on Citi TV on [Sat 25 Feb 2023], has implored the government to ensure that the country never runs out of vaccines for children. "A total of 120 cases of measles were recorded in the Northern Region. So that tells you the situation is severe. Many of the children were either not vaccinated or didn't know their vaccination status. This has happened and this should never happen again. Our children are vulnerable ... this should never happen in our nation again."

The Ghana Health Service (GHS) has attributed the shortage of vaccines used for routine immunization of babies to the depreciation of the Ghana Cedi (currently 1 USD is equivalent to about 12.7 Ghanaian Cedis).

Under the routine vaccination program, Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG), a vaccine for tuberculosis (TB) disease; oral polio vaccine 0 (OPV); measles-rubella; meningitis and diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whooping cough) are administered. Vaccines against polio, hepatitis B and Haemophilus influenza type B (DPT/Hep B/ Hib 1) and 6 infectious diseases that are particularly dangerous to babies are also among those administered.

The shortage of vaccines has the potential to increase the vulnerability of children to the diseases the vaccines seek to protect them against.

[byline: Reymond Awusei Johnson]

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

******
[2]  South Africa (Western Cape)
Date: Mon 27 Feb 2023
Source: Biz Community [edited]
<https://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/330/236321.html>


In the midst of a growing measles outbreak in the Cape Metro, the City of Cape Town's health department is urging parents to vaccinate their children. The outbreak was declared by The National Institute for Communicable Diseases. The most recent number of measles cases in 6 affected provinces has risen past 600, a tally that cites this as SA's worst outbreak in more than a decade.

A national measles vaccination campaign is under way, which kicked off after an outbreak in 5 other provinces. Children between the ages of 6 months and 14 years and 11 months will receive an additional measles vaccination at public schools, crèches and City of Cape Town clinics. Since [6 Feb 2023], 168 056 measles vaccines have been administered across the province to children in this age group.

"The vaccine is safe and provides lifelong immunity against the disease. We can protect our children from serious complications of measles such as diarrhoea, dehydration, middle-ear infection, brain infection (encephalitis), blindness, and even death," said the city's mayoral committee member for community services and health, Patricia Van der Ross.

City Health staff are visiting public schools and crèches to drop off the measles campaign pamphlets and consent forms. "Parents and caregivers are urged to complete the consent form for their children as they cannot be vaccinated without consent. Children can also be taken to their nearest clinic for vaccination. The measles vaccine is very effective at preventing measles, and with a declared outbreak, it is our duty to ensure our children are protected," said Van der Ross.

If a child is absent from creche or school on vaccination day, parents or caregivers can take the child to their nearest clinic where the additional measles vaccine will be administered. Currently, children receive the first measles vaccination at the age of 6 months and the 2nd one at 12 months, as part of the national immunisation schedule. The vaccine is free at all City clinics.

--
communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

******
[3] India [Madhya Pradesh state]
Date: Fri 24 Feb 2023 10:50 IST
Source: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]
<https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/indore-reports-11-new-measles-cases/articleshow/98194960.cms>


Indore district [Madhya Pradesh state] has reported 11 new cases of measles, taking the tally to 31 on [Thu 23 Feb 2023].

With this, the infection spread to at least 3 new areas - Bombay Bazaar (1), Janki Nagar (2), and Madina Nagar (2). The other new cases were reported from Khajrana (1), Chandan Nagar (3), and Juna Risala (2). The cases were mainly concentrated in areas like Khajrana, Chandan Nagar, Azad Nagar, and Juni Indore under the limits of the city.

District immunisation in-charge Dr Tarun Gupta said, "The cases are detected through an intensified survey in affected areas and its surrounding. The total case tally stood at 31 for measles and one for rubella."

In the affected areas, the authorities surveyed 5000 houses to detect 400 unvaccinated kids. Of them, 375 were administered vaccines. The cases are reported among kids aged 9 months to 19 years, show records. Further, 800 kids were administered drops of vitamin A supplement under a drive.

--
communicated by:
ProMED-SoAs

["Measles is an acute viral illness caused by a virus in the family paramyxovirus, genus _Morbillivirus_. Measles is characterized by a prodrome of fever (as high as 105 deg F [40.6 deg C]) and malaise, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis, followed by a maculopapular rash. The rash spreads from the head to the trunk to the lower extremities. Measles is usually a mild or moderately severe illness. However, measles can result in complications such as pneumonia, encephalitis, and death"
<https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/surv-manual/chpt07-measles.html>.

"Measles is one of the world's most contagious diseases. It is spread by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, or direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children are at the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death. Unvaccinated pregnant women are also at risk. Any non-immune person (who has not been vaccinated or was vaccinated but did not develop immunity) can become infected.

"Routine measles vaccination for children, combined with mass immunization campaigns in countries with high case and death rates, are key public health strategies to reduce global measles deaths" <https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/measles>.

"Indore is the largest and most populous city in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh. It serves as the headquarters of both Indore District and Indore Division" (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indore>. - Mod.GS]

******
[4] USA (Kentucky)
Date: Sat 25 Feb 2023
Source: Lexington Herald Leader [edited]
<https://www.kentucky.com/news/local/counties/jessamine-county/article272599543.html>


A case of measles has been confirmed in a Jessamine County resident who attended the spiritual revival at Asbury University on [Sat 18 Feb 2023], and Kentucky public health officials warned that people who attended the event that day may have been exposed. The resident was not vaccinated against the respiratory virus, the Kentucky Cabinet for Health and Family Services said in a news release on [Fri 24 Feb 2023]. 

The state said no other information will be released about the person. "Anyone who attended the revival on [18 Feb 2023] may have been exposed to measles," Dr Steven Stack, commissioner of the Kentucky Department for Public Health said in the news release. "Attendees who are unvaccinated are encouraged to quarantine for 21 days and to seek immunization with the measles vaccine, which is safe and effective."

The Jessamine County Health Department said in a Facebook post that it is working with health officials at Asbury to coordinate a measles vaccine clinic next week [w/e 5 Mar 2023].

Anyone who might have been exposed at Asbury who develops symptoms was asked to isolate from others and call their "medical provider, urgent care, or emergency department to seek testing", regardless of whether they have been vaccinated, Stack said. "Please do not arrive at a health care facility without advance notice so that others will not be exposed," he said.

The state said it is collaborating with Asbury, the Jessamine County Health Department and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. "All reported cases of measles are thoroughly investigated in Kentucky," the release stated.

The Cabinet for Health and Family Services said this is the 3rd case of measles in Kentucky in 3 months. The first was confirmed in Christian County in December and was linked to an outbreak in Ohio that sickened more than 80 children. The other case was reported in Powell County last month and did not have any known connections to the Ohio outbreak. The state said each of those cases was investigated and determined not to pose a threat to public health.

Children typically get their first dose of the MMR vaccine, which protects against measles, mumps, and rubella, between 12 and 15 months of age, and a 2nd dose is administered between ages 4 and 6 years. The Kentucky Department for Public Health said it is working with local health departments to encourage MMR vaccination in areas with lower vaccination rates. Recently released data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention indicate that Kentucky's rate of MMR vaccination among kindergarten students is among the lowest in the United States.

Kentucky residents can check their vaccination records through the Kentucky Immunization Registry Public Portal.

[byline: Karla Ward]  

--
communicated by:
ProMED

["For over 3 weeks, worshippers flew from across the country for the spontaneous event (that is, revival at Asbury University), standing in line outside of the college's main chapel for an opportunity to take part in the singing, praying and discussion unfolding within <https://www.cnn.com/2023/02/18/us/asbury-revival-christian-what-is-cec>. The event began on 8 Feb 2023 and ended on 23 Feb 2023, according to CNN affiliate WTVQ, and it hosted 50 000 - 70 000 people, CNN affiliate WKYT reported." <https://www.cnn.com/2023/02/25/health/kentucky-measles-asbury-revival/index.html>

Measles is a highly contagious respiratory virus that is spread through the air. A small number of cases are capable of quickly producing epidemics in high-risk, unvaccinated populations. For measles, R0 is often cited to be 12-18, which means that each person with measles would, on average, infect 12-18 other people in a totally susceptible population. But this number will vary depending on local conditions and level of pre-existing immunity. Mass events such as the one described above lend themselves to rapid virus spread. - Mod.LK

column2:
TRICHOMONIASIS, AVIAN - USA: (CALIFORNIA) PIGEON
************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023
Source: California Department of Fish and Wildlife [edited]
<https://wildlife.ca.gov/News/avian-parasite-responsible-for-band-tailed-pigeon-deaths>


Since early February [2023], the California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW) and many wildlife rehabilitation centers have received increased reports of sick and dead band-tailed pigeons from residents. Most reports have come from locations along California's Central Coast, the San Francisco Bay Area and foothill communities in the Sierra Nevada Mountains.

CDFW's Wildlife Health Laboratory has evaluated birds from several locations and determined the cause of death to be avian trichomonosis [ProMED uses the synonymous term "trichomoniasis"], a disease caused by a protozoan parasite, typically _Trichomonas gallinae_. Statewide, its estimated that roughly 200-300 band-tailed pigeons may have died of this infection so far this winter.

"Avian trichomonosis outbreaks occur periodically in band-tailed pigeons during some winters in California," said CDFW senior environmental scientist Krysta Rogers, an avian disease specialist. "Historically, larger outbreaks generally have been associated with drier conditions because the pigeons may be more likely to share a reduced number of water sources and the parasite can spread more rapidly among birds in the flock."

Band-tailed pigeons are native to California and may be unfamiliar to some residents given their mostly secretive and highly nomadic lifestyle. During winter, nearly the entire Pacific Coast population of band-tailed pigeons congregates in areas of Central to Southern California, sometimes forming relatively large flocks and seeking out acorns, their preferred food in winter.

The parasite that causes avian trichomonosis is primarily spread in water sources such as bird baths, fountains, and horse or cattle troughs where the parasite may become more concentrated. Once infected, caseous lesions ("cheese-like") may develop in the bird's mouth or throat leading to starvation or suffocation. Sick birds may appear weak, swallow repeatedly, have labored breathing, and may sit for prolonged periods. Severely affected birds may develop neurological signs such as lack of coordination or twisting of the head or neck. Band-tailed pigeons are especially susceptible to avian trichomonosis. Other bird species also may be susceptible when sharing water sources as are avian predators that may feed on infected birds.

Residents can help reduce disease transmission among birds by removing bird feeders and bird baths and emptying fountains while the pigeons are in their area. Observations of sick and dead pigeons may be reported to CDFW using the mortality reporting form. These reports are important to help document when and where birds may be impacted.

If there is a need to dispose of a dead bird, CDFW recommends wearing disposable gloves to collect the remains into a plastic bag, which may then be placed in the regular trash collection. Afterward, wash hands with soap and water. For guidance on orphaned, injured or sick live-wild birds, please contact your nearest wildlife rehabilitation center before collecting the animal.

--
communicated by:
ProMED rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi

[_Trichomonas gallinae_ is a common protozoan parasite of pigeons (Columbiformes) which principally infects the upper alimentary tract where it can cause necrotic ingluvitis. Epidemic mortalities in columbiform species are sporadically reported, and the parasite may infect other avian taxa such as birds of prey and songbirds. - Mod.PMB

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (07): CAMBODIA (PREY VENG) H5N1, ENDEMIC CLADE, 29 NEGATIVE CONTACTS TO INCLUDE SECOND POSITIVE CASE
***************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this update:
[1] Cambodia case H5N1 clade: Cambodia CDC Facebook
[2] Cambodia case: additional clade comments
[3] 29 contacts negative including the 2nd individual that previously tested positive

******
[1] Cambodia case H5N1 clade: Cambodia CDC Facebook
Date: Sat 25 Feb 2023
Source: Cambodia CDC Facebook [in Khmer, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.facebook.com/cdcmohcam>


The H5N1 bird flu virus, which is the leading cause of death of a girl in Roleang village, Romlech commune, Sithor Kandal district, is the most common bird flu virus [strain] in Cambodia during the last few years:
- The H5N1 avian influenza virus (clade 2.3.2.1c) is different from the H5N1 bird flu virus in other parts of the world.
- The follow-up on disease cases continues, while populations associated with patients continue to be monitored.
- To date, no human-to-human transmission of the H5N1 bird flu virus has been reported.

May all citizens avoid direct contact with sick or dead birds. Please join in protecting and preventing together for our health.

For more information, please contact 118.

******
[2] Cambodia case: additional clade comments
Date: Sun 26 Feb 2023
Source: Reuters [edited]
<https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/viruses-cambodian-bird-flu-cases-identified-endemic-clade-2023-02-26/>


The viruses that infected 2 people in Cambodia with H5N1 avian influenza have been identified as an endemic clade of bird flu circulating in the country, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said.

The cases reported last week had raised concerns they were caused by a new strain of H5N1, clade 2.3.4.4b, which emerged in 2020 and has caused record numbers of deaths among wild birds and domestic poultry in recent months.

But work so far suggests this is not the case.

Preliminary genetic sequencing carried out in Cambodia led its health ministry to identify the viruses as H5 clade 2.3.2.1c, which has circulated in Cambodia among birds and poultry for many years and has sporadically caused infections in people, the CDC said in a statement on Saturday [25 Feb 2023].

"Yes, this is an older clade of avian influenza that had been circulating around the region for a number of years and while it has caused human infections in the past, it has not been seen to cause human-to-human transmission. However, that doesn't mean that the threat is any less," said Erik Karlsson, director of the National Influenza Center of Cambodia and acting head of virology at the Institut Pasteur du Cambodge, which sequenced the virus.

He added that the response needed to be coordinated and swift to prevent any further spread and to limit exposure to any common source.

An investigation into the source and to detect any additional cases is ongoing, the CDC said, adding that so far there had been no indication of person-to-person spread.

Cambodia tested at least 12 people for the H5N1 strain last week, after an 11-year-old girl died from the virus in the first known transmission to humans in the country in nearly a decade.

The victim's father, who was part of a group the girl had been in contact with in a province east of the capital Phnom Penh, tested positive for the virus but did not exhibit any symptoms, Cambodia's Health Minister Mam Bunheng had said in a statement on Friday [25 Feb 2023].

Only the girl's case has been sequenced and the father's case is still being worked on, Karlsson said.

The World Health Organization said it is working with Cambodian authorities following the cases, describing the situation as worrying due to the recent rise in cases in birds and mammals.

[Byline: Juby Babu and Jennifer Rigby]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi

******
[3] 29 contacts negative including the 2nd individual that previously tested positive
Date: Sun 26 Feb 2023
Source: Khmer Times [edited]
<https://www.khmertimeskh.com/501245489/29-test-negative-for-h5n1-bird-flu-in-virus-epicentre/>


The Ministry of Health has just stated that 29 people tested for Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N1) in a village in Prey Veng province -- where an 11 year old girl died on Wednesday [22 Feb 2023] -- have all tested negative for the virus.

Dr. Yok Sambath, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Health, said that the H5N1 test results were conducted by the Institut Pasteur and the Institute of Public Health last night.

"Despite the negative results of all the bird flu cases, all of our officials continue to work with local authorities, not just in Prey Veng, we educate all over the country, to raise awareness and disseminate bird flu education spots on television, community and social media," she said.

"In addition, our emergency response officers are continuing to monitor Prey Veng, as well as other provinces, to make sure that the disease does not spread to other provinces, so we have tested directly on stakeholders and the results is negative, including the father [of the deceased girl, who had earlier tested positive for H5N1], he is now negative, and others we are continuing to research and educate people to implement health measures.

The outbreak was announced earlier this week after an 11 year old girl from Roleang village, Romlech commune, Sithor Kandal district, Prey Veng province died of the virus. It was the 1st death in Cambodia from the virus for 10 years. In response, Cambodia's neighbours Thailand and Vietnam have raised alert levels in provinces bordering Cambodia. The WHO said it was in close contact with the Cambodian authorities about the situation, including regarding the test results of the girl's other contacts.

Influenza A virus subtype H5N1 (A/H5N1) is a subtype of the influenza A virus which can cause illness in humans and many other animal species. A bird-adapted strain of H5N1, called HPAI A(H5N1) for highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of type A of subtype H5N1, is the highly pathogenic causative agent of H5N1 flu, commonly known as avian influenza ("bird flu"). It is enzootic (maintained in the population) in many bird populations, especially in Southeast Asia.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi

[Finally, some good news on the avian influenza front although I hesitate to go that far. Sequencing showed the H5N1 virus in the Cambodia fatality was clade 2.3.2.1c which circulates endemically in Cambodia, as opposed to the 2.3.4.4b clade virus that is affecting many other areas globally. 29 contacts were also tested and found to be negative to include the victim's father who tested positive previously. This reinforces that the initial result was likely environmental contamination as opposed to true infection as I would expect the father to still be shedding live virus unless he was infected earlier than the original victim. Hopefully the Cambodian CDC can follow up with the close contacts to monitor for seroconversion as that would help complete the puzzle in terms of who was actually infected. The Cambodian CDC and their collaborators should be commended for its timely release of information as they've been a model for how to release information promptly while trying to answer key questions around the outbreak. - Mod.JH
