column2:
CANINE DISTEMPER, STREPTOCOCCUS ZOOEPIDEMICUS - USA: (TEXAS) DOG
****************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 24 Feb 2023 19:32 CST
Source: KVIA.com [edited]
<https://kvia.com/animals/2023/02/24/outbreak-of-a-deadly-disease-in-dogs-in-the-borderland/>


An outbreak of distemper and "Strep zoo" [_Streptococcus equi_ subsp. _zooepidemicus_] in dogs is being addressed immediately by the City of El Paso Animal Service, city officials say.

According to a city press release, 20 dogs tested positive for canine distemper virus, a highly contagious and deadly disease in dogs after an animal service veterinarian noticed a high volume of respiratory illness. Additionally, 2 dogs tested positive for "Strep zoo", a rare pathogen in dogs.

Due to the outbreak, animal services will be closed to the public Saturday and Sunday [25-26 Feb 2023]. They will be deep cleaning all shelter grounds, including public areas. Lost pet reclaims and foster medical appointments will be the only services conducted via curbside service.

"Distemper is endemic to the borderland region, and most other southern states, which is why we continue to educate and encourage the community to vaccinate their pets," said Dr. Tony Chacon, El Paso animal services veterinarian. "With over 700 dogs already in the shelter, the only way for us to protect the animals in the shelter and the community is to temporarily suspend non-emergency intake."

Animal services has launched a testing plan to prevent further outbreaks, starting with dogs displaying signs of the disease, then testing asymptomatic dogs. Additionally, the department says safety protocols will include carefully monitoring healthy animals who may have been exposed.

[Byline: Kerry Mannix]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

["_Streptococcus equi_ subsp. _zooepidemicus_ (_S. zooepidemicus_) has caused several outbreaks of haemorrhagic pneumonia in dogs in recent years. This highly contagious and often fatal disease is characterised by sudden onset of clinical signs including pyrexia, dypsnoea and haemorrhagic nasal discharge. Postmortem examination typically reveals pulmonary haemorrhage and pleural effusion. Histopathology demonstrates fibrino-suppurative, necrotizing and haemorrhagic pneumonia in most cases. The pathogenesis of _S. zooepidemicus_ infection in dogs is incompletely understood. Bacterial virulence factors as well as host factors may contribute to the severe outcome. _S. zooepidemicus_ occasionally causes zoonotic infections with potentially serious consequences. Canine vaccines for _S. zooepidemicus_ are currently not available, and prevention of the disease therefore relies on limiting bacterial spread by implementing stringent control measures in kennels. Further research, particularly sequence analysis of canine strains, is required to gain insights into epidemiology and pathogenesis of this emerging disease" (<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20570190/>). There is currently no vaccine for _S. zooepidemicus_.

The following information on canine distemper has been provided by the American Veterinary Medical Association (<https://www.avma.org/resources/pet-owners/petcare/canine-distemper>):

"Canine distemper is a contagious and serious disease caused by a virus that attacks the respiratory, gastrointestinal and nervous systems of puppies and dogs. The virus can also be found in wildlife such as foxes, wolves, coyotes, raccoons, skunks, mink and ferrets and has been reported in lions, tigers, leopards and other wild cats as well as seals.

"How is canine distemper spread? Puppies and dogs most often become infected through airborne exposure (through sneezing or coughing) to the virus from an infected dog or wild animal. The virus can also be transmitted by shared food and water bowls and equipment. Infected dogs can shed the virus for months, and mother dogs can pass the virus through the placenta to their puppies.

"Because canine distemper also impacts wildlife populations, contact between wild animals and domestic dogs can facilitate the spread of the virus. Canine distemper outbreaks in local raccoon populations can signal increased risk for pet dogs in the area.

"What dogs are at risk? All dogs are at risk but puppies younger than 4 months old and dogs that have not been vaccinated against canine distemper are at increased risk of acquiring the disease.

"What are the symptoms of canine distemper? Initially, infected dogs will develop watery to pus-like discharge from their eyes. They then develop fever, nasal discharge, coughing, lethargy, reduced appetite, and vomiting. As the virus attacks the nervous system, infected dogs develop circling behavior, head tilt, muscle twitches, convulsions with jaw chewing movements and salivation ('chewing gum fits'), seizures, and partial or complete paralysis. The virus may also cause the footpads to thicken and harden, leading to its nickname 'hard pad disease.'

"In wildlife, infection with canine distemper closely resembles rabies. Distemper is often fatal, and dogs surviving usually have permanent, irreparable nervous system damage.

"How is canine distemper diagnosed and treated? Veterinarians diagnose canine distemper through clinical appearance and laboratory testing. There is no cure for canine distemper infection. Treatment typically consists of supportive care and efforts to prevent secondary infections; control vomiting, diarrhea and neurologic symptoms; and combat dehydration through administration of fluids. Dogs infected with canine distemper must be separated from other dogs to minimize the risk of further infection.

"How is canine distemper prevented? Vaccination is crucial in preventing canine distemper.
- A series of vaccinations is administered to puppies to increase the likelihood of building immunity when the immune system has not yet fully matured.
- Avoid gaps in the immunization schedule and make sure distemper vaccinations are up to date.
- Avoid contact with infected animals and wildlife.
- Use caution when socializing puppies or unvaccinated dogs at parks, puppy classes, obedience classes, doggy day care and other places where dogs can congregate.
- Pet ferrets should be vaccinated against canine distemper using a USDA-approved ferret vaccine."

- Mod.TG

column3: An outbreak of distemper and "Strep zoo" [_Streptococcus equi_ subsp. _zooepidemicus_] in dogs is being addressed immediately by the City of El Paso Animal Service, city officials say.According to a city press release, 20 dogs tested positive for canine distemper virus, a highly contagious and deadly disease in dogs after an animal service veterinarian noticed a high volume of respiratory illness. Additionally, 2 dogs tested positive for "Strep zoo", a rare pathogen in dogs.Due to the outbreak, animal services will be closed to the public Saturday and Sunday [25-26 Feb 2023]. They will be deep cleaning all shelter grounds, including public areas. Lost pet reclaims and foster medical appointments will be the only services conducted via curbside service."Distemper is endemic to the borderland region, and most other southern states, which is why we continue to educate and encourage the community to vaccinate their pets," said Dr. Tony Chacon, El Paso animal services veterinarian. "With over 700 dogs already in the shelter, the only way for us to protect the animals in the shelter and the community is to temporarily suspend non-emergency intake."Animal services has launched a testing plan to prevent further outbreaks, starting with dogs displaying signs of the disease, then testing asymptomatic dogs. Additionally, the department says safety protocols will include carefully monitoring healthy animals who may have been exposed.[Byline: Kerry Mannix]--Communicated by:ProMED["_Streptococcus equi_ subsp. _zooepidemicus_ (_S. zooepidemicus_) has caused several outbreaks of haemorrhagic pneumonia in dogs in recent years. This highly contagious and often fatal disease is characterised by sudden onset of clinical signs including pyrexia, dypsnoea and haemorrhagic nasal discharge. Postmortem examination typically reveals pulmonary haemorrhage and pleural effusion. Histopathology demonstrates fibrino-suppurative, necrotizing and haemorrhagic pneumonia in most cases. The pathogenesis of _S. zooepidemicus_ infection in dogs is incompletely understood. Bacterial virulence factors as well as host factors may contribute to the severe outcome. _S. zooepidemicus_ occasionally causes zoonotic infections with potentially serious consequences. Canine vaccines for _S. zooepidemicus_ are currently not available, and prevention of the disease therefore relies on limiting bacterial spread by implementing stringent control measures in kennels. Further research, particularly sequence analysis of canine strains, is required to gain insights into epidemiology and pathogenesis of this emerging disease" (<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20570190/>). There is currently no vaccine for _S. zooepidemicus_.The following information on canine distemper has been provided by the American Veterinary Medical Association (<https://www.avma.org/resources/pet-owners/petcare/canine-distemper>):"Canine distemper is a contagious and serious disease caused by a virus that attacks the respiratory, gastrointestinal and nervous systems of puppies and dogs. The virus can also be found in wildlife such as foxes, wolves, coyotes, raccoons, skunks, mink and ferrets and has been reported in lions, tigers, leopards and other wild cats as well as seals."How is canine distemper spread? Puppies and dogs most often become infected through airborne exposure (through sneezing or coughing) to the virus from an infected dog or wild animal. The virus can also be transmitted by shared food and water bowls and equipment. Infected dogs can shed the virus for months, and mother dogs can pass the virus through the placenta to their puppies."Because canine distemper also impacts wildlife populations, contact between wild animals and domestic dogs can facilitate the spread of the virus. Canine distemper outbreaks in local raccoon populations can signal increased risk for pet dogs in the area."What dogs are at risk? All dogs are at risk but puppies younger than 4 months old and dogs that have not been vaccinated against canine distemper are at increased risk of acquiring the disease."What are the symptoms of canine distemper? Initially, infected dogs will develop watery to pus-like discharge from their eyes. They then develop fever, nasal discharge, coughing, lethargy, reduced appetite, and vomiting. As the virus attacks the nervous system, infected dogs develop circling behavior, head tilt, muscle twitches, convulsions with jaw chewing movements and salivation ('chewing gum fits'), seizures, and partial or complete paralysis. The virus may also cause the footpads to thicken and harden, leading to its nickname 'hard pad disease.'"In wildlife, infection with canine distemper closely resembles rabies. Distemper is often fatal, and dogs surviving usually have permanent, irreparable nervous system damage."How is canine distemper diagnosed and treated? Veterinarians diagnose canine distemper through clinical appearance and laboratory testing. There is no cure for canine distemper infection. Treatment typically consists of supportive care and efforts to prevent secondary infections; control vomiting, diarrhea and neurologic symptoms; and combat dehydration through administration of fluids. Dogs infected with canine distemper must be separated from other dogs to minimize the risk of further infection."How is canine distemper prevented? Vaccination is crucial in preventing canine distemper.- A series of vaccinations is administered to puppies to increase the likelihood of building immunity when the immune system has not yet fully matured.- Avoid gaps in the immunization schedule and make sure distemper vaccinations are up to date.- Avoid contact with infected animals and wildlife.- Use caution when socializing puppies or unvaccinated dogs at parks, puppy classes, obedience classes, doggy day care and other places where dogs can congregate.- Pet ferrets should be vaccinated against canine distemper using a USDA-approved ferret vaccine."- Mod.TGProMED map:Texas, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708597,245>]

column2:
BOVINE EPHEMERAL FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES) CATTLE
************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Wed 22 Feb 2023
Source: Australian Rural & Regional News [edited]
<https://arr.news/2023/02/22/cases-of-three-day-sickness-in-cattle-reported/>


Cases of bovine ephemeral fever, also known as 3-day sickness, have been reported in cattle in the area. The disease was confirmed through laboratory testing in herds across the Northern Rivers.

Three-day sickness is an insect-transmitted virus of cattle causing a high fever and pain in the muscles and joints. It is usually seen in cattle between 6 months and 2 years of age; however, if they are from outside the region, adult cattle can also experience the disease.

Affected cattle are often by themselves, off their feed, seek shade and water, shiver, drool and are lame. Signs usually last only a few days, and most cattle recover uneventfully.

Some cattle -- especially bulls and heavier conditioned cattle -- may go down and take several days to get back on their feet. Heavier cattle are at an increased risk of secondary complications as a result of being down. Pregnant cows may abort, and bulls may become infertile for up to 6 months. Milk production can drop significantly in lactating cows.

The virus appears on the North Coast in summer as the population of the biting insects which transmit the disease increases. The recent rainfall provides favourable conditions for the insect populations to increase rapidly.

Producers are encouraged to seek veterinary advice. Medication is highly effective in bringing down the fever and reducing the muscle and joint pain. Recovery tends to be quicker with less weight loss. There are several other diseases that may resemble 3-day sickness requiring alternative treatment, so veterinary diagnosis is essential.

A paddock with plenty of shade, water and feed and free of steep gullies is ideal for cattle to recover in. Any affected cattle should be provided with shade, water and feed and turned or lifted twice daily to help prevent secondary complications.

Recently recovered cattle should not be sent to the abattoirs for several weeks, to give the body a chance to heal and avoid the possibility of downgrades from any residual muscle damage.

For further advice, contact your North Coast Local Land Services District Veterinarian or private veterinary practitioner.

[Byline: Susanna Freymark]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[It should be noted that bovine ephemeral fever is not a zoonotic disease. The following is excerpted from Fenner's Veterinary Virology, 5th edition (<https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/bovine-ephemeral-fever>):

"Diagnosis: Although the clinical and epidemiological presentations of bovine ephemeral fever are highly characteristic, laboratory confirmation is required. A diagnostic increase in antibody titer, or preferably, seroconversion, can be detected by enzyme immunoassay, including blocking ELISA, by neutralization assays, which are virus specific, or by immunofluorescence or agar gel precipitin tests, which are cross-reactive with related rhabdoviruses. Although virus isolation was the traditional 'gold standard,' real-time RT-PCR assays are now routinely employed to achieve rapid (i.e., 'same day') confirmation of bovine ephemeral fever.

"Immunity, prevention, and control: Infection results in solid, long-lasting immunity. Because outbreaks tend to involve a high proportion of animals in a herd, repeat clinical episodes usually involve young animals born since previous outbreaks. Prevention by vector control is impractical in the areas of the world where this disease is prevalent. Vaccination has been used in endemic countries, including Australia, Bahrain, China, Egypt, Israel, Japan, Namibia, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, South Korea, Taiwan, the Philippines, and Turkey. Both inactivated and live-attenuated vaccines are used, although repeated immunization is often required. Problems with conventional vaccines stem from their lack of potency: inactivated vaccines require more antigenic mass than it has been possible to achieve economically, and live-attenuated vaccines suffer from a loss in immunogenicity linked to the attenuation process (see Chapter 4: Antiviral Immunity and Virus Vaccines). Immunization with the bovine ephemeral fever virus G protein alone can confer protective immunity in cattle, as can recombinant vectors that express this protein." - Mod.TG

column2:
AFRICAN SWINE FEVER - ASIA (05): RUSSIA (PRIMORSKY) WILD BOAR
*************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: TASS [in Russian; machine trans., edited]
<https://tass.ru/obschestvo/17090363>


The 1st outbreak of the African swine fever virus in 2023 was detected in Primorsky, the Primorsky Interregional Directorate of Rosselkhoznadzor [Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance] reported on Monday [20 Feb 2023].

"The protocol of the Primorsky interregional veterinary laboratory of Rosselkhoznadzor dated 17 Feb 2023, confirmed a case of African swine fever (ASF) virus in the wild in the Khasan district. In particular, DNA of the African swine fever virus was found in the studied samples of pathological material taken from the corpse of a wild boar, found in a forest in the Khasan district," the agency said.

In the summer of 2019, ASF was first recorded in Primorsky, which for 3 years forced the authorities to introduce quarantine measures in different regions of the region. The last focus of African swine fever was discovered and eradicated in the Border Region of Primorsky in the spring of 2022. Specialists of hunting supervision and protected natural areas note that the number of wild boar declined dramatically during the fight against ASF. This was one of the reasons why tigers began to come out to settlements in the Far East more often in search of food.

ASF (Montgomery's disease) was first recorded in 1903 in South Africa. The virus does not pose a threat to humans but is extremely dangerous for wild and domestic pigs [and lapses in biosecurity measures favor the spread of the disease]. The disease is rapidly spreading among animals and causing serious damage to agriculture. Due to the consequences of the virus, the authorities of Primorsky in January [2023] imposed a ban on all types of wild boar hunting until 2025, since the wild boar is food for the Amur tiger and a further decline in the number of wild boar may adversely affect the population of this predator.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[African swine fever (ASF) is a devastating hemorrhagic fever of pigs with extremely high mortality rates. In affected countries, it causes huge economic losses. The importance of wildlife reservoirs for disease maintenance has been clearly demonstrated. In Eastern Europe, the disease spread into the local wild boar populations.

It is interesting that the report highlights a potential conservation impact of AFS, by the cascading effect on food shortage for Amur tigers. - Mod.PMB

ProMED map:
Khasan, Primorskiy, Russia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708581,14745>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): CAMBODIA (PREY VENG) H5N1, SPAIN FALSE POSITIVE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*****************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this posting:
[1] Cambodia (Prey Veng): 2nd case
[1] Cambodia (Prey Veng): 2nd case
[3] Spain (Castille La Mancha): 2 false positive humans, 2022

******
[1] Cambodia: 2nd case
Date: Fri 24 Feb 2023
Source: Khmer Times [edited]
<https://www.khmertimeskh.com/501245030/2nd-case-of-h5n1-bird-flu-in-cambodia-confirmed/>


The Ministry of Health has just issued a statement confirming the discovery of a second case of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in Prey Veng province -- the father of an 11-year-old girl who died from the virus on Wednesday [22 Feb 2023].

The outbreak is centered around Roleang village, Romlech commune, Sithor Kandal district, Prey Veng province.

The Ministry says that after the girl's death, the emergency research work team of the Ministry of Health in collaboration with local authorities and Prey Veng Provincial Health Department, together with health partners, arrived at the village immediately on [23 Feb 2023].

The emergency response team collected samples from 12 people. One of the 12 samples -- taken from a 49-year-old man living in Roleang village -- has been confirmed as positive. The Ministry of Health states that the virus was not previously found in humans for the past 9 years in the Kingdom of Cambodia. The emergency response team has been investigating the outbreak of the H5N1 virus, is responding to national procedures, and has been working with the emergency response team, human, and veterinary vets, to find the source of the infection.

Animals and humans will continue to be tested for suspected cases to prevent transmission to others in the community in the village where the incident occurred. Public health expert Dr Quach Mengly said the disease has symptoms similar to a cold, cough, and fever and is highly life-threatening without treatment. "To prevent the infection, please avoid touching and eating sick and dead animals," he said. "Bury the dead animals properly, and wash your hands properly after that."

Influenza A virus subtype H5N1 (A/H5N1) is a subtype of the influenza A virus which can cause illness in humans and many other animal species. A bird-adapted strain of H5N1, called HPAI A(H5N1) for highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of type A of subtype H5N1, is the highly pathogenic causative agent of H5N1 flu, commonly known as avian influenza ("bird flu"). It is enzootic (maintained in the population) in many bird populations, especially in Southeast Asia.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED via ProMED-MBDS

******
[2] Cambodia: 2nd case5
Date: Fri 24 Feb 2023
Source: Reuters [edited]
<https://www.reuters.com/article/health-birdflu-cambodia-idAFL1N3540CT>


Cambodia has tested at least 12 people for the H5N1 strain of avian influenza, the health ministry said, after an 11-year-old girl died this week from the virus in the 1st known transmission to humans in the country in nearly a decade.

The victim's father, who was part of a group the girl had been in contact with in a province east of the capital Phnom Penh, tested positive for the virus but did not exhibit any symptoms, Health Minister Mam Bunheng said in a statement on Friday [24 Feb 2023].

The statement did not disclose the test results of others in the group and did not specify how the victim's father had contracted the virus, commonly known as bird flu.

The girl's case was the 1st known human infection with the H5N1 strain in the Southeast Asian country since 2014, Bunheng had said on Thursday [23 Feb 2023].

The girl from Prey Veng province was diagnosed with bird flu after falling sick with a high fever and cough on 16 Feb 2023, the statement said. When her condition deteriorated, she was transferred to the National Children's Hospital in Phnom Penh but died on Wednesday [22 Feb 2023], the health ministry said.

Since early last year [2022], bird flu has ravaged farms around the world, leading to the deaths of more than 200 million birds because of the disease or mass culls, the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH) recently told Reuters.

The World Health Organization (WHO) earlier this month [February 2023] noted the spread to mammals of H5N1 influenza but said the risk to humans remained low.

H5N1 had spread among poultry and wild birds for 25 years, WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus told a briefing, but recent reports of infections in mink, otters, and sea lions "need to be monitored closely."

Cambodian health authorities urged people not to handle dead or sick animals and birds, and to contact a hotline if anyone suspected they had been infected by the disease.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[ProMED map of Prey Veng, Cambodia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708580,68899>]

******
[3] Spain: 2 false positive humans, 2022
Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023
Source: El Español [in Spanish, trans., edited]
<https://www.elespanol.com/eldigitalcastillalamancha/region/guadalajara/20230223/afirman-trabajadores-guadalajara-contagiados-gripe-falsos-positivos/743676003_0.html>


A study by researchers from several Spanish centers published in the journal Eurosurveillance [see reference below], has indicated that the asymptomatic cases of H5N1 avian influenza in 2 workers at a chicken farm in Guadalajara [Castille-La Mancha] detected in the fall of 2022 were not real infections but, "most likely", the product of environmental contamination.

For the authors, "the absence of symptoms in both workers together with the laboratory results, which showed a very low viral load and the absence of specific H5 antibodies against the A/H5 virus, suggested that the positive PCR results were most likely due to environmental contamination."

An outbreak of avian influenza was confirmed in a poultry farm in Guadalajara on 20 Sep 2022. After that, 2 workers tested positive in a PCR test. They were in charge, among other tasks, of collecting eggs and performing routine cleaning tasks.

Neither of them had symptoms and both remained in self-isolation from the 1st positive result until a 2nd negative sample was obtained 6 days later in one case, and 9 days later in the other. Given the cases and the increasing number of outbreaks of avian influenza, there has been growing concern about the possible occurrence of human cases.

For Gustavo del Real, from the National Institute for Agricultural and Food Research and Technology (INIA-CSIC), this work clearly and thoroughly describes all the epidemiological control steps carried out in relation to the outbreak, caused by the highly virulent strain of the H5N1 subtype.

"Apparently, there has been no significant proliferation in human cells and the positivity is a consequence of the high sensitivity of the test. It should be noted that the concentration of virus particles in the air or on the premises of the affected farm can be immense given the large number of affected birds, tens of thousands, which release virus to the outside."

Likewise, Elisa Pérez, also from INIA, stated that the results are interesting, but not surprising. "It had already been commented on many occasions that these 2 positive cases in the workers of the Guadalajara farm were possibly false positives."

--
Communication by:
ProMED via ProMED-ESP

[ProMED map of Castille-La Mancha, Spain: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708580,4943>

Reference:
----------
Aznar E, Casas I, González Praetorius A, et al. Influenza A(H5N1) detection in two asymptomatic poultry farm workers in Spain, September to October 2022: suspected environmental contamination. Euro Surveill. 2023; 28(8): pii=2300107. https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2023.28.8.2300107

One of the 12 contacts tested in Cambodia, the father of the girl who died, tested positive. Based on the timeline the test was most likely PCR-based. The 2nd article above notes the individual was asymptomatic so it begs the question if he was actually infected or if the sample was positive due to environmental contamination. It is particularly important to rule out the latter, as demonstrated by the 3rd article above, highlighting the very real risk of environmental contamination leading to false positive PCR tests.

Hopefully local authorities in Cambodia will follow up with serology on all 12 close contacts to determine how many seroconverted, which would give a better idea of true infection rates and rule out environmental contamination. Genomic sequencing with/without virus isolation could also help establish the chain(s) of transmission.

We are also still within the incubation window for additional cases if the 1st case turns into a human-to-human point source. As previous posts noted, if any exposed/infected animals are still in the area they remain an ongoing risk for spillover as well.

Any additional information on test results from humans or animals in the area would be greatly appreciated as this event, now involving 2 human cases plus as yet unidentified dead animals in the area, continues to be worrisome from the standpoint of human-to-human transmission. - Mod.JH]

column2:
CONTAMINATED DRUG - EUROPE (02): (DENMARK, ICELAND) DICLOXACILLIN, MULTIDRUG RESISTANT ENTEROBACTER HORMAECHEI ST79, RECALL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
****************************************************************************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: Statens Serum Institut (SSI) [in Danish, trans., edited]
<https://www.ssi.dk/sygdomme-beredskab-og-forskning/sygdomsudbrud/udbrud-af-cpo>


11 patients have been found positive with a unique epitype of the bacterium _Enterobacter hormaechei_. What the patients have in common is that they have taken the medicine dicloxacillin in capsules from the same manufacturer. The outbreak has been discovered via the national surveillance of multi-resistant bacteria, which SSI carries out in collaboration with the clinical microbiology departments. SSI follows the development in the number of new cases.

Carbapenemase-producing organisms (CPO) are a group of bacteria that can be difficult to treat because they are resistant to the antibiotics normally used to treat serious infections. In Denmark, CPO infection is most often seen after traveling abroad or during outbreaks in Danish hospitals. In 2021, a total of 221 patients with carbapenemase-producing intestinal bacteria, which make up the majority of CPO, were detected in Denmark.

Description of the disease outbreak
----------------------------------------------
From October 2022 to January 2023, 9 CPO patients with the same unique epitype were registered: 2 cases in October 2022, 2 cases in December 2022, and 5 cases in January 2023. The cases had no relation to each other, there was no suspicion that the infection had occurred in hospital or during travel. The epitype found was so unique and characteristic that the clinical microbiology departments were contacted to clarify the cause of the outbreak.

Odense University Hospital's clinical microbiology department subsequently noticed that 3 patients who had tested positive in their laboratory had received treatment with Dicillin® capsules shortly before the outbreak bacteria was detected. They examined unopened packages of Dicillin® and found that the CPO bacteria could be grown from the surface of a capsule of Dicillin® 500 mg. Furthermore, other clinical microbiology departments and the SSI were able to confirm that all patients had been prescribed Dicillin® from the same manufacturer prior to a positive test finding of the epitype.

Against this background, the drug manufacturer Sandoz has recalled the drug Dicillin®.

A single case has been found in Iceland with the same unique outbreak bacterium, where the patient was also prescribed the same drug.

None of the Danish patients have become ill from the bacteria, and none have received treatment for the bacteria. 2 of the patients have died due to serious underlying disease, but there is no evidence that this is due to the outbreak bacteria.

As part of the investigation into the outbreak, the doctors of the affected patients have been interviewed. In continuation of this, it has now been confirmed that 2 patients in 2020 with the same unique epitype also consumed the same drug shortly before detection.

The situation is closely monitored in close cooperation with the Danish Medicines Agency, the Danish Health Authority, and the Statens Serum Institut. After the recall, a closer investigation of the outbreak will now take place, and SSI will continuously monitor whether new cases with the same type of bacteria should be discovered in collaboration with the country's clinical microbiology departments.

SSI follows up on all new suspected cases with typing of the bacteria and an interview with the patient's doctor.

Especially for healthcare professionals
---------------------------------------
Patients admitted with infection who received Dicillin® during the period September 2022-February 2023 should be investigated for CPO according to local guidelines. Until an answer is available, isolation is not recommended, but the patient is to be instructed in good hand hygiene in connection with visits to the toilet.

For patients who have received Dicillin® and who turn to their own doctor, specialist practice, outpatient clinics, etc., it is recommended that they be examined and treated as usual.

The outbreak bacterium is an intestinal bacterium that is no more disease-causing or contagious than other bacteria. Most often, you just want the bacteria in your gut, as part of your gut flora. The outbreak bacterium has so far only been seen in people who have received treatment with Dicillin®. No spread of the outbreak bacteria between patients has been seen.

The outbreak bacterium is resistant to an antibiotic commonly used to treat infections in hospitalized patients. The outbreak bacterium can still be treated, as the outbreak bacterium is sensitive to several other antibiotics. If the person has an infection with the outbreak bacteria and needs to be treated, there are several options for effective treatment.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Dicillin is a brand name for dicloxacillin in Denmark, an orally administered beta-lactam antibiotic of the penicillin class that is active against Gram-positive cocci, including methicillin-susceptible staphylococci (MSSA) and streptococci, in particular, beta-lactamase (penicillinase)-producing _Staphylococcus aureus_ that are resistant to penicillin. However, methicillin-resistant _S. aureus_ (MRSA) are resistant to dicloxacillin.

The reports above say that 9 patients (who are not related) were colonized (but not infected) by the same carbapenemase-positive organism, now identified as _Enterobacter hormaechei_ sequence type 79, in the past 4 months (October 2022 to January 2023) in Denmark. These patients had been treated with Dicillin® (500 mg capsules) from the pharmaceutical company Sandoz. _E. hormaechei_ sequence type 79 was then identified on the surface of a capsule of Dicillin® 500 mg taken from previously unopened packages of Dicillin®.

In addition, one person in Iceland who had taken dicloxacillin manufactured by Sandoz in July 2022 was said to have developed an "infection" with the same bacterium identified in the 9 patients in Denmark. Also, this organism was isolated from 2 patients in 2020 in Denmark who had taken Dicillin® shortly before isolation of _E. hormaechei_ sequence type 79.

It is likely that several lots of dicloxacillin manufactured by Sandoz, called Dicillin® in Denmark and Staklox® in Iceland, have been contaminated since affected patients are located in 2 different European countries, and dates of exposure extend from 2020 to 2023. All dicloxacillin is being recalled by Sandoz in Denmark and Iceland. However, we are not told which lots of dicloxacillin are affected, where the affected lots of the drug were manufactured and bottled, or how widely these lots have been distributed.

More information on this outbreak would be greatly appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML

Iceland: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708574,38>]

column2:
HEARTLAND VIRUS - USA: (MARYLAND OR VIRGINIA) FATAL
***************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023
Source: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [abridged, edited]
<https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/29/5/22-1488_article>


ref: Liu S, Kannan S, Meeks M, et al. Fatal case of Heartland virus disease acquired in the mid-Atlantic region, United States. Fatal case of Heartland virus disease acquired in the Mid-Atlantic Region, United States. Emerg Infect Dis. 2023; 29(5). Online ahead of print
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
--------
Heartland virus (HRTV) disease is an emerging tick-borne illness in the midwestern and southern United States. We describe a reported fatal case of HRTV infection in the Maryland and Virginia region, states not widely recognized to have human HRTV disease cases. The range of HRTV could be expanding in the United States.

The study
---------
The patient was a man in his late 60s who had a medical history of splenectomy from remote trauma, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. He was seen at an emergency department in November 2021 for 5 days of fever, nonbloody diarrhea, dyspnea, myalgias, and malaise. At initial examination, he appeared fatigued but was alert and oriented.

The patient had homes in rural areas of Maryland and Virginia and had not traveled outside this area in the previous 3 months. He spent time outdoors on his properties but did not recall attached ticks or tick bites.

On day 7 after symptom onset, the patient returned to the emergency department with confusion, an unsteady gait, and new fecal and urinary incontinence; he was admitted for inpatient management. He had progressive encephalopathy with hyponatremia and rising transaminases (Table).

The patient's clinical course continued to deteriorate. He had acute respiratory failure, renal failure, and cardiac arrest. He was transitioned to comfort care and died on day 13 after symptom onset.

Conclusions
-----------
HRTV disease has been reported in > 50 patients in states across the midwestern and southern United States (1-7). A bite from an _Amblyomma americanum_ tick is the only known means of environmental HRTV transmission (1). Corresponding to _A. americanum_ tick seasonal activity, all reported cases have occurred during April-September, and symptoms developed during June in most case patients (1,3). Because the incubation period for HRTV is estimated to be 2 weeks, this patient was likely infected in late October. Adult ticks are minimally active at that time; however, larval ticks can become infected with HRTV and can still be observed during October (1,14). We suspect this patient was bitten by larval ticks unknowingly because of their small size, and that the bite marks healed before his clinical signs and symptoms appeared.

Maryland and Virginia fall within the _A. americanum_ tick distribution area, but we found no previous reports of HRTV illness from those states during a literature search, and CDC had no reported cases from those states. Among 193 ticks collected during tick drags of both properties, no HRTV-infected vectors were found, but this result does not exclude HRTV in either state. Previous studies report low overall minimum infection rates among _A. americanum_ ticks from other states, ranging from 0.4 to 11/1000 ticks (1 infected tick/90-2174 collected) (1,8,10,11). We suspect the Virginia property was the likely location of infection, based on the number of ticks VDH collected while sampling an area that the patient frequented 10-14 days before symptom onset and because fewer ticks were collected from the Maryland property (Appendix).

The patient's clinical and laboratory findings were consistent with HLH [hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis] secondary to HRTV infection. HLH has been documented in several cases of infection with the related _Bandavirus_, severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome virus, and in at least 1 case of HRTV infection (1,4). Reports showed corticosteroids and ribavirin did not effectively treat severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome-triggered HLH, but preliminary clinical data shows potential benefit from favipiravir (1,15). Currently, clinical management for HRTV infection is supportive care (3).

We hypothesize that HRTV infection is underrecognized and mainly diagnosed when severe disease leads to additional testing at referral centers. Although lack of responsiveness to appropriate antimicrobial agents for bacterial tickborne illness might suggest severe disease (2), self-limited disease likely is undiagnosed or diagnosed as another tickborne disease. Because tick ranges are increasing overall, incidence of previously regional tickborne infections, such as HRTV, likely will continue to increase. Expanding testing capabilities for arbovirus and tick-borne infections, including multiplex testing, would enable real-time assessment and management of patients with potential arboviral and other tick-borne infections.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The full article, including figures, appendix, and references is available at the source URL above.

This article reports a Heartland virus (HRTV) human infection in a new locality in the US: Maryland or, more likely, Virginia. The geographic area where HRTV infections have occurred in humans has been increasing in the eastern and midwestern states. The CDC indicates that as of November 2022, Heartland virus disease cases have been identified in residents from Arkansas, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Missouri, New York, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, and Virginia (<https://www.cdc.gov/heartland-virus/statistics/index.html>). The Virginia case may be the one described in the report above.

A 2015 report indicates that HRTV infects wildlife over an even wider geographic area. Of 1428 animals, 103 were seropositive: 55 deer, 33 raccoons, 11 coyotes, and 4 moose. 13 states had seropositive animals: Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Maine, Missouri, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, and Vermont (see reference below). The geographic range of infected wildlife will likely have widened over the 8 years since that study was published.

Reference
---------
Riemersma KK, Komar N. Heartland virus neutralizing antibodies in vertebrate wildlife, United States, 2009-2014. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(10): 1830-1833; <https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2110.150380>

It would be interesting to have additional surveillance of human cases with clinical pictures compatible with HRTV infections, not only in the states where the CDC reports cases but in surrounding ones and in a broader geographic area where antibodies are found in wild mammals. Surveillance of _A. americanum_ ticks would also be of interest. - Mod.TY

Maryland, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708571,223>
Virginia, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708571,247>]

He had progressive encephalopathy with hyponatremia and rising transaminases (Table).The patient's clinical course continued to deteriorate. He had acute respiratory failure, renal failure, and cardiac arrest. He was transitioned to comfort care and died on day 13 after symptom onset.Conclusions-----------HRTV disease has been reported in > 50 patients in states across the midwestern and southern United States (1-7). A bite from an _Amblyomma americanum_ tick is the only known means of environmental HRTV transmission (1). Corresponding to _A. americanum_ tick seasonal activity, all reported cases have occurred during April-September, and symptoms developed during June in most case patients (1,3). Because the incubation period for HRTV is estimated to be 2 weeks, this patient was likely infected in late October. Adult ticks are minimally active at that time; however, larval ticks can become infected with HRTV and can still be observed during October (1,14). We suspect this patient was bitten by larval ticks unknowingly because of their small size, and that the bite marks healed before his clinical signs and symptoms appeared.Maryland and Virginia fall within the _A. americanum_ tick distribution area, but we found no previous reports of HRTV illness from those states during a literature search, and CDC had no reported cases from those states. Among 193 ticks collected during tick drags of both properties, no HRTV-infected vectors were found, but this result does not exclude HRTV in either state. Previous studies report low overall minimum infection rates among _A. americanum_ ticks from other states, ranging from 0.4 to 11/1000 ticks (1 infected tick/90-2174 collected) (1,8,10,11). We suspect the Virginia property was the likely location of infection, based on the number of ticks VDH collected while sampling an area that the patient frequented 10-14 days before symptom onset and because fewer ticks were collected from the Maryland property (Appendix).The patient's clinical and laboratory findings were consistent with HLH [hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis] secondary to HRTV infection. HLH has been documented in several cases of infection with the related _Bandavirus_, severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome virus, and in at least 1 case of HRTV infection (1,4). Reports showed corticosteroids and ribavirin did not effectively treat severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome-triggered HLH, but preliminary clinical data shows potential benefit from favipiravir (1,15). Currently, clinical management for HRTV infection is supportive care (3).We hypothesize that HRTV infection is underrecognized and mainly diagnosed when severe disease leads to additional testing at referral centers. Although lack of responsiveness to appropriate antimicrobial agents for bacterial tickborne illness might suggest severe disease (2), self-limited disease likely is undiagnosed or diagnosed as another tickborne disease. Because tick ranges are increasing overall, incidence of previously regional tickborne infections, such as HRTV, likely will continue to increase. Expanding testing capabilities for arbovirus and tick-borne infections, including multiplex testing, would enable real-time assessment and management of patients with potential arboviral and other tick-borne infections.--Communicated by:ProMED[The full article, including figures, appendix, and references is available at the source URL above.This article reports a Heartland virus (HRTV) human infection in a new locality in the US: Maryland or, more likely, Virginia. The geographic area where HRTV infections have occurred in humans has been increasing in the eastern and midwestern states. The CDC indicates that as of November 2022, Heartland virus disease cases have been identified in residents from Arkansas, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Missouri, New York, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, and Virginia (<https://www.cdc.gov/heartland-virus/statistics/index.html>). The Virginia case may be the one described in the report above.A 2015 report indicates that HRTV infects wildlife over an even wider geographic area. Of 1428 animals, 103 were seropositive: 55 deer, 33 raccoons, 11 coyotes, and 4 moose. 13 states had seropositive animals: Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Maine, Missouri, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, and Vermont (see reference below). The geographic range of infected wildlife will likely have widened over the 8 years since that study was published.Reference---------Riemersma KK, Komar N. Heartland virus neutralizing antibodies in vertebrate wildlife, United States, 2009-2014. Emerg Infect Dis. 2015; 21(10): 1830-1833; <https://doi.org/10.3201/eid2110.150380>It would be interesting to have additional surveillance of human cases with clinical pictures compatible with HRTV infections, not only in the states where the CDC reports cases but in surrounding ones and in a broader geographic area where antibodies are found in wild mammals. Surveillance of _A. americanum_ ticks would also be of interest. - Mod.TYProMED maps:Maryland, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708571,223>Virginia, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708571,247>]

[A 13 Dec 2022 report indicated that India has 23 confirmed mpox cases up to 8 Dec 2022 (<https://www.udayavani.com/english-news/23-monkeypox-cases-reported-in-india-till-dec-8-this-year-mos-for-health-bharati-pravin-pawar>). The 23-case total is not yet reflected in the report above. - Mod.TY

This is a rather short update, as this report represents only 3 days of data globally. The same concerns remain from our last post about upcoming international gatherings, travel, and the spread of the virus. - Mod.CS]

******
[2] Belgium: persistent morbidity in clade IIb mpox patients
Date: Thu 16 Feb 2023
Source: EuroSurveillance [edited]
<https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2023.28.7.2300072>


Citation: Berens-Riha N, Bracke S, Rutgers J, et al. Persistent morbidity in clade IIb mpox patients: interim results of a long-term follow-up study, Belgium, June to November 2022. Euro Surveill. 2023; 28: 2300072.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

While mpox was well characterised during the 2022 global clade IIb outbreak, little is known about persistent morbidity. We present interim results of a prospective cohort study of 95 mpox patients assessed 3-20 weeks post-symptom onset. Two-thirds of participants had residual morbidity, including 25 with persistent anorectal and 18 with genital symptoms. Loss of physical fitness, new-onset/worsened fatigue and mental health problems were reported in 36, 19 and 11 patients, respectively. These findings require attention by healthcare providers.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[This article highlights the importance of preventive action and education to avoid long-term harm to the health of people. While most educational campaigns have focused on addressing risky behavior, the necessity of vaccination, and the need for early detection, there seems to be a lack of understanding or emphasis on the sequelae related to mpox. - Mod.CS]

column2:
ADENOVIRUS - INDIA (02): (WEST BENGAL) FATAL
********************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023
Source: Mint [abridged, edited]
<https://www.livemint.com/news/india/another-adenovirus-death-in-west-bengal-teenager-dies-in-kolkata-hospital-11677127838262.html>


Adenovirus has claimed another life in West Bengal. The victim is a Kharagpur-born 13-year-old girl. Throughout the previous week, she was admitted to Peerless Hospital. The young girl's name is [UR]. She reportedly succumbed to death on 22 Feb 2023 at 8:30 AM, local media reports claimed.

The girl, who had been diagnosed with Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) Type 2 at the age of 2, was undergoing treatment at the Kolkata hospital for the past one week.

[UR] began having trouble walking and getting out of bed at a young age. She was able to sit and stand with the use of a knee, ankle and foot orthosis (KAFO), but she was unable to walk unassisted. She was a girl with special needs.

[UR] wanted to pursue higher studies and aspired to be a classical singer. Her family hoped that her wings would not be tied by the shackles of this dreadful disease that was taking away her abilities bit by bit, tweeted Cure SMA India in February 2019.

Adenovirus is the 3rd greatest worry after coronavirus and dengue. Before this, 11 children reportedly passed away this winter due to the virus in West Bengal. Health workers in Kolkata have been told to be more alert about flu-like symptoms in youngsters in order to identify and treat probable adenovirus cases early.

[Byline: Sounak Mukhopadhyay]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Key personal details on the victim above have been abridged as they allowed for ready identification. This marks the 12th adenovirus associated death in India this winter (2022-2023). SMA Type 2 develops during childhood although many SMA Type 2 patients live into adulthood. The disease predisposes them to pneumonia and breathing difficulties (<https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/14505-spinal-muscular-atrophy-sma>). This increases the risk of severe illness with multiple respiratory pathogens to include adenovirus. - Mod.JH

ProMED map:
West Bengal State, India: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708570,323>]

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (05): CAMBODIA (PREY VENG) H5N1, MORE CASES SUSPECTED
****************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 23 Feb 2023
Source: Khmer Times [edited]
<https://www.khmertimeskh.com/501244375/after-death-of-girl-yesterday-12-more-detected-with-h5n1-bird-flu/>


Ms. Youk Sambath, secretary of state of the Ministry of Health, has confirmed that the Ministry of Health's emergency response team has found 12 more people infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in Prey Veng province.

The news follows the death yesterday of an 11-year-old girl from HPAI A(H5N1) in Roleang village, Romlech commune, Sithor Kandal district, Prey Veng province.

The secretary of state stated that 4 of the affected people have begun to show symptoms. She added that the emergency response team took their samples for analysis at a laboratory in Phnom Penh, and the results will be released tomorrow [24 Feb 2023].

Ms. Youk Sambath also said that the Ministry of Health's emergency response team will continue to search for those affected by bird flu in schools tomorrow [24 Feb 2023].

With the discovery of the infected people, Ms. Youk Sambath called on the villagers to increase vigilance and health care and follow the instructions of professional officials.

Influenza A virus subtype H5N1 (A/H5N1) is a subtype of the influenza A virus that can cause illness in humans and many other animal species.

A bird-adapted strain of H5N1, called HPAI A(H5N1) for highly pathogenic avian influenza virus of type A of subtype H5N1, is the highly pathogenic causative agent of H5N1 flu, commonly known as avian influenza ("bird flu").

It is enzootic (maintained in the population) in many bird populations, especially in Southeast Asia.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi

[It appears that the above text referring to 12 more confirmed cases is in error since the results are still pending. The 4 symptomatic cases would seem to be highly suggestive of either a larger transmission event from the animal point source, or evidence of human-to-human transmission. It will be important to rule the latter out via monitoring as well as ensuring that any symptomatic animals are appropriately euthanized and disposed of to eliminate any further virus spillover. - Mod.JH

ProMED map of Prey Veng Province, Cambodia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708549,68899>]

column2:
CANINE DISTEMPER - NEPAL: TIGER, CONSERVATION CONCERN
*****************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 17 Feb 2023
Source: Earth.com [edited]
<https://www.earth.com/news/canine-distemper-virus-detected-in-nepali-tigers/>


A team of scientists led by Cornell University has recently confirmed the 1st cases of canine distemper virus (CDV) in tigers and leopards in Nepal. This virus, usually affecting dogs, can cause fatal neurological diseases and thus be a significant threat to already dwindling big cat populations.

"Canine distemper virus has been repeatedly identified as a threat to wild carnivores and their conservation," said study senior author Martin Gilbert, a wild carnivore health specialist at Cornell. "This study is a 1st step to understanding the potential impact for Nepalese tiger and leopard populations."

Although scientists have already suspected that CDV can infect big cats, this is the 1st definitive proof of infection in Nepal. The experts found that 11 percent of tigers (3 out of 28) and 30 percent of leopards (6 out of 20) had antibodies to this virus, indicating that they had been infected in the past.

While relatively little is known about Nepal's leopards, studies suggest that their population is in decline due to a mixture of poaching, habitat loss, and human-wildlife conflicts. Moreover, they are also facing increasing competition caused by the expansion of the country's tiger population, which has tripled over the past 12 years (although, globally, this species remains endangered too).

As the larger and stronger species, tigers are frequently displacing leopards from national parks into areas with more people, where they often prey on street dogs. According to the researchers, these dogs may be the source of infection. "We already know CDV is circulating in the Nepali dog population, and that leopards frequently eat dogs, while tigers do not," said study co-author Jessica Bodgener, a veterinarian at Wildlife Vets International.

"When we found a greater exposure in leopards, it seemed like a good fit, but we need more evidence to be sure. And we can't forget 3 tigers also tested positive. If tigers aren't eating dogs, it raises the question, how did these animals get infected? The situation may not be straightforward." Other species, such as jackals or civets, could also act as reservoirs.

The scientists recommend several immediate actions to control the spread of the virus, including raising awareness of wildlife managers, expanding molecular testing and genetic sequencing of leopards and tigers, continuing to monitor the presence of antibodies, vaccinating dogs and potentially the big cats themselves, and -- since small, isolated populations are most at risk of CDV outbreaks -- increasing habitat connectivity through wildlife corridors.

"Since 2014, we have seen 10 leopards showing neurological disease that could be consistent with CDV infection. With increased awareness, we plan to confirm future cases and obtain genetic sequences to help determine the source of infections," concluded co-author Amir Sadaula, a veterinarian at the National Trust for Nature Conservation (NTNC).

The study is published in the journal Pathogens [see reference below].

[Byline: Andrei Ionescu]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Reference
---------
Bodgener J, Sadaula A, Thapa PJ, et al. Canine distemper virus in tigers (_Panthera tigris_) and leopards (_P. pardus_) in Nepal. Pathogens. 2023; 12(2): 203; <https://doi.org/10.3390/pathogens12020203>.

The pathogen flow at the carnivore wildlife-domestic interface is a major conservation concern, especially where feral dogs are abundant. Documentation of outbreaks in wild carnivores due to exposure to cat and dog pathogens abound throughout the world.

There have been reports of wild tigers dying due to CDV infection in Russia. Recent research suggested that native carnivores seem to be playing a role in maintaining CDV in the absence of dogs.

It is important to consider that canine distemper is not the only pathogen that domestic and wild carnivores can transmit to tigers.

There have been efforts to develop an anti-CDV vaccine to be used in tigers can be a powerful tool to avoid extinction. - Mod.PMB

column3: A team of scientists led by Cornell University has recently confirmed the 1st cases of canine distemper virus (CDV) in tigers and leopards in Nepal. This virus, usually affecting dogs, can cause fatal neurological diseases and thus be a significant threat to already dwindling big cat populations."Canine distemper virus has been repeatedly identified as a threat to wild carnivores and their conservation," said study senior author Martin Gilbert, a wild carnivore health specialist at Cornell. "This study is a 1st step to understanding the potential impact for Nepalese tiger and leopard populations."Although scientists have already suspected that CDV can infect big cats, this is the 1st definitive proof of infection in Nepal. The experts found that 11 percent of tigers (3 out of 28) and 30 percent of leopards (6 out of 20) had antibodies to this virus, indicating that they had been infected in the past.While relatively little is known about Nepal's leopards, studies suggest that their population is in decline due to a mixture of poaching, habitat loss, and human-wildlife conflicts. Moreover, they are also facing increasing competition caused by the expansion of the country's tiger population, which has tripled over the past 12 years (although, globally, this species remains endangered too).As the larger and stronger species, tigers are frequently displacing leopards from national parks into areas with more people, where they often prey on street dogs. According to the researchers, these dogs may be the source of infection. "We already know CDV is circulating in the Nepali dog population, and that leopards frequently eat dogs, while tigers do not," said study co-author Jessica Bodgener, a veterinarian at Wildlife Vets International."When we found a greater exposure in leopards, it seemed like a good fit, but we need more evidence to be sure. And we can't forget 3 tigers also tested positive. If tigers aren't eating dogs, it raises the question, how did these animals get infected? The situation may not be straightforward." Other species, such as jackals or civets, could also act as reservoirs.The scientists recommend several immediate actions to control the spread of the virus, including raising awareness of wildlife managers, expanding molecular testing and genetic sequencing of leopards and tigers, continuing to monitor the presence of antibodies, vaccinating dogs and potentially the big cats themselves, and -- since small, isolated populations are most at risk of CDV outbreaks -- increasing habitat connectivity through wildlife corridors."Since 2014, we have seen 10 leopards showing neurological disease that could be consistent with CDV infection. With increased awareness, we plan to confirm future cases and obtain genetic sequences to help determine the source of infections," concluded co-author Amir Sadaula, a veterinarian at the National Trust for Nature Conservation (NTNC).The study is published in the journal Pathogens [see reference below].[Byline: Andrei Ionescu]--Communicated by:ProMED[Reference---------Bodgener J, Sadaula A, Thapa PJ, et al. Canine distemper virus in tigers (_Panthera tigris_) and leopards (_P. pardus_) in Nepal. Pathogens. 2023; 12(2): 203; <https://doi.org/10.3390/pathogens12020203>.The pathogen flow at the carnivore wildlife-domestic interface is a major conservation concern, especially where feral dogs are abundant. Documentation of outbreaks in wild carnivores due to exposure to cat and dog pathogens abound throughout the world.There have been reports of wild tigers dying due to CDV infection in Russia. Recent research suggested that native carnivores seem to be playing a role in maintaining CDV in the absence of dogs.It is important to consider that canine distemper is not the only pathogen that domestic and wild carnivores can transmit to tigers.There have been efforts to develop an anti-CDV vaccine to be used in tigers can be a powerful tool to avoid extinction. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Nepal: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708562,139>]

column2:
ADENOVIRUS - INDIA: (WEST BENGAL) FATAL, CHILDREN
*************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023
Source: The Weather Channel [edited]
<https://weather.com/en-IN/india/health/news/2023-02-21-adenovirus-outbreak-in-west-bengal-know-all-about-it>


As temperatures rapidly change across India, many are falling sick to viral infections and flu-like cases, exacerbated by worsening pollution in many of our cities. However, in addition to this usual set of seasonal illnesses, a new contender has been wreaking havoc across West Bengal: the adenovirus.

Since the beginning of winter [2022], the disease has claimed 11 lives -- most prominently children -- and the virus was detected in 32% of respiratory infection samples tested by the National Institute of Cholera and Enteric Diseases (ICMR-NICED). As a result, hospital beds across the city are filling up quickly, with the adenovirus being a significant contributor.

What are the symptoms of adenovirus infection?
Adenoviruses typically manifest as mild cold- or flu-like symptoms in people of all ages. However, it is more common in babies and young children. While serious illness is uncommon, it can become severe for people with weakened immune systems or those with existing respiratory or cardiac problems.

According to the Centre for Disease Control (CDC), the illness can lead to common cold-like symptoms, fever, sore throat, acute bronchitis, pneumonia, conjunctivitis, as well as acute gastroenteritis, frequent peeing, and a burning sensation during peeing. These symptoms can last 2 days to weeks after contact with the virus.

How does an adenovirus infection spread?
Similar to other viral infections, adenoviruses are highly contagious and are commonly spread through the air when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or even through close personal contact such as touching an infected person or shaking their hands.

Additionally, it can also spread if someone touches their mouth, nose, and eyes after touching an object or surface contaminated with the virus. In rare cases, it can also pass through stools, such as during diaper changes.

How do I protect myself against adenoviruses?
The CDC urges people to frequently wash their hands with soap and water, and follow proper hygiene etiquette. In addition, as with COVID-19, avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands. It goes without saying that we should avoid close contact with infected since the disease is airborne.

You should call the doctor if you suspect your baby might have the virus or a weak immune system since symptoms could significantly worsen. Do also notify them if you have a high fever that persists for more than a few days, have problems with your vision, or are experiencing severe diarrhoea and vomiting.

What is the treatment for adenovirus infections?
There are no approved vaccines or antiviral medicines for patients with adenovirus infection. Since most cases are mild, symptoms can be managed by over-the-counter pain and fever medicines in the prescribed doses.

If you have the disease, get ample rest and drink plenty of fluids. Humidifiers and nose drops may help with any congestion. However, infants, babies, and children may need more intense care, such as treatment in a hospital with IV fluids, oxygen, and breathing treatment.

Which adenovirus strain is currently impacting West Bengal?
According to the ICMR-NICED, the current spike in cases can be attributed to a combination of strains 3 and 7 of the adenovirus. While strain 3 is the most commonly found genotype of the virus, strain 7 is the deadliest out of the over 100 adenovirus strains [more than 50 that can cause disease in humans] that we are aware of, making this pairing especially harmful and a cause for significant concern.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Adenoviruses can cause cold-like symptoms including fever, sore throat, pneumonia, diarrhea, and/or conjunctivitis. Adenovirus infection can strike at any age although the young, the old, and those that are immunocompromised are disproportionately affected. Adenovirus types 3, 4, and 7 are typically associated with respiratory illness, with type 7 having an association with more severe disease outcomes. It is not surprising that types 3 and 7 were both found in circulation, especially with multiple other respiratory pathogens in the mix globally, including COVID-19, influenza, and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). - Mod.JH

ProMED map:
West Bengal State, India: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708561,323>]
