column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (33): GLOBAL, HPAI H5N1, MAMMALS, ALERT, RESEARCH
*****************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

In this post:
[1] H5N1 in mammals - mink, zoonotic significance assessed
[2] H5N1 in mammals - mink, zoonotic significance assessed
[3] H5N1 in mammals - mink, zoonotic significance assessed
[4] H5N1 in mammals - red fox, zoonotic significance assessed, research

******
[1] H5N1 in mammals - mink, zoonotic significance assessed
Date: Sat 18 Feb 2023
Source: The Veterinary Record [edited]
<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36799613/>


Citation: Loeb J. Is avian influenza spreading among mammals? Vet Rec. 2023; 192(4): 143; doi: 10.1002/vetr.2736. (subscription)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) on a mink farm in Spain remains unexplained but there was "probably" some mammal-to-mammal transmission involved, one of the UK's most senior animal health experts has said.

Ian Brown, director of scientific services at the APHA [Animal and Plant Health Agency - UK] spoke to Vet Record following news that more than 50 000 mink on the farm in Galicia had to be culled as part of a "stamping out" strategy to deal with an outbreak of HPAI of a type belonging to the H5N1 group.

The outbreak occurred in October 2022, but a "rapid communication" about it did not appear in the infectious disease journal Eurosurveillance until January this year [2023] [ProMED post 20230122.8707905; see comment]. Shortly after publication, the World Health Organization (WHO) said that, while the risk to people was low, it was working out contingency plans and was in talks with vaccine manufacturers because of the human pandemic potential of H5N1.

The APHA recently confirmed it had found cases of HPAI H5N1 in several mammals, including foxes [see item 4] and otters, with the assumption being that these wild animals became infected through scavenging on dead or dying birds. It has also been recently confirmed that 4 seal carcases found in Scotland in late 2021/early 2022, which were sent to the APHA for screening, were positive for H5N1, according to the Scottish Marine Animal Strandings Scheme. Meanwhile, infection in sea lions in Peru has been confirmed, with scientists linking the virus to a mass die-off of over 500 sea lions.

Brown is the government's lead on avian influenza outbreak preparedness in the UK. He said the virus appeared to have changed in recent months in ways that gave rise to concern, explaining: "There are a number of things happening that are telling us that this virus is very, very efficient. It's now in the Americas and it's down into South America, and there are things happening there that are a concern.

"As the virus gets into other parts of the world where probably they're less experienced at dealing with it, how good is the surveillance and monitoring? And if it were to spill over into other populations, would they pick it up?" However, he said information from the WHO and World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH, formerly OIE) had helped prompt awareness.

On the infection pathway at play in the mink farm outbreak, he said there were "several possible explanations."

"It could have been contaminated raw meat products, although I think that's less likely," he said. "I believe the Spanish have excluded that. It could be that there are wild birds that have had access." He added that it was "not 100%" clear whether there had been mink-to-mink transmission but said: "We think that because of the number of animals that got infected, it probably had got from one mink cage to another."

Vet Record asked Brown whether the APHA had concerns about the possible role that rodent infestations on some UK poultry farms could be playing in outbreaks in the UK. He replied: "We are completely aware of the rodent issue. We haven't got direct evidence that rodents themselves get infected and shed virus. It's fair to say that mice are used in some laboratories as an animal to study responses [to the virus], but there's not really been any definitive work that says they harbour it and spread it among each other.

"We know rodents can access poultry houses. That's quite common, and there's rodent control. So, what's probably more likely is, where you've got an infestation, these animals forage in an environment around the farm, and that environment is also a touchpoint for wild birds that shed the virus in their faeces. So these rodents are in an environment common with wild birds.

"They can actually carry the virus in on their fur, so fomite transmission is, I think, highly plausible.

"I'm not saying the rodents are taking it in, but they've got to be a factor. Not all farms have rodent problems -- let's be clear about that -- but some do... I think this mechanical fomite transmission is something that's highly probable. We haven't got definitive evidence, but we are doing work to try and understand this."

Currently the APHA has not found cases of rats and mice being infected with HPAI. On wildlife cases, Brown said the possibility of the virus going from fox to fox or otter to otter could not be ruled out "absolutely" but added: "We've got no evidence at the moment from our surveillance that it is maintaining in those mammalian populations."

[Byline: Josh Loeb]

--
Communicated by:
Mary Marshall
<mjm2020@googlemail.com>

[The Eurosurveillance's rapid communication on the mink outbreak in Spain, published 19 Jan 2023, included the following abstract:

"In October 2022, an outbreak in Europe of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) A(H5N1) in intensively farmed minks occurred in north west Spain. A single mink farm hosting more than 50 000 minks was involved. The identified viruses belong to clade 2.3.4.4b, which is responsible of the ongoing epizootic in Europe. An uncommon mutation (T271A) in the PB2 gene with potential public health implications was found. Our investigations indicate onward mink transmission of the virus may have occurred on the affected farm."

A letter to the editor followed, addressing the said communication, published on 16 Feb 2023. It concluded: "Disruption of the 2SBS in H5N1 viruses in minks is thus far an unreported feature that they have in common with human-adapted influenza A viruses. Loss of the 2SBS may drive selection for changes in the receptor binding properties of HA, possibly resulting in increased binding to human-type receptors. Such changes in HA are expected to promote replication and transmission in mammalian hosts, including humans. Preservation or loss of the 2SBS is likely a viral host range determinant and could be an early adaptation signal that should be included in analysis of the pandemic potential of emerging IAVs."

In their response, published on the same issue of Eurosurveillance, the authors underlined the importance of carefully analysing whole-genome sequences and vigilantly monitoring virus evolution in each host, whether domestic or wild. "Any country that notifies an outbreak should ideally have access to sequencing and data-sharing mechanisms. Genomic surveillance is crucial to quickly identify any virus with zoonotic potential that could pose a threat to animal and public health."

Interested subscribers may wish to visit the letter (from E. de Vries and C.A.M. de Haan) at <https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2023.28.7.2300085>, and the authors' response at <https://www.eurosurveillance.org/content/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2023.28.7.2300109>. - Mod.AS]

******
[2] H5N1 in mammals - mink, zoonotic significance assessed
Date: Wed 8 Feb 2023
Source: JAMA [abridged, edited]
<https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2801499#:~:text=In%20April%202022%2C%20a%20dead,in%20a%20mammal%20in%20Japan>


As bird flu continues to circle the globe, a recent report suggests that the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) A(H5N1) virus spread between farmed mink in Spain last October [2022]. The virus also may have been transmitted between seals in coastal New England last summer.

The events mark the 1st large H5N1 outbreaks potentially driven by mammal-to-mammal transmission. The outbreaks, along with the virus' ongoing transmission in wild birds and poultry and increasing infections in wild mammals, have renewed concerns that H5N1, first identified in the mid-1990s, could be poised for spillover into humans.

The ongoing avian influenza outbreak is now the largest on record in Europe and North America, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). The outbreak is being driven by H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b viruses, which emerged in the Netherlands in October 2020 before spreading through Europe, Asia, and Africa. A recent report by the European Food Safety Authority and other agencies found that since October 2021, more than 58 million birds have died or been culled in H5N1-affected poultry establishments in 37 European countries. By December 2021, bird flu had arrived in North America. Within a year, wild bird outbreaks were confirmed in 47 US states, according to a recent epidemiological alert from the Pan American Health Organization. Nearly 60 million birds in commercial and backyard flocks in 47 US states have died or been culled, the US Department of Agriculture reported in early February [2023].

The virus has been detected in ducks, geese, gulls, pelicans, swans, vultures, crows, owls, eagles, and many other species of wild birds. With so many birds affected, the opportunities for exposure to other animals have been high. In addition to minks and seals, the list of mammals with confirmed infections in Europe and the Americas has now includes badger, black bear, bobcat, coyote, dolphin, ferret, fisher cat, fox [see item 4], leopard, lynx, opossum, otter, pig, polecat, porpoise, raccoon, raccoon dog, and skunk.

Martin Beer, DVM, who heads the Institute of Diagnostic Virology within the Friedrich-Loeffler-Institut, the Federal Research Institute for Animal Health, in Germany, said the mink farm outbreak requires special attention and awareness.

"[T]he likely animal-to-animal spread connected with clinical signs and mortality is significant, since spread between mammals might allow for further adaptation to the mammalian host," he wrote in an email to JAMA.

Although no human infections were reported on the mink facility, the incident indicates that the virus has the potential to spread in this intensively farmed species, said Isabella Monne, DVM, PhD, head of the viral genomics and transcriptomics laboratory at the Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale delle Venezie, the Italian public health institute that characterized the viruses identified in the outbreak, described in Eurosurveillance [ProMED post 20230122.8707905]. Monne warned in an email that the "increasing genetic diversity and geographical distribution of HPAI H5N1 viruses may result in more spillover events in mammals, posing great risks not only to the poultry industry but also to wildlife conservation and to human health."

Avian influenza viruses are classified as "highly pathogenic" or "low pathogenicity" based on their effects in birds, not necessarily in other animals. Although the highly pathogenic H5N1 virus has caused sporadic human infections since it was first detected in waterfowl in China in 1996, it doesn't spread easily between people and other mammals. Increasing mammalian infections raise the stakes, said Amesh Adalja,MD, a senior scholar at the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security. "Lots of flu viruses circulate in birds but never pose major threats to humans," Adalja said in an interview. "When you think about the steps that are related to the emergence of a new human influenza threat, the ability to infect mammalian species is one of those steps."

[ByJennifer Abbasi]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[3] H5N1 in mammals - mink, zoonotic significance assessed
Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023
Source: KSL Broadcasting via Associated Press [edited]
<https://www.ksl.com/article/50582530/why-sick-minks-are-reigniting-worries-about-bird-flu>


A recent bird flu outbreak at a mink farm has reignited worries about the virus spreading more broadly to people. Scientists have been keeping tabs on this bird flu virus since the 1950s, though it wasn't deemed a threat to people until a 1997 outbreak in Hong Kong among visitors to live poultry markets. As bird flu hits more and varied animals, like at the mink farm, the fear is that the virus could evolve to spread more easily between people, and potentially trigger a pandemic.

Scientists say another kind of bird flu was likely behind the devastating 1918-1919 flu pandemic, and avian viruses played roles in other flu pandemics in 1957, 1968, and 2009.

Still, the risk to the general public now is low, says Dr. Tim Uyeki of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

A look at the bird flu virus and why it is getting renewed attention:

What is bird flu?

Some flu viruses mainly affect people, but some others chiefly occur in animals. For example, there are cases of flu that occur in dogs, plus pig -- or swine -- flu viruses. And then there are avian viruses that spread naturally in wild aquatic birds like ducks and geese, and then to chickens and other domesticated poultry.

The bird flu virus drawing attention today -- Type A H5N1 -- was first identified in 1959, by investigators looking into a flu outbreak in chickens in Scotland. Like other viruses, it has evolved over time, spawning newer versions of itself.

By 2007, the virus was found in more than 60 countries. In the US, it has recently been detected in wild birds in every state, as well as in commercial poultry operations or backyard flocks in 47 states. Since the beginning of last year, [2022] tens of millions of chickens have died of the virus or been killed to stop outbreaks from spreading, one of the reasons cited for soaring egg prices.

How often do people get bird flu?

The Hong Kong outbreak in 1997 was the 1st time this bird flu was blamed for severe human illness. Out of 18 people infected, 6 died. To contain the outbreak, the Hong Kong government closed live poultry markets, killed all the birds in the markets, and stopped bringing in chickens from southern China. It worked, for a while.

Symptoms are similar to that of other cases of flu, including cough, body aches and fever. Some people don't have noticeable symptoms, but some develop severe. life-threatening pneumonia.

Globally, nearly 870 human infections and 457 deaths have been reported to the World Health Organization in 20 countries. But the pace has slowed, and there have been about 170 infections and 50 deaths in the last 7 years. In the vast majority of cases, the infected people got it directly from infected birds.

The 1st and only US case occurred just last April [2022]. A prison inmate in a work program picked it up while killing infected birds at a poultry farm in Montrose County, Colorado, in the western part of the state. His only symptom was fatigue, and he recovered.

Can it spread between people?

In some instances, investigators concluded that the bird flu virus apparently did spread from one person to another. That happened in Thailand, Viet Nam, Indonesia, China, and Pakistan, most recently in 2007.

In each cluster, it spread within families from a sick person in the home. Scientists do not believe it can spread easily through casual contact, as seasonal flu can. But viruses mutate and change. Scientists worry about the ever-increasing number of opportunities for bird flu to mix with other flu viruses in infected people or animals and mutate, making it easier to spread to people.

It wouldn't take much for that to happen "and then we would be in a really tough situation," said Dr. Luis Ostrosky, chief of infectious diseases and epidemiology at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston.

The CDC's Uyeki said the most worried he's been about H5N1 was during the earlier clusters. That kind of human-to-human spread does not appear to be happening right now, he said.

What happened at the mink farm?

Recent concern among public health experts has been fueled, in part, by detection of infections in a variety of mammals. The growing list includes foxes, raccoons, skunks, bears, and even marine mammals like seals and porpoises. Officials in Peru said 3 sea lions found dead in November [2022] tested positive, and the recent deaths of hundreds of others may be due to bird flu.

Then last month [January 2023], a European medical journal reported on a bird flu outbreak in October [2022] at a mink farm in Spain with nearly 52 000 animals, where the illness spread like wildfire [ProMED post 20221023.8706335].

The mink were fed poultry, and wild birds in the region had been found to have bird flu. But researchers said that however it started, they believe the virus then spread from mink to mink, a worrisome scenario. No workers were infected, though they wore masks as part of COVID-19 precautions.

Jennifer Nuzzo, director of the Pandemic Center at Brown University School of Public Health, said the outbreak virus is being watched for mutations that could make it more easily transmitted to people, and potentially between people.

"That's the real worry," said Nuzzo.

[Byline: Mike Stobbe] 

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[4] H5N1 in mammals - red fox, zoonotic significance assessed, research
Date: Tue 24 Jan 2023
Source: Microbiology Spectrum [abridged, edited]
<https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9927208/pdf/spectrum.02867-22.pdf>


Citation: Bordes L, Vreman S, Heutink R, et al. Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza Virus Infections in Wild Red Foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_) Show Neurotropism and Adaptive Virus Mutations. Microbiol Spectrum. 2023; e0286722; doi: 10.1128/spectrum.02867-22.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
-------
During the 2020 to 2022 epizootic of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI), several infections of mammalian species were reported in Europe. In the Netherlands, HPAI H5N1 virus infections were detected in 3 wild red foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_) that were submitted with neurological symptoms between December 2021 and February 2022. A histopathological analysis demonstrated that the virus was mainly present in the brain, with limited or no detection in the respiratory tract or other organs.

Limited or no virus shedding was observed in throat and rectal swabs. A phylogenetic analysis showed that the 3 fox viruses were not closely related, but they were related to HPAI H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b viruses that are found in wild birds. This suggests that the virus was not transmitted between the foxes. A genetic analysis demonstrated the presence of the mammalian adaptation E627K in the polymerase basic 2 (PB2) protein of the 2 fox viruses. In both foxes, the avian (PB2-627E) and the mammalian (PB2-627K) variants were present as a mixture in the virus population, which suggests that the mutation emerged in these specific animals. The 2 variant viruses were isolated, and virus replication and passaging experiments were performed. These experiments showed that the mutation PB2-627K increases the replication of the virus in mammalian cell lines, compared to the chicken cell line, and at the lower temperatures of the mammalian upper respiratory tract.

This study showed that the HPAI H5N1 virus is capable of adaptation to mammals; however, more adaptive mutations are required to allow for efficient transmission between mammals. Therefore, surveillance in mammals should be expanded to closely monitor the emergence of zoonotic mutations for pandemic preparedness.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The following wildlife-oriented comment by Mod.PMB is complementary: "Infections by HPAI viruses in mammals are typically uncommon, although since April 2022 there have been several events of Eurasian HPAI H5N1 in wild carnivores (Order Carnivora). Most reports have been done in red foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_, Family Canidae), but skunks (Family Mephitidae), raccoons (Family Procyonidae), seals (Suborder Pinnipedia, Family Phocidae), bears (Family Ursidae), and otters (Mustelidae) have been added, found infected. There have also been 3 cases in cetaceans" (ProMED post 20230123.8707926).

The numbers of human cases and deaths due to avian influenza A(H5N1) virus, accumulated since 2003, as often cited in media reports and scientific publications, are 868 and 457, respectively. For the annual numbers, per country, please refer to table 2 at <https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/global_statistics_avian_influenza_e.pdf>. The highest numbers were reported from Egypt (359 cases, 120 died), Indonesia (200, 168 died), Cambodia (56, 37), Mainland China (54, 32), Viet Nam (127, 64), and Thailand (25, 17). These data deserve being viewed with caution; for example, India reported one single (and fatal) case throughout the entire period. Most cases, globally, were recorded during the years 2003-2009 (468 cases, of which 282 fatal). In 2015 the numbers peaked due to the Egyptian epidemic. Since 2016 only sporadic cases were reported globally, totalling 22 (11, fatal) as of 20 Feb 2023.

While during the COVID-19 pandemic, the role of animals was mainly viewed in the context of academic, retrospective investigations into the origin of the pathogen while animals, primarily pets (but also minks!), were getting infected from man (reversed zoonosis), avian influenza is another story. The virus causes direct, tremendous losses to farm animals and to wildlife. The increased involvement of mammals is alarming, in view of the potential mutation of the virus. With the history of the 1918 pandemic in mind, and as concluded in all above reports and many others, published recently, a One Health, pro-active approach is, literally, vital. It prescribes coordinated, intensified surveillance in domestic and wild animals, even in remote regions, accompanied by virological investigations, and biosecurity-guided behaviour of those exposed to infected animals as well as the public at large. - Mod.AS]

[See Also:

Avian influenza (27): Americas (South America, Cuba, USA) mixed flocks, mammals 20230211.8708303

column2:
THOUSAND CANKERS DISEASE, EUROPEAN WALNUT - FRANCE: FIRST REPORT
****************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: January 2023
Source: European Plant Protection Organisation (EPPO) Reporting Service 01/2023/018 [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://gd.eppo.int/reporting/article-7500>


The NPPO [National Plant Protection Organisation] of France recently informed EPPO of the 1st finding of _Geosmithia morbida_ (EPPO A2 List) on its territory. The fungus, which is associated with the thousand cankers disease, was detected in central France in a park on 3 symptomatic walnut (_Juglans regia_) trees. The identity of the fungus was confirmed in November 2022 by morphological and molecular methods.

The detection occurred during surveys following capture of the insect vector _Pityophthorus juglandis_ (EPPO A2 List) in the area in September 2022 (EPPO RS 2022/232). A specific survey for _G. morbida_ and its vector will be carried out, including visual examination of host plants, sampling of symptomatic trees, and inspections of sites at risk. The source of this outbreak is under investigation.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Thousand cankers disease (TCD) of walnuts (_Juglans_ species) and other species in the family Juglandaceae is considered a disease complex involving the fungus _Geosmithia morbida_ (and possibly also other fungal species). It is spread by the walnut twig beetle (_Pityophthorus juglandis_; family _Curculionidae_, snout and bark beetles). The insect-fungus association, originating in North America, is considered to represent a new and significant threat to walnut species in the Americas and now also in Europe.

The fungus blocks the circulation system of the host. Symptoms may resemble drought stress and include yellowing, wilting, and browning of leaves, with subsequent canker development around beetle galleries. Affected mature trees may die within a year or less. Infectious vector beetles can spread on their own or be transported by human activities (such as wood transports). The fungus has a high mutation rate, and no resistant host cultivars are currently available. Phytosanitary and cultural measures, such as preventing bark damage as well as preventative systemic pesticide applications to avoid beetle infestation have been suggested, but no effective control options are currently known.


In Europe, the disease was reported for the 1st time from Italy in 2014 (ProMED post 20140206.2258062) on black walnut (_J. nigra_), its main host and an important forest tree in the Americas. The source of that incursion is unknown but is thought to have been infected vector insects on wood from the USA. The host of the new outbreak in France above, _J. regia_, is only a minor host in the Americas, but it is the main species grown for culinary walnuts in Europe, which further increases the risk from TCD for the region. Further details for the report above have most recently been published (see link below).

Affected mature trees may die within a year or less. Infectious vector beetles can spread on their own or be transported by human activities (such as wood transports). The fungus has a high mutation rate, and no resistant host cultivars are currently available. Phytosanitary and cultural measures, such as preventing bark damage as well as preventative systemic pesticide applications to avoid beetle infestation have been suggested, but no effective control options are currently known.In Europe, the disease was reported for the 1st time from Italy in 2014 (ProMED post 20140206.2258062) on black walnut (_J. nigra_), its main host and an important forest tree in the Americas. The source of that incursion is unknown but is thought to have been infected vector insects on wood from the USA. The host of the new outbreak in France above, _J. regia_, is only a minor host in the Americas, but it is the main species grown for culinary walnuts in Europe, which further increases the risk from TCD for the region. Further details for the report above have most recently been published (see link below).MapsFrance (with regions):<https://www.worldometers.info/img/maps/france_physical_map.gif>Europe, column2:
HEPATITIS A - INDIA: (JAMMU AND KASHMIR)
****************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023 14:30 IST
Source: Greater Kashmir [abridged, edited]
<https://www.greaterkashmir.com/todays-paper/editorial-page/outbreak-of-hepatitis-a>


Hepatitis A has broken out at Wathu village in Shopian district; 5 persons have tested positive. Samples of 150 persons have been also taken for the testing. This is not for the 1st time in recent times that hepatitis A has broken out in any South Kashmir village. According to reports, earlier some cases were reported from Ganowpora area in the same district. Few months back, 2 children had died due to hepatitis A at Turka Tachloo village in south Kashmir. The medical experts have been saying that consuming of unsafe water is the main cause for hepatitis A in the villages.

The health department should take more steps so that the further spread of the disease is stopped immediately. Those infected should get immediate treatment. If there is need for hospitalization in some cases, it should be done. The people should co-operate with the medical teams and listen to them and strictly follow their guidelines.

More testing needs to be not only in the affected village but in the other adjoining areas also. The medical teams must visit the affected areas on a regular basis for the time-being so that the affected people continue to get treatment and advice, and the rest of the population is educated about using only safe water for drinking.

Use of unboiled water should be avoided till safe water is made available. Awareness must be created among the people how to remain safe from hepatitis A. While the medical teams will do their job, providing of safe water is the responsibility of Jal Shakti Department.

No compromise should be made on this front. Reports quoting the villagers of Wathu say that there is some problem in the filtration plant. They alleged that nothing was done even as the matter was taken up with the concerned officials several times. They demand supply of safe water through tankers for the time-being. There is nothing wrong in their demand. All necessary steps should be taken to keep the water safe. The filtration of water and other required procedures must be adopted before the drinking water is supplied to people for consumption.

It is not about the affected village only; an exercise should be carried in other areas also to find out whether the water being supplied is safe. There are complaints of unsafe water from some other areas also.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[In much of the world, related to poor sewage and sanitation systems, an overwhelming number of the population has had hepatitis A in childhood, often without symptoms or jaundice. The serologic diagnosis of hepatitis A is made by finding positive IgM antibodies against the virus; a single positive IgG antibody against the virus is not diagnostic for acute disease. A variety of other infections could do this, including the hepatitis E virus, which is also mostly waterborne. - Mod.LL

column2:
BOTULISM - AUSTRALIA (02): (NEW SOUTH WALES) ALMOND MILK, ALERT, EXPANDED RECALL
********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023
Source: Food Safety News [abridged, edited]
<https://www.foodsafetynews.com/2023/02/almond-milk-linked-to-botulism-case-was-missing-storage-details/>


A brand of almond milk behind a case of botulism in Australia was missing storage information, according to investigators. Inside Out Nutritious Goods has expanded a recall because products are not labeled with instructions to keep refrigerated. Authorities said failure to refrigerate the products can lead to microbial growth and biotoxin contamination, which may cause illness if consumed. Botulism is a rare but life-threatening condition caused by toxins produced by the _Clostridium botulinum_ bacterium.

Initially, the company recalled JS Health x Inside Out Unsweetened Almond Milk Collagen + Calcium + Prebiotics sold in Woolworths stores in New South Wales (NSW). Now, 1-liter JS Health x Inside Out Unsweetened Oat Milk Collagen + Calcium + Prebiotics and the Barista version are affected. Drinks were sold at Woolworths outlets nationally and have a use-by date up to and including 18 May 2023. The earlier recall was updated following an NSW Department of Primary Industries inspection of the Inside Out manufacturing facility, which found the plant was in compliance with regulations and relevant standards.

The product is sold chilled and must be kept refrigerated. Consumers should not drink the beverage if it has not been kept refrigerated and stored below 4 degrees C (39.2 degrees F). One person suffered severe symptoms of botulism after drinking the dairy alternative. This person was hospitalized, and they are continuing to receive treatment. Investigations by authorities have confirmed the presence of botulinum toxin in a sample of the product. The NSW Food Authority is investigating the manufacturing process to determine the possible cause of contamination.


Growth of the bacterium and formation of toxins occurs in products with low oxygen content and certain combinations of storage temperature and preservation methods. Refrigeration temperatures combined with salt content or acidic conditions will prevent the growth of the bacteria and the formation of toxins, according to the WHO.

Botulism is extremely rare in Australia with 26 cases recorded since 1992. Only 3 of these have been foodborne.

Inside Out Nutritious Goods said it takes food safety, labeling, storage and handling instructions seriously. "Our thoughts are with the affected customer and we wish them a speedy recovery. As soon as we were informed of a potential contamination issue, we commenced a voluntary recall and have been providing every assistance to the relevant authorities. We are working with NSW Health and the NSW Food Authority to investigate what has happened. Inside Out is also engaging independent experts to investigate the matter," said a company statement.

The symptoms of botulism may include some or all of the following: double vision, blurred vision, drooping eyelids, slurred speech, difficulty swallowing, difficulty breathing, a thick-feeling tongue, dry mouth, and muscle weakness. People with botulism poisoning may not show all of these symptoms at once. These symptoms result from muscle paralysis caused by the toxin. If untreated, the disease may progress, and symptoms may worsen to cause paralysis of specific muscles, including those used in breathing and those in the arms, legs, and the body from the neck to the pelvis area.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[It is not specifically stated if the serotype of botulinum toxin found in the almond milk was the same causing the intoxication in the clinical case. The timing and method of contamination of the product are not clear, nor is whether the storage of the product was done appropriately, but it seems a warning to keep refrigerated was lacking. A food recall of spaghetti sauce related to a similar issue occurred in Quebec, Canada in 2020, but no clinical cases occurred (Botulism - Canada (02): (QC) spaghetti sauce, risk, recall, alert 20200929.7820697). Sodium citrate is often added to canned product to acidify the contents and decrease the risk of botulinum spores to germinate. The pH of almond milk is about 6, not low enough to do this.


Foodborne botulism usually occurs when preformed toxin is absorbed through the intestinal tract, and when the botulinum toxin is exposed to the neuromuscular junction, the heavy chain of the botulinum neurotoxin binds to glycoprotein structures specifically found on cholinergic nerve terminals. This specific docking is the reason for botulinum toxin's (BT's) high selectivity for cholinergic synapses. After internalization, the light chain of the botulinum neurotoxin binds with high specificity to the SNARE protein complex. The target proteins vary among the BT serotypes. BT-A cleaves synaptosomal-associated proteins of 25kDa (SNAP-25). BT-B cleaves vesicle-associated membrane protein (VAMP), also known as synaptobrevin II. - Mod.LL

column2:
AVIAN INFLUENZA (32): AMERICAS (PERU) HPAI H5N1, PELICAN, SEA LION
******************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023 9:31 AM PET
Source: KFGO, Reuters report [edited]
<https://kfgo.com/2023/02/21/bird-flu-kills-sea-lions-and-thousands-of-pelicans-in-perus-protected-areas/>


Bird flu has killed tens of thousands of birds, mostly pelicans, and at least 716 sea lions in protected areas across Peru, the authorities said, as the H5N1 strain spreads throughout the region.

Peru recorded its 1st case of the virus in November [2022] in birds in the north of the country. Since then it has killed 63 000 birds, according to government data.

"We have also recorded since mid-January [2023] the unusual death of many sea lions, so far we have about 716 dead sea lions in 7 protected natural areas of the coast," said Roberto Gutierrez, head of surveillance of the National Service of Natural Protected Areas.

Since the beginning of 2021, bird flu has ravaged the world, killing more than 200 million birds due to disease or mass culling, the World Organization for Animal Health has said.

In South America, bird flu cases have been detected in Ecuador, Bolivia, Chile, Paraguay, and recently in Argentina and Uruguay. In Brazil, the world's largest poultry exporter, there are still no confirmed cases.

In Chile, health authorities last week [week of 13 Feb 2023] detected the 1st positive case in a marine mammal, a sea lion on a beach in the north of the country.

The population of sea lions numbered about 110 000 in Peru in 2020, mainly in the coastal region of Ica and the Paracas nature reserve, according to Oceana, an international organization dedicated to protecting oceans.

In recent weeks [February 2023], crews from Peru's National Forestry and Wildlife Service, in protective plastic suits, gloves, and masks, have collected and buried hundreds of sea lions from several beaches along Peru's central coast.

"What we remember initially started with pelicans last year [2022] is now affecting these marine mammals," Javier Jara, a veterinarian with the service, said.

[Byline: Carlos Valdez, Marco Aquino]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The Eurasian HPAI H5N1 virus was first detected in January 2022 on the Atlantic coast of North America, and rapidly spread to many States of the USA, Canada, and Mexico, probably introduced to the Americas by one of the numerous species of birds that migrate along Nearctic and Palearctic flyways and breed in Arctic tundra regions. In November 2022, H5N1 was first detected in South America in pelicans from Peru, probably brought by infected migrants such as the blue-winged teal (_Anas discors_), which breed in North America and many winter in northern South America, including Peru. The report mentions Uruguay because a black-necked swan was recently detected infected in Rocha.

The list of countries where HPAI H5N1 has been detected south of Mexico includes Colombia, Peru, Venezuela, Chile, Bolivia, Uruguay, and Argentina. Passive and active surveillance should be enhanced in poultry and wild birds of the Neotropical region. 

Infections by HPAI viruses in mammals are typically not common, but since April 2022 there have been several events of Eurasian HPAI H5N1 in a wide spectrum of wild carnivores (order Carnivora). There have been reports have been in red foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_, family Canidae), bobcats (family Felidae), skunks (family Mephitidae), raccoons (family Procyonidae), bears (family Ursidae), otters (family Mustelidae), and seals and sea lions (suborder Pinnipedia, family Phocidae and family Otariidae, respectively). There have also been cases in cetaceans.

The numbers reported here suggest a considerable impact on the sea lion population of Peru. - Mod.PMB

column3: Bird flu has killed tens of thousands of birds, mostly pelicans, and at least 716 sea lions in protected areas across Peru, the authorities said, as the H5N1 strain spreads throughout the region.Peru recorded its 1st case of the virus in November [2022] in birds in the north of the country. Since then it has killed 63 000 birds, according to government data."We have also recorded since mid-January [2023] the unusual death of many sea lions, so far we have about 716 dead sea lions in 7 protected natural areas of the coast," said Roberto Gutierrez, head of surveillance of the National Service of Natural Protected Areas.Since the beginning of 2021, bird flu has ravaged the world, killing more than 200 million birds due to disease or mass culling, the World Organization for Animal Health has said.In South America, bird flu cases have been detected in Ecuador, Bolivia, Chile, Paraguay, and recently in Argentina and Uruguay. In Brazil, the world's largest poultry exporter, there are still no confirmed cases.In Chile, health authorities last week [week of 13 Feb 2023] detected the 1st positive case in a marine mammal, a sea lion on a beach in the north of the country.The population of sea lions numbered about 110 000 in Peru in 2020, mainly in the coastal region of Ica and the Paracas nature reserve, according to Oceana, an international organization dedicated to protecting oceans.In recent weeks [February 2023], crews from Peru's National Forestry and Wildlife Service, in protective plastic suits, gloves, and masks, have collected and buried hundreds of sea lions from several beaches along Peru's central coast."What we remember initially started with pelicans last year [2022] is now affecting these marine mammals," Javier Jara, a veterinarian with the service, said.[Byline: Carlos Valdez, Marco Aquino]--Communicated by:ProMED[The Eurasian HPAI H5N1 virus was first detected in January 2022 on the Atlantic coast of North America, and rapidly spread to many States of the USA, Canada, and Mexico, probably introduced to the Americas by one of the numerous species of birds that migrate along Nearctic and Palearctic flyways and breed in Arctic tundra regions. In November 2022, H5N1 was first detected in South America in pelicans from Peru, probably brought by infected migrants such as the blue-winged teal (_Anas discors_), which breed in North America and many winter in northern South America, including Peru. The report mentions Uruguay because a black-necked swan was recently detected infected in Rocha.The list of countries where HPAI H5N1 has been detected south of Mexico includes Colombia, Peru, Venezuela, Chile, Bolivia, Uruguay, and Argentina. Passive and active surveillance should be enhanced in poultry and wild birds of the Neotropical region. Infections by HPAI viruses in mammals are typically not common, but since April 2022 there have been several events of Eurasian HPAI H5N1 in a wide spectrum of wild carnivores (order Carnivora). There have been reports have been in red foxes (_Vulpes vulpes_, family Canidae), bobcats (family Felidae), skunks (family Mephitidae), raccoons (family Procyonidae), bears (family Ursidae), otters (family Mustelidae), and seals and sea lions (suborder Pinnipedia, family Phocidae and family Otariidae, respectively). There have also been cases in cetaceans.The numbers reported here suggest a considerable impact on the sea lion population of Peru. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Peru: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708539,10>]

column2:
DIPHTHERIA - INDONESIA: FATAL, MORE CASES, VACCINE CAMPAIGN, ALERT
******************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023 19:31 WIB
Source: Kompas.com [in Indonesian, machine trans., edited]
<https://bandung.kompas.com/read/2023/02/21/193119578/diduga-terpapar-difteri-7-warga-garut-meninggal-dunia>


As many as 7 residents of Sukahurip Village, Pangatikan District, Garut Regency, died of suspected exposure to diphtheria [bacterium]. This was confirmed by the Head of the Surveillance Team, Dewi Ambarwati, when contacted by cell phone, Tuesday [21 Feb 2023]. Dewi said the number occurred in the period of 6-19 February 2023. In early February there were 6 (dead), then added one more on [19 Feb 2023].

Dewi said that she did not yet know the exact cause of the death of the 7 people. However, based on preliminary analysis, they had close contact with residents affected by diphtheria.

These 7 people were not checked to determine whether they had diphtheria or not. However, because we suspected that the time of death was very close and we finally looked for those who had contact with those who had died and found 2 people who were positive (diphtheria)," she said.

In response to this, the West Java Health Office dispatched a team to the field to examine the condition of people who had close contact with people exposed to diphtheria, especially in the Sukahurip Village area.

"So children aged 15 and under in the village are subjected to an outbreak response. So we will inject all of them with diphtheria immunization," she said.

The West Java Health Office has also declared the status of an Extraordinary Event (KLB) of diphtheria in Garut Regency. "We say KLB. Meaning, we can say just one case (diphtheria) is KLB. So after that, we are looking for it in other cities to be examined," said Dewi.

According to Dewi, exposure to [_Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, the cause of diphtheria is a bacterium] can be prevented by injecting immunization. Therefore, the government will continue to carry out immunization efforts in the area with a joint approach from local community leaders.

"This village (Sukahurip) has a very high penalty, in the last 3 years the immunization coverage has been very low due to religious reasons," he said.

"Because this disease can be prevented by administering immunization according to a schedule -- for children under 11 months, later at the age of 2 years, and later at elementary school age -- the child's immunization must be repeated," she explained.

[Byline: Dendi Ramdhani, Reni Susanti]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi

******
[2]
Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023
Source: Nouvelles du monde [in French, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.nouvelles-du-monde.com/epidemie-de-diphterie-de-garut-rsud-dr-slamet-prepare-une-salle-disolement/>


The Garut Regency Government has declared an Extraordinary Event Status (KLB) related to diphtheria cases in Sukahurip Village, Pangatikan District, Garut Regency. The status of the KLB has been determined since [Sun 19 Feb 2023).

RSUD Dr Slamet [Regional General Hospital] Garut Regency, Deputy Director of Services, Willy Indrawilis, said his party had prepared a special room to anticipate a spike in diphtheria cases. Indeed, the management of diphtheria cases must be carried out in an isolation room.

"There were 3 people (diphtheria cases) being treated at RSUD. They have been admitted since Saturday [18 Feb 2023]," he said when confirmed by the Republika on Tuesday [21 Feb 2023].

According to him, the 3 people who are all children were placed in the isolation room of Dr Slamet Hospital. The reason is that the spread of diphtheria is considered easy.

According to him, so far, there have been no other referrals concerning cases of diphtheria. However, a team from the Garut district health office is still carrying out investigations on the ground.

"We have also prepared a place for the isolation of patients. We have prepared 7 rooms with 14 beds, but only 3 (beds) are used," Willy said.

Regarding the condition of the diphtheria patient being treated at Dr Slamet Hospital, Willy explained, all 3 children had symptoms of swollen necks and white membranes in their throats. However, currently, their condition is considered to be improving. "They were given diphtheria medication, and the swelling in the neck has gone down," he said.

Meanwhile, Garut district health office secretary Leli Yuliani said that so far there have been no additional diphtheria cases in Sukahurip village. However, he still continues to conduct field research.

"No (no additions)," he said when confirmed by the Republika on Tuesday [21 Feb 2023].

Based on the latest data as of Sunday [19 Feb 2023], there were 72 diphtheria cases in Sukahurip village, the majority of which were in children. Of the total cases, 4 people were included in the category of cases of observation of diphtheria, 4 suspected diphtheria, 2 cases of positive confirmation of diphtheria, 55 close contacts, and 7 people died without complete medical records (epidemiological link).

Also referring to the data, up to 3 people are currently undergoing treatment at Dr Slamet Hospital, Garut Regency. In addition, 8 other people are in independent isolation.

Leli said the Garut Regency government has also established an epidemic status regarding the diphtheria case in Sukahurip village. According to him, the KLB status will be valid until October 2023.

"Later, ORI (outbreak response immunization) will be done 3 times, at 0 months, 1 month, and 6 months," he said.

Earlier, Deputy Regent of Garut Helmi Budiman called on the community in Sukahurip village to immediately report to officers if they have symptoms of diphtheria. Health centers in the region are said to have opened special service posts for diphtheria.

"Officers will regularly perform swab checks on people in Sukahurip village who show symptoms," he said Monday [20 Feb 2023].

Helmi added that patients who have been diagnosed with diphtheria will be isolated in hospital if they need medical treatment. While close contacts will receive prophylactic treatment so that they do not contract diphtheria.

"I also recommend minimizing mobility. Then in this village we recommend wearing a mask," he said.

In addition, Helmi said, the Garut district health office will carry out mass vaccination in Sukahurip village. This effort should prevent diphtheria from spreading.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi

[For a discussion of diphtheria in Indonesia, please see my moderator comments in ProMED post Diphtheria - Indonesia: fatal, more cases, vaccine campaign 20180106.5542510.

Garut Regency (pop., over 2.6 million in 2021) is located in the West Java province on the western part of the island of Java (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garut_Regency>). Garut Regency is currently divided into 42 districts; Pangatikan (estim. pop., 38 472 in 2020) is a district in central West Java. A map showing the location of Pangatikan can be seen at <https://goo.gl/maps/JaLhc3sYA2oDrHTT6>.

ProMED map:
Kecamatan Pangatikan, West Java, Indonesia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708538,68898>]

column2:
SYPHILIS - USA (02): (MISSISSIPPI) CONGENITAL, INCREASING CASES, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
****************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: Healthnews [edited]
<https://healthnews.com/news/why-do-newborns-in-mississippi-have-syphilis/>


The number of newborns treated for congenital syphilis, an infection passed from their mothers, has dramatically increased in Mississippi [USA] over the past 5 years. Experts say this may be due to limited access to prenatal care and a lack of insurance.

An analysis of hospital bill data shared with NBC News and collected by Thomas Dobbs, MD, the medical director for the Mississippi State Department of Health's Crossroads Clinic in Jackson, reveals that cases of congenital syphilis rose by more than 900% in Mississippi [<https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/congenital-syphilis-treatment-mississippi-increase-rcna69381>]. In 2021, some 102 newborns in the state were treated for the condition, compared to only 10 babies in 2016.

Dobbs said that healthcare providers "are absolutely horrified."

"Mississippi is experiencing a frightening increase in pregnant women with syphilis and in turn, babies born with syphilis," said Dobbs, who is also a dean of the John D Bower School of Population Health at the University of Mississippi Medical Center (UMMC).

Congenital syphilis may have profound implications on a newborn's health, such as deformed bones, anemia, damaged organs, and brain and nerve problems. In most severe cases, the infection may lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, and premature birth, according to the CDC.

"Several newborns have died recently due to this entirely preventable problem. Other children have been diagnosed with severe neurological development disorders because of untreated syphilis," Dobbs said in a UMMC statement.

All pregnant women should be tested for syphilis at the 1st prenatal visit and treated with penicillin right away if they test positive, the CDC said. Mississippi, however, is one of the 6 states where syphilis screenings in pregnancy are not required by law.

Overall, STDs in the United States are skyrocketing [<https://healthnews.com/news/new-us-health-statistics-reveal-cancer-mortality-decreased-while-new-std-cases-skyrocketed/>]. The preliminary CDC data show that syphilis cases rose from 101 590 in 2017 to 171 074 in 2021. The same trend is observed in Mississippi, where new syphilis cases nearly tripled from 2013 to 2016.

Charlotte Hobbs, MD, professor of pediatric infectious diseases at UMMC, said that delayed prenatal care and testing are the main reasons women with syphilis are not getting treatment, followed by delays in accessing antibiotics. "To combat this public health crisis, our priority must be to engage moms early in pregnancy and ensure testing and treatment. This will require a committed partnership between physicians and clinics, public health, and insurers, primarily Medicaid," she added.

According to the doctors, the key to addressing this crisis is early prenatal care, access to which is limited by the lack of insurance and maternal care deserts.

Dobbs said, "From my discussions with physicians across the state, uninsured pregnant women must pay for care out-of-pocket prior to Medicaid approval. Although Medicaid will reimburse retroactively, most clinics require either payment or proof of insurance. This costly delay often puts women well beyond the 1st trimester before receiving care."

Children and women in Mississippi aren't the [only] ones impacted. California, Minnesota, and New Mexico have reported increases as well.

Resources
---------
- Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Congenital Syphilis -- CDC Fact Sheet (<https://www.cdc.gov/std/syphilis/stdfact-congenital-syphilis.htm>).
- Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Preliminary 2021 STD Surveillance Data (<https://www.cdc.gov/std/statistics/2021/default.htm>)

[Byline: Egle Kristopaityte]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[Trends in the number of congenital syphilis cases reflect rates of P&S syphilis among reproductive aged women. Since 2013, the rate of congenital syphilis has increased each year. In 2014, the incidence rate of reported congenital syphilis cases in the US was 11.6 cases per 100 000 live births (<https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6444a3.htm>). By 2020, the national congenital syphilis rate of 57.3 cases per 100 000 live births represents a 394% increase relative to 2014 (<https://www.cdc.gov/std/statistics/2020/overview.htm>).

In a CDC study of about 1300 cases of congenital syphilis reported nationwide in 2018, "missed opportunities" for prevention of congenital syphilis occurred, which varied by region (<https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6922a1.htm>). Racial/ethnic disparities existed within the highest morbidity regions: in the South, the most commonly missed prevention opportunity among white mothers of infants with congenital syphilis was no timely prenatal care and no timely syphilis testing (31.6%), whereas, among black and Hispanic mothers, no adequate maternal treatment despite a timely syphilis diagnosis (37%) was the commonest. These differences in missed prevention opportunities require strategies that are tailored to local situations.

The US states with rates of congenital syphilis above the national average in 2019 (48.5 cases per 100 000 live births) were in the South and Southwest, including Texas (138.2), Arizona (133.1), New Mexico (117.8), Nevada (114.7), Louisiana (111.4), California (94.3), Oklahoma (85.6), Florida (64.8), and Arkansas (56.0); however, in 2019, Mississippi ranked 40th, with 3 cases and a rate per 100 000 live births of 8.0 (<https://www.cdc.gov/std/statistics/2019/std-surveillance-2019.pdf>, Table 40). In 2021, there were 102 cases of congenital syphilis in newborns in the state.

Poverty and other social determinants have a big impact on rates of syphilis and other sexually transmitted diseases among women. More information on factors driving this increase in syphilis in Mississippi would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
Mississippi, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708535,226>]

By 2020, the national congenital syphilis rate of 57.3 cases per 100 000 live births represents a 394% increase relative to 2014 (<https://www.cdc.gov/std/statistics/2020/overview.htm>).In a CDC study of about 1300 cases of congenital syphilis reported nationwide in 2018, "missed opportunities" for prevention of congenital syphilis occurred, which varied by region (<https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6922a1.htm>). These differences in missed prevention opportunities require strategies that are tailored to local situations.The US states with rates of congenital syphilis above the national average in 2019 (48.5 cases per 100 000 live births) were in the South and Southwest, including Texas (138.2), Arizona (133.1), New Mexico (117.8), Nevada (114.7), Louisiana (111.4), California (94.3), Oklahoma (85.6), Florida (64.8), and Arkansas (56.0); however, in 2019, Mississippi ranked 40th, with 3 cases and a rate per 100 000 live births of 8.0 (<https://www.cdc.gov/std/statistics/2019/std-surveillance-2019.pdf>, Table 40). In 2021, there were 102 cases of congenital syphilis in newborns in the state.Poverty and other social determinants have a big impact on rates of syphilis and other sexually transmitted diseases among women. More information on factors driving this increase in syphilis in Mississippi would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.MLProMED map:Mississippi, United States: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708535,226>]

column2:
JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (02): (ODISHA)
****************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023 08:24 PM IST
Source: Hindustan Times [edited]
<https://www.hindustantimes.com/cities/others/5-girl-students-found-positive-with-japanese-encephalitis-at-odisha-hostel-101676904851706.html>


At least 5 girl students of Purubai Kanyashram hostel in the coastal Balasore district have tested positive for Japanese encephalitis 2 days after they were admitted to a government hospital complaining of fever, headache, and vomiting, district officials said.

On Saturday evening [18 Feb 2023], a class 10 student of the hostel, who complained of nausea and headache, passed away at Balasore district headquarters hospital a day after she was admitted.

Though her samples did not indicate the cause of her death, 5 others who were admitted along with her to the district headquarter hospital were found positive for the virus.

"We don't know how they got infected with Japanese encephalitis. But we got the students tested after they showed all signs of encephalitis. A detailed investigation would reveal how they were infected. As pigs are the carrier it's possible that the students had come in contact with pigs," said Dr Mrutyunjay Mishra, additional district medical officer, Balasore district. [This is incorrect. Pigs are amplifying hosts and do not transmit the virus directly to people. _Culex_ mosquitoes are the vectors and undoubtedly transmitted the virus to the girls. These mosquitoes may acquire the virus from pigs or from aquatic birds. - Mod.TY]

Meanwhile, 25 other girl students of the hostel who had similar symptoms as those with encephalitis tested negative for the virus. However, they are being kept under close observation, according to the officials.

Japanese encephalitis is a viral brain infection that's spread through mosquito bites. It is vector-borne in which the infected patients suffer from fever and abdominal pain and experience recurrent vomiting. Many of the affected patients have hypoglycaemia.

In Malkangiri district of Odisha, a severe outbreak of Japanese encephalitis and acute encephalitis syndrome was reported from September to November 2016, in which 336 children were affected, and 103 deaths were reported in the age group of 4 months to 13 years.

[Byline: Debabrata Mohanty]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[One hopes that the people living in the area are warned about the risk of Japanese encephalitis (JE) infection, advised to avoid mosquito bites, or to be vaccinated against this virus.

Although cases of Japanese encephalitis (JE) occur more frequently in Bihar and Assam states than in Odisha state, JE cases do occur there. Odisha state is endemic for JE virus, and cases occur there frequently. In some years, both JE and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) are reported in the state. For example, JE virus transmission was very active in 2017. As of the end of May 2017, there were 313 cases of AES with 10 deaths in Odisha and the case count increased to 473 with 13 deaths in the 1st week of August 2017. Some or all AES cases may include JE cases. If this year (2023) develops the same pattern of cases as 2017, there may be more cases coming. - Mod.TY


ProMED map:
Balasore, Odisha, India: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708532,66319>]

[See Also:

column2:
STRIPE RUST, WHEAT - INDIA: (HARYANA)
*************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 14 Feb 2023
Source: The Tribune [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://www.tribuneindia.com/news/haryana/next-few-days-critical-for-wheat-crop-agri-experts-tell-farmers-479490>


Current weather conditions are not optimal for wheat crops and farmers are advised to be vigilant to avoid yield loss. The department of Agriculture in Ambala district said that grain weight is likely to decrease with higher temperature. Current conditions are also conducive for fungal development. Field staff have been directed to be watchful. Farmers have been advised to report to the department if they find yellow rust in their fields so that the disease can be contained.

The disease spreads very quickly, so regular monitoring and timely prevention is needed to control it. Farmers were advised to consult experts for confirmation of yellow rust and spray fungicides. Camps are being organised to educate farmers. Over 87 000 hectares [214 982 acres] are under wheat crops in the district in 2023.

[Byline: Nitish Sharma]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Stripe rust (also called yellow rust) of cereals is caused by the fungus _Puccinia striiformis_. The disease affects wheat (_Triticum aestivum_), durum wheat (_T. turgidum_), some barley varieties, triticale (wheat/rye hybrids), and a number of wild grasses. It causes yellow stripes on leaves leading to loss of photosynthetic ability and plant vigour, as well as stunting of plants. Yield losses of 40-100% have been reported in wheat.

Spores are wind dispersed in several cycles during the cropping season. Grasses and volunteer crop plants may generate a "green bridge" providing inoculum for the next crop cycle. Disease monitoring is important so that timely action can be taken to limit the spread of the pathogen as well as build-up of inoculum. Disease management may include the use of resistant crop varieties, fungicide applications and control of pathogen reservoirs. Monitoring and resistance breeding programmes have been established in different regions for early detection of new rust strains and to attempt to stay ahead of pathogen evolution.

While stem rust (_P. graminis_) poses a huge potential threat to world wheat production, stripe rust is currently causing the most damage to wheat crops on a global scale. New strains of both rusts with increased virulence and additional fungicide resistances have been reported in recent years from wheat-growing areas worldwide. Climate warming allowing survival of wheat rusts on green bridges into higher latitudes is another example of pathogens extending their range due to climate change (e.g. ProMED posts 20141024.2895414, 20120809.1235745, 20090914.3230, and 20110718.2172). Projects for double-resistance breeding to manage both stripe and stem rusts simultaneously are in progress (see ProMED post 20120831.1274190).

The Himalayan region, including parts of India and Pakistan, has been identified as a source of most of the aggressive stripe rust races that have arrived in Europe over recent years (ProMED post 20150717.3517395). In India, of the cereal rusts, stripe rust is the most serious constraint to wheat production. A general alert for all wheat rusts has recently also been issued in Pakistan (see link below).

<https://www.worldometers.info/img/maps/india_physical_map.gif>

<https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/sites/gateway/files/styles/original/public/Stripe%20rust%20infected%20glume.JPG>

<http://www.planthealthaustralia.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Barley-stripe-rust-1.jpg>,
<https://extensionaus.com.au/FieldCropDiseasesVic/wp-content/uploads/sites/25/2017/03/Fig-2.-Barley-stripe-rust-.jpg> and
<https://pnwhandbooks.org/sites/pnwhandbooks/files/plant/images/barley-hordeum-vulgare-stripe-rust/225.jpg>

<http://plant-pest-advisory.rutgers.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/photo-15-e1378922274640.jpg>

<https://www.ars.usda.gov/midwest-area/stpaul/cereal-disease-lab/docs/cereal-rusts/wheat-stripe-rust/>,

<http://www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/158964/stripe-rust-in-wheat.pdf>

<http://wheatrust.org/yellow-rust-tools-maps-and-charts/> and

<https://bgri.cornell.edu/>

column2:
MARBURG VIRUS DISEASE - EQUATORIAL GUINEA (02): (KIE-NTEM) HEALTH ALERT
***********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Fri 17 Feb 2023
Source: US Embassy, Equatorial Guinea [edited]
<https://gq.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-malabo-equatorial-guinea-3/>


Health Alert: U. S. Embassy Malabo, Equatorial Guinea
-----------------------------------------------------
Event: As of the morning of 17 Feb 2023, there have been no new confirmed cases of Marburg Virus Disease (MVD) in Equatorial Guinea (EG) or the surrounding countries. There were 2 suspected cases detected across the border in Cameroon, but blood samples of both individuals tested negative for both MVD and Ebola. Authorities in EG, Cameroon, and Gabon are increasing health surveillance and testing for any individuals displaying possible MVD symptoms, and so reports of suspected cases will likely increase in the days and weeks ahead.

The World Health Organization (WHO) and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) continue to support EG's Ministry of Health and Social Welfare (MINSABS) to assist those impacted by the outbreak and to prevent the virus from spreading further. The Kie-Ntem province in the mainland region of EG remains under a general quarantine, and travel out of the province is not allowed, except by medical workers.

The U.S. Embassy will continue to send out regular updates to U.S. citizens living in or traveling to EG until health officials declare an end to the crisis. These alerts will also be posted to the Embassy's website here. More information on MVD can be found on the CDC's website.

Actions to take:
- Immediately report to a qualified medical professional if you experience fever, muscle soreness, weakness, abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, or hemorrhaging.
- Avoid contact with any individuals experiencing these symptoms and any people who have had contact with individuals displaying those symptoms.
- Do not eat or handle bushmeat, especially monkeys and other primates. Avoid contact with animal cadavers for any reason.
- Avoid caves or other areas where fruit bat populations are found.
- Practice good hygiene, including regular hand washing.
- Avoid large gatherings and wear a mask when in enclosed spaces.
- Do not attend wakes or funerals.
- Do not attempt to travel to the Kie-Ntem province or surrounding areas until health authorities advise it is safe to do so.
- If you reside in the Kie-Ntem province and/or are subject to the quarantine, alert the U.S. Embassy and follow instructions given by WHO and MINSABS officials.
- Do not attempt to cross the land border between Equatorial Guinea and Cameroon.
- Monitor news programs and websites to stay abreast of new health announcements from the government.
- Check your email regularly for additional updates from U.S. Embassy, Malabo.

--
Communicated by:
Preston Church
Sanaria Inc.
<lwpchurch@sanaria.com>

[The above report from the USA Embassy indicates that there are no new Marburg virus infections in Equatorial Guinea and that the 2 suspected cases in Cameroon were ruled out as Marburg virus infections. Although this information has been available previously from other sources, the above report is an illustration that valuable in-country health-related information is sometimes available from the US Embassy and may be a worthwhile source to check on before travel to that country. 

Preston Church is thanked for providing this report. - Mod.TY

ProMED map:
Equatorial Guinea: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708530,60>]

column2:
MALARIA - AFRICA: KENYA (MARSABIT) ANOPHELES STEPHENSI, FIRST REPORT, ALERT
***************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

[1]
Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023 02:35 (EAT)
Source: Citizen Digital [edited]
<https://www.citizen.digital/news/alarm-as-dangerous-malaria-vector-detected-in-kenya-n314684>


The Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) Entomology Research team has announced the discovery of a new malaria vector which poses a serious threat to Kenyans.

In a statement from acting Director General Samuel Kariuki on Sunday, KEMRI said the vector known as _Anopheles stephensi_ was first detected in Laisamis and Saku sub-counties of Marsabit County, where the research was being conducted.

The discovery, made alongside the Ministry of Health's Division of National Malaria Programme (DNMP), shows that the vector thrives in both urban and rural settings which may translate to a high transmission rate.

"Our surveillance studies indicate that the new vector, unlike the traditional malaria-causing mosquitoes namely _A. gambiae_ and _A. [funestus]_, is not only invasive and can spread very fast to new areas, but also adaptive to different climatic and environmental conditions," a part of the statement reads.

KEMRI says that further surveillance and studies are ongoing to establish the extent of the strain's distribution and mosquito infectivity rates.

Meanwhile, members of the public have been urged to continue utilizing the available malaria control tools such as using mosquito nets, repellents, and wearing long-sleeved clothing to prevent mosquito bites.

_A. stephensi_ is unique as it thrives in man-made containers such as [jerry] cans, tires, open tanks, sewers, cisterns, overhead tanks and underground tanks, and in polluted environments.

_A. stephensi_ was known to occur and spread malaria in South-East Asia, the Middle East, and Arabian Peninsula. The mosquito species has been expanding its geographic range over the last decade, with detections reported in Djibouti (2012), Ethiopia and Sudan (2016), Somalia (2019), and Nigeria (2020), according to KEMRI.

[Byline: Moses Kinyanjui]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

******
[2]
Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: Capital Radio Malawi, BBC News report [edited]
<https://www.capitalradiomalawi.com/2023/02/20/new-mosquito-brings-year-round-malaria-to-kenya/>


Kenyan researchers have detected a mosquito native to South Asia that is resistant to insecticides used in Africa.

Experts from the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) identified the mosquito, _Anopheles stephensi_, during routine surveillance in northern Marsabit county.

Data from hospitals there also showed an increase in malaria cases -- even though it was not the normal season for the disease as local mosquitoes don't do well in dry areas.

This invasive mosquito can thrive in both dry and rainy seasons and can breed anywhere. In other countries, its larvae have been found in water containers in urban centres.

Experts are concerned that malaria transmission will now continue all year round instead of being seasonal.

"Unfortunately, this detection in Kenya may translate to higher malaria transmission in urban and peri-urban settings in the country and could reverse gains made in the fight against malaria," said KEMRI's director-general, Samuel Kariuki.

It will also make it difficult to eradicate malaria, which is one of the top killers of children below 5 years.

The researchers are urging Kenyans to use available malaria control tools such as sleeping under treated mosquito bed nets, use of repellents, and wearing long-sleeved clothing to prevent mosquito bites.

In Africa, the mosquito was first detected in Djibouti 10 years ago and has now been spotted in Ethiopia, Sudan, Somalia, and Nigeria.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The original scientific report on which the articles above are based is available as a downloadable preprint [ref.1].

As discussed in ProMED's most recent post on malaria in Africa, _A. stephensi_ is already the major vector of _P. falciparum_ and _P. vivax_ in urban Ethiopia (see 1st item under See Also below). Given the certainty that this mosquito species will continue to spread through the Horn of Africa, it is not surprising that this 1st detection of _A. stephensi_ in Kenya occurred in Marsabit county, which forms much of Kenya's northern border with Ethiopia.

Because _A. stephensi_ is an urban mosquito and well adapted to dry weather, in contrast to _A. gambiae_, it is likely that malaria transmission and cases will rise in Africa, particularly if and when it reaches large cities [ref.2]. If controlling this urban mosquito proves to be as difficult as controlling the urban _Aedes aegypti_, eradication will not be possible with current approaches and will require a concerted integrated approach. As stated in the Conclusions of a recent perspective on this issue [ref.3]:

"While the presence of _A. stephensi_ in Africa is a concern, it should be viewed as a symptom of a broader and more important problem -- weakened vector surveillance and control programs. The invasion and spread of this vector species is one of multiple biological threats with potential to reverse malaria control and elimination efforts. Research efforts should establish relative contributions of _A. stephensi_ in different malaria transmission settings and identify important ecological and anthropogenic determinants of the species' spread to inform control. Countries and partners should enhance their surveillance systems to map the geographical extents and trajectories of the vectors in and beyond urban areas; and create integrated control programs operating across key sectors and on multiple vector species. The programs should resist any temptation to focus on _A. stephensi_ as a stand-alone threat, but instead adopt more holistic and integrated approaches. Lastly, it is important to involve local stakeholders in affected communities, and to tailor programs to the local context."

References
----------
1. Ochomo EO, Milanoi S, Abong'o B, et al. Molecular surveillance leads to the first detection of _Anopheles stephensi_ in Kenya. Research Square 2023. Preprint not peer-reviewed by a journal; <https://doi.org/10.21203/rs.3.rs-2498485/v1>
2. Takken W, Lindsay S. Increased threat of urban malaria from _Anopheles stephensi_ mosquitoes, Africa. Emerg Infect Dis. 2019; 25(7): 1431-3; <https://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2507.190301>
3. Mnzava A, Monroe AC, Okumu F. _Anopheles stephensi_ in Africa requires a more integrated response. Malar J. 2022; 21(1): 156; <https://doi.org/10.1186/s12936-022-04197-4>
- Mod.LXL
