GLANDERS - RUSSIA: (ZABAYKALYE) HORSE, WOAH
*******************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4915>


Russia, _Burkholderia mallei_ (infection with) (glanders)
---------------------------------------------------------
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 7 Jan 2023
Confirmed: 16 Feb 2023
Reported: 20 Feb 2023
Reason for notification: recurrence
Last occurrence: 27 Dec 2013
Causal agent: _Burkholderia mallei_
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Chita, Chitinskiy rayon, Zabaykal'ye [Zabaykalye]
Started: 7 Jan 2023
Epidemiological unit: farm
Affected animals:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Equidae / 84 / 6 / 2 / 4 / 0 / 0

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreaks(s): unknown or inconclusive

Control measures at event level
Domestic control measures applied: surveillance within the restricted zone; selective killing and disposal; quarantine; screening; movement control; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection.

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result
Regional Veterinary Laboratory, Volgograd/ Equidae / Bacterial culture / 16 Feb 2023 / Positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above.]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

["Glanders is an infectious and life-threatening disease that mainly affects horses, donkeys or mules caused by the bacterium _Burkholderia mallei_. Glanders can be transmitted to humans. Susceptibility to glanders has also been demonstrated in camels, felines living in the wild, bears, wolves, and dogs. Carnivores may become infected by eating infected meat. Guinea pigs and hamsters are highly susceptible. The disease causes nodules and ulcerations in the respiratory tract and lungs in animals. A skin form, known as 'farcy', also occurs. In humans the disease can take different forms such as: nasal, localized with nodules and abscesses, pulmonary, septicemia with disseminated or chronic infection, respectively. A cure is possible, however, if cases are treated rapidly with antibiotics; fatality rates for untreated infections are very high. The disease has been eradicated in North America, Australia and Europe through testing and then eliminating any infected animals, coupled with import control measures. However, glanders remains sporadically reported in a number of Asian, African, Middle Eastern, and South American countries. Glanders is a disease listed in the WOAH Terrestrial Animal Health Code and must be reported by Members according to the WOAH Code". (<https://www.woah.org/en/disease/glanders/>). - Mod.CRD

ProMED map:
Russia: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708527,98>]

column2:
SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE ENTERITIDIS - SWEDEN (04): (KALMAR) EGGS RECALL, CONTROL
********************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023
Source: SVT Nyheter [in Swedish, machine trans., edited] 
<https://www.svt.se/nyheter/lokalt/smaland/nytt-salmonellautbrott-pa-cedergrens-i-monsteras>


Sweden's largest egg producer, CA Cedergren in Fliseryd, Mönsterås municipality, has had a new confirmed case of salmonella. Several food suppliers are now recalling eggs after the discovery.

In January [2023], CA Cedergren had to kill roughly 164 000 chickens after salmonella bacteria were discovered in one of the coops. Now it has happened again, which the Barometer was the first to report.

"It is a different coop this time, the other one we are still cleaning up", says Maud Cedergren, operations manager at the company.

On Monday evening [20 Feb 2023], Ica, Coop and Axfood announced that they are recalling several egg packages, after salmonella was discovered during a routine check. CA Cedergren does not want to comment on what caused the outbreak yet.

"It's too early to tell, that's the way it is. We must be allowed to work on this in peace now, and refer to the Swedish Agency for Agriculture", says Maud Cedergren.

Cleanup is now underway and approximately the same number of chickens as in January [2023] will be euthanized this time.

"In this new coop, there are about 160 000 hens. They must be euthanized because they moved in the infected environment. That's the way we can handle the infection", says Maria Lundh, veterinarian and infection control officer at the Swedish Agency for Agriculture.
 
Additional eggs from the egg producer outside Mönsterås are now being recalled.

-- 
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The continuous or renewed infection of poultry in the same large laying plant, with _S. enteritidis_, an infamous zoonotic pathogen, is concerning, warranting a thorough epidemiological investigation. 

Sweden's policy addressing salmonellosis in animals and humans has been long considered as one of the most effective, globally. A severe domestic outbreak of _Salmonella_ Typhimurium in 1953 that involved more than 9000 people prompted the need for a control programme for _Salmonella_. Since then, the strategy for control has been to prevent _Salmonella_ in all parts of the production chain, from feed to food of animal origin.

When Sweden joined the European Union in 1995, the Swedish _Salmonella_ control programme was accepted. Sweden obtained additional guarantees that food products of animal origin from countries with a non-equivalent _Salmonella_ status should be tested for the presence of _Salmonella_ before being placed on the Swedish market. Specific salmonella-targetting programmes were developed and applied by Sweden's veterinary authorities. Monitoring is structured differently for different animal species. For example, there is mandatory monitoring of all commercial poultry flocks, where regular sampling takes place on the farm. Manufacturers of feed for food-producing animals are obliged to collect environmental samples in the facility every week to check form  salmonella. The feed manufacturer must also have a risk-based self-check to be able to guarantee that the feed does not contain salmonella. For cattle and pigs, among other things, random sample checks are carried out in connection with slaughter and sampling of young animals in connection with necropsy.

The number of newly infected herds is usually between 0 and 10 per animal species. During 2020, some pig herds were infected with a salmonella type that had not been found in Sweden since the 1970s, _Salmonella Choleraesuis_. This salmonella type was also detected among wild boar in some places in the country.

Additional information is available at <https://tinyurl.com/s5r7pz7r> (in Swedish). - Mod.AS

column2:
BRUCELLOSIS - KAZAKHSTAN: (ZHAMBYL)
***********************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: Kazinform [in Kazakh, machine trans., edited]
<https://www.inform.kz/ru/bolee-sta-zhiteley-zhambylskoy-oblasti-zaboleli-brucellezom_a4037994>


Brucellosis remains one of the urgent problems of the southern region of Kazakhstan, including the Zhambyl region, where in recent years the incidence rate has exceeded the national average by 2-3 times, a Kazinform correspondent reports. The press service of the health department of the Zhambyl region spoke about the state of the incidence of brucellosis and preventive measures.

"In the region, on average, about 150 patients are registered annually. One in 3 comes with a severe form, and one in 5 are children and adolescents; more than 15% of cases become chronic and drag on for decades. Brucellosis is a particularly dangerous infectious disease that affects all human organs and systems. You can get infected with this dangerous infectious disease only from animals with brucellosis and from environmental objects contaminated with the secretions of sick animals," the administration explained.

Brucellosis is not transmitted from person to person, the department noted. The disease begins with an increase in body temperature to 39-40 deg C [102-104 deg F], headache, chills, and weakness. Then there are pains and swelling in the joints and damage to the cardiovascular, nervous, and urogenital systems. These phenomena can sometimes pass but then become aggravated again; they can proceed for a long time, leading to disability and incapacity for work.

According to the regional health department, in 2022 103 residents of the region fell ill with this infection, of which 26 were children and adolescents.e

Every year in the Zhambyl region, before the start of the lambing campaign, letters are sent to akims [governors] of 11 regions of the region, interested departments and services, and territorial departments of the sanitary and epidemiological service for carrying out a set of preventive measures.

"At this time, the health organization of the region, together with the veterinary service, has announced a 3-month period to intensify organizational and methodological work in teams, as well as educate the population on observing the rules of personal hygiene when caring for farm animals. It is necessary to require a veterinary certificate when buying livestock, not to allow sick or unexamined animals into a healthy herd in a private household, to buy livestock products only in designated places, and to require documents certifying the quality and safety of products," the press service of the Zhambyl Region Health Department said.

[Byline: Galina Skripnik]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi

[Brucellosis is considered hyperendemic in Kazakhstan. A similar situation prevails in several other regional republics of the former Soviet Union (Kyrgyzstan, Georgia, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Turkmenistan). _Brucella melitensis_, of which small ruminants (sheep, goats) are the reservoir, is the main pathogen circulating in these countries, with a steadily increasing rate of spillover to cattle, though the typical pathogen in cattle is _B. abortus_. Most strains recovered from human patients in Kazakhstan have, traditionally, been identified as _B. melitensis_. - Mod.LL

ProMED map of Zhambyl Oblysy, Zhambyl, Kazakhstan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708522,2061>]

It is necessary to require a veterinary certificate when buying livestock, not to allow sick or unexamined animals into a healthy herd in a private household, to buy livestock products only in designated places, and to require documents certifying the quality and safety of products," the press service of the Zhambyl Region Health Department said.[Byline: Galina Skripnik]--Communicated by:ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi[Brucellosis is considered hyperendemic in Kazakhstan. A similar situation prevails in several other regional republics of the former Soviet Union (Kyrgyzstan, Georgia, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Turkmenistan). _Brucella melitensis_, of which small ruminants (sheep, goats) are the reservoir, is the main pathogen circulating in these countries, with a steadily increasing rate of spillover to cattle, though the typical pathogen in cattle is _B. abortus_. Most strains recovered from human patients in Kazakhstan have, traditionally, been identified as _B. melitensis_. - Mod.LLProMED map of Zhambyl Oblysy, Zhambyl, Kazakhstan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708522,2061>]

column2:
SHIGELLOSIS - EUROPE, USA: TRAVELERS, MULTIPLE PATHOGENS, ex CAPE VERDE
***********************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Tue 21 Feb 2023
Source: Food Safety News [abridged, edited]
<https://www.foodsafetynews.com/2023/02/u-s-involved-in-multi-country-shigella-outbreak/>


A dozen countries, including the USA, have reported more than 250 _Shigella_ infections in people who went to Cape Verde. An increase in shigellosis cases, mainly caused by _Shigella sonnei_, among travelers returning from Cape Verde, also known as Cabo Verde, has been reported in Europe, the UK, and the USA since September 2022.

Twelve countries have recorded 221 confirmed _Shigella sonnei_ infections and 37 possible cases, all with a link to Cape Verde, which is in West Africa. The UK has the most cases with 95, followed by the Netherlands with 47, Sweden with 42, and France with 31. The USA has 4 patients. Sequencing analysis of 106 human isolates from the Czech Republic, Netherlands, Sweden, UK, and the USA shows a genetically compact cluster suggesting a common source, said health officials.

Of the USA cases, one person reported going to Cape Verde, and the travel history for the other patients is unknown. Sick people include 3 females and one male aged from 3 to 88 years old. Collection dates ranged from 2 Nov 2021 to 2 Oct 2022.

Many ill people stayed in 5-star, all-inclusive hotels in the region of Santa Maria on the island of Sal. The most recent cases were in Sweden in mid-January 2023. Almost 3 times more women than men are affected. Two cases in Portugal were hospitalized.

Multiple modes of transmission are plausible, and the most likely way is through food, including via infected food handlers. However, person-to-person transmission is also possible, said the European Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (ECDC).

_Shigella_ co-infections with other bacterial and parasitic pathogens such as _Salmonella_ Mbandaka, _Campylobacter_, _Cryptosporidium_, and strains of _E. coli_ have been reported among patients. The _Shigella sonnei_ strain in the outbreak shows resistance to trimethoprim and streptomycin, but in some cases multidrug resistance has been found. Detection of a resistance gene against hydrogen peroxide indicates _Shigella sonnei_ isolates' regular exposure to this disinfectant, said ECDC.

ECDC and the European office of the WHO have been in contact with authorities in Cape Verde to support investigations on the sources of infection and to increase awareness among healthcare professionals in the country. Two meetings were held in January [2023] with officials from Cape Verde and the International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) to discuss the epidemiological situation, based on cases notified in 2022.

[Byline: Joe Whitworth]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[This posting adds the USA as another nation with traveler cases of shigellosis related to Cape Verde. It seems clear that the outbreak is related to unsafe food and water from multiple places and illnesses caused by multiple pathogens. Certainly, the genetic analysis suggests a commonality of the source of the _S. sonnei_ isolates. - Mod.LL

column2:
PARAPERTUSSIS - USA: (MISSOURI)
*******************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023 10:37 PM GMT+1
Source: WGEM [edited]
<https://www.wgem.com/2023/02/19/schuyler-county-suspected-whooping-cough-cases-confirmed-parapertussis>


The Schuyler County Health Department (MO) reported on Friday, 17 Feb 2023, they were notified of multiple cases of pertussis, also known as whooping cough, in the county. On Sunday, 19 Feb 2023, however, they reported those cases were confirmed as parapertussis, which is a respiratory illness that presents similar symptoms as pertussis but is less severe and less infectious.

Parapertussis does not require mandated reporting or management by communicable disease programs. People exposed to the illness should watch for symptoms 7-10 days after suspected exposure.

[Byline: Jayla Louis]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[It should be noted that _Bordetella pertussis_'s cousin, _B. parapertussis_, causes a similar, although milder, illness than _B. pertussis_. Many isolates of _B parapertussis_ do not produce pertactin, one of the _B. pertussis_ toxins and cross protection is limited.

Liko J, Robison SG, Cieslak PR. Do pertussis vaccines protect against _Bordetella parapertussis_? Clin Infect Dis. 2017; 64(12): 1795-1797; <https://doi.org/10.1093/cid/cix221>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
--------
"We calculated the effectiveness of pertussis vaccine in preventing parapertussis among Oregon children 2 months to 10 years of age using 2 methods. During 2011-2016, the 2 VE methods found 66% (95% CI, 59-75%) and 82% (95% CI, 69-90%) effectiveness against parapertussis. Pertussis vaccine may induce cross-immunity."

However, other studies did not suggest this cross-protection:
Karalius VP, Rucinski SL, Mandrekar JN, Patel R. _Bordetella parapertussis_ outbreak in Southeastern Minnesota and the United States, 2014. Medicine (Baltimore). 2017; 96(20): e6730; <https://doi.org/10.1097/md.0000000000006730>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
--------
"Whooping cough is traditionally ascribed to _Bordetella pertussis_; however, _Bordetella parapertussis_ can cause a similar clinical syndrome. This study describes an outbreak of _B. parapertussis_ in Southeastern Minnesota and the United States (US) in 2014. This was a retrospective analysis of Mayo Clinic and Mayo Medical Laboratories patients who tested positive for _B. parapertussis_ from 2012 to 2014. The medical records of Mayo Clinic patients who tested positive in 2014 were reviewed for demographic information, presenting symptoms, disease course, and vaccination history. In Southeast Minnesota, 81% of the 31 patients who tested positive for _B. parapertussis_ in 2014 were found to be positive from October through December. Their mean age was 5.9 years. 5 reported "exposure to pertussis." 2 pairs of siblings were affected. Patients reported having had symptoms for an average of 2.6 weeks before nasopharyngeal specimen collection for _B. parapertussis_ testing. Cough was the primary symptom reported. 40 percent reported posttussive vomiting, 40% coryza, 32% apnea/sleep disturbance, and 12% sore throat. All were current with pertussis vaccination. Based on the review of national data, an outbreak occurred nationally in the Northeast and Midwest US over the same time period. In 2014, there was an outbreak of _B. parapertussis_ in Southeastern Minnesota and likely other parts of the US. The presenting illness was similar to that of _B. pertussis_. All patients were vaccinated against pertussis, suggesting that pertussis vaccination is ineffective against _B. parapertussis_."
- Mod.LL

column2:
HEPATITIS E - CHINA: (HONG KONG) HUMAN, RAT VIRUS
*************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 16 Feb 2023
Source: The Government of Hong Kong SAR Press Releases [edited]
<https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202302/16/P2023021600521.htm>


CHP investigates case of human infection of rat hepatitis E virus
-----------------------------------------------------------------
The Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health today [16 Feb 2023] said that it is investigating a case of human infection of rat hepatitis E virus (HEV) and urged members of the public to be vigilant against hepatitis E infection and to strictly observe good personal, food, and environmental hygiene. The case involves a 28-year-old man with underlying illnesses. He was found to have a deranged liver function during his follow-up at Queen Elizabeth Hospital. The patient is now in stable condition. His blood sample tested positive for rat HEV upon laboratory testing.

The CHP's epidemiological investigations revealed that the patient resides in Ho Man Tin. He did not have contact with rodents or rats and had no travel history during the incubation period. "Based on the available epidemiological information, the source and the route of infection could not be determined. The CHP's investigation is ongoing," a spokesman for the CHP said. "The CHP has already informed the Pest Control Advisory Section of the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department about the case to carry out rodent control measures and a survey as appropriate," the spokesman added.

The exact mode of transmission of rat HEV to humans is unknown at the moment. Possible routes of transmission include ingestion of food or water contaminated by rodents or their excreta, exposure to environments or objects contaminated jj by rodents or their excreta, and direct contact with rodents or their excreta. The usual HEV causing human infection is transmitted mainly through the fecal-oral route.

To prevent hepatitis E infection, members of the public should maintain good personal, food, and environmental hygiene. For example, they should wash hands thoroughly before eating, store food properly or in the refrigerator, not leave food at room temperature for a long time, and use 1:99 diluted household bleach for general household cleaning and disinfection as household detergent may not be able to kill HEV. High-risk individuals, such as elderly persons with a major underlying illness (especially those who have undergone organ transplantation), pregnant women, patients with chronic liver disease, and patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (also known as G6PD deficiency), who are infected with HEV may develop a serious illness, so they should exercise extra caution.

The 5 keys to food safety should be adopted when handling food, i.e., choose (choose safe raw materials), clean (keep hands and utensils clean), separate (separate raw and cooked food), cook (cook thoroughly), and safe temperature (keep food at a safe temperature), to prevent food-borne diseases.

- Drink only boiled water from the mains or bottled drinks from reliable sources.
- Avoid drinks with ice of unknown origin.
- Purchase fresh food from hygienic and reliable sources. Do not patronize illegal hawkers.
- Clean and wash food thoroughly. Cook food, especially seafood (e.g. shellfish), pork and pig offal, thoroughly before consumption. Avoid raw food or undercooked food.
- Slice raw meat and offal into thin strips to allow thorough cooking, especially during hotpot or congee cooking.
- For sliced pig liver, depending on the thickness and quantity, boil at 100 deg Celsius [212 deg F] or stir-fry in a hot skillet/wok for at least 3 to 5 minutes.
- Heating to an internal temperature of 90 deg C [194 deg F] for 90 seconds is required for cooking of molluscan shellfish. If possible, remove the shells before cooking as they impede heat penetration. Otherwise, boil at 100 deg C until their shells open; boil for a further 3 to 5 minutes afterward. Discard any shellfish that do not open during cooking.
- For meat and offal, make sure that juices are clear, not red, and blood is not visible when cutting the cooked meat and offal.
- When having hotpot, use separate chopsticks and utensils for handling raw and cooked foods to prevent cross-contamination.

In general, rodents (such as rats) can transmit multiple diseases to humans directly and indirectly. The public is advised to adopt the following measures:
- Eliminate sources of food and nesting places for rodents in the living environment. Store food in covered containers and handle pet food properly to prevent it from becoming food for rodents;
- Store all refuse and food remnants in dustbins with well-fitted covers. Dustbins must be emptied at least once a day;
- Keep premises, especially refuse rooms and stairways, clean. Avoid accumulation of articles;
- Inspect all flower beds and pavements for rodent infestation regularly; and
- Avoid the high-risk activities below to reduce rodent contact: avoid rodent contact and places dirtied with rodent excreta; avoid handling rodents with bare hands; wash hands with liquid soap and water immediately after handling animals, and disinfect contaminated areas; and if a wound appears, clean the broken skin immediately and cover it properly with waterproof adhesive dressings.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[The citation and abstract for a recent publication regarding the virus in Hong Kong where it was first seen in humans follow:

Sridhar S, Yip CCY, Lo KHY, et al. Hepatitis E virus species C infection in humans, Hong Kong. Clin Infect Dis. 2021; ciab919; <https://doi.org/10.1093/cid/ciab919>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
--------
"Background
Hepatitis E virus (HEV) variants belonging to _Orthohepevirus_ species A (HEV-A) are the primary cause of human hepatitis E. However, we previously reported that _Orthohepevirus_ species C genotype 1 (HEV-C1), a divergent HEV variant commonly found in rats, also causes hepatitis in humans. Here, we present a clinical-epidemiological investigation of human HEV-C1 infections detected in Hong Kong, with an emphasis on outcomes in immunocompromised individuals.

"Methods
A surveillance system for detecting human HEV-C1 infections was established in Hong Kong. Epidemiological and clinical characteristics of HEV-C1 cases identified via this system between 1 Aug 2019 and 31 Dec 2020 were retrieved. Phylogenetic analysis of HEV-C1 strain sequences was performed. Infection outcomes of immunocompromised individuals with HEV-A and HEV-C1 infections were analyzed.

"Results
HEV-C1 accounted for 8 of 53 (15.1%) reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)-confirmed HEV infections in Hong Kong during the study period, raising the total number of HEV-C1 infections detected in the city to 16. 2 distinct HEV-C1 strain groups caused human infections. Patients were elderly and/or immunocompromised; half tested negative for HEV immunoglobulin M. Cumulatively, HEV-C1 accounted for 9 of 21 (42.9%) cases of hepatitis E recorded in immunocompromised patients in Hong Kong. Immunocompromised HEV-C1 patients progressed to persistent hepatitis at similar rates (7/9 [77.8%]) as HEV-A patients (10/12 [75%]). HEV-C1 patients responded to oral ribavirin, although the response to the 1st course was sometimes poor or delayed.

"Conclusions
Dedicated RT-PCR-based surveillance detected human HEV-C1 cases that evade conventional hepatitis E diagnostic testing. Immunosuppressed HEV-C1-infected patients frequently progress to persistent HEV-C1 infection, for which ribavirin is a suitable treatment option."

Additionally, a case was reported from Canada in 2019:
Andonov A, Robbins M, Borlang J, et al. Rat hepatitis E virus linked to severe acute hepatitis in an immunocompetent patient. J Infect Dis. 2019; 220(6): 951-955; <https://academic.oup.com/jid/advance-article-abstract/doi/10.1093/infdis/jiz025/5288497>.

A case was also reported in Spain:
Rivero-Juarez A, Frias M, Perez AB, et al. _Orthohepevirus_ C infection as an emerging cause of acute hepatitis in Spain: 1st report in Europe. J Hepatol. 2022; 77(2): 326-331; <https://www.journal-of-hepatology.eu/article/S0168-8278(22)00075-7/fulltext>.

Likely other countries will also report cases.

It is important to know that diagnostic testing for this virus, now reported in Europe and North America after first characterized in Hong Kong, can be problematic. - Mod.LL

The usual HEV causing human infection is transmitted mainly through the fecal-oral route.To prevent hepatitis E infection, members of the public should maintain good personal, food, and environmental hygiene. For example, they should wash hands thoroughly before eating, store food properly or in the refrigerator, not leave food at room temperature for a long time, and use 1:99 diluted household bleach for general household cleaning and disinfection as household detergent may not be able to kill HEV. High-risk individuals, such as elderly persons with a major underlying illness (especially those who have undergone organ transplantation), pregnant women, patients with chronic liver disease, and patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (also known as G6PD deficiency), who are infected with HEV may develop a serious illness, so they should exercise extra caution.The 5 keys to food safety should be adopted when handling food, i.e., choose (choose safe raw materials), clean (keep hands and utensils clean), separate (separate raw and cooked food), cook (cook thoroughly), and safe temperature (keep food at a safe temperature), to prevent food-borne diseases.- Drink only boiled water from the mains or bottled drinks from reliable sources.- Avoid drinks with ice of unknown origin.- Purchase fresh food from hygienic and reliable sources. Do not patronize illegal hawkers.- Clean and wash food thoroughly. Cook food, especially seafood (e.g. shellfish), pork and pig offal, thoroughly before consumption. Avoid raw food or undercooked food.- Slice raw meat and offal into thin strips to allow thorough cooking, especially during hotpot or congee cooking.- For sliced pig liver, depending on the thickness and quantity, boil at 100 deg Celsius [212 deg F] or stir-fry in a hot skillet/wok for at least 3 to 5 minutes.- Heating to an internal temperature of 90 deg C [194 deg F] for 90 seconds is required for cooking of molluscan shellfish. If possible, remove the shells before cooking as they impede heat penetration. Otherwise, boil at 100 deg C until their shells open; boil for a further 3 to 5 minutes afterward. Discard any shellfish that do not open during cooking.- For meat and offal, make sure that juices are clear, not red, and blood is not visible when cutting the cooked meat and offal.- When having hotpot, use separate chopsticks and utensils for handling raw and cooked foods to prevent cross-contamination.In general, rodents (such as rats) can transmit multiple diseases to humans directly and indirectly. The public is advised to adopt the following measures:- Eliminate sources of food and nesting places for rodents in the living environment. Store food in covered containers and handle pet food properly to prevent it from becoming food for rodents;- Store all refuse and food remnants in dustbins with well-fitted covers. Dustbins must be emptied at least once a day;- Keep premises, especially refuse rooms and stairways, clean. Avoid accumulation of articles;- Inspect all flower beds and pavements for rodent infestation regularly; and- Avoid the high-risk activities below to reduce rodent contact: avoid rodent contact and places dirtied with rodent excreta; avoid handling rodents with bare hands; wash hands with liquid soap and water immediately after handling animals, and disinfect contaminated areas; and if a wound appears, clean the broken skin immediately and cover it properly with waterproof adhesive dressings.--Communicated by:ProMED[The citation and abstract for a recent publication regarding the virus in Hong Kong where it was first seen in humans follow:Sridhar S, Yip CCY, Lo KHY, et al. Hepatitis E virus species C infection in humans, Hong Kong. Clin Infect Dis. 2021; ciab919; <https://doi.org/10.1093/cid/ciab919>--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Abstract--------"BackgroundHepatitis E virus (HEV) variants belonging to _Orthohepevirus_ species A (HEV-A) are the primary cause of human hepatitis E. However, we previously reported that _Orthohepevirus_ species C genotype 1 (HEV-C1), a divergent HEV variant commonly found in rats, also causes hepatitis in humans. Here, we present a clinical-epidemiological investigation of human HEV-C1 infections detected in Hong Kong, with an emphasis on outcomes in immunocompromised individuals."MethodsA surveillance system for detecting human HEV-C1 infections was established in Hong Kong. Epidemiological and clinical characteristics of HEV-C1 cases identified via this system between 1 Aug 2019 and 31 Dec 2020 were retrieved. Phylogenetic analysis of HEV-C1 strain sequences was performed. Infection outcomes of immunocompromised individuals with HEV-A and HEV-C1 infections were analyzed."ResultsHEV-C1 accounted for 8 of 53 (15.1%) reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR)-confirmed HEV infections in Hong Kong during the study period, raising the total number of HEV-C1 infections detected in the city to 16. 2 distinct HEV-C1 strain groups caused human infections. Patients were elderly and/or immunocompromised; half tested negative for HEV immunoglobulin M. Cumulatively, HEV-C1 accounted for 9 of 21 (42.9%) cases of hepatitis E recorded in immunocompromised patients in Hong Kong. Immunocompromised HEV-C1 patients progressed to persistent hepatitis at similar rates (7/9 [77.8%]) as HEV-A patients (10/12 [75%]). HEV-C1 patients responded to oral ribavirin, although the response to the 1st course was sometimes poor or delayed."ConclusionsDedicated RT-PCR-based surveillance detected human HEV-C1 cases that evade conventional hepatitis E diagnostic testing. Immunosuppressed HEV-C1-infected patients frequently progress to persistent HEV-C1 infection, for which ribavirin is a suitable treatment option."Additionally, a case was reported from Canada in 2019:Andonov A, Robbins M, Borlang J, et al. Rat hepatitis E virus linked to severe acute hepatitis in an immunocompetent patient. J Infect Dis. 2019; 220(6): 951-955; <https://academic.oup.com/jid/advance-article-abstract/doi/10.1093/infdis/jiz025/5288497>.A case was also reported in Spain:Rivero-Juarez A, Frias M, Perez AB, et al. _Orthohepevirus_ C infection as an emerging cause of acute hepatitis in Spain: 1st report in Europe. J Hepatol. 2022; 77(2): 326-331; <https://www.journal-of-hepatology.eu/article/S0168-8278(22)00075-7/fulltext>.Likely other countries will also report cases.It is important to know that diagnostic testing for this virus, now reported in Europe and North America after first characterized in Hong Kong, can be problematic. - Mod.LLProMED map:Ho Man Tin, Hong Kong: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708519,43819>]

RABIES (06): ASIA (KAZAKHSTAN) DOG, LIVESTOCK, WOAH
***************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Mon 20 Feb 2023
Source: WOAH-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2023 [edited]
<https://wahis.woah.org/#/in-review/4914>


Kazakhstan - rabies
-------------------
Report type: immediate notification
Started: 9 Jan 2023
Confirmed: 9 Jan 2023
Reported: 20 Feb 2023
Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease
Last occurrence: 13 Oct 2020
Causal agent: rabies virus
Serotype: RABV
Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory
This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.

Outbreak location: Saty village, Mayskiy, Pavlodar
Started: 9 Jan 2022
Epidemiological unit: backyard
Affected animals:
Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / Vaccinated
Cats / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 1
Cattle / 56 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 56
Dogs / 3 / 1 / 1 / - / 0 / 2
Sheep/goats (mixed herd) / 136 / 1 / 1 / - / 0 / 135

Epidemiology
Source of the outbreaks(s): unknown or inconclusive

Control measures at event level:
Domestic animals: screening; vaccination in response to the outbreak(s); quarantine; control of wildlife reservoirs.
Wild animal: screening; vaccination in response to the outbreak(s); quarantine; disinfection.

Diagnostic test results
Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result
Pavlodar Veterinary Laboratory / dog / microscopy with fluorescein isothiocyanate microscopy (FITC) / 9 Jan 2023 / positive

[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the WOAH report at the source URL above. - Mod.CRD]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[Rabies is endemic in Kazakhstan.

The following abstract comes from the article:
Yessembekova GN, Xiao S, Abenov A, et al. Molecular epidemiological study of animal rabies in Kazakhstan," J Integr Agric. 2022; in Press, journal Pre-proof, Available online 1 Dec 2022; <https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jia.2022.11.011>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Abstract
--------
"Rabies is a serious public health issue in Kazakhstan, with high economic impact and social burden. As part of a routine surveillance, 31 rabies-positive brain specimens taken from livestock (cattle) and carnivores (dogs, foxes, cats) during 2013-2021 were subject to viral sequencing. Phylogenetic and Bayesian analysis were performed using obtained rabies virus (RABV) sequences. All 31 strains of RABV candidate belonged to the Cosmopolitan clade, of which 30 strains belonged to the steppe-type subclade, and 1 dog strain belonged to another subclade. The 31 strains did not diverge from RABV strains in Kazakhstan and neighboring countries, including Russia, Mongolia, and China, suggesting that animal rabies has close relationship and transmission between borders. Fox-originated strains and cattle strains shared similar sequence signatures, and some animal rabies cases had space-time intersection, showing that infected foxes were a major transmission source of cattle rabies in different Kazakhstan regions. Besides, free-roaming dogs played a pivotal role in rabies epizootics of cattle in Kazakhstan. The recent spread of animal rabies presents an increasing threat to public health and provides updated information for improving current control and prevention strategies at the source for Kazakhstan and neighboring countries."
- Mod.CRD

ProMED map:
Saty, Pavlodar Region, Kazakhstan: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708518,68897>]

column2:
STREPTOCOCCUS, GP A UPDATE (06): DENMARK, INVASIVE, NEW SUBVARIANT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION
*******************************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023
Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]
<http://outbreaknewstoday.com/denmark-reports-three-times-the-normal-rate-of-group-a-streptococci-cases-51537/>


According to the Statens Serum Institut (SSI), the number of people affected by invasive group A streptococci cases (iGAS), where streptococci spread and cause serious conditions, has increased significantly. In November 2022 there were 21 cases, [ProMED previously posted 68 cases reported in December 2022 in Denmark], and in January this year [2023], 99 cases were reported in Denmark.

It is still mainly the elderly and children under 5 who are affected by the invasive cases. These can be, for example, blood poisoning, severe pneumonia with spread to the lung cavity [empyema], meningitis, and joint and muscle infections.

At the moment, 3 to 4 new cases are detected every day, which is 3 times the normal rate. Doctors are therefore encouraged to be extra vigilant.

"It is still important for doctors to be aware that there is widespread infection with GAS, which mainly manifests itself as strep throat and scarlet fever, but which is currently also causing an increased number of cases of invasive disease" -- Department manager and department doctor Peter Henrik Andersen from SSI.

However, the mortality rate for patients with invasive disease is at the same level as the period before November 2022. A few deaths have been seen among young children.

SSI continuously examines the streptococcal samples that have caused invasive disease, which are sent from all the country's clinical microbiology departments. 35% of the total cases are due to a new subvariant that has not previously been seen in Denmark. It has been observed in all parts of the country.

The non-invasive infections will typically manifest as throat and superficial skin infections. In some cases, GAS will give rise to more serious invasive cases, that is, infections detected in blood or other normally sterile areas. GAS are always sensitive to regular penicillin and its lack of effect should lead to renewed medical assessment.

[Byline: Robert Herriman]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[A discussion of infections due to group A streptococcus (also called GAS or _Streptococcus pyogenes_) can be found in my moderator comments in ProMED post Streptococcus, gp A update (05): UK, fatal, scarlet fever, iGAS 20221231.8707549.

Life-threatening invasive GAS infections (iGAS) are currently being reported in both children and elderly adults in the USA, Canada, the UK, some countries in the EU, Uruguay, and Australia (see also's below) at a time of increasing cases of localized GAS infections (for example, pharyngitis and scarlet fever). iGAS disease can involve abscesses around the tonsils or in the neck, bacteremia, pneumonia, empyema, endocarditis, meningitis, necrotizing fasciitis, and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.

The incidence of iGAS infections has increased compared to the period when COVID-19 pandemic control measures were in place and exposure to GAS infections was likely infrequent. Also, iGAS infections are known to complicate certain viral infections; GAS pneumonia and empyema are now occurring when respiratory viruses, such as influenza or RSV, have become more prevalent. Similarly, invasive GAS infections of the skin and soft tissues may complicate chickenpox. Other complications of chickenpox due to bacterial super-infections include bacterial pneumonia, septicemia, toxic shock syndrome, necrotizing fasciitis, osteomyelitis, and septic arthritis (<https://www.cdc.gov/chickenpox/hcp/index.html#complications>).

The news report above adds 2 points of new information to the previous of ProMED post on iGAS in Denmark (Streptococcus, gp A update (03): Denmark, invasive, increase, 2022 20230123.8707920): the total number of iGAS infections in Denmark in January 2023 is 99 (compared to 21 in November 2022 and 68 in December 2022), and 35% of the total cases are due to a new subvariant GAS that has not previously been seen in Denmark. Details describing the characteristics of this new subvariant strain were not given. In the UK, the majority of the current emm1 GAS isolates were noted to be part of the emm1 M1UK clone, first detected in 2010, for which there is upregulation of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin A (SpeA) expression, a virulence factor of _Streptococcus pyogenes_ (Streptococcus, gp A update (01): Netherlands, UK, iGAS, fatal, children, 2022 20230107.8707666).

More information on this outbreak in Denmark would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.ML

ProMED map:
Denmark: <https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8708507,111>]

column2:
LUMPY SKIN DISEASE - AFRICA: SOUTH AFRICA (EASTERN CAPE) CATTLE
***************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023
Source: IOL (Independent Online) [abridged, edited]
<https://www.iol.co.za/news/environment/mystery-disease-affecting-eastern-cape-livestock-linked-to-climate-change-c6872512-de21-4244-910b-e30ef785aecf>


Heavy rainfalls and extreme heat have affected the Eastern Cape hard, causing damage to the agricultural and farming sectors, especially due to the instability of the weather. Extreme weather conditions have badly affected farmers and livestock producers. 

In an interview with RACR (Rural Action for Climate Resilience), a few farmers say that they have noticed lumpy skin disease [LSD] in their livestock.

The virus affects cattle and is transmitted by insects that feed on blood, such as flies, mosquitoes, and ticks. It causes fever and nodules on the skin and can lead to death.

N.F. from Zibhodla village in Mqanduli is a young farmer; he explains to RACR that climate change resulting in extreme weather conditions have caused a new virus which makes cows, sheep, and horses to experience swelling, begin limping, and to lose appetite [see comment]. He tells RACR that he believes this new virus is caused by too much rainfall and extreme heat conditions. "I plead with the government to assist all the communities that are affected by this virus so we can at the same time prevent the ones that are not yet infected". 

Z.P. explains they are unable to isolate the infected cows, exposing healthy livestock to the risk of infection. "We would truly appreciate it if the Department of Agrarian Reform would assist us by sending vets and medications or injections; seeing a lot of your livestock as a farmer die every day does hurt a lot".

The farmers want the government and the department to intervene. They tell RACR that they cannot afford the necessary medications for this virus, and they also plead that the department goes to their communities to educate people in rural areas about these extreme weather conditions and viruses that attack livestock and help them find ways to prevent spreading any further threat to their livestock.

[Byline: Lindiwe Pakati]

--
Communicated by:
ProMED from HealthMap Alerts

[Lumpy skin disease (LSD) is caused by lumpy skin disease virus (LSDV), a virus from the family _Poxviridae_, genus _Capripoxvirus_. Sheeppox virus and goatpox virus are the 2 other virus species in this genus. 

The most typical changes caused by LSD in affected cattle are cutaneous nodules of 2-5 cm in diameter which develop, particularly on the head, neck, limbs, udder, genitalia, and perineum within 48 hours of the onset of the febrile reaction. These nodules involve the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and even the underlying muscles, and sometimes the lungs and digestive tract.
 
Morbidity rate varies between 10 and 20% although it has been reported in some places to be as high as 45%. Mortality rates of 1 to 5% are considered usual. 

LSD was first seen in Zambia in 1929, spreading into Botswana by 1943, and then into South Africa, where it affected over 8 million cattle causing major economic loss. In 1957, it entered Kenya and in 1970, spread north into Sudan and by the late 80's becoming regarded as endemic in most African countries. Later it spread into the Middle East, and since 2012, through the Middle East, into southeast Europe and West and Central Asia. Since 2019, LSD has spread to other parts of Asia, including China and India. 

Potent live-attenuated vaccines are effective and widely used in affected countries. 

WOAH technical disease pages addressing LSD are available at <https://www.woah.org/app/uploads/2022/06/lumpy-skin-disease-final-v1-1forpublication.pdf>. - Mod.AS]

column3: Heavy rainfalls and extreme heat have affected the Eastern Cape hard, causing damage to the agricultural and farming sectors, especially due to the instability of the weather. Extreme weather conditions have badly affected farmers and livestock producers. In an interview with RACR (Rural Action for Climate Resilience), a few farmers say that they have noticed lumpy skin disease [LSD] in their livestock.The virus affects cattle and is transmitted by insects that feed on blood, such as flies, mosquitoes, and ticks. It causes fever and nodules on the skin and can lead to death.N.F. from Zibhodla village in Mqanduli is a young farmer; he explains to RACR that climate change resulting in extreme weather conditions have caused a new virus which makes cows, sheep, and horses to experience swelling, begin limping, and to lose appetite [see comment]. He tells RACR that he believes this new virus is caused by too much rainfall and extreme heat conditions. "I plead with the government to assist all the communities that are affected by this virus so we can at the same time prevent the ones that are not yet infected". Z.P. explains they are unable to isolate the infected cows, exposing healthy livestock to the risk of infection. "We would truly appreciate it if the Department of Agrarian Reform would assist us by sending vets and medications or injections; seeing a lot of your livestock as a farmer die every day does hurt a lot".The farmers want the government and the department to intervene. They tell RACR that they cannot afford the necessary medications for this virus, and they also plead that the department goes to their communities to educate people in rural areas about these extreme weather conditions and viruses that attack livestock and help them find ways to prevent spreading any further threat to their livestock.[Byline: Lindiwe Pakati]--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts[Lumpy skin disease (LSD) is caused by lumpy skin disease virus (LSDV), a virus from the family _Poxviridae_, genus _Capripoxvirus_. Sheeppox virus and goatpox virus are the 2 other virus species in this genus. The most typical changes caused by LSD in affected cattle are cutaneous nodules of 2-5 cm in diameter which develop, particularly on the head, neck, limbs, udder, genitalia, and perineum within 48 hours of the onset of the febrile reaction. These nodules involve the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and even the underlying muscles, and sometimes the lungs and digestive tract. Morbidity rate varies between 10 and 20% although it has been reported in some places to be as high as 45%. Mortality rates of 1 to 5% are considered usual. LSD was first seen in Zambia in 1929, spreading into Botswana by 1943, and then into South Africa, where it affected over 8 million cattle causing major economic loss. In 1957, it entered Kenya and in 1970, spread north into Sudan and by the late 80's becoming regarded as endemic in most African countries. Later it spread into the Middle East, and since 2012, through the Middle East, into southeast Europe and West and Central Asia. Since 2019, LSD has spread to other parts of Asia, including China and India. Potent live-attenuated vaccines are effective and widely used in affected countries. WOAH technical disease pages addressing LSD are available at <https://www.woah.org/app/uploads/2022/06/lumpy-skin-disease-final-v1-1forpublication.pdf>. - Mod.AS]

column2:
UNDIAGNOSED DISEASE, MAIZE - BANGLADESH: (KHULNA)
*************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Thu 16 Feb 2023 08:45 AM BST
Source: The Daily Star, Star Business report [summ. Mod.DHA, edited]
<https://www.thedailystar.net/business/economy/news/crop-disease-decimating-maize-chuadanga-3249231>


A crop disease that has yet to be identified is devastating maize fields in Chuadanga district. The disease first dries the plant's roots causing them to eventually rot, resulting in the damage of cobs during the milk stage. Overall, over 6 hectares [14.8 acres] of maize have been affected in the area. The Bangladesh Wheat and Maize Research Institute has sent off a team of scientists to investigate the situation. They hope to know a reason within a couple of days.

Farmers say that there was a similar outbreak in 2020, but the extent of damage is far more widespread in 2023. Crops planted early in the season are being affected; it is a very big problem for growers when any disease causes plant roots to rot. Farmers ask that the government should deal will this issue on a priority basis to protect the crops from further damage.

--
Communicated by:
ProMED

[A large number of pathogens are known to affect maize in the region and worldwide. Root rots of the crop can be caused by a range of mainly fungal and bacterial pathogens. Symptoms as described above can be due to several of them or be caused by environmental factors. Any root disease may also affect development of the cobs by reducing plant vigour and disrupting nutrient transport.

A reliable diagnosis of the cause(s) is always essential before any management strategies can be designed. The prediction above of getting a clear molecular diagnosis within a few days seems very optimistic.

column2:
FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - INDONESIA: (JAWA TIMUR) LIVESTOCK, CONTINUING, CONTROL
*****************************************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023
Source: Antara News Agency [in Indonesian, machine trans., edited]
<https://jateng.antaranews.com/nasional/berita/3403944/sapi-terjangkit-pmk-di-ponorogo-naik-tajam>


An outbreak of FMD (foot and mouth disease) that infects cattle in Ponorogo Regency, East Java [also known as Jawa Timur - Mod.JH] is showing a sharp increasing trend: from the under 100 cases previously reported, now more than 300 cattle have been infected.

"Yes, most cases currently detected are in Sawoo District with 104 cases. The increased number of cases is suspected to be due to the non-optimal vaccination coverage", said Head of the Livestock Service Office, Food Security and Fisheries of Ponorogo Regency, Masun, in Ponorogo, Sunday [19 Feb 2023].

He added, "currently there are 8 cows that have died due to FMD.

"The most deficient vaccination rate is seen in Sawoo, Siman and Bungkal. Since the cattle in Pudak District have been 100% vaccinated, there has been just one case there, an animal kept outside the city", he said.

According to Masun, the deficient vaccination rate in the Ponorogo Regency may be attributed to one of the following scenarios: 
1. the breeders introduced unvaccinated animals (no eartags) from elsewhere, and/or
2. local cows have escaped vaccination. Such animals are mainly found in the districts of Sawoo, Siman and Bungkal.

To minimize transmission, continued Masun, so far his party has sprayed disinfectants at the animal market twice.

"We will continue to carry out biosecurity, spraying disinfectants before and after the market opens," he said.

Masun appealed to the public, especially breeders to be proactive with vaccination officers, so that the process of mitigating outbreaks or prevention efforts can be optimal.
 
[Byline: Destyan H. Sujarwoko]

-- 
Communicated by:
ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi

[It is necessary to continuously monitor the efficacy of the vaccine used and the (maintained) identity of the circulating virus strain. For this end, vaccinated animals ought to be sampled in case they present clinical signs, to check in the laboratory if the causative pathogen matches the initial virus strain, against which the vaccine was supposed to confer protection. There are ample examples of FMD events in which more than a single FMD strain or even serotype were involved, leading to confusion. Identifying such animals in Indonesia should be possible since, as it seems from the media report, they are ear-tagged when vaccinated. 

Indonesia's Ministry of Agriculture operates a website dedicated to the continuing FMD epizootic. The website presents (daily) updates on the course of the disease (number and locations of currently active cases, total confirmed cases, recovered, deaths, slaughtered) and of the vaccination performance. The data are spatial, to the level of districts and subdistricts within each province, while attending to each of the following animal species: beef cattle, dairy cattle, water buffalo, pigs, sheep and goats. A dynamic, interactive map is available at <https://crisiscenterpmk.ditjenpkh.pertanian.go.id/peta-terdampak-pmk/?l=en>. Currently, only one province, East Java, is coloured red, meaning that the number of subdistricts with active FMD cases exceeds 50% of the total number of the subdistricts in the province. Bali is among the provinces coloured aqua, meaning zero cases. The disease peaked in late 2022. 

Among the other data: totals (accumulated), 602 206 confirmed cases, of which 563 971 clinically recovered, 14 263 slaughtered, 11 174 deaths, 11 939 684 doses vaccine applied. All data are also presented per province, district, subdistrict, cities, as well as per animal species. The disease peaked on 26 Jun 2022, when 13 559 new cases were reported. - Mod.AS]

column2:
SEVERE FEVER WITH THROMBOCYTOPENIA SYNDROME - JAPAN
***************************************************
A ProMED-mail post
<http://www.promedmail.org>
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
<http://www.isid.org>

Date: Sun 19 Feb 2023
Source: Asahi Shimbun Digital [in Japanese, machine trans., edited]
<https://news.yahoo.co.jp/articles/1a4493f73464325e9be7467da63bee33f5a7c58c>


SFTS (severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome), one of the "viral hemorrhagic fevers" with a high fatality rate, is expanding [in Japan]. The number of infected people hit a record high last year [2022] and the year before [2021]. It has been 10 years since the 1st confirmation in Japan, and the risk of a new infection route through pets has become clear.

SFTS is transmitted by ticks that hide in forests and grass. It infects humans, cats and dogs. According to a medical guide compiled by a national research group, infection causes vomiting, melena and fever, and the fatality rate in humans reaches 25-30%.

It often occurs in the elderly, and there is still no effective treatment other than symptomatic treatment. It was 1st discovered in China in 2011, and was 1st reported in Japan in 2013 in Yamaguchi Prefecture.

The number of patients is on the rise. According to the National Institute of Infectious Diseases, a record 110 people were infected in 2021, followed by a record 118 in 2022. Until now, the epidemic has centered on western Japan, but the spread of the virus to the east continues, with the 1st confirmed cases in Aichi and Shizuoka prefectures in 2021 and Toyama prefecture in 2022.

In addition, there is growing concern about new infection routes. It has been found that owners and veterinarians can be infected through pet cats and dogs bitten by ticks. According to the Institute of Infectious Diseases, a total of 10 veterinary workers have been infected since 2018, and 2 more were infected in 2022.

Tamaki Okabayashi, professor at the University of Miyazaki, said, ``It has been said that SFTS is mainly transmitted by ticks, but is it really true? So," he pointed out.

[Byline: Takahiro Takenouchi]

--
Communicated by:
ProMeD

[Severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS) virus has been recognized in Japan since 2013 and has been spreading in the country since then. The number of human cases reported by the National Institute of Infectious Diseases was a record 110 people infected in 2021, followed by a record 118 in 2022. The above report does not indicate the number of cases so far this year (2023), but is probably too early in the season for tick activity. It will be interesting to see how many cases occur in Japan in coming months this year (2023).

SFTS is likely underreported in some areas. SFTS should be included in differential diagnoses when cases of _Rickettsia japonica_ infections are suspected. Since there is no vaccine, the best way to avoid infection is to avoid tick bites and contact with infected pets, especially cats.

As noted earlier, SFTS is a serious disease and of significant public health concern. Although SFTS virus infections may be serious, there is evidence for subclinical or mild infections as well, so the previous numbers may be an underestimate of the total number of infections. There is also some evidence for person-to-person direct transmission of the virus, but that appears to be a rare event. The virus is doubtless endemic in several countries in Asia, and cases have occurred previously in Japan. Apparently, there are 2 previously reported affected individuals who acquired their infections directly from an SFTS-virus-infected cat. No mention was made of tick transmission in that instance. The possible route of transmission from the cat to the veterinarian and veterinary nurse via exposure to blood or other bodily fluids was not mentioned (see Severe fever w/ thrombocytopenia synd. - East Asia (02): Japan (MZ) 20181211.6204927). The role of infected domestic companion animals as threats for transmission directly to humans in contact with them is not well defined. They certainly could carry infected ticks into areas where humans are present as well. 

SFTS virus is a tick-transmitted phlebovirus in the Bunyavirus family. Images of the longhorn tick, _Haemaphysalis longicornis_, the SFTS vector, can be seen at <http://www.lowchensaustralia.com/pests/paralysis-tick/haemaphysalis-longicornis-description.htm>. - Mod.TY
